column1: BACKGROUND: No known drug allergies. No known cardiovascular risk factors. No toxic habits. Non-ischaemic dilated cardiomyopathy with severe biventricular dysfunction (LVEF 15-20%) of debut in October 2010 evolving to advanced heart failure (ergospirometry with peak oxygen consumption of 12 ml/min/kg). AF of uncertain chronology diagnosed in 2010. CHA2DS2-VASc 1 point anticoagulated with dabigatran 150 mg every 12 hours. Implantation of an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) in primary prevention in January 2011
column2: with subsequent inappropriate shocks due to episodes of AF with rapid ventricular response. Usual treatment: dabigatran 150 mg every 12 hours
column3: bisoprolol 2.5 mg every 12 hours
column4: spironolactone 25 mg every 24 hours
column5: furosemide 40 mg every 12 hours
column6: digoxin 0.25 mg half tablet every 24 hours
column7: sildenafil 20 mg every 12 hours
column8: periodic cycles of levosimendan and ferric carboxymaltose.  CURRENT DISEASE: After completing the pre-transplant work-up (see complementary tests)
column9: the patient is electively listed for heart transplantation in March 2017
column10: being then in New Yor Heart Association (NYHA) functional class II-III. One month later
column11: on 18 April 2017
column12: he was telephoned for scheduled admission due to the appearance of an optimal donor for heart transplantation. He was admitted to the cardiology ward and on arrival an electrocardiogram (ECG)
column13: complete blood tests with coagulation study
column14: chest X-ray and blood product reserve was requested. The patient was anticoagulated with dabigatran 150 mg every 12 hours
column15: having taken the last dose on the morning of admission (< 8 hours).  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Good general condition. Conscious
column16: oriented and cooperative. Afebrile on admission. Haemodynamically stable with blood pressure (BP) 107/65 mmHg and heart rate (HR) 65 bpm. Eupneic at rest and speech with headrest at 30o. Slight jugular ingurgitation. On auscultation
column17: arrhythmic cardiac tones without audible murmurs. Bladder murmur preserved with no added pathological sounds. Lower limbs with slight perimalleolar oedema
column18: no signs of deep vein thrombosis. No other noteworthy findings on examination.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: AF at 53 bpm. Narrow QRS with left anterior hemiblock morphology. Chest X-ray: significant cardiomegaly at the expense of left cavities with opening of the carinal angle above 90o
column19: double right atrial contour and marked growth of left ventricular shadow showing a peculiar morphology of the cardiac tip in "hump" reminiscent of ventricular aneurysm. Normopositioned LAD. Transthoracic echocardiography: severely dilated left atrium. Globular left ventricle with end-diastolic diameter of 64 mm
column20: end-diastolic volume of 256 ml and thinned walls with non-compaction in septo-apical segments
column21: without systolic thickening and with an overall ejection fraction of 15-20%. Thin mitral valve with good mobility and with grade II/IV regurgitation directed to the posterolateral wall. Thin trivalve aortic valve with mild regurgitation directed to the anterior mitral leaflet. Dilated right ventricle with end-diastolic diameter of 40 mm and TAPSE of 17 mm. Hypocontractility in lateral segments. Electrocatheter in the right ventricle. Moderate tricuspid regurgitation with right atrium-right ventricle gradient of 37 mmHg. CORONARYGRAPHY: normal coronary arteries. RIGHT CATHETERISM: right atrium 18 mmHg
column22: right ventricle 59/18 mmHg
column23: pulmonary artery trunk 59/35-43 mmHg
column24: pulmonary capillary pressure 35 mmHg
column25: transpulmonary gradient 8 mmHg
column26: cardiac output 3.7 l/min. Peripheral vascular resistance 2.16 Wood units. Thoracic-abdominal CT scan: Noteworthy is the presence of pseudonodular hypodense areas in the liver
column27: at the level of segment II and between segments V and VI
column28: with unspecific characteristics that could correspond to fibrotic areas
column29: less likely patchy steatosis. DOPLER ultrasound of the supra-aortic trunks and lower limbs: no significant lesions. BLOOD GROUP A. Anti-HLA I-II antibodies negative. SEROLOGY: hepatitis C IgG negative
column30: hepatitis A IgG positive
column31: hepatitis B S antigen negative
column33: anti-HBc IgG negative. Positive IgG antibodies against mumps virus
column34: rubella
column35: measles
column36: herpes virus type 1
column37: varicella zoster and cytomegalovirus. IgG toxoplasma positive
column38: IgM toxoplasma negative. IgG tetanus positive. HIV 1-2 negative. IgG Epstein Bar virus negative
column39: IgM negative. Syphilis screening negative. TUMOUR MARKERS: negative. ANALYTICS pretransplant: glucose
column40: renal function
column41: abdominal profile and ions normal. Haemoglobin 11.3 g/dl. HbA1c 5.5%. NT-proBNP 1297 pg/ml. Coagulation with INR 1.31
column42: PT 14.5 seconds
column43: TPTA 57.1 seconds
column44: TPTA ratio 1.78. Lipid profile: total cholesterol 185 mg/dl
column45: LDL 95 mg/dl
column46: HDL 65 mg/dl. Normal thyroid profile. COAGULATION TEST after idarucizumab IV infusion: INR 1.13
column47: PT 12.4 seconds
column48: TPTA 30.3 seconds
column49: TPTA ratio 0.95.   CLINICAL EVOLUTION On receiving the analytical results requested on admission
column50: the effect of dabigatran on the patient's coagulation was confirmed by means of the TPTA (57.1 seconds) and TPTA ratio (1.78). At this point
column51: haematology was contacted to reverse the anticoagulation
column52: who indicated the administration of 5 g of idarucizumab IV by means of two consecutive infusions of 2.5 g/50 ml in 5-10 minutes each
column53: with a new control 15 minutes after administration
column54: normalising the coagulation times (TPTA 30.3 seconds and TPTA ratio 0.97). Once the anticoagulant effect of dabigatran had been reversed
column55: surgery was performed and orthotopic heart transplantation was performed using the bicava technique. The extracorporeal surgery time is 78 minutes and the anoxia time is 60 minutes. During surgery
column56: 3 g of fibrinogen was administered and the patient did not require transfusions of blood products. Heparinisation is reversed with protamine. Finally
column57: two mediastinal drains were left in place and were removed 48 hours after surgery without incident. In the immediate postoperative period
column58: the patient was admitted to the intensive care unit. He was extubated in the first 6 hours
column59: with a favourable evolution at all times
column60: with no bleeding complications. The usual immunosuppression protocol was started (tacrolimus + mycophenolate mofetil + prednisone). He was transferred to the cardiac transplant hospitalisation unit 72 hours after surgery and was discharged home early.  DIAGNOSIS Scheduled admission for orthotopic heart transplant with bicava technique in a patient on the elective waiting list for non-ischaemic dilated cardiomyopathy with severe biventricular dysfunction (LVEF 15-20%). Persistent anticoagulated AF (CHA2DS2-VASc 1 point

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION The patient is a 45-year-old woman with no known drug allergies. As cardiovascular risk factors
column3: she has recently diagnosed type 2 diabetes mellitus under dietary treatment and smokes half a pack a day. She had no previous cardiological history and had undergone parathyroidectomy. The patient was referred to the emergency department of our centre from her health centre due to headache
column4: pulsating frontal headache related to hypertensive emergency
column5: as well as dyspnoea on moderate exertion in the last few weeks. She denied chest pain
column6: dizziness or other cardiovascular symptoms. Physical examination on arrival at the ED showed blood pressure (BP) 180/100
column7: heart rate (HR) 74 bpm. Conscious
column8: oriented

column10: abdominal and lower limb auscultation without relevant alterations.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ELECTROCARDIOGRAM (ECG): sinus rhythm at 86 bpm. column24: Borrelia burgdorferi IgG-Lyme: negative. COAGULATION: Prothrombin T. 13

column29: T. partial thromboplastin (R 1.15). Fibrinogen derivative 1436. DDimer 750.00. INR 1.23. ECOCARDIOGRAM (admission) (videos 1-3) Left atrium (LA) slightly dilated. Left ventricle (LV) with severe concentric hypertrophy (21 mm approximately at septal level

column32: due to flow acceleration at this level (no SAM and no subaortic membrane). Normofunctioning mitral valve. Trivalve aortic valve with good opening without significant stenosis or insufficiency. Right ventricle (RV) with preserved function

column34: 5 months after discharge) (video 4): LV of normal size and thickness
column35: without alterations of segmental contractility and preserved systolic function. Normal diastolic pattern for age. RV of normal size and function. Mild mitral insufficiency. Mild-moderate tricuspid insufficiency that allows estimating a PSAP of 24 mmHg + PVC. Laboratory tests at the clinic: LDL cholesterol 100 mg/dl
column36: HbA1c 6.5%. Cardiac NUCLEAR MAGNETIC RESONANCE (MRI) (outpatient after control echocardiography): LV and RV images were obtained in cine sequences
column37: Stir and late enhancement after gadolinium administration. LV: normal size

column41: without morphological alterations

column44: normal size. Right atrium (RA): area 19 cm2
column45: normal size. Aortic root flow quantification (phase contrast velocity coding). Anterograde volume 78 ml and retrograde volume 2.35 ml. Regurgitation fraction 3%. Peak velocity 155 cm/s. Peak velocity 107 cm/s. Pressure gradient 4.5 mmHg. Pericardium: no significant pericardial thickening or effusion. Conclusions: LV of normal size and function. No significant hypertrophy (maximum thickness 12 mm) and no evidence of infiltrative cardiomyopathy.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION Electrocardiogram and laboratory tests were performed with markers of myocardial damage (creatine kinase and ultrasensitive troponin T) with elevation of these markers. In view of these findings and with the diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) type 2 in the context of hypertensive emergency
column46: admission was decided for adjustment of treatment and completion of studies. An echocardiogram was performed showing severe concentric hypertrophy causing a dynamic gradient at the LV outflow tract and a complete serological study
column47: given the recent onset of symptoms
column48: in order to try to exclude a possible infectious origin
column49: which was negative
column50: as well as coronary angiography
column51: given the mobilisation of markers of myocardial damage without evidence of significant angiographic lesions. The patient progressed favourably after starting antihypertensive treatment with a combination of olmesartan
column52: amlodipine and hydrochlorothiazide (40/5/12.5mg) and beta-blocker (bisoprolol 2
column53: 5mg)
column54: so in view of the results it was decided to discharge him home and a possible diagnosis of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy or hypertensive heart disease with severe left ventricular hypertrophy was established
column55: and to try to establish the differential diagnosis
column56: an outpatient cardiac MRI was requested. Simultaneously
column57: treatment was started with metformin 850 mg/12 hours and rosuvastatin 20 mg every 24 hours
column58: based on the results of the analytical controls. Three months after discharge
column59: she visited the cardiology outpatient clinic for a check-up. She required a progressive decrease in antihypertensive medication and at the time of consultation was treated with amlodipine 5 mg and bisoprolol 2.5 mg with optimal control of BP and ambulatory values maintained at around 120/60 mmHg. The physical examination revealed that the systolic murmur that had been present on admission had disappeared
column60: so it was decided to request an ABPM that confirmed optimal control of BP and an echocardiogram with normalisation of wall thicknesses and no other relevant alterations. Finally
column61: cardiac MRI was performed
column62: showing a LV of normal size and thickness with no evidence of pathological gadolinium uptake
column63: either early or late
column64: so structural heart disease was ruled out and a definitive diagnosis of resolved myocarditis was established.  DIAGNOSIS Acute myocarditis in resolution. Type 2 diabetes mellitus. column1: BACKGROUND: 74-year-old woman. Arterial hypertension. Rheumatic heart disease with predominantly mitral insufficiency. Mitral valve replacement by mechanical prosthesis Bjork no. 31 in 1976. 31 in 1976. Pacemaker implantation due to symptomatic slow atrial fibrillation in 1996 with last generator replacement in 2015
column2: presenting on that occasion with spontaneously draining bursa haematoma with negative blood cultures and normal TTE
column3: which was covered empirically with ampicillin + intravenous gentamicin with good subsequent evolution. Chronic treatment: acenocoumarol according to schedule
column4: olmesartan/hydrochlorothiazide 20/12.5 mg c/24 hours
column5: verapamil 120 mg c/24 hours
column6: zolpidem 10 mg c/24 hours
column7: formoterol/budesodin 160/4.5 mcg inh c/24 hours.  CURRENT ILLNESS: She attended the emergency department on 10/3/2016 for general malaise
column8: headache
column9: arthomyalgia
column10: anorexia
column11: fever and weight loss of 2 weeks' evolution. Initial suspicion of pneumonia in the left upper lobe led to empirical antibiotic treatment with levofloxacin
column12: escalating to imipenem due to persistent febrile syndrome and general deterioration
column13: in addition to finding growth of Streptococcus gordinii in blood cultures.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Temperature 36 oC. Blood pressure 126/63 mmHg
column14: heart rate 66 bpm
column15: oxygen saturation 97% with nasal goggles at 2 l/min
column16: RR 16 rpm. Conscious
column17: oriented and cooperative. Good general condition. Eupneic at rest. Good distal perfusion
column18: adequate hydric status. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds with prosthetic click without murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: rhonchi
column19: minimal crackles in the left base. Lower extremities: no oedema
column20: no signs of deep vein thrombosis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: ventricular rhythm stimulated by pacemaker at 60 bpm. THORAX X-RAY: condensation at the level of the left upper lobe. ANALYSIS: Haemogram: Hb 10 g/dl. Leukocytes 24
column21: 300 u/l (neutrophils 85%
column22: lymphocytes 8%)
column23: platelets 201
column24: 000 u/l. Biochemistry: glucose 135 mg/dl. Urea 54 mg/dl. Creatinine 1.28 mg/dl. GFR 41 ml/min. Sodium 132 mmol/l. Potassium 4.4 mmol/l. C-reactive protein 211 mg/l. CPK 119 U/l. Troponin T 19 ng/l (normal). Coagulation: PT 16 s. INR 4.2. Fibrinogen 905 mg/dl. Blood gases: pH 7.47
column25: pO2 68 mmHg
column26: pCO2 29 mmHg
column27: SatO2 97%. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) and transesophageal echocardiography (TEE): endocarditis on mitral prosthetic valve. Bjork mechanical prosthesis in mitral position with no signs of dysfunction. In the posterior portion of the annulus (close to the atrial appendage) there is an anechoic cavity of pulsatile appearance of approximately 2.6 cm x 1.6 cm with images of greater density in its interior
column28: suggesting an abscess in the clinical context of the patient. Left ventricle (LV) neither dilated nor hypertrophic LVEF 58%. Right ventricle (RV) not dilated
column29: normal global contractility. Both atria moderately dilated. Normofunctioning aortic valve. Tricuspid normal
column30: mild insufficiency. Pulmonary arterial systolic pressure (PSAP) 50 mmHg + 15-20 mmHg (severe pulmonary hypertension). Pericardium without effusion. Right pleural effusion. Inferior vena cava slightly dilated with respiratory variation present. Pacemaker electrode in right ventricle without apparent alterations. Chest PET-CT scan: hypermetabolism in the mitral region suggesting an infectious process
column31: with no evidence of hypermetabolic foci in the path of the pacemaker lead. Uptake at the generator site (residual of recent replacement versus very low activity infection). Post-surgical changes in mitral valve with replacement by mechanical prosthesis. Collection with contrast in its interior of 28 x 17 x 15 mm depending on the anterior portion of the mitral annulus
column32: suggestive of pseudoaneurysm.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION Due to persistent febrile syndrome and positive cultures for multisensitive Streptococcus gordinii
column33: it was decided to perform the aforementioned studies. TTE showed an image on the atrial side in the lateral region of the mitral annulus suggestive of an abscess compatible with the diagnosis of endocarditis on the prosthetic valve. This finding was corroborated by PET/CT
column34: which showed a collection in the anterior portion of the mitral annulus suggestive of pseudoaneurysm with hypercaptation at this level. Urgent surgical intervention was decided in June 2016 and an open abscess was found towards the left atrium at the level of leaflets A1-P1. In addition
column35: on examining the mechanical prosthesis
column36: there was evidence of restriction of the movement of the disc due to pannus with calcified mitral annulus
column37: as well as part of the atrial wall. The abscess was closed with two stitches and a Perimount Edwards No 27 biological mitral prosthesis was implanted
column38: as well as a generator replacement due to minimal hypercaptation
column39: as seen on PET-CT. During her stay in hospital she evolved favourably
column40: de-escalating antibiotic treatment and prescribing benzylpenicillin
column41: with negative blood cultures for control and prosthetic material. She was asymptomatic and progressed well in hospital
column42: so it was decided to discharge her and continue outpatient follow-up
column43: completing antibiotic treatment with amoxicillin for two months.  DIAGNOSIS Infectious endocarditis due to multisensitive Streptococcus gordinii on mechanical mitral prosthesis complicated by mitral periannular abscess. Replacement of mechanical mitral prosthesis with Perimount Edwards No 27 biological mitral prosthesis. column1: Personal history 81-year-old male patient. Moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
column2: ex-smoker since 1998
column3: hypertension
column4: dyslipidaemia and insulin-dependent type II diabetes mellitus (DM). In 2010
column5: severe aortic stenosis treated by bioprosthesis
column6: whose postoperative period was complicated by respiratory infection
column7: surgical wound infection and sternal dehiscence
column8: reintervened 15 days after surgery. Moderate heart failure
column9: Barthel index: 50 (moderate). In 2012
column10: the patient had numerous episodes of enterococcal bacteraemia and was admitted to hospital on four occasions. Given the recurrence of the infection
column11: an exhaustive study was carried out in search of possible foci of infection
column12: with particular interest in the prosthetic valve
column13: with only a gallium 67 scan performed in February 2013 showing hypercaptation in the right sternoclavicular joint
column14: leading to a diagnosis of enterococcal sternal osteomyelitis and antibiotic treatment was completed with ampicillin for 4 weeks. Three days after returning home

column16: general malaise
column17: dyspnoea
column18: increased cough and secretions and returned to the hospital.  CLINICAL OBSERVATION At the last admission before the current illness
column19: he was diagnosed with sternal osteomyelitis due to enterococci.  Initially
column20: third generation cephalosporin was administered
column21: which was changed to ampicillin and finally to amoxicillin-clavulanic acid. During this admission
column22: up to 4 red blood cell concentrates were administered due to significant anaemisation and also due to extravasation coinciding with the administration of a blood transfusion.  - Physical examination: conscious and oriented

column43: HCO3 20. - Blood cultures: Enterococcus faecalis was isolated. - Transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiogram: In the posterior annulus of the mitral valve a mass image of 16 x 12 mm is observed. With echogenic borders that was not seen in the previous transesophageal echocardiogram in December 2012. - Provisional diagnosis: subacute enterococcal mitral endocarditis complicated by anaemia due to chronic disease
column44: acute renal failure due to aminoglycosides
column45: exacerbation of COPD due to nosocomial respiratory infection with Stenotrophomona maltophilia and organic brain syndrome. - Initial treatment: low molecular weight heparin (LMWH)
column46: furosemide
column47: ampicillin
column48: inhalers
column49: oxygen therapy
column50: rest
column51: vital signs monitoring and oxygen saturation.  Evolution After being diagnosed with mitral endocarditis
column52: the patient was treated for 6 weeks with ampicillin and 2 weeks with gentamicin; in the fourth week of admission
column53: the patient suffered an exacerbation of his COPD due to a respiratory infection by Strenotrophomonas maltophilia
column54: receiving treatment with cotrimoxazole for 2 weeks
column55: achieving clinical and microbiological resolution of the episode. Due to the administration of this whole battery of antibiotics
column56: he suffered acute renal failure due to aminoglycosides
column57: but after discontinuation of treatment in the sixth week of treatment
column58: this resolved. During admission
column59: there was a progressive worsening of the patient's chronic anaemia associated with the subacute infectious disease and the prolonged administration of antibiotics
column60: which led to the administration of three red blood cell concentrates. Between the third and fourth week
column61: the patient's general condition worsened significantly
column62: and the nursing team focused on addressing collaboration problems and diagnosing activity intolerance related to an imbalance between oxygen intake and demand
column63: and on self-care diagnoses. The patient's haematocrit and haemoglobin figures improved markedly after resolution of the infectious process and administration of plasma derivatives. From the fifth week of treatment
column64: the patient gradually recovers
column65: and it is possible to work with him on the diagnoses of anxiety and deficient knowledge as well as to progressively increase the number of activities aimed at self-care. During his prolonged illness and numerous hospitalisations
column66: in the last months of his hospital stay
column67: the patient suffers a serious functional deterioration
column68: being unable to ambulate and carry out basic activities of daily living; current Barthel index: 15 (Total).   Medical discharge Following resolution of the infectious process
column69: he was discharged from hospital on 28 May 2013 and transferred to a medium-stay hospital for the purpose of rehabilitation. A half-stay hospital is a level of care used to complete the rehabilitation of patients with real possibilities of recovery
column70: who require longer stays than those traditionally accepted in the hospital environment. The average stay in this centre is between 25 and 30 days
column71: and the maximum stay should not exceed 3 months. The medical treatment received at discharge consisted of: rehabilitation
column72: heparin
column73: diuretics
column74: inhalers (salbutamol and Seretide® 50/100 mcg)
column75: iron and vitamin B9. For several weeks prior to discharge

column1: A 76-year-old man with a history of type II diabetes mellitus
column2: hypertension
column3: hypercholesterolemia and chronic renal failure. The patient came to the emergency department of our centre with general malaise
column4: nausea
column5: vomiting and episodes of profuse sweating without chest pain. Five days earlier he had been discharged from hospital after two stents had been placed for ischaemic heart disease. She was admitted with leukocytosis with left shift
column6: acute renal failure
column7: normochromic normocytic anaemia and a CRP of 112mg/L. The electrocardiogram showed complete right bundle branch block and second-degree atrioventricular block. During the first days of admission to the ICU he was afebrile
column8: with rising leukocytosis without clear focus
column9: and showing some episodes of temporospatial disorientation with psychomotor agitation. Treatment with piperacillin/tazobactam was started and a cranial CT scan was performed showing a small occipital subarachnoid haemorrhage. On the sixth day of admission
column10: the patient presented fever over 38oC
column11: with tachypnoea and increased respiratory work with severe metabolic acidosis
column12: accompanied by a deterioration in the level of consciousness. A chest CT scan showed bilateral pleural effusion. Urine
column13: bronchial aspirate and blood samples were collected for culture. The following day the microbiology laboratory reported that two blood cultures grew gram-positive cocci in clusters which were later identified as Staphylococcus lugdunensis not producing beta-lactamase. Following this result
column14: antibiotic treatment was adjusted according to the antibiogram to cloxacillin and gentamicin. A transesophageal echocardiogram was performed
column15: showing two vegetations on the atrial side of the mitral valve
column16: one in the septal leaflet measuring 12 x 12 mm and the other in the posterior leaflet measuring 13 x 12 mm
column17: indicating moderate mitral insufficiency. Surgery for valve replacement was considered
column18: but the patient died before surgery could be performed. The patient was diagnosed with mitral endocarditis on native valve. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: a 61-year-old man came to the internal medicine department for the study of an almost daily febrile fever and occasionally a fever of over 38oC. His personal history included: hypertension
column3: hypercholesterolaemia
column4: haemochromatosis under treatment with periodic bleeding up to a year earlier
column5: ex-smoker
column6: and a patient with a prosthetic mitral valve and stent since 2008 due to ischaemic heart disease with biventricular involvement.  Six months earlier
column7: the patient had started to experience a progressive onset of fever
column8: asthenia
column9: hyporexia and cough. In March of the same year
column10: he was referred by his primary care physician for the finding of three peripheral pulmonary micronodules measuring 5 mm. Complementary examinations revealed moderate normochromic anaemia
column11: elevated ESR and CRP together with significant homogeneous splenomegaly. No fever was noted and he was discharged to continue the study in the outpatient department. In April he returned to the ED with fever of 38.7oC and pleuritic pain in the left hemithorax. Two blood cultures were taken and were negative after 5 days of incubation. He started empirical antibiotic treatment with amoxicillin/clavulanic acid with partial improvement of symptoms. From the Internal Medicine department and due to a further worsening of symptoms
column12: it was decided to admit him. At that time he was anaemic
column13: with iron levels of 34 mcg/dl
column14: a blood rate of 56 mm/h and CRP of 3.6 mg/dl. Thoracic-abdominal CT showed splenomegaly with an image compatible with splenic infarcts and persistence of the aforementioned unchanged pulmonary micronodules. A transesophageal echocardiogram showed a mechanical mitral prosthesis with two vegetation images
column15: a medial one measuring 14 x 5 mm and a lateral one measuring 13 x 4 mm on the atrial side. There was no prosthetic dysfunction. Three blood cultures were taken (aerobic and anaerobic flasks). All three anaerobic flasks grew a non-spore-forming
column16: pleomorphic gram-positive bacillus at 7
column17: 8 and 10 days. The isolate was sent to the Centro Nacional de Microbiología in Majadahonda where it was identified as Propionibacterium acnes by amplification and sequencing of the 16S rRNA gene. When initially reporting the growth of an anaerobic gram-positive bacillus in blood cultures
column18: the patient was treated with vancomycin
column19: ceftriaxone and gentamicin. Subsequently
column20: ceftriaxone and gentamicin were replaced by clindamycin. After suspecting that the microorganism was P. acnes
column21: it was decided to change antibiotherapy to penicillin G sodium
column24: 000 IU every 4 hours. The patient's evolution at the start of treatment was favourable
column25: but the reappearance of fever with peaks above 38oC after ten days
column26: together with the results of a second transesophageal echocardiogram (unchanged from the previous one)
column27: made it advisable to perform surgery to replace the prosthesis. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: The patient was a 64-year-old woman who presented to the emergency department of a tertiary hospital with erythematous lesions on both hands and swelling
column2: pain and functional impotence of the right wrist joint. She had a biological aortic valve prosthesis
column3: implanted fifteen months before the current consultation. Examination of the patient revealed that she was febrile (38oC) and Osler nodules were observed on the hands and feet
column4: as well as nail haemorrhages. Blood tests showed leukocytosis (12.8 x 106/L). Blood cultures were taken and a chest ultrasound showed a large vegetation on the prosthetic valve annulus. She was diagnosed with prosthetic valve endocarditis and treatment was started with vancomycin
column5: gentamicin and rifampicin at appropriate doses. After two days of evolution
column6: the patient showed decreased level of consciousness and right hemiparesis. A normal head CT scan and lumbar puncture were performed. CSF biochemistry showed no alterations and a sample was sent to the Microbiology Department. It was decided to perform surgery for a new valve replacement
column7: but the patient died eight hours later due to cardiorespiratory arrest
column8: before she could be operated on. No autopsy was performed. Blood cultures and cerebrospinal fluid were negative after seven days of incubation. Blind passages of blood cultures were given and all culture media sown showed whitish cream coloured colonies with a membranous appearance after three days of incubation. Microscopic examination revealed yeasts
column9: short filaments and arthroconidia.  The micro-organism grew in the subculture after 72 h of incubation on standard culture media. The vast majority of yeasts that cause infections in humans can have these characteristics. However
column10: Candida species usually grow within 24 h on standard media
column11: so the yeast may be thought to belong to a slow-growing species (Cryptococcus
column12: Trichosporon
column13: Rhodotorula
column14: Geotrichum
column15: Galactomyces). The macroscopic appearance of the colonies (cream-coloured and membranous appearance) helps to rule out pigmented yeasts such as Rhodotorula and Sporobolomyces
column16: which are red and orange
column17: respectively. However
column18: the most significant data is the microscopic morphology (yeast-like organisms
column19: with hyphae and arthroconidia). The presence of hyphae helps to rule out a genus such as Cryptococcus which does not usually produce filaments. The presence of arthroconidia helps to make a presumptive identification. Arthroconidia are a type of asexual reproduction
column20: consisting of the generation of conidia by simple fragmentation of the hyphae in the area where the septa are located. It is typical of several species belonging to the genera Trichosporon
column21: Galactomyces and Geotrichum.  Within the arthroconidial group
column22: three species cause the vast majority of infections in humans: Galactomyces geotrichum (Geotrichum candidum)
column23: Dipodascus capitatus (Geotrichumcapitatum) and Trichosporon beigelii. The latter can be considered as a genospecies and in recent taxonomic classifications has been divided into multiple species
column24: of which at least 6 are pathogenic to humans (T. asahii
column25: T. cutaneum
column26: T. inkin
column27: T. mucoides
column28: T. ovoides and T. asteroides). Of these
column29: T. asahii is the most important from a pathogenic point of view
column30: as it is the one that causes almost all cases of deep Trichosporon infections. To distinguish between the three arthroconidial species requires morphological study
column31: biochemical tests and complementary techniques. Macroscopic morphology does not help to differentiate between the three species
column32: as the colonies of all species are white or cream coloured and membranous in appearance. Microscopic morphology is somewhat more specific
column33: although not definitive
column34: as sometimes only hyphae and arthroconidia are observed. The microscopic morphology of D. capitatus is characterised by narrow hyphae branching at acute angles
column35: with anelloconidia and endospores. G. geotrichum usually has thicker hyphae branching at right angles. T. beigelii has a variable morphology as it is a genospecies.  Generally speaking
column36: it usually has fine disarticulated hyphae
column37: with abundant formacubic and sometimes appressoria (narrow filamentous structures
column38: attached to the hyphae and branching very irregularly) and giant spindle cells. Both biochemical tests and complementary techniques are used as confirmatory methods of identification. Trichosporon species are easily distinguished from Galactomyces and Dipodascus as they assimilate a large number of carbohydrates and produce urea hydrolysis. G. geotrichum and D. capitatus assimilate fewer carbohydrates (glucose
column39: galactose and some others depending on the strain) and do not hydrolyse urea. These two species can be distinguished because Galactomyces does not usually grow well at 37oC and because many strains also assimilate xylose. None of the three species ferment carbohydrates. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 55-year-old man with a history of ischaemic heart disease attended the emergency department for fever of 6 months of intermittent evolution
column2: accompanied by chills
column3: sweating
column4: asthenia and anorexia. On examination he presented a temperature of 39oC
column5: septic mouth and rhythmic cardiac auscultation at 90 bpm with a multifocal systolic murmur III/VI. Laboratory tests showed haemoglobin 12.5 g/dL
column6: haematocrit 37%
column7: MCV 91 fL
column8: white and platelet series normal
column9: and CRP 9.0 mg/dL. Chest X-ray was normal. Serial blood cultures were taken and the patient was admitted. A transesophageal echocardiogram showed two warts in the anteroseptal mitral leaflet with mild mitral insufficiency. Empirical antibiotic treatment for infective endocarditis was started with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid (2 g/4 h
column10: iv) and gentamicin (80 mg/8 h
column11: iv). Seven days after admission
column12: bacterial growth was detected in 3 of the 4 blood culture bottles. No microorganisms were observed in the direct Gram stain. At 48 hours
column13: in the subculture performed on chocolate agar in a CO2 atmosphere
column14: greyish-coloured punctate colonies grew
column15: which corresponded to gram-negative coccobacilli in the Gram stain. Biochemical tests were as follows: catalase positive
column16: oxidase negative
column17: urea negative
column18: indolnegative and non-fermenting of glucose
column19: galactose and lactose. The micro-organism did not grow in aerobic atmosphere at 37oC or on EMB agar
column20: but did grow on Brucella enanaerobiosis agar. A subculture was performed in thioglycollate broth and after 7 days of incubation
column21: growth was observed in the form of clumps adhering to the wall of the tube and then becoming diffuse throughout the broth. Serological tests for Brucella were negative. Due to the microbiological results obtained and the appearance of new febrile episodes
column22: it was decided to change the antibiotic treatment to ceftriaxone (2g/24 h
column23: iv). The original culture was incubated for a prolonged period of time in a CO2 atmosphere and after 25 days rough colonies with a stellate appearance in the centre were observed by low magnification light microscopy. The sensitivity study was performed by the disc-plate method after prolonged incubation
column24: resulting sensitive to penicillin
column25: cephalosporins
column26: aminoglycosides
column27: quinolones
column28: cotrimoxazole
column29: rifampicin and tetracycline
column30: and resistant to glycopeptides and clindamycin
column31: being the determination of beta-lactamase negative. The patient's clinical evolution was satisfactory
column32: with no complications. He was discharged and continued with outpatient antibiotic treatment
column33: completing 5 weeks of treatment with ceftriaxone.  The existence of endocarditis with a subacute course and the late growth of gram-negative microorganisms in the blood culture should lead us to suspect the participation of microorganisms belonging to the HACEK group
column34: which includes bacteria that are difficult to grow and have special nutritional and incubation requirements. This group includes the following microorganisms: Haemophilus (H. aphrophilus
column35: H.paraphrophilus
column36: etc.)
column37: Actinobacillus actinomycetemcomitans
column38: Cardiobacterium hominis
column39: Eikenella corrodens and Kingella kingae. The common characteristics of all of them are the following: they are part of the normal flora of the oropharyngeal cavity and upper respiratory tract
column40: they are small gram-negative coccobacilli
column41: they are demanding microorganisms
column42: very slow growing
column43: requiring prolonged incubation in a CO2 atmosphere and producing similar clinical pictures of insidious course
column44: endocarditis being the most frequent pathology.  According to the microbiological results
column45: A. actinomycetemcomitans was identified as the causative organism of this infection. It is a gram-negative
column46: capnophilic
column47: facultative anaerobic
column48: very slow-growing coccobacillus
column49: which is part of the normal bacterial flora of the oral cavity. It requires blood-enriched culture media and does not grow on selective media such as MacConkey agar or EMB.  Endocarditis due to A. actinomycetemcomitans is very rare on both native and prosthetic valves
column50: with 102 cases reported in the literature so far. It is the microorganism of the HACEK group that most frequently causes endocarditis
column51: especially in patients with underlying cardiac pathologies. The entry point is usually an oropharyngeal infection
column52: but it can also be secondary to instrumentation in the oral cavity. On other occasions
column53: as in our case
column54: the origin is related to a septic mouth with teeth in poor condition.  A. actinomycetemcomitans is sensitive to cephalosporins
column55: aztreonam
column56: rifampicin
column57: aminoglycosides
column58: aminoglycosides
column59: cotrimoxazole
column60: tetracycline
column61: chloramphenicol and quinolones
column62: with variable sensitivity to penicillin. In endocarditis caused by this microorganism
column63: the most commonly used treatment regimen has been the combination of penicillin or ampicillin with an intravenous aminoglycoside
column64: although penicillinase-producing strains have been described. For this reason
column65: third-generation cephalosporins
column66: associated with either rifampicin or an aminoglycoside
column67: are an option to consider due to their excellent in vitro activity. The recommended duration of treatment is 4 weeks in endocarditis on native valves and 6 weeks when prosthetic valves are affected. The use of fluoroquinolones
column68: as well as cotrimoxazole or aztreonam
column69: should be considered as an alternative in patients who are intolerant or allergic to beta-lactams
column70: given their high sensitivity rates and the in vitro demonstration of synergy with rifampicin. Isolated cases of complete cure have been reported after treatment with oral ciprofloxacin
column71: alone or in association with rifampicin or doxycycline
column72: for a longer period of time than with parenteral treatments (8 weeks). These data suggest that oral fluoroquinolones may be a valid option
column73: as monotherapy or in combination with other antimicrobials
column74: in episodes of A. actinomycetemcomitans endocarditis without serious complications. Valve replacement is necessary in 24% of cases. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column1: A 70-year-old male patient presented to the emergency department with fever of two weeks' duration
column2: with chills
column3: shivering
column4: up to 39oC
column5: predominantly in the evening
column6: which resolved well with paracetamol but reappeared a few hours later. The fever is accompanied by asthenia and generalised osteoarticular pain. No cough
column7: no expectoration
column8: no dyspnoea
column9: no chest pain. No nausea or vomiting. Soft stools
column10: without pathological products in the last weeks. No micturition symptoms. Since coming to the emergency department
column11: on treatment with levofloxacin for 5 days with clinical improvement
column12: but relapse of fever and general malaise 48 hours after finishing the antibiotic. No trips abroad. No skin lesions or dental interventions. The family reports that the patient has been more depressed for the last 6 months
column13: coinciding with the last pacemaker replacement. Since then
column14: his activity has been progressively decreasing
column15: with the appearance of joint pain. Weight loss
column16: but no loss of appetite.   BACKGROUND - ADR: Hypersensitivity to beta-lactams. - Toxic habits: Non-smoker. Drinker of 2 glasses of wine a day for 3-4 months. - Personal history: AHT

column24: without complications. Vertebral ankylosing hyperostosis and gout
column25: seen in rheumatology in November 2016 and in follow-up by general practitioner. Community-acquired pneumonia in 2015 - Surgical history: appendectomy
column26: prosthesisaortic. - Retired
column27: former car body repairer
column28: lives in El Palmar. Self-employed for all ABVD
column29: drives his car
column30: has a small vegetable garden   PHYSICAL EXAMINATION - BP: 120/40mmHG HR: 70lpm T: 37"2 oC. Eupneic at rest - No adenopathies in the main lymph node groups. - Normal colour. Not hydrated. No jaundice - Septic mouth. Normal pharynx without exudate. - No crepitus

column33: non-painful

column35: with palpable pulses
column36: no signs of DVT. - No skin lesions or loss of skin continuity. - Conscious
column37: oriented
column38: cooperative
column39: normal speech
column40: mobilises all 4 limbs
column41: normal cranial nerves. Negative meningeal signs.  COMPLEMENTARY EXPLORATIONS - ECG: pacemaker rhythm at 70lpm
column42: with ventricular stimulation
column43: left bundle branch block. - Chest X-ray: global cardiomegaly
column44: signs of LVI. Pacemaker with electrodes in AD and VD. - Biochemistry: glucose 168 mg/dl Urea:78 mg/dl Creatinine: 1.65 mg/dl Ck: 48 ui/l - Sodium 131 CRP: 134 FG: 41 Fibrinogen: 667 - Blood gases - Haematology: Leucocytes: 15"2x10e9/lneutrófilos 11"9x10e9/l - Brucellamelitensisrosa de bengala: negative - Abnormal and sediment: normal. column47: normal function

column1: 69-year-old man. History of biological AVR 9 months earlier. Native of CABA
column2: with no relevant epidemiological history. Evaluated for fever and intermittent chills of 2 months of evolution. Samples were taken for HC which were repeatedly negative; TEE: anechoic image compatible with drained abscess in mitroaortic fibrosa territory; PET-CT: hypercaptation at perivalvular level. He underwent empirical antibiotic treatment with Daptomycin 10 mg/kg/day + Ceftriaxone 2 g/day for 6 weeks with a diagnosis of probable early Ao IVPVD with negative HC. As the patient progressed favourably
column3: it was decided not to perform surgery during the hospitalisation. Two months after completion of ATB treatment
column4: she returned with fever and chills. HC again negative and TEE with progression of the perivalvular lesion
column5: it was decided to perform surgery. Perivalvular sample was sent for culture
column6: AP and PCR in which C. burnetti was detected by 16S DNA sequencing. Serology by IFA for Coxiella IgG 1/256. Treatment with Doxycycline 200 mg/day + Hydroxychloroquine 400 mg/day was started. During his evolution and without ever being able to go outside
column7: he suffers multiple complications associated with health care
column8: which lead to his death 5 months after surgery. Coxiella burnetti is a rare cause of IE. It should be suspected especially in patients with negative HC and specific epidemiological factors such as contact with cattle
column9: sheep and goats. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 59-year-old male with a high fever (39o) of 2 days' evolution and an episode of convulsive crisis. He appears stuporous.  BP 97/80 mmHg. Fc 132 bpm. SatO2 95%. Fr 22 rpm. Ta 34
column2: 2oC.  Fulfils criteria of SEPSIS SERIOUS: Ta34
column3: 2o. Acute renal failure (Creatinine 2
column4: 2); elevated PCT and CRP (bacterial infection); Hypotension (97/80) with signs of poor perfusion (cold and sweaty)
column5: Metabolic acidosis (low bicarbonate)
column6: elevated lactate (hypoperfusion); Oligoanuria; very striking Plateletopenia (16.000); Tachycardia (AF at 132 x ́)
column7: Tachypnoea at 26 x ́(low pCO2). The FOCO is unknown.  Let's go by parts:  1) Sepsis-induced hypotension: 2
column8: 000 cc of Physiological Serum is administered and later in ICU 1
column9: 500 cc SF. -> maintains BP 105/75  2) Atrial fibrillation at 130 x ́ -> AMIODARONE IV .... -> Sinus rhythm.  3) Antibiotic? After 2 blood cultures -> MEROPENEM IV
column10: -> CLOXACILLIN + CEFOTAXIME + CYPROFLOXACIN was chosen in ICU. -> and subsequently: CLOXACILLIN + DAPTOMYCIN -> currently CLOXACILLIN + GENTAMYCIN.  4) Convulsive crisis that recurred after a few hours. CT scan: SUBARACHNOID HEMORRHAGE
column11: probably related to plateletopenia or mycotic (= infectious) aneurysm -> start treatment with IV LEVETIRACETAM.  5) Plateletopenia. -> Consultation with haematology: "does not meet criteria for TTP
column12: HIT or haemophagocytic syndrome; ITP versus vasculitis is not ruled out in addition to the septic picture". Treatment was started with corticoids + platelet perfusion: a daily pool.  6) Search for FOCO: transthoracic echocardiogram was performed: NO warts were visualised.  7) Blood cultures positive for STAPHILOCOCCUS AUREUS (sensitive to methicillin)  8) Transesophageal echocardiogram was carried out: an image of VERRUGE in the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve was visualised.  9) Consultation with Cardiovascular Surgery: surgical treatment was ruled out at the present time due to SAH. Reassessment after 6 weeks.  10) Appearance of purpuric lesions (ecchymotic) of probable embolic origin on the tips of the fingers and soles of the feet.  After a week in ICU
column13: she remained stable. She was transferred to the ward.  DIAGNOSTIC JUDGEMENT:  - Myxomatous myxomatous degeneration due to S. AUREUS.  - SEVERE SEPSIS with RENAL FAILURE (corrected at discharge). SEVERE PLATELETOPENIA.  - SUBARACHNOID HAEMORRHAGE. Generalised EPILEPTIC CRISIS  - ACxFA (reverted to sinus rhythm)  Commentary: Staphylococcus aureus: S.Aureus lives on human skin -> causes skin infections: folliculitis

column15: skin abscesses
column16: furunculosis
column17: mastitis
column18: cellulitis

column2: 56 years old. No known drug allergies. No known cardiological history. Behçet's disease (pulmonary aneurysms in the right lung
column3: surgery in 1995). Chronic hepatitis B. Home treatment: ASA 300 mg
column4: peginterferon alfa 2a
column5: entecavir.  Present illness She has been suffering from generalised asthenia for about 15 days
column6: with chest pain on exertion that subsides immediately when she stops. No orthopnoea
column7: no paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea. No pre/syncope. No fever or dysthymic sensation in the previous days.  Physical examination BP 123/79 mmHg. HR 41 bpm. Ta 35.2°C. Conscious
column8: oriented
column9: cooperative. Good general condition. Eupneic on ambient air. Head and neck: no IVY at 45o. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column10: no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur
column11: no extra sounds. Abdomen: soft
column12: depressible
column13: non-painful. No organomegaly. Extremities: no oedema. No evidence of deep vein thrombosis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: high degree AV block with 2:1 conduction. QRS 130 ms. QRS axis at -60o. Bifascicular block (BRDHH + HAI) with ventriculophasic sinus arrhythmia. Chest X-ray: no evidence of acute pleuropulmonary pathology. Loss of right lung volume and metallic density material in the lower portion of the ipsilateral hemithorax in relation to surgical history. Cardiopericardial silhouette of normal size. Annular calcifications projecting on the cardiac silhouette
column14: already present in the previous study. CBC: leukocytes 2
column16: L 34.9 %). Hb 12.9 g/dl. Platelets 93
column17: 000/uL. INR 1.12. TPPA Ratio 1.12. Glucose 83 mg/dl. Urea 65 mg/dl. Creat 0.74 mg/dl. Na 143. K 4.5. Troponin I: < 0.017 ng/dl. Echocardiogram: left ventricle not dilated
column18: with preserved ejection fraction. Trivalve aortic valve
column19: with good opening and slight central insufficiency. Left atrium not dilated. Mitral valve with good opening
column20: diastolic mitral regurgitation. Aortic root not dilated. Right chambers not dilated
column21: good right ventricular contractility. Mild tricuspid insufficiency. No pericardial effusion. Coronary angiography: left coronary trunk without lesions. Anterior descending: calcified aneurysmal dilatation of the proximal wall with slowing of distal flow. Circumflex: large aneurysmal dilatation at proximal level
column22: calcified
column23: with partial thrombosis of the lumen
column24: which conditions flow slowing at distal level. Right coronary artery: no lesions. Aortography: no aneurysmal dilatation. Coronary CT: coronary saccular aneurysms in circumflex (partially thrombosed and with a 3-4 mm neck) and in the anterior descending artery (not thrombosed and seated on a 15 mm long dysplastic artery segment).   EVOLUTION A 56-year-old patient was admitted to the Coronary Care Unit for 2:1 AV block with wide QRS and symptoms compatible with recent-onset exertional angina. Coronary angiography was performed
column25: showing evidence of anterior descending artery with calcified aneurysmal dilatation of the proximal wall with slowing of distal flow
column26: proximal circumflex artery with large aneurysmal dilatation
column27: calcified
column28: with partial thrombosis of the lumen
column29: leading to slowing of distal flow. The case was discussed in a medical-surgical session and coronary surgery was decided upon
column30: prior to the implantation of a permanent pacemaker. The convenience of temporarily suspending treatment with peginterferon alfa in order to improve the leukocyte and platelet count figures as much as possible in preparation for surgery was discussed at the session. In this regard
column31: he was assessed by Hepatology and they recommended suspending peginterferon prior to surgery and resuming it as soon as possible after the operation. On 21 October 2016
column33: which revealed infra-Hisian AV block
column34: and a definitive bicameral pacemaker was subsequently implanted without complications. Post-implantation controls of the pacemaker showed adequate functioning of the device. He was stable cardiovascular and asymptomatic
column35: with no evidence of HF
column36: and was discharged from hospital for admission the following week for cardiac surgery. On 4 November 2016
column37: coronary revascularisation surgery with a double "Y" mammary artery under ECC was scheduled. Bypass of the left mammary artery to the anterior descending artery and of the right mammary artery to the obtuse marginal artery was performed. Distal and proximal ligation of the anterior descending aneurysm was also performed. Intervention without complications. Postoperative resuscitation without incident.  DIAGNOSIS Behçet's disease. Infra-Hisian atrioventricular 2:1 block. Implantation of a definitive bicameral pacemaker. Ischaemic heart disease due to coronary aneurysms. Coronary revascularisation with double mammary artery to anterior descending and obtuse marginal. column2: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION We present the case of a 72-year-old patient
column3: operated on for symptomatic severe aortic stenosis with implantation of a biological aortic prosthesis (Mitroflow no21)
column4: who was admitted for febrile syndrome. The patient had a personal history of hypertension and dyslipidaemia
column5: and was being treated with enalapril 10mg
column6: one tablet every 12 hours
column7: and simvastatin 40 mg
column8: one tablet per day. Three months after the operation
column9: the patient consulted the emergency department for two weeks of fever (> 38°C)
column10: asthenia
column11: anorexia and deterioration of general condition. On physical examination he was haemodynamically stable (BP 140/80 mmHg; HR 75 bpm
column12: SatO2 97 % breathing room air). Cardiopulmonary auscultation revealed rhythmic
column13: tachycardic sounds
column14: with systolic murmur II/VI in the aortic focus
column15: with no clinical signs of heart failure. The rest of the examination was unremarkable
column16: with no cutaneous stigmata of endocarditis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS The admission blood test showed a high white blood cell count (16
column17: 000/μL) at the expense of neutrophils (87%) with elevated acute phase reactants (CRP 267 mg/l)
column18: the rest of the analytical parameters being normal. The electrocardiogram showed sinus tachycardia and signs of left chamber enlargement with an overload pattern. On admission
column19: 4 batches of serial blood cultures were taken and Staphylococcus epidermidis was isolated in all the bottles
column20: so antibiotherapy with vancomycin
column21: gentamicin and rifampicin was started
column22: in accordance with the regimen recommended by the clinical practice guidelines. As a first approach
column23: transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) was performed
column24: which showed a biological prosthesis in the aortic position
column25: with adequate opening of its leaflets
column26: without the presence of periprosthetic regurgitation. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) showed no evidence of prosthetic dysfunction or conclusive signs of endocarditis. Given the high clinical suspicion of infective endocarditis
column27: it was decided to extend the study with positron emission tomography with 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (18F-FDG-PET/CT)
column28: which showed increased FDG uptake at the level of the aortic root
column29: periprosthetic
column30: of annular morphology and with a SUVmax (Standard Uptake Value) of 5
column31: compatible with endocarditis. It was decided to perform a new TEE
column33: where signs of endocarditis with significant periprosthetic involvement were observed: presence of periannular pseudoaneurysm with fistulisation towards the right atrium
column34: vegetations and signs of periprosthetic dehiscence.  EVOLUTION After two weeks of antibiotic therapy with negative blood cultures
column35: valve replacement surgery and repair of the aorto-atrial fistula with pericardial patch was performed. Microbiological analysis of the excised surgical tissue showed abundant polymorphonuclear cells without microorganisms in the Gram stain
column36: and the culture was finally negative.  DIAGNOSIS Early infective endocarditis on aortic biological prosthesis due to Staphylococcus epidermidis. Periprosthetic pseudoaneurysm
column37: fistulised to right chambers. Antibiotic and surgical treatment with good evolution. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column11: arriving at the emergency department in a conventional ambulance with an estimated NIHSS of 16. In previous days she had referred mild catarrhal symptoms associated with a feeling of dystrophy.  Physical examination Neurological (NIHSS score): alert (0). column12: slight withdrawal (1). Ataxia not assessable (0). Mutism (3+1). Not assessable extinction. BP 120/75 mmHg
column13: Sat 99 % with nasal goggles at 3 bpm
column14: HR 70. Temperature not recorded AC: RsCsRs without audible murmurs
column15: prosthetic click. AP: mvc
column16: no added sounds. Abdomen: soft
column17: depressible. MMII without oedema or signs of DVT.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: sinus rhythm at 66 bpm. Left anterior hemiblock. Chest X-ray: no condensation or signs of HF. Laboratory tests: biochemistry: Glc 187 mg/dl. Urea 45 mg/dl. Creatinine 0.95 mg/dl. Na 133 mmol/l. K 4.8 mmol/L. TnT 16 ng/l (normal < 35 ng/l). CPK 66 U/l (normal < 200 U/l). column18: 300/uL with 78 % neutrophils. Platelets 199.000/uL. Coagulation: PT 45 %; INR 1.86. Cranial CT: discrete hypodensity with loss of differentiation between grey matter and white matter at the level of the left frontal insula and operculum
column19: compatible with acute ischaemic lesion (ASPECTS 8). No intra- or extra-axial haemorrhages are observed. Morphology of sulci and ventricles within normal limits for the patient's age. Discrete bilateral periventricular hypodensity compatible with chronic small vessel disease. Centred midline. Permeable base cisterns. Cerebral perfusion CT: in the superficial territory of the left MCA there is an increase in time to peak
column20: mean transit time and drainage time
column21: with a decrease in cerebral blood flow. At the level of the insula and the left frontal operculum there is a decrease in volume
column22: compatible with established infarction
column23: while in the rest of the superficial territory of the left MCA the volume is preserved
column24: compatible with a penumbra area. Angio-CT of supra-aortic trunks and Willis polygon: repletion defect at the level of the distal M1 segment of the left MCA
column25: with poor distal collateral circulation. No other repletion defects
column26: aneurysmal formations or other alterations at the level of the intra- or extracranial circulation. Absence of both posterior communicating arteries. Carotid shafts slightly elongated. Patent vertebral arteries with right dominance. Basilar artery dependent exclusively on the right vertebral artery
column27: with left vertebral artery leading directly into the PICA. Cerebral angiography: under sedation
column28: cerebral arteriography was performed via the right femoral approach
column29: without groin complications. Occlusion of the distal M1 segment of the left MCA was confirmed
column30: with the existence of a proximal loop in the internal carotid artery. We proceeded to perform mechanical thrombectomy with an extractor device
column31: achieving complete recanalisation of this artery
column32: although with migration of two small emboli: one in the distal posterior parietal region (non-occlusive embolus) and the other in the sylvian region. Blood cultures: positive for Enterococcus faecalis. TTE and TEE: endocarditis on prosthetic aortic valve. Ascending aortic aneurysm of 49 mm. Mechanical aortic prosthesis with good disc mobility
column33: maximum gradient of 35 mmHg
column34: washout insufficiency. Two vibrational images compatible with vegetation visualised in LVOT are observed. Thickening of the aortic root and mitro-aortic junction suggestive of abscess at this level. MV with mild insufficiency. LV of normal dimensions with preserved systolic function. RV of normal dimensions with normal function. Moderate TR
column35: with estimated PSAP of 30 mmHg plus PVC. Normal vena cava. No pericardial effusion.  EVOLUTION On arrival at the emergency department
column36: on suspicion of acute stroke
column37: the above-mentioned complementary tests were performed and cerebral angiography confirmed the presence of occlusion of the distal M1 segment of the middle cerebral artery. As a result
column38: mechanical thrombectomy was performed
column39: achieving complete recanalisation of the artery. The patient was then admitted to the Intensive Care Unit for neurological and haemodynamic monitoring and surveillance. The patient progressed satisfactorily in the ICU
column40: where a transthoracic echocardiogram was performed with suspicion of endocarditis. Isolation of Enterococcus faecalis in blood cultures. A transesophageal study was performed with the results described. Once stable
column41: in the light of the echocardiographic findings
column42: discharge from the ICU to the Cardiology ward was decided in order to assess valve surgery. During his admission to Cardiology
column43: he was assessed by the Rehabilitation Service and Neurology
column44: who began motor and phoniatric recovery exercises. Cardiologically
column45: he remained stable
column46: with prolonged PR. Two days later
column47: the patient had two episodes of sudden loss of consciousness
column48: and telemetry showed complete atrioventricular block
column49: so he was transferred to the Coronary Unit for implantation of a provisional pacemaker via the right jugular vein. The case was discussed with Cardiac Surgery who
column50: given the electrical worsening and the need for a temporary pacemaker on command to maintain stability
column51: decided to perform surgery within 48 hours. The patient underwent surgery two days later and a metallic valve prosthesis was extracted with abscess cleaning and a biological prosthesis was implanted in the aortic position
column52: as well as a supracoronary tube due to the discovery of an aneurysm of the ascending aorta. Immediate and late postoperative evolution was favourable
column53: except for the persistence of advanced AVB in ECG despite the absence of images compatible with abscesses in echocardiography
column54: so it was decided to implant a definitive DDD pacemaker. Hospital discharge was decided in view of the good clinical evolution in the postoperative period 40 days after the neurological ischaemic event.  DIAGNOSIS Late prosthetic endocarditis due to Enterococcus faecalis. Ischaemic stroke due to thrombotic occlusion in left middle cerebral artery. Thrombectomy performed successfully. Complete atrioventricular block with definitive DDDR pacemaker implantation (MCP). Aortic valve replacement with Perimount biological aortic prosthesis no23. ʟʟ Ascending aortic aneurysm.
