column1: Sam is a 52-year-old male ex-smoker who denies any other cardiovascular risk factors. He has developed an unresectable squamous cell carcinoma of the tonsil (T4bN2bM0) as a result of his past tobacco use. Currently undergoing radical treatment with cetuximab and radiotherapy. Asymptomatic from the cardiological point of view until the night of the day before the consultation
column2: when he presented with central thoracic pain
column3: oppressive and radiating to the back and neck
column4: lasting a few hours. He denies having had fever or infectious symptoms. He consulted his primary care doctor who performed an electrocardiogram (ECG) in which they described an increase in the lower ST and high and low lateral ST
column5: and was assessed by members of the Canary Islands Emergency Service (SUC) who informed the hospital of the diagnosis of inferolateral acute myocardial infarction (AMI) with a view to carrying out primary angioplasty. On arrival at the Emergency Department he was found to be hypotensive
column6: so dopamine was started at a dose of 15 mcg/kg/min
column7: and the Haemodynamics section was contacted for urgent catheterisation
column8: so the cardiologist on duty went down to assess the patient. The ECG was repeated. Physical examination revealed a poor general condition
column9: with significant tachypnoea and arterial hypotension of 85/55 mmHg despite catecholamines and mild jugular venous insufficiency. Cardiac sounds are very diminished with no murmurs or friction rub. There is an erythematous lump on the neck
column10: warm and painful on palpation.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Laboratory tests: no leukocytosis
column11: normocytic normochromic anaemia of 9.7 mg/dL and acute renal failure with creatinine of 2.4 mg/dL. Hb: 13.3 g/dL
column12: leukocytes 64
column14: platelets 77x10^3/mcL. Echocardiography: global and segmental left ventricular function was preserved and severe pericardial effusion was detected with a maximum of 36 mm at the anterior level. Its appearance is dense
column15: hyperechogenic and mottled. There were signs of haemodynamic compromise
column16: with collapse of the left atrium and a slight collapse of the right ventricle. Other complementary tests during admission: ECG: sinus rhythm at 100 bpm
column17: normal PR
column18: normal electrical axis
column19: narrow QRS with generalised concave ST-elevation (I
column20: II
column21: III
column22: aVF
column23: V3-V6) Pericardial fluid culture and blood cultures: Streptococcus constellatum. Chest CT with contrast: bibasal lung consolidations. To evaluate possible bronchoaspiration. Minimal right pleural effusion. Pneumopericardium with drainage catheter inside. Multiple hepatic abscesses in LHI. LOE in LHI in relation to abscess versus metastatic disease (not present in previous study). Rest normal
column24: no mesenteric or retroperitoneal adenopathy. Neck CT: favourable response of left tonsillar neoplasm and adenopathic conglomerates. Significant response with a decrease in the overall tumour volume of the neoplasm originating in the left lingual tonsil
column25: with a residual necrotic lesion persisting at this level with a diameter of 24.8 + 30 mm
column26: which protrudes towards the left lateral margin of the floor of the mouth.  EVOLUTION It was decided to perform an urgent therapeutic pericardiocentesis in the haemodynamics room. Initially
column27: 600 cc of foul-smelling
column28: purulent fluid was extracted. After analysing the emergency fluid
column29: it was found to be purulent and S. constellatum
column30: which was also isolated from blood
column31: was isolated. An aetiological study was completed with a CT scan of the chest and abdomen to identify the possible origin of the purulent collection
column33: in whose culture different microorganisms grew
column34: although they were also present in the oral microbiota: Gemella morbillorum and Parvimonas micra. In the first few days after drainage
column35: the patient continued to require catecholaminergic support due to septic shock
column36: so he was admitted to the ICU
column37: where empirical intravenous antibiotic treatment was initially established
column38: and subsequently adjusted to the antibiogram. Within a week of complete drainage of the fluid and despite optimal antibiotic treatment
column39: the patient developed severe pericardial effusion again. Urgent pericardiocentesis and pericardial window were performed the following morning surgically by thoracoscopy.  DIAGNOSIS Purulent pericarditis complicated by pericardial tamponade. Polymicrobial septic shock with liver abscesses. T4N2bM0 tonsil carcinoma. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Background A 63-year-old patient with no known drug allergies
column2: with cardiovascular risk factors (hypertension
column3: dyslipidaemia
column4: obesity) and a history of epilepsy
column5: hypothyroidism secondary to thyroiditis and chronic renal failure with baseline creatinine levels of around 1.91. In December 2012
column6: he presented with a first episode of congestive heart failure and was diagnosed with a bicuspid aortic valve with severe insufficiency and moderate LV dysfunction
column7: and the medical-surgical committee decided to perform surgery. Preoperative coronary angiography ruled out significant coronary lesions. The operation was successfully performed on 08/04/2013 and a St Jude No. 25 mechanical prosthesis was placed. During the postoperative period
column8: the patient had a torpid evolution with atrial flutter with a high ventricular response that was difficult to control
column9: oliguric renal failure with an increase in creatinine levels to a maximum of 4 mg/dl
column10: a generalised tonic-clonic seizure episode with a good pharmacological response to valproate and levetiracetam and retroperitoneal haematoma in the head and body of the pancreas. After progressive improvement with favourable evolution
column11: the patient was discharged from hospital. Pre-discharge echocardiography: aortic prosthesis with normofunction criteria. LV slightly dilated (LVED 56 mm) and LVEF approximately 50%. Central mild MI. ECG prior to discharge: sinus rhythm with HRBBB at 60 bpm. Subsequently
column12: correct follow-up by Cardiology outpatients without new cardiological events of interest and with normal echocardiographic controls. Regular treatment with synthrom
column13: omeprazole 40 mg
column14: ezetimibe/simvastatin (10/40 mg)
column15: fenofibrate 200 mg
column16: eutirox 100 mcg
column17: allopurinol 300 mg and levetiracetam 1
column18: 000 mg every 12 hours. Current history: on 5/01/2017 he attended the Emergency Department of our hospital due to initially diffuse and episodic abdominal pain that later became localised in the right hypochondrium for six hours
column19: with no accompanying vegetative cortex. There was no thermometric fever
column20: although there was a feeling of dystrophy. The patient also presented an increase in his usual dyspnoea to the point of minimal effort and orthopnoea. No syncope or presyncope. No palpitations or chest pain.  Physical examination BP 120/57
column21: HR 63 bpm
column22: Temperature: 37.7°C
column23: Baseline O2 Sat 97% Patient conscious and temporospatially oriented
column24: well perfused and hydrated. Colour slightly jaundiced
column25: eupneic at rest. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds without audible murmurs. Aortic valve click. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur in all fields without added pathological sounds. Abdomen globular but depressible
column26: pain on palpation in the right hypochondrium. Murphy. Hydro-aerial sounds present. No signs of peritoneal irritation. Lower extremities without oedema or signs of DVT.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Blood tests on arrival at the ED: glucose 341
column27: urea 84
column28: creatinine 2.59
column29: Na 131
column30: Cl 101
column32: liver profile and bilirubin without alterations. Myocardial necrosis markers: troponin I 0.06
column33: myoglobin 97. ProBNP 3.984. Haemogram: Leukocytes 8
column34: 700 (75.4 % neutrophils)
column37: platelets 19
column39: prothrombin activity 25 %. ECG: complete AV block with escape rhythm at 56 bpm. BRDHH. No acute repolarisation abnormalities. Chest X-ray: (06/01/2017) atheromatosis and aortic elongation. Aortic prosthesis
column40: cardiomegaly. Hilar thickening with vascular appearance. Ultrasound of the abdomen: (07/01/2017) distended gallbladder (125 x 44 mm) with thickening and parietal oedema (4 mm)
column41: perivesicular oedema
column42: perivesicular-perihepatic free fluid and maximum pain at the gallbladder site. Inside
column43: there are few small hyperechogenic images
column44: one of them with posterior shadowing. Overall
column45: the patient fulfils the criteria for acute cholecystitis as the first diagnostic possibility. It could be
column46: although less likely
column47: a stress gallbladder in the context of heart failure or alliasic cholecystitis (diabetic debut). Liver with a marked diffuse increase in steatotic echorefringence. No bile duct ectasia. Pancreatic area is not visible due to abundant abdominal weathering. Spleen of normal size and morphology. Kidneys of normal morphology and symmetrical. Abdominal aorta not approachable. Bladder without alterations.  EVOLUTION Given the ultrasound findings of acute cholecystitis
column48: antibiotherapy was started as conservative management without improvement of the picture
column49: persisting fever and worsening analytical control analysis: procalcitonin 6.84
column50: creatinine 4.13
column51: chlorine 108
column52: sodium 135
column53: potassium 5.4
column54: amylase 95
column55: lipase 258
column56: normal liver profile
column57: leucocytes 13.500 N87.3 %
column58: Hb 9.5
column59: haematocrit 30.7 %
column61: prothrombin activity 4 %. In view of this situation
column62: it was decided to perform an urgent cholecystectomy. Prior to surgery
column63: the Anaesthesia Service requested our assessment. Given the finding of complete AVB and fever
column64: it was decided to perform echocardiography with the following result: Echocardiography: (09/01/2017) non-dilated LV (LVEDD 55 mm)
column65: preserved LVEF (estimated by Teicholz 65%). Septa with flattened motion. MV: slightly fibrous leaflets with calcium in the mitral annulus
column66: mild central MI
column67: no images suggestive of endocarditis on the mitral valve. St Jude mechanical aortic prosthesis no. 25
column68: slightly elevated gradients for model and number of prosthesis (maximum gradient of 45 mmHg
column69: mean gradient of 24 mmHg). At the level of the mitro-aortic junction
column70: a filiform image of anarchic movement suggestive of an endocarditic process can be seen. At apical level 5C there is flow from VAo to LA suggestive of aorto-auricular fistula. Right chambers not dilated. Preserved RVEF (TAPSE 23 mmHg)
column71: mild TR. Non-dilated IVC with normal inspiratory collapse. PAPs 35 mmHg. No pericardial effusion
column72: perihepatic free fluid. In view of the new evidence
column73: blood cultures were taken and empirical antibiotic treatment was started with cloxacillin
column74: ampicillin and gentamicin
column75: adjusted according to renal function. He was admitted to the coronary ICU of our hospital pending transesophageal echocardiography and assessment by Cardiac Surgery. On admission to the ICU
column76: he presented disconnection from the environment
column77: right hemiplegia and complete aphasia. An urgent cranial CT scan was performed which showed an acute cerebral haematoma in the right parieto-temporal region measuring 29 x 25 x 32 mm with an estimated volume of 12 cc
column78: subarachnoid discharge and minimal intraventricular blood. After acute haemorrhagic stroke
column79: action by Cardiac Surgery was postponed. Subsequent poor evolution with persistent fever
column80: septic symptoms and haemodynamic deterioration despite targeted antibiotic therapy. Blood cultures isolated Streptococcus gallolyticus sensitive to beta lactams. The patient died on 17/01/2017 after progressive worsening and multiorgan failure.   DIAGNOSIS Acute cholecystitis with torpid evolution
column81: persistent fever and complete AV block. Streptococcus gallolyticus endocarditis on prosthetic AV complicated by aorto-cavitary fistula to the left atrium. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 19-year-old female patient with a personal history of anorexia-bulimia for 2 years undergoing psychological treatment
column3: with no toxic habits. Diagnosed in January 2016 with severe bone marrow aplasia
column4: with no response to immunosuppressive treatment
column5: on the waiting list for a bone marrow transplant. Carrier of subcutaneous venous reservoir. Current history: fever up to 39°C
column6: vomiting and dizziness of less than 24 hours of evolution. She also reports a dry
column7: irritative cough of about 15 days' duration. No rhinorrhoea
column8: no otalgia. No micturition symptoms. No alterations in stool habits. Last transfusion last Thursday. She reported pain and discomfort in the area of the reservoir for a week
column9: with erythematous area and increased local heat.  Physical examination Blood pressure 108/68. Heart rate 123 pm. Temperature 38.50 oC. Oxygen saturation 99 % basal. Conscious
column10: oriented
column11: reactive. Glasgow 15. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds
column12: tachycardic. No murmurs were heard. Pulmonary auscultation: normal ventilation in all fields. Bilateral PPR negative. Lower extremities: no oedema
column13: no signs of DVT. Abdomen: soft
column14: depressible
column15: painful on palpation of the epigastrium. No masses or visceromegaly palpable. Peristalsis preserved
column16: no signs of peritonism. Blumberg and Murphy negative.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS CBC: 900 leukocytes with 400 neutrophils per dl
column17: Hb 9.8 g/dl
column19: platelets 8
column20: 000. Glucose 103 mg/dl
column21: urea 42 mg/dl
column22: creatinine 0.67 mg/dl
column23: total bilirubin 2.11 mg/dl
column24: Na 136 mEq/l
column25: K 3.8 mEq/l. FA 71 mg/dl
column26: GGT 15 mg/dl
column27: GOT 89 mg/dl
column28: GPT 106 mg/dl
column29: LDH 144 mg/dl. Blood cultures: positive for Staphylococcus epidermidis
column30: resistant to cloxacillin. Chest X-ray: possible consolidating focus in LID. Echocardiogram: normal LVEF and no contractile asymmetries. Normal diastole. LA not dilated. MV of fine veils
column31: preserved kinetics

Non-compaction cardiomyopathy with left ventricular systolic function (LVEF) at the lower limit of normal. 1-vessel coronary artery disease: 2nd obtuse marginal artery. Percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty and implantation of two drug-eluting stents. Mixed dyslipidaemia. Diabetes mellitus (DM) type II. column1: Background 42-year-old woman with no known drug allergies. No hypertension
column2: dyslipidaemia or diabetes mellitus. No toxic habits. Inactive ulcerative colitis under treatment. Periodic follow-up by digestology. Last colonoscopy in 2013. Migraine in treatment with triptans.  Current illness Puerpera patient with an uneventful pregnancy who
column3: after the 4th day of euthocic delivery
column4: began to feel dyspnoea with slight precordial pressure and headache
column5: not associated with vegetatism. Elevated blood pressure and proteinuria were observed
column6: and a diagnosis of pre-eclampsia was made. Creatinine levels were normal. A fundus examination was performed and found to be normal. After starting treatment with labetalol and magnesium sulphate
column7: the patient progressed favourably
column8: with control of blood pressure and improvement in headache and general condition. Laboratory tests showed an initial increase in LDH with a subsequent decrease. Labetalol ev and magnesium sulphate were maintained until 48 hours had elapsed
column9: and the patient was subsequently switched to oral labetalol (300 mg/6h). Given the clinical and analytical stability
column10: the patient was transferred to the hospital ward. During her stay in the hospital ward
column11: the patient remained hypertensive despite nifedipine 10 mg/6h vo and enalapril 5 mg/12h vo. Recurrence of severe headaches without neurological focality
column12: so a cranial CAT scan was performed
column13: which was normal. Given the persistence of the headache and his history of migraine
column14: sumatriptan was started with clinical improvement. After 48 hours of her stay on the ward
column15: she presented peak blood pressure of 180/110 mmHg together with chest tightness. An ECG was performed
column16: showing RS at 60 bpm
column17: with normal PR
column18: HBASHH
column19: ST elevation of 0.5 mm anterolateral with negative T. Nitroglycerin perfusion was started and the patient was asymptomatic after 15 minutes. She was transferred to our centre from the maternity hospital. On arrival
column20: no chest pain. BP 160/90 mmHg. HR 65 bpm. SaO2 100% (ambient air). No semiology of congestion.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: shows normalisation of ST
column21: although HBASHH persists and minimal R in precordial leads. Initial TnI 0.7 ng/ml. Laboratory tests: CRP 0.95 mg/dl; creatinine 0.44 mg/dl; Na 141 mmol/L; K 3.8 mmol/l; leukocytes 6
column22: 800/mcl; Hb 130 g/l; Hto 40 %; Plaq 298
column23: 000/mcl; PT 86.2 %; D-dimer 10
column24: 000 ng/ml. A portable echocardiogram was performed
column25: showing preserved LV systolic function
column26: with hypokinesia of the apical segments and slight pericardial effusion. Chest X-ray: no cardiomegaly. No signs of parenchymal congestion. Free costophrenic sinuses.  EVOLUTION Admitted to the Acute Cardiac Care Unit
column27: presenting haemodynamic stability with a tendency to hypertension. No new episodes of chest pain or signs of congestion. Peak Tn I 24 ng/ml. Normal renal function. Twenty-four hours after arrival
column28: coronary angiography showed coronary dissection of the distal LAD with apical recurrence (TIMI 3 flow) and conservative management was chosen. The echocardiogram showed non-dilated left ventricle with EF 50%. Septoapical hypokinesia and mild mitral insufficiency. Normal RV function. Anti-aggregation treatment was maintained with adiro 100 mg indefinitely and anticoagulant treatment was discontinued after 72 hours. Due to a tendency to hypertension
column29: treatment was started with ACE inhibitors
column30: amlodipine and beta-blockers. She was discharged home asymptomatic and with controlled blood pressure.  DIAGNOSIS Spontaneous coronary artery dissection of the LAD in a postpartum patient. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Background Sister with congenital heart disease: ventricular septal defect No medical or surgical history of interest No usual treatment No known drug allergies  Current illness A 21-year-old male patient came to the emergency department with a sensation of dizziness accompanied by transitory paraesthesia in the left arm
column2: without loss of consciousness or trauma. He reported no chest pain
column3: dyspnoea
column4: palpitations or syncope and was discharged from the emergency department. Previously completely normal life
column5: with intense sport. He is currently a football referee.  Two weeks later he presented with dizziness of a few minutes' duration with chest pain while playing sport with subsequent abnormal sensations consisting of general malaise and slight dizziness for at least an hour
column6: relieved by diazepam.  Physical examination Normal jugular venous pressure. Carotid pulses full and symmetrical. No frémito or impulsive precordial beats. Cardiorespiratory auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur
column7: without added pathological sounds. Rhythmic cardiac tones with holosystolic murmur II/VI in the lower left sternal border. Abdomen: soft
column8: depressible
column9: non-painful
column10: without megaliths. Lower limbs: no oedema and preserved distal pulses.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Chest X-ray: normal cardiothoracic index
column11: normal cardiophrenic and costodiaphragmatic sinuses
column12: no pleural effusion
column13: no infiltrates or condensation. No alterations in bone or soft tissues were observed. Laboratory tests: all parameters were normal. Glucemia 89 mg/dL
column14: urea 29 mg/dL
column15: 0.89 mg/dL
column16: sodium 144 mmol/L
column17: potassium 4.1 mmol/L
column18: chlorine 108 mmol/L. Leukocytes 10130 uL with 58.4% neutrophils. Haemoglobin 17.4 g/dL with MCV 89.4 fl
column19: platelets 223000Ul. Cardiac markers (troponin). 0.0 in two determinations.  ECG: sinus rhythm at 79lpm with PR 180 ms. Image of BCRDHH
column20: IAH and biauricular growth.  Transthoracic echocardiography: situs solitus. Atrioventricular and ventricular arterial concordance. Atrioventricular septal defect: AV valves at the same level. Spontaneously closed ventricular septal defect with closing aneurysm. Wide defect of the inflow septum and ostium secundum. Left right shunt. Tabication in the wall of the left atrium cor triatriatum type
column21: delimiting a posterior cavity where the pulmonary veins drain and communicating with a restrictive orifice with the left atrium adjacent to the mitral valve. The four pulmonary veins cannot be precisely located. Moderately dilated right ventricle (52 mm basal and 46 mm in the mid region measured in apical 4-chamber projection). Good longitudinal displacement
column22: TAPSE of 22 m. Left ventricle of normal diameters
column23: walls and ejection fraction (parasternal projection
column24: long axis: end-diastolic diameter 44 mm
column25: end-systolic diameter 23 mm
column26: basal septum thickness 10 mm
column27: posterior wall thickness 8 mm). Left atrium not dilated. Left atrial valve with elongated leaflets. Good opening. Slight central regurgitation. Right AV valve with leaflet coaptation defect. Moderate central insufficiency. AD-VD gradient of 32 mmHg. Inferior vena cava not dilated (19mm) with preserved inspiratory collapse. No pericardial effusion. Aortic sag without abnormalities. Estimated PSAP between 40-45 mmHg.  Transesophageal echocardiography: wide interatrial septal defect in the region of ostium primum plus part of ostium secundum. Membrane septum in the upper portion of the left atrium. Appears to have two entry points: one posterior approximately 17x10 mm
column28: with accelerated flow through it and another anterolateral in relation to the entrance of the left atrial appendage and through the entrance region of the left atrial appendage into the inflow tract and mitral valve. Apparent drainage of the four pulmonary veins into this posterior chamber.  EVOLUTION Currently asymptomatic
column29: accepted for cardiovascular surgery. column1: A 47-year-old man was brought to our centre by the emergency services after presenting a recovered cardiorespiratory arrest.  History Cardiovascular risk factors: type 2 diabetes mellitus
column2: hypertension
column3: dyslipidaemia
column4: smoker of 1 pack/day. Gout episode in 2010 treated with colchicine and allopurinol. he underwent bilateral inguinal hernioplasty. ʟʟ No known previous cardiovascular history or family history of early ischaemic heart disease.  Usual treatment: losartan 50 mg
column5: metformin 850 mg (half a tablet per day).  Present illness: he was brought to our centre by the emergency services after presenting with witnessed cardiorespiratory arrest in the street
column6: and basic cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) manoeuvres were started by a technician for 15 minutes. After the arrival of the emergency services
column7: advanced CPR and orotracheal intubation (OTI) were started. A defibrillable rhythm was identified on the monitor and two shocks were applied at maximum energy
column8: after which sinus rhythm was restored and the electrocardiogram (ECG) showed an ST-segment elevation in the lower face. On arrival at our centre
column9: the ECG was repeated
column10: showing normalisation of the ST segment in the inferior face. A portable transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) was performed
column11: showing akinesia of the inferior face. The patient was transferred urgently to the haemodynamics room and a therapeutic hypothermia protocol was initiated. Coronary angiography was performed
column12: showing occlusion of the ostial circumflex artery (CX)
column13: which receives heterocoronary collateral circulation from the anterior descending artery (AD)
column14: and severe stenosis in the middle segment of the right coronary artery (RCA) with an image of complex plaque. In view of the electrocardiographic and TTE findings
column15: the CD artery was considered to be responsible for the condition
column16: so angioplasty and implantation of 2 coated stents was performed with suboptimal results due to poor stent apposition due to the significant calcium load and irregular distribution of calcium. Subsequently
column17: he was transferred to the Acute Cardiac Care Unit intubated
column18: sedoanalgesiated and relaxed
column19: and cooled with physiological saline solution at 4oC.  Physical examination Blood pressure: 108/60. Heart rate: 65 bpm. oxygen saturation: 100%. Head and neck: jugular venous pressure normal. Pulmonary auscultation: decreased vesicular murmur in the right hemithorax. Cardiac auscultation: no murmurs or extratonos. Abdomen: hydro-aerial sounds present. Soft
column20: without masses or organomegaly. Extremities: pulses of slightly decreased amplitude
column21: symmetrical
column22: no oedema in the lower limbs
column23: slow capillary filling. Neurological: reactive symmetrical pupils. Ramsay 6.   COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG (after defibrillation): sinus rhythm
column24: narrow QRS
column25: ST-segment elevation of up to 4 mm in inferior face
column26: greater in lead III than in II
column27: with specular decrease from V1 to V3. ECG (on arrival at our centre): normalisation of ST-segment elevation in the inferior face.  Analysis on admission: Hb 14 g/dL
column28: leukocytes 17300/μL (neutrophils 85%)
column29: platelets 270000/μL
column30: INR 1
column31: D-dimer 15346 ng/mL
column33: urea 27 mg/dL
column34: creatinine 0.83 mg/dL
column35: Na 134 mg/dL
column36: potassium 4.3 mg/dL
column37: NTproBNP 280 pg/mL
column38: ALT 48 U/L
column39: GGT 32U/L
column40: alkaline phosphatase 76U/L
column41: amylase and lipase normal
column42: Mg 2.3 mg/dL
column43: Ca 8.1 mg/dL
column44: P 6.4 mg/dL
column45: total cholesterol 138 mg/dL
column46: LDL 84 mg/dL
column47: HDL 35 mg/dL
column48: triglycerides 92 mg/dL
column49: HbA1c 6.2%
column50: TSH 0.03 ulU/mL
column51: free T4 17.6 pg/mL
column52: free T3 3.9 pg/mL. Myocardial necrosis markers: peak troponin I 149 ng/mL
column53: peak CK 2512 U/L. Neuron specific enolase: 1st determination: 29.4 ng/mL. Second determination: 43.3 ng/mL.  Blood cultures
column54: urine culture and bronchial aspirate culture: negative. Chest X-ray on admission: atelectasis in the right upper lobe.  Chest X-ray 2 days after admission: alveolointerstitial infiltrate in right lung and left lung base. Resolution of right upper lobe atelectasis.  Portable echocardiogram on admission (during induction of hypothermia): moderate-severe left ventricular dysfunction with estimated LVEF 35%
column55: with posterior and inferior akinesia and lateral hypokinesia. Right ventricle with slightly reduced systolic function (TAPSE 15 mm)
column56: mild mitral insufficiency
column57: no pericardial effusion.  Echocardiogram after termination of hypothermia and extubation: mildly reduced left ventricular systolic function (LVEF by biplane 57%). Apical akinesia and hypokinesia of the inferior and septal aspect. Mild mitral insufficiency. Urgent coronary angiography: left main coronary artery: no stenosis. DA artery: vessel of adequate calibre and development
column58: without stenosis. Artery CX: vessel of adequate size and development
column59: with 100% ostial occlusion that receives homocoronary Rentrop-3 collateral circulation from the diagonal branches of the DA artery. CD artery: severely calcified dominant vessel
column60: of adequate size and development
column61: with 75% stenosis in its proximal segment and 90% ulcerated plaque image in its middle segment. Balloon angioplasty and implantation of 2 overlapping drug-eluting stents in the middle and proximal segments of the CD artery
column62: with TIMI III distal flow.  EVOLUTION On arrival at the Acute Cardiac Care Unit
column63: a femoral venous hypothermia catheter (Coolgard®) was inserted and cooling was completed
column64: reaching a target temperature of 33°C within a few hours. The admission X-ray showed an image of atelectasis in the right upper lobe
column65: probably related to secretion impaction
column66: which resolved in the subsequent control X-ray after aspiration of the endotracheal tube and mobilisation of the patient. Therapeutic hypothermia was maintained for 24 hours
column67: and subsequent rewarming was carried out without complications. The patient evolved well
column68: allowing him to be extubated on the third day of admission. After rewarming and extubation
column69: the patient made a good neurological recovery
column70: with adequate mobilisation of all four limbs
column71: and was oriented
column72: able to understand and obey orders
column73: with some frontal deficit
column74: which gradually recovered. On discharge he persisted with mild dysarthria
column75: pending assessment and follow-up by rehabilitation and speech therapy. Incidentally
column76: during his admission he presented a bout of atrial fibrillation on telemetry
column77: which cardioverted to sinus rhythm after starting amiodarone
column78: with no new arrhythmic episodes. On arrival at the hospital
column79: the emergency services informed us of the possibility of bronchoaspiration during OTI
column80: so blood
column81: urine and bronchial aspirate cultures were taken on admission
column82: and empirical antibiotic coverage with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid was started. The cultures
column83: however
column84: were negative. After completing rewarming
column85: fever was observed for more than 24 hours
column86: with purulent secretions in the ventilation tube
column87: so antibiotic therapy was modified and meropenem and metronidazole were started
column88: with good evolution
column89: with no new febrile peaks. The patient was discharged with treatment with adiro 100 mg
column90: prasugrel 10 mg
column91: pantoprazole 20 mg
column93: enalapril 10 mg and metoprolol 50 mg at breakfast and 25 mg at dinner. The patient was referred to the cardiac rehabilitation department of our centre.  DIAGNOSIS Cardio-respiratory arrest due to recovered ventricular fibrillation. Killip I inferior STEACS. Angioplasty and implantation of drug-eluting stents in the proximal and middle right coronary artery. Total occlusion of ostial circumflex artery with collateral circulation. Therapeutic hypothermia. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 53-year-old male. No known drug allergies.  Family history Mother died suddenly at the age of 72. Maternal uncle died in the operating theatre during anaesthetic induction.  Cardiovascular risk factors Smoker of about 30 pack-years Non-drinker No hypertension
column3: DM or LD No known cardiac history Other: reactive depression Treatments: omeprazole and deprax  Current illness 53-year-old patient who consults for syncope. First syncope 18 months ago
column4: when she consulted this centre
column5: but requested voluntary discharge before the aetiology could be studied. Repeated another 6 times
column6: with prodromes - loss of consciousness - rapid recovery. One of them at rest.  Physical examination COC. Afebrile. A: 100/60. HR: 55 bpm. BEG. NHNC. Normal PC. Arterial pulse bisferiens. Cardiac auscultation: RsCsRs with systolic murmur III/VI with preserved s2 in aortic focus irradiated to the rest of foci. Decrease in murmur until it disappeared with squatting. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur. Soft
column7: non-painful abdomen with no masses or megaliths. Positive radial and pedial arterial pulses
column8: bilateral and symmetrical.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Blood count
column9: biochemistry and coagulation: no alterations. Chest X-ray: cardiothoracic index normal
column10: without condensation or signs of heart failure. ECG: sinus rhythm with LV enlargement and signs of overload. Transthoracic echocardiogram: LA moderately dilated (33 cm2 and 4.5 cm). LV with severe hypertrophy of septal predominance (23 mm)
column11: not dilated
column12: with preserved systolic function. Mitral SAM. LVOT obstruction with maximum gradient 111 mmHg
column13: baseline. Severe eccentric MI. Telemetry during hospitalisation: no rhythm alterations.  EVOLUTION Patient admitted to Cardiology for syncope under study. Auscultation revealed a murmur that decreased with manoeuvres that increased ventricular volume (increased afterload with squatting) and an ECG with criteria of left ventricular hypertrophy and a bisferiens arterial pulse
column14: for which he was admitted with the suspicion of obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. This suspicion was confirmed by echocardiography
column15: which revealed atrial dilatation and obstruction of the left ventricular outflow tract. The patient was monitored with telemetry from admission
column16: and no arrhythmic events were observed. In accordance with the new guidelines on hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
column17: the risk of sudden death at 5 years is calculated
column18: with a result of more than 6%
column19: and therefore the implantation of a defibrillator is recommended. Consent was obtained both for ICD implantation and for blood extraction for genetic study
column20: and the family study of the index case was initiated.  DIAGNOSIS Index case obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Secondary syncope. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Objective: the interpretation of the ECG and the clinical context is key to diagnosis and subsequent treatment. A 31-year-old primigravid 33-week-old woman was transferred to the Cardiology Department of the Hospital Central de Asturias due to dizziness
column3: palpitations and electrocardiographic alterations. AP: Allergy to diclofenac and naproxen. She works in a supermarket. Cardiovascular risk factors No toxic habits. No hypertension
column4: mixed dyslipidaemia (currently discharged by endocrinologist
column5: treated with simvastatin and fenofibrate
column6: no follow-up). Gestational diabetes treated with insulin Lispro 25/75: 12 units in the morning
column7: 10 units at night. No previous cardiological history. Hepatic steatosis. Herniated disc. Breast reduction surgery.  Present illness The patient attended her referral hospital due to dizziness of 24 hours of evolution in relation to standing upright. The symptoms improve with decubitus. No chest pain or dyspnoea. Occasional episodes of palpitations. The patient reported catarrhal symptoms a few days earlier. ECG was performed and described as wide QRS tachycardia at 180 bpm. Vagal manoeuvres were performed but were ineffective and 6 and 12 mg of adenosine were prescribed with no response
column8: so he was referred to our centre. We do not have the patient's baseline ECG. On arrival at our centre
column9: the patient was asymptomatic and haemodynamically stable.  Physical examination BP: 110/75 mmHg. HR: 188 bpm. O2 Sat: 98% without oxygen therapy. Conscious
column10: oriented
column11: cooperative. Normohydrated and normal colour. AP: preserved vesicular murmur with no other superimposed noises. AC: rhythmic heart sounds with mitral SS III/IV with normal S2. Abdomen: 33 weeks pregnant. Scar on the breasts. MMII: no oedema
column12: no signs of DVT.   COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Blood count: Hb 12.5g/dl
column13: MCV 82.6 fL
column14: leukocytes12500 uL (normal formula)
column15: platelets 239000 uL. Biochemistry: glucose 125mg/dl
column16: urea 17 mg/dl
column17: creatinine 0.61 mg/dl
column18: sodium 135 mg/dl
column19: CK 56 U/L
column20: troponin T 33 ng/L. Coagulation: PT 87%
column21: INR 1.09
column22: fibrinogen 686
column23: D-dimer 1187 ng/ml. ECG transthoracic echocardiography: study performed at 160 bpm. Non-dilated LV
column24: non-hypertrophic
column25: hypercontractile
column26: without alterations of regional contractility. Preserved LVEF
column27: no dilatation of the right chambers. Moderate mitral insufficiency.  EVOLUTION Admission to the Advanced Cardiac Care Unit for monitoring and treatment. Vagal manoeuvres and adenosine 6 and 12 mg were repeated
column28: both without success. IV atenolol 4mg was prescribed
column29: with no response
column30: so electrical cardioversion (ECV) was decided. The case was discussed with the Gynaecology and Anaesthesiology departments and two ECV (100 and 200J) were performed under maternal sedation with propofol and foetal monitoring
column31: both of which were unsuccessful. No foetal distress was observed at any time. The patient remained asymptomatic at all times and haemodynamically stable. Monitoring showed persistent wide QRS tachycardia (same morphology as on the arrival ECG) at similar frequencies (170-190 bpm). Given the persistence of the arrhythmia
column32: it was decided to start treatment with an infusion of beta-blockers (labetalol at 20 ml/h) and an ampoule of 0.5 mg of intravenous digoxin. The tachycardia rate was initially reduced to around 150 bpm
column33: with progressively more frequent presence of sinus beats interspersed with the arrhythmia
column34: followed by trigeminy (visualisation on telemetry recording). A few hours later
column35: sinus rhythm was observed
column36: with isolated ventricular extrasystoles persisting. At 12 hours after the start of perfusion
column37: after several hours in stable sinus rhythm
column38: beta-blocker perfusion was discontinued and the patient's ECG was as shown in figure 2. The patient reported only symptoms of gastro-oesophageal reflux
column39: for which oral ranitindin was prescribed if necessary. After a further 8 hours of monitoring with persistent sinus rhythm
column40: she was transferred to the Cardiology ward and the TTE was repeated. The patient remained hospitalised for a further 48 hours and after finding that there were no gynaecological complications and that she remained asymptomatic with an ECG recording in sinus rhythm without alterations
column41: discharge was decided with prophylactic treatment with metropolol pending outpatient consultation with the Arrhythmia section of our centre. After assessment by gynaecology
column42: no complications related to pregnancy were detected
column43: so outpatient follow-up was decided as planned.  DIAGNOSIS This must be resolved by the contestant through the interpretation of the ECG. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Male
column3: 36 years old.  History AHT Stage III chronic renal failure secondary to vesicoureteral reflux Current illness The patient reported fever and vomiting for 3 days
column4: general malaise
column5: generalised aches and pains
column6: dystrophic sensation
column7: chills
column8: sweating and vomiting.  Physical examination BP: 100/40 Ta: 39.5 °C Normal colour
column9: hydrated and perfused Eupneic at 0° Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic with systolic murmur in EIB Pulmonary auscultation: VCM Abdomen: no evidence of peritoneal irritation  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECHOCARDIOGRAPHY: RS
column10: BCRIHH. Chest X-ray: normal. Laboratory tests: biochemistry: creatinine 7.99 mg/gl; Na 131 mEq/l; K 4.59 mEq/l
column11: CRP 23.09 mg/dl. Gases: pH 7.23
column12: pCO2 36 mmHg
column13: pO2 14 mmHg
column14: HCO3 15 mmol/l
column15: Ebb - 11.6 mmol/l. Haemogram: Hb 11.6 g/dl
column16: platelets 80 x1000/ul
column17: leucocytes 16.30x1000/ ul
column18: neutrophils 94.7%. Coagulation: prothrombin activity 65%
column19: INR 1.34 Abdominal CT scan with chest sections: abdomen normal. Chest sections included in the study showed a 1 cm nodule in LID
column20: two in LII (the largest measuring 5 mm) and another in the anterior part of the lingula
column21: all undetermined
column22: with an infectious aetiology to be assessed. Blood cultures: methicillin-sensitive S. aureus. Transthoracic echocardiogram: image compatible with endocardial wart of 15x10 mm anchored to the IV septum. Restrictive ventricular septal defect. Transesophageal echocardiogram recommended. Transesophageal echocardiogram: rules out involvement of other valves.  EVOLUTION In view of the febrile syndrome presented by the patient
column23: two sets of blood cultures were requested. A possible abdominal focus was suspected on the basis of the clinical manifestations and an abdominal CT scan was performed
column24: which ruled it out
column25: although possible infectious foci in the lungs were evident. Two sets of blood cultures were taken and were positive for Staphylococcus aureus. After isolation of S. aureus in both sets and the presence of previously unknown left bundle branch block and murmur
column26: a transthoracic echocardiogram was performed showing an endocardial wart dependent on the tricuspid subvalvular apparatus or the interventricular septum; and a restrictive ventricular septal defect (GP max 140 mmHg). Antibiotic therapy with intravenous cloxacillin was started
column27: after which the patient remained afebrile
column28: asymptomatic
column29: with a decrease in acute phase reactants and sterile serial blood cultures. A control transthoracic echocardiogram was performed 7 days after starting antibiotic therapy and it was found that the wart image had not decreased in size. A wait-and-see attitude was maintained and 14 days after starting antibiotic treatment
column30: a new echocardiographic check-up was performed
column31: which showed no changes with respect to the diagnostic echocardiogram. Given the persistence of the vegetation
column32: surgical intervention was indicated in conjunction with the Cardiac Surgery Service. The possibilities were explained to the patient and he accepted. The vegetation was resected and the VSD was closed with direct suture. The patient evolved favourably and was included in the haemodialysis programme.  DIAGNOSIS Tricuspid endocarditis due to S. aureus. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 56-year-old male
column3: no known allergies
column4: with a history of arterial hypertension
column5: moderate obesity
column6: paroxysmal paroxysmal atrial fibrillation anticoagulated with sintrom and gout. He was a bus driver by profession. He came to the emergency department with a single episode of oppressive central chest pain that woke him up in the early hours of the morning
column7: of approximately one hour's duration
column8: non-radiating and without associated vegetative cortex
column9: with no other concomitant symptoms (dyspnoea
column10: palpitations
column11: syncope
column12: etc.). The chest pain subsided during her stay in the emergency department after starting intravenous solinitrin infusion and controlling her blood pressure. On arrival
column13: he was in good general condition. Blood pressure was 200/121 mmHg
column14: heart rate 83 beats per minute and oxygen saturation 96% on room air. Cardiopulmonary auscultation and the rest of the physical examination were normal. A patient with an episode of chest pain at rest and troponin elevation in the context of very high blood pressure was admitted to Cardiology with the initial diagnosis of hypertensive emergency.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG on admission: sinus rhythm at 65 bpm. Narrow QRS. Q in III and VF with ST elevation of less than 1mm. V3-V6 and negative T in aVL. Poor progression of R in precordial leads. No changes in serial ECG
column15: all without pain. Laboratory tests in the emergency department: haemogram
column16: biochemistry and coagulation normal. Myocardial necrosis markers slightly elevated (maximum US TnT 16 ng/ml being the limit 14
column17: without typical curve of acute coronary syndrome). Chest X-ray: cardiomegaly. Aortic elongation. Hilar thickening. Transthoracic echocardiogram: non-dilated left ventricle with moderate concentric hypertrophy (14-14 mm)
column18: without alterations of segmental contractility. Dilatation of the ascending aorta. Stress cardiac MRI with dipyridamole: hypertensive heart disease with normal LVEF. Absence of inducible ischaemia or myocardial necrosis. Image of slight thickening of the thoracic aorta at the ascending and descending levels compatible with intramural haematoma. Angio-CT scan: intramural haematoma affecting the aortic arch and extending to the descending thoracic aorta without reaching the abdominal aorta. No images of penetrating ulcer or signs of dissection were identified. No aneurysmal dilatations were observed. The rest of the aorta had no significant findings. Central laboratory: urea 38 mg/dl
column19: creatinine 0.88 mg/dl
column20: uric acid 10.6 mg/dl. uric acid 10.6 mg/dl
column21: sodium 139 mmol/l
column22: potassium 4.4 mmol/l
column23: chlorine 102 mmol/l
column24: cholesterol 273 mg/dl
column25: triglycerides 341 mg/dl
column26: HDL cholesterol 44 mg/dl
column27: direct LDL cholesterol 190 mg/dl
column28: leucocytes 9100 /mm3
column29: haemoglobin 13.6 g/dl
column30: OHT 41%
column31: platelets 250000/mm3
column33: HbA1c 7%
column34: TSH 0.7 μU/ml.  EVOLUTION During his stay in the cardiology ward
column35: the patient remained clinically stable and asymptomatic
column36: without new episodes of chest pain
column37: with good control of blood pressure under treatment with beta-blockers
column38: oral nitrates and ACE inhibitors. After performing a transthoracic echocardiogram on the first day of hospital admission
column39: and finding dilatation of the ascending aorta
column40: a stress MRI with dipyridamole was requested to evaluate the aorta and rule out both acute aortic syndrome and ischaemic heart disease. Following the diagnosis of intramural haematoma with the imaging tests
column41: successive angio-CT scans were performed to assess the evolution
column42: given that the patient remained clinically stable. Given the absence of haematoma growth on imaging tests and as the ascending aorta was not compromised
column43: expectant management was decided
column44: with discharge from hospital and preferential follow-up in the Cardiovascular Surgery outpatient department. Twenty-five days after discharge
column45: the patient returned to the emergency department with a new episode of sudden and intense pain in the lumbar region accompanied by paraesthesia in the right lower limb. Examination revealed an absence of femoral pulses bilaterally. An emergency angio-CT scan was performed
column46: revealing a type A dissection with extension from the ascending aorta to both iliac arteries
column47: as well as thrombosis of the false lumen in the ascending aorta
column48: highlighting the significant increase in the diameter of the ascending aorta compared to the previous study. In view of these findings
column49: urgent surgery was decided. During the surgical procedure
column50: it was not possible to detect the entrance door at the level of the ascending aorta or the arch
column51: so a diagnosis of a type B dissection with retrograde progression was finally made
column52: and the ascending aorta was replaced with a 32 mm Dacron graft. Subsequently
column53: the patient had a torpid evolution during his stay in the ICU
column54: requiring vasoactive drugs and daily haemofiltration in the immediate postoperative period. After clinical stabilisation
column55: the patient was extubated and discharged from the intensive care unit. During his stay in the ward
column56: the patient evolved adequately without new complications and was discharged and referred to outpatients for follow-up with an intensive rehabilitation programme. Currently
column57: 3 months after admission for hypertensive emergency
column58: the patient is clinically stable.   DIAGNOSIS The cardiac MRI
column59: which was negative for ischaemia
column60: showed an image compatible with intramural haematoma in the thoracic aorta
column61: without affecting the ascending aorta
column62: so CT angiography was requested and confirmed the findings previously described. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  Personal history No known drug allergies. No DM
column3: DLP or AHT. Active smoker. Chronic gastritis. Surgical interventions: bilateral breast prosthesis. Family history: mother died suddenly at the age of 48 and sister died at the age of 50 (AMI?). Second-degree relatives with Chagas disease. usual treatment: pantoprazole.  Current disease The patient was a 45-year-old woman from Brazil who presented with two episodes of oppressive central thoracic pain radiating towards the MSI
column4: the first of which was self-limiting and lasted 5-10 minutes and the second persistent over time
column5: accompanied by a sensation of dizziness
column6: for which she went to the emergency department of a regional hospital. The patient reported self-limited palpitations the previous night
column7: for which reason she did not consult the emergency department. In view of these symptoms
column8: an electrocardiogram was performed showing a regular tachycardia with a wide QRS at 230 bpm which subsided after administration of flecainide 200 mg by mouth and went into sinus rhythm 20 minutes after treatment
column9: with a 1st degree BAV and an ST descent of up to 2 mm with a horizontal slope in V4-V6. Examination revealed: poor general condition with tachypnoea and tachycardia
column10: with a large component of anxiety. Blood pressure 113/77 mmHg. O2 Sat 100%. Cardiopulmonary auscultation without findings
column11: except tachycardia. No oedema in the lower limbs. During her stay in the ED
column12: she remained asymptomatic with no new episodes of tachycardia
column13: normalisation of the ST segment and a slight increase in TnI (0.019 to 0.14) with normal CPK. He was admitted to the ICU of a regional hospital for monitoring and treatment. During her stay in the ICU
column14: the patient remained asymptomatic and haemodynamically stable
column15: with no new episodes of tachycardia
column16: no changes in the electrocardiogram
column17: no clinical signs of heart failure and normalisation of TnI. An echocardiogram was performed with an LVEF of 55% with no alterations in contractility and mild mitral insufficiency. From there
column18: the case was discussed with the Arrhythmia Unit and an electrophysiological study was requested in which
column19: after isoproterenol perfusion
column20: regular tachycardia with wide QRS was induced
column21: compatible with ventricular tachycardia of basal and upper left ventricular origin. In view of SMVT in a patient with a family history of sudden death
column22: it was decided to admit him to our hospital ward to complete the study and assess treatment (pharmacological vs. ablation). Treatment was started with beta-blockers.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG (regional hospital emergency department): regular tachycardia with wide QRS (180 ms) with morphology of complete right bundle branch block (positive V1) and lower frontal plane axis
column23: concordant in precodials and atrioventricular dissociation compatible with ventricular tachycardia of basal anterolateral origin of the left ventricle. ECG (after TVMS): sinus rhythm at 65 bpm
column24: PR 220 ms (BAV 1st degree)
column25: normal axis (0o)
column26: narrow QRS
column27: ST descent 2 mm maximum in V4-V6 with negative T in II
column28: III and aVF. CBC (ED regional hospital): glucose 188 mg/dl
column29: urea 26 mg/dl
column30: creatinine 0.88 mg/dl
column31: Na 140 mEq/l
column33: Ca 8.4 mg7dl
column34: CRP <0.5 mg/dl
column35: NT proBNP 322 ng/l
column36: other biochemistry normal. Haemoglobin 13.8 g/dl
column37: haematocrit 41.1%
column38: leukocytes 10400 ui (neutrophils 67%
column39: lymphocytes 27%)
column40: platelets 385000 ui. Coagulation normal. Chest X-ray: normal CTI with no infiltrates or signs of pleural effusion. Echocardiography: non-dilated left ventricle with moderate to severe hypertrophy at septal level with preserved global LVEF (65%) with thinning and akinesia at lower basal segments and to a lesser extent inferolateral basal and posterior septal basal segments. Atria not dilated. Non-dilated right ventricle with preserved RVEF. Aortic root of normal dimensions. Normal mitral valve with trival mitral regurgitation jet. Trivalve aortic valve of normal morphology and jet of mild aortic insufficiency. Mild tricuspid regurgitation with normal PSAP. No pericardial effusion. Diastolic pattern compatible with type I relaxation disorder. Conclusion: aneurysm in the region of the basal inferior-septal
column41: basal inferior and basal lateral-inferior segments with preserved LVEF. Cardiac MRI: mild left ventricular dysfunction (LVEF 50%) with akinesia of basal inferior and inferolateral segments and late subendocardial enhancement at this level. Right ventricle of normal morphology and function. Coronary angiography: radial approach. Epicardial coronary arteries without lesions. Ventriculography shows a posterobasal aneurysm of the left ventricle and a small apical aneurysm. Preserved LVEF. Electrophysiological study: basal conduction intervals are normal. No ventricular pre-excitation or double nodal pathway. Pacing manoeuvres from CS and from the basal area of the RV do not induce tachycardia. Under isoproterenol perfusion (3 mcg/min)
column42: a tachycardia equal to the clinically documented tachycardia that meets the criteria of ventricular origin is spontaneously induced with ventricular extrasystoles. From the morphology of the complexes
column43: it originates in the basal and superior zone of the LV (mitroaortic continuity
column44: aortic semilunar
column45: superior zone of the mitral annulus). Tachycardia is induced on several occasions and is suppressed by ventricular overstimulation. Blood and urine cultures: negative. Serology: HBV
column46: HCV and HIV negative. Anti-Trypanosoma cruzi serology: positive.  EVOLUTION During her stay on the ward and while the TVMS study was being completed
column47: the patient presented rapid palpitations with general malaise and dizziness
column48: and the monitor showed a wide QRS tachycardia similar to the one described
column49: which spontaneously reverted to sinus rhythm. The patient was transferred to the coronary unit. After performing cardiac MRI and subsequent coronary angiography
column50: which ruled out ischaemic origin in the presence of structural heart disease in the echocardiography (posterobasal aneurysm and small apical aneurysm) with the patient's personal history
column51: everything led to suspect possible Chagas disease
column52: so serology for Trypanosoma cruzi was requested
column53: with positive results. A referral was made to the Infectious Diseases Unit

column60: it was decided to discharge her home to continue monitoring her at the ECCC. There was no impact on her outpatient evolution. column74: and a cardiac mass infiltrating the lung was observed during the procedure. On 30 October he returned to the ICU for respiratory failure due to increased left pleural effusion that required evacuating thoracentesis with an output of 1
column75: 000 cc. The biopsy reported thymoma
column76: however
column77: a sample was sent to another hospital to corroborate the diagnosis because the impression of the imaging tests (CT) and thoracic surgery was of a primary pericardial lesion/tumour with mediastinal bulging and because the diagnosis of T-type lymphoblastic lymphoma could not be definitively ruled out due to the anatomopathological data and the absence of visualisation of thymic masses (although ectopic thymomas have been described). The diagnosis of thymoma was confirmed. In view of this finding
column78: a myasthenia gravis study was requested by neurology
column79: which ruled it out. On 16 December
column80: surgery was performed to try to remove the tumour. This consisted of a median sternotomy and access to the anterior mediastinum
column81: which could only be exploratory as a large tumour mass was observed with infiltration of the right upper lobe
column82: junction to the cava and pericardium
column83: making dissection impossible. She was assessed by the oncology department and no curative treatment could be started. Given the poor clinical situation and the null possibility of curative treatment
column84: analgesia was intensified and the patient died. column2: current illness and physical examination A 43-year-old man
column3: with no previous history of interest
column4: who has been doing intense aerobic sports (athletics and paddle tennis) for about 7 hours a week since childhood
column5: was referred to the Cardiology department for the finding of isolated monomorphic ventricular extrasystoles (VE) on ECG performed during an examination at work. Physical examination was normal.  Complementary tests Echocardiogram
column6: chest X-ray and laboratory tests showed no abnormalities. There were no signs or symptoms of ischaemia in the exercise stress test
column7: but the density of ventricular extrasystoles increased slightly at maximum effort.  Clinical course Treatment was started with bisoprolol 5 mg per day and the Holter monitoring recorded disappearance of VE but nocturnal atrioventricular block (AVB) with several pauses
column8: the longest of 12 seconds. The patient remained asymptomatic at all times and denied any family history of conduction disorder
column9: dilated cardiomyopathy or sudden death. The Holter monitoring was interpreted as advanced AVB
column10: bisoprolol was discontinued and the patient was admitted for study and monitoring. Nocturnal pauses were recorded in relation to AVB and/or sinus bradycardia of up to 7 seconds and very occasional VS. Baseline conduction was found to be normal by electrophysiological study and sleep apnoea was ruled out by polysomnography. Given the poor clinical situation and the lack of curative treatment possibilities
column11: analgesia was intensified and the patient died.  Diagnosis In view of the absence of structural heart disease and relevant family history
column12: he was diagnosed with VAB mediated by vagal hypertonia and was advised to reduce his sporting activity
column13: but he refused. The risk-benefit balance of implanting a single-chamber pacemaker was explained to him and he refused. During follow-up he remained asymptomatic
column14: although Holter ECG monitoring showed that nocturnal pauses lasting up to 9 seconds persisted. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: current illness and physical examination Personal history: 54-year-old male. No known drug allergies. AHT with good control
column3: dyslipidaemic and active smoker 1.5 packs/day. Ex-drinker. Hyperuricaemia. Chronic bronchitis type COPD. Under cardiology follow-up for moderate double aortic lesion and mild pulmonary hypertension. Occupation: waiter.  Present illness: he came to the emergency department with progressive dyspnoea of one month's duration. Initial evaluation showed narrow QRS tachycardia at 144 bpm with irregular RR that reverted to sinus rhythm after administration of verapamil and amiodarone. During observation
column4: the patient presented haemodynamic deterioration
column5: with arterial hypotension
column6: poor perfusion
column7: profuse sweating and volumetric resuscitation was started
column8: a femoral line was cannulated and nor-adrenaline perfusion was started. A transthoracic echocardiogram was performed
column9: showing biventricular dilatation with severe dysfunction without segmental disorders
column10: moderate mitral insufficiency
column11: moderate double aortic lesion and moderate-severe tricuspid insufficiency. The patient was admitted to the ICU and cardiogenic shock persisted. Chest CT was requested and pulmonary thromboembolism was ruled out. The patient was monitored and cardiogenic shock pattern with IC 1.5 was observed
column12: so dobutamine
column13: noradrenaline and levosimendan were started and the haemodynamic situation recovered and improved progressively
column14: and could be withdrawn in 48 hours. During his stay in the ICU
column15: a new regulated transthoracic echocardiogram was performed
column16: showing an improvement in LVEF (50-55% subjective)
column17: moderate functional mitral regurgitation and double aortic lesion with severe aortic regurgitation. It was decided to perform a TEE and the existence of severe aortic insufficiency was confirmed
column18: with two jets
column19: one due to prolapse of the right coronary leaflet
column20: directed towards the anterior mitral leaflet and the other appears to be caused by a possible perforation of the base of the right coronary leaflet.  Physical examination: poor general condition. Skin coldness. Profuse sweating. Jugular ingurgitation. ACR: arrhythmic tones at 130 bpm. Systolic-diastolic murmur III/VI predominantly in aortic focus. MVC with crackles up to midfields in both lung fields.  Complementary tests CBC: glucose 97
column21: creatinine 0.65
column22: potassium 4.7
column23: GGT 44
column24: CT 145
column25: LDL 88. Hb 46.1. Htco 47. ʟʟ Blood cultures: negative. ECG: atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response at 130 bpm. Thoracic CT scan: a study was performed with intravenous contrast administration from the bases to the apex of the lungs. Adequate opacification of the pulmonary arterial tree bilaterally
column26: without identifying intravascular repletion defects suggestive of PTE. No evidence of mediastinal or axillary adenopathy of pathological size or other notable abnormalities in the mediastinum. Lung parenchyma was normal bilaterally
column27: without nodular images or alterations of the parenchymal architecture. Contrast reflux to the suprahepatic veins in the context of heart failure. High abdominal sections show perihepatic free fluid lengue and relative hypertrophy of the left hepatic lobe
column28: which may be secondary to chronic liver disease. Conclusion: PTE is ruled out. TT echocardiogram: moderately-severely dilated left ventricle
column29: with mild concentric hypertrophy and global systolic function at low limits of normality (monoplane Simpson LVEF 49%
column30: subjective 50-55%
column31: Teicholz 54%). LA dilated (34 cm2). RV neither dilated nor hypertrophic with preserved global systolic function. Dilated RA. Mitral valve with non thickened leaflets
column33: preserved opening
column34: appreciating MI directed towards the posterolateral wall of LA which appears to be moderately functional. There are no images suggestive of endocarditis at the mitral valve level. Tricuspid aortic valve
column35: fibrosclerosed
column36: with severe thickening of the right coronary leaflet
column37: which presents a hyperechogenic nodular image on which sits a less echodense and flapping image suggestive of endocarditis wart. Prolapse of the right coronary leaflet can be seen
column38: causing a very eccentric AoI
column39: which appears to be severe. The apical projection shows two regurgitation jets
column40: one directed towards the anterior mitral leaflet caused by the prolapse of the right coronary leaflet and the other directed towards the ventricular septum/cavity. Slightly restricted opening with mean AoTG of 22 mmHg
column41: AVAo per EC of 1.99 cm2. Mild TR allowing estimation of PSAP of 29 mmHg + PAD (dilated IVC with inspiratory collapse of approximately 50%). No pulmonary valvulopathy was observed. Normal ascending aorta. Septum intact. No pericardial effusion. Transesophageal echocardiogram: severe AoI was observed
column42: best visualised in the mid-oesophageal projection at 120o
column43: conditioned by the existence of 2 regurgitation jets that occupy almost all of the LVOT. One of them originates from prolapse of the right coronary leaflet
column44: directed towards the anterior mitral leaflet. The other appears to be caused by a possible perforation of the base of the right coronary leaflet. Grade III MR is seen
column45: conditioned by a scarce coaptation of mitral leaflets of functional origin
column46: reaching the atrial roof with a 6 mm vena contracta. There were no images suggestive of endocarditis on the mitral valve. The atrial appendage is free of thrombus. The rest is compatible with the TTE study. Conclusion: study suggestive of endocarditis on the aortic valve
column47: severe AoI
column48: mild AoE. Grade III MI. LVEF in low limits of normality.  Clinical evolution The patient was referred to the cardiac surgery unit and underwent successful surgery with implantation of mitral and aortic metallic prosthesis. The native mitral and aortic valves were removed and endocardial involvement by Coxiella burnetii was diagnosed. During follow-up
column49: the patient presented multiple falls in atrial flutter with 2 CVE and recurrence
column50: as well as severe ventricular dysfunction and multiple episodes of NSVT on Holter. He was referred to the arrhythmia unit and CTI ablation was performed and a CRT+ADI pacemaker was implanted
column51: with improvement in LVEF during follow-up
column52: and he is currently in GF I-II.  Diagnosis Cardiogenic shock in the context of tachycardiomyopathy due to rapid atrial fibrillation of uncertain onset and treatment with verapamil. Mitro-aortic endocarditis due to Coxiella burnetii. Implantation of metallic mitral and aortic prostheses. Successful CTI ablation. column2: current disease and physical examination A 25-year-old man came to the cardiology department after an episode of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response while exercising on the beach and was treated by pharmacological cardioversion with amiodarone in the emergency department. The patient had been experiencing episodes of palpitations related to intense exertion for a year. He had no functional class deterioration or other cardiovascular symptoms.  Personal history: In preparation for competitive firefighter training. Labelled episodes of anxiety with chest pain
column3: sensation of dyspnoea and acute elevation of blood pressure. No other cardiovascular risk factors or drug use. Mallory Weiss syndrome. ʟʟ No regular medication.   Family history: one brother had died of transposition of great vessels and ventricular septal defect
column4: another brother had died in utero due to interruption of the aortic arch and he had a cousin with pre-excitation syndrome.  Physical examination: conscious
column5: oriented
column6: normal colour
column7: eupneic. Normal phenotype. Blood pressure 218/110 mmHg in right upper limb
column8: 169/86 mmHg in left upper limb. Peripheral pulses present. Pulmonary auscultation with preserved vesicular murmur
column9: cardiac auscultation: ejective proto-mesosystolic murmur in aortic focus and left parasternal border grade II over LV also audible in interscapular focus. Abdomen and lower limbs without findings.  Complementary tests Electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm with normal cardiac axis. Presence of incomplete right bundle branch block and signs suggestive of left ventricular hypertrophy. Chest X-ray: no cardiomegaly
column10: absence of pleural effusion or pulmonary infiltrates. Rib indentations are seen. Transthoracic echocardiogram: mild septal hypertrophy
column11: mild mitral anterolateral leaflet prolapse with trivial mitral insufficiency. In the suprasternal window
column12: a flow acceleration and gradient of 86.6 mmHg in the descending thoracic aorta below the left subclavian outflow was noted. The rest of the study including left atrial dimensions and left ventricular diastolic function was normal. Thoracic-abdominal CT angiography: presence of aortic coarctation distal to the ostium of the left subclavian artery with a reduction of the aortic lumen to 0.6 cm in diameter
column13: with hypertrophy of the left intercostal arteries distal to the coarctation
column14: the left subclavian artery and the left mammary artery. Nuclear magnetic resonance angiography: saccular aneurysm adjacent to the bifurcation of the right middle cerebral artery. Normal karyotype
column15: absence of 22q11.2 selection.   Clinical course Given the findings compatible with coarctation of the descending aorta and the diagnosis of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation
column16: the patient was admitted to the cardiology ward to complete the study and decide on the therapeutic approach. Thoracic-abdominal CT angiography was performed
column17: which confirmed coarctation distal to the ostium of the left subclavian artery. Given the association of this aortic pathology with cerebrovascular malformations
column18: it was decided to perform a cerebral magnetic resonance angiography
column19: which revealed an aneurysm in the middle cerebral artery. In addition
column20: given the family history
column21: karyotyping was performed and a FISH hybridisation study of one of the deletions associated with this type of pathology was carried out
column22: both tests being normal. With the diagnoses described
column23: the case was presented at the clinical session
column24: and the decision was made to first operate on the cerebral aneurysm and then to surgically correct the coarctation of the aorta. The patient underwent successful surgery and is currently asymptomatic.   Diagnosis  Main Coarctation of aorta in descending thoracic AO Intracranial aneurysm in middle cerebral artery  Secondary Paroxysmal AF

column2: current illness and physical examination A 48-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension
column3: dyslipidaemia
column4: obesity and ex-smoker. After fumigating for approximately 3 continuous hours with organophosphates without any protection
column5: he suddenly presented with intense dyspnoea
column6: diaphoresis and intense oppressive central thoracic pain radiating to both upper limbs; his family described that he went home after the onset of the symptoms with twitching in the upper limbs
column7: trembling in both hands and inability to speak due to abundant salivation and bronchorrhoea. His family took him to the local hospital. On arrival he presented cardiorespiratory arrest in VF rhythm
column8: resuscitation manoeuvres were started
column9: and after 5 shocks the rhythm was reversed
column10: but the patient was still haemodynamically unstable with significant respiratory insufficiency
column11: so vasoactive support and orotracheal intubation were started. After 45 minutes of resuscitation manoeuvres
column12: ECG showed complete AV block with escape rhythm at 45 bpm and ST elevation in II-III-aVF
column13: from V3 to V6 and V3R-V4R
column14: and specular decrease in I-aVL-V1-V2. Fibrinolysis was decided as there was no Haemodynamics Unit at the centre and CORECAM (Castilla la Mancha Infarction Code) was activated. Despite NKT
column15: the patient persisted with ST elevation and was referred for rescue PTCA.  Physical examination: relaxed sedentary patient
column16: mechanically ventilated and requiring high doses of vasoactive drugs. BP 70/40
column17: HR 30 bpm
column18: RR 20
column19: afebrile
column20: SaO2 100% MV. Head and neck: miosis and abundant sialorrhoea. Cardiac auscultation: bradycardic
column21: rhythmic and regular. Lung fields with inspiratory and expiratory wheezing
column22: crackling rales in both bases and abundant mobilisation of secretions. Abdomen globular
column23: soft
column24: depressible
column25: not assessable. Extremities with fasciculations and generalised myoclonus.  Complementary tests CBC: leukocytes 22
column26: 300 with adequate differential count

column29: platelets 221

column62: QS in II-III-aVF
column63: transition from QRS V1 to V2 with high R in V2 and V3

column67: bronchorrhoea
column68: fasciculations

column70: signs (miosis

column77: hyperglycaemia
