column2: 31 years old
column3: construction worker. No known drug allergies
column4: ex-smoker of half a packet/day for 5 years
column5: not an excessive drinker
column6: not a consumer of other toxic substances. No significant personal or family history.  History
column7: current illness and physical examination Previously asymptomatic
column8: he presented with intense pain
column9: coldness and generalised pallor in the left hand of sudden onset (without previous trauma) while carrying out his daily tasks
column10: for which he consulted his health centre. As no radial or ulnar pulse was found
column11: the patient was referred to our hospital where he was assessed in the emergency department by Vascular Surgery
column12: which documented acute occlusion of the humeral artery
column13: which led to an urgent embolectomy without incident
column14: embolic material was sent for pathological anatomy and a cardiological assessment and echocardiography were requested. On physical examination the patient was in good general condition
column15: conscious
column16: oriented and cooperative. Well hydrated and perfused
column17: eupneic at rest and tolerating decubitus. Afebrile
column19: HR 70xmin
column20: normal cardiopulmonary auscultation
column21: no signs of heart failure. Embolectomy wound in MSI with no data of complication. The rest of the physical examination was completely normal. A transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) was performed at the bedside
column22: which revealed a mass in the lateral wall of the left atrium and the patient was admitted to Cardiology for further study.  Complementary tests - Analysis: Complete blood count
column23: coagulation and profiles with no noteworthy data. - Electrocardiogram: Sinus rhythm maintained
column24: no repolarisation alterations
column25: conduction disorders or findings suggestive of cavity growth. - Chest X-ray: Normal cardiac silhouette. Absence of congestive pattern
column26: no pleural effusion. No space-occupying images in lung parenchyma. - Echocardiography TT/TE + ECO 3D: Mass of 40x27 mm that occupies the entire left atrial appendage
column27: protrudes out of it towards the atrium
column28: has irregular edges with some areas of increased echogenicity suggesting fibrosis and on the atrial surface has filamentous and mobile extension of 12 mm with characteristics of high embolic risk. The left pulmonary veins are not invaded
column29: with normal flow. The ADA and ACX are seen in the AV groove below the atrial appendage
column30: without being invaded. Normal mitral valve
column31: aortic valve and right valves. Left ventricle of normal dimensions
column32: wall thickness and contractility. Normal right chambers. No pericardial effusion. - Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): Tissue formation in the left atrium that completely occupies the atrial appendage and extends into the atrial cavity as a vegetative mass with well-defined contours
column33: attached to the upper and lateral wall. It measures approximately 4cm in its maximum axis which is craniocaudal. In the four-chamber plane it measures approximately 34x27mm. Although it is adjacent to the pulmonary ostium
column34: these remain patent. It is not related to the mitral valve or the interatrial septum. It has homogeneous and intermediate signal intensity in all sequences. In the late enhancement sequences
column35: annular peripheral fine enhancement is found
column36: which can be observed in myxomas. No alterations in thickness and segmental and global contractility or alterations in tissue signal or late enhancement in myocardium. No cardiovascular anatomical alterations.  Clinical evolution During his stay on the hospital ward
column37: the patient remained asymptomatic and without incident. In the imaging tests mentioned above
column38: a differential diagnosis was made between atrial myxoma of atypical location vs. thrombus. In the pathological anatomy study of embolic material
column39: high-grade cellular atypia suggestive of malignant neoplasia was found. Cardiac surgery was consulted and the case was accepted for resection of the mass under extracorporeal circulation and the procedure was carried out without complications. The intraoperative pathological anatomy study confirmed high-grade dysplasia
column40: and the left atrial appendage was resected over its entire length
column41: achieving lesion-free margins. During his stay in the ICU he evolved favourably without incident and after stabilisation he was transferred to the cardiac surgery ward. The definitive pathological anatomy study of the resected mass was reported as undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma
column42: an extension study was performed with thoracoabdominal CT where no metastatic lesions were documented and it was decided to discharge him on anticoagulation and to carry out out outpatient follow-up with Oncology. Two weeks after surgery
column43: the patient was readmitted for clinical manifestations compatible with embolic stroke secondary to tandem occlusion of the left internal carotid artery and left middle cerebral artery. He was successfully treated by mechanical thrombectomy and the patient was left without residual neurological deficit; the pathological anatomy study of the embolic material confirmed its tumoural aetiology. He was subsequently admitted to Oncology
column44: and a repeat TTE and extension study (cranial MRI
column45: thoracoabdominal CT and bone scintigraphy) documented a recurrence of the mass in the left atrium with similar size and characteristics to those described in the pre-surgical study and the presence of brain
column46: lung
column47: liver
column48: adrenal and bone metastases. Chemotherapy with adriamycin was started. Despite chemotherapy treatment
column49: the patient had an unfavourable evolution and died three months after the initial diagnosis was made.    Diagnosis - Undifferentiated pleomorphic cardiac sarcoma with early recurrence after surgical resection. - Rapidly progressive multiple metastatic disease. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column1: Patient referred to Cardiology from Neurology for assessment.  History
column2: current illness and physical examination  Family history: Mother with plicate tongue without facial paralysis. Two brothers and two nephews with Steinert's syndrome. Two healthy children.  Current history: The patient presented with new electrocardiogram (ECG) abnormalities consisting of a PR of 280 milliseconds (msg)
column3: QRS of 150 msg
column4: with an image of complete left bundle branch block (LBBB). Electrocardiogram two years earlier with no conduction disturbances. He was assessed as an outpatient in the Cardiology Department

column6: presyncope
column7: palpitations or other symptoms.  Complementary tests - ECG on admission: Sinus rhythm at 75 bpm. PR 240-280 msg. QRS of 150 msg. column8: ions and renal function normal. No anaemia or leukopenia. Plateletopenia of 84
column9: 000 platelets mm3. - Transthoracic echocardiography: Left ventricle not dilated or hypertrophic. Left atrium not dilated. Mild tricuspid regurgitation directed medially with an atrioventricular gradient of 17 mmHg
column10: which allows estimating a pulmonary artery pressure of 30 mmHg. Trivial pulmonary insufficiency. Non-collapsed
column11: non-dilated vena cava. No pericardial effusion. - Chest X-ray: Cardiac silhouette at the limit of normality without alterations at the pulmonary parenchyma level. No pleural effusion. column1: A 63-year-old woman presented with a clinical picture of three months' evolution consisting of feverish peaks with shivering
column2: intense asthenia
column3: hyporexia and a weight loss of 7 kg. She had previously required dental manipulation (osseo-integrated implants).  History
column4: current illness and physical examination No medical history of interest
column5: no cardiovascular risk factors
column6: no toxic habits or surgical history
column7: no known drug allergies. Blood tests performed by the primary care physician showed normocytic anaemia and persistent leucocyturia and haematuria in urine
column8: so treatment was started with ferrous salts and two 10-day cycles of treatment with ciprofloxacin 400 mg/12h
column9: one month apart
column10: achieving improvement in general condition and disappearance of fever
column11: which reappeared 7 days after the end of the last cycle of treatment. He suddenly presented with motor aphasia
column12: left facial paralysis and loss of strength in the left upper limb; the neurological symptoms were fluctuating and recurrent
column13: with residual weakness persisting in the left upper limb
column14: and after visiting the emergency department he was admitted to the Neurology Department for examination. Physical examination on admission: BP 110/60 mmHg
column15: HR 90 bpm
column16: O2 sat 98% baseline. Conscious
column17: oriented
column18: reactive
column19: perceptive. No palpable lymphadenopathies. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart tones at 85 bpm
column20: pansystolic murmur of intensity III/VI at mitral focus
column21: radiating to the axilla. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur. Abdomen: soft
column22: depressible
column23: not painful on palpation
column24: no masses or megaliths palpable. Lower extremities: no oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis. Neurological examination in the emergency department revealed: very mild motor aphasia
column25: left central facial paralysis and paresis of the left upper limb with strength 4/5.  Complementary tests - Blood tests: Normal renal function with GRF MDRD-4 79.27 ml/min/1.73 m2
column26: normal ions. ESR up to 62 mm/hour. Maximum CRP of 4.65 mg/dl. Maximum procalcitonin 1.08 ng/ml. Normal liver function: FA 62U/l
column27: GGT 41U/l
column28: GOT 17 U/l
column29: GPT 20U/l
column30: LDH 222 U/l. Regarding the haemogram: Leukocytes 6600/μl with 64% neutrophils. Haemoglobin 10.1 g/dl
column31: MCV 91.80 fL
column33: 600 0/ mcl. - ECG: Sinus rhythm at 90 bpm
column34: normal PR
column35: normal QRS
column36: 60o axis
column37: without repolarisation alterations. - Chest X-ray: cardiomediastinal silhouette without alterations
column38: without pleuroparenchymal findings of acute evolution. - CT scan of the brain: No space-occupying lesions or midline displacements were observed. No acute ischaemic or haemorrhagic lesions. Cisternal and ventricular system without alterations. No significant radiological findings. - Thoracoabdominal CT scan: hepatosplenomegaly
column39: uterine myoma. Rest of the examination with no significant findings. - Transcranial Doppler and echo-Doppler of supra-aortic trunks: Normal
column40: no findings. - Lumbar puncture: Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) biochemistry: No alterations. CSF serology: Lúes
column41: Borrelia and Brucella negative. CSF microbiology: CSF Gram: no microorganisms were observed. DNA of herpes simplex virus and varicella zoster by PCR negative. - Serology of serum/plasma: No findings for lupus
column42: hepatitis B and C
column43: HIV
column44: cytomegalovirus
column45: varicella-zoster
column46: Epstein-Barr
column47: Borrelia burgdorferi. - Microbiology. Blood cultures: Gram-positive coccobacilli in chains (in 2 of 2 samples sent initially) with final isolation of Abiotrophia defectiva
column48: of intermediate sensitivity to penicillin (MIC 0.25)
column49: sensitive to the rest of antibiotics tested. Urine culture: Negative. - Transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiography: Left ventricle not dilated
column50: hyperdynamic
column51: LVEF 80%. Left atrium not dilated. Mitral valve: Prolapse of the P1 festoon of the posterior leaflet. Image of 8x6 mm in the cusp of festoon A1 of the anterior leaflet
column52: with anarchic movement
column53: echolucent areas inside
column54: suggestive of endocardial vegetation. Severe mitral insufficiency towards the septum and anterior wall that reverses the flow in pulmonary veins. Restrictive filling pattern with elevated end-diastolic pressure data. Normal aortic valve and flow. Aortic root of normal size. Normal right chambers
column55: no IT detected that would allow estimation of PAP. No pericardial effusion.  Clinical evolution Given the echocardiographic findings of endocarditis on the mitral valve (with prolapse of the P1 festoon of the posterior leaflet and vegetation on the cusp of the A1 festoon of the anterior leaflet) with severe mitral insufficiency with haemodynamic repercussions
column56: and data suggestive of acute severe valvular regurgitation (absence of dilatation of left chambers) with a picture of probable peripheral embolism at cerebral level (with normal neurological tests)
column57: it was decided to transfer him to the Coronary Unit for initial evolutionary control: During five days in the unit
column58: the patient remained haemodynamically stable
column59: without requiring vasoactive drugs
column60: remaining normotensive and in sinus rhythm at 90-100 bpm. Renal function was preserved
column61: with good diuretic response at low doses and no clinical or radiological signs of heart failure. From the neurological point of view: Glasgow 15
column62: persistence of central left facial paresis and with improvement of strength and sensitivity of the left upper extremity until normalisation. She was subsequently transferred to the cardiology ward for follow-up. From the beginning
column63: the patient was followed up by the Infectious Diseases Unit: Initially
column64: given the clinical suspicion of endocarditis of three months' evolution and the findings in blood cultures of gram-positive coccobacilli in chains (suspected streptococcus)
column65: empirical antibiotherapy was started with ceftriaxone (2 g iv/24 hours) associated with gentamicin (3 mg/kg/day iv/24 hours) and vancomycin (30 mg/kg/day iv in 2 doses/24h)
column66: achieving rapid disappearance of fever. Once the germ was identified in blood cultures as abiotrophia defectiva
column67: after 10 days of empirical treatment
column68: it was decided to modify antiobiotherapy to ampicillin (2g/4h) + ceftriaxone (2 g/12h)
column69: which had to be suspended after an urticarial reaction secondary to its administration. The new antibiotic regimen consisted of vancomycin + gentamicin
column70: with negative fever and blood cultures
column71: and a total of six weeks of antibiotic therapy was recommended. After two weeks of antibiotic treatment
column72: a new transesophageal echocardiogram was performed
column73: with findings similar to the initial one: persistence of severe mitral insufficiency
column74: prolapse of the P1 festoon and an image suggestive of endocarditis over the A1 festoon. Four weeks after the start of antibiotic therapy
column75: scheduled surgery was performed to replace the mitral valve with a St Jude No 29 mechanical prosthesis
column76: without preservation of the posterior subvalvular apparatus. The entire procedure was uneventful. Good postoperative evolution in the ICU and on the Cardiac Surgery ward without arrhythmias
column77: with early withdrawal of inotropes and mechanical ventilation
column78: normal renal function and absence of fever. In agreement with the Infectious Diseases Unit
column79: it was decided to discontinue antibiotic treatment 6 weeks after its initiation
column80: after confirming negative microbiology in the heart valve sample
column81: with control blood cultures after 48 hours (which were negative) and subsequent follow-up in the Outpatient Department. Prior to discharge
column82: a transthoracic echocardiogram was performed
column83: showing normal mitral prosthetic function and no images suggestive of endocarditis. Asymptomatic and stable
column84: she was discharged from hospital. She was followed up in outpatient clinics without incident.  Diagnosis - Infective endocarditis on native mitral valve (with valvular prolapse of the p1 leaflet of the posterior leaflet and endocardial vegetation in the a1 leaflet of the anterior leaflet) with column9: palpitations or syncope. Physical examination: Conscious
column10: oriented

column13: good opening and two jets of moderate central regurgitation. Pulmonary valve without alterations. Severely dilated trunk and main pulmonary branches justified by pulmonary hypertension  Clinical evolution The patient was assessed at the Cardiology Department

column1: We present the case of a 41-year-old patient who was referred to the clinic on the same day for assessment of a pathological ECG
column2: which had been performed as part of the preoperative work-up for surgery on his right shoulder
column3: where he was suffering from chronic pain.  History
column4: current illness and physical examination He did not suffer from any illness
column5: except for pain in his back and right shoulder for which he took painkillers sporadically. He practised sport regularly and was in very good physical condition
column6: although he reported greater fatigue in recent months. The patient showed an obvious absence of several phalanges in his left hand which was attributed
column7: in the country of his birth (he was the son of seasonal agricultural workers)
column8: to possible maternal exposure to thalidomide. He also had other musculoskeletal anomalies
column9: and claimed to have other relatives with some minor upper limb defects. Physical examination revealed pectus excavatum and other musculoskeletal abnormalities in the upper and lower extremities. On cardiac auscultation
column10: there was a rhythmic heartbeat at 35 bpm
column11: and a systolic murmur with fixed splitting of the second sound. No signs of heart failure. BP 100/60. The ECG showed the presence of complete AV block. Transthoracic echocardiography was performed and it was decided to place a definitive bicameral pacemaker and continue the patient's study.  Complementary tests - Transthoracic echocardiography: It had shown dilatation of the right chambers
column12: mild tricuspid insufficiency with a PAP of 50 mmHg and preserved ventricular function. Due to pectus excavatum
column13: it was not possible to correctly visualise the atrial septum. - Chest CT angiography: showed dilatation of the right chambers and the pulmonary cone. - Transesophageal echocardiography: it was possible to verify the existence of a 21mm ostium secundum type atrial septal defect
column14: with left-right shunt. - Traumatologic study: It reported the presence of pectus excavatum
column15: glenohumeral subluxation in the right shoulder
column16: patellar subluxation of the right knee
column17: agenesis of several phalanges of the fingers of the left hand
column18: radioulnar synostosis in the left elbow
column19: pes cavus and agenesis of the distal phalanx of the first toe of the right foot.  Clinical course Given the combination of musculoskeletal defects
column20: complete AV block and ASD ostium secundum
column21: a genetic study was requested. The family tree showed several cases of musculoskeletal defects and even some cases of sudden death. Genetic testing revealed a mutation (c.100-101insG) in the TBX5 gene
column22: and a diagnosis of Holt Oram syndrome was made. Finally
column23: the patient underwent surgery and the interatrial defect was closed using an autologous pericardial patch
column24: without postoperative complications. To date
column25: he remains asymptomatic cardiovascular.  Diagnosis Holt Oram syndrome: Various musculoskeletal alterations
column26: Ostium Secundum atrial septal defect and complete atrioventricular block. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 65-year-old patient with a history of liver transplantation and cirrhosis due to hepatitis B virus (HBV)
column2: who came to the emergency department with swelling
column3: oedema and pain in the right lower extremity. Background
column4: current disease and physical examination We present the case of a 65-year-old patient with a history of liver transplantation with cirrhosis due to hepatitis B virus (HBV) the previous year
column5: smoking and no other cardiovascular risk factors who attended the emergency department for swelling
column6: oedema and pain in the right lower limb twin region. A Doppler ultrasound was performed and a diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) was made. The patient was discharged with anticoagulant treatment (subcutaneous enoxaparin). The patient returned to the emergency department 2 hours after discharge with symptoms of motor aphasia and right hemiparesis suggestive of right middle cerebral artery stroke.  Complementary tests - Cerebral CAT scan: Normal. - ECG: Subepicardial lesion of 4-5 mm in inferior face with specular image in high lateral face and decrease of ST in V1-V2 of up to 4 mm compatible with posterior lesion - Transthoracic echocardiogram: non-dilated LV
column7: preserved LVEF
column8: severe infero-posterior hypokinesia and we observed a redundant interatrial septum with image in right atrium compatible with persistence of Chiari network. - Urgent catheterisation: Right coronary occluded medially with an image suggestive of an abundant thrombotic component
column9: mechanical thrombectomy was performed with a catheter
column10: extracting several red thrombi with subsequent normalisation of flow (TIMI 3) without finding a residual lesion
column11: so coronary embolism was suspected as the cause of the occlusion of the right coronary
column12: no stent was placed. The left coronary artery was normal.  Clinical Evolution Once the catheterisation was performed
column13: the patient was transferred to the Coronary Unit where he remained for two days with satisfactory evolution from the cardiological and neurological point of view. Subsequently
column14: given the suspicion of paradoxical embolism (finding of an infero-posterior acute myocardial infarction (AMI) accompanied by a stroke in a patient with a history of recent DVT)
column15: a transthoracic echocardiogram was repeated with injection of agitated saline without observing a clear left right shunt. Given the high level of suspicion
column16: we decided to perform a TEE which confirmed the presence of a patent foramen ovale. A CT body scan was also performed to rule out a neoplastic process as the cause of the prothrombotic state
column17: which showed images compatible with hepatic
column18: splenic and renal embolisms. The hypercoagulability study was normal. The patient was discharged on oral anticoagulant treatment and remained asymptomatic to date.  Diagnosis Multiple embolism (probably paradoxical) in a patient with patent foramen ovale. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 70-year-old male. History of pulmonary tuberculosis with residual left fibrothorax
column2: several episodes of severe haemoptysis years earlier. Pulmonary auscultation showed generalised hypophonesis
column3: greater in the left hemithorax and scattered rhonchi. No oedema.  History
column4: current illness and physical examination 70-year-old male. CVRF: Ex-smoker of 50 packs per year
column5: hypercholesterolemia. Mild COPD. Ischaemic stroke in 2011. Paroxysmal AF not anticoagulated due to risk of bleeding. History of pulmonary tuberculosis 30 years ago
column6: with residual left fibrothorax. Several episodes of severe haemoptysis years ago
column7: some with haemodynamic instability that required admission to the ICU. During one of them
column8: during a thoracic CT scan
column9: two heterotopic bronchial arteries were observed
column10: originating in the left subclavian artery and draining into multiple tortuous vessels associated with an area of saccular bronchiectasis located in the left lower pulmonary lobe. Embolisation was then performed using microcoils and embo-spheres of these aberrant arteries
column11: despite which episodes of haemoptysis persisted
column12: so pulmonary lobectomy was decided as the best therapeutic option for the patient.  Physical examination: BP 140/75
column13: PVY normal. Cardiac auscultation rhythmic
column14: without murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation showed generalised hypophonesis
column15: greater in the left hemithorax and scattered rhonchi. No oedema.  Complementary tests Prior to surgery
column16: a transthoracic echocardiogram was performed
column17: which showed a left ventricle of normal size and function
column18: a slightly dilated right ventricle with good function
column19: mild biauricular dilatation
column20: mild MR and mild TR with moderate-severe pulmonary hypertension. A haemodynamic study and coronary angiography were requested to our hospital for surgical evaluation of the patient. Cardiac catheterisation showed moderate pulmonary hypertension with normal PCP
column21: but coronary angiography revealed a large coronary-bronchial fistula originating in the circumflex artery and draining into multiple tortuous vessels located in the left lower pulmonary lobe.  Clinical course With the diagnostic suspicion that the coronary-bronchial fistula could be the cause of the patient's current episodes of haemoptysis
column22: it was successfully embolised using a 6F AL 2 guide catheter (Cordis LBT
column23: NJ
column24: USA) and an angioplasty guide (Runthrough Hipercoat
column25: Terumo Europe
column26: Netherlands) to introduce a microcatheter (Progreat
column27: Terumo Europe
column28: Netherlands) to the most distal area of the fistula and finally release three microcoils (Cook Medical) sequentially
column29: until angiographically demonstrating flow abolition. Surgery was postponed until clinical evolution was observed. One year after the procedure the patient remains asymptomatic
column30: with no new episodes of haemoptysis.  Diagnosis Recurrent haemoptysis secondary to large coronary-bronchial fistula. Successful percutaneous embolisation. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: with a history of hypertension and dyslipidaemia
column3: with aortic prosthesis and pacemaker
column4: who attended the Emergency Department for a sudden onset of right hemiparesis
column5: dysphasia
column6: disorientation
column7: headache and vomiting.  History
column8: current illness and physical examination Personal history: 67-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension and dyslipidaemia; aortic prosthesis holder since 2004 and a normal functioning VDD pacemaker
column9: with replacement 3 months ago.  Present illness: The patient consulted the Emergency Department for a sudden onset of right hemiparesis
column10: dysphasia
column11: disorientation
column12: headache and vomiting. He refers to a history of influenza with fever measured by thermometry during the last few days.  Physical examination: On arrival at the ED
column13: the patient was haemodynamically stable with blood pressure of 101/63 mmHg
column14: heart rate of 77 bpm and oxygen saturation of 94% at baseline. On physical examination the patient was vigilant and alert without ophthalmoparesis or campimetric alteration due to threat. He had global dysphasia
column15: slight deviation of the labial commissure to the left and right brachial hemiparesis 1/5
column16: crural hemiparesis 4/5 with right extensor plantar cutaneous reflex. Cardiopulmonary auscultation revealed periprosthetic aortic sounds with mitral murmur III/VI and scattered rhonchi in both lung fields. Given the diagnosis of ischaemic stroke in the left MCA territory of non-filial origin
column17: a stroke code was ruled out as it exceeded the window period and admission was decided for aetiological study and treatment.  Complementary tests Given the clinical symptoms suggestive of cerebral ischaemia
column18: during his stay in the Emergency Department
column19: a cranial CT scan was requested
column20: showing hypodensity in the left basal ganglia in relation to an acute ischaemic lesion in the middle cerebral artery territory. The study in this department was completed with an ECG
column21: the reading of which revealed a VDD pacemaker rhythm at 77 bpm; a basic blood test including haemogram and coagulation with Hb 11.9 g/dl
column22: leukocytes 18
column24: INR 5.7
column25: FD 610 mg/dl
column26: troponin I 894 pg/ml
column27: CRP 157 mg/L; and a chest X-ray showing cardiomegaly
column28: with no images of condensation or pleural effusion. Blood cultures were also taken. On admission to the ward
column29: in view of the laboratory findings described and the history of febrile syndrome and recent pacemaker replacement
column30: it was decided to perform urgent transthoracic echocardiography to rule out endocarditis as the aetiological focus of the cerebral infarction. The echocardiogram showed dilatation of the left atrium with preserved FEV1 without alterations in contractility and normal mitral valve. There was a dysfunctional aortic prosthesis with high gradients (peak gradient 60 mmHg
column31: mean 35 mmHg). The peak gradient in the previous control was 30 mmHg. There is an image compatible with endocardial vegetation in its posterior disc
column33: pedunculated and sessile. Moderate pulmonary hypertension and mild tricuspid insufficiency
column34: which had already been reported in previous studies
column35: were described. The echocardiographic finding was confirmed within 24 hours by transesophageal echocardiography
column36: which showed a large vegetation of about 20 mm in the outflow tract and a large periaortic abscess open to the bloodstream extending to the interatrial septum. The appearance of the mitral valve and left ventricular function are normal. At that time
column37: preliminary blood culture results were received showing growth of Gram-positive cocci in clusters. The definitive result was S. epidermidis.  Clinical course This is a 67-year-old patient with AHT
column38: DM
column39: aortic prosthesis and VDD pacemaker who was admitted for an abrupt onset of language disorder and right hemiparesis related to ischemic stroke in CMI territory
column40: with an INR on admission of 5.7. On admission
column41: given the presence of leukocytosis and elevated CRP supporting the suspicion of endocarditis
column42: an emergency transthoracic echocardiogram was performed which showed endocardial vegetation on the aortic valve
column43: and antibiotic treatment was started with vancomycin
column44: gentamincin and rifampicin after extraction of blood cultures. The patient had undergone a pacemaker replacement three months ago and for the last week had been experiencing general malaise
column45: profuse sweating with fever peaks of up to 39oC
column46: which he related to a case of influenza. A transesophageal echocardiogram was completed
column47: confirming vegetation and open periaortic abscess
column48: and the Cardiac Surgery Department of the referral hospital (H. Clínico Universitario de Valladolid) was contacted for transfer. During his stay in our hospital
column49: the neurological evolution was slightly favourable with improvement of the right brachio-crural motor deficit 4/5
column50: with persistent central facial
column51: hemianopsia due to threat and global dysphasia. There were no signs of heart failure or arrhythmias.  Diagnosis Given the findings described above
column52: the final diagnosis was late prosthetic endocarditis due to Staphylococcus epid. complicated with ischaemic stroke and periaortic abscess. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: who attended his point of continuous care in the early hours of the morning due to vomiting and agitation
column3: accompanied by pain in the left rib cage with coughing since the middle of the night.  History
column4: current illness and physical examination Personal history: Male
column5: 26 years old. Allergy to penicillin. Previous history of drug intoxication. Usual treatment: No. Present illness: This is a 26-year-old male
column6: who came to his point of continuous care in the early hours of the morning with vomiting and agitation
column7: accompanied by pain in the left rib cage with cough since the middle of the night (4-5 am). Given the patient's condition
column8: it was decided to transfer him to his regional referral hospital. He denied the use of toxic substances and cocaine. Physical examination: BP 92/62 mmHg HR 71 bpm. Conscious
column9: agitated
column10: anxiety
column11: pallor
column12: sweating. Signs of poor peripheral perfusion. Cardiac auscultation showed no murmurs or evidence of heart failure.  Complementary tests - CBC: Haemogram: Leukocytes: 27
column14: Hb 17.3 g/dl
column16: platelets 400
column17: 000 /ml. Basic biochemistry: Glucose 187 mg/dl; urea 30 mg/dl; creatinine 1.2 mg/dl; Na 143 meq/l
column18: K 3.7 meq/l. Myocardial damage markers: TpI 0.03. Coagulation: PT 99; aPTT 23.3. - Urine toxicity: cocaine
column19: benzodiazepines and cannabinoid products. - Chest X-ray: No acute pleuropulmonary pathology. - Initial electrocardiogram: Sinus rhythm 60 bpm. ST-segment elevation > 2 mm in the anterolateral side. - Electrocardiogram 2: Sinus rhythm 80 bpm. In view of the clinical findings (chest pain
column20: signs of poor peripheral perfusion; preshock K status) and electrocardiographic findings (AMI with ST-segment elevation) and given that the patient was in a regional hospital with no possibility of early access to a centre with primary angioplasty
column21: it was decided to perform thrombolysis with 8000 IU of metalyse. However
column22: after thirty minutes there were no clinical or electrocardiographic criteria for reperfusion
column23: so it was decided to transfer the patient to a reference centre for primary PTCA. At the start of the transfer
column24: the patient presented good saturation and data of capillary hypoperfusion with a capillary refill time > 2 seconds. During the transfer he presented episodes of supraventricular tachycardia and slow ventricular tachycardia. After 20 minutes he presented with pulseless electrical activity (PEA) and advanced CPR manoeuvres were initiated. After 30 minutes
column25: asystole was observed and advanced CPR manoeuvres were continued. He arrived at the haemodynamics room of our centre in asystole
column26: an urgent echocardiogram was performed which showed no evidence of cardiac rupture and after 50 minutes of unsuccessful advanced CPR
column27: the patient died.  Diagnosis - Acute myocardial infarction with ST-segment elevation due to cocaine use. - Exitus. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: current illness and physical examination A 12-year-old boy was admitted to the PICU after being transferred by ambulance for cardio-respiratory arrest at home. He presented with a 12-hour history of odynophagia with a fever of 38°C maximum. After administering antipyretic medication
column3: the mother reported noticing pathological respiratory sounds and loss of consciousness
column4: so she called 112. On arrival of the basic support ambulance
column5: an ICD was connected
column6: confirming ventricular fibrillation
column7: and defibrillation and cardiopulmonary resuscitation were performed
column8: achieving an organised rhythm with a pulse after 4 minutes (after two shocks of 360 J). The medicalised ambulance arrived home
column9: and the patient was intubated

column31: maintaining a core temperature of 33-34°C for 48 hours. column1: A 17-year-old federated sportsman who consulted the Emergency Department on up to six occasions for episodes of fainting
column2: leading to loss of consciousness in the middle of a sporting competition
column3: over the last two months.  History
column4: current illness and physical examination Personal history: 17-year-old male. Federated sportsman. No known drug allergies. No cardiovascular risk factors. No toxic habits. No personal or family history of heart disease. Present illness: A 17-year-old federated sportsman who consulted the Emergency Department on up to 6 occasions for episodes of fainting
column5: leading to loss of consciousness in the middle of a sporting competition
column6: over the last two months. Given the presence of repeated syncopes related to exercise
column7: the patient was admitted to Cardiology for screening for a cardiac cause. He also reported other episodes of dizziness and syncope with a vaso-vagal profile (syncope preceded by abdominal discomfort
column8: nausea and dizziness lasting seconds). As additional symptoms
column9: she reported occasional headache that increased with coughing and exertion. She did not report dyspnoea
column10: chest pain or palpitations. Given the normality of the initial complementary tests performed (ECG
column11: chest X-ray
column12: echocardiogram
column13: ECG monitoring and ergometry)
column14: the patient was discharged with the diagnosis of syncope of probable neuromediated origin
column15: and it was recommended that the maximum heart rate should not be exceeded during physical exertion. Two weeks later
column16: he was admitted again after presenting three syncopal episodes
column17: one of them just after performing an exercise stress test
column18: where he reached 197 bpm. It is reported that at the end of the test
column19: once the recovery period was over and the ECG electrodes had been disconnected
column20: he presented syncope with very severe hypotension and without giving time for electrocardiographic monitoring. The second episode occurred after playing a football match preceded by abdominal discomfort
column21: and finally the third episode occurred after a shower
column22: taking about 4 minutes to recover
column23: according to the family. To complete the study
column24: a cardiac MRI was performed to rule out arrhythmogenic dysplasia
column25: a flecainide test to simulate a Brugada type II ECG pattern
column26: a tilt table test and a neurological study given the prolonged duration of the last episode. The cardiac MRI was reported as normal
column27: as well as the flecainide test and the electroencephalogram.  Neurology was consulted and a cranial MRI was requested
column28: which gave the diagnosis as the cerebellar tonsils were found to be descended with rectification of the floor of the fourth ventricle. The patient was discharged with the diagnosis of Chiari malformation type I.  Physical examination: BP 90/50. HR 60lpm. Conscious and oriented. Normohydrated and normoperfused. Eupneic at rest. ACR: rhythmic tones without audible murmurs. VCM without superimposed noises. Abdomen: soft
column29: depressible
column30: without masses or megaliths. Not painful on palpation. Lower extremities with preserved and symmetrical pulses.  Complementary tests - Complementary examination. - ECG: Sinus rhythm at 75 bpm and incomplete right bundle branch block with J point elevation in right precordial leads and normal QTc interval. - Chest X-ray: Cardiothoracic index within normal limits. No congestive signs. - Echocardiogram: Left ventricle not dilated or hypertrophic
column31: with global and segmental systolic function within normal limits. Left atrium not dilated. Normal right chambers. Normal left ventricular filling pattern. No valvular or pericardial abnormalities. Normal aortic root and ascending aorta. Atrial septum and interventricular septum intact. No gradient in descending aorta. - Ergometry: Stopped due to twin contracture
column32: at 78% of submaximal heart rate. No clinical or electrical events of interest were observed. - Flecainide test: Stopped after 7 minutes of infusion (2/3 dose of the drug) as the patient felt dizziness and without any electrocardiographic alteration suspicious of Brugada syndrome. - Cardiac MRI: non-dilated right ventricle
column33: with a free wall of normal thickness
column34: without irregularities or images of pseudoaneurysm. There was no fatty infiltration of the wall. There was no RV dysfunction
column35: with volumes and EF within normal limits. - Electroencephalogram: baseline cerebral bioelectrical activity was normal. No focal or generalised paroxysmal abnormalities were observed. - Cerebral MRI: Cerebellar tonsil descent with rectification of the floor of the fourth ventricle. No signs of hydrocephalus or intracerebral lesions were observed. The diagnosis of Arnold-Chiari is confirmed.  Clinical evolution The patient was referred to neurosurgery and underwent a suboccipital craniectomy and laminectomy of C1. The patient has progressively resumed sporting activity without new syncopal episodes. column1: Clinical history and current disease 53-year-old patient with a history of dyspnoea on exertion of 6-12 months of evolution
column2: poor window in previous echocardiogram. She came for a new echocardiogram after losing weight due to diet. No chest pain or syncope. HIGH BLOOD PRESSURE. Metrorrhagia with uterine curettage in 2004. She was assessed in the Internal Medicine outpatient department in 2004 for severe anaemia secondary to the above
column3: and a colonoscopy was also performed for rectorrhagia with the finding of internal haemorrhoids. Chronic HBsAg carrier followed up in Preventive Medicine. Admitted in 2009 for pneumonia. Previous medication: ibuprofen 600 mg
column4: spironolactone 25/hydrochlorothiazide 15 mg
column5: metoprolol 50 mg
column6: ramipril 5 mg.  Additional tests - CBC: white blood cells 6

column22: glomerular filtration rate EPI 71. - Electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm at 53 bpm with no other alterations of interest. No changes suggestive of ischaemia
column23: cavity enlargement (perhaps LA enlargement) or conduction disturbances. - Chest X-ray: mild cardiomegaly with no radiological signs of heart failure. - Echocardiogram: LV not dilated or hypertrophic. Preserved systolic function. Mild aortic insufficiency with no gradient across it. Large mass (58x42 mm) in the left atrium with no visible pedicle or Doppler flow inside it
column24: which protrudes minimally into the left ventricle
column25: causing mild mitral insufficiency and moderate mitral obstruction flow. Mild TR with estimated PSP of 60-65.  Clinical evolution In view of the echocardiogram findings
column26: the patient was transferred to the referral hospital where the evaluation was completed with coronary angiography showing coronary arteries with right dominance and no significant angiographic lesions and cardiac magnetic resonance imaging showing a mass in the left atrium (62x46x40 mm) with a pedicle originating in the interatrial septum
column27: the signal was intermediate in T1-weighted sequences
column28: hyperintense in T2-weighted sequences and with central enhancement in the late phases of the dynamic study with gadolinium compatible with myxoma that prolapses through the mitral annulus during diastole. It was decided to perform elective surgery by transseptal access
column29: myxoma implant was found in the septum-ceptum of the left atrium and complete resection of myxoma was performed
column30: closing the septum with an autologous pericardium patch. During the postoperative period

column1: Clinical history and current illness A 73-year-old man was admitted to the Infectious Diseases Department for a new febrile syndrome of 4 days' duration
column2: with no clear focal symptoms and a physical examination with no significant findings. No known drug allergies. Ex-smoker. High blood pressure under pharmacological treatment. column3: lisinopril/HCTZ
column4: clopidogrel
column5: ranitidine
column6: haemovas. ECG on admission: sinus rhythm at 45 bpm
column7: PR 260 msec
column8: HBAI
column9: BCRDHH
column10: negative T waves in III and aVF. Chest X-ray on admission: no alterations. Blood cultures were taken from the emergency department

column12: after infusion of a dose of augmentin iv
column13: the patient reported intense itching all over the body with the appearance of exanthematous skin lesions
column14: arterial hypotension

column16: aVL and V1-V4. Treatment was started with iv corticoids + iv polaramine + serotherapy
column17: which improved the AT and the allergic symptoms. Following this clinical improvement
column18: the ECG was repeated and the aforementioned alterations disappeared
column19: returning to an ECG similar to that on admission. Given the ECG alterations and the presence of chest pain
column20: the patient was transferred to the Cardiology Department. column21: without dysfunction. Mild TR with RV-AD gradient of 30 mmHg and estimated PSAP of 40 mmHg. No pericardial effusion.  Clinical evolution Once the allergic reaction was overcome
column22: the patient remained asymptomatic and did not present any further episodes of chest pain. Following the results of these complementary tests

column25: penicillin V

column45: accompanied by symptoms typical of ischaemia. In view of these findings
column46: it was decided to admit the patient for coronary angiography
column47: which showed coronary arteries with anatomical findings coinciding with those described in the CT scan. Selective injection of the LAD showed the existence of a unidirectional intercoronary communication from the distal LAD to a well-developed posterior interventricular artery (PVI)
column48: with no evidence of obstructive lesions that could justify the development of collateral circulation. During admission
column49: a hypercoagulability study was performed
column50: which was negative. The patient was discharged with beta-blocker treatment with a diagnosis of myocardial ischaemia secondary to unidirectional intercoronary communication between distal LAD and PVI with coronary steal phenomenon. At the one-year follow-up the patient remained asymptomatic. column1: Clinical history and current illness A 68-year-old man with hypertension
column2: operated in 1990 for aortic valve disease with mechanical prosthesis. Complete AV block in the immediate postoperative period requiring implantation of a transient ventricular epicardial pacemaker and epicardial lead in AD
column3: subsequently a permanent ventricular endocardial lead was implanted. The generator was replaced in 2008 and later the ventricular lead was replaced due to malfunction and a new endocardial system was implanted in July 2009. Since 2009
column4: the patient reported periodic skin erosions in the implantation area
column5: with serofibrinous exudate during the following two years
column6: and during the last six months he had episodes of shivering with a few tenths of fever
column7: especially at night
column8: which led him to consult his doctor on several occasions. He came to our centre feverish
column9: with a marked worsening in the last two weeks (39.8oC)
column10: affected but haemodynamically stable and with suppuration from the decubitus orifice of the pacemaker
column11: for which he was admitted.  Complementary tests - Physical examination: serofibrinous suppuration through the generator implantation area. - Laboratory tests: leukocytosis of 26
column13: Hb 11 g/dL
column14: CRP 63
column15: creatinine 0.90 mg/dL
column16: urea 35 mg/dL. - Chest X-ray: 3 electrodes are visualised
column17: two of them normoinserted attached to the implanted generator
column18: normoinserted and a dissected epicardial lead lodged in the right atrium. Condensation images are also seen in the right hemithorax. - Blood cultures: two batches taken 30 minutes apart from each other from two different sites and on different days with and without fever
column19: with growth of methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus epidermidis. - Culture of decubitus exudate: methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus epidermidis. - Transthoracic echocardiography: a vegetation of about 20 mm is visualised in the right atrial cable. Other echocardiographic parameters were normal. No prosthetic dysfunction. Mild tricuspid regurgitation.   Clinical evolution After admission
column20: the infection was treated comprehensively with parenteral bactericidal antibiotherapy directed at the germ isolated in the cultures and the removal of the entire system and a new implant on the right side once the patient remained afebrile and blood cultures were repeatedly negative
column21: after two weeks of antibiotic treatment.  Diagnosis Endocarditis due to infection of the pacemaker generator and leads without valvular involvement. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Medical history and current illness 46-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and dyslipidaemia. Followed up by cardiology in childhood for a pathology that the patient cannot specify
column2: with no subsequent follow-ups. She began with sudden symptoms of speech impairment and lower right facial paralysis. In the absence of contraindications and with a normal brain CT scan
column3: fibrinolytic treatment with alteplase was administered
column4: with a good initial neurological response. After 3 hours
column5: the patient presented a new clinical deterioration and a new brain CT scan was performed which showed a left frontoparietal haemorrhage with associated small subarachnoid haemorrhage. Physical examination on admission showed baseline O2 saturation 88%
column6: with signs of peripheral hypoperfusion with lip cyanosis. Cardiac auscultation showed rhythmic tones with audible systolic ejection murmur in all foci. Hypoventilation in the lower third of the left hemithorax on pulmonary auscultation. Neurological examination revealed aphasia of expression and right central facial paresis. During admission
column7: lip cyanosis persisted with low oxygen saturation and platypnoea-orthodeoxia syndrome. A transthoracic echocardiogram was performed showing tricuspid valve with atrial displacement and severe insufficiency compatible with Ebstein's disease. In addition
column8: an ostium secundum atrial septal defect (ASD-OS) was observed in the posterior septum with bidirectional shunt. Despite the finding of heart disease with a high risk of embolism in the echocardiogram
column9: it was decided to postpone the start of oral anticoagulation due to extensive cerebral bleeding.  Complementary tests - Laboratory tests: normal. - Arterial blood gases: compensated respiratory acidosis
column10: basal SatO2 77%. - Electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm at 85 bpm
column11: right bundle branch block. - Initial brain CT scan: normal. Post-fibrinolysis brain CT scan: left frontoparietal haematoma and associated small subarachnoid haemorrhage. - Transesophageal echocardiogram: tricuspid with septal leaflet displacement of 38 mm and severe insufficiency
column12: severe right atrial (RA) dilatation
column13: normal right ventricular (RV) contractility
column14: RV-RA gradient 20 mmHg. Celermajer index 1.21. Pulmonary flow and other valves normal. Atrial septal defect (ASD) ostium secundum in posterior septum 15 mm with bidirectional shunt
column15: absence of superoposterior border. - Chest X-ray: cardiomegaly at the expense of the right cavities. Right pleural effusion. - Thoracic CT angiography: right PTE with extensive pulmonary infarction in the lower lobe. - Echo-Doppler of lower limbs: normal.  Clinical evolution During admission
column16: good neurological evolution with complete recovery at the end of the stay. During her stay on the ward
column17: the patient presented increasingly severe episodes of oxygen desaturation
column18: reaching oxygen saturations of 67% at baseline
column19: which improved partially with oxygen therapy. The patient reported progressive dyspnoea until minimal exertion
column20: with limited ambulation in the corridor
column21: which improved in the supine position. Given the very low oxygen saturation figures
column22: which the patient had never presented previously
column23: concomitant pulmonary pathology was suspected. Thoracic CT angiography showed right pulmonary thromboembolism (PTE) with extensive pulmonary infarction in the lower lobe. At the time of diagnosis
column24: 10 days had passed since the cerebral bleeding. On finding the PTE
column25: treatment with acenocoumarol was started
column26: with clinical improvement and improvement in oxygen saturation figures. Since then
column27: good clinical evolution
column28: with no new brain bleeds or other embolic complications. Given the data of severe TR
column29: the wide OS-ASD
column30: the deterioration of functional class and the multiple embolism situation (stroke and PTE)
column31: tricuspid valve repair surgery and ASD closure were indicated and carried out without complications. The patient is currently in good functional class.  Diagnosis - Left frontoparietal stroke with haemorrhagic transformation - Cardioembolic PTE - Ebstein's anomaly and ASD ostium secundum with bidirectional shunt |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Clinical history and current illness A 72-year-old male smoker with no other history of interest came to the emergency department for abdominal pain
column2: fever and poor general condition. Physical examination revealed calorie and protein malnutrition (body mass index of 13)
column3: fever of 38oC and cardiopulmonary auscultation showed a globally decreased vesicular murmur and rhythmic heart sounds with a systolic murmur IV/VI in the peak
column4: radiating to the axilla.  Complementary tests A transthoracic echocardiogram showed cardiac cavities of normal size and contractility
column5: with a 2.5x1 cm mobile mass located in the left atrium and implanted in the fossa ovalis suggestive of atrial myxoma and a myxomatous mitral valve with prolapse of the posterior leaflet with significant insufficiency. With the diagnosis of atrial myxoma
column6: he was admitted to the Cardiology Department to complete the study. The blood test showed haemoglobin 9.3 g/dl
column8: 880 leukocytes/mm3 with 86.1% neutrophils and ESR 92 mm. Other parameters and coagulation values were within normal range. Biochemistry showed urea 40 mg/dl
column9: creatinine 1.05 mg/dl
column10: triglycerides 128 mg/dl
column11: total cholesterol 100 mg/dl
column12: HDL 13 mg/dl
column13: LDL 60 mg/dl
column14: total protein 5.4 g/dl
column15: albumin 2 g/dl. Urine sediment showed microscopic haematuria (1-5 red blood cells/field). Blood cultures were taken and were positive for Streptococcus agalactiae. Electrocardiogram showed sinus tachycardia at 120 beats per minute with normal repolarisation. In view of these findings
column16: transesophageal echocardiography showed a mobile
column17: pedunculated mass located in the left atrium
column18: implanted in the interatrial septum at the level of the fossa ovalis
column19: smooth in outline and with a small cystic area inside
column20: compatible with atrial myxoma. A mitral valve with prolapse of the P3 segment and 1 cm of vegetation on it was also observed; with severe mitral insufficiency and eccentric jet directed towards the interatrial septum and the myxoma area. Twenty-four hours after admission
column21: he presented transient paresis of the left upper limb
column22: and an urgent cranial computed tomography (CT) scan showed a right frontal lacunar stroke (semioval centre) without being able to determine the time of evolution; therefore
column23: an urgent brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) assessment was requested
column24: which confirmed the acute right frontal lacunar stroke (in the semioval centre) as well as acute right hemispheric ischaemic cortical lesions. The study of systemic embolisms was completed with thoracoabdominal CT
column25: highlighting the presence of an extensive cortical hypodense area in the upper pole of the right kidney measuring 6.5x4.6x3 cm and three focal lesions of similar characteristics smaller than 1 cm in the left kidney
column26: suggestive of bilateral renal infarcts. Catheterisation showed a normal coronary tree.  Clinical course Treatment and evolution: antibiotic treatment was started with ampicillin and gentamicin
column27: and in view of the patient's calorie and protein malnutrition
column28: the Nutrition and Rehabilitation Service was contacted for support and complementary treatment
column29: with good initial evolution. The transthoracic echocardiogram twelve days after admission showed a mass in the fossa ovalis with multiple hypoechogenic areas in its interior that seemed to have lost the area of greatest motility located at the apical level. Fifteen days after admission
column30: she presented new febrile peaks
column31: abdominal pain and congestive heart failure
column32: requiring depletive treatment and non-invasive mechanical ventilation. Once stable
column33: she was transferred to the Cardiac Surgery Department for surgical treatment
column34: and the atrial mass was resected by resection of the fossa ovalis through the right atrium and removal of the tumour and its implantation base through the left atrium. The mitral valve apparatus was completely resected and a St Jude porcine biological prosthesis (model Epic E100-29M) was implanted. The anatomopathological and infectious diagnosis by Polymerase Chain Reaction (universal PCR of the 16S rRNA gene) confirmed atrial myxoma and infectious involvement of the mitral valve by Streptococcus agalactiae and ruled out infection of the mitral valve tumour. Postoperatively
column35: the patient had a torpid evolution with gastrointestinal haemorrhage
column36: and was exsitus.    Diagnosis Atrial myxoma and endocarditis on mitral valve with constitutional syndrome and associated systemic embolisms. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Clinical history and present illness 43-year-old male admitted for non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (NSTEACS).  Personal history - Allergy to pollen and mites - Allergic rhinitis. Strinsic bronchial asthma with frequent flare-ups - Smoker - No known hypertension
column2: dyslipidaemia or DM - IQ: appendectomy and right ulnar-radius fracture  Usual treatment: seretide 50/500. Ventolin on demand. Omeprazole and occasional almax. Current illness: on 15/10/2011 she woke up in the early hours of the morning with oppressive chest pain radiating to the left arm. She went to the hospital emergency department 12 hours after the onset of the pain
column3: presenting ST-segment depression and elevated cardiac enzymes in the ECG. Physical examination: good general condition. A.T. 100/70. Eurnic. No IY. C.C.: rhythmic
column4: without murmurs or friction. A.P.: normal. Abdomen and EEII: no significant findings.  Complementary tests - ECG: sinus rhythm with slight ST-segment elevation in II
column5: V3 to V5
column6: without Q waves. - Laboratory tests: creatinine 1.14. Glucose 78
column7: urate 7.6. Cholesterol 182. HDL-C 30. TG 136. LDL-C 125. TnT ultrasensitive on admission 306
column8: TnT ultrasensitive peak 1
column10: ProBNP 105
column11: CPK 98. GOT 47. GPT 61. C-reactive protein 12.2. TSH 1.68. Haemogram with 12300 leucocytes. - Coronary angiography: angiographically normal coronary arteries. Preserved EF and no regional motility disorders. - Echocardiogram: left ventricle neither dilated nor hypertrophic
column12: with normal EF (60%). No alterations in segmental contractility were observed. E: 52
column14: TDE: 190. Anatomically and functionally normal valves. Non-dilated left atrium. Right chambers not dilated. TAPSE: 19 mm. Aortic root and ascending aorta of normal calibre. No pericardial effusion. - Cardiac MRI: multiple areas of patchy subepicardial and intramyocardial involvement affecting anterolateral
column15: lateral
column16: apical
column17: inferomedial face in left ventricle. Preserved systolic function.  Clinical course On admission the symptoms were interpreted as NSTEACS and treatment was started with double antiplatelet therapy
column18: LMWH
column19: nitrates and ACE inhibitors. Beta-blocker treatment was not started due to a history of asthma with frequent flare-ups. The clinical evolution was good
column20: with no recurrence of chest pain or signs of heart failure. There was no electrocardiographic evolution and no new Q waves appeared. However
column21: ultrasensitive TnT remained elevated after admission. Cardiac catheterisation was performed the day after admission
column22: showing angiographically normal coronary arteries and preserved global systolic function without segmental alterations of contractility in ventriculography or echocardiography. Cardiac MRI was performed showing late gadolinium enhancement typical of myocarditis.  Diagnosis - Acute myocarditis - Angiographically normal coronary arteries - Preserved left ventricular systolic function |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Clinical history and current illness 47-year-old male admitted to the Infectious Diseases Department for dyspnoea and febrile syndrome. No drug allergies. Ex-ADVP. Smoker. HIV C-3 infection on triple antiretroviral therapy until two months ago with good adherence to ART but not attending check-ups. Oesophageal candidiasis. Castlemann's disease diagnosed in 2006
column2: completing chemotherapy treatment with good evolution. Kaposi's sarcoma diagnosed in September 2007 with chemotherapy treatment. Bacteremic pneumonia due to Acinetobacter baumanii in September 2007. Chronic hepatopathy due to HCV without previous decompensation. Sporadic use of inhaled cocaine and cannabis
column3: no injecting drug use. A few months ago
column4: he reported a traffic accident with the death of two close relatives
column5: as a result of which he abandoned his usual treatment and started taking drugs (intravenous cocaine and smoked heroin). Treatment: methadone (25-0-25) and atripla. The patient was admitted to the Infectious Diseases Department for symptoms that started approximately 30 days ago
column6: which debuted as a cough with expectoration that was initially mucopurulent and later rusty. Chest pain that was exacerbated by coughing and inspiration
column7: partially relieved by trunk flexion. Progressive dyspnoea
column8: initially on exertion until becoming resting dyspnoea in the last ten days
column9: with orthopnoea and episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea. Dysthermic sensation with a maximum thermometric fever of 39oC. In view of the clinical manifestations
column10: the Cardiology Service was requested to assess the patient.  Complementary tests - Physical examination: BP 80/45mmHg
column11: HR 115 bpm
column12: satO2 95% baseline
column13: afebrile. Conscious and oriented. Cachectic
column14: with good peripheral perfusion. Tachypneic at rest. Multiple venipuncture sites. Jugular ingurgitation. Cardiac auscultation rhythmic and without murmurs. Conservative vesicular murmur. Soft and depressible abdomen
column15: large hepatomegaly
column16: oedema in the lower extremities and trophic skin lesions. - ECG: sinus tachycardia at 120 bpm
column17: axis at 90o
column18: narrow QRS without repolarisation alterations. - CBC: urea and Cr normal. Na 126
column19: K normal. Hb 10.3 g/dL
column20: leukocytes 16
column22: platelets 253
column24: INR 1.29
column25: APTT 34.7. - Chest X-ray: cardiomegaly
column26: condensation in the right pulmonary base. - Echocardiogram: normal LV with preserved global and segmental systolic function. RV not dilated and with preserved systolic function. No valvulopathies. No stigmata of endocarditis. Severe pericardial effusion
column27: enveloping
column28: about 5 cm with signs of tamponade.   Clinical course The echocardiogram showed severe pericardial effusion with signs of tamponade
column29: so evacuating pericardiocentesis was performed by subxiphoid access draining 1000 ml of purulent fluid. Gram staining of the fluid showed gram + cocci in chains
column30: and the culture was positive for Streptococcus pneumoniae. Blood cultures were negative and pneumococcal antigen positive in urine. Antibiotic treatment was started with ceftriaxone and levofloxacin. A control echocardiogram was performed
column31: showing that the pericardial effusion had practically resolved
column32: with a minimal amount of fluid remaining in the posterior sac. There were no signs of haemodynamic compromise (no cavitary collapse or respirophasic variations). In a situation of clinical stability
column33: the patient was discharged to the hospital ward for follow-up. Days later
column34: he presented a new clinical and haemodynamic worsening. He was tachycardic and tachypneic
column35: with a tendency to arterial hypotension. The echocardiogram showed severe pericardial effusion and a new evacuating pericardiocentesis was performed
column36: aspirating 250 ml of purulent liquid and leaving him connected to drainage with aspiration with a total debit of 1200 ml in 48 hours.
