column1: Medical history and current illness 51-year-old male. Cardiovascular risk factors: former smoking
column2: hypertension since 1998
column3: type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with oral antidiabetics. Anaplastic T-cell lymphoma in 2007 treated with chemotherapy
column4: radiotherapy and BEAM-conditioned autotransplantation
column5: currently in complete remission. Refractory myelodysplastic cytopenia syndrome with multilineage dysplasia and complex karyotype treated with azacitidine as a bridge to bone marrow transplant. Idiopathic thrombopenic purpura. No known allergies. Cardiological check-up in 2006 with normal ECG
column6: echocardiogram and stress test. He usually reports being asymptomatic cardiovascular. Patient presented to the Emergency Department for 3 days with fever of up to 38.3oC
column7: asthenia
column8: general malaise and general aches and pains. Also
column9: on the day of consultation
column10: he had started with oppressive retrosternal pain of increasing intensity
column11: radiating to the back
column12: shoulders and jaw
column13: which increased in intensity with deep inspiration and supine decubitus
column14: with accompanying malaise and dyspnoea and BP levels of 70/40 mmHg. Physical examination was normal
column15: except for hypoventilation in both lung bases.  Complementary tests - ECG: sinus tachycardia with mild diffuse ST-segment elevation slightly higher than the previous one and non-specific repolarisation alterations. - Laboratory tests showed an increase in infectious-inflammatory parameters (CRP 32; procalcitonin 10); macrocytic anaemia
column16: plateletopenia and leukopenia. Slight increase in myocardial damage markers: CPK 210; CPK MB 19 and troponin T 0.62. Acute renal failure (Cr 2.1) with preserved diuresis (GFR 36 mL/min). Acid-base balance and the rest of the laboratory tests were normal. - Urgent Doppler echocardiogram: global and segmental contractility alterations
column17: pericardial effusion and acute pathology were ruled out. - Chest CT scan: ruled out the existence of acute aortic pathology
column18: pulmonary thromboembolism or significant infectious process.   Clinical evolution During his admission
column19: broad-spectrum antibiotics and antifungals were administered empirically
column20: without microbiological isolation in blood cultures
column21: urine cultures and sputum cultures. Viral serologies were also negative. Monitoring of myocardial damage markers was performed
column22: with maximum troponin T of 1.59
column23: CPK of 279 and CPK of 43 four days after admission
column24: with progressive decrease and normalisation at discharge. ProBNP was determined and reached a maximum of 8319 pg/mL 5 days after admission. In the absence of an infectious focus
column25: a transesophageal echocardiogram was performed 5 days later
column26: showing borderline left ventricular function (LVEF: 0.45-0.50)
column27: with no images suggestive of endocarditis or other significant findings. Treatment was started with corticoids
column28: beta-blockers
column29: ACE inhibitors and diuretics with clinical and analytical improvement
column30: with borderline systolic function persisting in the echocardiogram at discharge. Seen in consultation ten days later
column31: he reported being asymptomatic cardiovascular. He underwent a control electrocardiogram in which the aforementioned alterations persisted
column32: an echocardiogram in which a dilated left ventricle with borderline systolic function was observed
column33: without pericardial effusion or alterations in contractility
column34: and a blood test in which slight thrombopenia and leukopenia persisted
column35: with normal infectious-inflammatory parameters. The following day
column36: an MRI of the heart was performed with adenosine stress
column37: showing signs compatible with acute myopericarditis and borderline systolic function
column38: without inducing myocardial ischaemia. The same treatment was maintained and the patient was scheduled for a follow-up appointment one month later.    Diagnosis - Septic shock with an unfiltered focus - Acute myopericarditis - Myelodysplastic syndrome refractory cytopenia type |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Male
column3: 67 years old
column4: retired. Active and independent life.   PERSONAL HISTORY No known drug allergies. Cardiovascular risk factors: ex-smoker of 30 pack-years. Arterial hypertension under treatment for years. Dyslipidaemia under dietary treatment.  Cardiological history At the age of 65 he was referred to an outpatient clinic for an asymptomatic systolic murmur in the mitral focus. A transthoracic echocardiogram was performed (2016) showing preserved left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) and moderate mitral insufficiency
column5: with no other relevant findings. Outpatient follow-up is scheduled. Other medical history of interest Severe sleep apnoea syndrome with use of CPAP since 2012. Chronic gastritis and hiatal hernia. Depressive syndrome in 2016 resolved. Associated somatoform disorders. Left vocal cord paralysis after prolonged orotracheal intubation for viral pneumonia in 2016. Recent diagnosis of localised prostate neoplasia without distant extension pending prostate resection surgery. Chronic medication Escitalopram 10 mg (1 tablet at breakfast); aliskiren/HTZ 300/12.5 mg (1 tablet at breakfast).  CURRENT ILLNESS He was transferred to the emergency department of our hospital by the mobile ICU after out-of-hospital cardiorespiratory arrest
column6: which was recovered in less than ten minutes with basic cardiac resuscitation manoeuvres (CPR) and a semi-automatic external defibrillator (AED) shock when the rhythm was interpreted as defibrillable. After regaining spontaneous circulation in sinus rhythm
column7: the patient persisted with a low level of consciousness
column8: requiring intubation and connection to mechanical ventilation by the mobile ICU. The event took place in the street
column9: with no close relatives as witnesses. Subsequently
column10: the patient had no memory of what happened at that moment (lacunar amnesia) and reported having been asymptomatic in the previous days.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION On arrival he was afebrile
column11: with heart rate (HR) 82 bpm
column12: blood pressure (BP) 155/83 mmHg and SatO2 100% with orotracheal intubation
column13: connected to mechanical ventilation with FiO2 50%. Carotid auscultation without murmurs. Jugular venous pressure normal. Rhythmic cardiac auscultation with a striking holosystolic murmur in the mitral focus radiating to the axilla (similar to that described in previous cardiology examinations). Pulmonary auscultation with preserved vesicular murmur. Abdominal examination with no pathological findings. Good distal perfusion
column14: without oedema. Central and distal pulses present.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Laboratory: biochemistry: glucose 260 mg/dl
column15: creatinine 1.26 mg/dl
column16: urea 36 mg/dl
column17: normal ions
column18: troponin T US 18 ng/l and at 3 hours 32 ng/l (reference value 14 ng/l) and CK 107 U/l. Haemogram: Hb 15.6 g/dl
column19: leucocytes and platelets normal. Coagulation: PT 109%
column20: TTPa and D-Dimer in normal range. Toxins: ethanol not detectable
column21: other toxins in urine negative. Arterial blood gases: pH 7.2
column22: pCO2 65 mmHg
column23: pO2 163 mmHg
column24: bicarbonate 21.3 mmol/l. Portable chest X-ray: cardiomegaly in anteroposterior projection. Endotracheal tube properly positioned. No evidence of pulmonary congestion. Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus rhythm at 75 bpm. Normal PR. Left axis. Left anterior hemiblock. Narrow QRS. ST-segment depression of approximately 1 mm in V4-V6 and flattened T wave in aVL. Urgent cranial CT scan: no evidence of acute intracranial pathology. Normal perfusion map and normal supra-aortic trunks. Emergency echocardioscopy: poor echocardiographic window. Left ventricle (LV) of normal size and slightly hypertrophic. LVEF moderately affected by global hypokinesia with zone of thinning and hypocontractility in the inferoposterior basal segment. Normal right ventricle (RV). Mitral regurgitation at least moderate
column25: very eccentric (ischaemic versus prolapsed). Normal aortic and tricuspid valves. No pericardial effusion. Coronary angiography: epicardial coronary arteries with minimal irregularities
column26: without significant stenosis. Regulated transthoracic echocardiogram: preserved LVEF. Posterobasal and inferobasal akinesia. Normal RV. Mitral insufficiency at least moderate (probably severe) with posterior leaflet prolapse. Rest normal. Transesophageal echocardiogram: confirms severe mitral insufficiency due to posterior leaflet prolapse predominantly at P2
column27: with eccentric jet directed anteriorly with Coanda effect. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): mitral prolapse with associated severe mitral insufficiency. Dilated LV (VTD 120 ml/m2). Thinning and hypocontractility of the basal and mid-inferolateral segments
column28: with late intramyocardial enhancement in the basal inferolateral segment. RV of normal size and function.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient's evolution was good during his stay in the ICU
column29: and he was extubated after 24 hours and transferred to the hospital ward stable and asymptomatic. A broad differential diagnosis of cardiorespiratory arrest had already begun in the ED. The complementary tests described above were performed
column30: which led to the diagnosis of malignant mitral prolapse as the cause of the event. During his hospitalisation he presented several bouts of non-sustained monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (with superior axis and right bundle branch block morphology). In view of the severe mitral insufficiency with LV dilatation confirmed by MRI
column31: it was decided in a medical-surgical session to perform mitral valve repair
column33: with implantation of two 4/0 Goretex neochords at P2 and AM (Physio 30 mm) plus a 30 mm mitral ring
column34: without complications. Subsequently
column35: an automatic defibrillator was implanted for secondary prevention. Clinical progress was satisfactory and he was discharged with the following medication: torasemide 10 mg
column36: ramipril 2.5 mg
column37: bisoprolol 5 mg
column38: atorvastatin 40 mg
column39: omeprazole 20 mg
column40: ferrimanitol ovalbumin 40 mg
column41: metamizol 575 mg and tramadol 100 mg; and follow-up in cardiology outpatient clinics.  DIAGNOSIS Malignant mitral valve prolapse. Resuscitated cardiorespiratory arrest
column42: in defibrillable rhythm. Severe mitral regurgitation secondary to mitral prolapse. Left ventricular dilatation. Non-sustained monoform ventricular tachycardias. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Patient aged 53 years reporting allergy to penicillin (not confirmed by allergy tests). Active smoker (15 packs/year)
column3: denies other toxic habits. No pathological history of interest
column4: no surgical interventions. No usual treatment. He came to the emergency department with a high fever of up to 39 ̊C with drowsiness and "clumsiness" in the right hand for one hour. He reported being a teacher and expressed great concern about being unable to write. In the anamnesis
column5: he reported fever and cough with cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy for the last 2 months
column6: which his primary care doctor labelled as mononucleosis syndrome
column7: although this was not confirmed and he did not receive any treatment. Subsequently
column8: despite some improvement in her symptoms
column9: she continued with occasional fever
column10: asthenia and unquantified weight loss. She denies recent trips or risky relationships
column11: no contact with animals
column12: has not had any dental procedures
column13: but refers to a tooth that had been affected by caries for months. Examination on admission: blood pressure 105/60 mmHg
column14: heart rate 81 bpm
column15: saturation 96% basal
column16: 39 ̊C. Pallor. No jugular ingurgitation. Small cervical and axillary lymph nodes. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds with systolic murmur in mitral focus grade 3/6 radiating to the axilla. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur with no additional sounds. Abdomen soft and non-painful
column17: with hepatomegaly of 1-2 fingerbreadths. Upper extremities (EESS) without skin lesions. Lower extremities (LES) without oedema with pulses present
column18: but with erythematous macular lesions on both soles compatible with Janeway spots. Basic neurological examination: Glasgow 14 (O3-V5-M6)
column19: bradypsychia with tendency to somnolence
column20: cranial nerves without alterations. EESS with dysmetria in the right upper extremity with preserved strength and sensitivity. No other alterations in the lower limbs.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Blood tests: glycaemia 105 mg/dl
column21: creatinine 0.97 mg/dl
column22: Na 132 mEq/l
column23: Cl 98 mEq/l
column24: K 4.1 mEq/l. Leukocytes 15300/ml with 89% neutrophils. Hb 12.6 g/dl
column25: Hto 38%
column26: platelets 136000/mcl. INR 1.62
column28: AP 58%
column29: FD 421 mg/dl. ESR 83 mm/h
column30: CRP 21 mg/l
column31: procalcitonin 1.38 mg/dl. Electrocardiogram (ECG) on admission: sinus rhythm at 81 bpm
column33: normal PR
column34: narrow QRS without repolarisation alterations. Chest X-ray on admission: normal cardiothoracic index
column35: no signs of consolidating focus or vascular redistribution. Blood cultures (positive after 72 hours of admission): Aggregatibacter aphrophilus
column36: no resistance. Serology: HIV
column37: HBV
column38: HCV negative. Brucella
column39: Coxiella
column40: Bartonella negative. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) on admission: left ventricle (LV) slightly dilated (LVEDD of 56 mm and LVEDV of 165 ml) with normal wall thickness. Preserved LV systolic function (Simpson's estimate ́s 55%). No segmental contractility alterations. Pseudonormal diastolic pattern (E/A 1.8). Slightly dilated left atrium (area 22 cm2). Right chambers at the high limit of normality (RV baseline diameter on A4C of 40 mm) with preserved right ventricular (RV) contractility (TAPSE of 23 mm
column41: S ́ in lateral TDI of tricuspid annulus of 12 cm/sg). Mitral valve (MV): thickened leaflets
column42: not limited in its opening. At the level of the posterior region of the mitral annulus (A3-P3)
column43: hyperdense and heterogeneous image with anarchic movement of 18 x 6-7 mm
column44: which is difficult to map by transthoracic access
column45: generating mitral valve destructuring causing moderate-severe mitral insufficiency (MI) characterised by a wide eccentric regurgitation jet towards the lateral wall of the left atrium (LA)
column46: VC of 8 mm
column47: E wave of 1.2 m/sg
column48: PISA radius of 10 mm
column49: abolition of flow in the pulmonary valve (PV). Regurgitant volume of 49 ml and ERO of 0.35 cm2. Aortic valve (VAo): trivalve
column50: normal sigmoid
column51: not limited in its opening. Competent. No images suggestive of infective endocarditis (IE) at this level. Mild tricuspid insufficiency (TI)
column52: estimating pulmonary artery systolic pressure (PAAP) 32 mmHg. Inferior vena cava (IVC) not dilated with normal inspiratory collapse. No pericardial effusion. TTE in the first 24 hours of admission: study similar to previous TTE. With respect to the MV
column53: large mass of approximately 27 x 16 mm
column54: with irregular borders and echolucent regions inside
column55: located in the region of the posteromedial commissure encompassing part of the P3-A3 scallops. It shows increased mobility with protrusion to the LV. Likewise
column56: a solution of continuity can be seen in the commissural region previously described and in P3
column57: allowing a jet that crosses the echolucent tracts and generating a severe MI contained by this mass. In summary
column58: the image is suggestive of a large abscess. Cranial CT scan on admission: in the non-contrast scan two focal lesions were identified: a 1 cm hyperdense subcortical lesion next to Rolando's fissure surrounded by oedema and another in the right cerebellar hemisphere of heterogeneous density and larger in size (3 cm) with a slight mass effect on the fourth ventricle without producing compressive hydrocephalus. They have a haemorrhagic component. No significant enhancement or annular enhancement after contrast administration. Thoracic-abdominal CT scan 48 hours after admission: hypodense mass measuring 27 x 15 mm located in the posterior and anterior leaflet of the mitral valve (A3 and P3) with extension towards the left atrial cavity
column59: and continuity of the mass to the mitral periannular region; findings compatible with paravalvular abscess. Hepatomegaly with focal hypodense lesion of 4 mm in segment VII of cystic nature. Splenomegaly with the presence of three peripherally located focal hypodense lesions in the posteroinferior region of the spleen suggesting infarcts. In the upper cortical pole of the left kidney there is a focal lesion of 11 mm
column60: with poorly defined contours and small peripheral enhancement (suspicious of abscess). Subpleural pulmonary nodules in the posterior segment of the LSD
column61: the largest of 5 mm with an inflammatory appearance. Cranial magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) 48 hours after admission: multiple small hyperintense lesions in T2 sequences of supratentorial location compatible with microembolism. There is a haemorrhagic lesion already visible on CT imaging in the left parietal convexity with haemorrhagic discharge into the subarachnoid space and another larger lesion located in the right cerebellar hemisphere. Behind it there is another haemorrhagic microfocus. They are hyperintense in T1 and show no significant enhancement after gadolinium injection. The cerebellar lesion causes a discrete mass effect on the fourth ventricle without obliterating it
column62: so there is no evidence of hydrocephalus. Non-specific diffusion study. Ultrasound scan of the abdomen on day 8 of admission: mild homogeneous global hepatomegaly with homogeneous echostructure. Porta permeable. Suprahepatic veins not dilated. No space-occupying lesions (LOE) were observed. Adequately distended gallbladder with preserved wall and normal content. Bile ducts are not dilated. Pancreas and spleen of preserved size
column63: morphology and echostructure. Kidneys of normal size and morphology. Excretory systems not dilated. No abdominal collections
column64: ascites or ultrasound alterations in the gastrointestinal tract.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION Given the clinical manifestations of constitutional syndrome and neurological focality
column65: a cranial CT scan was requested in the emergency department where two lesions with a haemorrhagic component (one cerebral and the other cerebellar) were observed
column66: which could be related to an embolic or metastatic origin. In order to identify their origin and given the presence of mitral systolic murmur on physical examination
column67: a TTE scan was performed which showed a mass dependent on the posterior mitral leaflet with significant MR and a normal-sized left atrium
column68: suggesting acute subacute MR. In addition
column69: blood cultures and serology were taken in the emergency department. The diagnosis of IE was established given the presence of one major criterion (mass dependent on the posterior mitral leaflet) and two minor criteria (fever and embolisms at the level of the brain
column70: cerebellum and IIJS). Despite significant mitral regurgitation
column71: the patient was haemodynamically and neurologically stable
column72: with no signs of heart failure
column73: so it was decided to admit him to the cardiology ward. After discussion with on-call internal medicine (infectious diseases)
column74: given his allergy to beta-lactam antibiotics
column75: the aggressiveness of his symptoms and his residence near an area endemic for methicillin- and vancomycin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus strains
column76: empirical antibiotic treatment was started with daptomycin iv 675 mg/24 hours
column77: gentamicin iv 200 mg/24 hours and fosfomycin iv 4 g/8 hours. Twenty-four hours after admission
column78: a thoracoabdominal CT scan was performed
column79: revealing multiple embolisms and abscesses in the left kidney and spleen. Transesophageal echocardiography was also performed
column80: revealing a mitral perivalvular abscess in the region of the posteromedial commissure
column81: encompassing part of the A3-P3 scallops and causing severe mitral insufficiency due to partial rupture of the posterior mitral leaflet. At 48 hours later
column82: a cranial MRI was performed
column83: which showed two lesions compatible with infarcts with haemorrhagic transformation and a funduscopic examination to rule out Candida involvement (showing emboligenic involvement). Subsequently
column84: intense asthenia persisted
column85: with slight improvement in neurological symptoms and febrile peaks of up to 39 ̊C. After 72 hours of admission
column86: Aggregatibacter aphrophilus was isolated in several blood cultures
column87: so with two major and two minor criteria the diagnosis of definite IE was established. Once the antibiogram was obtained (fourth day of admission)
column88: with no resistance
column89: the infectious diseases department decided to adjust antibiotherapy consisting of ceftriaxone 2 g/24 hours and ciprofloxacin 500 mg/24 hours (controlled administration after verifying an unlikely allergy to penicillins in childhood
column90: and consulting with the HRV allergy department). Clinical improvement in the neurological sphere
column91: with persistence of occasional febrile peaks
column92: so that on the eighth day of admission an ultrasound scan of the abdomen was requested
column93: which was compatible with normality. The case was presented at the medical-surgical session on the third day of admission and in constant communication with cardiac surgery
column94: and after consultation with neurology
column95: it was decided to complete a certain period of time with antibiotherapy prior to surgery. Subsequent good clinical evolution
column97: with improvement in writing and controls by radiology by means of CT and MRI (brain MRI control after 10 days which showed a reduction in microbleeds
column98: microinfarcts and previous intraparenchymal haemorrhage). Extraction of the affected tooth by maxillofacial surgery. Finally
column100: mitral valve replacement with Saint Jude mechanical prosthesis no. 33 was performed
column101: confirming the diagnosis of infective endocarditis (perivalvular abscess) by pathological anatomy and microbiology. Correct postoperative evolution without incident
column102: being discharged on the 16th day after surgery. He has remained clinically stable until the present day
column103: and has resumed his teaching activity.  DIAGNOSIS Subacute infective endocarditis on native mitral valve due to Aggregatibacter aphrophilus. Perivalvular mitral abscess in the region of the posteromedial commissure
column104: encompassing part of the A3-P3 scallops and causing severe mitral insufficiency due to partial rupture of the posterior mitral leaflet. Multiple septic embolisms (cerebral
column109: distal extremities). Haemorrhagic transformation of cerebral embolic lesions located in the left parietal convexity and right cerebellar hemisphere. column1: PERSONAL HISTORY This is a 67-year-old patient from France
column2: resident in the summer in a town in the Aragonese Pyrenees. He worked in the construction sector
column3: but is currently retired. There is no record of any previous medical history in our health system. In a report provided by his wife
column4: there are no known drug allergies to date
column5: and his medical history only includes active smoking (IPA 50)
column6: type II diabetes mellitus being treated with metformin and hyperuricaemia
column7: for which he takes allopurinol 100 mg every 24 hours.  CURRENT DISEASE At the end of June 2018
column8: after returning home with intense low back pain after doing farm work in an orchard
column9: he takes a diclofenac tablet. Half an hour earlier
column10: he reported having been bitten by an insect that he did not identify. Shortly afterwards
column11: after dinner (during which he had not eaten any new food in his diet)
column12: he presented with a pruritic rash
column13: initially on his arms
column14: which quickly became generalised
column15: and a feeling of dyspnoea. Subsequently
column16: he began to experience oppressive central thoracic pain and loss of consciousness with rapid spontaneous recovery with blood pressure (BP) 65/35 and SpO2 88% recorded by the emergency services mobilised to his home. Systemic treatment with methylprednisolone and dexchlorpheniramine was started
column17: and the anaphylactic symptoms resolved. The electrocardiograms (ECG) performed showed transient lower-posterior and lateral ST-segment elevation
column18: so after administering loading doses of acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) and ticagrelor
column19: he was transferred to our centre by helicopter for urgent coronary angiography. Echocardioscopy was performed in the antechamber and showed hypokinesia of anterolateral and inferolateral basal and medial segments.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION On arrival in the haemodynamics room
column20: the physical examination was normal except for the presence of a discrete rash on the trunk which disappeared during the procedure. BP 105/60 mmHg
column21: heart rate (HR) 80 bpm. Baseline SpO2 97%. Afebrile. Oropharynx slightly hyperemic. No jugular venous engorgement. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic sounds without murmurs or extratonos. Pulmonary auscultation: minimal scattered wheezing
column22: no hypoventilation. Abdomen: nondescript. Lower extremities: no oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Initial ECG: sinus rhythm at 62 bpm
column23: normal PR
column24: narrow QRS with axis at +80o. Up to 4 mm ST-segment elevation in inferior leads
column25: V4-V6
column26: with V1-V3 descent and in high lateral leads. ECG at 60 min (on arrival in the cath lab): sinus rhythm at 54 bpm
column27: normal PR
column28: narrow QRS
column29: small Q wave in inferior leads with R>S in V2. ST isoelectric in all leads
column30: negative T wave in III and aVF. Chest X-ray on admission: normal cardiomediastinal silhouette. Calcified aortic atheromatosis. No signs of acute haemodynamic decompensation
column31: nor images suggesting pulmonary condensation. Echocardioscopy: preserved left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF)
column32: hypokinesia of basal and medial anterolateral and lateral segments. No mechanical complications or pericardial effusion. Echocardiogram: non-dilated left atrium. Fine mitral valve
column33: slight posterior annular calcification that does not restrict valve opening. Minimal central insufficiency. Normal filling pressures. Left ventricle not dilated (VTDVI 4C 114 cm3
column34: VTSVI 4C 44 cm3)
column35: nor hypertrophied. Biplane LVEF 59.7% without clear alterations in segmental contractility. Trivalve aortic valve
column36: normal flow. Aortic root not dilated. Non-dilated right chambers with normal contractility (TAPSE 28). Tricuspid valve with normal flow. No indirect evidence of pulmonary hypertension. No pericardial effusion. Urgent coronary angiography (29/06/2018): right dominance. Ischaemic heart disease with severe stenosis of obtuse marginal ostioproximal large-calibre ostial artery (artery responsible for infarction) due to severely calcified plaque and severe stenosis of proximal-medial anterior descending artery. Percutaneous coronary intervention on severe stenosis of CX-MO by means of PTCA with conventional balloons
column37: cutting balloon and rotational atherectomy. Subsequent implantation of a zotarolimus-eluting drug-eluting stent with good angiographic results. Second-time coronary angiography (06/07/2018): good result of the drug-eluting stent implanted on CX-MO. Percutaneous coronary intervention on long calcified plaque in proximal-middle anterior descending coronary artery by means of percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty (PTCA) and implantation of zotarolimus-eluting drug-eluting stent. Blood tests on admission to the ward: haemogram: Hb 13.1 g/dl; Hct 37.5%; leukocytes 7.3 mil/mm3; platelets 163 mil/mm3. Biochemistry: basal glucose 159 mg/dl; glycated Hb 9.6%
column38: urea 0.33 g/l
column39: creatinine 1 mg/dl
column40: glomerular filtration rate estimated by CKD-EPI 76 ml/min/1.73m2
column41: total cholesterol 131 mg/dl
column42: triglycerides 200 mg/dl
column43: HDL-c 30 mg/dl
column44: LDL-c 61 mg/dl
column45: AST 27 U/l
column46: ALT 30 U/l
column47: GGT 28 U/l
column48: sodium 140 mEq/l
column49: potassium 4.4 mEq/l. ESR 29 mm (0-20). CRP 1.86 mg/dl. Complement factors C3 and C4 normal. Normal circulating immunocomplexes. Allergy tests: skin tests to common trophoallergens. Negative to (profilin and LTP)
column50: soya
column51: latex and anisakis. Total IgE value: 184 IU/ml (0-180). Tryptase value (29/06/2018 IAM day): 14 mcg/ml (0-10). Tryptase value (02/07/2018): 6.03 mcg/ml (0-10). Specific IgE: Pru p 3: < 0.1 ku/l (peach protein) (0-0.35)
column52: bee venom < 0.1 ku/l (0-0.35); vespula wasp venom 0.2 ku/l (0-0.35)
column53: polistes wasp 1.78 (0-0.35)
column54: poliste dominulus 3.76 ku/l (0-0.35). Prick test against diclofenac positive. Maximum myocardial necrosis markers: TnTus 338 ng/l (0-14); CPK 97 U/l (39-308)
column55: CK-MB 21 U/l (5-24).  CLINICAL EVOLUTION On arrival at the haemodynamics ward of our centre
column56: the ECG normalised
column57: the chest pain practically disappeared
column58: although some discomfort and regional contractility anomalies persisted as assessed by echocardioscopy
column59: as well as a great improvement in the anaphylactoid reaction. Urgent coronary angiography revealed severe stenosis in an ostioproximal marginal branch with distal TIMI 2-3 flow
column60: in addition to another severe lesion in the LAD. Given the characteristics of the Cx-MO lesion
column61: the intervention was complex
column62: requiring PTCA with cutting balloons and even rotational atherectomy. Despite this
column63: a drug-eluting stent was implanted with good angiographic results. After the procedure
column64: the patient was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU)
column65: where he made a very favourable evolution. Suspicion of possible Kounis syndrome type II led to a request for a tryptase blood test
column66: which was positive. After 36 hours in the ICU
column67: where he presented no complications
column68: and without significant elevation of myocardial necrosis markers
column69: he was transferred to the cardiology ward. During admission to the ward she did not present any further episodes of chest pain. Second-time coronary angiography was performed on a severe lesion of the LAD
column70: and another drug-eluting stent was implanted. A regular echocardiogram was performed
column71: showing only slight alterations in LV segmental contractility. The patient was assessed by the allergology department
column72: who performed an analytical study and found normal tryptase
column73: elevated values of specific IgE against wasp venom and a skin test that was positive for diclofenac. Given the good evolution
column74: he was discharged
column75: pending completion of the study and assessment of the need for immunotherapy against wasp venom
column76: which he decided to undergo in his country of origin.  DIAGNOSIS Non-Q Killip I allergic infarction in the context of anaphylactic shock: Kounis syndrome type II. Coronary artery disease of 2 main vessels (anterior descending [AD]
column77: circumflex [Cx]) with complete revascularisation. Preserved LVEF at discharge. Anaphylactic shock probably secondary to diclofenac. Sensitisation to wasp venom. column1: PERSONAL HISTORY No drug allergies. Family history: mother with ischaemic heart disease and stroke at an early age (familial hypercholesterolaemia). Cardiovascular risk factors: heterozygous familial hypercholesterolemia diagnosed in childhood (genetic study with M079 c.1342C>T mutation). Active smoker. Usual treatment: rosuvastatin 10 mg every 24 hours  CURRENT DISEASE A 29-year-old woman attended the emergency department for intermittent chest pain of 3 days' duration
column2: which worsened with deep inspiration and improved with sitting
column3: accompanied by fever up to 38 ̊C and a respiratory infection of the upper respiratory tract. He had been treated with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid for a week for an odontogenic infection following the extraction of a molar tooth. No dyspnoea
column4: palpitations or syncope. No previous angina-like chest pain either.    PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Temperature 37.8 ̊C. Blood pressure (BP) 123/83 mmHg. Heart rate (HR) 90 bpm. Basal SatO2 99%. Good general condition
column5: good hydration and colour of extremities. Eupneic at rest. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column6: no murmurs or pericardial friction. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur with no extra sounds. Abdominal examination showed no alarm signs. No oedema in the lower extremities. Distal pulses present in the extremities and symmetrical. COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Laboratory tests: haemoglobin: 14.3 g/dl. Leukocytes 19
column7: 700 u/μl (leukocyte formula with 85% neutrophils). Platelets 256
column8: 000 u/μl. Coagulation without alterations. Creatinine 0.78 mg/dl (estimated glomerular filtration rate > 90 ml/min). Urea 36 mg/dl. Sodium 137 mEq/l. Potassium 3.5 mEq/litre. Glucose 78 mg/dl. HbA1c 5.2%. Total cholesterol 276 mg/dl. HDL cholesterol 44 mg/dl. LDL cholesterol 217 mg/dl. Triglycerides 73 mg/dl. Liver profile within normal parameters. Serial troponin I 3.29 ng/ml - 5.70 ng/ml - 5.17 ng/ml (normal laboratory values < 0.04 ng/ml). ECG: sinus rhythm at 90 beats per minute
column9: PR 150 ms
column10: narrow QRS with normal axis. QS in V1-V3 with negative T waves in V1-V3. Chest X-ray: bilateral breast prostheses. Cardiothoracic index within normality. Pulmonary parenchyma without findings. Free costophrenic sinuses. Transthoracic echocardiogram: left ventricle neither dilated nor hypertrophic with mild systolic dysfunction (LVEF 41%). Apical akinesia and mid-segment akinesia of the anterior face and anterior septum. Non-dilated
column11: non-hypertrophic right ventricle with preserved longitudinal systolic function. Atria of normal size. No significant valvular heart disease. No pericardial effusion. Cardiac MRI: left ventricle with global contractility at the limit of normality (LVEF 50%). Hypokinesia of the apical septum
column12: apical anterior face and apex with subendocardial perfusion defect in the middle and apical septum. Late enhancement with subendocardial gadolinium in mid and apical septum. Right ventricle of normal size and morphology with preserved function. Angio-CT of coronary arteries: Coronary arteries with normal anatomical origin. Right dominance. Left coronary artery trunk: vessel of good development
column13: without lesions. Anterior descending: vessel of good development
column14: which after the exit of the first diagonal
column15: in its middle segment
column16: and up to the exit of the second diagonal
column17: a subocclusive lesion with thrombotic content is observed in its interior which could correspond to thrombotic disease or spiroid dissection with thrombosis of the false lumen; after the exit of the second diagonal
column18: the flow is recovered
column19: the middle-distal segment of the anterior descending being of scarce calibre. The ostium of the second diagonal is affected by the lesion previously described in the anterior descending artery. Circumflex artery: the proximal and middle segments of the vessel are well developed
column20: the distal segment being of smaller calibre
column21: with no lesions. Marginal obtuse of good calibre
column22: ending in a bifurcation
column23: without lesions. Right coronary: dominant vessel of very good development
column24: without lesions. Posterolateral branch of good development
column25: without lesions. Posterior descending branch of good development
column26: without lesions. Conal and acute marginal arteries of moderate development and without lesions. Coronary angiography: right radial access. Right coronary tree: slight lesion in the proximal third of the right coronary artery (CD)
column27: the rest without significant lesions. Left coronary tree: coronary trunk without lesions. Anterior descending artery (AD) with acute thrombotic occlusion in the proximal-middle third junction with distal TIMI 0 flow. Circumflex artery of good calibre
column28: without significant lesions. Percutaneous coronary intervention: guidewire is advanced to the first diagonal and treated with drug-eluting balloon without stenting. A 2.5 x 38 mm drug-eluting stent was implanted in the middle third of the LAD
column29: leaving TIMI 3 flow in the LAD and second diagonal.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION Pain and fever initially subsided in the emergency department with anti-inflammatory drugs. A transthoracic echocardiogram was performed showing mild LV systolic dysfunction with segmental alterations (apical akinesia and mid-segment akinesia of the anterior face and anterior septum). Due to the pericardial characteristics of the pain and the elevation of myocardial damage enzymes
column30: the first diagnostic suspicion is acute myopericarditis
column31: although the electrocardiogram does not show typical signs. However
column32: taking into account the patient's high cardiovascular risk (familial hypercholesterolemia with poor lipid control
column33: active smoking
column34: family history of early ischaemic heart disease)
column35: a coronary origin of the condition cannot be ruled out
column36: so the patient is admitted to the coronary unit for monitoring. The patient remained haemodynamically stable
column37: with no arrhythmic events and with disappearance of symptoms with high doses of aspirin and colchicine. In addition
column38: lipid-lowering treatment was reinforced with a high-intensity statin (atorvastatin 80 mg every 24 hours) and treatment for ventricular dysfunction was started with enalapril 2.5 mg every 12 hours (she could not tolerate higher doses due to hypotension)
column39: bisoprolol 2.5 mg every 24 hours and eplerenone 25 mg every 24 hours. With suspicion of myopericarditis
column40: cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was scheduled for the following day
column41: showing a subendocardial perfusion defect at the level of the mid-apical septum with late enhancement in this area
column42: suggestive of ischaemic heart disease. On the same day
column43: an angio-CT scan of the coronary arteries was also performed
column44: which showed a subocclusive lesion of possible thrombotic origin in the middle LAD
column45: without being able to rule out a coronary dissection. Given that the patient was stable and asymptomatic
column46: it was decided to perform a scheduled coronary angiography two days later
column47: which confirmed the thrombotic occlusion in the proximal-medial LAD. Percutaneous coronary intervention was performed on the lesion with implantation of a drug-eluting stent. Prasugrel was added as a second antiplatelet agent. Taking into account the clinical presentation
column48: the results and the evolution
column49: the most likely diagnosis is that of acute anterior myocardial infarction with post-infarction pericarditis without pericardial effusion. The patient progressed favourably and was discharged 7 days after admission. She is recommended to attend the cardiac rehabilitation programme
column50: to stop smoking
column51: and to modify her diet and lifestyle towards healthier habits. Taking into account the poor lipid control (LDL 217 mg/dl) and that she had presented an acute coronary syndrome
column52: it was decided to add ezetimibe 10 mg every 24 hours and to evaluate the need for a PCSK9 inhibitor in the follow-up. The patient subsequently attended cardiac rehabilitation
column53: managed to quit smoking with the help of varenicline and
column54: given that LDL cholesterol remained above target (121 mg/dl) 6 months after the event despite diet and treatment
column55: evolocumab 140 mg in subcutaneous injections every 15 days was added with good response (a reduction in LDL cholesterol levels to 63 mg/dl was observed at 12 weeks).  DIAGNOSIS Acute anterior myocardial infarction evolved with thrombotic occlusion of the middle anterior descending artery
column56: revascularised with a drug-eluting stent. Mild LV systolic dysfunction of ischaemic origin. Acute post-infarction pericarditis without associated pericardial effusion. Heterozygous familial hypercholesterolemia with poor lipid control. column2: no known drug allergies
column3: active and independent life. Family history of Marfan syndrome in a brother with a positive genetic study (mutation in the FBN1 gene). Our patient was tested for this mutation
column4: which was negative
column5: and did not have a marfanoid morphotype. Cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF): smoker of 1 pack a day (IPA 30)
column6: no hypertension (HT)
column7: no diabetes mellitus (DM)
column8: no dyslipidaemia. Cardiological history: Admitted to hospital 3 months ago for chest pain
column9: mainly exertional
column10: of 1 year's duration
column11: with typical characteristics
column12: but of shortened duration and a syncopal episode with a cardiogenic profile. On admission
column13: no arrhythmic alterations were documented after more than 72 hours of continuous electrocardiogram (ECG) monitoring
column14: echocardiography ruled out relevant structural heart disease and an ischaemia detection test was performed using ergometry
column15: which was clinically and electrically negative
column16: so she was discharged with a diagnosis of non-coronary chest pain and syncope under study and referred to the syncope clinic. On discharge
column17: hygienic-dietary measures were insisted upon
column18: but no pharmacological treatment was started. No other medical or surgical history of interest. No usual medical treatment.  CURRENT ILLNESS Three months after discharge from hospital
column19: while accompanying a relative to the hospital
column20: he again lost consciousness and was immediately transferred to the emergency critical care unit. During the transfer
column21: he suffered cardiorespiratory arrest (CRA)
column22: and cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) manoeuvres were started
column23: with the first rhythm detected after monitoring in ventricular fibrillation requiring three defibrillations at 360J to restore spontaneous circulation and orotracheal intubation (OTI) and connection to invasive mechanical ventilation (IMV)
column24: with a total CRA time of 9 min. According to his relative
column25: moments before the onset of the condition
column26: he reported chest discomfort of rapid onset. The first post-arrest ECG
column27: in sinus rhythm
column28: initially showed diffuse ST-segment elevation with an increase in aVR and persistent ST-segment elevation in lateral leads in serial ECGs. Therefore
column29: emergent coronary angiography was performed
column30: showing coronary arteries without angiographic lesions
column31: aortography and ventriculography without data suggesting acute aortic syndrome or alterations in contractility. Echocardioscopy performed in the acute phase showed no significant alterations
column32: including the absence of dilatation of the right chambers suggestive of pulmonary thromboembolism or aortic flap. Finally
column33: the patient was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU)
column34: where she had a good clinical evolution and early weaning was possible. With no recurrence of arrhythmias during her stay in the ICU
column35: she was transferred to the cardiology ward and monitored for further study and treatment.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Examination on the cardiology ward: blood pressure (BP) 122/94
column36: heart rate (HR) 62 bpm
column37: temperature 36.4 ̊C
column38: baseline SpO2 94%. Conscious and oriented. Normal colour
column39: normohydrated. Eupneic at rest. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic tones at 78 bpm
column40: no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: normal ventilation
column41: no added pathological sounds. Abdomen: nondescript. Lower extremities: symmetrical pulses
column42: no signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Emergency laboratory tests: no significant alterations. Glucose 195 mg/dl
column43: creatinine 0.8 mg/dl
column44: Na 141 mEq/l
column45: K 3.9 mEq/l
column46: Mg2+: 2.2 mEq/l (normal 1.5-2.5)
column47: Ca2+: 9.3 mg/dl (normal 8.8-10.5 mg/dl); D-dimer 452. Myocardial damage markers: initial TnTus < 13 ng/l
column48: CPK 205 U/l; CK-MB 23 (U/l) (normal 5-24). Maximal: TnTus 138 ng/l (0-14); CPK 397 U/l (39-308)
column49: CK-MB 51 U/l (5-24). General laboratory tests: biochemistry: glucose 81 mg/dl
column50: urea 0.36 g/l
column51: creatinine 0.63 mg/dl
column52: calculated GFR > 90 ml/min/1.73 m2
column53: albumin 3.69 g/dl
column54: total cholesterol 208 mg/dl
column55: LDL 152.8 mg/dl
column56: liver profile normal
column57: total calcium 9.33 mg/dl
column58: Na 139.9 mEq/l
column59: K 4.51 meq/l
column60: TSH 0.79 mU/l. Haemogram: Hb 15.2 g/dl
column62: leucocytes 9
column65: platelets 267
column66: 000. Catecholamines in 24-hour urine: negative. Chest X-ray: normal CTI
column67: mediastinum and lung fields without significant alterations. Post-arrest ECG: sinus tachycardia at 108 bpm
column68: normal PR
column69: no pre-excitation
column70: narrow QRS
column71: ST-segment elevation of up to 3 mm in V3-V6
column72: and less than 1 mm in inferior leads
column73: with ST-segment elevation of 1 mm in aVR and V1. At 5 minutes only the descent from V4-V6 remains. Normal QTc Normal baseline ECG: sinus rhythm at 88 bpm
column74: normal PR without pre-excitation
column75: no conduction or repolarisation disturbances. Slow R wave progression in precordial leads. Normal QTc. Echocardiogram: left atrium not dilated. Thin leaflet mitral valve with preserved mobility and opening; no regurgitation. Left ventricle neither dilated (LVEDV 4C: 83 ml; LVESV: 25 ml) nor hypertrophic with preserved ejection fraction and no clear segmental alterations of contractility. Preserved GLS (-22.3%). Trivalve aortic valve
column76: thin with good opening and mobility; normal flow. Valvular annulus and aortic root of normal dimensions; the rest of the thoracic aorta cannot be assessed. Right chambers not dilated; right ventricular contractility preserved. Tricuspid valve with good opening and mobility; minimal regurgitation. Pulmonary valve with good opening; flow curve with normal characteristics. No pulmonary hypertension. No pericardial effusion. Continuous ECG monitoring: no arrhythmic or ST alterations for 72 hours. Emergent catheterisation: coronary angiography: epicardial coronary arteries without angiographically significant lesions. Ventriculography: LV neither dilated nor hypertrophied
column77: with preserved global systolic function
column78: without clear segmental alterations in contractility (video 6). Aortography: aortic root and ascending aorta not dilated without angiographic data suggestive of acute aortic syndrome. Ajmaline test: negative.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION During admission
column79: he did not present new episodes of chest pain with the treatment given
column80: nor sustained arrhythmias
column81: only a 4-second NSVT flap. Blood and urine catecholamine tests were requested for 24-hour urine and blood tests were negative. Therefore
column82: despite the fact that the baseline electrocardiogram showed no data suggestive of channelopathies (normal QTc
column83: absence of J wave and spontaneous Brugada pattern
column84: previous ergometry without alterations)
column85: ajmaline test was performed to unmask a possible hidden Brugada syndrome pattern
column86: which was negative
column87: and finally
column88: it was decided to implant an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) for secondary prevention. After this
column89: the patient was discharged from hospital with a diagnosis of cardiorespiratory arrest due to probable ventricular fibrillation
column90: and treatment was recommended with acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) 100 mg/24h
column91: sotalol 80 mg/8h and a high-potency statin given the presence of dyslipidaemia with LDL of 152 mg/dl. One month after implantation
column92: he presented an appropriate ICD discharge due to rapid polymorphic VT and several non-sustained episodes of polymorphic VT. For this reason
column93: low-dose bisoprolol was added. The patient clinically continued with episodes of short-lasting chest discomfort
column94: more frequently since the initiation of beta-blockade. In view of the suspicion of vasospasm
column95: ECG recording of the symptoms was insisted on using 12-lead Holter
column97: coinciding with two episodes of chest pain
column98: a marked transient ST-segment elevation in the inferior and lateral face and ST-segment underleveling in V1 to V4 (which appears to be posterior ST-segment elevation) lasting about 3 minutes and accompanied by ventricular extrasystoles and a brief NSVT that was interpreted as a transient subepicardial infero-posterolateral lesion
column99: supporting the diagnosis of coronary vasospasm. A new hospital admission was decided to adjust his treatment
column100: suspending the beta-blocker and starting amlodipine and transdermal nitrites. During the first few days he presented repeated episodes of vasospastic angina
column101: one of them with sustained VT and appropriate ICD discharge. Titration to maximum tolerated doses was achieved and finally after association with a second calcium antagonist (verapamil)
column102: the clinical symptoms resolved. After more than 72 hours asymptomatic and without arrhythmias
column103: the patient was discharged from hospital
column104: with the following diagnoses and associated with previous treatment with ASA and statin
column107: and nitroglycerin patch 5 mg/24h. The patient has had regular check-ups at the cardiology clinic during these 3 years. Since discharge
column108: she has not presented any further syncopal episodes
column109: episodes of chest pain are practically non-existent and ASA has been discontinued after subsequent review that the coronary angiography images showed no significant atherosclerosis
column110: and only in one of the device reviews was there a bout of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT) that was successfully treated by means of overstimulation.  DIAGNOSIS High-risk syncope. Cardiorespiratory arrest probably secondary to ventricular fibrillation. Vasospastic angina. ICD implantation in secondary prevention. Sustained and non-sustained ventricular tachycardias in the context of vasospastic angina. column1: PERSONAL HISTORY Intolerance to acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) due to duodenal ulcer. CVRF: smoking (20 pack-years). No known cardiological history. Other history: duodenal ulcer 10 years ago. No relevant surgical interventions. Usual treatment: not reported.  CURRENT ILLNESS A 57-year-old male patient with the aforementioned history attended the emergency department of our centre due to oppressive central thoracic pain
column2: of about 30 minutes' evolution
column3: radiating to both upper limbs (MMSS) and neck
column4: which started suddenly while at rest
column5: with associated mild vegetative cramping. On arrival at the emergency department
column6: the clinical manifestations persisted. She denied previous episodes of central thoracic pain. She reported an active daily life. No clinical signs of CHF or infectious disease in previous days.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Blood pressure (BP) 140/60 mmHg (left arm)
column7: 90/50 mmHg (right arm)
column8: heart rate (HR) 65 bpm. SpO2 (FiO2 21%) 99%. Regular general condition
column9: affected by severe pain. Eupneic at rest. Normal colour and normohydrated. Sweating. Patient conscious and oriented
column10: cooperative and alert. No neurological focality. Cardiopulmonary auscultation: regular sounds
column11: diastolic murmur predominantly in the left sternal border. Conservative vesicular murmur (VCM) with no added noise. Abdomen: soft and depressible
column12: without mass or megaliths
column13: not painful on palpation. MMSS: asymmetric radial pulses. Lower limbs: weak and symmetrical distal pulses.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG on arrival at the ED: sinus rhythm at 95 bpm
column14: PR 170 ms
column15: narrow QRS
column16: 0o axis
column17: LVH criteria. No changes in serial ECG. Initial laboratory tests: CBC: red blood cells *4.62 10*12/l. Haemoglobin 14.3 g/dl. Haematocrit 42.9%. MCV 92.9 fl. MCH 30.9 pg. MCHC 33.3 g/l. ADE 13.1%. Leukocytes 8.6 10*9/l. Neutrophils 54.6%. Lymphocytes 32
column18: 2%. Platelets 198 10*9/l. Haemostasis: prothrombin time (PT) 11 sec. Quick's index 100%
column19: INR 0.95. APTT 28.7 sec. Biochemistry: glucose *103 mg/dl. Sodium 139 mEq/l. Potassium 4.3 mEq/l. Chlorine 103 mEq/l. Urea 34.2 mg/dl. Creatinine 0.86 mg/dl. Biomarkers of myocardial damage: troponin I (hsTnI) 3
column20: 2 ng/l. Urgent echocardiogram (TTE) in the critical care unit: left ventricle with slight concentric hypertrophy
column21: normal diameters and preserved systolic function
column22: with no alterations in segmental contractility at rest. Significant aortic insufficiency
column23: without other valvulopathies. Right ventricle of normal size and function. Aortic root with increased diameters (45 mm)
column24: without a clear flap image. Normal inferior vena cava (IVC). Mild pericardial effusion. Angio-CT of the aorta: type A aortic dissection with involvement of the aortic root extending along the anterior aspect of the aortic wall close to the left coronary trunk (LMCA) from the valvular plane to the origin of the inferior mesenteric artery with involvement of the proximal origin of the ASD. Dilatation of aortic root and tubular portion of ascending aorta (47 mm). Descending aorta 37 mm. Descending aorta 31 mm. At the level of the thoraco-abdominal aorta
column25: the true lumen has a reduced calibre. The celiac
column26: superior mesenteric and right renal trunks originate from the true lumen. The left renal arises from a gateway between the true lumen and the false lumen with good renal perfusion. Distal aorta and normal iliofemoral sector. Conclusion: type A dissection extending from the aortic root to the aortic segment proximal to the inferior mesenteric origin.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION In a patient with intense oppressive chest pain
column27: without significant ECG alterations suggestive of ischaemia
column28: it was decided to perform an urgent TTE
column29: which revealed aortic root dilatation with significant insufficiency. In view of these findings
column30: it was decided to request an angio-CT scan
column31: which confirmed the diagnosis of type A aortic dissection. With the results of the complementary examinations and the diagnosis
column32: the cardiac surgery department was contacted and emergency surgery was performed using the mechanical Bono-Bentall technique (Carboseal 29 mm) (consisting of aortic valve replacement
column33: aortic root and ascending aorta replacement
column34: as well as coronary ostium reimplantation in the same surgical procedure)
column35: under extracorporeal circulation
column36: electromechanical heart arrest and circulatory arrest with selective bicarotídeal cerebral perfusion. No replacement of the aortic arch or descending aorta was performed
column37: given the critical condition of the patient
column38: the complexity of the intervention and the improvement after elimination of the main tear and reinstatement of true lumen flow. Evolution in ICU: prolonged stay to 8 days after emergent Bentall surgery. Early extubation at 12 h post IQ without incident. At 48 hours the patient developed global respiratory failure oriented as postoperative acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) by congruent radiography with image of scattered infiltrates in both lung fields with heterogeneous distribution. Influenza A negative PCR. He required high-flow nasal spectacles
column39: with progressive improvement. On the other hand
column40: acute renal failure resolved. Haemodynamically
column41: the patient remained stable from the immediate postoperative period
column42: with no signs of active bleeding and no transfusion requirements. Good evolution in the cardiac surgery room
column43: with discharge home on 7/3/19.  DIAGNOSIS Acute type A aortic dissection. Emergent surgery with metallic Bono-Bentall. Smoking. Arterial hypertension. Acute respiratory failure due to ARDS. Resolved prerenal renal failure. |O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column1: PERSONAL HISTORY 60-year-old male patient with the following history: Family history of early ischaemic heart disease: brother died of acute myocardial infarction at the age of 48
column2: sister with chronic ischaemic heart disease since the age of 50. No known drug allergies. Arterial hypertension with good control as usual. Diabetes mellitus (DM) type 2 in treatment with oral antidiabetics
column3: with last HbA1c 7% (November 2017). Probable difficult to control familial hypercholesterolaemia. Chronic ischaemic heart disease with completely revascularised multivessel disease and preserved biventricular systolic function. Debut in January 2017 with non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (NSTEACS) of the non-Q acute myocardial infarction (AMI) type
column4: with coronary angiography finding multivessel disease
column5: with severe lesion in the distal trunk affecting the origin of the anterior descending artery (LAD) and severe lesion in the middle third of the right coronary artery (RCA)
column6: undergoing triple coronary artery bypass (left internal mammary to LAD
column7: saphenous to obtuse marginal and saphenous to RCA). At discharge echocardiography with preserved systolic function (LVEF 67%) without segmental alterations of contractility and analysis with hypercholesterolaemia (total cholesterol 200 mg/dl
column8: LDL-C 140 mg/dl
column9: HDL 23 mg/dl) despite treatment with atorvastatin 80 mg. Admission to cardiology in February 2017 due to a new episode of chest pain with pleuritic characteristics and no elevation of myocardial damage markers
column10: with a new echocardiogram performed
column11: superimposing the previous one except for the finding of slight pericardial effusion with no data of haemodynamic compromise. Treatment was started with high-dose acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) with clinical improvement
column12: and the patient was discharged with a diagnosis of Dressler's syndrome. A new blood test also showed LDL-C 201 mg/dl and treatment was started with atorvastatin 80 mg/ezetimibe 10 mg on discharge. Subsequent follow-up in cardiology outpatient clinics
column13: with good functional class and no effort angina
column14: as well as good therapeutic compliance with controlled blood pressure and good glycaemic control. In analytical tests
column15: hypercholesterolemia persisted with marked elevation of LDL-C levels. Other surgical interventions: meniscopathy.  CURRENT DISEASE 60-year-old patient under follow-up in cardiology outpatient clinic since previous admission for AMI undergoing surgical revascularisation. The patient reports being in good clinical condition
column16: with no angina or dyspnoea on exertion after discharge. He denies orthopnoea or episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea. He reported having completed the cardiac rehabilitation programme and was living a routine life without limitations. He attended the consultation to collect the results.    PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Good general condition. Conscious
column17: oriented. Well hydrated and perfused. Eupneic at rest. SatO2 98% without oxygen therapy. Blood pressure (BP) 130/80
column18: heart rate (HR) 70. No jugular engorgement. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column19: at a good frequency. No murmurs or audible extratonos. Conserved vesicular murmur
column20: without pathological noises. Lower limbs: no oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Distal pulses preserved and symmetrical.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG (April 2018): sinus rhythm at 70 bpm
column21: normal axis
column22: normal PR
column23: narrow QRS
column24: Q wave in III and aVF with negative T in I and aVL
column25: no other repolarisation alterations
column26: no signs of acute ischaemia
column27: normal QTc. Echocardiography (April 2018): non-dilated left ventricle without hypertrophy of its walls. Left atrium slightly dilated. Thoracic aorta within the normal range. No significant valvular heart disease. Preserved left ventricular systolic function
column28: with LVEF calculated by Simpson BP at 67%
column29: without segmental contractility disorders. Transmitral filling pattern of impaired relaxation without increased filling pressures. Inferior vena cava not dilated with adequate inspiratory collapse. No pericardial effusion. CBC (April 2018): CBC: leukocytes 8
column30: 100 units
column31: haemoglobin 13.4 g/dl
column33: 000 units. Biochemistry: Cr 0.84 mg/dl
column34: normal ions
column35: normal hepatobiliary profile. HbA1c 7.0% Lipid profile: total cholesterol 345 mg/dl
column36: LDLc 278 mg/dl
column37: HDL 52 mg/dl
column38: triglycerides 75 mg/dl. Blood tests (June 2018
column39: after starting alirocumab): CBC: leukocytes 9
column40: 100 units
column41: haemoglobin 13.9 g/dl
column42: platelets 280
column43: 000 units. Biochemistry: Cr 0.90 mg/dl
column44: normal ions
column45: normal hepatobiliary profile. HbA1c 6.9%. Lipid profile: total cholesterol 147 mg/dl
column46: LDL-C 78 mg/dl
column47: HDL 55 mg/dl
column48: triglycerides 72 mg/dl.   CLINICAL COURSE The patient attended the consultation to collect the results
column49: reporting a good clinical condition. He denies myalgia with high-dose statin treatment
column50: but reports concern about the difficulty of controlling his cholesterol given his personal and family history. He reported good compliance with treatment
column51: with good control of blood pressure and blood glucose levels at home
column52: as well as the recommended hygienic and dietary measures. The control blood test showed persistent hypercholesterolaemia
column53: with total cholesterol levels of 345 mg/dl and LDL-C of 278 mg/dl despite treatment with atorvastatin 80 mg/ezetimibe 10 mg. Given that the cholesterol levels were far from the optimal range
column54: it was decided to start treatment with alirocumab 150 mg every two weeks and to review in one month with a new blood test. The patient returned for another check-up in June 2018
column55: denying having had any adverse reaction after starting treatment. The control analysis showed a total cholesterol level of 147 mg/dl with LDL-C levels of 78 mg/dl.  DIAGNOSIS Chronic ischaemic heart disease with completely surgically revascularised multivessel disease and preserved left ventricular systolic function. Probable familial hypercholesterolemia of very difficult control. column1: PERSONAL HISTORY Female patient aged 88 years. No known allergic reactions to medication. Cardiovascular risk factors: hypertension
column2: dyslipidaemia. No cardiological history of interest. Peripheral arteriopathy with significant atheromatosis of the left superficial femoral artery documented by angiography four years earlier
column3: under medical treatment. Polyarthrosis under follow-up by rheumatology. Surgical intervention for appendicitis at the age of 25. Usual treatment: acetylsalicylic acid 100 mg every 24 hours
column4: clopidogrel 75 mg every 24 hours
column5: enalapril 20 mg every 24 hours
column6: doxazosin 4 mg every 24 hours
column7: simvastatin 10 mg every 24 hours
column8: pantoprazole 20 mg every 24 hours.  CURRENT ILLNESS The patient came to the emergency department with chest pain in the retrosternal region that appeared at rest and was described as severe. This picture lasts approximately 20 minutes and subsides spontaneously. She describes associated vegetative cramps. In the last two months
column9: the patient reported frequent episodes of epigastric discomfort
column10: with irradiation to the precordium and left upper limb
column11: which occurred with the exertion of her household chores.    PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Temperature 36.2 ̊C
column12: blood pressure 150/52 mmHg
column13: heart rate 59 beats per minute
column14: oxygen saturation by pulse oximetry 93% at baseline
column15: no signs of tachypnoea at rest. Neurological examination was unaltered. Cardiac auscultation was rhythmic
column16: without murmurs
column17: pulmonary auscultation with generalised hypophonesis. The abdominal examination showed no palpable organomegaly
column18: negative hepatojugular reflux and no signs of ascites. The lower limbs showed signs of chronic venous insufficiency.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Analytical parameters during his admission to cardiology: leukocytes 7.5 mil/ml
column19: haemoglobin 13.3 g/dl; platelets 299 mil/l; No coagulation alterations; basal glucose 81 mg/dl
column20: glycosylated haemoglobin (HbA1c) 5.6%
column21: urea 58 mg/dl; creatinine 1.03 mg/dl; estimated glomerular filtration rate (MDRD-4) 56 ml/min/1.73 m2
column22: total bilirubin 0.4 mg/dl
column23: GOT 19 IU/l
column24: GPT 13 IU/l
column25: CPK 64 IU/l
column26: Ions in normal range. Seriation of biomarkers: troponin I peak 0.228 ng/ml (normal range: less than 0.06 ng/ml)
column27: CKMB 3.7 ng/ml (normal range: less than 6 ng/ml)
column28: CPK 111 IU/l (normal range: 30-200 IU/l). Laboratory parameters during his admission to internal medicine: leukocytes 12.3 mil/ml
column29: haemoglobin 11.3 g/dl
column30: platelets 336 mil/l. No coagulation alterations. Basal glucose 90 mg/dl
column31: urea 55 mg/dl. Creatinine 1.15 mg/dl
column32: estimated glomerular filtration rate (MDRD-4) 44 ml/min/1.73 m2. Total bilirubin 2.7 mg/dl
column33: direct bilirubin 1.9 mg/dl
column34: GOT 940 IU/l
column35: GPT 660 IU/l
column36: GGT 2711 IU/l
column37: CPK 5074 IU/l
column38: Ions in normal range. Immunoglobulins and complement without significant alterations. Proteinogram: albumin 3.16 g/dl with no other significant alterations. Negativity in the study for: anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA)
column39: anti-mitochondrial antibodies (AMA)
column40: anti-smooth muscle antibodies (AML) and anti-LKM-1 antibodies. Emergency resting electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm at 77 bpm. PR of 145 ms with atrioventricular conduction 1:1. Narrow QRS with normal axis. Inframilimetric ST-segment depression from V4 to V6. QTc interval of 444 ms. Abdominal ultrasound: liver of normal morphology and echogenicity with no evidence of lesions inside. Abdominal-pelvic CT scan: no space-occupying lesions were seen in the blood parenchyma
column41: which had a normal morphology. There is no evidence of retroperitoneal pathology. Kidneys with cortical notches of normal size and morphology. The rest of the examination showed no significant tomographic findings.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was admitted to the cardiology department with a diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction without ST-segment elevation
column42: with an intermediate risk profile. Preferential coronary angiography was performed with implantation of a drug-eluting stent in the right ostial coronary artery
column43: which presented a critical ostial lesion
column44: with no other angiographically significant lesions. Transthoracic echocardiography was performed on admission with no notable alterations. The patient
column45: who was already on double antiplatelet therapy
column46: was discharged after an admission without notable complications
column47: adding bisoprolol 2.5 mg daily to her usual treatment and replacing the previous lipid-lowering treatment with atorvastatin 80 mg. At this time the patient's LDL cholesterol level was 98 mg/dl. After a period of one month of home treatment
column48: the patient visited her primary care physician for lumbar pain radiating to the right abdomen and the physician performed a blood test showing hypertransaminasemia with GOT levels of 677 IU/l and GPT of 701 IU/l
column49: referring the patient to the emergency department. The patient was readmitted to the emergency department
column50: where she reported asthenia
column51: weakness predominantly in the shoulder girdle
column52: and a repeat laboratory test was performed
column53: expanding the parameters (see section on complementary tests). The patient was admitted to the internal medicine department for hypertransaminasemia under study
column54: rhabdomyolysis and acute renal failure with a pre-renal profile. During her admission to internal medicine
column55: an ultrasound scan of the abdomen and abdominal CT scan were performed (see section on complementary tests) to assess retroperitoneal pathology. Finally
column56: she was diagnosed with toxic hepatitis and rhabdomyolysis related to statins. The patient progressed favourably during her admission and was discharged with ezetimibe 10 mg every 24 hours. To date
column57: the patient has continued her check-ups in cardiology consultations with no new notable events and her LDL cholesterol levels are 105 mg/dl
column58: with transaminase and creatine phosphokinase levels within the normal range.  DIAGNOSIS Acute myocardial infarction without ST-segment elevation. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 78-year-old woman. She is hypertensive
column3: diabetic on oral treatment and hyperuricaemic. In addition
column4: she had an infiltrating breast carcinoma treated 8 years ago with radical mastectomy
column5: chemotherapy and radiotherapy
column6: and is currently free of disease. Hepatitis B cured. Intrathoracic goitre. As cardiological history
column7: she has permanent atrial fibrillation treated with direct-acting anticoagulant and
column8: in the face of severe symptomatic aortic stenosis
column9: due to a history of thoracic radiation
column10: percutaneous replacement with Corevalve Evolut 26 transfemoral TAVI implant was chosen one year ago
column11: with no incidents. On regular treatment with digoxin 0.5 mg (1-0-0)
column12: dabigatran 150 mg (1-0-1)
column13: valsartan/amlodipine 160/5 mg (1-0-0)
column14: furosemide 40 (1-0-0)
column15: allopurinol 100 (0-1-0) and metformin 850 (0-1-0). She reported febrile symptoms of one week's evolution
column16: with fever of more than 38 ̊C thermometrically measured
column17: treated with fosfomycin by her general practitioner for suspected urinary tract infection
column18: with little improvement. Twenty-four hours after starting antibiotic treatment
column19: she began with liquid diarrhoea without pathological products and intense periumbilical pain
column20: also associated with the progressive appearance of oedema in the legs and progressive dyspnoea
column21: for which she went to the emergency department. She denied cough or expectoration
column22: as well as chest pain
column23: dizziness or syncope. She also had no neurological focality. She was admitted to the internal medicine department as a possible complicated urinary tract infection for study and treatment. On examination
column24: she had a blood pressure of 95/62 mmHg
column25: a heart rate of 85 bpm
column26: fever of 37.9 ̊C and was eupneic with nasal goggles at 2 l/min (O2 saturation 97%). Jugular venous pressure is increased. On auscultation she is arrhythmic at 80 bpm
column27: with murmur in aortic focus II/VI and normal second sound; she also has hypoventilation in the bases and crackles in the midfields. The abdomen was soft
column28: depressible and painful at the epigastric level
column29: with no evidence of peritoneal irritation or visceromegaly. Lower extremities with oedema with pitting up to the knee
column30: with no evidence of venous thrombosis. Peripheral pulses present and symmetrical. No peripheral stigmata of endocarditis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram: atrial fibrillation at 80 bpm
column31: narrow QRS
column32: normal axis. Repolarisation abnormalities corresponding to a digitalis tray. Chest X-ray: cardiomegaly. TAVI in aortic position. Vascular redistribution and fluid in cystic cracks compatible with heart failure. Widening of the superior mediastinum compatible with known endothoracic goitre. Analysis: Biochemistry: glucose 98 mg/dl

column36: Na 125 mEq/l

column54: with positive synergism with aminoglycosides. Urine: isolated red blood cells. No leucocyturia or bacteriuria
column55: negative nitrites Faeces: usual flora
column56: no parasites and negative Clostridium difficile toxin. Serology: HIV and HCV negative. Anti HBs and Anti HBc positive. Autoimmunity study: ANA

Slight dilatation of the left atrium. Normofunctioning aortic biological prosthesis with known trivial insufficiency. Mild mitral insufficiency and tricuspid insufficiency
column61: with mild pulmonary hypertension at rest. No images suggestive of endocarditis are detected. Transesophageal echocardiogram: CoreValve TAVI type aortic bioprosthesis with several small mobile images
column62: mainly at the level of the right coronary leaflet equivalent and another small image
column63: with identical characteristics
column64: adhered to the stent at the same level
column65: suggestive of endocarditis.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION On admission
column66: antibiotic treatment was started empirically with ceftriaxone with initial suspicion of pyelonephritis
column67: later changing to cloxacillin
column68: rifampicin and gentamicin at a dose of endocarditis due to high clinical suspicion
column69: despite the initial negative transthoracic echocardiogram. The study was later completed with a transesophageal echocardiogram that showed images compatible with endocarditis on TAVI
column70: establishing the diagnosis with positive blood cultures for S. aureus. Treatment with gentamicin was maintained due to microbiological evidence of synergy with cloxacillin
column71: but the patient suffered a rapid deterioration of renal function
column72: with a drop in glomerular filtration rate to 6 ml/min. Rapidly progressive worsening with evidence of septic shock with anuria
column73: decreased level of consciousness and coagulopathy
column74: refractory to initial measures. The case was discussed with cardiology
column75: internal medicine and the infectious diseases department
column76: and in this critical situation
column77: further valve replacement or other aggressive measures were rejected
column78: and the patient died in the context of septic shock secondary to endocarditis on TAVI.  DIAGNOSIS Late endocarditis on TAVI aortic bioprosthesis due to Staphylococcus aureus. column25: AV zone and RV for recording and stimulation. The procedure is performed without complications. Basically the conduction intervals are AV: LC 704 ms
column26: AH 95 ms
column27: HV: 44 ms. The nodal Wenckebach point was obtained at 190 bpm. No VA conduction is observed above 100 bpm. column29: so it cannot be considered positive. Genetic testing for sudden death: no clinically relevant variants have been identified.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION As this was a 63-year-old patient with repeated syncope suggestive of cardiogenic origin
column30: it was decided to admit him to the cardiology department to complete the stiological study. Cardiac imaging studies were performed with transthoracic echocardiography and CMR
column31: which showed no structural alterations. During her hospital stay she did not present arrhythmic events on continuous monitoring. A cranial CT scan was performed
column32: which showed no significant alterations. In addition
column33: as she presented complete right bundle branch block (image 1)
column34: it was decided to complete the aetiological study with an electrophysiological study and carotid sinus massage
column35: which did not prove the cause of the syncope. Finally
column36: given the high suspicion of cardiogenic origin
column37: it was decided to implant a subcutaneous Holter (Reveal®) for continuous ambulatory monitoring. During review of the monitoring alerts
column38: a tracing was detected. The patient was notified to interrogate the subcutaneous Holter (Reveal®)
column39: which revealed an episode of ventricular fibrillation and subsequent asystole triggered by ventricular extrasystole with T-wave coupling. The patient reported that he had suffered a syncopal episode of identical characteristics to the previous ones. Given the morphology of the QRS in the baseline ECG
column40: a flecainide test was performed with an increase in the J point in V1 and V2 without exhibiting a typical Brugada pattern. Following the indications of the clinical practice guidelines on sudden death and ventricular tachycardia
column41: coronary angiography was requested
column42: which showed no significant lesions. Genetic testing was requested for the study of sudden death without structural heart disease
column43: including the genes most frequently associated with Brugada syndrome and catecholaminergic ventricular tachycardia
column44: but no clinically relevant variants were identified. In view of the repeated syncope and the finding of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation
column45: implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) implantation was decided for secondary prevention. Subsequently
column46: during follow-up in outpatient clinics
column47: on performing a detailed and directed family tree
column48: it was found that the paternal grandfather had sudden death at the age of 56 and that one of his paternal uncles had been diagnosed with Brugada syndrome after sudden death had been recovered (with negative genetics
column49: but with a type 1 pattern).  DIAGNOSIS Repeated cardiogenic syncope in the context of ventricular fibrillation due to probable Brugada syndrome. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 26-year-old male admitted for chest pain and elevated markers of myocardial damage.  PERSONAL HISTORY Baseline: native of Colombia.
