column3: who two weeks before admission started episodes of oppressive central thoracic pain radiating to both jaws
column4: unrelated to exercise or respiratory movements. No vegetative cortex associated. Self-limited cessation of these episodes within a few minutes. She also reported non-specific dizziness and occasional dystrophic sensation
column5: without thermometric fever. No palpitations
column6: dyspnoea or syncopal symptoms. She denied previous infectious symptoms.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Afebrile
column7: blood pressure 106/62 mmHg
column8: heart rate 60 bpm
column9: baseline O2 saturation 98%
column10: referred weight 70 kg. Conscious
column11: oriented and cooperative. Well hydrated and perfused. Good general condition. Eupneic at rest. Jugular venous pressure normal. No palpable lymph nodes. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic without murmurs or rubbing. Pulmonary auscultation: respiratory sounds were preserved with no over-additions. Abdomen: soft
column12: depressible and non-painful. No masses or megaliths palpable. Peristalsis present. Lower extremities: no oedema. Distal pulses present and symmetrical.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram: sinus bradycardia at 50 bpm. Normal PR. Narrow QRS. Q wave at the limit of pathological significance and ST elevation 0.5 mm in the inferior face. Laboratory tests on admission: haemoglobin 15 g/dl
column13: platelets 350.000 u/mm3
column14: leukocytes 11.3 x103/mm3 (neutrophils 33.4%-3790 u/l
column15: lymphocytes 31.4%-3560 u/l
column16: eosinophils 27.7%-3150 u/l)
column17: basal glucose 81 mg/dl
column18: urea 23 mg/dl
column19: creatinine 0.79 mg/dl
column20: sodium 131 mEq/l
column21: potassium 4.2 mEq/l
column22: conventional troponin I 2.7 ng/dl (normal < 0.01). Chest X-ray: normal cardio-thoracic index. No acute pleuroparenchymal lesions. Transthoracic echocardiogram: non-dilated left ventricle
column23: normal thickness
column24: no alterations in segmental contractility. Normal systolic function (biplane Simpson LVEF 65%). Hyperechogenic appearance of the inferolateral wall myocardium respecting the endocardium. Right ventricle of normal size with preserved systolic function. Mitral valve of normal appearance and function. Trivalve aortic valve
column25: without insufficiency or stenosis. Tricuspid valve of normal appearance
column26: with minimal insufficiency. Normal functioning pulmonary valve. Aortic root of normal size
column27: no coarctation. No pericardial effusion. Cardio-MRI: ventricles of preserved size and function. Hypokinesia
column28: oedema and late intramyocardial enhancement of subepicardial predominance in the inferolateral face are observed; findings that may be related to myocarditis in the appropriate clinical context. column29: with preserved patency
column30: without thrombotic or stenotic images.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was admitted to the coronary unit for monitoring and further complementary tests. As a specific cardiological test
column31: a transthoracic echocardiogram was performed
column33: followed by cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (CMR)
column34: which was found to be compatible with myocarditis. After 48 hours without development of arrhythmic complications or heart failure
column35: he was transferred to the hospital ward for further care and to complete studies. The analysis on admission showed leukocytosis due to marked eosinophilia that persisted in subsequent analyses
column36: so an assessment was requested by internal medicine
column37: which expanded the battery of tests with autoimmunity
column38: virus and infectious serology
column39: which was positive for IgM Toxocara spp. Subsequently
column40: a CT scan of the coronary arteries was requested to rule out embolisms
column41: which was also normal. Suspicion of eosinophilic myocarditis secondary to Toxocara parasite infection led to treatment with albendazole. The patient had a good clinical evolution and was discharged from hospital after 7 days asymptomatic
column42: with normalisation of myocardial damage markers and decreasing eosinophilia. column39: acceptable quality of the study

column42: after the origin of a large first diagonal presents a moderate stenosis (50-75%) concentric
column43: without calcified plaque

column45: with a slight non-calcified lesion at its origin (< 50%). Intermediate branch of small development. Dominant right coronary artery
column46: without significant stenosis or calcifications

column48: non-calcified stenosis (< 50%) at its origin.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION Patient with a family history of early coronary heart disease and suspected familial hypercholesterolemia
column49: asymptomatic from the cardiological point of view until the current episode

column52: but this was replaced due to ineffectiveness (LDL-C > 180 mg/d) by atorvastatin 10
column53: which had to be discontinued due to liver damage

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 56-year-old male
column3: no allergies
column4: ex-smoker and paranoid schizophrenia treated in the past with ECT and multiple antipsychotics. He was found unconscious by his brother; on arrival of the ambulance he presented blood pressure of 60/40 mmHg with O2 saturation of 65%
column5: temperature 34.8 °C. On auscultation he had crackles and rhonchi in both lung fields. Orotracheal intubation was performed and catecholamine perfusion (noradrenaline and adrenaline) was started. On arrival at the emergency department
column6: a cardiological assessment was requested for an electrocardiogram (ECG) suggestive of inferolateral infarction. The ECG showed a nodal rhythm with QRS of 120 ms and rSR morphology of V2-V6 with the last R tied to the ST. Echocardioscopy with preserved left ventricular (LV) function and no segmental alterations. Laboratory tests described in evidence. The chest X-ray was compatible with multilobar pneumonia. Cardiology maintained a wait-and-see attitude
column7: and the patient was admitted to the intensive care unit for treatment of the respiratory infectious process.    COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Arrival ECG: nodal rhythm with QRS of 120 ms and rSR morphology of V2-V6 with the last R tied to the ST. ECG after temperature correction: virtual disappearance of Osborn waves
column8: returning to normal sinus rhythm. ANALYSIS: haemoglobin 14.4 g/dl
column9: haematocrit 41.6%
column10: leukocytes 1700x10^3/μl
column11: neutrophils 93.3%
column12: platelets 133
column13: 000x10^3/μl. Coagulation: INR 1.61
column14: IQ 52%
column16: APTT 42.9
column17: D-dimer 708 ngr/ml. BIOCHEMISTRY: glucose 163 mg/dl
column18: urea 57 mg/dl
column19: creatinine 0.39 mg/dl
column20: GFR MDRD4; 60 ml/min/1.73m2
column21: sodium 127 mm/l
column22: potassium 4.4 mm/l
column23: magnesium 2.2 mm/l. Creatine kinase 672 U/L. Lactate 2.37 mm/l. Procalcitonin 0.96 ng/ml. Troponin I < 0.01 ng/dl. CK-MB mass 139.93 ng/ml. Arterial blood gases: pH 7.29. pCO2 67 mmHg. pO2 42 mmHg. HCO3 32.2 mm/l. Base excess 3.36 mm/l. THORAX RADIOGRAPHY: compatible with multilobar pneumonia (image 2). ECOCARDIOSCOPY: non-dilated left ventricle with preserved function. No segmental alterations of contractility. No aortic valvulopathy. Minimal mitral insufficiency. Right chambers with normal morphology and function. No intracardiac effusion or masses.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The team of intensivists requested a new assessment of the patient due to doubts about the decision taken by cardiology. After re-evaluating the electrocardiograms
column24: a new patient temperature was requested
column25: which was undetectable at the time. The patient was gradually warmed with thermal blankets and warm saline. At 32 °C partial correction of the waves is observed
column26: which disappear completely at 36 °C. A diagnosis of Osborn waves due to hypothermia and acidosis was made. The patient finally died of respiratory failure.  DIAGNOSIS Community-acquired multilobar pneumonia. Acute respiratory failure. Hypothermia and acidosis
column27: with Osborn waves on electrocardiogram. Preserved left ventricular function
column28: no structural heart disease. column2: 170 cm tall and weighing 65 kg. His medical history included Hodgkin's lymphoma at 5 years of age
column3: which required splenectomy
column4: liver and mesenteric lymph node biopsy for staging and was treated with radiotherapy to the thorax. At the age of 34
column5: he underwent haemithroidectomy for follicular adenoma.  Previously asymptomatic and leading an active life
column6: he attended the emergency department for 2 days of general malaise
column7: myalgias
column8: arthralgias
column9: lumbar pain
column10: vomiting
column11: diarrhoea and febrile fever. Laboratory tests showed slight leukocytosis. Abdominal ultrasound and simple thoracic and lumbar radiology revealed no abnormalities. The electrocardiogram showed normal sinus rhythm. The patient was diagnosed with low back pain and discharged. Three days later he was urgently admitted for worsening symptoms with shivering
column12: fever of 40 ̊C and hypotension. Blood tests showed 34.8 × 103 leukocytes/μL (92% neutrophils and 15% white blood cells)
column13: platelets 465 × 103/μL
column14: ESR of 40 mm
column15: creatinine 1.55 mg/dL
column16: procalcitonin 6.46 ng/mL
column17: C-reactive protein 20.18 mg/dL. Urine sediment showed bacteriuria
column18: 5-10 leucocytes/field and oxalate crystals. Blood and urine cultures were taken. With suspicion of severe sepsis
column19: rescue fluid therapy was administered and antibiotic treatment with meropenem and linezolid was started.  Two days after admission
column20: the patient presented with dyspnoea at rest and pulmonary oedema
column21: probably related to intravenous fluids
column22: requiring intubation and mechanical ventilation. The electrocardiogram showed 2nd degree AV block progressing to complete AV block with output at 70 bpm. The transesophageal echocardiogram showed moderate tricuspid regurgitation
column23: mild mitral regurgitation and a normofunctioning aortic valve
column24: as well as mobile images suggestive of vegetation on the anterior mitral leaflet. Dopamine perfusion was started to maintain the heart rate
column25: and antibiotic treatment was modified to include cloxacillin
column26: daptomycin and gentamicin on suspicion of infective endocarditis. The patient's evolution was favourable and allowed extubation 6 days after admission.  Ten days after admission
column27: the patient presented retrosternal pain and signs of sudden onset pericarditis. The echocardiogram showed mild pericardial effusion and progression of endocarditis with vegetations on the anterior mitral leaflet
column28: tricuspid septal leaflet and mitro-aortic junction without significant valvular insufficiencies. Computed tomography angiography showed an aneurysm of probable mycotic origin on the anterior aspect of the ascending aorta as well as a small thoracic aorta and pulmonary artery. The patient was referred for urgent surgery.  After opening the pericardium
column29: the pericardial fluid was bloody in appearance and was sent for culture. Although subjectively appreciated
column30: the aorta
column31: cavae and pulmonary artery appeared to the surgical team to be very small for the size of the patient. A haematoma was noted on the anterior aspect of the aorta and the epicardial fat of the right ventricle. The haematoma was cannulated and then debrided
column32: draining copious pus followed by active arterial bleeding due to possible rupture of the mycotic aneurysm.  Once the extracorporeal circulation was connected and the aorta clamped
column33: the ascending aorta was opened
column34: revealing abundant atheroma plaques
column35: a small mycotic aneurysm with signs of inflammation and a small
column36: thin
column37: competent aortic valve with a 16 mm Hegar ring. Below the aortic valve
column38: vegetation anchored to the membranous septum was observed and resected. After brushing the septum with povidone iodine
column39: a Teflon reinforced stitch was placed because of suspected communication with the right atrium. The portion of the aortic wall including the mycotic aneurysm was resected and direct closure of the aorta was performed respecting the aortic valve. A right atriotomy was performed
column40: revealing a large vegetation in the commissure between the anterior leaflet and the septal leaflet
column41: probably related to the resected vegetation on the left ventricular side. The vegetation was resected
column42: brushed with Betadine and the commissure was reinforced with a stitch. The interatrial septum was then opened and a large vegetation on the anterior mitral leaflet was observed and resected. At the end of the operation
column43: a definitive epicardial pacemaker was implanted over the right ventricle.  Blood and urine cultures were negative. Pericardial fluid culture was positive for S. pneumoniae. Although culture of vegetations was negative
column44: DNA polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was positive for S. pneumoniae in all samples.  The patient's postoperative evolution was initially favourable and the echocardiogram showed normally functioning valves with no residual shunts. However
column45: 3 weeks after surgery the patient suffered progressive deterioration of general condition with fever and hypotension. Several blood cultures were positive for Candida orthopsilosis. Despite antifungal treatment
column46: the patient died of septic shock and multi-organ failure 2 months after surgery. Necropsy showed invasive candidiasis in the liver and lung. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 63-year-old male with multiple cardiovascular risk factors (hypertension
column2: type 2 diabetes mellitus on oral antidiabetic treatment
column3: dyslipidaemia and obesity)
column4: COPD
column5: chronic kidney disease with baseline creatinine of 1.2 mg/dl and permanent atrial fibrillation
column6: who was admitted to our centre in May 2018 in cardiogenic shock requiring vasoactive support and non-invasive mechanical ventilation. The patient had dilated cardiomyopathy of probable enolic origin
column7: with severe left ventricular systolic dysfunction with an estimated left ventricular ejection fraction of 20%
column8: with implantation of a single-chamber implantable cardioverter defibrillator as primary prevention in 2003.  The admission echocardiogram showed severe aortic stenosis and double mitral lesion with moderate insufficiency and mild stenosis of probable rheumatic origin with significant calcification of the leaflets. Given the patient's situation and personal history (EuroScore II 19.35%)
column9: it was decided to implant a 29 mm Edwards SapienTM transcatheter aortic prosthesis via the transfemoral route by the interventional cardiology team
column10: and percutaneous treatment of the mitral valve was ruled out at the same surgical time. The post-implantation echocardiogram showed a normofunctioning aortic prosthesis with a mean transprosthetic gradient of 5 mm Hg and mitral regurgitation unchanged from the preoperative echocardiogram.  Four months after the procedure the patient was readmitted to our centre for multiple inappropriate shocks of the implantable cardioverter defibrillator
column11: accompanied by fever and chills. We analysed the device data
column12: and observed multiple episodes of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia
column13: most of which ended with a shock
column14: and which were undetected by the patient. All episodes were preceded by marked bradycardia requiring pacemaker pacing. Pacemaker pacing was increased to a minimum heart rate of 75 bpm and blood cultures were drawn and tested positive for Staphylococcus epidermidis. Given these results
column15: the persistence of fever and elevated acute phase reactants and the history of TAVI implantation
column16: infective endocarditis was suspected and a transesophageal echocardiogram was performed. The echocardiogram showed a large hypoechoic vegetation measuring 4.3 × 1.9 cm
column17: with a deflected irregular border extending from 1 cm below the valve plane to 3 cm above the valve plane
column18: filling most of the TAVI stent and causing the prosthesis to behave as a moderate-severe stenosis with a peak gradient of 38 mm Hg without insufficiency. The mitral valve had extensive degenerative changes
column19: with severe calcification of the leaflets and subvalvular apparatus
column20: and a severe central insufficiency jet.  Antibiotic treatment with daptomycin and fosfocimin was started and the case was discussed in a medical-surgical session. Given the lack of clinical and echocardiographic improvement
column21: surgery was decided. During surgery
column22: large vegetations were observed on the ventricular and aortic side of the prosthesis. The TAVI was explanted and an aortic valve replacement with a 25 mm Magna Ease biological aortic prosthesis was performed. In addition
column23: a mitral valve replacement with a 25 mm Magna Ease biological prosthesis was performed.  The explanted prosthesis was analysed microscopically with Gram stain
column24: where gram-positive cocci were observed in clusters
column25: and cultures on the prosthesis were positive for Staphylococcus epidermidis.  Subsequently
column26: the patient had a good postoperative evolution
column27: with no associated complications
column28: and was discharged from hospital after completing the 5-week course of antibiotic treatment. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 42-year-old man from China with no past history of interest
column2: who came to the emergency department for an episode of syncope together with general malaise and dysthermia. He was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of possible septic shock of respiratory origin with bilateral necrotising pneumonia. Imaging tests showed abscesses in the lung
column3: kidney and liver
column4: as well as a thrombus in the inferior vena cava and in the cavo-auricular junction. An echocardiogram was performed
column5: showing a large multilobulated mass with apparent origin in the Eustachian valve. In the first blood cultures and bronchial aspirate Klebsiella pneumoniae was isolated. Subsequent blood cultures isolated oxacycline-resistant coagulase-negative Staphylococcus epidermidis. Subsequently
column6: no new microorganisms were isolated
column7: and the rest of the cultures were sterile. The main diagnostic possibilities were myxoma
column8: vegetation and thrombus. Despite antibiotic and anticoagulant treatment
column9: new abscesses and pulmonary lesions continued to appear and echocardiography showed no changes in the mass
column10: so that
column11: given the suspicion of vegetation with/without associated thrombus
column12: complete surgical resection under extracorporeal circulation was decided upon. In order to carry out the intervention with the greatest possible safety for venous drainage
column13: percutaneous cannulation of the femoral vein (progressing the cannula to the inferior vena cava) and cannulation of the superior vena cava were chosen. A right longitudinal atriotomy and temporary release of the inferior vena cava tourniquet was performed for resection of the pedicle implantation base. The resected mass had a pedicle insertion into the Eustachian valve and was approximately 35 × 10 mm in size. As the Eustachian valve was a large and prominent structure
column14: it was resected. No new abscesses or pulmonary lesions appeared after surgery. The microbiological study was sterile
column15: and the histopathological study of the mass was compatible with fibrino-thrombotic material
column16: so anticoagulant treatment was maintained. At the end of the course of intravenous antibiotherapy
column17: the patient was discharged without sequelae and underwent rehabilitation. After 4 months of follow-up he was in functional class I
column18: the control echocardiogram showed no new intracardiac masses and the imaging tests showed resolving pulmonary lesions with no new abscesses. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 72-year-old man with an aortic bioprosthesis implanted in 2010 was diagnosed with prosthetic endocarditis due to Enterococcus faecalis 5 years after surgery. The transesophageal echocardiogram showed an abscess at the level of the mitroaortic junction
column2: 11 mm in diameter
column3: with a 9 mm vegetation attached to the ventricular side of the non-coronary leaflet.  A computed axial tomography (CT) scan revealed a large abscess with gas within it
column4: at the level of the aortic root
column5: extending into the right ventricular outflow tract. Gas bubbles were also present within the pulmonary artery trunk. A positron emission tomography (PET)/CT scan with 18F-fluoro-2-deoxyglucose (18F-FDG) confirmed the extension of the infection in both locations.  At surgery
column6: the infected prosthesis was replaced with a cryopreserved aortic valve homograft
column7: sutured subcoronary. Surgical samples were positive for the same microorganism isolated from the blood. No macroscopic involvement of the main pulmonary artery was found. The free wall of the right ventricular outflow tract was explored
column8: and although it was compacted
column9: its puncture did not yield any pathological product
column10: ruling out frank collections at that level.  The postoperative period was uneventful. The control 18F-FDG PET/CT scan showed no evidence of residual gas or significant 18F-FDG uptake. Control blood cultures were similarly negative. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 62-year-old male.  History No known drug allergies. Baseline functional status: independent for daily activities
column3: higher functions preserved. Active life without dyspnoea or angina. No family history of sudden death or early ischaemic heart disease. Non-smoker. As the only cardiovascular risk factor: arterial hypertension (AHT)
column4: on pharmacological treatment with telmisartan/amlodipine 80/10 mg (1-0-0). No known previous heart disease. Other personal medical history: anxiety disorder being monitored by psychiatry and treated with ziprasidone 40 mg (0-0-1)
column5: lorazepam 5 mg (0-0-0.5)
column6: mirtazapine 30 mg (0-0-1) and vortioxetine 10 mg (1-0-0).  Present illness An asymptomatic patient
column7: while in a shoe shop
column8: suddenly lost consciousness witnessed by his wife without subsequent recovery
column9: so she called the emergency services. On arrival of the first resuscitators (after 5-8 minutes without basic CPR) they observed CPR in a defibrillable rhythm for the AED. S1e administered 2 adrenaline and 4 AED shocks. After advanced life support arrived
column10: the patient persisted in CPR with a shockable rhythm
column11: so a new shock was administered and spontaneous circulation was restored. In the output electrocardiogram (ECG)
column12: atrial fibrillation (AF) rhythm with ventricular response at 160 bpm with ST elevation in I
column13: aVL and V3-V6. After this
column14: in view of the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 3 points
column15: orotracheal intubation (OTI) was performed. Contact was made with our cardiology department and
column16: in view of CRA due to shockable rhythm with anterolateral ST elevation
column17: it was decided to transfer the patient directly to the haemodynamics department for emergent coronary angiography
column18: and the hypothermia protocol was initiated. Total time of cardiorespiratory arrest: 20 minutes. Time without assistance: 5-8 minutes.  Physical examination On arrival at hospital: blood pressure (BP) 139/87 mmHg; heart rate (HR) 94 bpm; post-OIOT oxygen saturation 100%; afebrile. GCS 4 points. On admission he was kept on sedative treatment with continuous perfusion of midazolam. Intubated
column19: well adapted to the ventilator with FiO2 35%
column20: normal colour and well perfused. On examination: no jugular plethora. Rhythmic cardiac auscultation without murmurs. Normal pulmonary auscultation
column21: good bilateral ventilation. Abdomen soft and depressible. No oedema or evidence of venous thrombosis in the lower extremities
column22: with palpable pulses.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS AED recording: ventricular fibrillation arrest rhythm. ECG (immediately after discharge): atrial fibrillation with ventricular response at 160 bpm and ST elevation of up to 3 mm anterolateral (lateral and precordial). ECG on admission to the coronary unit: sinus rhythm at 100 bpm
column23: axis at 60o
column24: normal PR
column25: narrow QRS. Normal QT. Correct progression of R in precordial leads. No acute repolarisation abnormalities. No early repolarisation pattern. Post-PCR analysis on admission: Biochemical parameters within normal range
column26: including lipid profile
column27: with renal function and ions (magnesium
column28: sodium
column29: calcium
column30: potassium) in range. Normal haemogram and coagulation. Initial myocardial damage markers: CK 181 U/l and ultrasensitive TnT 187 ng/l (N: 0-14); with maximum peak CK 2
column31: 127 U/l and ultrasensitive TnT 951 ng/l. Urine toxicity test: negative. Emergency echocardioscopy: LV neither dilated nor hypertrophic with preserved global and segmental systolic function
column32: hyperdynamic. No significant valvulopathies. RV not dilated with good function. No pericardial effusion.  Emergency tests performed on arrival: Emergent coronary angiography: coronary arteries without lesions. Cerebral CT and thoraco-abdominal CT angiography: no significant findings. Transthoracic echocardiogram (in coronary unit): left ventricle (LV) not dilated or hypertrophic with preserved systolic function (LVEF 65%) without alterations in segmental contractility. Diastolic pattern of elongated relaxation (E/E'9). Normal left atrium (20 cm2). Right ventricle (RV) not dilated and with good function. Trivalve aortic valve with preserved opening
column33: without functional alterations. Aortic root not dilated (30 mm). Mitral valve of normal appearance with minimal insufficiency. Tricuspid valve with mild insufficiency. Inferior vena cava not dilated with inspiratory collapse > 50%. Estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure (PSAP) of 25 mmHg. No pericardial effusion.  Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) on the general cardiology hospital ward: non-dilated left ventricle (LV) with preserved global and segmental function (LVEF 62%). Mild-moderate concentric LV hypertrophy (12-13 mm). Non-dilated right ventricle (RV) with preserved global and segmental function (RVEF 63%). In the late enhancement sequences no pathological uptakes were seen. Findings compatible with hypertensive heart disease
column34: with good biventricular function
column35: without pathological enhancements.  Negative for the phenotype of long QT syndrome: standing ECG with normal QTc (440 ms) and stress test with measurement of QTc at the 4th minute of recovery also normal (445 ms). During the stress test
column36: there were no arrhythmic events compatible with catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. Negative for Brugada syndrome phenotype: modified ECG negative for Brugada pattern in right precordial leads
column37: and negative flecainide test: normal basal sinus rhythm
column38: normal atrioventricular (AV) conduction and normal QRS. The test was negative
column39: although during the pharmacological test with flecainide
column40: the frequent appearance of monomorphic ventricular extrasystoles with right bundle branch block morphology (RBBB) and superior axis
column41: suggestive of origin in the posterior fascicle
column42: drew attention. Finally
column43: with the history of ST elevation in the ECG after the arrest
column44: it was decided to perform an echocardiographic test with ergobasin: clinically
column45: electrically and echocardiographically negative.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was admitted to the coronary unit after coronary angiography
column46: cerebral-thoracic-abdominal CT and TTE without alterations. After haemodynamic stabilisation with a slow but progressive neurological improvement
column47: and without new arrhythmic events on telemetry
column48: it was decided to transfer him to the general cardiology hospital ward to complete the study with advanced cardiac imaging and provocation tests for channelopathies or coronary vasospasm
column49: the results of which have been detailed previously. The patient remains cardiologically asymptomatic throughout the hospital stay. He was monitored with telemetry
column50: with no recorded arrhythmic events
column51: and daily ECGs were performed
column52: with normal QTc in all of them.  The tests performed during admission ruled out the main causes of cardiac arrest: 1. Ischaemia: normal coronary network in urgent coronary angiography. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging also showed no pathological ischaemic enhancements. 2. Structural: no evidence of pulmonary thromboembolism (PTE) or cardiac tamponade in emergency echocardiography or CT; no evidence of underlying cardiomyopathy in regular transthoracic echocardiography or cardiac magnetic resonance imaging. 3. Channelopathies: negative provocation tests for long QT syndrome
column53: Brugada
column54: and catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. The baseline ECG also shows no short QTc morphology or early repolarisation pattern. 4. Coronary vasospasm: negative ergobasin echocardiography test. 5. No toxic-metabolic alterations to justify the picture. The patient had no family history of sudden death or early ischaemic heart disease. His father has permanent atrial fibrillation and his mother has paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. On discharge
column55: his two children and his sister
column56: all of whom were healthy
column57: were referred to the family heart disease clinic for an ECG and transthoracic echocardiogram. A diagnosis of idiopathic ventricular fibrillation was established. A subcutaneous implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) was placed for secondary prevention
column58: and the patient underwent outpatient monitoring in the electrophysiology department.  DIAGNOSIS Out-of-hospital CRA resuscitated by shockable rhythm. Idiopathic ventricular fibrillation: Angiographically normal coronary network. No structural heart disease. Good biventricular function. Pharmacological tests to unmask channelopathy and vasospasm negative. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  Personal history Allergies: doubtful intolerance to penicillin (syncope in youth after IM penicillin)

Mild to moderate pericardial effusion of global distribution
column114: predominantly posterior and lateral (posterior 12 mm -especially posteroapical-

column121: which was present in most of the analytical controls prior to the clinical picture. Haematology was contacted and ruled out monoclonal expansion and alteration of fusion genes (tyrosine kinase). Cardio-MRI was performed
column122: showing findings compatible with eosinophilic endomyocarditis (or Loeffler's) with intraventricular thrombus
column123: so treatment was started with methylprenisolone 1g IV and later changed to prednisone 1 mg/kg/day
column124: with a gradual decrease in eosinophil numbers and pericardial effusion. In addition
column125: enoxaparin was started at an anticoagulant dose. Within hours of enoxaparin administration
column126: the patient presented a reaction consisting of erythematous exanthema with central clearing involving both inguinal flexures
column127: which was categorised by dermatology as SDRIFE (symmetric drug-related intertriginous and flexural exanthema) attenuated by corticosteroids
column128: recommending the replacement of enoxaparin with bemiparin. Subsequent echocardiography showed a reduction in pericardial effusion
column129: located mainly at the posterolateral level
column130: which did not require drainage. Given the favourable response and compatible findings in cardio-MRI with idiopathic hypereosinophilic hypereosinophilic syndrome with cardiac involvement (eosinophilic endomyocarditis)
column131: endomyocardial endomyocarditis was rejected for confirmation given the invasiveness of this test and the limited experience in our centre. Troponin I levels plateaued at 6
column132: 000 ng/l for the first 6 days and subsequently decreased to normal. During his stay in the coronary unit he remained haemodynamically stable
column133: with no arrhythmic events and resolution of flu-like symptoms (arthromyalgia
column135: etc.). After transfer to the cardiology ward
column136: he presented adequate tolerance to ambulation and remained asymptomatic
column137: so he was discharged home with therapeutic adjustment and follow-up in outpatient clinics.  Treatment on discharge: Bemiparin 10
column138: 000 IU subcutaneous daily as a bridge to acenocoumarol. Acenocoumarol according to guideline. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History Young 19-year-old male Family history: paternal grandfather died at an advanced age due to massive pulmonary thromboembolism. Father and mother without thrombosis. Mother without miscarriages. No known drug allergies. Primary antiphospholipid syndrome: diagnosed after an episode of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in 2017. High-risk serological profile: triple antibody positivity (AL + aCL + Antiβ2-GPI positive). Active smoker of 3-5 cigarettes/day. No surgical history. Usual treatment: acenocoumarol.  Present illness A 19-year-old male presented to the emergency department for oppressive central thoracic pain with associated vegetative crusade of 3 hours' duration that started during exercise and did not subside with rest. It did not radiate
column3: did not change with movement or breathing
column4: no palpitations
column5: dyspnoea or infectious symptoms. He admits not having taken the dose of acenocoumarol for the previous 5 days for fear of its interaction with alcohol
column6: which he had consumed.  Physical examination Blood pressure (BP) 130/85 mmHg. Heart rate (HR) 65 bpm. Basal oxygen saturation 99%. Respiratory rate 16 rpm. Good general condition. Conscious and oriented. Afebrile. Sweating. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic without murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur
column7: without added sounds. Lower extremities without oedema or signs of DVT.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Emergency ECG: Sinus bradycardia at 55 bpm. Normal PR. Narrow QRS with normal axis. ST elevation of 3-4 mm in DII
column8: DIII and aVF and 1-1.5 mm in V5-V6
column9: specular ST descent in DI and aVL. Laboratory tests: INR on arrival 1.1. Haemoglobin 15.6 g/dl
column10: leukocytes 11
column12: platelets 177
column13: 000 /μl. Troponin I (hs-TnI normal range 0-53.5) initial 5
column15: peak 116
column17: HbA1C 5.5%
column18: total cholesterol 136 mg/dl
column19: HDL 37 mg/dl
column20: LDL 62 mg/dl
column21: triglycerides 188 mg/dl
column22: creatinine 0.86 mg/dl
column23: glomerular filtration rate > 90 ml/min
column24: sodium 136 mmol/l
column25: potassium 3.5 mmol/l
column26: TSH 1 μIU/ml
column27: iron profile normal. Emergent coronary catheterisation: right radial access. Truncus: no lesions. Anterior descending coronary artery (AD): normal development
column28: no angiographic lesions. Circumflex coronary artery (Cx): no angiographic lesions. Right coronary artery (RCA): dominant
column29: complete thrombotic occlusion in the middle segment. Percutaneous coronary interventionism (PCI): guidewire is advanced to the distal RCA and several thrombus aspirations are performed
column30: obtaining abundant red thrombus. TIMI 3 flow was recovered and a long lesion was observed with slight stenosis and remnants of thrombus in the mid-distal DC. Distal bed of good development and without lesions. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) was performed
column31: which showed remains of red thrombus adhered to the wall
column32: without images suggestive of plaque rupture
column33: in a vessel with no signs of atherosclerosis
column34: although at some points the arterial wall was not visible due to the presence of thrombus. In view of these findings
column35: it was decided not to implant a stent. Transthoracic echocardiogram: left ventricle not dilated or hypertrophic
column36: with normal overall systolic function (LVEF by Simpson biplane of 54%). Akinesia of medial and basal segments of inferior and inferolateral face. E/E' ratio of 7.5. Right ventricle of normal size and function. Atria of normal size. Mild mitral insufficiency. Mild tricuspid insufficiency that allows estimating a PSAP of 35 mmHg. Normal aortic root and ascending aorta. No pericardial effusion. ECG at discharge: sinus rhythm at 75 bpm. Normal PR. Narrow QRS with Q wave and negative T waves in inferior (DII
column37: DIII
column38: aVF) and lateral (V4-V6).  CLINICAL EVOLUTION On arrival
column39: an electrocardiogram was performed showing ST elevation and the haemodynamic alert was activated for emergent coronary catheterisation. Thrombotic occlusion was observed in the right coronary artery
column40: and thromboaspiration and balloon angioplasty were performed
column41: recovering TIMI 3 flow. Intracoronary imaging with OCT was performed with visualisation of residual red thrombus adhered to the wall
column42: with no evidence of plaque rupture or atherosclerosis. In view of these findings
column43: it was decided not to implant a stent. A transthoracic echocardiogram was performed with normal global function and segmental alteration in the DC territory. Double antiplatelet therapy and anticoagulation were started. The patient remained monitored during admission
column44: stable
column45: reintroducing oral anticoagulation
column46: with no complications of renal function or radial puncture. Since this was a thrombotic event
column47: in the context of incorrect anticoagulation and with coronary arteries without lesions
column48: it was decided to maintain anticoagulation and indefinite statins together with antiplatelet therapy with acetylsalicylic acid for one month. On discharge
column49: the patient was referred to the cardiac rehabilitation programme. A coronary CT scan at 2 months showed epicardial coronary arteries without lesions.  DIAGNOSIS Acute inferolateral myocardial infarction of thrombotic origin. Urgent right coronary artery revascularisation. Preserved LV systolic function. Primary antiphospholipid syndrome with high-risk profile. Abandonment of oral anticoagulant therapy. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 47-year-old woman referred for syncope with 2:1 atrioventricular block (AVB).  History Independent for ABVD
column3: but in need of support. Lives with her parents. Separated. No known drug allergies. No family history of heart disease or early sudden cardiac death. No toxic habits. No cardiovascular risk factors. Normal weight (weight 57.5 kg
column4: height 1.58 m). Mitochondrial cytopathy phenotype MELAS (diagnosis at 23 years of age). Predominance of severe sensorineural deafness and exercise intolerance due to myopathy. On treatment with valproate and phenobarbital
column5: with last complex tonic comical seizure 1 year ago. CT scan with no new lesions. Frequent hyponatremia. Right bundle branch block and left anterior hemiblock. Surgical interventions: cholecystectomy (2012) and appendectomy in childhood. Usual medication: valproate 500 mg 1-1-1
column6: phenobarbital 50 mg 0-0-1
column7: ubiquinone 100 mg 0-1-0
column8: lorazepam 1 mg 0-0-0-1.  Present illness Anamnesis through the family for aphasia and severe hypoacusis of the patient. They report that on waking up in the morning she is pale with sweating and nausea. Subsequently
column9: dizziness intensified
column10: falling to the floor with loss of consciousness and rapid recovery.  The emergency service was called
column11: but the clinical manifestations persisted on arrival
column12: revealing a 2:1 AVB
column13: conducted heartbeat with morphology of left bundle branch block. She was referred to the regional hospital
column14: being asymptomatic on arrival and with ECG in sinus rhythm with AV conduction 1:1. No chest pain
column15: palpitations
column16: dyspnoea or other accompanying symptoms. She was referred to our centre for cardiology assessment.  Physical examination Blood pressure (BP) 92/62 mmHg
column17: heart rate (HR) 72 bpm
column18: SatO99%
column19: temperature 35 oC. Conscious and oriented. No neurological focality. Rhythmic tones
column20: no murmurs or rubs. Symmetrical pulses. No jugular ingurgitation. No oedema. Good bilateral air entry
column21: no extra sounds. Abdomen soft
column22: slight distension at epigastric level
column23: not painful on palpation. Peristalsis preserved.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS First ECG (performed by the emergency service at the first medical contact): BAV 2:1 at 35 bpm
column24: conducted beat with QRS of 110 msec with short PR of 100 msec and electrical image compatible with negative delta wave in V1
column25: positive in V3-V6
column26: II
column27: III
column28: aVF. ECG on admission to our centre: sinus rhythm at 80 bpm
column29: AV conduction 1:1 PR 100 ms and QRS of 110 msec with image compatible with pre-excitation
column30: similar to the previous one. Posteroanterior chest X-ray performed in the emergency room of our centre: normal cardiac silhouette. No condensation in the lung parenchyma. No signs of heart failure or pleural effusion. Initial blood tests: glucose 305 mg/dl
column31: creatinine 0.8 mg/dl (GFR > 90 ml/min)
column33: CK 328 mU/ml
column34: TnUs 61 ng/l
column35: Na 130 mEq/l (corrected 136 mEq/l)
column36: K 4.6 mEq/l. Haemogram: leucocytes 13.1x109 l (N 53.1%
column38: haemoglobin 12.1 g/dl
column39: haematocrit 36%
column40: platelets 217 x109 l
column41: INR 0.98. Venous blood gas on admission: pH 7.231
column42: pCO2 40.7 mmHg
column43: HCO3 15.5 mEq/L
column44: EB -10.5 mEq/L
column45: lactate 8.6 mEq/l. Control blood test 5 hours after admission: CK 292 mU/ml
column46: troponin I US 100 ng/l
column47: lactate 4.4m Eq/l. Transthoracic echocardiogram: non-dilated left ventricle
column48: slightly concentrically hypertrophied
column49: with normal systolic diastolic function. No significant valvulopathies. Mild pulmonary hypertension (estimated PAPs 36-38 mmHg). Normal right ventricle.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION A 47-year-old woman with MELAS syndrome was admitted for symptomatic (syncopal) 2:1 AVB and with an image compatible with pre-excitation that persisted despite the conduction disorder
column50: leading to the diagnosis of an associated fasciculoventricular accessory pathway (origin posterior to the atrioventricular node). The echocardiogram showed mild ventricular hypertrophy with slightly elevated PSAP. Laboratory tests showed initial lactate of 8 mEq/l and later 4 mEq/l
column51: with slight initial acidosis that remained with slightly elevated lactate and was attributed to mitochondrial disease (previous lactate always elevated 2.5-11). Admitted to the coronary unit for close monitoring and implantation of a permanent pacemaker. Favourable evolution since admission
column52: remaining asymptomatic at all times
column53: in sinus rhythm with 1:1 AV conduction
column54: with no recurrence of bradyarrhythmia. Twenty-four hours after admission
column55: a bicameral pacemaker was implanted without incident and subsequently
column56: after verifying the normal functioning of the device and the absence of complications
column57: she was discharged home.  DIAGNOSIS Symptomatic 2:1 AV block (syncopal). Electrocardiographic image compatible with ventricular pre-excitation by a fasciculoventricular accessory pathway (considering persistence of QRS morphology despite AVB). MELAS syndrome (mitochondrial myopathy
column58: encephalopathy
column59: lactic acidosis
column60: and stroke). |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  Personal history No known drug allergies. Cardiovascular risk factors: dyslipidaemia under pharmacological treatment. Active cannabis smoker (7 cigarettes a day)
column3: former tobacco smoker (accumulated 2 packs/year). No known arterial hypertension (AHT) or diabetes mellitus (DM). No previous cardiological history.  Other: Testicular cancer (classic clinical stage IIA seminoma after right orchiectomy) on active treatment with QT (cisplatin + etoposide)
column4: he has only received one cycle. Ankylopoietic spondylitis diagnosed 6 years ago. Chronic treatment: atorvastatin 20 mg
column5: 1 tablet at dinner.  Present illness A 37-year-old man came to the emergency department with chest pain of approximately 1 hour's duration. It subsides after administration of paracetamol. He describes it as oppressive
column6: non-radiating
column7: with no accompanying vegetative cortex and onset at rest. It does not increase with inspiration or chest movements. No previous angina. Cough with expectoration for 4 days. No fever
column8: no dyspnoea
column9: no abdominal pain
column10: no alterations in bowel habits. No other symptoms.   Physical examination Blood pressure (BP) 125/82 mmHg
column11: heart rate (HR) 72 bpm
column12: basal O2 Sat 98%. Good general condition. Conscious
column13: oriented and cooperative. Normohydrated and normal colour. Eupneic at rest. No neurological focality. Jugular venous pressure normal. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column14: no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: vesicular murmur (vvm)
column15: without added noises. Abdomen: normal hydro-aerial sounds
column16: soft and depressible
column17: no pain on palpation. No signs of peritoneal irritation. Lower extremities: pulses preserved
column18: no oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Laboratory tests: Serial myocardial damage markers on admission (on arrival
column19: at 3 hours
column20: at 24 hours
column21: at 36 hours and at discharge): Biochemistry: glucose 101 mg/dl
column22: urea 52 mg/dl
column23: creatinine 1.13 mg/dl
column24: sodium 137 mmol/l
column25: potassium 4.5 mmol/l
column26: magnesium 2 mg/dl. Lipid profile: total cholesterol 220 mg/dl
column27: LDL 145 mg/dl
column28: HDL 45 mg/dl
column29: TG 147 mg/dl. HbA1c 5.4%. TSH 1.22 μUI/ml. Haemogram: Hb 15.6 g/dl
column30: MCV 85.6 fl
column31: MCH 28.8 pg
column34: platelets 222
column35: 000 /μl. Creatine kinase: 33 -> 47 -> 102 -> 47 -> 29 U/l. Troponin t US (normal < 14): 18 -> 102 -> 267 -> 140 -> 99 ng/l. Coagulation: INR 1.12
column36: prothrombin time 83.0 %2. Partial thromboplastin time 28.6 s
column37: partial thromboplastin time ratio 0.95. D-Dimer 411 ng/mg. Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus bradycardia around 50 bpm. Normal PR. Narrow QRS with normal axis
column38: without acute repolarisation alterations. Chest X-ray: normal CTI
column39: no masses
column40: no parenchymal condensations
column41: no signs of heart failure.  Coronary angiography on admission: Left coronary artery: no lesions. Anterior descending artery (LAD): long vessel of good calibre and development. Large intraluminal thrombus organised in the middle segment
column42: causing a stenosis of 60% and with TIMI 3 flow. Distal bed good
column43: without lesions or thrombotic material. Circumflex: vessel of good calibre and development
column44: without lesions. Right coronary: dominant
column45: without lesions.  Control coronary angiography (after one week of triple antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy): coronary arteries without angiographically significant lesions. Complete resolution of the previous thrombus. Transthoracic echocardiogram on admission
column46: prior to coronary angiography: left ventricle (LV) of normal size and thickness
column47: preserved ejection fraction (LVEF)
column48: with no alterations in regional contractility. No evidence of ventricular thrombus. No valvular heart disease. No pericardial effusion. Consultation with the medical oncology service: chemotherapy was suspended due to its association with arterial thrombotic events. Ipsilateral radiotherapy was proposed as an alternative treatment. ECG at discharge: sinus rhythm at 60 bpm. Normal PR. No pathological Q waves. Narrow QRS with normal axis
column49: without repolarisation alterations.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION 37-year-old male smoker and dyslipidaemic
column50: with a history of testicular seminoma and active treatment with chemotherapy (cisplatin + etoposide) with the last dose administered 8 days before admission. He was admitted for chest pain with mobilisation of markers of myocardial damage without changes in the ECG
column51: and it was decided to admit him as an acute myocardial infarction without ST segment elevation (STEMI)
column52: postulating a possible relationship with his pathology or oncological treatment. Treatment was started with anticoagulation with low molecular weight heparin and double antiplatelet therapy with acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) and clopidogrel. On admission
column53: coronary angiography showed an organised thrombus in the middle segment of the LAD with a stenosis of 60%. Given this history
column54: conservative management was decided
column55: initially with tirofiban perfusion for 24 hours and then a change to ticagrelor together with ASA and anticoagulation with low molecular weight heparin (triple antithrombotic therapy)
column56: with the idea of repeating the coronary angiography and trying to avoid stent implantation. After a week of treatment
column57: the coronary angiography was repeated and showed disappearance of the previous thrombus
column58: with no significant underlying lesions in the three vessels
column59: and anticoagulant treatment was then suspended. The transthoracic echocardiogram showed preserved LVEF. Good clinical evolution: asymptomatic
column60: haemodynamically stable and with troponins in decline. Finally
column61: he was discharged home to continue medical treatment with double platelet antiplatelet therapy with ASA and ticagrelor. From the point of view of his testicular cancer
column62: an assessment was requested from medical oncology
column63: who decided to suspend chemotherapy treatment due to the relationship of cisplatin with acute coronary thrombotic events
column64: proposing a change to radiotherapy (outpatient) and follow-up on his part.  DIAGNOSIS STEMI. Acute anterior descending thrombosis secondary to treatment with cisplatin
column65: resolved after one week of triple antiplatelet therapy and anticoagulation. Coronary arteries without underlying atherosclerotic lesions. Preserved LVEF. Classic stage IIA seminoma with active chemotherapy treatment (cisplatin + etoposide)
column66: which was discontinued. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Personal history Male patient aged 28 years. No known allergic reactions to medication. No cardiovascular risk factors. No known consumption of toxic substances. Cardiological history: no known heart disease. No other relevant pathologies. Family history: paternal uncle suffered from colorectal cancer at the age of 58. No other family history of interest. He does not take treatments on a regular basis.  Current illness Patient presented to the emergency department for sudden loss of consciousness while watching a football match. He did not present chest pain before or after the episode
column3: but did report an abrupt onset of palpitations at a high frequency in the moments prior to the event. He reported some previous general malaise
column4: but denied fever or infectious symptoms. He denied the use of drugs or toxic substances. The observers did not describe shaking or signs attributable to neurological focality. The patient's memory of the moments after regaining consciousness was preserved. During his transfer to out-of-hospital medical services
column5: he presented a new episode of loss of consciousness
column6: at which time the electrocardiographic recording showed a rhythm compatible with ventricular fibrillation
column7: which resolved after 2 shocks at 100 J
column8: restoring sinus rhythm.  Physical examination Temperature 36o C; blood pressure 159/83 mmHg; heart rate 86 bpm; O2 saturation 97% without contributions. No signs of tachypnoea at rest. Neurological examination without alterations. Cardiac auscultation was rhythmic
column9: without murmurs and pulmonary auscultation without pathological sounds. Abdominal examination showed no palpable organomegaly
column10: hepatojugular reflux was negative. The lower limbs were free of oedema and there were no signs of deep vein thrombosis. Pulses were strong and symmetrical.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Laboratory tests in the ED: leukocytes 8300 /ml
column11: haemoglobin 15.3 g/dl; platelets 235000 u/l. No coagulation alterations; basal glucose 108 mg/dl; urea 43 mg/dl; creatinine 0.67 mg/dl; estimated glomerular filtration rate (MDRD-4) 97 ml/min/1.73 m2; total bilirubin 0.6 mg/dl; GOT 22 IU/l; CPK 107 IU/l; Na 136 mmol/l; potassium 4.4 mmol/l; corrected calcium 9.5 mg/dl; magnesium 2 mg/dl; urine toxins/drugs of abuse: negative. Out-of-hospital electrocardiogram (ECG) during loss of consciousness: ventricular fibrillation rhythm evidenced during out-of-hospital monitoring. Baseline 12-lead surface ECG: sinus rhythm without pre-excitation or atrioventricular (AV) conduction block. QRS with Ic-oved type Brugada pattern morphology. A right bundle branch block morphology with rsR" complex is observed
column12: which continues with a descending ST that crosses the isoelectric line to continue with a negative T. The corrected QT interval is normal. The corrected QT interval is normal. As the electrostatic positioning is moved up one intercostal space the pattern becomes more evident. Urgent transthoracic echocardiogram: preserved systolic function
column13: without alterations of segmental contractility. Chambers neither dilated nor hypertrophic. Tricuspid aortic valve with no remarkable valvulopathy. Normally functioning mitral valve. No other significant valvulopathies were observed. No pericardial effusion. Inferior vena cava not dilated
column14: with adequate inspiratory collapsibility. Conclusion: study within normal parameters Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): MRI study with anatomical sequences in the axial plane enhanced in T1 and T2
column15: cine sequences in short axis
column16: four chambers and right ventricular outflow tract (RV) and
column17: finally
column18: late enhancement in short axis and four chambers. Anatomical assessment: cavities neither hypertrophic nor dilated
column19: within normal limits: left atrium 58 x 20 mm; right atrium 52 x 46 mm; left ventricle 55 x 98 mm; right ventricle 42 x 88 mm. Interventricular septum 9 mm with free wall 7 mm. Right ventricle wall 3 mm. No contractility alterations were observed. No oedema is seen in the T2 sequences. No late enhancement after gadolinium administration. There was no pericardial effusion. In the functional study the following parameters were found: left ventricular ejection fraction 58.8%; stroke volume 104.3 ml; cardiac output 5.5 l/min; end-diastolic volume 177.5 ml; end-systolic volume 73.2 ml. Conclusion: no pathological findings. Study not suggestive of structural cardiomyopathy (video 1). Genetic study: channelopathies panel. Missense mutation in geSnCN5. Sequence NM_198056. Nucleotide change G298S.    CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was admitted to the cardiology department for study of underlying heart disease and intensive monitoring with the option of defibrillation. A morphological study was performed with transthoracic echocardiography and cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) (video 1). After completing a study that ruled out other heart disease and after the surface ECG of one of the daily controls showed a spontaneous Brugada pattern type 1 (shark fin)
column20: the patient was diagnosed with Brugada syndrome and the implantation of an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) was indicated for secondary prevention. As this was the first known event
column21: hygienic-dietary and lifestyle recommendations were made
column22: but no further treatment was indicated. During follow-up
column23: with quarterly reviews of the device
column24: asymptomatic low-density ventricular extrasystoles were detected
column25: and beta-blocker treatment with carvedilol 6.25 mg daily was started. A genetic study was performed for family counselling (presenting a missense mutation in the SCN5 gene) and clinical assessment of the family
column26: in which the father was found to be a carrier of the mutation
column27: although with an anodyne surface ECG and negative provocation test. The mother had a type 2 electrocardiographic pattern
column28: although the provocation test and genetic study were negative. At subsequent follow-up
column29: at 7 months
column30: she presented a new syncopal episode with appropriate discharge of the device due to the presence of ventricular fibrillation (VF) with a 180 ms cycle apparently triggered by ventricular extrasystole with right ventricular outflow tract morphology. A new morphological study was performed
column31: which was anodyne
column33: toxins
column34: metabolic alterations
column35: etc.) and it was proposed to start treatment with quinidine
column36: which the patient refused. The dose of carvedilol was increased to 12.5 mg daily. Outpatient follow-up continued when
column37: after 7 months
column38: he presented another episode with 2 shocks due to ventricular fibrillation with similar characteristics to those previously described. Treatment was then started with quinidine at a dose of 200 mg every 6 hours. After 13 months of treatment with quinidine
column39: the patient had no new shocks or events during follow-up. There have been no adverse effects related to drug treatment.  DIAGNOSIS Brugada syndrome with spontaneous type I pattern and pathological mutation. Recurrent ventricular fibrillation. Carrier of implantable automatic defibrillator in secondary prevention. Absence of structural heart disease in morphological studies. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  Personal history Steinert's myotonic dystrophy. Works in a car parts factory. Intervened 8 years earlier for OS type ASD by minimally invasive surgery (modified Heart Port type right mini-thoracotomy). Postoperative course without apparent complications.  Present illness A 45-year-old woman presented to the emergency department with dyspnoea on exertion of about 5 years' duration (NYHA functional class I-II/IV)
column3: progressing to minimal exertion (NYHA III/IV) with the appearance of cyanosis in recent months.  Physical examination Weight 50 kg
column4: height 1.60 m. Body mass index (BMI) 19.5 kg/m . Blood pressure (BP) 104/82 mmHg. Heart rate (HR) 80 bpm. O2 saturation (SatO2) 75% on room air. Eupneic at rest
column5: without orthopnoea or platypnoea. Generalised cyanosis. Jugular venous pressure normal. Negative hepatojugular reflex. Absence of acropacities. Cardiac auscultation: regular
column6: no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur. No aggregates. Extremities: No oedema. Peripheral pulses preserved and symmetrical.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus rhythm at 93 bpm. PR 120 ms. QRS 60 ms. QTc 398ms. No repolarisation alterations. CBC: haemoglobin 20 g/dl
column7: haematocrit 62%
column8: platelets 144
column10: leukocytes 7400/μl. Erythropoietin 7.71 mlU/ml (2.59-18.5). International normalised ratio (INR) 1.05. Basal glycaemia 82 mg/dl. Urea 36 mg/dl
column11: creatinine 0.81 mg/dl
column12: sodium 137 mEq/l
column13: potassium 4.1 mEq/l. Arterial blood gases: pH 7.42
column14: pCO2 35 mmHg
column15: pO2 41 mmHg
column18: lactate 1 mmol/l. Chest X-ray: cardiomediastinal silhouette centred. Cardiothoracic index (CTI) less than 0.5. Translucent lung fields without pleural effusion or condensation. Transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiogram: transesophageal examination (without sedation due to baseline hypoxaemia): atrial septal defect without significant residual shunt (minimal shunt at the level of the pericardial patch without any functional repercussions). Left ventricle with preserved diameters
column19: volumes and global systolic function. No alterations in segmental contractility were observed. No significant valvulopathies. Left ventricular diastolic pattern within normality. Right ventricle of normal diameters with preserved global systolic function. Mild tricuspid insufficiency allowing PAPs 20-25 mmHg to be quantified. Normal inferior vena cava. Sinus rhythm. Injection of gelafundin shows no bubble passage to left cavities when administered in both upper limbs. Angio-CT: no evidence of repletion defects in main
column20: lobar
column21: segmental or sub-segmental pulmonary arteries suggestive of pulmonary thromboembolism (PTE). No signs of pulmonary hypertension or pulmonary infarcts. No pulmonary nodules or pulmonary consolidations are evident. No pleural or pericardial effusion. No bone lesions suggestive of malignancy. No other relevant findings by this technique. Ventilation/perfusion scintigraphy: scintigraphic study with no perfusion or ventilation defects. Spirometry: discrete pulmonary restriction
column22: with normal diffusion. Cardiac magnetic resonance: left ventricle (LV) with small volumes (LVOT 38 ml/m
column23: STV 13 ml/m
column24: LVMI 35 g/m) without significant hypertrophy of its walls or alterations of segmental contractility at rest and with preserved global systolic function (GSF) (LVEF 66%). Non-dilated right ventricle (RV) (RVOT 14 ml/m
column25: STV 5 ml/m) with preserved global systolic function (LVEF 62%). Aorta and great vessels of normal diameter and morphology. Atria of normal dimensions. QP/QS (1.4/4.1)= 0.34
column26: indicative of right left shunt. Gadoteric acid (0.15 mM/kg) was administered for 3D vascular study: aorta and pulmonary trunk with normal diameters and morphology. Abnormal systemic drainage is observed with drainage of the inferior vena cava into the left atrium (LA). Normal pulmonary vein drainage. Necrosis and viability study: absence of myocardial LGE suggestive of necrosis/fibrosis. Conclusion: anomalous systemic drainage with inferior vena cava draining into the LA with QP/QS of 0.34 (indicative of left right shunt) with LV and RV volumes and preserved GSF.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION Given the clinical suspicion of a residual right-to-left shunt
column27: transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) and transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) were initially requested to try to confirm the diagnosis. Both studies demonstrated normal biventricular function without associated pulmonary hypertension. Contrast was administered through both upper limbs with no evidence of bubble passage to the left cavities. Continuing with the diagnostic process
column28: a pulmonary CT scan and a ventilation/perfusion scan were performed
column29: both with normal results. However
column30: given the high clinical suspicion
column31: it was decided to conclude the study with a cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) in which an anomalous drainage of the inferior vena cava (IVC) to the left atrium was observed. In view of these findings
column32: an anatomical correction of the anomalous IVC drainage was performed. During the operation
column33: a repaired atrial septal defect (ASD) located in the lower portion of the atrial septum was observed
column34: with a prominent Eustachian valve and an erroneous suture causing drainage of the IVC into the left atrium (LA). In the absence of postoperative complications
column35: the patient was discharged and remained asymptomatic with normal arterial blood gases and echocardiography.  DIAGNOSIS Anomalous drainage of the inferior vena cava in the left atrium after surgical repair of atrial septal defect. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION This is a 37-year-old female patient
column3: with no family or personal history of interest
column4: except for smoking (pack-year index: 15)
column5: which was her only known cardiovascular risk factor. He had been under cardiology consultation for 20 years due to palpitations. These symptoms corresponded to frequent monomorphic ventricular extrasystoles with an extrasystolic load of up to 20% and non-sustained ventricular tachycardias of up to 8-10 complexes
column6: without echocardiographic or cardiac MRI evidence of structural heart disease
column7: gadolinium enhancement or deterioration of left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF). He had recently undergone a coronary CT scan with a calcium score of 0 points and coronary artery disease was ruled out by non-invasive coronary angiography. During this period
column8: several attempts were made to initiate antiarrhythmic treatment (beta-blockers
column9: calcium antagonists
column10: amiodarone and flecainide)
column11: which he was unable to tolerate due to marked asthenia
column12: dizziness and hypotension. Since the summer of 2019
column13: she has presented clinical deterioration that she refers to as increased palpitations
column14: mainly on exertion and limitation of physical activity
column15: without associated chest pain and without a clear increase in functional class
column16: orthopnoea or oedematisation of the lower limbs. He has never presented with syncopal or presyncopal symptoms.  At the first consultation (September 2019)
column17: a new attempt was made to start beta-blockers at low doses (nebivolol 1.25 mg/24 h) and she was assessed again in consultation 3 weeks after starting treatment with transthoracic echocardiography
column18: ergometry and Holter-ECG.  Physical examination in consultation: good general condition
column19: blood pressure 95/60 mmHg
column20: heart rate (HR) 80 bpm. Baseline SpO2 99%. Afebrile. Head and neck: no jugular venous engorgement. Cardiac auscultation: arrhythmic sounds at 75 bpm without murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: normoventilation in all fields Abdomen: nondescript. Lower extremities: no oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Initial electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus rhythm at 90 bpm
column21: normal PR
column22: narrow QRS
column23: isolated supraventricular extrasystoles. Ventricular extrasystoles with right bundle branch block (RBBB) morphology
column24: inferior axis and V1-V2 transition. Holter ECG (under treatment with nebivolol 1.25 mg/24 h): sinus rhythm throughout the tracing with adequate heart rates (mean 65
column25: maximum 130 and min 45 bpm). Frequent monomorphic ventricular extrasystoles (extrasystolic load 17.2% (previous load 12%)
column26: sometimes grouped in the form of ventricular bigeminy and 2 short bursts of up to 9 complexes (coinciding with the time of physical activity reported by the patient between 13 and 14 h). Very isolated supraventricular extrasystoles. No significant bradycardias or pauses. Conventional ergometry: Bruce protocol on treadmill: stopped at the beginning of stage 4
column27: at 9 min 34 of exercise due to physical fatigue
column28: reaching 165 bpm (90% of maximum theoretical HR). No clinical signs suggestive of angina. 12.3 METS
column29: good functional capacity for age and sex. No alterations in the ST. Adequate blood pressure behaviour. Monomorphic ventricular extrasystoles throughout the recording
column30: which became more frequent during maximum effort and early recovery by means of ventricular trigeminy. Isolated ventricular doublet without VT. Conclusion: ventricular extrasystoles more frequent during maximal exercise without complex forms. Clinically and electrically negative for ischaemia.  Transthoracic echocardiogram: left atrium not dilated. Normal mitral valve. Minimal central insufficiency. Normal filling pressures. Left ventricle not dilated (VTDVI 4C 114 cm
column31: VTSVI 4C 44 cm)
column32: nor hypertrophied. Biplane LVEF 59.7% without segmental alterations. Trivalve aortic valve
column33: normal flow. Aortic root not dilated. Non dilated right chambers with normal contractility (TAPSE 28). Tricuspid valve with normal flow. No indirect evidence of pulmonary hypertension. No pericardial effusion.  Blood analysis: no alterations
column34: including normal TSH. Electrophysiological study (images 3-6 and video 2): double right femoral venous puncture. Introduction of a decapolar diagnostic catheter in the coronary sinus and tetrapolar to His-VD. Pacing protocol was performed from the base of the RV at two frequencies and two extras
column35: basal and under isoproterol perfusion without inducing tachycardia
column36: although extras appeared spontaneously. Right femoral arterial puncture and introduction of Orion catheter. The Rhythmia® system was used to map LVOT and aortic sinuses first (surface ECG with ventricular extrasystoles at the BRD and inferior axis
column37: r wave in V1-V2 and V2 transition). Subsequent RVOT mapping. The best precocities (24 ms) are found with respect to QRS onset between the left and right aortic sinus
column38: with fragmented bipolar electrogram and unipolar qs. Pacemapping was performed from the theoretical ablation point
column39: obtaining ventricular complexes that were 98% concordant with the mapped extrasystole. After verifying by electroanatomical integration with previous coronary CT a distance > 6 mm (14 mm) with respect to the LMCA ostium
column40: and absence of proximity to His
column41: radiofrequency ablation was performed (40 W
column42: 48o C) with a gold-tipped irrigated catheter at that point
column43: and the extrasystoles disappeared after the third second of the single application. After 10 min after ablation
column44: the pacing protocol was repeated without the appearance of extrasystoles.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION At the next consultation (October 2019)
column45: the patient reported withdrawal of medication due to orthostatism and marked asthenia. The results of the tests requested in the previous consultation highlighted an increase in extrasystolic load in Holter-ECG (17.2%
column46: which was 5% more than in the previous one) with very brief and isolated bouts of ventricular tachycardia (VT)
column47: without deterioration of systolic function in echocardiography. Given the evolution of our patient
column48: and in accordance with her preferences
column49: an electrophysiological study was proposed. We explained in detail the suspected left origin of the extrasystoles
column50: probably in the region of the LV outflow tract or aortic cusps
column51: and the risks derived both from the approach and from a possible ablation in this region
column52: which she accepted. An electrophysiological study (November 2019) revealed the left origin of the extrasystoles
column53: specifically between the left and right aortic cusps. After checking the safety distance with respect to His and aostium of the coronary arteries
column54: radiofrequency was applied in this region
column55: which was successful
column56: achieving the disappearance of the arrhythmia. After verifying the absence of post-procedural complications
column57: the patient was discharged after 24 hours. Since then
column58: she has visited us twice
column59: reporting a very significant clinical improvement. In the control Holter-ECG only very isolated ventricular extrasystoles were recorded (150 VE in 24 h)
column60: so she is not currently receiving any antiarrhythmic treatment.  DIAGNOSIS Frequent ventricular extrasystoles originating in the left ventricular outflow tract. Electrophysiological study --> successful ablation of the extrasystolic focus.
