column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  Background 27-year-old male
column3: student and candidate for the state security forces. Athletic build
column4: with no known toxic habits or metabolic disorders.  Cardiological history: No cardiological history of interest
column5: no family history of heart disease or sudden death.  Other history: Infiltrating adenocarcinoma of the rectosigmoid junction T2N2
column6: diagnosed after anaemia study five months before the episode. Treated by laparoscopic rectosigmoidectomy one month after diagnosis. Currently on chemotherapy treatment with oxaliplatin and capecitabine
column7: having received a first cycle 15 days before the cardiorespiratory arrest. Stage II pulmonary sarcoidosis
column8: diagnosed four months before the episode
column9: following extension studies of the rectal neoplasia. Diagnosis confirmed by biopsy of paratracheal adenopathy and untreated at the time of cardiorespiratory arrest. No other medical treatment apart from chemotherapy (oxaliplatin and capecitabine
column10: having received a first cycle 15 days ago).  Current illness The patient suffered a cardiorespiratory arrest during a football match. On arrival of the emergency services
column11: advanced cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) was started and the patient presented with a shockable rhythm of ventricular fibrillation. After two shocks and a single dose of adrenaline
column12: the patient regained rhythm and was transferred to our hospital under orotracheal intubation (OTI) and mechanical ventilation. When the patient was questioned during his stay on the ward
column13: he reported having no memory of the episode. He denied any clinical manifestations prior to the cardiorespiratory arrest. He also reported no previous symptoms of angina
column14: dyspnoea or syncope and maintained his usual NYHA I/IV functional class without any symptoms of heart failure.  Physical examination The first examination was performed on arrival at the emergency critical care ward of our hospital
column15: with the patient sedated
column16: relaxed and on invasive ventilation and OTI. The temperature was 36.8oC; heart rate 100 bpm; blood pressure 105/67 mmHg; saturation 100% (OTI). He is well hydrated
column17: skin warm and well perfused. Rhythmic heart sounds without over-additions. Bladder murmur preserved with symmetrical ventilation in both hemithoraxes and no over-added sounds. Abdomen with a recent laparoscopic scar of good appearance. Soft
column18: with no palpable masses or megaliths. No defence on palpation. Extremities well perfused
column19: pulses present and symmetrical. No signs of oedema or venous thrombosis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS  Laboratory tests: Biochemistry: glucose 83 mg/dl
column20: urea 30 mg/dl
column21: creatinine 0.94 mg/dl
column22: glomerular filtration rate > 90 ml/min/1.78 m
column23: sodium ion 142 mmol/l
column24: potassium ion 4.3 mmol/l
column25: ultrasensitive troponin T 110 ng/l (VN < 14 ng/l)
column26: creatine kinase 537 U/l (VN < 200 U/l)
column27: alkaline phosphatase 49 U/l
column28: AST 64 U/l
column29: ALT 78 U/l
column30: GGT 22 U/l
column31: total bilirubin < 1.0 mg/dl
column33: HDL 35 mg/dl
column34: triglycerides 134 mg/dl
column35: calculated LDL cholesterol 80 mg/dl
column36: HbA1C 4.9%
column37: TSH 0.92 mU/l. CBC: haemoglobin 16.3 g/dl
column38: haematocrit 45.8%
column39: red blood cells 5.67x106/μl
column40: leukocytes 8
column42: neutrophils 7
column44: lymphocytes 680/μl
column45: monocytes 540/μl
column46: eosinophils 8/μl
column47: basophils 16/μl
column48: platelets 105
column49: 000/μl. Coagulation: prothrombin time (PT) 11.8 sec; partial thromboplastin time (PTT) 24 sec; INR 1.04; derived fibrinogen 37 mg/l Urine toxicity: negative for benzodiazepine
column50: cocaine
column51: methadone
column52: opiates
column53: methamphetamines
column54: amphetamines
column55: cannabis
column56: ecstasy
column57: barbiturates
column58: tricyclic antidepressants. Urine system and urine sediment: normal. 3-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) (cardiorespiratory arrest rhythm): ventricular fibrillation. 12-lead ECG (arrival at the hospital emergency room): sinus tachycardia at 120 bpm. P wave of normal size and duration. Normal PR segment. Narrow QRS complex
column59: axis at 60o and transition in V3 in precordial leads. ST segment without suprathreshold. Negative T wave in lateral leads (V6
column60: I and aVL) and in inferior face (II and aVF).  Chest X-ray: cardiac silhouette of normal size. Mediastinal enlargement with bilateral hilar adenopathies without tracheal deviation or compression. Endotracheal tube 2 cm above the tracheal carina. No vascular redistribution
column61: pleural effusion or pneumothorax. Distended gastric chamber. Transthoracic echocardiogram: normal sized atria. Left ventricle (LV) slightly dilated with normal thickness
column62: normal global and segmental systolic function (LVEF 60%)
column63: normal left ventricular filling pressures. Right ventricle of normal size
column64: preserved systolic function (TAPSE 31 mm). Normally functioning atrioventricular valves with no evidence of stenosis or insufficiency. Thin trivalve aortic valve
column65: normal function. Pulmonary valve without stenosis
column66: with mild pulmonary insufficiency. No pericardial effusion. Normal flow in descending aorta and abdominal aorta. Computed tomography (CT) coronary arteries: epicardial arteries without lesions or congenital anatomical alterations. Cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR): left ventricle slightly dilated (TVD 118 ml/m2 and STV 49 ml/m2)
column67: normal myocardial mass (104 g/m2) without contractility alterations and with normal systolic function (EF 58%). No areas of hypertrophy or non-compaction are seen. No hyperintense areas suggestive of intramyocardial oedema are seen in the STIR sequence. Several areas of intramural late gadolinium enhancement (LGE) are seen in the basal anteroseptal segment and in the inferior junction of both ventricles compatible with areas of intramyocardial scarring. Right ventricle of normal size
column68: with preserved systolic function. Left atrium slightly dilated (22 cm2) and right atrium of normal size. Aorta
column69: pulmonary artery and pericardium without alterations. Positron emission tomography with 18F-deoxyglucose (PET): multiple hypermetabolic adenopathies located in supraclavicular
column70: mediastinal and hilar compartments compatible with confirmed stage II pulmonary sarcoidosis. No hypermetabolic pathological foci in the myocardium suspicious of acute sarcoidotic or other inflammatory involvement. The rest of the study showed no findings of interest.  CLINICAL COURSE A 27-year-old man who presented with out-of-hospital cardiorespiratory arrest due to recovered ventricular fibrillation. The patient was admitted intubated to the cardiac intensive care unit where he remained for 4 days and was extubated in the first 24 hours. He was subsequently transferred to the cardiology ward to complete the studies. Throughout his stay
column71: he remained asymptomatic from the cardiovascular point of view
column72: with no rhythm alterations detected on telemetry. The aforementioned studies were performed in order to reach a diagnosis and guide treatment. Initially
column73: many diagnostic options were considered as possible aetiologies for ventricular fibrillation: ischaemic heart disease
column74: ventricular arrhythmias in a structurally healthy heart or even the possibility of cardiac toxicity due to chemotherapy treatment. After the initial echocardiographic study
column75: CT of the coronary arteries and the subsequent CMR study
column76: the presence of intramyocardial fibrosis was confirmed. This finding
column77: together with the episode of ventricular fibrillation and the previous diagnosis of systemic sarcoidosis (by biopsy) confirmed the diagnosis of cardiac sarcoidosis and thus the cause of cardiorespiratory arrest.  In the absence of data of acute inflammatory activity in the CMR
column78: and with a view to assessing possible anti-inflammatory treatment
column79: it was decided to complete studies with PET-CT
column80: which again ruled out the presence of intramyocardial inflammatory activity.  For this reason
column81: in agreement with the autoimmune unit of the internal medicine department
column82: anti-inflammatory treatment was finally rejected and a subcutaneous implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) was implanted for secondary prevention of sudden death. To date
column83: the patient remains stable and without new arrhythmic events.  DIAGNOSIS Out-of-hospital cardiorespiratory arrest due to ventricular fibrillation. Cardiac sarcoidosis with intramyocardial scarring but no evidence of active intramyocardial inflammation. Left ventricular systolic function preserved. Coronary arteries without lesions or coronary anomalies. Subcutaneous ICD implantation for secondary prevention. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: a high-intensity sportsman
column3: with an electrocardiogram (ECG) compatible with left ventricular hypertrophy and cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) suggestive of athlete's heart. Subsequent follow-up in the arrhythmia unit following an episode of flutter
column4: with persistence of the electrocardiographic alterations described.  HISTORY
column5: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History No family history of heart disease or early sudden death. Active high-intensity sportsman (cyclist
column6: cycling about 100 km per day). Allergy to acetylsalicylic acid. Ex-smoker of half a pack/day until 4 years ago. Non-drinker. High blood pressure (HBP) under treatment with good control as usual. No known diabetes mellitus (DM) or dyslipidaemia (DLP). Admission to cardiology in February 2016 due to chest pain with atypical characteristics for ischaemic heart disease associated with hypertensive crisis
column7: ECG with negative inferolateral T findings and echocardiogram with preserved LVEF
column8: without segmental alterations of contractility and concentric ventricular hypertrophy (IVS 15 mm
column9: PIL 15 mm)
column10: without intraventricular dynamic gradient. Ergometry was performed with negative results for myocardial ischaemia and ventricular arrhythmias. Cardiac MRI was requested on discharge to complete the study
column11: which was performed at another centre due to lack of availability at our centre
column12: with the finding of maximum thickness at the level of the basal septum of 12 mm (upper limit of normality)
column13: with the rest of the segments with preserved thicknesses and without late enhancement
column14: classifying it as an athlete's heart. Episode of palpitations in May 2018
column15: ECG in the emergency department compatible with paroxysmal counterclockwise atrial flutter. Programmed electrical cardioversion was performed after anticoagulation for 3 weeks
column16: and the patient went into sinus rhythm. In September 2018
column17: cavotricuspid isthmus ablation (CTI) was performed with the CARTO system without the use of scopy. Subsequent follow-up in the arrhythmia unit showed that the patient remained asymptomatic and in sinus rhythm
column18: with persistent negative inferolateral T-segments and concentric hypertrophy on serial echocardiograms. The patient was instructed to cease high-intensity exercise for further re-evaluation. No surgical interventions of interest.  Usual treatment: Ramipril 2.5 mg one tablet at breakfast.  Current illness The patient was reviewed at the arrhythmia clinic after having stopped all physical exercise for the last 8 months. The patient remains asymptomatic
column19: with no new episodes of palpitations. He denied exertional dyspnoea
column20: syncope or other symptoms. An ECG was performed in consultation
column21: with persistence of left ventricular hypertrophy criteria together with deep and asymmetrical negative T in precordial leads and inferior face. An echocardiogram was performed
column22: with the finding of mild-moderate concentric hypertrophy of its walls (IVS 13 mm
column23: LIP 11 mm) but with the presence at the apical level of a greater myocardial thickness of about 15-16 mm
column24: with systolic closure in "ace of spades" morphology with slight hypokinesia of the most apical segments. No SAM or intraventricular gradient was observed. Given the electrocardiographic and echocardiographic findings after stopping exercise
column25: despite the patient having a cardiac MRI 3 years earlier compatible with athlete's heart and without findings compatible with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
column26: it was decided to request a new cardiac MRI to complete the study.  Physical examination Acceptable general condition. Eupneic at rest. O2 saturation 98% without oxygen therapy. Blood pressure 142/83. Heart rate 55 bpm. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column27: at a good frequency. No audible murmurs at baseline or after Valsalva manoeuvre. Bladder murmur preserved
column28: without pathological noises added. Lower limbs: no oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Distal pulses preserved and symmetrical.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Cardiac MRI (February/2016): left ventricle (LV) not dilated
column29: with preserved global and segmental mobility. EF measured with the Simpson method of 72%. Maximum basal septal thickness of 12 mm
column30: with the rest of the segments with preserved thicknesses. The myocardial mass is 107 g
column31: indexed at 61.43 g/m . The right ventricle is normal. No abnormalities were observed in the late enhancement sequence.  Electrocardiogram (June/2019): sinus bradycardia at 50 bpm
column33: PR 224 ms
column34: Narrow QRS with criteria of left ventricular hypertrophy by Sokolow criteria
column35: biphasic T in V1-V2
column36: negative in I
column37: II
column38: III
column39: aVF and deep and asymmetric negative in V3-V6
column40: with ST rectification in these leads
column41: QTc 428 ms. Echocardiogram (June/2019): non-dilated left ventricle with mild concentric hypertrophy of its walls (IVS 13.5 mm
column42: LIP 11.5 mm)
column43: a greater myocardial thickness is seen at the apical level
column44: about 15-16 mm
column45: with systolic closure in "ace of spades" morphology with slight hypokinesia of the most apical segments
column46: so it could not be ruled out that it is an apical hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with little myocardial involvement.  Biauricular dilatation. Mitral with mild insufficiency
column47: without SAM. Mild aortic insufficiency due to slight dilatation of the aortic root. Rest of valves without alterations. Preserved LV systolic function with LVEF 65-70%. LV diastolic and RV systolic function unaltered.  Cardiac MRI (June/2019): non-dilated left ventricle with hypertrophy only at the apical level
column48: mainly of the lower apical segments and the true apex with thicknesses between 12-13 mm and maximum thickness in the lower apical segment reaching 15 mm. In cine sequences in the vertical long axis plane
column49: the left ventricle shows the typical "ace of spades" morphology. The EF measured with the Simpson method is 60%. Myocardial mass 93 g
column50: indexed by body surface area of 54 g/m. Right ventricle without alterations. In the first-pass perfusion sequence
column51: no basal perfusion defects. Late enhancement/viability sequence shows no fibrosis or necrosis.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient underwent a new outpatient cardiac MRI at our centre
column52: with the finding of a non-dilated left ventricle with hypertrophy only at the apical level
column53: mainly of the lower apical segments and the true apex with thicknesses of between 12-13 mm
column54: with the lower apical segment reaching 15 mm and the left ventricle presenting the typical "ace of spades" morphology in cine 2C. The EF measured with the Simpson method is 60%. The late enhancement/viability sequence showed no fibrosis or necrosis. The patient subsequently visited the clinic to collect the results and reported to be completely asymptomatic. The nature of the disease and its hereditary nature were explained to the patient
column55: and it was decided
column56: given the low diagnostic yield of the genetic study in the apical variant of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) and that the patient had no children and only one sibling
column57: to continue the family study by echocardiography and/or cardiac MRI if this was inconclusive. Subsequent follow-up in the arrhythmia unit with 24-hour Holter monitoring is indicated.  DIAGNOSIS Non-obstructive apical hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. No fibrosis by cardiac MRI. HCM-SCD Score 0.99%. Paroxysmal counterclockwise atrial flutter. Effective CTI ablation without the use of scopy. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION A 60-year-old man attended the emergency department of our centre due to chest pain.  History The patient had the following medical history: Cardiovascular risk factors: type 2 diabetes mellitus
column3: non-insulin-dependent
column4: on treatment with two drugs
column5: with good metabolic control (HbA1c 6.8%); well-controlled arterial hypertension (home blood pressure (BP) < 140/80 mmHg) with two drugs. No previous cardiological history. Other relevant medical history: peripheral vascular disease
column6: with stenosis in the right superficial femoral artery and absence of right pedal pulse
column7: treated with drug-eluting balloon angioplasty with good results.  Usual treatment: Sitagliptin + metformin 50/1000 mg
column8: 1 tablet every 12 hours. Valsartan + amlodipine 40/10 mg
column9: 1 tablet per day. Omeprazole 20 mg
column10: 1 capsule per day. Acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) 100 mg
column11: 1 tablet per day.  Present illness On arrival at the emergency department
column12: the patient presented with oppressive central thoracic pain radiating to the neck and both arms
column13: lasting 2 hours from onset at rest
column14: associated with cold sweating. No previous similar episodes. No symptoms suggestive of exertional angina with usual physical activity.  Physical examination BP 105/70 mmHg
column15: heart rate (HR) 100 bpm
column16: oxygen saturation 95% on room air. Jugular venous pressure normal. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column17: no murmurs or pathological sounds. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur with no extra sounds. Abdomen: soft and depressible
column18: not painful on palpation
column19: no masses or megaliths
column20: Blumberg and Murphy negative. Extremities: no oedema in the lower extremities
column21: peripheral pulses preserved and symmetrical
column22: no signs of phlebitis An electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed in less than 10 minutes
column23: which showed the presence of subepicardial lesion current in the inferior face
column24: so a haemodynamic alert was activated.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG on arrival at the emergency department: sinus rhythm at 100 bpm. Normal PR. QRS 90 ms. qS in V1. ST-segment elevation up to 3 mm in DII
column25: DIII and aVF with specular decrease in DI and aVL. Portable chest X-ray: slightly increased cardiothoracic index in this anteroposterior projection. No pleural effusion
column26: no signs of vascular redistribution. No condensation. Emergent coronary angiography: right dominance. Left main coronary artery (LMCA) without lesions. Anterior descending artery (AD) with severe lesion of 90% in the middle segment. Circumflex with 40% lesion in distal segment. Right coronary artery (RCA) with 90% long lesion that starts in the proximal segment and extends to the middle segment. Good distal bed. It was decided to perform percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) on the DC lesion. After predilating with a 2.5 x 20 mm semi-compliant balloon
column27: a 2.75 x 30 mm sirolimus-eluting drug-eluting stent was implanted with a good final angiographic result. Echocardiogram in the coronary unit: mild left ventricular (LV) hypertrophy
column28: with preserved diameters and slightly depressed LVEF (Simpson BP 50%) secondary to inferolateral and inferior mediobasal hypokinesia. Absence of significant valvular heart disease. Normal transmitral filling
column29: estimated normal LV end-diastolic pressure (E/E' = 7). RV with normal diameters and preserved function. Absence of tricuspid insufficiency (TI) allowing estimation of pulmonary artery systolic pressure (PSAP). Normal inferior vena cava (IVC). Absence of pericardial effusion.  Ordinary laboratory tests: Blood count: haemoglobin 13.9 g/dl
column30: without leukocytosis or left shift. Platelets 241 x 10^9/l. Haemostasis: INR 0.99
column31: TTPa 29.3 sec. Biochemistry: fasting glucose 118 mg/dl
column33: potassium 4 mEq/l
column34: creatinine 0.49 mg/dl (GFR > 90 ml/min/1.72 m2)
column35: NT-proBNP 266 pg/ml
column36: C-reactive protein 0.7 mg/dl
column37: HbA1c 6.8%
column38: total cholesterol 176 mg/dl
column39: triglycerides 102 mg/dl
column40: HDL cholesterol 37 mg/dl
column41: LDL cholesterol 119 mg/dl. Myocardial damage biomarker curve (hsTnI
column42: normal < 19.8 ng/l): 53 - 24
column43: 900 (above detection limit) - 15
column46: 977 ng/l. ECG at discharge (image 3): sinus rhythm at 65 bpm. Normal PR. QRS 90 ms with axis at 60o. Negative T wave in DII
column47: DIII and aVF. Elective coronary angiography (video 4): good result of stent implanted in CD. PCI on LAD: lesion is predilated with SC balloon 2.5 x 20 mm and NC 3 x 20 mm
column48: implanting a 3 x 26 mm zotarolimus-eluting drug-eluting stent
column49: with a good final angiographic result.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION After finding ST-segment elevation in the inferior face in a patient with anginal chest pain
column50: a loading dose of prasugrel was administered (the patient was already receiving chronic treatment with ASA 100 mg) and the infarction code was activated. Emergent coronary angiography showed three-vessel disease
column51: with two severe lesions (in the MD and DCM) and a moderate lesion in the distal circumflex (DC). A decision was made to perform constant pharmacoactive PCI on the middle DC
column52: the artery responsible for the infarction (ARI)
column53: which was performed without incident. After angioplasty
column54: he was admitted to the coronary unit
column55: where beta-blocker and lipid-lowering treatment was started
column56: and he remained asymptomatic and haemodynamically stable. After 48 hours without arrhythmic events
column57: it was decided to discharge him to the cardiology ward and
column58: after mobilisation without incident
column59: to his home. Medical treatment at discharge was: Acetylsalicylic acid 100 mg
column60: 1 tablet per day. Prasugrel 10 mg
column61: 1 tablet per day. Rosuvastatin 20 mg
column62: 1 tablet at night. Dapagliflozin + metformin 5/1000 mg
column63: 1 tablet every 12 hours. Nebivolol 2.5 mg
column64: 1 tablet per day. Omeprazole 20 mg
column65: 1 capsule per day. Valsartan + amlodipine 40/10 mg
column66: 1 tablet per day. After discharge
column67: the patient was scheduled 3 weeks later for elective outpatient angioplasty on the severe lesion of the middle anterior descending artery
column68: which was performed without complications. After this second procedure
column69: the patient was included in the cardiovascular rehabilitation programme of our centre.  DIAGNOSIS Acute myocardial infarction with ST-segment elevation of inferior location. Killip I. Three-vessel coronary artery disease: Mid CD (ARI) 90%
column70: mid DA 90%
column71: distal Cx 40%. Primary PCI with drug-eluting stentliberator over mid-CD. Second outpatient elective PCI on severe mid LAD lesion. Mild left ventricular dysfunction (LVEF 50%). Peripheral arterial disease. Type 2 diabetes mellitus with good metabolic control. LDL cholesterol above target (< 50 mg/dl). column2: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 57-year-old male with a personal history of arterial hypertension (AHT)
column3: no other known cardiovascular risk factors and Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW) with no invasive treatment to date. On treatment only with atenolol 100 mg per day. On waking up on the morning of admission at 8:00 a.m.
column4: he felt dizzy and unstable and fell to the floor. He was rushed to the emergency department for assessment. Haemodynamic stability was observed
column5: with elevated blood pressure 190/117 mmHg
column6: heart rate 59 bpm
column7: afebrile state and baseline oxygen saturation of 92%. The neurological examination showed a NIHSS 7: dysarthric speech
column8: left central facial paresis
column9: striking horizontal-rotatory nystagmus with rapid leftward movement
column10: claudication of the lower limbs and mild hypoaesthesia of algesic predominance in the right hemibody including the face. The rest of the physical examination showed cardiac auscultation without murmurs or extratonos and respiratory auscultation with preserved vesicular murmur without added noises. An electrocardiogram in sinus rhythm was requested
column11: and blood tests showed platelets and normal coagulation
column12: with only an elevated D-dimer. An emergency multimodal computed tomography (CT) scan (without perfusion) was performed
column13: showing occlusion of the left vertebral artery along segment V3-4
column14: compatible with acute thrombus
column15: as well as chronic ischaemic lesions in the basal ganglia
column16: left thalamus and cerebellar hemispheres.  Given the acute nature of the picture
column17: the clear neurological deficit
column18: the evidence of thrombus
column19: a good baseline situation assessed on the Ratkin Scale and the absence of contraindications for the same
column20: a pharmacoinvasive strategy was decided
column21: so r-TPA was administered and the patient was transferred to the referral hospital for clinical monitoring in the Stroke Unit due to the possibility of progression to the basilar artery and the need for surgical treatment.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Baseline electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus rhythm at 78 bpm
column22: short PR with initial QRS flattening compatible with a delta wave
column23: repolarisation disturbance consisting of non-significant ST segment underleveling in left precordial leads and lateral face with negative T wave
column24: probably secondary to WPW. ED CBC: leukocytes 8
column26: segmented 45.4% (3
column28: lymphocytes 40.3% (3
column30: red blood cells 5.790 million/μl
column31: haemoglobin 15.1 g/dl
column33: MCV 82 fl
column34: platelets 163 thousands/μl
column35: prothrombin time 11.4 seconds
column36: prothrombin activity 94%
column37: aTTP 28.2 seconds
column38: fibrinogen 484 mg/dl
column39: urgent D-dimer 2
column40: 099 ng/ml
column41: INR 1.04
column42: serum glucose 109 mg/dl
column43: urea 26 mg/dl
column44: creatinine 0.88 mg/dl. Urgent cranial CT and perfusion CT: subcortical hypodensity of about 5 mm in the right cerebellar hemisphere suggestive of chronic ischaemic lesion. Hypodensities in the anterior arm of the internal capsule
column45: in the lenticular nucleus and in the thalamic region of the left hemisphere
column46: with attenuation similar to CSF
column47: suggestive of chronic lacunar infarcts. Fourth ventricle of normal size and morphology
column48: centred in the midline. Basal cisterns free and symmetrical. No densitometric alterations were observed in the brainstem. No intra- or extra-axial bleeding or midline deviation. Hyperdensity of the V4 segment of the left vertebral artery in probable relation to acute thrombus. The perfusion study is not valid in the study performed to assess the vertebrobasilar axis. Retention cysts in maxillary and left sphenoidal sinuses. Angio-CT of TSA and urgent cerebral arteries: carotid axes of normal morphology and paths up to the bifurcation
column49: with non-obstructive flat calcified atheroma plaque at the origin of the left internal carotid artery. Both internal carotid arteries are patent and of normal calibre. Right vertebral artery patent up to the basilar trunk. Repletion defect along V3 and V4 of the left vertebral artery
column50: compatible with acute thrombus. No associated collaterals were seen in this segment. Intracranially
column51: the vascular structures of the polygon of Willis are permeable and of normal calibre with no repletion defects or aneurysms. Conclusion: findings compatible with acute thrombus in V3 and V4 of the left vertebral artery. Chronic ischaemic lesions in the left basal ganglia and thalamus and in the right cerebellar hemisphere. Routine laboratory tests on the neurology ward: glucose 111 mg/dl. Urea 20 mg/dl. Creatinine 0.69 mg/dl. Estimated glomerular filtration rate (CKD-EPI) > 90 ml/min/1.73 m . Uric acid 3.2 mg/dl. Sodium 140.4 mEq/l. Potassium 3
column52: 71 mEq/l. Chlorine 104
column53: 4 mEq/l. Calcium 9 mg/dl. Phosphorus 2
column54: 6 mg/dl. Total proteins 6
column55: 85 g/dl. Albumin 4.1 g/dl. Cholesterol 205 mg/dl. HDL cholesterol 55 mg/dl. Calculated LDL cholesterol 117 mg/dl. Triglycerides 166 mg/dl. GOT(AST) 17 U/l. GPT(ALT) 16 U/l. GGT 21 U/l. Total bilirubin 0.5 mg/dl. Alkaline phosphatase 38 U/l. Glycosylated haemoglobin 5.7%. Thrombophilia study: normal results. Antithrombin III 84%
column56: protein C 145%
column57: resistance to activated protein C 3.1
column58: antigenic free protein S 108%
column59: prothrombin factor 20210 A gene negative
column60: momocysteine 8 MicroMol/l. Chest CT with VSD (PET protocol): multiple entral repletion defects are observed at the level of: lobar artery for LID with extension to segmental and subsegmental branches
column61: segmental arteries for LM
column62: LSD and LII
column63: some with extension to subsegmental branches. Findings in relation to bilateral acute pulmonary thromboembolism (PTE). Increased calibre of the pulmonary artery trunk (35 mm) and its main branches (APD of 25 mm
column64: API of 25 mm)
column65: in relation to PTE. No signs suggestive of right heart cavity overload. No pericardial effusion is observed. No significant supraclavicular
column66: axillary
column67: mediastinal or hilar lymphadenopathy. Accessory fissure of the azygos as an anatomical variant of normality. Laminar bibasal atelectasis. Small calcified granuloma in LSD. Rest of the lung parenchyma without pathological findings. No pleural effusion. Mild dorsal spondyloarthrosis. Hiatal hernia. Diagnostic impression: findings compatible with bilateral acute PTE and PHT. Post-fibrinolysis control CT scan: evolving ischaemic lesion in the left cerebellar hemisphere in the territory of the PICA. No signs suggesting haemorrhagic transformation. Echo Doppler of the lower extremities: no evidence of DVT. Transthoracic echocardiogram performed in the stroke unit: non-dilated left ventricle
column68: mild septal hypertrophy with preserved systolic function (LVEF 60%) without alterations in segmental contractility. Right ventricle not dilated
column69: normofunctioning (TAPSE 24 mm
column70: S wave 0.21m/s). Diastolic flattening of the IVS suggestive of volume overload in the right chambers; no other signs suggestive of right chamber involvement. Degenerative aortic valve disease resulting in mild aortic insufficiency (VC 3 mm). Mitral filling pattern not assessable by wave fusion. Mild tricuspid insufficiency allowing estimation of PSAP 33 mmHg. Absence of pericardial effusion. IVC at the upper limit of normality with respirophasic variations in its calibre. Aneurysm of the interatrial septum with redundant movement
column71: without intracavitary claroshunt. It is recommended to complete the study with bubble echocardiogram to rule out shunt from right to left cavities. Transthoracic echocardiogram with bubbles: very positive bubble test
column72: with passage of abundant bubbles (> 30) in first beats without Valsalva. Transesophageal echocardiogram: a study was performed to assess the interatrial septum due to stroke
column73: PTE and positive bubble test. The presence of PFO of the tunneled type with significant passage of bubbles to the left cavities at baseline was confirmed. The edges of the septum secundum are thick
column74: 18 mm long inferiorly and 26 mm posteriorly
column75: the distance between the two edges being about 25 mm. Left atrial appendage without thrombus and with normal flow. Conclusions: patent foramen ovale tunnel type. Electrophysiological study: baseline findings: HV 0 ms. Concentric and decremental retrograde conduction (therefore absence of retrograde conduction through the pathway) 1:1 up to 400 ms. Preexcitation with 1:1 accessory pathway conduction only up to 560 ms. Anterograde PW 450 ms
column76: PRENAV 600/350 ms. An area with AV continuity and ventriculogram with precocity with respect to the onset of delta is identified. Anterograde conduction via the accessory pathway is transiently interrupted very easily in relation to the manipulation of the catheter in the area. A 35 W RF application is performed
column77: with interruption of the pre-excitation at the start of the application. A total of 7 applications are performed
column78: with a total RF time of 154 ms. After the waiting period
column79: the absence of bidirectional conduction in the pathway was verified. Complete atrial and ventricular pacing protocols were repeated after the ablation
column80: confirming 1:1 concentric and decremental VA conduction up to 380 ms
column81: a PW of 133 bpm
column82: with an anterograde nodal curve without AH jump and without inducing echoes or tachycardia. After the wait
column83: two additional safety applications were performed with the same parameters (duration 58 s). A subcutaneous Holter was implanted in the left parasternal position.  Post-ablation ECG: sinus rhythm at 68 bpm. No signs of pre-excitation. No alteration in repolarisation or intraventricular conduction. Percutaneous closure of PFO: a 30 mm cribriform closure device was implanted. By means of the depush and pull manoeuvre and angiography
column84: its correct position is verified.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION During his stay in the stroke unit
column85: haemodynamic support
column86: cardiorespiratory monitoring and strict control of cardiovascular risk factors were carried out. On arrival on the ward
column87: a blood test was drawn with a coagulation study that included a D-dimer determination
column88: as the first determination carried out in the emergency department was elevated
column89: the new result being even higher. For this reason
column90: together with the presence of slight dyspnoea
column91: it was decided to rule out pulmonary thromboembolism (PTE). After an angio-CT scan of the pulmonary arteries revealed the existence of acute bilateral PTE
column92: a control cranial CT scan was performed to rule out haemorrhagic transformation after fibrinolysis. Therefore
column93: after a risk-benefit assessment
column94: it was decided to start anticoagulation with IV sodium heparin
column95: with subsequent transition to LMWH. A Doppler ultrasound of the lower limbs was performed
column96: which ruled out the existence of deep vein thrombosis
column97: and a transthoracic echocardiogram ruled out right ventricular dysfunction but revealed the existence of an aneurysm of the interatrial septum
column98: which was studied by means of a bubble echocardiogram and a transesophageal echocardiogram
column99: revealing the existence of a PFO
column100: unknown until then. The most likely cause of the stroke + PTE was considered to be paradoxical embolism due to PFO in a patient with WPW and possible associated arrhythmia (the most plausible being atrial fibrillation associated with WPW). It was then decided to study and ablate the accessory pathway
column101: implanting a subcutaneous Holter at the same time to study subsequent arrhythmias
column102: whether unrelated to WPW syndrome or due to recurrence. The evolution from the neurological point of view was very favourable
column103: with practically complete resolution of the clinical manifestations
column105: so it was decided to discharge the patient. In a second stage
column107: percutaneous closure of the tunneled PFO is performed
column108: given that it has anatomical risk criteria. After this last intervention
column109: the patient is recommended hygienic-dietary measures
column111: as well as a varied diet
column113: and with sugar control given his pre-diabetes stage. Endocarditis prophylaxis for the next 6 months
column114: if invasive dental procedures are performed. Regarding medication: rivaroxaban 20 mg/24 hours
column117: atorvastatin 80 mg/24 hours. Regarding the maintenance of anticoagulation
column118: a new control angio-CT scan could be considered to rule out thrombotic remnants of the PTE and in that case its withdrawal could be considered
column119: also subject to the possible detection of atrial fibrillation with the subcutaneous Holter.  DIAGNOSIS Acute ischaemic stroke in vertebrobasilar territory
column120: acute occlusion segment V3-4 of the left vertebral artery with involvement of the ipsilateral posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) and bilateral acute pulmonary thromboembolism on admission with fibrinolysis. Permeable tunnelled foramen ovale closed percutaneously. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION History 80-year-old male. No known drug allergies. Ex-smoker for 20 years (AE 15 packs/year). Cardiovascular risk factors include arterial hypertension (AHT) on treatment with candesartan 32 mg per day and type 2 diabetes mellitus on treatment with empagliflozin/metformin 5/1
column3: 000 mg per day. No known cardiological history. History only includes benign prostatic hyperplasia and cataract surgery in both eyes. Independent for all basic activities of daily living
column4: including advanced activities (Rankin 0).  Present illness The patient was brought to the emergency department of our centre by basic life support after being found by his sister on the floor of her home at 15:00 hours with clinical symptoms consisting of deviation of the right corner of the mouth
column5: ocular deviation to the left and speech impairment. He had a scalp injury suggestive of cranioencephalic trauma. The last time he was seen asymptomatic was the previous day at around 11:00 am.  Physical examination Blood pressure (BP) 187/98 mmHg
column6: heart rate (HR) 98 bpm
column7: basal oxygen saturation 94%. Mixed aphasia: language not very fluent
column8: although communication is possible. Understands some simple commands. Altered naming. Left visual preference. Right homonymous hemianopsia on confrontational campimetry. Left supranuclear facial paresis. Rest of cranial nerves preserved. Claudication of the right lower limb (NIHSS of 8 points). Cardiac auscultation: regular sounds without murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur
column9: without pathological sounds. Abdomen was normal. Normal and symmetrical pulses.   COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus rhythm at 95 bpm. PR 140 ms. Narrow QRS with normal axis. Embryonic R in precordials up to V4 with negative T in I
column10: aVL
column11: V5-V6. CBC: glucose 138 mg/dl. Urea 39 mg/dl. Creatinine 0.91 mg/dl. Sodium 141 mmol/l. Potassium 4.4 mmol/l. CPK 98 U/l. CRP 7.0 mg/l. Hb 15.7 g/dl. MCV 92 fl. Leukocytes 4
column12: 6x10^9/l. Platelets 165 x10^9/l. INR 1.07. Troponin T ultrasensitive 76 pg/ml -> 68.3 at 6 hours (normal < 14). Chest X-ray: no consolidation or pleural effusion. Vacuum cranial computed tomography (CT): discrete cerebral corticosubcortical atrophy. Left occipital and left thalamus hypodensities of acute ischaemic origin of new onset
column13: not present in previous CT (2015). Hypodensity in left insula of probable chronic ischaemic origin already present in previous CT scan. Angio-CT of supra-aortic trunks and Willis polygon after administration of intravenous contrast (image 2): repletion defect in P2A segment of left posterior cerebral artery. The rest of the arteries of the polygon of Willis are patent
column14: with no aneurysmal dilatations or significant stenosis or images suggestive of thrombosis/occlusion. Perfusion CT scan after administration of IVC: penumbra area in the left posterior cerebral artery territory
column15: with mismatch greater than 20%. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with angio-MRI: extensive acute ischaemic infarction in the left temporo-occipital and left thalamic territory (the latter with haemorrhagic transformation). Angiographic sequences identify supra-aortic trunks with no evidence of significant stenosis. The arterial structures of the polygon of Willis show a normal carotid system and basilar system with no evidence of vascular malformations or significant stenosis. Transthoracic echocardiography: cardiac cavities of normal size
column16: with moderate hypertrophy
column17: predominantly septal. Slightly depressed LVEF (48% by Simpson) at the expense of akinesia of the septum and anterior wall in its apical segments and strict apex akinesia. Normal TAPSE. No significant valvulopathy. There was a mass attached to the septoapical wall
column18: protruding and mobile
column19: measuring 20x17 mm
column20: compatible with left intraventricular thrombus. Cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR). Late enhancement sequence: rounded thrombus of 11x16x15 mm adhered to septoapical wall. Lateral hypokinesia
column21: apical segments and strict apex. Absence of myocardial oedema. Non-transmural subendocardial necrosis on the lateral aspect. Absence of necrosis in the apical segments. Transthoracic echocardiography two months after discharge: resolution of the thrombus observed in the previous echography with persistence of the contractility alterations described in previous echocardiographies.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was 80 years of age
column22: with a good functional level
column23: who presented with clinical symptoms compatible with ischaemic stroke in the left posterior cerebral artery territory with NISS > 6. The emergency department activated the stroke code
column24: observing P2 segment occlusion in the CT angiography. Fibrinolytic treatment was ruled out due to the uncertain evolution time and interventional radiology was contacted for evaluation of endovascular treatment
column25: which was also ruled out due to hypodensity established in the vacuum CT scan and occlusion distal to P1. Subsequently
column26: ischaemia was observed in different arterial territories in cerebral MRI. Angiography showed a normal carotid and basilar system with no evidence of vascular malformations or significant stenosis. As part of the aetiological study of the stroke
column27: a regular transthoracic echocardiography was requested
column28: showing intraventricular thrombus adhered to the septoapical wall. The cardiology department was consulted and the study was completed with cardiac magnetic resonance imaging
column29: which also showed lateral hypokinesia of the apical segments and strict apex and non-transmural subendocardial necrosis on the lateral aspect compatible with old infarction. In the directed anamnesis
column30: the patient had no previous symptoms of chest pain
column31: dyspnoea or other cardiological symptoms. Given the characteristics of the patient; elderly and with a recent stroke with haemorrhagic transformation in some of the affected brain territories
column32: anticoagulation with rivaroxaban 20 mg per day was agreed with the neurology department. Given that the patient had not previously experienced chest pain
column33: LVEF was not severely compromised and given the acute situation of stroke with haemorrhagic transformation
column34: it was decided not to perform coronary catheterisation for the time being and to assess after resolution of the apical thrombus. On discharge
column35: the patient's language was not very fluent
column36: but he understood orders
column37: named correctly and repeated. Persistence of campimetric deficit consisting of right homonymous hemianopsia. No motor deficit (NIHSS of 3 points). The control echocardiography at one month on an outpatient basis showed a decrease in the size of the thrombus and in the control echocardiography at two months
column38: resolution of the thrombus with persistence of the contractility alterations described in previous echocardiographies.  DIAGNOSIS Ischaemic stroke in the left posterior cerebral artery territory of embolic aetiology. Intraventricular thrombus. Old myocardial infarction in lateral face and apical segments. Type 2 diabetes mellitus. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History No known allergic drug reactions. Active smoking. Morbid obesity with a body mass index (BMI) of 41. Diabetes mellitus treated with oral antidiabetics. Dyslipidaemia. Stage 3A chronic kidney disease. Chronic ischaemic heart disease: three-vessel lesion surgically revascularised in 1981
column3: by endarterectomy and resection of endothelial membrane of left coronary ostium and saphenous bypass to anterior descending artery (LAD)
column4: with posterior occlusion of the bypass. Chronic total occlusion of the LAD since 2012. Several admissions for non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (NSTEACS) since 2012
column5: with multiple percutaneous revascularisations: left main coronary artery (LMCA)
column6: first marginal branch (MB)
column7: circumflex bifurcation (Cx)-first MB
column8: right coronary artery (RCA). Usual treatment: acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) 100 mg daily
column9: clopidogrel 75 mg daily
column10: enalapril 5 mg every 12 hours
column11: metoprolol 100 mg every 12 hours
column12: amlodipine 5 mg every 12 hours
column13: isosorbide mononitrate 40 mg daily
column14: ranolazine 500 mg every 12 hours
column15: furosemide 40 mg daily
column16: atorvastatin 80 mg daily
column17: empagliflozin/metformin 5/1000 mg every 12 hours
column18: omeprazole 20 mg daily.  Present illness A 72-year-old man with complex chronic ischaemic heart disease
column19: with multiple revascularisations
column20: came to the emergency department for an episode of oppressive central thoracic pain at rest lasting about 15 minutes
column21: with partial relief after taking sublingual nitroglycerin
column22: with residual discomfort remaining afterwards. During the previous two months she had presented episodes of chest pain with moderate exertion (climbing stairs)
column23: which resolved with rest or taking nitroglycerine
column24: which is why ranolazine had been associated with her last visit. She denied other symptoms
column25: such as dyspnoea
column26: oedema of the lower limbs
column27: palpitations or infectious symptoms.  Physical examination Vital signs: blood pressure 182/132 mmHg. Heart rate 69 bpm. Oxygen saturation 98% basal. Good general condition. Conscious and oriented
column28: cooperative
column29: normohydrated and normoperfused. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column30: no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur
column31: no extra sounds. Abdomen: hydro-aerial sounds preserved
column33: not painful on palpation. Lower limbs: no oedema
column34: distal pulses preserved.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Laboratory tests on admission: glucose 83 mg/dl
column35: creatinine 1.46 mg/dl
column36: glomerular filtration rate 47.30 ml/min
column37: sodium 139 mmol/l
column38: potassium 3.9 mmol/l
column39: chlorine 106 mmol/l
column40: C-reactive protein 2.6 mg/l (0 - 5)
column41: two troponin I determinations 0.0 ng/ml
column42: natriuretic peptide (BNP) 83.8 pg/ml. Analysis of cardiovascular risk factors: HbA1c 7.6%
column43: LDL 73 mg/dl
column44: triglycerides 110 mg/dl. Electrocardiogram (ECG) with chest pain: sinus rhythm at 78 bpm. ST-segment elevation downward sloping by 1 mm
column45: especially in precordial leads
column46: I and aVL. Pain-free ECG (image 2): sinus rhythm at 72 bpm. Correction of dynamic repolarisation changes. Coronary angiography: LMCA with a mild calcified plaque in the distal segment of 30%. Calcified LAD with total occlusion in the middle segment
column47: with retrograde distal collateral filling. Cx of good calibre and development with a stent in the middle segment permeable and without restenosis
column48: and another stent in the first marginal branch permeable and without restenosis. Distally in the obtuse marginal branch he has a significant lesion of 70%
column49: evaluated with pressure guide and intracoronary adenosine with a result of 0.77 (significant). Dominant DC of good calibre and development with a moderate plaque in the proximal segment of 60% evaluated with pressure guide and intracoronary adenosine with FFR = 0.87 (not significant)
column50: distally with diffuse irregularities and an under-occlusion of the PL branch of chronic aspect. Echocardiogram: non-dilated left ventricle with preserved ejection fraction
column51: without gross alterations of segmental contractility. Mild left ventricular hypertrophy. Right ventricle of normal size and function. No significant valvulopathies.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was admitted to cardiology and
column52: given the progression of his symptoms over the last few months despite the adjustment of anti-anginal medication
column53: it was decided to perform coronary angiography
column54: where a significant lesion was found in the first MVO (assessed by pressure guidewire)
column55: which was revascularised with a drug-eluting stent. During hospitalisation
column56: the patient had no new episodes of chest pain and was discharged early. Despite being a patient widely known to cardiology
column57: cardiovascular risk factors are not controlled
column58: so special emphasis is placed on this aspect. It seems particularly important to optimise glycaemic control and
column59: given that the patient is obese
column60: it is decided to associate a GLP1 agonist (semaglutide 0.25 mg once a week)
column61: with a target HbA1c of less than 7%. In addition
column62: ezetimibe was added to his treatment
column63: with a target LDL of less than 55 mg/dl. At the follow-up consultation after completion of the cardiac rehabilitation programme
column64: the patient had achieved weight loss of 8 kg
column65: smoking cessation and better laboratory control (HbA1c 6.8%
column66: LDL 54 mg/dl).  DIAGNOSIS NSTEACS type unstable angina. Significant lesion of 70% in the first OM assessed by pressure guidewire (FFR 0.77) revascularised percutaneously by means of a pharmacoactive destenting implant. Chronic total occlusion of the middle anterior descending artery. Complex chronic ischaemic heart disease
column67: revascularised in a mixed form on multiple occasions. Type 2 diabetes mellitus with poor glycaemic control. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History The patient is an 18-year-old male
column3: with no known drug allergies or toxic habits. He had presented in childhood with some episodes of bronchospasm related to mite and pollen allergy that improved with beta-2 mimetic inhalers
column4: but he had been crisis-free since the age of 14 years
column5: and he regularly played sports with good tolerance. He first consulted the emergency department of our hospital in 2004 for self-limited abdominal pain
column6: and the following findings were noted in the complementary tests performed: The electrocardiogram (ECG) showed sinus rhythm at 55 bpm
column7: with a right QRS axis and morphology of complete right bundle branch block (RBBB)
column8: criteria for right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)
column9: and repolarisation abnormalities in V1-V4. Laboratory tests showed discrete polyglobulia (17.3 gn/dl). The chest X-ray showed prominence of the pulmonary arteries and the arch of the azygos. In view of these findings
column10: a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) was performed
column11: which revealed indirect evidence of severe pulmonary hypertension
column12: with moderate hypertrophy and mild dilatation of the right ventricle (RV)
column13: as well as a hitherto unknown patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Subsequently
column14: a right heart catheterisation confirmed the presence of severe pulmonary hypertension (PHT) (high mean pulmonary artery pressure (mPAP) and normal pulmonary capillary pressure (PCP). In May 2004
column15: the patient underwent surgery at a private centre
column16: with section and closure of both ductal stumps by left thoracotomy. He had the following complications from the procedure: a resolved left recurrent nerve palsy and a left pneumothorax. In the following years
column17: fibrosing mediastinitis was also discovered
column18: requiring treatment with systemic corticosteroids. In September 2005
column19: a post-surgery right heart catheterisation was performed
column20: which revealed persistent severe pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) (PAPm 73 mmHg
column21: PCP 7 mmHg
column22: pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) 13.75 UW
column23: cardiac output (CO) 4.8 l/min). In addition
column24: there was evidence of reopening of the PDA with residual flow. In view of these findings
column25: the patient began follow-up in the monographic pulmonary hypertension clinic at our hospital. He had normal respiratory function tests
column26: NT-proBNP 22 ng/ml and persistent polyglobulia (20 g/dl)
column27: no nocturnal desaturation in pulse oximetry and in the 6-minute walk test he covered 705 m with maintained constants. In 2008 he was referred to a pulmonary hypertension unit of a reference hospital for pulmonary hypertension. At that time the patient was in functional class I
column28: without cyanosis or signs of right heart failure (HF). Discrete polyglobulia persists
column29: and on TTE the PAWD is seen with a right-to-left flow and a hypertrophic RV with moderate dysfunction. Ergospirometry shows functional class I with moderately reduced functional capacity and normal blood pressure (BP). Given the patient's good functional class
column30: re-evaluation in 9 months is recommended before starting specific treatment for PAH. Finally
column31: given the persistence of severe PAH in a new catheterisation (PAPm 90 mmHg
column33: PVR 14 UW
column34: GC 5.6 l/min)
column35: it was decided to start specific treatment for PAH
column36: initially with sitaxentan
column37: which was suspended due to its withdrawal from the market and replaced by ambrisentan 5 mg/24 hours
column38: later adding tadalafil 40 mg/24 hours. In November 2018
column39: he was referred for the first time to the adult congenital heart disease clinic at our hospital. At that time he was clinically stable with NYHA I-II/IV dyspnoea. NT-proBNP 279 pg/ml. TTE unchanged with respect to previous ones. On treatment with ambrisentan 10 mg/24 hours + tadalafil 40 mg/24 hours + symbicort 160/4.5 mcg 1 inhalations/12 hours. Subsequent check-ups did not show much functional change
column40: changes in TTE or treatment. In April 2019
column41: a cardiac MRI was performed
column42: showing progression of RV dysfunction with RV ejection fraction (RVEF) of 37% (RVEF in May 2018 was 57%). However
column43: it seems that the patient is reluctant to have a follow-up right heart catheterisation
column44: even though it is suggested to him to consider adding a third drug to the treatment of his PAH.  Current disease In June 2019
column45: the patient was admitted for an episode of frank haemoptysis (50 cc) and a gurgling sensation in the left hemithorax that required admission to the coronary unit of our hospital for close monitoring. He had previously presented another episode of haemoptysis in April of the same year
column46: which required admission to the respiratory department and had been managed conservatively.  Physical examination On admission to the coronary unit
column47: the patient was haemodynamically stable (blood pressure (BP) 110/58 mmHg
column48: heart rate (HR) 98 bpm)
column49: oxygen saturation (O2) 96% with inspired O2 fraction (FiO2) 21% and no signs of right HF.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: sinus rhythm at 50 bpm
column50: normal PR
column51: right axis
column52: QRS with BCRDHH morphology with criteria of HVD and secondary repolarisation alterations in precordial leads. CBC: glucose 93 mg/dl
column53: urea 32 mg/dl
column54: creatinine 1.09 mg/dl
column55: GPT 14 U/L
column56: bilirubin 0.9 mg/dl
column57: calcium 9.6 mg/dl
column58: sodium 140 mEq/l
column59: potassium null
column60: chlorine 105 mEq/l
column61: albumin 4.4 g/dl
column62: C-reactive protein (CRP) 1.60 mg/l
column63: creatine kinase (CK) 104 U/l
column64: lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) null. Haemoglobin 20.9 g/dl
column65: haematocrit 59.5%
column66: mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 85.5 fL
column67: mean corpuscular haemoglobin (MCH) 30 pg
column68: erythrocyte distribution amplitude (EDA) 14.8%
column69: platelets 172000
column70: 5170 leukocytes (35.40% lymphocytes
column71: 52.60% neutrophils
column72: 7.70% monocytes). Prothrombin time 66%
column73: international normalised ratio (INR) 1.3
column74: activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT) 42s
column75: fibrinogen 313 mg/dl. Chest X-ray: cardiothoracic index 0.5
column76: with prominence of the pulmonary arteries. TTE: left ventricle (LV) neither dilated nor hypertrophic with preserved global function
column77: very marked septal flattening due to overload of right pressures
column78: with a diastolic eccentricity index of 1.5. The mitral valve is normofunctioning and the aortic valve is bicuspid due to complete fusion of the right and left coronary sinuses
column79: with minimal aortic insufficiency. The RV is moderately dilated and severely hypertrophic
column80: with moderately depressed function. The tricuspid valve is thickened with poorly visualised right ventricle-right atrium (RV-RA) gradient
column81: but at least 100 mmHg. The inferior vena cava is not dilated
column82: with inspiratory collapse greater than 50%. Mild flow acceleration of up to 26 mmHg without diastolic tail is seen in the arch. Dilated pulmonary artery trunk (40 mm). The ductus is wide
column83: with right-to-left systolic flow.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient remained monitored and under conservative treatment with oral codeine and morphine chloride for 24 hours in the coronary unit
column84: haemodynamically stable at all times and with no new episodes of haemoptysis. The patient was transferred to the reference hospital for pulmonary hypertension to assess the possibility of starting a third line of treatment for PAH. At this hospital
column85: a new right catheterisation was performed prior to starting intravenous prostacyclin (PAPm 87 mmHg
column86: PCP 6 mmHg
column87: PVR 17.34 UW
column88: GC by thermodilution 4.67 l/min). Initially
column89: epoprostenol was prescribed
column90: but it required several changes of venous line due to phlebitis
column91: so finally
column92: titration with subcutaneous treprostinil was started with good tolerance
column93: reaching a dose of 24 ng/kg/min at discharge. After implantation of the subcutaneous pump
column94: treprostinil can be progressively increased. Since the start of the drug
column95: the patient reports clinical improvement
column96: no alarm symptoms and no new episodes of haemoptysis. In addition
column97: the control echocardiogram performed showed an improvement in RV function
column98: which was currently at the lower limit of normality.  DIAGNOSIS Severe residual pulmonary arterial hypertension after surgery. Intervened patent ductus arteriosus. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 53-year-old woman with no known allergic reactions to medications.  History Family history: sudden death during sleep of maternal grandfather at 70 years of age and of a maternal uncle at 50 years of age
column3: also during sleep. Daughter with long QT on baseline ECG and son with incipient hypertrophic cardiomyopathy phenotype.  Personal history: No toxic habits
column4: no arterial hypertension (AHT)
column5: no diabetes
column6: no dyslipidaemia. Non-obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: accidental diagnosis in another centre after starting a study due to palpitations. Phenotype with asymmetric septal hypertrophy
column7: with a maximum thickness of 18 mm in the basal anterior septum
column8: maximum gradient of 15 mmHg
column9: LVEF 65% and faint mesocardial fibrosis in areas of hypertrophy and at the lower insertion point of the RV in cardiac MRI. Holter: sinus rhythm with an average heart rate of 60 bpm
column10: anecdotal supraventricular extrasystoles with a SVT salvo of 4 beats
column11: anecdotal ventricular extrasystoles with a nocturnal triplet at 90 bpm
column12: with no other events. Ergometry with 8.8 METS
column13: clinically negative
column14: electrocardiographically positive from minute 5 (upward sloping ST-segment depression in II
column15: III
column16: aVF
column17: V5 and V6 of up to 1.5 mm
column18: which persists at minute 2 of recovery
column19: subsiding spontaneously)
column20: with a drop in blood pressure at maximum effort
column21: although asymptomatic. Overlap with long QT syndrome (LQTS). Genetic study: no pathogenic/probably pathogenic variant related to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is identified. A probably pathogenic variant in KCNQ1 compatible with LQTS type 1 is identified
column22: also confirmed in his daughter. Other: fibromyalgia
column23: chronic low back pain. Surgical interventions: hysterectomy and double adnexectomy due to metrorrhagia. Usual treatment: propanolol 10 mg every 8 hours
column24: duloxetine 60 mg every 24 hours.  Present illness The patient was referred from another centre for an episode of loss of consciousness the previous night in bed
column25: witnessed by her husband
column26: who reported snoring
column27: ocular eversion and tonic spasm lasting a few seconds
column28: for which she did not consult. The following morning she presented with precordial pressure and went to the emergency department
column29: where atrial fibrillation with controlled response was observed
column30: which spontaneously reverted to sinus bradycardia with complete cessation of the precordial pressure. He reported almost daily palpitations lasting a few minutes
column31: unrelated to exertion
column33: as well as dyspnoea on moderate exertion.  Physical examination Blood pressure (BP) 120/80 mmHg; heart rate (HR) 55 bpm. Good general condition. Conscious and oriented
column34: eupneic
column35: well perfused. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column36: no murmurs at rest or with Valsalva manoeuvres. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur with no added sounds. Lower limbs: no oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis
column37: pulses present and symmetrical.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Baseline ECG: sinus bradycardia at 50 bpm

column39: narrow QRS with normal axis

column41: aVF
column42: V4 and V5

column44: leukocytes 6

Transthoracic echocardiogram: left ventricle of normal size with severe asymmetric septal hypertrophy (IVSd 18 mm; PPd 13 mm) generating acceleration in the LV outflow tract without significant obstruction either at baseline or with Valsalva (maximum gradient 15 mmHg). Preserved global systolic function without segmental alterations of contractility (LVEF 65%). Diastolic pattern compatible with impaired relaxation. Moderately dilated left atrium (area 30 cm2). Preserved RVEF. Mitral valve with good opening and mild mitral insufficiency (MI). No SAM is seen. Poorly visualised aortic valve with trivalve impression and no pathological flow. Poorly visualised tricuspid valve that appears normal without tricuspid insufficiency (TI) that would allow estimation of pulmonary artery systolic pressure (PSAP). No indirect evidence of pulmonary hypertension (PHT). Inferior vena cava not dilated with adequate inspiratory collapse. Aortic root of normal size with slight dilatation of tubular ascending aorta (40 mm)

column62: cardiothoracic index within normal
column63: lung parenchyma without alterations

column65: narrow QRS with normal axis
column66: biphasic T wave in III
column67: aVF
column68: V4 and V5
column69: notched in V2. QTc 480 ms.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION This is a patient with a previous diagnosis of non-obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with overlapping long QT syndrome type 1 who presented with syncope of cardiogenic profile under beta-blocker treatment. Given the patient's HCM Risk-SCD of 3.52% (low 5-year risk)
column70: the nocturnal profile of syncope and family history of nocturnal sudden death (SD)
column71: it seems likely that the syncopal event is related to long QT syndrome type 1 rather than to her hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. In the presence of cardiogenic syncope under beta-blocker treatment
column72: ICD implantation was decided. Given the diagnosis of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and the finding of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation not previously documented
column73: anticoagulant treatment was started. Bicameral ICD implantation was performed without incident
column74: being programmed in DDDR ICD mode
column75: at a pacing rate of 60 bpm.  DIAGNOSIS Syncope with cardiogenic profile. Non-obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with overlapping long QT syndrome type 1 (probably pathogenic variant in KCNQ1). Symptomatic paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (haemodynamic angina in relation to rapid ventricular response). Present illness A 78-year-old man was admitted from the emergency department to the internal medicine department for painless swelling of the right knee for the last 1 month with no history of trauma and no additional inflammatory semiology. An anamnesis was carried out by apparatus and was anodyne

column15: without skin erythema or local temperature increase. Mild pain on movement. column41: more striking in the right knee. ECG performed with magnesium correction and potassium 3.1 mEq/l: sinus rhythm at 75 beats per minute. Normal PR. Narrow QRS. column42: the patient develops a Brugada type 1 pattern. Genetic test for Brugada syndrome: negative.  CLINICAL COURSE The gonalgia was treated with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) with suspicion of a pseudogout crisis due to probable chondrocalcinosis
column43: with complete resolution of the symptoms within several days. In view of the ECG findings described above
column44: the ionic alterations were corrected and the ECG pattern evolved as shown in the images. The patient remained completely asymptomatic from the cardiovascular point of view
column45: and was discharged with subsequent controls in outpatient electrophysiology consultations
column46: with suspicion of Brugada pattern phenocopy in the context of ionic alterations. A flecainide test was performed on an outpatient basis with intravenous administration of this drug at a dose of 2 mg/kg in 10 minutes
column47: obtaining a Brugada type 1 pattern. He remained in the hospital for several hours with telemetry without observing arrhythmic events. Subsequently
column48: echocardiography was performed without showing notable alterations (preserved LVEF
column49: without significant valvular heart disease). A genetic study of p channelopathies/myocardiopathy was performed
column50: which was negative. The patient has remained asymptomatic in his 73 years of life from the cardiovascular point of view
column51: with no notable family history or sudden deaths. An echocardiogram was also performed without showing any notable alterations (preserved LVEF
column52: no significant valvular heart disease). Therefore
column53: what initially appeared to be only a Brugada pattern phenocopy turned out to be true Brugada syndrome. He was informed of the current process and of the prohibited drugs
column54: prohibition of alcohol and the rapid treatment of fever with antipyretics
column55: which is also reflected in his history. At present
column56: she has also started the family study for the control of her relatives.  DIAGNOSIS Brugada syndrome. No structural heart disease (preserved LVEF). |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History No known allergic drug reactions. Active smoking: 30 cigarettes a day. Morbid obesity. Arterial hypertension. Insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus. Dyslipidaemia. Hyperuricaemia. Hypothyroidism. Stage 3B chronic kidney disease (basal glomerular filtration rate 30-35 ml/min). Peripheral arterial disease: intermittent claudication Fontaine grade IIa. Ischaemic heart disease: admitted for unstable angina in 2008. Catheterisation revealed severe damage to three vessels (anterior descending [DA]
column3: right coronary [CD]
column4: first obtuse marginal [OM]). Only the LAD was surgically revascularised with a left internal mammary artery graft. Usual treatment: acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) 100 mg per day
column5: enalapril 20 mg per day
column6: atenolol 12.5 mg per day
column7: furosemide 40 mg at breakfast and lunch
column8: metformin 850 mg every 12 hours
column9: mixed insulin (regular 30%
column10: isophane 70%) 30 units in the morning and 20 units in the evening
column11: simvastatin 40 mg per day
column12: allopurinol 100 mg per day
column13: eutirox 50 mcg per day
column14: omeprazole 20 mg per day.  Present illness An 84-year-old woman came to the emergency department for an episode of non-radiating central thoracic pain that appeared with minimal effort
column15: lasting minutes and ceased spontaneously
column16: with similar characteristics to her previous angina
column17: although of lesser intensity. While in the emergency department
column18: she presented another episode
column19: during which dynamic electrocardiographic changes were observed
column20: which subsided with the administration of sublingual nitroglycerine. The patient had been asymptomatic from the cardiovascular point of view since her previous admission in 2008.  Physical examination Vital signs: blood pressure in left arm 125/63 mmHg
column21: in right arm 143/75 mmHg. Heart rate 63 bpm. Oxygen saturation 97% basal. Good general condition. Conscious and oriented
column22: cooperative
column23: normohydrated and normoperfused. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column24: systolic murmur II/VI predominantly in aortic focus
column25: with second noise present. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur
column26: with no added sounds. Abdomen: hydro-aerial sounds preserved
column27: soft and depressible
column28: not painful on palpation. Lower limbs: no oedema
column29: weak distal pulses.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS CBC on admission: haemoglobin 16.6 g/dL without alterations
column30: no leukocytosis. Normal haemostasis. Glucose 152 mg/dl
column31: creatinine 1.44 mg/dl
column33: sodium 143 mmol/l
column34: potassium 4.1 mmol/l
column35: chlorine 106 mmol/l
column36: C-reactive protein 3.8 mg/l
column37: two determinations of troponin I 0.0 ng/ml. LDL 119 mg/dl. HbA1c 8.6%. Electrocardiogram (ECG) with chest pain: atrial fibrillation at 95 bpm. Narrow QRS. Low voltages. Infradevelation of 1 mm and ST rectification from V2 to V6
column38: DI and aVL. Painless ECG: sinus rhythm at 65 bpm. Correction of repolarisation alterations. Coronary angiography: 90% lesion in the mid-segment of the LAD. Mammary bridge to mid-distal LAD is observed
column39: which fills retrograde from the LAD. Dominant circumflex (Cx) chronically occluded from the proximal segment
column40: with poor filling by homocoronary collaterals distally. Poorly developed DC with chronic occlusion in the middle segment
column41: distally filled by homocoronary collateral circulation. The bridge from the mammary to the LAD is patent and without lesions. Significant stenosis is observed at the origin of the left subclavian artery with a pressure gradient across it of 60 mmHg. Angio-CT scan: chronic stenosis of the proximal left subclavian artery about 32 mm from its origin
column42: conditioned by a mixed plaque. The origin of the left internal mammary artery is 11 mm from the plaque. Echocardiogram: non-dilated left ventricle with preserved ejection fraction. Alterations of segmental contractility in inferior and inferolateral segments. Mild left ventricular hypertrophy. Right ventricle of normal size and function. Biauricular dilatation. No significant valvulopathies.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION After finding significant stenosis of the left subclavian artery with compromised flow towards the mammary bypass to the anterior descending artery
column43: CT angiography was performed to evaluate the three-dimensional anatomy of the stenosis. Given the patient's profile and her high surgical risk
column44: percutaneous revascularisation was chosen
column45: with angioplasty and destent implantation in the left subclavian artery
column46: which proceeded without complications. During admission
column47: deterioration of renal function was observed in relation to contrast administration and insufficient fluid intake
column48: which improved with serum therapy
column49: returning to baseline creatinine and glomerular filtration rates. The patient was discharged with special emphasis on the control of cardiovascular risk factors: smoking cessation
column50: heart-healthy diet
column51: weight loss
column52: physical exercise... As for pharmacological treatment of risk factors
column53: liraglutide was added to improve glycaemic control and promote weight loss
column54: and simvastatin 40 mg was replaced by atorvastatin 80 mg to achieve LDL target of less than 55 mg/dl. Regarding the antithrombotic regimen
column55: at discharge
column56: double therapy was prescribed with rivaroxaban 10 mg per day and clopidogrel 75 mg per day
column57: suspending the ASA previously taken by the patient. After the intervention
column58: the patient remained asymptomatic
column59: with no new episodes of chest pain during admission and subsequent follow-up in outpatient clinics.  DIAGNOSIS Unstable angina due to subclavian-coronary steal syndrome. In a patient with severe three-vessel coronary artery disease and partial surgical revascularisation with left internal mammary bypass to anterior descending artery in 2008. Preserved LV systolic function. Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation in this context. Acute renal failure AKIN III on chronic kidney disease
column60: prerenal origin and iodinated contrast nephrotoxicity. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
