column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History No known drug allergies. Cardiovascular risk factors: smoking and occasional alcohol consumption (very low burden). No other drug use. No arterial hypertension (AHT)
column3: no dyslipidaemia
column4: no diabetes mellitus. Cardiological history: no known cardiological history
column5: no family history of heart disease or sudden death in the family. Surgical interventions: tonsillectomy. No usual treatment.  Present illness A 36-year-old male patient came to the emergency department referred from his health centre for palpitations and syncope
column6: with an electrocardiogram (ECG) showing irregular tachycardia with wide QRS. After getting up quickly from the sofa
column7: the patient reported sudden onset of palpitations
column8: without initial dizziness. Subsequently
column9: after approximately one minute
column10: he went to the bathroom to urinate and after urinating
column11: he reported a rapid sensation of dizziness and fell to the floor
column12: with spontaneous recovery of consciousness (he reported approximately 10 minutes of loss of consciousness
column13: he was alone at home
column14: with no witnesses). After the episode
column15: he reported only palpitations
column16: denying chest pain
column17: dyspnoea or other symptoms. Given the persistence of the palpitations and after recovering from the syncope
column18: he decided to consult his health centre and was referred to our centre. The patient denies the use of toxic substances. He reported 4 similar episodes of palpitations related to physical effort for which he had never consulted before
column19: self-limited
column20: without syncope.  Physical examination On arrival at the emergency department
column21: good general condition
column22: normal colour
column23: normohydrated
column24: eupneic at rest. Blood pressure (BP) 147/68 mmHg. Heart rate (HR) 180-210 bpm. SpO2 (FiO2 21%) 99%. Neurological examination: conscious and oriented
column25: alert
column26: cooperative. No neurological focality. Cardiac and pulmonary auscultation: irregular tachycardic sounds
column27: no murmurs. Preserved vesicular murmur (VCM)
column28: without added noises. Abdomen soft
column29: depressible
column30: without masses or megaliths. No pain on palpation. No signs of peritoneal irritation. Lower limbs: no oedema
column31: no signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   COMPLEMENTARY TESTS  ECG: Initial ECG on arrival at the ED: wide QRS irregular tachycardia with approximate ventricular response between 180-210 bpm. Occasionally there are narrow QRS beats. ECG after CVE: sinus rhythm at 95 bpm
column33: 60o axis
column34: QRS 120 ms with positive delta wave in inferior aspect and from V3 to V5. No repolarisation abnormalities. ECG at discharge: sinus rhythm 80 bpm. PR 150 msg. Narrow QRS without repolarisation alterations.  Chest X-ray: cardiothoracic index (CTI) within normal
column35: no condensation or pleural effusion
column36: no signs of pneumothorax.  Laboratory tests: CBC: red blood cells 5.08 10*12/l
column37: haemoglobin 15.6 g/dl
column38: haematocrit 47%
column39: leukocytes * 11.6 10*9/l
column40: neutrophils 50.5%
column41: lymphocytes 38.3%
column42: platelets 295 10*9/l. Biochemistry: glucose * 111 mg/dl
column43: sodium 139 mEq/l
column44: potassium 3.6 mEq/l
column45: chlorine 102 mEq/l
column46: GPT 39 U/l
column47: urea 23.1 mg/dl
column48: creatinine 0.87 mg/dl
column49: C-reactive protein 0.06 mg/dl. Baseline haemostasis: prothrombin time 10.3 sec; I. Quick 99; INR 1.02; aPTT 25.9 sec. Echocardiogram: left ventricle with preserved diameters and global systolic function. Absence of alterations in segmental contractility at rest. Trivial mitral insufficiency. Aortic root 36 mm
column50: without valvulopathies. Right ventricle of preserved size and function. Minimal tricuspid insufficiency that allows estimating PAPs of approximately 30 mmHg. Normal inferior vena cava. Electrophysiological study (EEF): on ECG suspicion of a possible left lateral accessory pathway
column51: access was gained via the retrograde aortic route and an ablation catheter was located in the lateral mitral annulus
column52: obtaining precocities of up to -10 ms with respect to delta wave and QS in unipolar
column53: performing 3 applications of RF reaching up to 56 oC temperature with cessation of anterograde and retrograde conduction of the pathway. With programmed st. A programmed (600/260)
column54: orthodromic tachycardia is induced by another left posterior accessory pathway and ablation is performed during tachycardia
column55: observing cessation of tachycardia with a V without rising to A. After this
column56: no eccentric retrograde conduction is observed and tachycardia is not induced. The result was maintained after 20 min of waiting and the procedure was terminated.   CLINICAL EVOLUTION On arrival at the emergency department of our centre
column57: given the clinical and ECG findings at the health centre
column58: the patient was transferred directly to the critical care unit. An ECG was performed with persistent wide QRS irregular tachycardia and
column59: given haemodynamic stability and good clinical tolerance to the tachycardia
column60: pharmacological cardioversion was decided with procainamide 200 mg i.v. without cessation of tachycardia. Subsequently
column61: the patient was sedated with 2 mg of midazolam and 6 mg of etomidate
column62: and electrical cardioversion (ECV) was performed with a 200 J shock
column63: and the patient went into sinus rhythm at 75 bpm. The post-CVE ECG showed sinus rhythm with short PR with delta wave + in inferior and lateral leads. In light of the ECGs
column64: the patient was labelled as having syncopal pre-excited atrial fibrillation and was admitted to cardiology with continuous monitoring to complete the study and treatment. During his stay in cardiology the patient remained asymptomatic and without arrhythmic events on monitoring. Morphological studies were completed with transthoracic echocardiography (TTE)
column65: which showed no significant alterations. The convenience of performing accessory pathway ablation was explained to the patient
column66: as well as the risks of not doing so
column67: and the patient accepted the procedure. In the EPS
column68: 2 accessory pathways were located (left lateral and left posterior) and both were effectively ablated. In the absence of complications 24 hours after the procedure
column69: the patient was discharged home with ECG with no signs of pre-excitation. In subsequent ambulatory controls
column70: the patient remained asymptomatic and no pre-excitation was observed in the control ECGs.  DIAGNOSIS Syncopal pre-excited atrial fibrillation (AF). Left lateral and left posterior accessory pathway ablation. Normal left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) with trivial mitral regurgitation (MR). |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Male
column3: 41 years old
column4: from Romania. Hypertensive and smoker. History of syncope: 1999 in Romania: attributed according to the patient to a first CHF episode (no reports available). 2012: non-specific symptoms with suspected vasovagal aetiology. 2015: new episode with prodromes and post-critical period
column5: leading to a neurological study with cranial computed tomography (CT)
column6: which was found to be normal. 2016: two episodes
column7: with a cardiogenic profile. Admission to the cardiology ward. She came to the emergency department for two consecutive syncopal episodes
column8: the first of which was not witnessed
column9: while walking
column10: without prodromes
column11: with a fall to the ground and trauma to the jaw and mouth. While recovering from this (he got up and went to drink water)
column12: he had another episode
column13: this time preceded by intense heat and dizziness
column14: with loss of consciousness lasting seconds. Subsequent full recovery. No tonic-clonic movements or sphincter relaxation. Subsequently asymptomatic. No clinical chest pain or palpitations. No dyspnoea or signs of heart failure.  Physical examination Blood pressure (BP) 144/91 mmHg
column15: Spo2 99%
column16: heart rate (HR) 72 bpm. Conscious and oriented. Eupneic. Cardiopulmonary auscultation normal. Lower limbs: no oedema. Palpable and symmetrical pulses.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus rhythm at 52 bpm
column17: 90o axis
column18: narrow QRS
column19: asymmetric negative T in III and up to V2
column20: biphasic in V3. Notched QRS in V3. Early repolarisation in V6. Chest X-ray: cardiac shift to the left. Erasure of the right cardiac border (overlapping of the spinal column). Pectus excavatum. CBC: ultrasensitive troponin T 4 pg/ml. Glucose 85 mg/dl
column21: urea 35 mg/dl
column22: creatinine 0.95 mg/dl. Sodium 137 mmol/l. Potassium 4.2 mmol/l. CK 279 U/l. Haemoglobin 14.5 x10^3/mcl
column23: platelets 304x10^3/mcl
column24: leucocytes 13.29x10^3/mcl (N 86%). D-dimer 198 μg/ml. PET scan protocol: no repletion defects in main
column25: lobar or segmental pulmonary arteries. No mediastinal or hilar adenopathies of significant size. No images compatible with infiltrates
column26: nodules or pleural effusion. Echocardiogram: left ventricle (LV) not dilated or hypertrophic with preserved LVEF and no alterations in segmental contractility except septal flattening and anomalous movement in relation to right ventricular dilatation. Non-dilated left atrium (LA) with an AP diameter of 26 mm and area of 14 cm. Dilated right ventricle (RV) with diameters of 45 mm basally
column27: 40 mm medially and 59 mm longitudinally with borderline RVEF (TAPSE 16
column28: S DTI 14) with free wall hypokinesia and akinesia-dyskinesia at the apex. Aortic root and ascending aorta not dilated. Tricommissural aortic valve with preserved opening. Mitral and tricuspid of normal morphology. Inferior vena cava (IVC) not dilated. Aneurysm of the interatrial septum (AIS) that appears to be intact. No pericardial effusion is visualised. Normal diastolic function. Trivial mitral regurgitation (MR). Mild tricuspid regurgitation (TR). Signal-averaged ECG: filtered QRS duration: 108 ms
column29: RMS40: 37 mcV
column30: SAB: 23 ms. No positive criteria. Negative signal averaging study. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): morphological and functional sequences show non-dilated LV with normal wall thickness and normal global and regional EF. Normal LA. RA not dilated. RV not dilated
column31: with estimated RVEF 47%. At the level of the RV outflow tract
column33: with no other significant alterations in segmental contractility or aneurysmal areas. Cardiac displacement towards the left hemithorax
column34: with significant horizontalisation of the cardiac axis. No oedema is seen in T2 sequences. Perfusion sequences do not show any first-pass defects. No enhancement indicating pathological substrate was observed in the viability sequences. Extracardiac findings: lungs with normal vascularisation
column35: although there is volume loss in lingular segments associated with cardiac displacement.  Conclusion: Normal LV. RV not dilated
column36: with borderline EF (47%)
column37: without conclusive data for diagnosis of dysplasia. Electrophysiological study: negative study
column38: no data of channelopathy. At the end of the study and to complete the study
column39: a SJM model Confirm DM2100 subcutaneous Holter was implanted. Coronary CAT scan (image 4): normal cardiac cavities. Atria not dilated. Aortic valve: tricuspid
column40: morphologically normal. Mitral valve: morphologically normal. Coronary tree: Agatston 0. Dominance: right. Normal coronary anatomy. No abnormalities or stenosis. Rotation of the cardiac silhouette to the left and posterior and virtual absence of the pericardium
column41: with some residual tracts in the anterior margin of the right ventricle.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was admitted to the cardiology ward for further investigation. In the emergency department
column42: angio-CT ruled out PTE. Initially
column43: right ventricular dysplasia was suspected (ECG with negative T1-V2
column44: echocardiogram with a doubtful aneurysmal image in the right ventricle)
column45: so the study was completed with MRI and a new echocardiogram was repeated: the right ventricle was of normal size
column46: without dilatation or clear criteria of dysplasia. During admission
column47: he remained asymptomatic and stable
column48: without dizziness or syncope and with telemetry that did not record any event (no ventricular or supraventricular extrasystoles or arrhythmias of any kind). The syncope study was completed with signal-averaged ECG
column49: flecainide test and electrophysiological study with no inducibility of ventricular tachycardia or findings justifying an arrhythmic mechanism. A subcutaneous Holter was implanted. A coronary CAT scan was also performed which ruled out coronary anomalies
column50: with probable almost total agenesis of the left pericardium (chest X-ray also compatible with this diagnosis)
column51: which does not justify the current clinical picture.  DIAGNOSIS Repeated syncope of non-filarial origin (probably neuromediated). Negative electrophysiological study. Implantable Holter. Coronary CAT scan with no coronary lesions or anomalies. Almost total pericardial agenesis. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History 70-year-old woman. No known drug allergies. No toxic habits. Cardiovascular risk factors: hypertension and dyslipidaemia. Permanent atrial fibrillation (AF) anticoagulated with acenucoumarol since 2014. Surgical interventions: right knee. Autonomous for basic activities of daily living. Active life
column3: no previous angina or dyspnoea. Usual treatment: digoxin 0.25 mg daily
column4: lorazepam 1 mg at bedtime
column5: acenocoumarol 4 mg as prescribed
column6: amlodipine/telmisartan 80/5 mg at dinner
column7: verapamil 240 mg at breakfast
column8: atorvastatin 40 mg at dinner
column9: tramadol 100 mg if required
column10: paracetamol 1 g if required
column11: topical calcipotriol 0.005%.  Present illness 70-year-old woman who started the morning of admission
column12: while doing housework
column13: with oppressive chest pain
column14: radiating to the left upper limb
column15: without accompanying vegetative cortex
column16: which forced her to stop and persisted at rest for about 30 minutes. Slight discomfort persisted in the left hemithorax at the time of assessment.  Physical examination Blood pressure (BP) 147/80 mmHg; heart rate (HR) 80 bpm; SatO2 97% on room air; afebrile. Conscious
column17: oriented
column18: normal colour and well perfused. Head and neck: no jugular plethora. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column19: no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur. Abdomen: nondescript. Lower limbs: trophic disorders due to chronic venous insufficiency. Right paedial pulse present
column20: left absent. No oedema.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram (ECG) on arrival at the emergency department: AF with ventricular response at 75 bpm. Narrow QRS
column21: axis at 30o. No repolarisation alterations. Normal QTc. Laboratory tests on admission: urea 24 mg/dl
column22: creatinine 0.58 mg/dl
column23: albumin 3.5 g/dl
column24: total bilirubin 0.9 mg/dl
column25: GPT 13 U/L
column26: CK 134 U/l
column27: troponin T US 482 ng/l (normal < 14 ng/l)
column28: LDH 233 U/l
column29: sodium 140 mEq/l
column30: potassium 3.6 mEq/l
column31: CRP 11 mg/l
column33: platelets 232.000 /μl
column34: leukocytes 8
column35: 300 /μl (lymphocytes 25%
column36: neutrophils 64%). Protombin index 66%
column37: INR 1.3
column38: aPTT 38 sec. Total cholesterol 181 mg/dl
column39: triglycerides 116 mg/dl
column40: LDL 109 mg/dl
column41: HDL 49 mg/dl
column42: non-HDL cholesterol 132 mg/dl. Serum chylomicrons negative. Chest X-ray on admission: normal cardiothoracic index. No congestive signs
column43: no condensation in the lung parenchyma. Free costophrenic sinuses. Echocardiogram on admission to the coronary unit: left ventricle (LV) not dilated
column44: with hypertrophy at the level of the interventricular septum. Moderately depressed global systolic function (LVEF 35%) due to akinesia of the mid-apical segments of the septum
column45: anterior and lateral face and apical of the inferolateral and inferior face. Aortic root not dilated. Trivalve aortic valve
column46: sclerocalcified
column47: with preserved opening and mild insufficiency. Sclerocalcified mitral valve with restriction of the posterior leaflet and moderate insufficiency. Moderately dilated left atrium. Right ventricle (RV) not dilated
column48: normocontractile. Mild tricuspid insufficiency that does not allow estimation of RV-AD gradient. Acceleration time in pulmonary artery not suggestive of pulmonary hypertension. No pericardial effusion. ECG on readmission to the coronary unit after an episode of pain on the ward: AF with ventricular response at 75 bpm. Q wave in V3-V4 with ST elevation in V3-V5
column49: maximum of 2 mm in V4
column50: negative T wave in V2-V6
column51: not present in previous ECGs. Urgent cardiac catheterisation: right radial access. Normal left main coronary artery. Dissection of the distal anterior descending artery (DA) up to the tip
column52: with occlusion of the vessel at a very distal level. Right circumflex and coronary artery without lesions. The patient was not considered suitable for percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). Balloon counterpulsation is implanted via the right femoral artery. Echocardiogram at discharge from the coronary unit: left ventricle of normal size. Basal anterior septum with severe hypertrophy with remaining wall thickness slightly increased. Ejection fraction by Simpson biplane of 48%. Akinesia of the apical segments
column53: with an area near the RV tip suggestive of pseudoaneurysm (1 cm) with a narrow and anfractuous neck filled with Sonovue contrast. Mild-moderate mitral insufficiency. Mild-moderate tricuspid insufficiency. RV-AD gradient of 35 mmHg
column54: undilated inferior vena cava with inspiratory collapse greater than 50%. Estimated PSAP of 40 mmHg. Minimal aortic insufficiency. Aortic root of normal size. No pericardial effusion. Angio-CT of coronary arteries: synchronised helical study without and with intravenous contrast. Median sternotomy. Post-surgical patch at apex level. Aneurysm and apical pseudoaneurysm up to 6 x 3 cm with several lobulations towards inferior aspect. No pericardial effusion. Small left pleural effusion and subsegmental atelectasis in the left lower lobe. ECG at discharge: AF with ventricular response at 88 bpm. Deep negative T waves from V2 to V6
column55: less pronounced negative T waves in DI
column56: aVL and DII.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION Woman with angina at rest
column57: ECG without repolarisation alterations
column58: ultrasensitive troponin T elevation and apical akinesia. Given the suspicion of tako-tsubo syndrome versus previous high-risk NSTEACS
column59: it was decided to admit her to the coronary unit for monitoring and clinical surveillance. Pending invasive coronary angiography
column60: treatment was started with double antiplatelet therapy and anticoagulation with enoxaparin (INR below 2). During the first 24 hours the patient remained asymptomatic
column61: without new episodes of pain
column62: haemodynamically and respiratory stable
column63: with no arrhythmic events on telemetry. Given her clinical stability
column64: it was decided to transfer her to the hospital ward with telemetry the day after her admission
column65: pending catheterisation. However
column66: a few hours after his admission to the ward
column67: he started again with chest pain of similar characteristics to the previous one
column68: this time presenting ST segment elevation from V3 to V5
column69: so emergent catheterisation was performed. The catheterisation showed spontaneous dissection at the level of the distal LAD
column70: with very distal occlusion that was not considered susceptible to percutaneous treatment
column71: and it was decided to implant an intra-aortic balloon counterpulsation device to improve coronary perfusion. The patient was readmitted to the coronary unit
column72: maintaining the previously established treatment with double antiplatelet therapy (clopidogrel + ASA) and anticoagulation with enoxaparin. While stable
column73: 12 hours after the catheterisation
column74: she suddenly began to feel unwell
column75: with sinus tachycardia and hypotension up to 50/30 mmHg
column76: with rapid worsening and deterioration of the level of consciousness. Echocardioscopy showed severe hyperechogenic pericardial effusion not previously present
column77: with involvement of the right chambers. Suspicion of cardiac tamponade secondary to cardiac rupture led to orotracheal intubation
column78: emergency pericardiocentesis with scant haemorrhagic fluid output
column79: and the cardiac surgery team was notified for emergency surgery. Noradrenaline perfusion is started at increasing doses
column80: intensive serum therapy and several red blood cell concentrates are transfused. On arrival of the cardiac surgeons
column81: an urgent sternotomy was performed in the coronary unit box with extraction of abundant clots and visualisation of active bleeding in the apical infarcted region
column82: making it difficult to contain the bleeding. He presented with brief CRA due to AESP which returned after direct cardiac massage and digital tamponade of the bleeding point. After obtaining systolic blood pressure (SBP) figures of around 70-100 mmHg
column83: the patient was transferred to the cardiac surgery operating theatre and the apical defect was repaired with direct suture and BioGlue
column84: which proved difficult due to the extensive friable area
column85: with the need for resternotomy after further bleeding on the first attempt to transfer him to the coronary unit. After surgery
column86: she was admitted to the coronary unit sedated
column87: well adapted to the ventilator in "Pressure Controlled Volume" mode with standard parameters
column88: with continuous perfusion of dobutamine
column89: noradrenaline and adrenaline for mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 100 mmHg
column90: with 1:1 balloon counterpulsation. In the days following this event
column91: she remained sedated and intubated
column93: although progressively at lower doses. Persistent anuria
column94: so on the third day of admission she consulted the nephrology department
column95: which started haemofiltration. On the fourth day and again suddenly
column96: he presented a new episode of severe hypotension up to 40-50 mmHg with 500 ml of rapid haematic output in the thoracic drainage tubes. Echocardioscopy was performed and showed cardiac tamponade secondary to effusion and the presence of clots in the right chambers. In view of the findings
column97: cardiac surgery was immediately notified and the sternotomy was opened in the same room
column98: extracting abundant clots from the pericardial sac
column99: again visualising apical tearing with abundant active bleeding. They proceeded to perform multiple stitches with Teflon support. During the procedure
column100: he presented severe arterial hypotension requiring high doses of catecholamines (noradrenaline and adrenaline
column101: as well as repeated boluses of phenylephrine). Sternotomy was left open with a Bogotá bag until 48 hours later
column102: when sternal closure was performed as scheduled
column103: which passed without incident. The patient was subsequently admitted to the coronary unit for a further 21 days
column104: with a slow but favourable clinical evolution. In the control echocardiogram prior to discharge to the ward
column105: a progressive improvement in biventricular function was observed
column107: due to the presence of a patch in the apex
column108: drawing attention to the existence of a 1 cm pseudoaneurysm in the junctions of the middle segment with the apical segment of the inferior face. After improvement in renal function
column109: a CT angiography of the coronary arteries was requested on the ward
column110: showing an aneurysm and apical and lower apical polylobulated pseudoaneurysm. After discussing the case with cardiac surgery
column111: given the high risk of reoperation
column112: conservative medical treatment was decided. After a total of 74 days in hospital
column113: the patient was discharged home with haemodialysis sessions scheduled every other day
column114: and is currently progressively recovering renal function
column115: asymptomatic from the cardiological point of view
column116: pending an outpatient echocardiogram. Medication at discharge: omeprazole 20 mg at breakfast
column118: enoxaparin 40 mg intra-dialysis circuit on Tuesdays
column119: Thursdays and Sundays and subcutaneous the rest of the days
column121: atorvastatin 20 mg at dinner.  DIAGNOSIS Main diagnosis: Killip I anterior STEMI. Spontaneous distal LAD dissection with distal vessel occlusion
column122: not amenable to coronary intervention. CRA by pulseless electrical activity (PEA) in the context of cardiac tamponade due to rupture of the free wall of the left ventricle
column123: on two occasions.  Secondary diagnoses: Pseudonaneurysm and apical and lower apical polylobulated aneurysm. Slightly depressed LVEF. Severe acute renal failure on haemodialysis. Polytransfusion. Permanent anticoagulated atrial fibrillation. Arterial hypertension. Dyslipidaemia. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  50-year-old male
column3: no known drug allergies. No toxic habits. No cardiovascular risk factors. No relevant family history. No medical or surgical history. No chronic treatments.  First consultation: Referred to cardiology consultation from the emergency department. He had consulted for an episode of palpitations and supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) was identified
column4: which slowed with vagal manoeuvres but was reversed with IV atenolol. Physical examination was unaltered. At the consultation
column5: the diagnosis of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia was established and it was decided to start treatment with beta-blockers (bisoprolol 2.5 mg at breakfast)
column6: request 24-hour Holter and transthoracic echocardiography (TTE).  Second consultation (at 5 months): In the time between consultations
column7: he attended the emergency department three times for palpitations related to SVT episodes that sometimes reverted with vagal manoeuvres. Several medication changes due to intolerance or ineffectiveness. At the time of the second assessment she was on atenolol 50 mg c/24 hours. Prior to the consultation
column8: a TTE was performed which showed dilatation of the right chambers with normal RV systolic function and PSAP 26 + PVC. An agitated saline test was performed with no evidence of bubble passage between cavities
column9: which was interpreted as an improbable sign of shunt. 24-hour Holter in sinus rhythm with adequate heart rate (HR) and one episode of non-sustained SVT (< 30 seconds).  Given the frequency of tachyarrhythmic episodes
column10: the patient was referred to the electrophysiology department for evaluation of ablation. In view of the echocardiographic findings
column11: cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was requested in order to try to identify the aetiology of the dilatation of the right chambers. Electrophysiology consultation: It was decided to request an electrophysiological study and ablation in the face of symptomatic and recurrent TPSV of one year's evolution
column12: despite beta-blockers and which were suppressed by vagal manoeuvres.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram (ECG) in the emergency department: supraventricular rhythm at 120 bpm
column13: one sinus beat and in the rest with variable RP-PR intervals and RP > 70ms. Narrow QRS with 60o axis. ST-segment depression of 1mm from V3-V5. Baseline ECG: sinus rhythm. No data of pre-excitation. No other specific alterations. CBC: glucose 108 mg/dl
column14: urea 48 mg/dl
column15: creatinine 0.86 mg/dl
column16: sodium 137 mEq/l
column17: potassium 4.2 mEq/l
column18: TSH 1.83 mU/l
column19: haemoglobin 16.6 g/dl
column20: leucocytes 9250/microL
column21: platelets 331000/microL. 24-hour Holter: 24-hour electrocardiographic recording. Sinus rhythm throughout the tracing
column22: mean HR 85 bpm. No significant block or pauses. Streak of non-sustained supraventricular tachycardia. TTE: right ventricular dilatation (RV/LV ratio 1.1
column23: baseline DTD 55 mm and RV outflow tract 43 mm)
column24: with preserved systolic function. Mild functional tricuspid regurgitation. Estimated PSAP of 26 mmHg (+PVC). Non-dilated left ventricle with normal wall thickness. Preserved systolic function. Prolonged relaxation. No significant valvulopathies. TTE with agitated saline: injection of agitated saline without bubbles passing into the left cavities either at baseline or after the Valsalva manoeuvre. The existence of intra- or extracardiac shunt is unlikely.  MRI of the heart: Conclusion: LV of normal size and systolic function. No areas of hypertrophy
column25: no compaction or late enhancement. Dilated RV with normal systolic function. Extracardiac left-right shunt due to anomalous venous drainage from the right superior pulmonary vein to the superior vena cava with Qp/Qs of 1.7.  Most relevant data: RV: dilated
column26: without morphological alterations
column27: with VTD of 125 ml/m2 (range 55-105 ml/m2) and STV of 51 ml/m2 (range 15-43 ml/m2). EF 59%
column28: cardiac output 7.9 l/min and stroke volume/beat 149 ml. Normal contractility. Anomalous venous drainage from the right superior pulmonary vein to the superior vena cava. LA: area 21 cm2
column29: slightly dilated. RA: area of 29 cm2
column30: slightly dilated. Flow quantification in aortic root (phase contrast velocity coding). Anterograde volume 80 ml and retrograde volume 4.7 ml. Regurgitation fraction: 5.9%. Quantification of flow in main pulmonary artery (phase contrast velocity coding). Anterograde volume 139 ml and retrograde volume 4 ml. Regurgitation fraction: 3%. Qp/Qs: 1.7.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION In the time until the next consultation
column31: an electrophysiological study was carried out with the finding of focal atrial tachycardia
column32: with greater precocities at the level of the superior vena cava to the RA. Radiofrequency ablation of the focus was performed and proved effective. As can be seen in the results of the cardiac MRI
column33: an anomalous pulmonary venous connection (APVC) was found due to drainage of the right superior pulmonary vein to the superior vena cava
column34: which caused a volume overload of the right cavities that explained the dilatation
column35: with a significant left-right conshunt (Qp/Qs 1.7). No evidence of other associated defects. After ablation
column36: the episodes of supraventricular tachycardia ceased and the patient was in very good functional class. At this time
column37: according to the adult congenital heart disease guidelines (AHA/ACC 2018)
column38: we find that surgical repair in our patient has a grade IIA recommendation: "surgery may be useful for partial anomalous connections of both left and right pulmonary veins
column39: in asymptomatic adults with RV volume overload
column40: left-right shunt large enough to cause physiological sequelae (e.g.
column41: QP/QS > or = 1.7)
column42: and in those with a left-right shunt large enough to cause physiological sequelae (e.g.
column43: QP/QS > or = 1.7)
column44: and in those with a left-right shunt large enough to cause physiological sequelae (e.g.
column45: QP/QS > or = 1.7)". QP/QS >or= 1.5)
column46: in the presence of pulmonary pressures that are 50% lower than systemic pressures and pulmonary resistances less than one third of systemic pressures". It was decided to refer the patient to the adult congenital heart disease clinic where the need to request a right heart catheterisation to complete the haemodynamic study will be assessed before referring to cardiac surgery for repair.  DIAGNOSIS Anomalous pulmonary venous connection: drainage from right superior pulmonary vein to superior vena cava. Significant left-right shunt with right ventricular volume overload. Normal RV systolic function. Focal atrial tachycardia. Radiofrequency ablation effective. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO column2: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION A 59-year-old man
column3: hypertensive and hypercholesterolemic
column4: with a history of Bentall surgery with implantation of a mechanical aortic prosthesis and a valved tube
column5: as well as coronary revascularisation in the same procedure by means of a bypass of the left internal mammary artery to the anterior descending artery
column6: in its middle segment. This intervention took place 4 years ago. She has no other personal history of interest. On treatment with acenocoumarol
column7: atorvastatin 40 mg/day
column8: enalapril 10 mg/day and bisoprolol 2.5 mg/day. At the present time
column9: she presented to the emergency department with fever
column10: shivering and marked asthenia of 24 hours' evolution
column11: with no other associated clinical manifestations or epidemiological history of interest. On arrival
column12: he presented with fever (temperature 39°C) and hypotension (BP 85/45 mmHg)
column13: as well as sinus tachycardia (110 bpm). SatO2 90% on room air. Poor peripheral perfusion with coldness of acral parts. High jugular venous pressure. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column14: prosthetic sounds. Pulmonary auscultation: crackles in both bases. Lower extremities without oedema. The initial examinations and complementary tests revealed a situation of hyperlactacidemic metabolic acidosis
column15: which appeared serious
column16: with haemoglobin levels of 12.7 g/dl and leukocytes of 11
column17: 500 with neutrophilia (80%)
column18: and blood cultures were taken a few minutes after arrival.  In this context
column19: volume expansion
column20: empirical antibiotic therapy with cloxacillin
column21: ampicillin and gentamicin was started
column22: as well as administration of vasoactive drugs
column23: and he was admitted to the intensive care unit. Initially
column24: a transesophageal echocardiogram was performed
column25: with no data suggestive of infective endocarditis (IE).  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Two days after admission
column26: the patient developed marked right hemiparesis
column27: and an emergency CT scan and cranial MRI scan were performed
column28: showing the presence of a 2 x 2 cm intraparenchymal cerebral haemorrhage at the level of the left prerirolandic cortex
column29: interrupting his anticoagulant treatment (prescribed by his mechanical prosthesis). At this point in his evolution
column30: the results of the blood cultures taken were positive for Staphylococcus aureus
column31: and given the high suspicion of infective endocarditis
column32: a cerebral angiography was performed which ruled out the presence of mycotic aneurysms. Given the existence of a transesophageal echocardiogram 3 days earlier with no signs of endocarditis
column33: a positron emission tomography/computed tomography (PET/CT) with 18F-Fluorodeoxyglucose (18F-FDG) was performed
column34: which revealed abnormal uptake in the aortic valve prosthesis and in the aortic peritubular area. CT reconstruction showed periaortic thickening
column35: with irregular contour and peripheral late enhancement
column36: compatible with the existence of a periaortic abscess. No abnormal uptake of 18F-FDG was observed in extracardiac locations. At this point
column37: the patient already met the criteria for infective endocarditis (1 major and 3 minor criteria) due to S. aureus on the prosthetic aortic valve and valved tube. Three days later
column38: a new transesophageal echocardiogram was performed
column39: which documented the presence of a large aortic vegetation of 11 mm in greatest diameter. At this point
column40: one of the first debates in the patient's evolution arose
column41: with the complex decision to choose the optimal time for surgery
column42: which was postponed due to intracranial bleeding. As for the clinical situation at this time
column43: the patient remained afebrile and progressively experienced an ad integrum recovery of his neurological deficits. 18 days after his admission
column44: after an apparent good evolution
column45: 6 days before his scheduled surgery
column46: he presented with sudden abdominal pain
column47: arterial hypotension and a syncopal episode
column48: and an urgent venous blood gas analysis showed acute anaemisation with Hb of 6 g/dl. Intravenous crystalloids and red cell concentrates were administered. An emergency abdominal ultrasound showed the presence of free intra-abdominal fluid compatible with haemoperitoneum
column49: and a large splenic haematoma
column50: and he was readmitted to the intensive care unit. Thus
column51: with the diagnosis of acute abdomen
column52: urgent abdominal surgery was performed
column53: which confirmed the diagnosis of haemoperitoneum and acute splenic rupture
column54: making it necessary to proceed with a splenectomy to contain the bleeding
column55: with subsequent anatomopathological analysis confirming the aetiology of the aforementioned splenic rupture as secondary to septic embolism. Five days later
column56: when the patient was once again on the hospital ward
column57: he presented with severe rectorrhagia with anaemia and haemodynamic instability
column58: requiring transfusion of haemoconcentrates. Initially
column59: endoscopic management was performed and a diagnosis was made of stress gastropathy with multiple duodenal ulcers
column60: treated by implantation of haemoclips. Despite all this
column61: the bleeding recurred on two occasions
column62: so that emergency surgery was finally necessary
column63: and a partial duodenectomy was performed
column64: removing the affected segment.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION Finally
column65: one month after the initial admission
column66: his cardiac surgery for infective endocarditis was performed and the infected material was replaced by a new mechanical aortic prosthesis and a valved tube. S. aureus growth was confirmed in the removed prosthetic material. On the fifth day post-surgery
column67: the patient presented with dizziness and severe arterial hypotension and tachycardia
column68: and a transthoracic echocardiogram confirmed the diagnosis of cardiac tamponade
column69: and he underwent urgent pericardiectomy
column70: with an apparent good result. After his return to the hospital ward
column71: a control echocardiogram was performed to rule out further complications
column72: which revealed the presence of a pericardial haematoma measuring 6 x 7 x 9 cm
column73: involving the right atrium
column74: which had to be evacuated again in the operating theatre. Finally
column75: the patient managed to complete the 6 weeks of antibiotic therapy
column76: without presenting new complications
column77: and was discharged after 7 weeks of hospitalisation. Currently
column78: 2 years after his infective endocarditis due to S. aureus
column79: he is asymptomatic from the cardiovascular point of view.  DIAGNOSIS Late prosthetic infective endocarditis due to S. aureus. Aortic valve and tube replacement in ascending aorta. Complicated with: Intraparenchymal cerebral haemorrhage secondary to septic embolism. Acute abdomen due to splenic rupture due to septic embolism. Upper gastrointestinal bleeding secondary to duodenal stress ulcers. Partial duodenectomy. Post-surgical cardiac tamponade. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 51-year-old male
column3: no known drug allergies to date. Cardiovascular risk factors: ex-smoker for 3 years and dyslipidaemia on treatment with atorvastatin 40 mg/24 hours. No family history of heart disease or sudden death. No other pathological history of interest. She came to the emergency department the previous night while walking to the toilet
column4: presenting with oppressive central thoracic pain radiating to the left upper limb with accompanying vegetative symptoms that subsided self-limited in approximately 20 minutes. No previous history of syncope
column5: exertional angina or palpitations. Usual NYHA functional class I. Physical examination: blood pressure (BP) 120/80. Baseline SatO2 99%. Heart rate (HR) 90 bpm. Jugular venous pressure normal. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds
column6: without murmurs or extratonos. Pulmonary auscultation: normal ventilation. Lower limbs: no oedema
column7: no signs of deep vein thrombosis. Palpable and symmetrical distal pulses.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Blood tests: creatinine 0.74 mg/dl
column8: urea 43 mg/dl
column9: total cholesterol 207 mg/dl
column10: LDL 128 mg/dl
column11: triglycerides 182 mg/dl
column12: Na 138 mEq/l
column13: potassium 5 mEq/l
column14: troponin I US 15 → 40 ng/l (normal 0-19.8)
column15: Hb1AC 5.5%
column16: haemoglobin 16.4 g/dl
column17: leukocytes 7
column19: platelets 201
column20: 000/mm3. Basic coagulation without alterations. Chest X-ray: normal cardiothoracic index. No pleuroparenchymal alterations. Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus rhythm with rectified ST segment in lateral leads. No dynamic changes in successive ECGs.  Transthoracic echocardiogram: left ventricle of normal size and systolic function (EF estimated by Simpson biplane 65%)
column21: without segmental alterations of contractility. Normal wall thickness. Altered relaxation pattern. Trivalve aortic valve with thin leaflets
column22: competent. Mitral valve with thin leaflets
column23: without restriction to its opening
column24: with central trivial reflux. Right ventricle not dilated
column25: with normal systolic function (TAPSE 20 mm). Tricuspid valve with thin leaflets
column26: minimal insufficiency that prevents estimation of PAPs. Inferior vena cava (IVC) not dilated with preserved inspiratory collapse. Aortic root and ascending thoracic aorta visualised as normal. Absence of pericardial effusion or intracavitary masses by this technique. Cardiac catheterisation: left coronary artery (LMCA): no lesions. Anterior descending (LAD): no angiographically significant lesions. Sign of non-perfused myocardium
column27: with avascular area in the posterolateral area of the left ventricle. Circumflex (Cx): anomalous origin of its origin from the right coronary sinus adjacent to the DC ostium
column28: with retroaortic trajectory. Subocclusive artery from its origin that receives collateral circulation to the marginal branch from the CD artery. Right coronary (RCA): dominant. Diffuse atheromatosis with two moderate tandem lesions in distal RCA. The posterior descending (PD) artery presents angiographically moderate lesion at the ostium level and significant at the medial level. Percutaneous coronary interventionism (PCI) was performed on: Cx: multipurpose catheter and hydrophilic guide. Predilatation with conventional 2 x 20 mm balloon. Implantation of two overlapping drug-eluting stents
column29: everolimus-eluting
column30: 2.25 x 28 and 2.25 x 32 mm. Good angiographic result. PD: AR2 catheter and hydrophilic guidewire. Implantation of a 2.75 x 26 mm everolimus-eluting drug-eluting stent. Good angiographic result.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION With the diagnosis of NSTEACS
column31: the patient was admitted to the coronary unit. Anti-aggregation treatment was started with acetylsalicylic acid and ticagrelor and anticoagulation with fondaparinux. In the first 24 hours
column32: cardiac catheterisation showed a suboccluded circumflex artery with anomalous origin from the right coronary sinus adjacent to the ostium of the right coronary artery
column33: with a retroaortic trajectory
column34: which received collateral circulation from the right coronary artery. Given the favourable coronary anatomy
column35: two overlapping drug-eluting stents were implanted over the circumflex artery and one drug-eluting stent over the significant lesion in the posterior descending artery. The patient had a good clinical evolution during his admission
column36: with no heart failure or arrhythmic events. No clinical events occurred after three months of outpatient follow-up.  DIAGNOSIS Acute coronary syndrome without ST elevation of lateral location. Evolution to non-Q AMI. Killip I. Anomalous origin of circumflex coronary artery from right coronary sinus with retroaortic course. Two-vessel coronary artery disease: circumflex artery suboccluded at the origin
column37: significant stenosis in the posterior descending branch of the right coronary artery. Complete percutaneous revascularisation with drug-eluting stents. Preserved left ventricular systolic function. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: This is a 50-year-old woman with a finding of complete left bundle branch block (LBBB) and long QT (QTc) on a routine electrocardiogram (ECG). The main diagnostic tests for the complete study of long QT syndrome (LQTS) were performed and she was diagnosed with LQTS but no underlying genetic mutation was found.  HISTORY
column2: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History Family history No history of heart disease or sudden death. Maternal cousin studied for recurrent syncope.  Personal history No known drug allergies Smoker of 5 cigarettes/day (8 packs/year). Non-drinker. Arterial hypertension under pharmacological treatment
column3: with good control as usual. No known diabetes mellitus or dyslipidaemia. Admitted for acute bacterial meningitis at the age of 20
column4: with no sequelae. Surgical interventions: appendectomy. Left inguinal herniaplasty  Usual treatment: Ramipril 5 mg per day.  Present illness A 50-year-old woman was referred to the cardiology department for routine ECG findings of LBBB. The patient reported being completely asymptomatic
column5: without dyspnoea on exertion
column6: without episodes of chest pain
column7: palpitations or syncope.  Physical examination Good general condition. Well hydrated and perfused. Eupneic at rest. SatO2 99% with FiO2 0.21. Blood pressure (BP) 128/64 mmHg. Heart rate (HR) 63 bpm. Neck: absence of IY. No palpable lymph nodes. Carotid arteries without murmurs. Cardiac and pulmonary auscultation: rhythmic
column8: at a good frequency. No murmurs or audible extratonos. Vesicular murmur preserved
column9: no pathological sounds. Abdomen: soft and depressible. Not painful on palpation
column10: no signs of peritonism. No masses or megaliths. Lower limbs: no oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Distal pulses present and symmetrical.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG in consultation: sinus bradycardia at 57 bpm
column11: normal axis
column12: PR 120 ms
column13: wide QRS (130 ms) with LBBB morphology with secondary repolarisation alterations
column14: QT 480ms
column15: QTc 470 ms.  Echocardiogram: Cavities and great vessels: left ventricle not dilated (DTDVI 42mm)
column16: with slight concentric hypertrophy of its walls (SIV 12mm
column17: PIL 11mm). Non-dilated left atrium. Right ventricle of normal dimensions. Normal right atrium. Normal visualisation of the aorta. Valves: Trivalve aortic valve with mild degenerative signs and jet of mild insufficiency
column18: with normal anterograde gradients. Mitral valve with normal appearance and function. No tricuspid insufficiency detected. Ventricular function: Preserved LV systolic function
column19: estimated at 55% by Simpson BP. No segmental alterations in contractility were observed
column20: although there was a marked asynchrony of the interventricular septum by LBBB. Diastolic function compatible with impaired relaxation
column21: with no increase in filling pressures. Preserved RV systolic function. Other: Inferior vena cava not dilated and with adequate inspiratory collapse. No pericardial effusion. Cardiac single photon emission tomography (SPECT): negative for myocardial ischaemia. 24-hour Holter: tracing in sinus rhythm with LBBB
column22: with minimum HR 49 bpm
column23: mean 68 bpm and maximum 115 bpm
column24: without significant pauses. QTc minimum 391 ms
column25: mean 461 ms and maximum 562ms. No T wave alternans or ventricular arrhythmias were observed. Ergometry (images 2
column26: 3 and 4): Baseline HR 63 bpm. Basal QT 480 ms. Basal QTc 511 ms. Maximum HR of 138 bpm (81% of maximum HR) reached at 5:20 minutes of exercise. Peak exercise QT 320 ms. Maximal exercise QTc 482 ms. Presence of isolated ventricular extrasystoles during exercise. In recovery phase (5 minutes): HR 74 bpm
column27: QT 460 ms and QTc 490 ms. No evidence of ischaemic signs throughout the test. Viskin bideptation test. At rest: HR 60 bpm
column28: QT 480 ms and QTc 480 ms. After standing: HR 70 bpm
column29: QT 500 ms
column30: QTc 559 ms. Genetic test (channelopathy panel): negative.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was referred by her primary care physician due to a routine ECG finding of LBBB. The ECG at the consultation confirmed this finding together with the presence of secondary repolarisation alterations
column31: a QT of 480 ms and a QTc of 470 ms. The patient denied at all times having presented any symptoms
column33: palpitations or chest pain on exertion. Given the electrical alterations
column34: it was decided to complete the study with an echocardiogram
column35: which showed a left ventricle with mild concentric hypertrophy of its walls with normal function and mild degenerative aortic insufficiency
column36: with the rest of the study compatible with normality. Myocardial SPECT was also requested
column37: which ruled out the presence of ischaemia. To complete the study of the suspected long QT syndrome
column38: the Viskin standing test was performed
column39: which showed a lengthening of the QTc interval
column40: from 480 ms in the supine position after 10 minutes of rest to 559 ms after standing. An ergometry test was also performed with baseline QTc and at maximum exercise
column41: presence of isolated ventricular extrasystoles and QTc in recovery of 490 ms. Finally
column42: a 24-hour Holter is requested without observing arrhythmic events or T wave alternation. Based on these tests
column43: the patient was diagnosed with asymptomatic long QT syndrome (LQTS) and treatment was started with beta-blockers (bisoprolol 2.5 mg per day). In addition
column44: a genetic study was requested
column45: but it was negative. Subsequently
column46: the patient explained to us that her two maternal cousins had been diagnosed with LQTS but both had a negative genetic study. Currently the patient remains asymptomatic
column47: with no cardiac events during follow-up.  DIAGNOSIS Long QT syndrome (negative genetics). Mild aortic insufficiency. Normal systolic function. Complete left bundle branch block. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 65-year-old male referred preferentially from primary care to cardiology outpatient clinics due to chest pain.  History Cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF): ex-smoker for 10 years (35 pack-years). No arterial hypertension (AHT)
column3: diabetes mellitus (DM) or dyslipidaemia. No previous cardiological history. No family history of heart disease. Other history: glaucoma
column4: peptic ulcus. Treatment: omeprazole 20 mg: 1 tablet per day. Latanoprost
column5: dorzolamide and timolol eye drops.  Present illness He reported chest pain in the left hemithorax with oppressive characteristics
column6: without irradiation
column7: sometimes accompanied by cold sweating
column8: generally triggered by exertion
column9: although there were also some episodes at rest
column10: and progressive improvement of the pain in about 30 minutes after cessation of exertion. The patient denied changes in the threshold of exertion or progression of the symptoms in recent weeks. He reported no symptoms suggestive of heart failure
column11: palpitations or episodes of loss of consciousness.  Physical examination Good general condition
column12: normal colour and normohydrated
column13: eupneic at rest and conscious
column14: oriented and cooperative. Blood pressure (BP) 124/73 mmHg
column15: heart rate (HR) 55 bpm
column16: SatO2 98% on room air. No murmurs were detected on cardiac auscultation and pulmonary auscultation showed a preserved vesicular murmur with no added noises except for some isolated tele-expiratory wheezing. Radial and pedial pulses were palpable
column17: rhythmic and symmetrical.   COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Basal electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus rhythm at 55 beats per minute. Axis 60o. PR 0.16s. Narrow QRS. No repolarisation alterations. Laboratory tests: glucose 91 mg/dl
column18: creatinine 0.78 mg/dl
column19: estimated glomerular filtration rate (CKD-EPI) over 90 ml/min/1.73 m2
column20: total cholesterol 172 mg/dl
column21: triglycerides 71 mg/dl
column22: HDL cholesterol 54 mg/dl
column23: calculated LDL cholesterol 113 mg/dl. Transthoracic echocardiography: left ventricle of normal diameter and wall thickness with preserved LVEF (67%). No segmental alterations in contractility were observed. Normal transmitral filling pattern. Mean E/e" of 9.5 (LVEDP globally estimated as normal). Non-dilated right ventricle with good contractility (TAPSE 21 mm
column24: s" tricuspid annulus 13.2 cm/s). Atria of normal size. No relevant valvulopathies. Inferior vena cava (IVC) not dilated with adequate inspiratory collapse. Absence of pericardial effusion. Ergometry on treadmill: maximum ergometry with Bruce protocol on a moving treadmill
column25: the test was stopped due to oppressive
column26: non-limiting precordial pain
column27: similar to that which motivated the request
column28: and maximum horizontal ST depression of 2 mm in 5 leads (II
column29: III
column30: aVF
column31: V4 and V5); both the clinical and ECG changes persisted for about 5 minutes after the end of the effort. Correct adaptation of HR and BP. Normal functional capacity (reaches 12.6 METS). No significant arrhythmias detected. Coronary angiography (video 2): left dominance. Left coronary trunk
column32: anterior descending artery and circumflex artery without significant angiographic lesions. Right coronary artery with anomalous origin from left coronary sinus and probable interarterial trajectory
column33: of scarce development and without significant angiographic lesions. CT of the coronary arteries with cardiac synchronisation and prospective acquisition: coronary anatomy: left dominance. Intermediate branch as an anatomical variant of normality. Anomalous right coronary outflow from left coronary sinus with high interarterial course. Left main coronary artery: long
column34: without lesions. Anterior descending: no lesions. Circumflex: no lesions. Right coronary artery: outflow from contralateral coronary sinus with high interarterial course
column35: without lesions. Other cardiac findings: small diverticulum in the left inferoposterior wall of the left atrium. No intra-atrial thrombus. Extracardiac findings: hiatal hernia. Stress cardiac MRI with dipyridamole: left ventricle with wall thickness
column36: volumes and segmental and global systolic function within normal (LVEF 70%). Right ventricle volume and systolic function within normal (LVEF 64%). Atria and great vessels of normal size. Provocation of ischaemia with i.v. dipyridamole (0.84 mg/kg
column37: well tolerated) NEGATIVE. Basal 57 bpm and 137/76 mmHg. Stress 84 bpm and 127/70 mmHg. Absence of myocardial fibrosis or necrosis. In short
column38: absence of inducible ischaemia.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION Following the echocardiographic assessment
column39: which showed no structural heart disease
column40: the available data
column41: the clinical management recommendations at that time
column42: the local availability of complementary tests and estimating an intermediate pretest probability
column43: treadmill exercise testing was requested to assess the presence of ischaemia and confirm the diagnosis of suspected stable exertional angina. This was clinically and electrically compatible with high-load ischaemia. With this result and the patient's clinical presentation
column44: treatment was started with acetylsalicylic acid 100 mg 1 tablet per day and atorvastatin 20 mg 1 tablet per day
column45: and coronary angiography was requested. During the technique
column46: cannulation of the left main coronary artery showed left-dominant anterior descending and circumflex arteries without significant lesions. The right coronary artery could not be cannulated from the right coronary sinus
column47: so the origin of the right coronary artery was sought in the left coronary sinus. After several attempts and sub-selective injections
column48: the right coronary artery was found to have an anomalous origin in the left coronary sinus
column49: with a probable interarterial course. The artery itself was poorly developed and practically rudimentary. To confirm the origin and especially the course of the right coronary artery
column50: a coronary CT scan was requested
column51: which showed
column52: in agreement with the coronary angiography
column53: an origin from the left sinus
column54: as well as a high interarterial course. The patient was presented at a medical-surgical session to consider reimplantation of the right coronary artery
column55: parietal resection or unroofing or bypass with proximal ligation. It was decided to request an imaging test to assess and locate the presence of ischaemia as additional data to indicate possible surgery. Antianginal treatment was added sequentially with nitrate patch 5 mg per day
column56: lercanidipine 10 mg 1 tablet per day and ranolazine 500 mg 1 tablet every 12 hours. Beta-blockers were not tolerated due to a tendency to sinus bradycardia. A stress CMR with vasodilator (dipyridamole) was performed
column57: which ruled out the presence of myocardial necrosis and also showed no evidence of ischaemia. It should be noted that the mechanism of stress induction by this technique (vasodilatation) did not produce an increase in BP
column58: so there would have been no evidence of ischaemia if the mechanism had been compression of the coronary artery with interarterial trajectory by expansion of the aorta and pulmonary trunk
column59: a mechanism that would have occurred if the stress induction had been due to exertion. Finally
column60: surgery by cardiac surgery was ruled out due to the small calibre and development of the affected artery
column61: the technical difficulties of the intervention and the good response to medical treatment. To date
column62: the patient remains stable with a CCS (Canadian Cardiovascular Society) functional class for angina II/IV
column63: pending full optimisation of anti-anginal treatment. He has had no cardiovascular events during follow-up.  DIAGNOSIS Coronary anomaly: right coronary artery with origin in left coronary sinus and high interarterial path. Stable angina. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History This is a 73-year-old woman with arterial hypertension as a cardiovascular risk factor. She was assessed by cardiology in a private centre for mitral prolapse
column3: with normal ventricular function and asymptomatic during follow-up. Her main comorbidity is oncological
column4: with a history of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the descending colon stage II (pT3 pN0 cM0)
column5: which debuted with intestinal obstruction in 2014
column6: initially treated with total colectomy in August 2014
column7: followed by adjuvant chemotherapy with Gramont scheme with 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) x 12 cycles (last cycle date: February 2015). A CT scan in December 2015 revealed millimetric lung lesions
column8: which were observed until their growth was confirmed by PET scan in June 2016
column9: so first-line chemotherapy with FOLFOX (oxaliplatin
column10: 5-fluorouracil and folinic acid) was started
column11: with oxaliplatin being discontinued after 7 cycles due to neurotoxicity. She was maintained on 5-fluorouracil until the present day
column12: achieving stabilisation of the disease  Current disease While the patient was in the supermarket
column13: she had an apparently sudden loss of consciousness and cardiorespiratory arrest was observed
column14: and basic cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) manoeuvres were started immediately by the health personnel present. The semi-automatic external defibrillator (AED) detected a shockable rhythm and 2 shocks were administered
column15: with recovery of pulse and consciousness
column16: and orotracheal intubation was not required. The output electrocardiogram (ECG) showed complete right bundle branch block
column17: with no evidence of acute ischaemia. She was transferred by the out-of-hospital emergency services to our centre
column18: where she arrived haemodynamically stable
column19: conscious and oriented. On initial anamnesis
column20: the patient reported short episodes (2 minutes) of chest pain in the previous days
column21: at rest
column22: with no other associated symptoms.  Physical examination Blood pressure (BP) 115/70 mmHg
column23: heart rate (HR) 74 bpm. Good general condition
column24: conscious and oriented
column25: eupneic at rest. Normoperfused. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column26: no murmurs or extratonos. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur with no extra sounds. Lower limbs: no oedema.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS EGC: sinus rhythm at 80lpm. Normal PR. QRS 120 msec with BCRDHH morphology. No significant repolarisation alterations. Blood tests (on admission): normal haemogram. Normal coagulation except D-dimer 4477 ng/ml. Arterial blood gases: pH 7.38
column27: pCO2 35 mmHg
column28: bicarbonate 21 mEq/l
column29: lactate 4.2 mmol/l. In the biochemistry normal renal function
column30: without ionic alterations and with negative acute phase reactants. Cardiac markers: evolution of ultrasensitive troponin I 7.7 - 174 - 40 ng/ml
column31: with normal CK. Nt-proBNP 457 pg/ml. Chest X-ray on admission: normal cardiothoracic index
column32: no evidence of heart failure. Control chest X-ray after ICD implantation: subcutaneous defibrillator with pre-sternal electrode. Minimal subcutaneous emphysema. Subcutaneous reservoir with terminal at the confluence of the brachiocephalic venous trunks. Urgent coronary angiography: access via right radial artery. 177 cc of contrast. Left coronary trunk without lesions. Anterior descending artery of small calibre and development with a non-significant lesion in the distal portion (corresponding to the middle third of the theoretical trajectory) with a blurred image and with a distal vessel of small development and calibre. Coronary anomaly with middle and distal portion of the anterior descending artery with exit from the right coronary sinus
column33: close to the exit of the right coronary artery. Circumflex and right coronary without lesions. Echocardiogram: left ventricle not dilated
column34: with normal wall thickness. Normal global systolic function (LVEF 60-65%)
column35: hypokinesia of inferior septum and inferior face. Transmitral filling pattern of impaired relaxation. E/e' ratio 6. Left atrium not dilated. Non-dilated right atrium. Non-dilated right ventricle
column36: with normal global systolic function. Mitral valve with calcium in the annulus and leaflets. No stenosis. Slight insufficiency. Aortic valve morphologically and functionally normal. Tricuspid valve morphologically normal. Slight insufficiency. Pulmonary artery systolic pressure not estimable. Inferior vena cava not dilated with physiological inspiratory collapse. No pericardial effusion. Epicardial fat. Non-dilated aortic root. Cardiac magnetic resonance: study within normal limits. No areas of myocardial inflammation or ischaemic scarring. Biventricular size and systolic function within normal limits. CT coronary arteries: calcium quantification (Agatston) 410 (80th percentile for age
column37: sex and race). CT angiography: extensive coronary atheromatosis. Anterior descending artery that exhausts at the proximal-middle level of the IV anterior sulcus. Ectopic vessel originating in the right sinus running anterior to the TAP that reaches the IV groove at mid level. It has a concentric stenosis at its origin of 30%.  Assessment by medical oncology: in the absence of further information
column38: it appears that pulmonary metastases have an indolent behaviour
column39: with long-lasting stabilisation
column40: so that in the face of this complication and the current suspicion
column41: therapeutic rest could even be considered. If this is not the case or if progression occurs
column42: there are non-cardiotoxic alternatives to 5-fluorouracil (raltitrexed
column43: irinotecan). It will be up to the discretion of your regular oncologist to choose the most suitable treatment depending on the clinical situation at discharge. Electrophysiology: a 6 cm incision is made in the left mid-axillary region and dissection is carried out up to the muscular plane
column44: the serratus anterior muscle is divided to form the pocket for the generator; tunneling is carried out from the left mid-axillary line to the left parasternal region where a 3 cm incision is made at the level of the sixth intercostal space (EIC) and from the latter it is tunneled to the second EIC (left parasternal). An electrode is fixed at the level of the sixth parasternal left EIC and connected to the generator
column45: which is fixed to the muscular plane; it is closed in planes. The procedure was concluded without complications. Induction of ventricular fibrillation (VF) was performed on three occasions
column46: which cardioverted to sinus rhythm spontaneously
column47: for which a 10 J shock was performed to measure the impedance of the circuit
column48: which was normal (75 Ohm); at the end of the procedure the radiological position was assessed as adequate and a low probability of defibrillation failure was estimated (PRAETORIAN SCORE). Conditional zone is programmed at 220 bpm and VF zone at 250 bpm (5 therapies of 80 J). Post-discharge pacing on. Shock impedance in normal range. Smart Pass filter on. Vector chosen primary x 1.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient arrived at our centre haemodynamically stable
column49: without chest pain or signs of heart failure
column50: without ionic or other alterations. In the transthoracic echocardiogram
column51: biventricular size and function were normal
column52: with no significant alterations. It was decided to perform emergent coronary angiography
column53: which showed the anomaly in the anterior descending artery (LAD) described
column54: with no images suggestive of significant disease. Analytically
column55: there was minimal elevation of myocardial damage markers in the serialisation
column56: with a peak of 140 of ultra-sensitive troponin I. Once the initial study had been performed
column57: three aetiologies of the arrest were considered: Coronary anomaly
column58: although coronary angiography did not show an inter- or intra-arterial trajectory of the LAD. Acute coronary syndrome due to plaque rupture in the distal LAD
column59: this entity being unlikely. Vasospasm secondary to treatment with 5-fluorouracil on previous plaque. With these options
column60: it was decided to first perform a coronary CT scan
column61: which ruled out an intra-arterial trajectory of the anterior descending artery. The study continued with cardiac MRI as a myocardial study
column62: with no evidence of structural heart disease or ischaemic lesions. During admission
column63: the patient remained on cardiac monitoring
column64: with no arrhythmic events. At this point
column65: having ruled out all other aetiologies
column66: the first diagnostic possibility was vasospasm due to 5-fluorouracil; however
column67: as this could not be confirmed reliably
column68: she was presented at an interdisciplinary medical-surgical session (clinical and interventional cardiology
column69: cardiac surgery and medical oncology)
column70: where it was considered that the implantation of an ICD device was indicated for secondary prevention
column71: with a subcutaneous ICD being the ICD of choice
column72: as she was a carrier of a central venous reservoir for active use.  The procedure was performed without periprocedural complications. However
column73: in the following 12 hours on the ward
column74: she presented two inappropriate shocks
column75: assessed by electrophysiology and the company's technicians
column76: and showed evidence of retrosternal air interference visualised in the first control X-ray after the procedure. After two days of monitoring
column77: a new X-ray was taken which showed reabsorption of the subcutaneous emphysema
column78: with no further discharges after 48 hours of observation. In view of the good evolution
column79: the patient was discharged from hospital with follow-up in monographic cardio-oncology consultations. During the follow-up
column80: new administrations of 5-fluouracil were prohibited and replaced by a new chemotherapy agent
column81: and the patient progressed favourably from both the cardiological and oncological points of view. She has not presented any new discharges since discharge.  DIAGNOSIS Out-of-hospital cardiorespiratory arrest with immediate cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) recovered in second shock. Possible vasospasm due to fluoropyrimidines. Subcutaneous ICD implantation in secondary prevention. Inappropriate discharge due to air interference. Anterior descending with middle and distal portion with exit from right coronary sinus. Normal biventricular function. Adenocarcinoma of the colon intervened in control with 5-FU chemotherapy. column1: We present the case of a 70-year-old man with ischaemic heart disease and atrial fibrillation with indication for anticoagulation.  HISTORY
column2: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History No known drug allergies. Cardiovascular risk factors: hypertension
column3: dyslipidaemia
column4: ex-smoker for 12 years (smoking history 20 packs/year). Drinker of two beers per day and one glass of wine per day.  Previous cardiological history: Chronic ischaemic heart disease; debut as acute myocardial infarction in 1998. Diffuse multivessel coronary artery disease. Catheterisation (4/11/2008): atheromatous and calcified anterior descending artery in proximal and middle segments
column5: diseased vessel not approachable. Circumflex artery with diffuse disease of the whole vessel with poor distal beds. Atheromatous right coronary artery with irregularities. Preserved left ventricular ejection fraction. Other medical history: Mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. No surgical interventions. Current treatment: acetylsalicylic acid 100 mg/24 hours
column6: nitroglycerin patch 15 mg/24 hours
column7: carvedilol 25 mg/12 hours
column8: ivabradine 5 mg/12 hours
column9: candesartan 4 mg/24 hours
column10: rosuvastatin 20 mg/24 hours
column11: ezetimibe 10 mg/24 hours
column12: inhaled tiotropium and budesonide.  Present illness 70-year-old man with episodes of exertional angina for the past year. When climbing hills or accelerating his pace
column13: he experienced oppressive discomfort in the left hemithorax that sometimes radiated to the inner arm
column14: which self-limited within 5-10 minutes after stopping the activity. It is also associated with chest pain during sexual intercourse. No episodes at rest.   Physical examination Good general condition. Conscious
column15: oriented and cooperative. Normal colour. Blood pressure (BP) 130/71 mmHg. Heart rate (HR) 75 bpm. No semiology of heart failure. Cardiopulmonary auscultation: arrhythmic heart
column16: no murmurs. Bladder murmur preserved with no added pathological noises. Lower limbs: no oedema or fovea. No evidence of deep vein thrombosis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram: atrial fibrillation at 90 bpm. Narrow QRS
column17: normal axis. No repolarisation alterations. Chest X-ray: normal cardiothoracic index. Free costophrenic sinuses. No images of pulmonary condensation. Laboratory tests: creatinine 0.8 mg/dl. Haemoglobin 15.4 g/dl. Ultrasensitive troponin T 17 ng/l (normal < 14 ng/l). Echocardiogram: normal aortic root
column18: trivalve aortic valve with preserved opening and closing. Left atrium not dilated. Normal mitral valve. Left ventricle of normal size
column19: with normal myocardial thickness. Normal global and segmental systolic function. Ventricular filling with monophasic pattern. Normal right chambers. Absence of pericardial effusion. Inferior vena cava not dilated. Prognostic ergometry
column20: treadmill
column21: Bruce protocol
column22: under beta-blocker treatment: clinically negative. Electrically positive with ST-segment elevation at the end of stage 2
column23: due to ST-segment elevation in V3-V6 of 1 mm
column24: with an accentuated decrease in recovery up to 3 mm. Slow recovery
column25: persisting after 6 minutes with a 2-mm decline in V3 (V2-V6 decline). Exercise time 6:06 minutes
column26: limited by leg fatigue. Functional capacity: 7.2 METS. Normal blood pressure response. HR response attenuated by beta-blockers. Normal HR recovery. Reached 86% of maximum heart rate. All tracing in atrial fibrillation. Immediate post-stress echocardiogram: physiological hypercontractility with apical akinesia. Diagnostic and therapeutic coronary angiography: right radial access. Left dominance. Left common trunk practically non-existent giving rise to 2 independent ostia of the anterior descending artery (ADA) and circumflex artery (ACx). ADA very calcified
column27: of small calibre with diffuse atheromatosis along its entire length
column28: causing areas of significant stenosis at mid-distal level over a small calibre
column29: thin and diseased vessel. Dominant circumflex artery
column30: of large calibre and course. It presents significant eccentric stenosis proximally and medially. It emits a first marginal branch of little entity and a second branch of large calibre and route where there is a short and significant stenosis in its proximal segment. Hypodeveloped right coronary artery with diffuse atheromatosis. Percutaneous coronary intervention: on marginal branch of the LMCA by means of simple angioplasty with conventional balloon (2 mm). On CAx by implanting two drug-eluting stents after dilatation with conventional balloon at mid-distal (Resolute Onyx 3 x 30 mm
column31: post-dilated at high pressure with a 3.5 mm non-compliant balloon) and proximal (Resolute Onyx 3.5 x 22 mm at 16 atmospheres) levels. Good final angiographic result.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was evaluated in the chest pain unit where an ergometry was performed with electrical positivity with segmental alterations in immediate post-strengthening echocardiography
column32: so it was decided to admit the patient to hospital for coronary angiography. In addition
column33: an electrocardiogram showed atrial fibrillation of uncertain chronology with controlled ventricular response. After coronary angiography revealed approachable coronary lesions
column34: given that the patient had angina despite optimal antianginal treatment and inducible ischaemia in the non-invasive ischaemia detection test
column35: percutaneous intervention was performed on the marginal branch and on the proximal and middle circumflex artery in order to improve the patient's symptoms. On discharge
column36: the patient required anticoagulation (atrial fibrillation with CHA2DS2-VASc 3 points) and antiplatelet therapy (coronary revascularisation)
column37: so taking into account that the bleeding risk is high (HAS-BLED 4 points) and exceeds the ischaemic risk
column38: a PIONEER strategy was decided and the patient was discharged with clopidogrel 75 mg/24 hours and rivaroxaban 15 mg/24 hours (including acetylsalicylic acid 100 mg/24 hours for the first week). Clopidogrel
column39: if there are no incidents
column40: will be withdrawn after 6 months
column41: to continue with rivaroxaban at a dose of 20 mg per day if the renal glomerular filtration rate remains above 50 ml/min.  DIAGNOSIS Chronic ischaemic heart disease with multivessel coronary artery disease and exertional angina despite medical treatment. Preserved LV systolic function. Percutaneous revascularisation of circumflex artery and marginal branch. Atrial fibrillation of uncertain chronology (CHA2DS2-VASc 3 points; HAS-BLED 4 points). |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
