column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 51-year-old male admitted for out-of-hospital cardiorespiratory arrest.  History Allergic to rifampicin. Hypertension of short evolution. No toxic habits. No previous cardiological history
column3: no family history of heart disease or sudden death. No other history of interest. Usual treatment: losartan/hydrochlorothiazide 50/12.5 mg 1 tablet per day.  Present illness Previously asymptomatic
column4: on the day of admission he presented
column5: while at work
column6: a syncopal episode without previous symptoms
column7: witnessed by a relative. No pulse was noted and basic cardiopulmonary resuscitation manoeuvres were started for 15 minutes. On arrival of the emergency services
column8: orotracheal intubation was performed and advanced cardiopulmonary resuscitation manoeuvres continued for 20 minutes. AED recording showed ventricular fibrillation and after 5 defibrillation attempts and administration of 5 mg of adrenaline
column9: 3 mg of atropine and 300 mg of amiodarone intravenously
column10: the patient recovered a pulse
column11: recording sinus rhythm with ST-segment elevation in leads V1-V5
column12: DI and aVL. During transfer to the hospital
column13: he suffered a new episode of cardiorespiratory arrest with pulseless ventricular tachycardia
column14: this time recovering a pulse after a single electrical cardioversion.  On arrival at the hospital
column15: an urgent haemodynamic study was performed
column16: which revealed epicardial coronary arteries without angiographically significant stenosis. In view of the results of the catheterisation
column17: it was decided to perform a cranial CT scan without contrast and a chest CT scan with contrast to assess the pulmonary arteries and rule out other causes of cardiorespiratory arrest
column18: ruling out intracranial haemorrhage
column19: pulmonary thromboembolism and acute aortic syndrome.  Physical examination Systolic blood pressure (SBP) 134 mmHg
column20: diastolic blood pressure (DBP) 98 mmHg
column21: heart rate (HR) 81 bpm. Afebrile. Intubated and connected to mechanical ventilation
column22: SatO2 100% with FiO2 80%. No jugular ingurgitation. Negative hepatojugular reflux. Glasgow 8
column23: under the effect of midazolam and cisatracurium used in the induction prior to orotracheal intubation. Rhythmic heart sounds without murmurs. Scattered rhonchi in both lung fields. Abdomen soft and depressible
column24: not distended. Lower extremities without oedema
column25: with femoral
column26: popliteal
column27: tibial and pedial pulses bilaterally present and symmetrical. Radial pulses preserved.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Semiautomatic defibrillator (AED) recording: ventricular fibrillation. After electrical cardioversion
column28: sinus rhythm at 75 bpm
column29: QRS of 120 ms with intraventricular conduction disturbance
column30: ST segment elevation from V1 to V5
column31: DI and aVL
column32: with specular decrease in inferior face. Electrocardiogram (ECG) on admission to the coronary unit: sinus rhythm at 80 bpm
column33: narrow QRS with normal axis
column34: no ST alterations
column35: flattened T wave in limb leads. Venous blood gases (on arrival at our centre): pH 7.11
column36: pCO2 67.9 mmHg
column37: pO2 56.9 mmHg
column38: HCO3 16.7 mmol/l
column39: Sat O2 78%
column40: lactic acid 5.4 mmol/l
column41: pO2(a
column42: T)/FIO2 56.9 mmHg. Biochemistry (admission): glucose 223 mg/dl
column43: urea 49 mg/dl
column44: creatinine 1.04 mg/dl
column45: CKDEPI estimate 83 ml/min/1.73 m2
column46: sodium 138 mmol/l
column47: potassium 4.4 mEq/l
column48: chlorine 106 mEq/l
column49: calcium 8
column50: 2 mg/dl
column51: magnesium 1.8 mg/dl
column52: CK 359 IU/l
column53: CKMB 50 U/l
column54: ultrasensitive troponin 996.1 ng/l (normal < 15 ng/l)
column55: procalcitonin 6.45 ng/ml
column56: C-reactive protein 8.3 mg/l. Haemogram (admission): leucocytes 23
column58: 84% neutrophils
column59: haemoglobin 17 g/dl
column60: haematocrit 50%
column61: platelets 302
column62: 000 /μl. Coagulation (admission): prothrombin rate 100%
column63: INR 1
column64: derived fibrinogen 361 mg/dl. Haemodynamic study (admission): coronary arteries without angiographically significant stenosis. Ventriculography: left ventricle with normal function
column65: with LVEF 53% (TVD 144 ml and STV 67ml). Aortography: trivalve aorta without insufficiency or significant transvalvular gradient. Ascending aorta not dilated. No images suggestive of aortic dissection. Chest CT with contrast (admission): no signs of pulmonary thromboembolism. Pulmonary artery trunk and thoracic aorta of normal size. No pericardial or pleural effusion. Right hilar adenopathy of 1.5 cm
column66: non-specific. Small ipsilateral ipsilateral lateroaortic and interlobar prevascular calcified adenopathies
column67: probably residual. Lung apexes artefacted by respiratory movements. Endotracheal tube about 3 cm from the carina. The posterior segment of the LSD
column68: part of the apical segment and posterobasal segments of the LID
column69: as well as the apical and posterobasal segments of the LII are consolidated with air bronchogram (suggesting atelectasis)
column70: probably secondary to accumulation of secretions
column71: decubitus or bronchoaspiration. Linear subpleural calcification in the posterior subsegment of the LSI of cicatricial or residual appearance. Secretions in proximal trachea. Marked dilatation of gastric chamber with hydro-aerial level in relation to previous CPR manoeuvres. CT scan of the brain without contrast (admission): no significant alterations. Echocardiogram: left ventricle of normal dimensions and geometry
column72: with preserved ejection fraction (LVEF 60%). Right ventricle of normal dimensions
column73: with normal systolic function. Morphologically normal valves
column74: with trivial mitral insufficiency. No alterations of note. Chest X-ray (admission): normal cardiothoracic index
column75: lung parenchyma and bronchovascular tract without alterations. Continuous electrocardiographic monitoring (second day of admission): sinus rhythm without repolarisation alterations. Progressive ST-segment elevation was observed in the only lead recorded
column76: subsequently presenting sustained monomorphic ventricular tachycardia that degenerated into ventricular fibrillation with normalisation of repolarisation alterations after administration of intravenous nitroglycerine. MRI (12th day of admission): no global or segmental alterations in myocardial contractility. Late enhancement sequences without alterations. Normal first-pass myocardial perfusion study. Cardiac cavity diameters: VITD 50 mm
column77: VITS 34 mm
column78: LA 23 cm2
column79: VDTD 40 mm
column80: VDTS 31 mm
column81: AD 22 cm2. Left ventricular function preserved
column82: with LVEF 62%
column83: with values indexed by body surface area (m2): VTD 125 ml
column84: VTS 47 ml
column85: stroke volume 78 ml. Flow artefacts compatible with mitral insufficiency (MI) and tricuspid insufficiency (TI)
column86: not significant. Conclusion: study within normal limits.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was transferred to the emergency department of our centre due to out-of-hospital cardiorespiratory arrest. Given that he presented electrocardiographic alterations suggestive of acute coronary syndrome
column87: urgent coronary angiography was performed showing coronary arteries without lesions
column88: cranial CT and thoracic CT angiography
column89: which ruled out acute pathology justifying the arrest. The patient was admitted to the cardiac critical care unit and therapeutic hypothermia was started. Echocardioscopy was performed
column90: showing a left ventricle with preserved ventricular function and no abnormalities of contractility
column91: with no significant alterations. On the second day of admission he presented a sudden rise in the ST segment recorded in the single lead of the continuous electrocardiographic monitoring
column92: with a subsequent bout of sustained ventricular tachycardia that degenerated into ventricular fibrillation without haemodynamic compromise
column93: which resolved after treatment with intravenous nitroglycerine. Given clinical suspicion of vasospasm
column94: an urgent blood test and arterial blood gas analysis were performed
column95: ruling out hydroelectrolyte alterations; even so
column96: hypothermia therapy was withdrawn. During his stay in the cardiovascular critical care unit
column97: the patient presented a febrile peak and parameters of infection of probable respiratory origin
column98: which was resolved with antibiotic therapy with imipenem 1 g i.v. every 8 hours and linezolid 600 mg i.v. every 12 hours for 10 days. Given the good haemodynamic
column100: the patient was extubated without incident on the eighth day of admission.  After being discharged to the hospital ward
column101: he made good progress. Cardiac magnetic resonance was performed
column103: ruling out structural heart disease. Prior to discharge
column104: it was decided to implant a single-chamber automatic implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) as secondary prevention
column105: and he was discharged stable and asymptomatic.  DIAGNOSIS Out-of-hospital cardiorespiratory arrest recovered due to ventricular fibrillation. Structurally normal heart. Acute coronary syndrome with non-persistent ST-segment elevation due to coronary vasospasm. Single-chamber ICD implantation for secondary prevention. Respiratory infection secondary to bronchoaspiration

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION A 66-year-old male
column3: hypertensive
column4: type 2 diabetic
column5: dyslipidaemic and ex-smoker
column6: with no other history of interest
column7: attended the emergency department in April 2020 for progressive dyspnoea of several days' evolution and fever
column8: with no other associated cardiovascular symptoms. Home treatment with enalapril 5 mg/24 hours
column9: atorvastatin 40 mg/24 hours and metformin 850 mg/24 hours. On first examination
column10: the patient was haemodynamically stable
column11: although his general condition was poor. Blood pressure (BP) 130/75 mmHg
column12: heart rate (HR) 75 bpm
column13: RR 30 rpm
column14: basal saturation 85%
column15: temperature 38.3 oC. Pulmonary auscultation showed bilateral crackles in both fields
column16: with normal cardiac auscultation and no oedema in the lower limbs.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Arterial blood gases Hypoxaemic respiratory failure. pH 7.35
column17: pCO2 30 mmHg
column18: pO2 62 mmHg
column19: HCO3- 25 mmol/l
column20: lactic 2.3. Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus rhythm at 75 bpm
column21: normal PR
column22: narrow QRS
column23: normal axis
column24: diffuse repolarisation alterations (flattened T in inferior and lateral face) not suggestive of acute ischaemia. Chest X-ray: peripheral infiltrate in the left mid-inferior field and of lesser density in the peripheral region of the midfield and right paracardiac region
column25: compatible with SARS-CoV2 infection of moderate degree from the radiological point of view. CBC: creatinine 0.96 mg/dl
column26: no ionic alterations
column27: liver profile with mild elevation of transaminases
column28: first troponin T 150 ng/dl
column29: second troponin T 200 ng/dl
column30: CK 100U/l
column31: LDH 450U/l
column33: platelets 160
column35: leukocytes 9000/ul
column36: neutrophils 80%
column37: lymphocytes 1000/ul
column38: D-dimers 900 ng/ml. Nasopharyngeal PCR for SARS-CoV2: positive.  CLINICAL COURSE In view of these findings
column39: the patient was diagnosed with bilateral SARS-CoV2 pneumonia with associated acute hypoxaemic respiratory failure
column40: so he was admitted and treatment was started with oxygen therapy for SatO2 > 90%
column41: reducing the patient's respiratory rate
column42: hydroxychloroquine (400 mg/12 hours for the first 24 hours and then 200 mg/12 hours v. o.)
column43: liponavir and liponavir (400 mg/12 hours for the first 24 hours and then 200 mg/12 hours v. o.).o.)
column44: liponavir-ritonavir (200/50 mg/12 hours o.v.)
column45: azithromycin 500 mg/24 hours o.v. and ceftriaxone 2 g/24 hours i.v. When markers of myocardial damage were elevated due to suspicion of associated myocarditis
column46: the cardiology department was consulted. In the transthoracic echocardiogram
column47: the patient showed a non-dilated
column48: slightly hypertrophic left ventricle
column49: with hypokinesia of the distal middle segments of the inferior septum
column50: and normal LVEF; a non-dilated
column51: normofunctioning right ventricle
column52: and absence of significant valvular heart disease or pericardial effusion (video 1). We interpreted the elevated markers of myocardial damage as justifiable by the clinical context of the patient (hypoxaemia
column53: acute infection
column54: possible underlying heart disease) and did not perform further tests. The patient evolved favourably and was discharged 10 days after admission.  DIAGNOSIS Bilateral SARS-CoV2 pneumonia with elevated markers of myocardial damage in this context. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History No drug allergies. No toxic habits. Cardiovascular risk factors: Arterial hypertension. Dyslipidaemia.  Cardiological history: PAF subjected to ablation in 2015. Chronic ischaemic heart disease
column3: debut in 2010 as exertional angina
column4: and underwent percutaneous revascularisation by implanting a conventional stent in the circumflex artery. In 2013
column5: readmission for unstable angina with percutaneous revascularisation and implantation of a stent-eluting stent in the proximal segment of the anterior descending artery. Ejection fraction preserved.  Other antecedents: Spondyloarthrosis. Prostatic syndrome. Bilateral hearing loss. Surgical interventions: Pertrochanteric fracture of the left hip in 2018. Baseline situation: independent for basic activities of daily living. Preserved higher functions. Home treatment: carvedilol 25 mg
column6: half a tablet every 12 hours. Omeprazole 20 mg
column7: 1 tablet every 24 hours. Ramipril 5 mg
column8: 1 tablet every 24 hours. Ezetimibe 10 mg/atorvastatin 80 mg
column9: 1 tablet every 24 hours. Edoxaban 60 mg
column10: 1 tablet every 24 hours. Alendronic acid every 28 days.   Present illness A 76-year-old man came to the emergency department with fluctuating weakness of the left limbs after a fierce argument with his son and associated nervousness. column11: and angio-CT without occlusion of a large vessel. As a result
column12: and in view of the improvement in symptoms

column15: and a new cranial CT scan was performed which confirmed the existence of an established infarct with a new appearance of a hypodense focal area in the right lenticular and radial crown. The patient was treated with edoxaban as anticoagulation for PAF
column16: ensuring good compliance with treatment.  Physical examination Good general condition. Haemodynamically stable
column17: blood pressure 128/68 mmHg and heart rate 53 bpm. Afebrile. Eupneic at rest and when speaking

No dysmetria

Platelets 183
column27: 000. INR 1.21. Troponin T ultrasensitive 15 ng/l. Creatine kinase 59 U/l. Chest X-ray: normal cardiothoracic index. Prominent aortic button. Thickened hilae

column30: without insufficiency. The left ventricle (LV) is of normal dimensions (end-diastolic diameter 44 mm). Ejection fraction by Simpson biplane 60% without regional contractility alterations. Septum 10 mm. Posterior wall 8 mm. Mitral E 79 cm/s
column31: A: 64 cm/s. Trivalve aortic valve with good opening and closing. Sinuses of Valsalva: 37 mm
column32: ascending tubular aorta: 32 mm. Right ventricle of normal size and contractility. Normal tricuspid valve without insufficiency. column33: in the posterior wall of the atrial roof. In this area of the atrial wall there is a minimal pericardial fluid sheet of 1.5 mm. The mass is 6.1 cm long (maximum width 2 cm)
column34: highly mobile
column35: polylobulated-branched
column36: with an irregular surface and several long
column37: mobile outgrowths. The length of the mass causes it to prolapse in diastole through the mitral orifice into the base of the LV without causing mitral obstruction. The echogenicity of the mass is hypoechoic in the area of implantation
column38: with the rest being of higher echogenicity
column39: with some rounded hypoechoic area in the body. Mitral valve with normal leaflets
column40: without insufficiency. Left atrial appendage without thrombus. Normal aortic valve and proximal aorta. Descending thoracic aorta with some uncomplicated atheroma plaque. Conclusions: large mass (6.1 x 2 cm) mobile in left atrium
column41: inserted with wide pedicle (2.1 cm) in atrial roof-posterior wall. Thoracoabdominal CT scan: LA of normal dimensions. Hypodense mass of irregular contours and with excrescences that seems to be fixed in the angle formed by the posterior wall of the LA with the inferoposterior slope of the interatrial septum (below the mouth of the right inferior pulmonary vein without affecting its drainage). Its approximate dimensions are 47 x 21 mm in the apical 4C (Ap x T) plane and a CC axis of 29 mm in the EL plane. Apart from the described anchorage
column42: its growth is fundamentally intracavitary

column44: slightly elongated and with calcium-predominant atheromatosis in the arch and origin of supra-aortic trunks. Pulmonary trunk of normal dimensions
column45: as well as the branches

column48: bile duct

column52: not very appreciable. Small bowel loops and right colon with mural thickness caliber disruption. Moderate aortoiliac atheromatosis. No inguinal adenomegaly of suspicious appearance. Conclusion: irregular hypodense mass anchored in the angle between the lower wall of the LA and the posteroinferior aspect of the interatrial septum. No signs of current metastatic spread. Coronary angiography: right radial access. column53: the largest of which was 2x1 cm
column54: one of which was found adhered to the muscle wall. Conclusion: myxoma with respect of the implantation base.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION On admission to the neurology ward
column55: and in view of the suspected embolic origin of the stroke
column56: a regular echocardiography was requested
column57: where the culprit of the event was discovered. Initially
column58: a transthoracic study was performed
column59: where a normal heart was visualised
column60: finding a large mobile mass (6.1 x 2 cm) attached to the posterior wall of the left atrium
column61: so for a better characterisation the study was completed with transesophageal echocardiography. Despite the high suspicion of myxoma
column62: the characteristics of the mass (wide insertion not in the interatrial septum
column63: polylobulated-branched and with hypoechoic areas inside) do not clearly indicate this aetiology
column64: but rather extend the differential diagnosis to other entities with a worse prognosis... such as sarcoma. A CT scan of the thorax and abdomen was performed
column65: which provided some reassurance as no signs of metastatic dissemination were observed. After diagnosis
column66: the patient was transferred to the cardiology ward
column67: where the pre-surgical study was completed (coronary angiography with stability of coronary disease). After a week of hospitalisation
column68: without complications and with greater safety from the point of view of intracranial haemorrhagic risk
column69: surgery was performed
column70: in which wedge resection of the floor of the left atrium was performed with the implantation base of the tumour
column71: which the surgeons described as a brownish
column72: gelatinous and very friable tumour. Subsequent evolution in the intensive care unit and on the cardiology ward was very favourable and without complications. The patient was discharged 7 days after the operation
column73: and in agreement with neurology
column74: anticoagulation was restarted with edoxaban 60 mg every 24 hours. After the anatomopathological study of the surgical specimen
column75: it was possible to name the tumour
column76: confirming the initial suspicion of myxoma that the echocardiography had provided. The patient is currently undergoing motor rehabilitation due to the sequelae of left lower limb hemiparesis
column77: and from the cardiological point of view he is asymptomatic and without any complications.  DIAGNOSIS Ischaemic stroke in the right choroidal artery of embolic origin. Pedunculated atrial myxoma implanted in the roof of the left atrium. Surgical excision of left atrial myxoma without complications. Normal left ventricular function. Stable chronic coronary syndrome with two-vessel disease (Cx and LAD) with complete percutaneous revascularisation. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION A 52-year-old man consulted for chest pain.  History No known drug allergies. Toxic habits: ex-smoker

column7: CURB65 =1

column28: right coronary artery (RCA) and circumflex artery (CxA)
column29: with fine calibre of the entire coronary tree

Normal pericardium
column32: no pericardial effusion. 12-lead ECG performed on the cardiology ward after cardiorespiratory arrest: sinus rhythm at 65 bpm. Narrow QRS. Deep negative T waves V2-V6. Negative T waves of lesser magnitude in inferior face
column33: I and aVL. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): no evidence of space-occupying lesion
column34: haemorrhage or recent acute or subacute infarction. CT scan of the chest and abdomen with contrast: thickening of the duodenal papilla. Adenopathies of non-specific appearance in the lesser sac
column35: mesentery and retroperitoneum. Bilateral pleural effusion with passive collapse of posterior basal subsegments. Nonspecific micro-nodule in the right lower lobe.   CLINICAL EVOLUTION After being assessed in the emergency department with normal complementary tests
column36: he was admitted to the cardiology ward to complete the study. A few hours after admission
column37: he began to experience chest pain and the ECG showed ST elevation in the lower lobe. Urgent coronary angiography showed severe spasm of the left main coronary artery
column38: right coronary artery and circumflex artery
column39: with fine calibre of the entire coronary tree
column40: which resolved with intracoronary nitroglycerine. After administration of intravenous nitroglycerine
column41: no angiographically significant lesions were detected. Subsequently
column42: he was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) where myocardial damage markers were normal and
column43: after remaining stable for 48 hours
column44: he was returned to the cardiology ward. Once on the ward
column45: treatment was started with calcium antagonists (ACA) and nitrates
column46: which were titrated to the maximum tolerated doses. Despite this
column47: he presented with a new episode of precordial pain followed by cardiorespiratory arrest (CRA) in electromechanical dissociation. After advanced cardiopulmonary resuscitation manoeuvres for 10 minutes with the need for orotracheal intubation
column48: he recovered a pulse in sinus tachycardia for 1 minute and subsequently presented with polymorphic ventricular tachycardia requiring urgent electrical cardioversion. He was transferred to the ICU where he again registered polymorphic ventricular tachycardia
column49: requiring a new electrical cardioversion
column50: with exit in sinus rhythm. After CRP
column51: myocardial damage markers were serum tested and an enzyme curve was found compatible with acute myocardial infarction and electrocardiographic changes compatible with subendocardial ischaemia. A new urgent echocardiogram was performed with no changes with respect to the previous one. In the control analysis that had been drawn just before the CRA
column52: renal function and ions
column53: including potassium and magnesium
column54: were normal. Subsequently
column55: he required prolonged admission to the ICU due to haemodynamic instability requiring treatment with vasoactive amines. After achieving haemodynamic stability
column56: he returned to the cardiology ward
column57: where treatment was optimised with the addition of fluvastatin and high doses of calcium antagonists and nitrates
column58: which were poorly tolerated due to hypotension. Despite this
column59: the patient presented recurrent vasospasm crises (with electrocardiographic confirmation). In view of the severe vasospasm refractory to treatment
column60: an extensive study was carried out to detect underlying pathologies that could be associated with or justify the recurrent vasospasm (metabolic
column61: tumour
column62: autoimmune
column63: etc.). As the only findings during admission
column64: the endocrinology department diagnosed partial adrenal insufficiency of pituitary origin due to moderate hypoosmolar hyponatraemia with clinical repercussions (drowsiness)
column65: which was corrected with hydrocortisone. In addition
column66: a monoclonal IgM Kappa band was detected in the proteinogram. Finally
column67: after ruling out a correctable cause associated with the recurrent vasospasm crises and given the lack of response and poor tolerance of nitrates
column68: it was decided to withdraw the latter and empirically add cilostazol (phosphodiesterase-3 inhibitor) to the ACAs. After starting this treatment
column69: the patient remained asymptomatic
column70: with no new episodes of chest pain or vasospasm. After ruling out other possible causes of CRA
column71: it was determined that there was a high possibility that CRA occurred in the context of prolonged vasospasm. Therefore
column72: it was decided to implant an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) for secondary prevention. Once the ICD was implanted and the vasospasm crises were controlled
column73: we progressively reduced cilostazol until complete withdrawal of the drug
column74: after which the patient was asymptomatic and haemodynamically stable. At discharge
column75: treatment with ACA and fluvastatin was maintained with excellent response
column76: with no new events occurring in the first year of follow-up.  DIAGNOSIS Recurrent vasospastic angina refractory to treatment. In-hospital cardiorespiratory arrest related to acute myocardial infarction secondary to vasospastic angina. Implantation of an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD VR) in secondary prevention. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History 81-year-old male. Cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF): dyslipidaemia
column3: arterial hypertension
column4: overweight grade 2
column5: type 2 diabetes mellitus. Cardiological history: permanent atrial fibrillation anticoagulated with dabigatran (150 mg/12 hours). Other history: complete constitutional syndrome (weight loss of 10 kg in the last 4 months
column6: night sweats) of 2 years of evolution (suspected histiocytosis). Gastro/colonoscopy: negative. PET scan: perirenal fat deposits with involvement of hip and spine bones. Perirenal fat biopsy: fibroadipose tissue with mild lymphoplasmacytic inflammatory infiltrate with isolated eosinophils
column7: perivascular and diffuse. Mixed phenotype COPD. Intermittent claudication MMII. Usual treatment: empagliflozin 10 mg 1 tablet daily: metformin 850 mg 1 tablet every 12 hours; dabigatran 150 mg 1 tablet every 12 hours; inhaler (salmeterol + fluticasone); atorvastatin 40 mg 1 tablet per day; diltiazem 120 mg per day; dutasteride/tamsulosin 0.5/0.4 mg 1 tablet per day; oral iron; lorazepam 1 mg 1 tablet per day; omeprazole 20 mg 1 tablet per day
column8: valsartan 80 mg 1 tablet per day.  Current illness Patient admitted to the internal medicine department (MIN) for progressive worsening of functional class to the point of presenting minimal effort dyspnoea (NYHA III)
column9: associated with orthopnoea
column10: paroxysmal dyspnoea and intense asthenia. No chest pain or palpitations. Under study for known serositis (pleural) and asthenia in constitutional syndrome followed in MIN outpatient clinic (CCEE). Once admitted to the MIN ward
column11: he showed little improvement with the prescribed intravenous treatment. Forty-eight hours after admission
column12: there was a significant clinical deterioration and an assessment by the on-call cardiology department was requested.  Physical examination Tachypnoea with poor tolerance to decubitus
column13: mucocutaneous pallor
column14: MEG. Blood pressure (BP) 80/50 mmHg
column15: O2 saturation 90% with GN at 3L/min
column16: respiratory rate (RR) 28 rpm
column17: heart rate (HR) 118 bpm. Jugular ingurgitation. Positive hepatojugular reflex. Cardiopulmonary: irregular and hypophonetic heart sounds without murmurs. Respiratory sounds present with generalised hypoventilation. Abdomen: globular
column18: soft and depressible
column19: diffusely painful on palpation
column20: no Bloomberg
column21: no Murphy. Extremities: no oedema in declining parts
column22: no signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Signs of distal hypoperfusion.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS AP chest X-ray from 2019 prior to current admission: centred cardiomediastinal silhouette with no widening or retractions. Cardiothoracic index (CTI) less than 0.5. Translucent lung fields with no evidence of pleural effusion or pneumonic condensation. Current AP chest X-ray: enlarged cardiomediastinal silhouette with CTI greater than 0.5. Bilateral interstitial infiltrate with apical vascular flow redistribution. Right cysuritis. No evidence of pleural effusion or pneumonic condensation. Electrocardiogram (ECG): atrial fibrillation at 145 bpm. QRS: 60 ms. AXIS: -60o. Left anterior hemiblock of the His bundle. Negative T waves in DI and aVL. Isolated ventricular extrasystoles. Low voltages.  Blood tests: CBC: red blood cells 3.11 10*12/l. Haemoglobin 8.8 g/dl. Haematocrit 27.1%. MCV 87.2 fl. MCH 28.2 pg. MCHC 32.3 g/dl. ADE 15.3%. Leukocytes 8.9 10*9/l. Neutrophils 7.9 10*9/l. Lymphocytes 0.5 10*9/l. Monocytes 0
column23: 4 10*9/l. Eosinophils 0
column24: 1 10*9/l. Basophils 0
column25: 1 10*9/l. Platelets 539 10*9/l. Haemostasis (initial): prothrombin time (PT) 22.8 sec. Quick index 31%. INR 1.97. APTT 55.5 sec. Ratio (aPTT) 1.86. Derived fibrinogen 890 mg/dl. Haemostasis (after idarucizumab administration): prothrombin time (PT) 15.8 sec. Quick ratio 62%. INR 1.26 APTT 23.4 sec. Ratio (aPTT) 0.79 Derived fibrinogen 700 mg/dl. Biochemistry: Glucose 125 mg/dl. Sodium 133 mEq/l. Potassium 3.8 mEq/l. Chlorine 103 mEq/l. Total bilirubin 1.54 mg/dl. Aspartate aminotransferase GOT 69 U/l. Alanine aminotransferase GPT 59 U/l. Alkaline phosphatase 110 U/l. Gamma-glutamyl transferase 80 U/l. Creatinine 2.20 mg/dl. Uric acid 4.8 mg/dl. Protein 7.2 g/dl. Creatin phosphokinase 119 U/l. CRP 15.1 mg/dl. Iron profile: ferritin 54 μg/l. Iron 94 μg/dl. Total Fe fixation capacity 371 ug/dl. Transferrin saturation index 12.3%. Latent Fe binding capacity 277 ug/dl. Congestion markers: NT-proBNP 5700 pg/ml
column26: Ag. carbohydrate 125 (CA125) 225 IU/ml. Lipid profile: total cholesterol 319 mg/d. Triglycerides 90 mg/dl. HDL cholesterol 72 mg/dl. LDL cholesterol 229 mg/dl. Total cholesterol / HDL 4.4. Hormones: thyrotropin (TSH) 1.77 uIU/ml. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) (video 1): left ventricle with preserved diameters
column27: preserved global systolic function (LVEF 64%). Atria of normal size. Absence of alterations in segmental contractility at rest. Absence of significant valvulopathies. Right ventricle with preserved contractility. Trivial tricuspid insufficiency (TI) with PAPs 45 mmHg. Dilated inferior vena cava 24 mm without inspiratory collapse. Severe pericardial effusion of global distribution with significant haemodynamic compromise of the right cavities.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION On evaluation by the cardiologist on duty
column28: the patient was in obstructive shock secondary to cardiac tamponade as seen by transthoracic echocardiography. It was decided to cautiously administer intravascular volume
column29: to associate treatment with norepinephrine and to immediately transfer him to the coronary care unit. Once in the coronary care unit
column30: it was decided to check the patient's haemogram and haemostasis in order to perform diagnostic/therapeutic pericardiocentesis
column31: with unacceptable figures for this procedure without haemorrhagic risk. Given the persistence of obstructive shock in the context of cardiac tamponade despite the prescribed intravenous treatment
column32: it was decided to request and administer 2 ampoules of idarucizumab as an antidote for the patient's anticoagulation. The improvement of haemostatic parameters was verified in control analyses
column33: which allowed the procedure to be carried out one hour after administration. Diagnostic/therapeutic pericardiocentesis guided by echocardiography was performed and 650 cc of serohematic fluid was extracted with evident haemodynamic improvement. Samples of pericardial fluid were sent for study. In the following days the patient showed a favourable evolution with haemodynamic stability without vasoactive/inothropic support and negative balances and progressive improvement of clinical and radiological signs of congestion. A control echocardiogram was performed showing minimal residual pericardial effusion with no evidence of haemodynamic compromise
column34: so the drain was removed without complications after 24 hours
column35: dabigatran was reintroduced and medical discharge was decided.  DIAGNOSIS Obstructive shock in the context of cardiac tamponade. Severe pericardial effusion complicated by cardiac tamponade. Reversal of dabigatran anticoagulation with idarucizumab for emergent pericardiocentesis. Pericardiocentesis with drainage of 560 cc serohematic cc. Permanent atrial fibrillation anticoagulated with dabigatran. Polyserositis under study. Constitutional syndrome under study

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION A 68-year-old woman was referred to the outpatient cardiology department for a cardiac mass found on computed axial tomography (CT).  History No known cardiovascular risk factors. Independent for basic activities of daily living. Left renal neoplasm (clear cell carcinoma with sarcomatoid differentiation 80%
column3: PT3A) with left nephrectomy in 2013 and reoperation for secondary eventration in 2017. Normofunctioning multinodular goitre
column4: in evolutionary follow-up. No other history of interest and without usual pharmacological treatment.  Current disease Previously asymptomatic cardiovascular patient
column5: she presented with pain in the left hemithorax (VAS 4)
column6: with pleuritic characteristics
column7: not triggered by exertion
column8: of prolonged duration and appearing sporadically at rest. In the CT scan of renal neoplasia
column9: a left ventricle-dependent mass was detected
column10: with progressive growth
column11: and the patient was referred to cardiology.  Physical examination Blood pressure 120/80 mmHg. Heart rate 70 bpm. Eupneic at rest. Jugular venous pressure normal. Cardiac auscultation rhythmic
column12: with protomesosystolic murmur II/VI in aortic focus with preserved second sound
column13: pulmonary auscultation with preserved vesicular murmur
column14: without added pathological noises. Abdominal examination with no significant findings. No oedema in the lower extremities
column15: with preserved and symmetrical peripheral pulses.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm at 85 bpm
column16: PR 160ms
column17: QRS 100ms
column18: cardiac axis -15o with HBAI
column19: non-pathological septal Q wave
column20: isolated negative T in V1 without other alterations. Analysis: leukocytes 6
column22: haemoglobin 14.2 g/dl
column23: platelets 190
column25: glucose 93 mg/dl
column26: urea 53 mg/dl
column27: creatinine 0.91 mg/dl
column28: MDRD-IDMS: > 60 ml/min
column29: AST 16 IU/l
column30: ALT 14IU/l
column31: GGT 16IU/l
column33: K 4.4 mmol/l. Chest X-ray: normal cardiothoracic index. No mediastinal widening. No evidence of heart failure. Echocardiogram: left ventricle of normal size with preserved ejection fraction
column34: without segmental contractility abnormalities. Right ventricle of normal size and function. Grade I diastolic dysfunction. Mild mitral regurgitation. Large mass of irregular echogenicity
column35: paracardiac
column36: in the posterior and lateral area of the left ventricle
column37: which does not compromise ventricular function. Thoracic-abdominal CT with contrast: solid mass with heterogeneous attenuation and estimated maximum diameters of 6.3 x 5.5 x 3.8 cm (craniocaudal
column38: AP and transverse axes respectively)
column39: dependent on the lateral and basal wall of the left ventricle
column40: which imprints and slightly deforms the lateral wall of the left atrium. An asymmetric thickening of the left ventricular wall is observed coinciding with the location of the current lesion. Cardiac MRI: large mass in the lateral area of the left ventricle and atrioventricular groove (6.4 x 5.2 cm maximum diameter)
column41: affecting the full thickness of the wall and with a mass effect on the lateral aspect of the left atrium. Well-defined outline
column42: with myocardial and pericardial infiltration. The signal is isointense on T1 enhancement
column43: faintly hyperintense on T2 and markedly hyperintense on STIR
column44: with evidence of intense vascularisation on first-pass images after intravenous gadolinium administration. Heterogeneous late enhancement
column45: predominantly central
column46: in the form of a ring surrounding the necrotic area. Pathology: the endomyocardial fragments show areas of infiltration by a tumour with a growth pattern in solid nests or irregular cords
column47: with dense inflammatory response
column48: and consisting of cells with rounded or lobulated nuclei with moderate anisokaryosis
column49: and clato- or acidophilic cytoplasm. Focally the tumour adopts a rhabdoid pattern and morphology. Immunohistochemistry shows expression of CK AE1-AE3
column50: vimentin and CD10 in neoplastic cells. Diagnosis: endomyocardial fragments with metastasis of renal cell carcinoma (sarcomatoid histopathological pattern
column51: similar to that described in the patient's previous biopsy).  CLINICAL EVOLUTION It was decided to extend the study with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to better identify the cardiac mass
column52: with the results described above. Given the findings of the MRI and the patient's clinical history
column53: metastatic implantation was suspected as the first option
column54: and an endomyocardial biopsy was performed
column55: which was found to be compatible with metastasis of renal cell carcinoma. Subsequently
column56: the patient was referred to the oncology outpatient department
column57: which started treatment with sunitinib 50 mg every 24 hours
column58: 2/1 schedule
column59: presenting growth of the cardiac mass and increased pericardial effusion after 5 months of treatment
column60: so it was decided to start immunotherapy with nivolumab
column61: achieving a complete tumour response
column62: with regression of the cardiac tumour mass
column63: with no evidence of progression at present.  DIAGNOSIS Paracardiac mass with pericardial and intramural infiltration
column64: compatible with metastasis of renal carcinoma. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History Brother with previous recurrent myocarditis in 2000
column3: with clinical diagnosis and no subsequent follow-up. No history of sudden death or other heart disease in first-degree relatives. No known drug allergies. No toxic habits. She had no cardiovascular risk factors or medical or surgical history of interest.  Present illness A 36-year-old man consulted for non-radiating
column4: oppressive
column5: central thoracic pain that started at rest and woke him from sleep. The pain was accompanied by nausea
column6: sweating and a sensation of dyspnoea and improved slightly when he got into bed. The patient mentioned the presence of fever and pharyngeal pain 2 days before the onset of the symptoms. On arrival at the hospital
column7: electrocardiographic alterations and elevated markers of myocardial damage in the infarct range were observed
column8: so an urgent coronary angiography was performed in which no coronary lesions were found.  Physical examination Good general condition
column9: conscious and oriented in all 3 spheres. Haemodynamically stable. Eupneic at rest. Normal colour
column10: well hydrated and perfused. Afebrile. Blood pressure (BP) 151/84 mmHg
column11: heart rate (HR) 72 bpm
column12: SatO2 99% without contributions. No signs of heart failure. Cardiorespiratory auscultation: rhythmic at a good frequency
column13: no murmurs or extratonos. Vesicular murmur preserved
column14: no pathological noises added. Abdomen: soft and depressible
column15: not painful on palpation. No signs of defence or peritoneal irritation. Lower limbs without oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis.   COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG on admission to the ward: sinus rhythm at 64 bpm. Normal PR. QTc 441 msec. J point elevation of < 1 mm from V4 to V6. Negative T wave from V4 to V6. Emergency laboratory tests: CBC: leukocytes 10420 (1360 lymphocytes)
column16: Hb 15.7 g/dl
column17: platelets 182000. Biochemistry: glucose 142 mg/dl
column18: AST 42 U/l
column19: renal function and ions normal
column20: CRP 195.4 mg/l. Enzyme serum: creatine kinase 270 - 641 - 723 U/l
column21: ultrasensitive troponin T 500 - 1061 - 1744 - 1184 - 1225 ng/dl. Chest X-ray: normal. Cardiothoracic index normal. No signs of pulmonary congestion
column22: condensation or effusion. Coronary angiography: angiographically normal coronary arteries. Anomalous outflow of the right coronary artery from the left sinus
column23: without angiographically significant lesions. Serology: negative for HIV
column24: syphilis and Mycoplasma pneumoniae. Positive for past infection by adenovirus
column25: CMV
column26: Echovirus
column27: EBV
column28: parvovirus B19 and Coxsackie. Laboratory tests: Biochemistry: glucose 87 mg/dl
column29: renal function and ions normal
column30: LDH 388.00 U/l
column31: hepatobiliary profile without alterations. Total protein 7.7 g/dl. NT-proBNP 379 pg/ml. C-reactive protein 65.0 mg/l. Lipid profile: cholesterol 210 mg/dl
column33: HDL 26 mg/dl
column34: triglycerides 156.00 mg/dl. Thyroid hormones and HbA1c normal. CBC: three normal series. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): left ventricle neither dilated nor hypertrophic
column35: with preserved global and segmental mobility. Ejection fraction (EF) measured with the Simpson method: 68.8%. LVEDV of 140 ml
column36: indexed by body surface area of 67 ml/m2
column37: LVESV of 44 ml
column38: indexed by body surface area of 21 ml/m2. Myocardial mass 119 g
column39: indexed by body surface area of 57 g/m.Right ventricle not dilated or hypertrophic
column40: with preserved global and segmental mobility; EF measured by Simpson's method of 81% VTDVD of 110 ml
column41: indexed by body surface area of 53 ml/m. VTSVD of 21 ml
column42: indexed by body surface area 22 of 10 ml/m. Both atria of normal size (left atrium with an area of 22 cm
column43: indexed to 11 cm/m and right atrium of 19 cm
column44: indexed to 9 cm/m). In the sequence STIR shows hyperintense signal compatible with oedema in the inferior and anterior basal and medial segments
column45: medial lateral and in all apical segments. The first-pass perfusion sequence shows no basal perfusion defects. In the late enhancement/viability sequence
column46: there was extensive subepicardial and intramyocardial fibrosis in the basal and middle inferior and middle anterior and inferolateral segments and in all apical segments. Conclusion: acute myocarditis with extensive fibrosis and preserved biventricular function.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION After a favourable evolution during admission
column47: our patient was discharged
column48: with initiation of 5 mg of enalapril per day. After 4 months during which he was asymptomatic
column49: he was admitted again for symptoms compatible with acute myopericarditis (ultrasensitive troponin T peak of 2174 ng/dl)
column50: with gastroenteritis of probable viral origin as a possible trigger. A new transthoracic echocardiogram was performed
column51: showing slight global hypokinesia with an EF of 50%. After a satisfactory evolution
column52: the patient was discharged
column53: and colchicine was prescribed as a preventive treatment for new recurrences. A new cardiac MRI was performed on an outpatient basis
column54: in the first 2 weeks after discharge
column55: which showed the persistence of extensive fibrosis of similar distribution to the previous study
column56: as well as denovo fibrosis at the level of the basal and medial septum (images 5 and 6). Both ventricles had normal morphology and volumes
column57: with no detectable segmental contractility disturbances
column58: and biventricular systolic function was preserved. In the STIR and black blood sequences
column59: there were no intramyocardial fatty deposits and there was significant oedema at the level of the septum. In view of the results of the MRI
column60: a 24-hour Holter monitor was requested
column61: which showed isolated monotopic ventricular extrasystoles with morphology of right bundle branch block with transition in V3 and superior axis
column62: and it was decided to increase the doses of ACE inhibitors (enalapril 5 mg/12 hours) and to start beta-blocker treatment (bisoprolol 2.5 mg/24 hours). His brother was seen at our clinic due to a history of recurrent myocarditis
column63: and a cardiac MRI was performed
column64: confirming the presence of subepicardial fibrosis in the free wall of the left ventricle
column65: compatible with past myocarditis. Finally
column66: given the pattern of fibrosis in the MRI together with the history of a first-degree relative with recurrent myocarditis
column67: the differential diagnosis of acute recurrent myocarditis with extensive fibrosis versus arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy of the left ventricle was considered and it was decided to request a genetic study with a cardiomyopathy panel
column68: the results of which are still pending.  DIAGNOSIS Acute myocarditis with extensive fibrosis and preserved biventricular function versus arrhythmogenic left ventricular dysplasia with myocarditis-e flares. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 58-year-old woman
column3: no known drug allergies.  History Cardiovascular risk factors: active smoker (8-10 cigarettes a day). Depressive syndrome. Menopause at 50-51 years of age. No known cardiological history
column4: neither in relatives. Usual treatment: citalopram 10 mg.  Current illness Consultation in the emergency department for chest discomfort onset at rest
column5: with associated presyncopal symptoms lasting approximately 50 minutes. On assessment
column6: she was asymptomatic
column7: with an initial electrocardiogram (ECG) with no abnormalities and positive troponin determination
column8: so the patient was diagnosed as non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (NSTEACS) Killip I and admission to the intermediate care unit was decided.  Physical examination Blood pressure (BP) 110/60 mmHg. Heart rate (HR) 60 bpm. Oxygen saturation (basal) 96%. Afebrile. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic without audible murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: normal. Abdomen: nondescript. Lower limbs: no oedema
column9: no signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: sinus rhythm at 72 bpm
column10: normal PR
column11: narrow QRS
column12: without acute repolarisation alterations. Laboratory tests: NT-proBNP 22 pg/ml
column13: troponin I US 1
column14: 871 -> peak 5
column15: 212 pg/ml (normal value <14 pg/ml). Renal function and ions normal. Haemoglobin 14.4 g/dl
column16: platelets 201
column18: leucocytes 5
column19: 600/μl. Glucose 87 mg/dl
column20: creatinine 0.74 mg/dl
column21: Na 139 mEq/l
column22: K 4.9 mEq/l
column23: TSH normal
column24: total cholesterol 259 mg/dl
column25: HDL 58 mg/dl
column26: LDL 183 mg/dl. Chest X-ray: cardiac silhouette
column27: parenchyma and pulmonary vascularisation without pathological findings. Cardiac catheterisation: epicardial coronary arteries without angiographic lesions in main vessels. Only a third obtuse marginal branch showed a sudden change in calibre from 1.5 mm to less than 1 mm
column28: which subsequently recovered the size of the vessel
column29: which could correspond to an area of haematoma/spontaneous dissection. Ventriculography: left ventricle (LV) with preserved systolic function
column30: very localised akinesia of the mid-basal inferolateral area. Echocardiogram: non-dilated LV
column31: normal wall thickness
column33: no segmental alterations. Atria not dilated. Right ventricle (RV) not dilated with normal contractility (TAPSE 20 mm
column34: S wave 11.5 cm/s). Slight mitral sclerosis
column35: correct and competent opening. Trivalve aortic valve with calcium spot in non-coronary leaflet and mild sclerosis
column36: not restricted in opening and with mild central insufficiency. Mild tricuspid insufficiency
column37: RV-AD gradient 15 mmHg. Mild pulmonary insufficiency
column38: protodiastolic gradient 6 mmHg. Pulmonary acceleration time 130 ms. Inferior vena cava (IVC) not dilated (13 mm) with normal collapse. Normal PAPs. Absence of pericardial effusion. Computed tomography (CT) body: origin of the supra-aortic trunks of normal morphology. Axillary-subclavian arterial axes and carotid axes permeable and of normal calibre. Cervical segment of internal carotid artery with slight irregularity
column39: not conclusive of dysplasia. Left vertebral dominance. Left coronary trunk and circumflex artery of normal calibre. Patent aorta with preserved calibre. Bilateral accessory renal artery with origin cranial to the ipsilateral main renal artery. Main renal arteries of arrosariado-displastic appearance. Patent and ectatic iliac arterial shafts. External iliac arteries with arrosative-dysplastic appearance. None of the focal stenoses that condition the dysplastic appearance of the main renal arteries and the external iliac arteries is significant. Extravascular findings: left adrenal with nodular thickening of adenomatous appearance. Right kidney with small fatty nodule in its lower third compatible with small angiomyolipoma and left kidney with small cortical cyst in its upper third. Calcified uterine myoma. Sigmoid diverticulosis. Conclusion: main renal arteries and external iliac arteries of arrosariado aspect
column40: a finding that suggests fibromuscular dysplasia.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION Coronary angiography was performed in the first 24 hours with the finding of epicardial coronary arteries without angiographic lesions in the main vessels
column41: but a sudden decrease in calibre was observed in the third obtuse marginal branch
column42: compatible with spontaneous coronary dissection at that level. Subsequent evolution was favourable
column43: with no complications in the vascular access area or clinical recurrence. A transthoracic echocardiogram was requested with overall systolic function preserved
column44: with no segmental asymmetries at discharge
column45: and no notable valvulopathies. Given the diagnosis of spontaneous coronary artery dissection
column46: the study was completed with a body CT scan to detect fibromuscular dysplasia
column47: which was finally confirmed
column48: with involvement of the main renal and external iliac arteries. In a situation of clinical stability
column49: the patient was discharged
column50: indicating cessation of smoking and indefinite taking of simple antiplatelet therapy and high-potency statins.  DIAGNOSIS Acute myocardial infarction without Q wave due to spontaneous coronary dissection of the third obtuse marginal branch. Normal LV systolic function. Fibromuscular dysplasia with involvement of renal and iliac arteries. Smoking. Dyslipidaemia. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History The patient is an 80-year-old woman
column3: with a history of: Risk factors: hypertension
column4: dyslipidaemia
column5: smoker of 2-3 cigarettes/day. She has had a dual-chamber pacemaker since July 2015 due to sinus dysfunction and paroxysmal atrioventricular block (AVB) reprogrammed in VVI due to atrial lead failure. In 2014 she was referred to cardiology for gait instability and palpitations. A regular echocardiogram was performed
column6: which revealed a tumour mass in the left atrium
column7: starting from the foramen ovale
column8: probably an atrial myxoma
column9: which slightly interfered with mitral valve kinetics
column10: causing mild dynamic stenosis. One year later
column11: she had an ischaemic stroke of probable cardioembolic origin
column12: and once she had recovered
column13: it was decided to perform surgery on the myxoma
column14: and a complete resection of the myxoma was performed with good results. In 2016 and 2018
column15: she had two episodes of posterior circulation stroke (POCI) of undetermined origin
column16: with diplopia and instability. During these admissions
column17: an echocardiogram was performed
column18: which was normal
column19: and Doppler of the supra-aortic trunk showed moderate stenosis of both carotid arteries
column20: so it was decided to start antiplatelet therapy with acetylsalicylic acid.  Current disease Admitted in October 2019 for intermittent episodes of gait instability
column21: assessed by neurology
column22: a diagnosis of repeated vertebrobasilar transient ischaemic attack (TIA) was made and she was admitted to complete the study. During admission
column23: an echocardiogram was performed which revealed a mass in the left atrium
column24: suggesting recurrence of myxoma.  Physical examination The patient was conscious and oriented in space and time. No language alterations
column25: preserved nomation. Pupils isochoric and normoreactive. No nystagmus. EOM (external ocular motor) preserved. Examination of cranial nerves normal. Upper and lower limb strength preserved. Examination of superficial and deep sensitivity preserved. Bicipital and patellar osteotendinous reflexes preserved. Finger-nose and finger-finger test with some slowness
column26: possible dysmetria. Romberg's sign doubtful. Stability with increased base of support
column27: unstable gait with lateropulsion to the left. Tandem gait impossible for her. No signs of meningeal irritation. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic tones without audible murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur
column28: no extra sounds. Abdomen: soft and depressible
column29: not painful on palpation
column30: no palpable masses or megaliths
column31: no signs of peritoneal irritation
column32: preserved peristalsis. Lower limbs: no oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Pedial pulses were preserved.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus rhythm at 74 bpm
column33: normal PR
column34: narrow QRS
column35: no repolarisation alterations. Blood tests: biochemistry: glucose 105 mg/dl
column36: urea 22 mg/dl
column37: creatinine 0.66 mg/dl
column38: Na 136 mmol/l
column39: K 4.0 mmol/l. Haemogram: leucocytes 8400/mcl
column40: Hb 13.3 mg/dl
column42: platelets 356000. Coagulation: INR 1.04
column43: AP 99%
column44: fibrinogen 5.9 g/l. Chest X-ray: cardiomediastinal silhouette and pulmonary vascularisation within normality. Signs of chronic bronchopneumopathy. No other significant pleuroparenchymal alterations were observed. MCP with electrodes in the right cavities. Mid sternotomy sutures. Dorsal spondylosis Brain computed tomography (CT): signs of chronic ischaemia. Infarcts in the right parietal lobe and at the left parasagittal level next to the convexity
column45: both with an old appearance. Transesophageal echocardiogram: left atrium (LA) of normal dimensions. Inside the left atrium there is an image of a heterogeneous
column46: rounded
column47: echodense mass
column48: 21 x 23 mm in size
column49: with a wide implantation base (15 mm) on the interatrial septum
column50: which does not interfere with the correct kinetics of the mitral valve. Compatible with recurrence of atrial myxoma. Left ventricle not dilated
column51: not hypertrophic. Preserved systolic function
column52: without asymmetry of segmental contractility. Altered diastolic relaxation pattern. Right chambers of normal dimensions
column53: normocontractile right ventricle. Aortic valve trivalve
column54: not limited in its opening and competent. Mitral valve not limited in its opening
column55: with mild mitral insufficiency. Mild tricuspid insufficiency (TI)
column56: with RV-AD gradient 25 mmHg. Inferior vena cana (IVC) not dilated
column57: with preserved inspiratory collapse. Estimated normal PSAP. Absence of pericardial effusion or intracardiac masses.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION During admission to neurology
column58: anticoagulation with synthroid was started and the patient was considered for surgical reintervention. A diagnostic cardiac catheterisation was performed
column59: which revealed coronary arteries without significant lesions
column60: and an evaluation by the geriatrics department estimated a short-term mortality risk of 21%
column61: recommending that surgery should be performed within a period of less than 6 months. Finally
column62: she was re-evaluated in a medical-surgical session
column63: and given the high surgical risk of the patient and her baseline clinical situation
column64: conservative management was decided. During follow-up
column65: she has not presented any further neurological symptoms.  DIAGNOSIS Recurrence of atrial myxoma. column25: predominantly at free edges
column26: with bicommissural fusion
column27: resulting in severe stenosis (area calculated by hemi-pressure time 0.94 cm2 and by planimetry 0.76 cm
column28: with maximum gradient 17 mmHg and mean gradient 13 mmHg). column2: after excessive cocaine consumption

column49: with the two masses persisting with the appearance of a thrombus in the LV apex. No alterations in segmental contractility. Atria not dilated. Morphologically and functionally normal valves. No pericardial abnormalities. T2 STIR sequences do not show areas suggestive of oedema. CONCLUSION: Absence of images compatible with ventricular thrombus. Absence of myocardial oedema and late enhancement suggestive of ischaemic heart disease. Qp/Qs 1.33 with presence of partial anomalous pulmonary venous drainage with left superior pulmonary vein draining into left brachiocephalic trunk. The angio-CT scan showed proximal occlusion of the right humeral artery
column51: so a Fogarty catheter embolectomy was performed
column52: as well as
column53: incidentally
column54: an image compatible with intraventricular thrombus. column55: confirming the presence of two apical thrombi
column56: so
column57: given the suspicion of complicated acute myocardial infarction of undetermined time of evolution
column58: an urgent coronary angiography was performed which showed normal coronary arteries. He was transferred to the coronary unit
column59: where sodium heparin perfusion was started and
column60: in stable condition
column61: he was transferred to the conventional hospital ward. During his stay there
column62: he presented a new embolic event in the right lower limb despite correct anticoagulation (evidenced by serial controls by aPTT
column63: with frequent adjustments of the sodium heparin infusion rate) which required urgent thrombectomy
column64: with good subsequent evolution. A regular CMR was performed
column65: which showed LVEF recovery
column66: without late enhancement and with resolution of the thrombus. Given the clinical stability and the resolution of the medical-surgical processes that led to his admission
column67: after 10 days of hospitalisation he was discharged from hospital with outpatient monitoring. Anticoagulation with acenocoumarol was decided for 3-6 months with subsequent review in vascular surgery and cardiology consultations.  DIAGNOSIS Cocaine-induced stress cardiomyopathy (tako-tsubo syndrome). Intraventricular thrombus in the context of the above
column68: resolved on discharge. Proximal occlusion of right humeral artery of embolic nature
column69: treated by embolectomy. Embolism in the left common and external iliac arteries and in the third portion of the left popliteal artery
column70: treated by transfemoral thromboembolectomy. Asymptomatic right lower pole renal infarction. Partial anomalous pulmonary venous drainage with left superior pulmonary vein draining into left brachiocephalic trunk. column29: in the absence of pulmonary hypertension. Absence of pericardial effusion. Ergometry with hyperventilation test: hyperventilation test is performed for 2 minutes without appreciating significant changes in ventricular repolarisation. Subsequently
column30: he exercised according to the Bruce protocol
column31: stopping the test at the beginning of the 4th stage of the Bruce protocol (11 METS) due to maladaptation to the treadmill

column33: without lesions. Coronary fistulas to LV. Circumflex artery (ACX): non-dominant without lesions. Right coronary artery (RCA): dominant
column34: without lesions. Vasospasm test with acetylcholine: acetylcholine test was performed with increasing doses in the left coronary artery
column35: with no clinical changes observed in ECG or vasospasm. In ACD

column37: followed by transient complete atrioventricular block (AVB)

column42: which was normal

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION A 37-year-old woman reported an episode of transfixing interscapular pain radiating to the cervical region and to both upper limbs (MMSS)
column3: which had been going on for hours. She reported episodes of chest pain of identical characteristics related to exertion
column4: which subsided with rest
column5: of several months' evolution
column6: without having presented episodes of prolonged chest pain up to the present time
column7: for which she had not consulted. As personal history
column8: he had no known cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF) and was being followed up by cardiology at a private centre for moderate aortic insufficiency of unknown aetiology
column9: without access to previous echocardiogram images. Vital signs at triage. Blood pressure (BP) 140/80 mmHg. Heart rate (HR) 110 bpm. SatO2 (FiO2 21%) 93%. Temperature 37.2 ̊C.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Good general condition
column10: normal colour and normal hydration. Eupneic at rest. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic with systolic murmur III/VI (already known previously). Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur without added noise. No lower limb oedema. Radial
column11: femoral and pedial pulses present
column12: bilateral and symmetrical.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram (ECG) on arrival at the MEDU (with pain): sinus rhythm at 85 bpm. PR 150ms. Narrow QRS with axis in the lower left quadrant. ST elevation of up to 3 mm in avR with generalised ST descent of up to 5 mm. Chest X-ray: normal cardiomediastinal silhouette
column13: without images of consolidation or pleural effusion. Urgent transthoracic echocardiogram: left ventricle (LV) neither dilated nor hypertrophied
column14: with moderately depressed systolic function (Simpson 40-45% with study performed with HR 120-130 bpm)
column15: with inferior and lateral hypokinesia at mid and apical levels. Non-dilated right ventricle (RV) with normal TDI. Aortic valve (VAo) apparently tricuspid with hypoplastic non-coronary leaflet and moderate-severe aortic insufficiency with diastolic reverse flow in descending aorta. Mild eccentric mitral insufficiency. No biauricular dilatation. Aortic root
column16: ascending aorta
column17: aortic arch and descending aorta of normal size. Doubtful image in the arch. No IT signal detected to estimate pulmonary artery pressure. Absence of pericardial effusion. CT of the aorta: no signs of aortic dissection
column18: penetrating ulcer or intramural haematoma. No pericardial or pleural effusion. Cardiomegaly. No signs suggestive of pulmonary thromboembolism in pulmonary
column19: lobar or segmental arteries. Bilateral diffuse septal thickening suggestive of interstitial oedema. No pulmonary nodules or masses. Air trapping in the apical segment of the left lower lobe (LII). Small area of subpleural ground glass in LII. No mediastinal
column20: hilar or axillary adenopathy. Laboratory tests: Myocardial damage marker curve: ultrasensitive troponin T (TnT us) 480 ----- (4 h) 499. Normal values < 14 pg/ml. N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) 2050 pg/ml. Rest of biochemistry
column21: haemogram and coagulation anodine.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION After the introduction of perfused nitrates
column22: symptomatology was controlled
column23: the patient remained asymptomatic and the generalised decrease in the ST segment normalised. Given the electrical changes
column24: signs of systolic dysfunction in the urgent echocardiogram and elevated markers of myocardial damage
column25: admission to the coronary unit was decided with a diagnosis of non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI)
column26: and double antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) was initiated (acetylsalicylic acid [ASA] + clopidogrel) and antiplatelet treatment with subcutaneous fondaparinux 2.5 mg. 14 hours after admission
column27: early coronary angiography was performed
column28: showing a conical aortic root morphology that made catheterisation of the left coronary trunk (LMCA) impossible due to the recurrent drop in pressure
column29: which was visualised indirectly
column30: with an image of impingement at its origin. The ostium of the right coronary artery (RCA) also appears to be compromised. After performing the diagnostic coronary angiography
column31: the case was discussed again with radiology who
column33: commented that there was a striking deformity of the circumference of the aortic root
column34: with areas of flattening in the medial wall (forming a conical morphology and thickening of the lateral wall. Both findings may correspond to an intramural haematoma in the aortic root. Absence of visualisation of the outflow ostium of both coronary arteries. The diagnostic study was completed by transesophageal echocardiography
column35: which showed a retraction of the non-coronary leaflet with a regurgitation jet originating at its junction with the right coronary artery
column36: leading to valvular insufficiency that was classified as severe. With this information
column37: the case was discussed with the cardiac surgery department
column38: and the patient was left pending surgical revascularisation. In the following 12 hours
column39: the patient continued to present episodes of precordial pain with dynamic electrical changes
column40: similar to those described previously
column41: which were controlled with antianginal drugs
column42: with markers of myocardial damage on the rise (maximum TnT us of 6000)
column43: and she was scheduled for coronary revascularisation surgery 24 hours after her consultation in the emergency department. The surgical report highlights "a severely thickened aortic root wall
column44: which appears to be aortitis. A small ulcer in the wall of the aorta (Ao) is also identified. Trivalve AoA
column45: with thickened leaflets and non-coronary leaflet collapse
column46: which would justify the picture of severe aortic insufficiency (AIo). Coronary ostia with complete occlusion of ACDp and subtotal occlusion of the LMCA. Healthy coronary arteries". With all this
column47: aortic valve replacement (AVR) with a 23 mm mechanical valve + double coronary artery bypass (saphenous to ADAp and saphenous to ACDp) was performed
column48: and samples of the aortic root were sent to pathological anatomy. The patient had a favourable postoperative evaluation
column49: with no complications and a control transthoracic echocardiogram with a normofunctioning aortic valve and left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 50%
column50: with no new episodes of precordial pain and was discharged home 7 days after surgery
column51: with early clinical control in cardiology outpatient clinics. A few weeks later
column52: the results of the pathological anatomy showed a chronic inflammatory infiltrate with congestive blood vessels accompanied by haemorrhagic areas suggestive of active aortitis. The excisional biopsy of the valve showed extensive sclerosis and abundant areas of myxoid degeneration
column53: corresponding to scar tissue.  DIAGNOSIS Acute non-infectious aortitis with NSTEMI secondary to involvement of the coronary ostia. Severe aortic insufficiency. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  PERSONAL HISTORY No known drug allergies. No toxic habits. Essential arterial hypertension in treatment with two drugs. Dyslipidaemia. Usual treatment: amlodipine 5 mg (1 tablet per day)
column3: ramipril 5 mg (1 tablet per day)
column4: atorvastatin 40 mg (1 tablet per day).  CURRENT ILLNESS The patient is admitted to the stroke unit for 40 minutes of headache and transient loss of vision in the left half of the visual field. He denies infectious symptoms.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Vital signs: blood pressure 130/72 mmHg. Basal oxygen saturation 98%
column5: temperature 36.8 ̊C. Patient conscious
column6: oriented
column7: alert. Normoperfused
column8: normohydrated. Head and neck: no jugular engorgement
column9: no nuchal rigidity. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column10: no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur
column11: no extra sounds. Lower extremities: pulses present
column12: symmetrical. No oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis. Neurological examination: preserved nomation and repetition. No alterations in cranial nerves. Strength and sensitivity preserved. No dysmetria or dysdiadochokinesias. No presence of meningeal signs.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Blood tests: glucose 84 mg/dl. Creatinine 1.17 mg/dl. Glomerular filtration rate 66.82 ml/min. Sodium 145 mm/l. Potassium 4.0 mm/l. AST 23 U/l. ALT 38 U/l. LDH 214 U/l. Alkaline phosphatase 43 U/l. Haemoglobin 15.8 g/dl. Platelets 245
column13: 000/μl. Leukocytes 7
column14: 800/μl. INR 0.99. HbA1c 5.5%. Antinuclear antibodies (ANA)
column15: Beta-2 glycoprotein (IgM
column16: IgG) cardiolipin (IgM
column17: IgG): negative. HIV (Elisa): negative. Syphilis IgG
column18: IgM: negative. Electrocardiogram: RS
column19: 70 bpm
column20: PR 180 msec
column21: narrow QRS
column22: lateral ST rectification. Chest X-ray: cardiothoracic index within normal. No infiltrate or condensation. No pleural effusion. Multimodal computed tomography (CT): Cranial CT without VSD: No early signs of acute ischaemia. No foci of intra/extra-axial haemorrhage are identified. ASPECTS (10/10). CT-perfusion (image 4): increased times in the right occipital region. Angio-CT: extracranial: supra-aortic trunks permeable
column23: with no evidence of significant stenosis. Intracranial: anterior and posterior circulation permeable. Degree of leptomeningeal collaterality: good (3/3 CS Collateral Score). Brain MRI: small right temporoccipital corticosubcortical ischaemic lesions in subacute phase in the territory of the right posterior cerebral artery
column24: hyperintense in Flair/T2
column25: hypointense in T1 and restricting in diffusion (characteristic of subacute lesions: 5 days). Transthoracic echocardiogram: non-dilated left ventricle with preserved systolic function. Normal right chambers. Atria of normal size. No significant valvulopathy or pericardial effusion. Hypermobile atrial septum. Agitated saline was administered and bubble passage was observed from the first beat
column26: compatible with patent foramen ovale (PFO). Transesophageal echocardiogram: aneurysmal atrial septum. PFO both anatomically and by passage of abundant bubbles from the first heartbeat. Non-dilated left ventricle with preserved function. Normal right chambers. Normal sized atria. No significant valvulopathy or pericardial effusion. Atrial appendage free of thrombus. No significant aortic atheromatosis.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient had a good neurological evolution
column27: with recovery ad integrum of the visual defect. He was discharged and referred to the outpatient cardiology department to assess percutaneous closure of the PFO. After joint assessment by neurology and cardiology
column28: he was scheduled for percutaneous closure of the defect. Under general anaesthesia and under echocardiographic control
column29: the foramen was closed. Access was gained through the right femoral vein. The left atrium is passed through the PFO with an MP catheter and a support guidewire is passed into the left superior pulmonary vein. Occlutech 9 F releasing sheath is advanced and the Occlutech Figulla Flex II 30-27 mm closure device is advanced through the sheath and positioned at the level of the atrial septum. After verification of adequate anchorage on transesophageal echocardiography imaging
column30: the device is successfully released.  DIAGNOSIS Cryptogenic right temporo-occipital ischaemic stroke. PFO. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  PERSONAL HISTORY 76-year-old male. No known drug allergies. Lives alone
column3: independent for basic activities of daily living
column4: no cognitive impairment. Ex-smoker (80 pack-years) and former heavy drinker for 7 years. No known metabolic diseases of interest. Cardiological history: self-limited episode of atrial fibrillation (AF)

column7: acenocoumarol (according to haematology guidelines) and clomethiazole 192 mg/24h.  CURRENT ILLNESS Referred for cardiology consultation following diagnosis of AF on presentation to the emergency department 2 months ago due to dizziness and loss of consciousness lasting a few seconds
column8: with subsequent recovery ad integrum. AF was recorded in the ED and spontaneously reverted to sinus rhythm and treatment was started with acenocoumarol and amiodarone. After 3 weeks of treatment
column9: the patient discontinued amiodarone due to an error in dosage. Currently
column10: he denies dyspnoea
column11: chest pain or palpitations and has not experienced dizziness or syncope.
