Good general condition. Conscious
column12: oriented and cooperative. Eupneic. Thinness and skin pallor. Well perfused. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds
column13: no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur. Abdomen: soft
column14: depressible
column15: not painful on palpation
column16: no masses or megaliths. Lower extremities: no oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis.   COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Laboratory tests: biochemistry: glucose 108 mg/dl. Urea 32 mg/dl. Creatinine 1.11mg/dl. Sodium 142 mmol/l. Potassium 4 mmol/l. Troponin I ultrasensitive < 17ng/l. Haemogram: 13
column17: 550 leucocytes (10
column18: 080 neutrophils). Haemoglobin 16.5 g/dl. 182.000 platelets. Coagulation: PT 92%
column19: fibrinogen 509 mg/dl
column20: D-dimer 380 ng/ml. Electrocardiogram (ECG) in the emergency department: AF with ventricular response at 120 bpm
column21: incomplete right bundle branch block (RBBB)
column22: without repolarisation alterations. ECG in cardiology consultation: sinus rhythm (SR) at 68 bpm
column23: normal PR
column24: RBBB
column25: no repolarisation abnormalities. Chest X-ray: normal cardiothoracic index
column26: no condensation or vascular redistribution. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE): non-dilated left ventricle (DTD 47)

column28: with normal global systolic function (LVEF 65%)

column30: with normal morphology and systolic function (TAPSE 20). Normal mitral filling pattern of impaired relaxation without elevation of filling pressures (E/E ́11). Normal mitral valve. Aortic valve sclerotic

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  PERSONAL HISTORY 50-year-old male. Allergy to streptomycin. No family history of ischaemic heart disease. Toxic habits: smoker 1.5-2 packs a day for 30 years until 1 week before the event. Alcohol consumption: not until the event. Other intoxicants: cannabis use in youth
column3: not for years. Cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF): hypertension (HT) under treatment. Mixed dyslipidaemia. Cardiological history: admission to cardiology from 8/7 to 19/7 for acute myocardial infarction without ST-segment elevation (STEMI). A first catheterisation was performed (8/7/2017) which revealed severe three-vessel coronary artery disease (CAD) with acute obstruction of the cuneiform artery (Cx). Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) was performed with two stents coated in CX with good results. The right coronary artery (RCA) and anterior descending (AD) had significant lesions amenable to percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty (PTCA) in the second stage. Another catheterisation was performed at a second time (18/7/2017) with scheduled PCI with implantation of two coated stents in the DA
column4: DX and another two in the CD with a good final angiographic result. The echocardiogram performed during admission (8/7/17) reports: non-dilated left ventricle (LV) with LVEF 45-50%. Inferolateral hypokinesia. Normal right ventricle (RV). No valvulopathies. Rest normal. From the clinical point of view
column5: no complications during admission. Double antiplatelet therapy was started with ticagrelor
column6: which was later changed to prasugrel (due to possible interaction with antiretrovirals). Good tolerance to angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACE inhibitor) and beta-blocker at medium doses. Other personal history: HIV infection
column7: currently on treatment with undetectable viral load. With proteinuria
column8: hepatic haemangiomas and hypovitaminosis D. No other relevant medical-surgical history. Baseline functional status: Diet: average adherence to Mediterranean diet. Physical activity: before the event
column9: moderate activity during working hours
column10: not in leisure time. Psychosocial profile: he was a baker and deliveryman
column11: he closed his company 2 years ago. He now takes care of his mother. He has two children aged 13 and 15. Previous treatment: adiro 100 mg (every 24 hours)
column12: prasugrel 10 mg (every 24 hours)

column17: height 1.76 m. BMI 25.9 kg/m2. Abdominal circumference 98 cm. ABI 0.97 right and 0.96 left. Rest without findings.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: sinus rhythm at 62 bpm. Normal PR. Narrow QRS with 0o axis and prominent R from V2. Small negative T in V6. Ergospirometry preprogramme (January/18): submaximal stress test limited by hypertensive reaction to peak stress. Completed 11 minutes and 7 seconds of the modified Bruce protocol in ramp reaching a HR of 106 bpm (62% of the MHRF) and a peak VO2 of 16.5 ml/min/kg (52% of the predicted for a person of his characteristics). No clinical or electrical data of ischaemia. Good initial BP progression with excessive elevation at peak effort. Normal submaximal cardiovascular parameters. Limited aerobic capacity due to peripheral cause and hypertensive reaction. Anaerobic threshold at 83 bpm. Respiratory compensation point at 102 bpm. Pre-programme blood tests (16/10/17): glucose 101 mg/dl

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  A 69-year-old man was referred to the outpatient cardiology department for presenting coronary calcifications evidenced in a thoracic CT scan for lung cancer screening. The patient has a history of arterial hypertension (AHT) with good home control
column3: impaired fasting blood glucose (pre-diabetes)
column4: obesity (body mass index [BMI] 33.2 kg/m2)
column5: past smoking with cumulative exposure of 50 pack-years
column6: chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) of the chronic bronchitis type and benign prostatic hypertrophy (BPH). His usual treatment consists of simvastatin 10 mg/day
column7: terazosin 2 mg/day
column8: valsartan/hydrochlorothiazide 320/25 mg/day and omeprazole 20 mg/day. He has no chest pain at rest or on exertion or symptoms suggestive of heart failure. He is completely asymptomatic. During the consultation
column9: he was in good general condition
column10: normal colour and normohydrated. Eupneic at rest. Blood pressure (BP) 125/70 mmHg
column11: heart rate (HR) 65 bpm
column12: SatO2 98% (with room air). Jugular venous pressure normal. Cardiac auscultation is rhythmic with no audible murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation shows preserved vesicular murmur without added sounds. Radial and pedial pulses are palpable
column13: rhythmic and symmetrical. There was no oedema. With the available data
column14: treadmill exercise testing was requested in order to rule out silent myocardial ischaemia.   COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Chest CT scan without contrast: signs of pulmonary emphysema predominantly in the upper lobes. No visible pulmonary masses or nodules. No adenopathy in the mediastinal region. Severe calcification of coronary arteries (visual CAC-DRS: 3). Slight aortic calcification. Chest X-ray (PA and lateral): no alterations in the cardiomediastinal silhouette. No signs of consolidation
column15: masses or pleural effusion. Apparent calcifications in coronary arteries and aorta. Blood tests: glucose 110 mg/dl
column16: creatinine 0.89 mg/dl
column17: estimated GFR by CKD-EPI 87.51 mg/dl
column18: total cholesterol 215 mg/dl
column19: HDL cholesterol 58 mg/dl
column20: LDL cholesterol 149 mg/dl
column21: HbA1c 5.6%
column22: haemogram and coagulation without alterations. Baseline ECG: sinus rhythm at 85 bpm. Normal PR (160 ms). Left axis (HSAI). Narrow QRS
column23: q wave in I and aVL. T wave inversion in aVL. Occasional supraventricular extrasystoles. Ergometry on treadmill: performed according to Bruce protocol and stopped due to physical exhaustion. Maximum effort test (maximum HR 157 bpm
column24: 103% theoretical maximum HR) normal. Well tolerated. Adequate adaptation of heart rate and blood pressure (maximum BP 200/100 mmHg). Normal aerobic functional capacity (exercised for 8 minutes and reached a work level of 10.2 METS)
column25: adequate double product reserve (19
column26: 385). No significant arrhythmias have occurred. No electrocardiographic or clinical signs of inducible ischaemia during the test.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient has remained cardiologically asymptomatic. Given the finding of severe calcification of the coronary arteries by visual score
column27: without clinical angina or evidence of ischaemia in the ergometry
column28: conservative treatment with optimisation of pharmacological treatment was decided upon. The patient was considered at very high risk
column29: so simvastatin 10 mg/day was replaced by rosuvastatin 20 mg/day with a target LDL < 70 mg/dl and acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) 100 mg/day was added to the usual treatment. We insisted on hygienic-dietary measures
column30: BP measurements at home and the need for weight loss
column31: as well as the symptoms for which she should consult. Follow-up with blood tests were scheduled to assess LDL cholesterol and impaired fasting blood glucose levels.  DIAGNOSIS Subclinical coronary atherosclerosis. Severe coronary calcification
column32: asymptomatic. Very high cardiovascular risk: exobtachism. Dyslipidaemia with suboptimal control. Hypertension with good control. Impaired fasting blood glucose. Obesity. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  PERSONAL HISTORY No known drug allergies. No known cardiovascular risk factors. No toxic habits. Depressive syndrome. Admitted in 2016 to another hospital for situational syncope and chest pain. Discharged with a diagnosis of acute myocarditis. Usual treatment: fluoxetine 20 mg every 12 hours.  PRESENT ILLNESS A 32-year-old male with the previously described personal history was brought to the emergency department of our hospital for fainting with loss of consciousness not witnessed
column3: coinciding with defecation
column4: and preceded by dizziness and chest pain that continued after regaining consciousness. The patient defines the chest pain as oppressive
column5: radiating to the throat and without associated vegetative cortex
column6: which has subsided spontaneously. He denies palpitations
column7: no dyspnoea or other associated symptoms. The patient reports that the episode is similar to the one he presented in 2016 and that he had not presented any similar symptoms since then. He denies worsening of functional class and no other symptoms from a cardiological point of view. He regularly practises sport and has not presented any infectious symptoms in previous days.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Stable patient in good general condition. Eupneic at rest
column8: tolerating decubitus. Afebrile and haemodynamically stable. Blood pressure (BP) 115/70 mmHg
column9: heart rate (HR) 58 bpm. No congestive semiology. Cardiorespiratory auscultation with rhythmic tones
column10: no murmurs. Conservative vesicular murmur with no other superimposed noises. Lower limbs without oedema.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram (ECG) on admission: sinus bradycardia at 49 bpm
column11: normal axis
column12: normal PR
column13: narrow QRS with tendency to ST-elevation < 1 mm in inferior aspect
column14: V5-V6. Chest X-ray: CTI in the upper limit of normality. Free costophrenic sinuses. No evidence of pulmonary congestion. No image of pneumothorax
column15: no consolidation. CBC: glucose 77 mg/dl
column16: peak creatinine 1.34 mg/dl (previous normal
column17: at discharge normal)
column18: glucose and ions in normal range. Relative neutrophilia without leukocytosis. Haemoglobin 16.2 g/dl. Platelets 218
column19: 000. Coagulation without alterations. TnTus 55 - 234 - 72.7 - 5.5 ng/l. CPK 127 - 136 - 121 mU/ml. Lipid profile: total cholesterol 169 mg/dl
column20: HDL 47 mg/dl
column21: LDL 105 mg/dl
column22: triglycerides 84 mg/dl. LDL/HDL 2.2. Autoimmunity test negative. Iron metabolism: sideremia 106.4 micrograms/dl
column23: transferrin 253 mg/dl
column24: transferrin saturation index 30%
column25: ferritin 85 micrograms/litre. Transthoracic echocardiography: left atrium of normal dimensions (AP 37 mm
column26: volume 19 ml/m2). Normal mitral valve
column27: with leaflets without organic involvement
column28: no insufficiency. Left ventricle with slightly increased volumes (DTD 56 mm
column29: DTDi 26 mm/m2
column30: VTD 160 ml
column31: VTDi 80 ml/m2
column32: VTS 66 ml). EF 59% without segmental alterations of contractility. Normal myocardial thickness
column33: with 8 mm septum and 8 mm posterior wall. Normal mitral filling pattern with E wave 69 cm/s and A wave 38 cm/s. Septal E" 7 cm/s and lateral E" 15.3 cm/s. Trivalve aortic valve
column34: with anatomically normal leaflets
column35: without insufficiency. Sinuses of Valsalva 36 mm. Right ventricle of normal dimensions and contractility. TAPSE 22 mm
column36: tricuspid S" 12.7 cm/s. Trivial tricuspid insufficiency with Vmax 2m/s. Mild pulmonary insufficiency. Normal inferior vena cava with adequate inspiratory collapse. Systolic pulmonary artery pressure 19 mmHg. No pericardial effusion. Coronary angio-CT: Agastson calcium score of 1 (no identifiable plaques). Coronary angiography from axial slices
column37: multiplanar
column38: curved and 3D reconstructions: left common trunk arising from the left coronary sinus
column39: long
column40: 21 mm long and without significant alterations. It bifurcates into the anterior descending artery (ADA) and circumflex artery (ACx). ADA without angiographically significant lesions
column41: of good development and calibre
column42: giving multiple diagonal branches of small calibre (up to 3 diagonal branches)
column43: all of them without lesions. ACx without angiographically significant alterations
column44: which is of small calibre
column45: but almost at its origin gives an Om1 branch of very good development and calibre
column46: which has a normal proximal trajectory
column47: but its entire middle and distal course follows an intramyocardial route presenting an "intramyocardial bridge of significant length" and which in systolic sections shows a decrease in its calibre and systolic compression phenomenon (coincides with the inferolateral side as it depends on the circumflex artery and the course of an OM artery). Right coronary artery (RCA) arising from the right coronary sinus without angiographically significant alterations. It gives two posterolateral branches
column48: but does not clearly give the posterior descending branch or this is a very small branch. Right dominant pattern. Conclusion: OM1 of very good development and calibre
column49: which has a normal proximal trajectory
column50: but its entire middle and distal trajectory follows an intramyocardial course presenting an "intramyocardial bridge of significant length" and which in systolic sections presents a decrease in its calibre and a phenomenon of systolic compression. The trajectory has been estimated at 7.5-8 cm. The rest of the coronary arteries had no angiographically significant lesions
column51: no anomalies in their trajectory or disposition.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION After documenting in enzyme serology in the emergency department
column52: discrete enzyme mobilisation with ischaemia curve (peak TNT Us: 234 ng/l)
column53: it was decided to admit the patient to cardiology on suspicion of a new episode of myopericarditis given his history. During his admission
column54: the patient evolved favourably
column55: with no further chest pain and no other symptoms. Given that the clinical picture was not characteristic of myopericarditis
column56: due to its characteristics and duration
column57: nor did he present compatible electrical alterations
column58: with alterations on the underside more suggestive of ischaemic aetiology
column59: as well as the behaviour of the cardiac ferment serum
column60: with a very rapid rise and fall
column61: again more characteristic of an ischaemic profile
column62: it was decided to request an intermediate test to detect ischaemia during admission as a screening test for coronary artery disease. A coronary angio-CT scan was performed which revealed the existence of an intramyocardial tract of significant length in the OM1 branch and which in the systolic sections showed a decrease in its calibre and systolic compression phenomenon
column63: with the rest of the coronary arteries being normal. Given the findings
column64: it is considered that the picture of situational vagal syncope with associated hypotension and the presence of the long intramyocardial tract would explain the picture of transient ischaemia that led to admission. The patient also provided the report of the cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) performed in the previous admission in 2016
column65: which described the presence of mild enhancement of predominantly subendocardial enhancement in the inferolateral wall
column66: coinciding with the trajectory and could be explained by this same reason. Given the good evolution
column67: the patient was discharged with acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) 100 mg every 24 hours and amlodipine 5 mg every 12 hours. It is recommended to avoid high intensity exercise
column68: especially isometric exercise (weight lifting). The patient is seen in an outpatient clinic 2 months later and remains asymptomatic.  DIAGNOSIS Myocardial infarction with coronary arteries without obstructive lesions (MINOCA) secondary to significant intramyocardial trajectory of the obtuse marginal artery with systolic compression column2: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION We present the case of a 45-year-old man with an active life
column3: currently asymptomatic
column4: who came to the echocardiography department of our hospital for transesophageal monitoring after percutaneous closure of the left atrial appendage with an Amulet device (St Jude Medical) due to repeated strokes despite having been under anticoagulant treatment.  PERSONAL HISTORY Cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF): hypertension. Dyslipidaemia. Smoker of 7-8 cigarettes a day (10.5 packs a year) Cardiological history: Permanent atrial fibrillation diagnosed in December 2001 (2 unsuccessful attempts at CVE in 2002 after which frequency control strategy was chosen). Transthoracic echocardiography: left ventricle of normal diameters and volumes
column5: with preserved global systolic function (LVEF 58%). Very dilated left atrium (volume 4c 154 ml). Transmitral filling with single E wave. Absence of significant valvular heart disease. Right ventricle with preserved diameters and global systolic function. Absence of tricuspid insufficiency (TI) allowing estimation of pulmonary arterial systolic pressure (PsAP). Percutaneous closure of the left atrial appendage with Amulet device (St. Jude Medical) in 2018: In 2016
column6: the patient presented with a stroke with a cardioembolic profile under treatment with acenocoumarol anticoagulation with poor INR control
column7: so acenocoumarol was discontinued and rivaroxaban was started. Under treatment with rivaroxaban 20 mg/24 hours correctly adjusted to his renal function
column8: he suffered a new cardioembolic stroke in 2017
column9: so it was decided to close his left atrial appendage. In 2018
column10: percutaneous closure of the left atrial appendage was performed with an Amulet device (St. Jude Medical) without complications. On discharge
column11: following the recommendations of the commercial company
column12: double antiplatelet therapy was started with aspirin 100 mg and clopidogrel 75 mg. Although
column13: according to the guidelines
column14: the patient had an indication for anticoagulant treatment due to the risk of stroke
column15: this was rejected because he had experienced minor bleeding episodes during treatment with rivaroxaban. Other medical history: Repeated cardioembolic stroke (2016 and 2017) expressed as TIA
column16: despite anticoagulation. The first of these was located in the left occipital lobe
column17: confirmed by imaging techniques. The second was in the left carotid profile and was not confirmed by imaging techniques. Clinical criteria of chronic bronchitis without respiratory functional tests Surgical interventions: gastric bypass. Supraumbilical hernia. Current treatment: Foli-Doce 1 (tablet per day)
column18: olmesartan + HCT 40/25 mg
column19: atenolol 50 mg (1 tablet per day)
column20: atorvastatin 20 mg (1 tablet per day)
column21: acetylsalicylic acid 100 mg (1 tablet per day).  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Good general condition
column22: conscious
column23: oriented
column24: normohydrated and normal colour. Blood pressure (BP) 132/76 mmHg
column25: heart rate (HR) 67 bpm
column26: SatO2 94% (FiO2 21%). Cardiac auscultation: irregular sounds without murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: slight global hypophonesis
column27: with scattered rhonchi. Soft abdomen with no masses or megaliths
column28: not painful on palpation. Lower extremities without oedema. Peripheral pulses present and symmetrical.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Laboratory tests: Blood count: haemoglobin 15.1 g/dL. MCV 84 fl. MCH 30.7 pg. Leukocytes 5.8x10*9/l. Platelets 316x10*9/l. Biochemistry: glucose 83 mg/dl. HbA1c 5.8%. Sodium 138 mEq/l. Potassium 4.3 mEq/l. Chlorine 104 mEq/l. Bilirubin 0.46 mg/dl. GOT 16 U/l. GPT 14 U/l. Alkaline phosphatase 77 U/l. Gamma-glutamyl transferase 13 U/l. Creatinine 0.96 mg/dl (GFR CKD-EPI > 90 ml/min/1.73 m2). Iron metabolism: transferrin 249 mg/dl. Ferritin 26 ug/l. Iron 60 ug/l
column29: IST 17.8%. Lipid metabolism: total cholesterol 150 mg/dl. Triglycerides 64 mg/dl. HDLc 34 mg/dl. LDLc 126 mg/dl. Haemostasis: prothrombin time 12 s
column30: IQ 84%. INR 1.03. APTT 27.3 s. Electrocardiogram (ECG): atrial fibrillation with MVR at 67 bpm. Axis 15o. QRS 90 ms. non-significant Q wave and negative T in dIII. Flattened T in avF. No other repolarisation alterations. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) (2D and 3D) 5 months after implantation of atrial appendage closure device: marked left atrial dilatation (volume 4c 175 ml) with presence of spontaneous echocontrast. An image suggestive of a small protruding thrombus is seen on the disc of the normally positioned atrial appendage closure device. Left ventricle with increased diameters and normal global systolic function (LVEF 60%). Absence of significant valvular heart disease. Right ventricle with normal diameters and preserved function. Absence of IT allowing estimation of PsAP. Exploration in atrial fibrillation.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION Taking into account that the patient was an asymptomatic 45-year-old man who
column31: although he had correctly completed the double antiplatelet therapy prescribed according to the recommendations of the device manufacturer
column32: without anticoagulant treatment by the patient's own decision
column33: a thrombosis of the Amulet device (St Jude Medical) for closure of the left atrial appendage was detected in the control TEE. It was decided to restart anticoagulant treatment with acenocoumarol with INR targets (2-3). Three months later a new follow-up TEE was performed and the thrombus had resolved. However
column34: despite the resolution of the condition
column35: it was decided to maintain oral anticoagulation with acenocoumarol (INR 2-3) and to perform a new echocardiographic control in 12 months
column36: in order to assess the definitive withdrawal of anticoagulant treatment. At present
column37: 8 months have passed and the patient remains asymptomatic
column38: without haemorrhagic or thrombotic complications
column39: under treatment with acenocoumarol and awaiting a repeat transesophageal echocardiography control.  DIAGNOSIS Permanent atrial fibrillation with controlled ventricular response. CHA2DS2VAS-c 3
column40: HASBLED 2. Two strokes with cardioembolic profile despite anticoagulation with acenocoumarol or rivaroxaban (left atrial appendage preclosure). Left atrial appendage closure with Amulet device (St Jude Medical). Thrombosis on left atrial appendage closure device
column41: resolved with oral anticoagulation with acenocoumarol. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  PERSONAL HISTORY Intolerance to acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) due to duodenal ulcer. CVRF: smoking (20 pack-years). No known cardiological history. Other history: duodenal ulcer 10 years ago. No relevant surgical interventions. Usual treatment: not reported.  CURRENT ILLNESS A 57-year-old male patient with the aforementioned history attended the emergency department of our centre due to oppressive central thoracic pain
column3: of about 30 minutes' evolution
column4: radiating to both upper limbs (MMSS) and neck
column5: which started suddenly while at rest
column6: with associated mild vegetative cramping. On arrival at the emergency department
column7: the clinical manifestations persisted. She denied previous episodes of central thoracic pain. She reported an active daily life. No clinical signs of CHF or infectious disease in previous days.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Blood pressure (BP) 140/60 mmHg (left arm)
column8: 90/50 mmHg (right arm)
column9: heart rate (HR) 65 bpm. SpO2 (FiO2 21%) 99%. Regular general condition
column10: affected by severe pain. Eupneic at rest. Normal colour and normohydrated. Sweating. Patient conscious and oriented
column11: cooperative and alert. No neurological focality. Cardiopulmonary auscultation: regular sounds
column12: diastolic murmur predominantly in the left sternal border. Conservative vesicular murmur (VCM) with no added noise. Abdomen: soft and depressible
column13: without mass or megaliths
column14: not painful on palpation. MMSS: asymmetric radial pulses. Lower limbs: weak and symmetrical distal pulses.   COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG on arrival at the ED: sinus rhythm at 95 bpm
column15: PR 170 ms
column16: narrow QRS
column17: 0o axis
column18: LVH criteria. No changes in serial ECG. Initial laboratory tests: CBC: red blood cells *4
column19: 62 10*12/l. Haemoglobin 14.3 g/dl. Haematocrit 42.9%. VCM 92.9 fl. HCM 30.9 pg. CHCM 33.3 g/l. ADE 13.1%. Leukocytes 8.6 10*9/l. Neutrophils 54.6%. Lymphocytes 32
column20: 2%. Platelets 198 10*9/l. Haemostasis: prothrombin time (PT) 11 sec. Quick's index 100%
column21: INR 0.95. APTT 28.7 sec. Biochemistry: glucose *103 mg/dl. Sodium 139 mEq/l. Potassium 4.3 mEq/l. Chlorine 103 mEq/l. Urea 34.2 mg/dl. Creatinine 0.86 mg/dl. Biomarkers of myocardial damage: troponin I (hsTnI) 3
column22: 2 ng/l. Urgent echocardiogram (TTE) in critical care unit (no images available): left ventricle with slight concentric hypertrophy
column23: normal diameters and preserved systolic function
column24: with no alterations in segmental contractility at rest. Significant aortic insufficiency
column25: without other valvulopathies. Right ventricle of normal size and function. Aortic root with increased diameters (45 mm)
column26: without a clear flap image. Normal inferior vena cava (IVC). Mild pericardial effusion. Angio-CT of the aorta: type A aortic dissection with involvement of the aortic root extending along the anterior aspect of the aortic wall close to the left coronary trunk (LMCA) from the valvular plane to the origin of the inferior mesenteric artery with involvement of the proximal origin of the ASD. Dilatation of aortic root and tubular portion of ascending aorta (47 mm). Descending aorta 37 mm. Descending aorta 31 mm. At the level of the thoraco-abdominal aorta
column27: the true lumen has a reduced calibre. The celiac
column28: superior mesenteric and right renal trunks originate from the true lumen. The left renal arises from a gateway between the true lumen and the false lumen with good renal perfusion. Distal aorta and normal iliofemoral sector. Conclusion: type A dissection extending from the aortic root to the aortic segment proximal to the inferior mesenteric origin.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION In a patient with intense oppressive chest pain
column29: without significant ECG alterations suggestive of ischaemia
column30: it was decided to perform an urgent TTE
column31: which revealed aortic root dilatation with significant insufficiency. In view of these findings
column32: it was decided to request an angio-CT scan
column33: which confirmed the diagnosis of type A aortic dissection. With the results of the complementary examinations and the diagnosis
column34: the cardiac surgery department was contacted and emergency surgery was performed using the mechanical Bono-Bentall technique (Carboseal 29 mm) (consisting of aortic valve replacement
column35: aortic root and ascending aorta replacement
column36: as well as coronary ostium reimplantation in the same surgical procedure)
column37: under extracorporeal circulation
column38: electromechanical heart arrest and circulatory arrest with selective bicarotídeal cerebral perfusion. No replacement of the aortic arch or descending aorta was performed
column39: given the critical condition of the patient
column40: the complexity of the intervention and the improvement after elimination of the main tear and reinstatement of true lumen flow. Evolution in ICU: prolonged stay to 8 days after emergent Bentall surgery. Early extubation at 12 h post IQ without incident. At 48 hours the patient developed global respiratory failure oriented as postoperative acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) by congruent radiography with image of scattered infiltrates in both lung fields with heterogeneous distribution. Influenza A negative PCR. He required high-flow nasal spectacles
column41: with progressive improvement. On the other hand
column42: acute renal failure resolved. Haemodynamically
column43: the patient remained stable from the immediate postoperative period
column44: with no signs of active bleeding and no transfusion requirements. Good evolution in the cardiac surgery room
column45: with discharge home on 7/3/19.  DIAGNOSIS Type A acute aortic dissection. Emergent surgery with metallic Bono-Bentall. Smoking. Arterial hypertension. Acute respiratory failure due to ARDS. Resolved prerenal renal failure. |O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  PERSONAL HISTORY Male
column3: 43 years old
column4: regular moderate-high intensity sportsman. No drug allergies. No toxic habits or cardiovascular risk factors. No previous cardiological history. Migraine with aura studied in 2015 with brain MRI without pathological findings and asymptomatic since then. No surgical interventions or chronic treatments.  CURRENT ILLNESS A 43-year-old male presented with sudden loss of consciousness while performing moderate-intensity physical exercise (running)
column5: with no previous clinical manifestations. The witnesses who accompanied him reported having observed him fall to the ground with no response to stimuli and with no spontaneous breathing and no palpable pulse
column6: so they started basic cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) manoeuvres and called the emergency services. On arrival of the medical team
column7: ventricular fibrillation was detected. A single effective shock was administered
column8: achieving sinus rhythm with a pulse. He was immediately transferred to the reference centre sedated and anaesthetised
column9: with orotracheal intubation on mechanical ventilation and haemodynamically stable without amines.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Anthropometric data: weight 74 kg
column10: height 1.82m. Body mass index (BMI) 22.3 kg/m2. Vital signs: blood pressure (BP) 104/82 mmHg. Heart rate (HR) 62 bpm. O2 saturation (SatO2) 98% with FiO2 at 21%. Cardiovascular: jugular venous pressure normal. Hepatojugular reflex negative. Cardiac auscultation: regular
column11: no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur. No aggregates. Abdomen: flat. Hydro-aerial sounds present. Soft
column12: depressible. No visceromegaly. Neurological: isochoric pupils. Pupillary reflexes preserved. Motor reflexes in extremities without alterations (II/IV). Extremities: no oedema. Peripheral pulses preserved and symmetrical.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus rhythm at 93 bpm. PR 120 ms. QRS 60 ms. QTc 398ms. No repolarisation alterations. Admission blood tests: haemoglobin 16 g/dl
column13: haematocrit 47.5%
column14: platelets 223
column16: leukocytes 7
column17: 400 /μl. International normalised ratio (INR) 1.05. Basal glycaemia 82 mg/dl. Urea 36 mg/dl. Creatinine 0.81 mg/dl. Sodium 137 mEq/l. Potassium 4.1 mEq/l. Myocardial damage markers: troponin I US: 0.0 ng/ml. Chest X-ray: centred cardiomediastinal silhouette. CTI less than 0.5. Lung fields without condensation or pleural effusion. Transthoracic echocardiogram: left ventricle with preserved diameters
column18: volumes and global systolic function (LVEF 65%). Absence of alterations in segmental contractility at rest. Normal transmitral filling pattern. Absence of significant valvulopathies. Normal left atrium. Normal right ventricle. Absence of tricuspid insufficiency (TI) allowing estimation of pulmonary artery systolic pressure (PAPs) without data suggestive of pulmonary hypertension (PHT). Normal inferior vena cava (IVC). Exploration in sinus rhythm. Coronary angiography: epicardial coronary arteries without atheromatosis. Anomalous origin of the left coronary throne (LCT) in the right sinus of Valsalva
column19: high and anterior
column20: opposite to the origin of the right coronary artery (RCA) which is filled during the administration of contrast in the cannulation of the LCT. Possible interarterial tract of the LMCA. Coronary CT angiography: trivalve aortic valve with preserved diameters. The presence of an LMCA with origin in the right sinus of Valsalva and interarterial trajectory (between the pulmonary trunk and the aorta) is confirmed. Descending artery with evidence of large diagonal without significant lesions. Circumflex artery without lesions. Origin of the right coronary artery in the right sinus of Valsalva without lesions. Conclusion: origin of the left coronary artery in the right sinus of Valsalva with interarterial trajectory. Post-surgical ergometry: maximal test stopped at 13:33 minutes of the Bruce protocol (14.5 METS) due to physical exhaustion. No angina or ST segment alterations that meet the criteria for positivity in relation to the baseline electrocardiogram. No arrhythmias. Adequate blood pressure and chronotropic response. Good functional capacity. Post-surgical stress echocardiogram: cycloergometer stress test. Maximum test reaching 103% of the maximum theoretical heart rate. Performs a total of 15 minutes 26 seconds of exercise
column21: corresponding to 1 minute 27 seconds of stage 8 of the WHO protocol (200 watts). No alterations in segmental contractility were observed at rest or on exertion
column22: with no electrical changes or chest pain.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION Young man with cardiorespiratory arrest recovered in ventricular fibrillation during moderate exertion
column23: presenting post-CRP electrocardiogram in sinus rhythm
column24: without repolarisation alterations and with normal QTc interval. An emergent echocardiogram showed no abnormalities with normal LVEF
column25: no indirect signs of massive pulmonary thromboembolism (PTE)
column26: no aortic flap and no pericardial effusion. The emergency chest X-ray ruled out pneumothorax. Arterial blood gas analysis showed hyperlactacidemia with other parameters and normal haemoglobin levels. Emergent brain computed tomography (CT) without haemorrhagic or acute ischaemic event. Given the normality of the initial aetiological studies
column27: it was decided to perform an emergent coronary angiography where epicardial arteries were found without angiographic lesions with anomalous origin of the left main coronary artery (LMCA) in the right sinus of Valsalva with a possible interarterial trajectory. Admitted to the coronary unit
column28: haemodynamically stable without the need for amines
column29: in sinus rhythm without arrhythmic events and allowing progress in weaning with early extubation in the first 48 hours with no neurological deficit. Studies were completed with CT of the coronary arteries which confirmed the anomalous origin of the LMCA in the right sinus of Valsalva with interarterial trajectory. During his admission to the coronary unit he remained asymptomatic and haemodynamically stable. The case was discussed in a medical-surgical session and it was decided to perform surgery with double bypass implantation: right mammary artery to obtuse marginal artery and left mammary artery to anterior descending artery with a favourable postoperative period with no incidents. The patient remained asymptomatic in subsequent outpatient check-ups. Ergometry and stress echocardiography were performed
column30: both tests being maximal and negative for ischaemia.  DIAGNOSIS Cardiorespiratory arrest during physical exercise in ventricular fibrillation. Anomalous origin of the left coronary trunk from the right sinus of Valsalva with interarterial trajectory. Surgical revascularisation with double bypass. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION A 71-year-old woman
column3: with no toxic habits or cardiovascular risk factors and with a personal history of aortic sclerosis
column4: hypertensive heart disease
column5: recurrent paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia and renal lithiasis
column6: attended the emergency department for oppressive central thoracic pain
column7: not radiating or associated with vegetative cortex
column8: which did not change with palpation
column9: deep inspiration or movement
column10: lasting about 3 hours. He denied orthopnoea
column11: paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea
column12: palpitations
column13: dyspnoea at rest/exertion
column14: malleolar oedema or reduced diuresis. He had not made any dietary transgressions or modified his usual medication. As a point of interest
column15: she commented that she had gone to the dentist hours earlier having undergone a root canal. On arrival at the emergency department the patient was stable
column16: normotensive (124/74 mmHg)
column17: with heart rate (78 bpm) and oxygen saturation (98% baseline) normal. Afebrile. Conscious and oriented
column18: good general condition
column19: eupneic at rest
column20: normohydrated
column21: normo-coloured and normoperfused. Carotid pulses were rhythmic and symmetrical and we did not detect jugular ingurgitation. Cardiopulmonary auscultation was rhythmic and without murmurs
column22: with subcrepitant rales from middle and lower lung fields. Abdominal examination revealed a soft and depressible abdomen
column23: no pain on superficial or deep palpation
column24: no masses or megaliths
column25: generalised tympanism
column26: no peritonism and positive hydro-aerial sounds. The lower extremities showed no malleolar oedema; pedial and posterior tibial pulses were present and symmetrical
column27: with no stigmata of venous insufficiency or deep vein thrombosis. No skin rash was observed.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Blood analysis: haemoglobin 12.9 g/dl
column28: hcto 38.7%
column29: MCH 26 pg
column30: MCV 78.2 fl
column31: leukocytes 13300/microlitre
column33: normal biochemistry
column34: CPK 1127 IU/l peak (30 - 200 IU/l)
column35: CK-MB 119.11 ng/ml peak (< 6 ng/ml) and troponin-I 29.130 ng/ml peak (< 0.06)
column36: normal renal function
column37: normal ions and normal coagulation. Anteroposterior chest X-ray (portable): preserved cardiothoracic index
column38: vascular redistribution with bilateral bronchovascular enhancement and bilateral and diffuse interstitial infiltrates Electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm at 60 bpm
column39: PR 180 msec
column40: narrow QRS
column41: QRS axis at 30o
column42: ST-segment elevation in II
column43: III
column44: AVF
column45: V3-V6. QTc 394 msec. Catheterisation: right dominance. Right coronary artery of good calibre and development
column46: without lesions. Anterior descending artery of good calibre
column47: with very distal thrombotic occlusion
column48: this being a very long vessel
column49: which appears to go around the apex. Circumflex artery of intermediate calibre and good development
column50: without lesions. Transthoracic echocardiogram: left ventricle neither dilated nor hypertrophied
column51: with apical akinesia
column52: diastolic pattern of impaired relaxation and preserved systolic function (LVEF 55% by Simpson biplane). Right and left atrium of normal size. Right ventricle neither dilated nor hypertrophied
column53: with normal systolic function (TAPSE >18 mm). Mitral valve of normal morphology
column54: with good opening and no regurgitant jets. Aortic valve of trivalve morphology
column55: with restriction of its opening in the range of moderate stenosis (GP 53 mmHg) and regurgitant jet that conditioned mild aortic insufficiency (AIo)
column56: without apparent dilatation of the aortic root. Morphologically normal tricuspid valve
column57: with good opening and mild insufficiency
column58: did not allow adequate estimation of pulmonary artery systolic pressure (PSAP) (although there were no indirect signs of pulmonary hypertension [PHT]). Pericardium of normal thickness and refractoriness
column59: without effusion
column60: and non-dilated inferior vena cava
column61: with collapse > 50% with inspiration Cardio-MRI with gadolinium: apical anteroseptal akinesia with subendocardial uptake greater than 50% at the apical and strict apical anteroseptal level
column62: and less than 50% in the basal anterolateral region. Rest of the study without alterations.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION A loading dose of double antiplatelet therapy was administered and antianginal medical treatment was started. Given the persistence of the clinical and electrocardiographic findings
column63: an urgent catheterisation was performed
column64: which showed thrombotic occlusion of the anterior descending artery at a very distal level
column65: this being a very long vessel
column66: which probably went around the apex. Ventriculography showed anterior-apical and inferior-apical hypokinesia. Neither thromboaspiration nor coronary angioplasty was performed due to the distal location of the thrombus and he was treated with double antiplatelet therapy and anticoagulation. He was then transferred to the coronary unit
column67: where enzymatic and electrocardiographic serialisation was completed. A transthoracic echocardiogram showed a non-dilated and non-hypertrophied left ventricle with septoapical akinesia
column68: diastolic pattern of impaired relaxation and preserved systolic function (LVEF 55% by Simpson biplane). Right and left atrium of normal size. Right ventricle neither dilated nor hypertrophied
column69: with normal systolic function (TAPSE > 18 mm). Mitral valve of normal morphology
column70: with good opening and no regurgitant jets. Aortic valve of trivalve morphology
column71: with restriction of its opening in the range of moderate stenosis (GP 53 mmHg) and regurgitant jet that conditioned mild AoI
column72: without apparent dilatation of the aortic root. Morphologically normal tricuspid valve
column73: with good opening and mild insufficiency
column74: did not allow adequate estimation of PSAP (although there were no indirect signs of PHT). Pericardium of normal thickness and refractoriness
column75: without effusion
column76: and non-dilated inferior vena cava
column77: with collapse > 50% with inspiration. During his stay in the unit he remained cardiologically stable
column78: with blood pressure figures with a tendency to hypotension and afebrile. She did not present new episodes of angina at rest/light exertion
column79: palpitations or dyspnoea. Given the clinical and haemodynamic stability
column80: the patient was discharged to the cardiology ward. Prior to discharge
column81: the patient provided the report of the dental extraction performed a few hours before the onset of the symptoms
column82: in a private centre
column83: which included the use of a local anaesthetic consisting of lidocaine 2% (36 mg) + epinephrine (0.0225 mg). Subsequently
column84: cardiac magnetic resonance imaging with gadolinium was performed
column85: which revealed apical anteroseptal akinesia with subendocardial uptake greater than 50% at the apical and strict apical anteroseptal level
column86: and less than 50% in the basal anterolateral region
column87: all compatible with acute myocardial infarction (AMI) as a first possibility. Thus
column88: the patient was discharged with hygienic-dietary recommendations
column89: double antiplatelet therapy
column90: beta-blockers
column91: angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors) and statins. One year later
column93: with no alterations in segmental contractility by echocardiography.  DIAGNOSIS Acute ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) apical Killip I. Thrombotic occlusion of the very distal anterior descending artery (AD). Rest of the coronary tree without lesions. Apical akinesia. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  PERSONAL HISTORY The patient is a 52-year-old female active smoker with chronic non-revascularised ischaemic heart disease and preserved ventricular function. She made her debut in October 2018 as a non-ST-elevation Killip I acute myocardial infarction
column3: diagnosed by coronary angiography as spontaneous coronary artery dissection with haematoma image in the posterior interventricular branch. She progressed favourably with medical treatment and was discharged without complications after 72 hours of hospitalisation. She had no family history of early sudden death or cardiovascular disease. She is being treated with acetylsalicylic acid 100 mg at lunch
column4: bisoprolol 2.5 mg at breakfast
column5: atorvastatin 40 mg at dinner and omeprazole 20 mg at breakfast.  CURRENT ILLNESS Consultation in November 2018 for sudden syncope while standing upright
column6: with spontaneous recovery and no periepisodic symptoms (palpitations
column7: dizziness
column8: sweating
column9: nausea
column10: etc.). She denied recurrent angina in the previous days
column11: changes in medication or other intercurrent events (infections
column12: etc.) that could have acted as triggers. On arrival at the emergency department
column13: telemetry monitoring was started pending the results of the complementary tests and assessment by the on-call cardiologist. In the meantime
column14: he presented with polymorphic ventricular tachycardia that rapidly degenerated into ventricular fibrillation. ROSC (return of spontaneous circulation) after single electrical cardioversion (ECV) and iv amiodarone embolisation. Subsequently
column15: she presented with a new rhythm of ventricular fibrillation (VF) with ROSC after two ECV. She remained asymptomatic and was admitted to the acute cardiac care unit (ACCU) for monitoring. With no new arrhythmic events or heart failure since admission
column16: she was transferred to the hospital ward.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Blood pressure (BP) 165/80 mmHg
column17: heart rate (HR) 85 bpm. Good general appearance. Capillary refill < 2 seconds
column18: no sweating. Eupneic in decubitus. No jugular ingurgitation. Rhythmic cardiac auscultation without murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation with preserved vesicular murmur
column19: without added sounds. No oedema in the lower limbs or signs of deep vein thrombosis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram (ECG) on admission: sinus rhythm at 80 bpm with normopositioned narrow QRS and adequate progression in precordial leads. Small non-significant q wave in III and aVF. No repolarisation alterations. ECG on discharge: no relevant changes. Urgent blood tests on arrival: haemoglobin 14 g/dl (volumes and indices within normal ranges)
column20: platelets 275000/ul
column21: leukocytes 9520/ul with normal formula. INR 1.02
column22: APTT 27.2 sec. Glucose 99 mg/dl. Uric acid 4.8 mg/dl. ALT 28 U/l. GGT 34 U/l. Alkaline phosphatase 110 U/l. Creatinine 0.57 mg/dl (estimated glomerular filtration rate > 60 ml/min/1.73 m2)
column23: sodium 144 mmol/l
column24: potassium 4.1 mmol/l
column25: C-reactive protein 1.7 mg/dl. Peak myocardial damage markers on serialisation: ultrasensitive troponin I 392 ng/l (normal < 15.6)
column26: CK 186 U/l (normal < 192). Blood tests with profiles: glycosylated haemoglobin 6.3%
column27: TSH 1.55 mIU/l
column28: total cholesterol 125 mg/dl
column29: LDL cholesterol 51 mg/dl
column30: HDL cholesterol 47 mg/dl
column31: triglycerides 134 mg/dl. Transthoracic echocardiogram: biventricular function preserved without valvulopathy or cavity dilatation. Akinesia of the middle and distal segments of the inferior face and hypokinesia of the middle and distal segments of the inferolateral face. Cardiac MRI with contrast: non-dilated left ventricle
column32: with normal thickness. Focal dyskinesia of the mediodistal segment of the inferior face. Akinesia of the inferior distal segment and inferolateral segment respecting the strictly apical segment. Rest of segmental contraction without alterations. Normal global systolic function (LVEF 55%). T2-STIR sequences show a very localised hyperintense transmural area in the distal segment of the inferior face with subendocardial extension towards the apex. Perfusion in first subendocardial perfusion defect affecting the distal thirds of the inferior septum
column33: inferior and inferolateral aspect. T2 MAPs at septal level: 49 ms (within normal limits)
column34: at distal lateral level: 72 ms (value above normal
column35: suggestive of acute inflammation) T1 MAPs native septal value: 1013 +/- 30 ms (within normal limits). Late enhancement: an area of enhancement compatible with an ischaemic eschar occupying approximately 70% of the myocardial thickness is observed in the distal segment of the inferior and inferolateral face respecting the apex. Minimal subendocardial focus in the distal lateral aspect. Right ventricle neither dilated nor hypertrophic. No alterations of segmental contraction. Normal systolic function. No late enhancement foci. Left and right atrium of normal size. Mitral valve with thin leaflets
column36: normal opening. Trivalve aortic valve
column37: functionally normal. Sinus aorta not dilated. Coronary angiography: short left main coronary artery
column38: without lesions. Anterior descending artery of good development and calibre
column39: without lesions. Circumflex artery of good development and calibre
column40: without lesions. Right coronary artery: vessel of good development and calibre
column41: with an image suggestive of haematoma in the posterior interventricular branch
column42: with a vessel distal to the lesion of small calibre and short course. Study superimposed on the one performed 10 days earlier.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient evolved favourably
column43: with no new arrhythmic events after transfer to the hospital ward. Beta-blockers were prescribed up to the maximum tolerated dose
column44: as well as other antihypertensive drugs. Coronary angiography showed persistence of haematoma in PVI and only discrete acute myocardial damage in the context of ventricular arrhythmias and resuscitation. Therefore
column45: ruling out the existence of new dissections
column46: progression of the previous one or other potential triggers of ventricular fibrillation
column47: it was decided to implant a subcutaneous ICD for secondary prevention in a patient with ischaemic heart disease with preserved ventricular function and recovered sudden death. After this
column48: the patient was discharged  DIAGNOSIS In-hospital cardiac arrest recovered in ventricular fibrillation. Chronic ischaemic heart disease: inferior infarction. Spontaneous PVI coronary artery dissection. Preserved systolic ventricular function. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Patient aged 15 years. Correct vaccination schedule
column3: with no relevant history at birth
column4: during the neonatal period or in childhood. His father reported that he had a "benign murmur" at cardiac level
column5: discharged without further check-ups. Personal history of streptococcal pharyngitis and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Absence of usual treatment. He came to the emergency department after finding elevated blood pressure: 210/90 mmHg
column6: asymptomatic
column7: taken at home with a blood pressure monitor. Given the patient's age and the suspicion of secondary hypertension
column8: nephrological assessment was requested. Following blood and urine tests with no findings and a normal abdominal ultrasound scan
column9: we requested an assessment by us. His grandfather
column10: who was undergoing treatment for hypertension
column11: measured his blood pressure (BP) daily. As an entertainment
column12: imitating his grandfather
column13: he started to use his blood pressure monitor
column14: with a very different result to the expected... He tells us that in the last two weeks he has been taking daily BP readings
column15: with average BPs of 160-170 mmHg. Today
column16: on finding a higher figure than usual
column17: he decided to go to the emergency room. Asymptomatic
column18: no neurological or cardiovascular symptoms. Physical examination showed good general condition
column19: correct growth and development. Normal features. BP after initiation of short half-life antihypertensive drugs 159/92 mmHg. Heart rate 80 bpm
column20: no audible murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation normal ventilation
column21: interscapular systolic murmur. Radial pulses present and symmetrical. Femoral and pedial pulses decreased. BP measurement in both arms and legs with the following result: ESD 155/85 mmHg
column22: ESI 142/81 mmHg
column23: EID 105/65 mmHg
column24: EII 105/70 mmHg.  S ECG: sinus rhythm at 65 bpm. Revisema a Narrow QRS
column25: normal axis around 70o. LV hypertrophy criteria: Sokolow-Lyon 39 mm. No relevant repolarisation alterations. Chest X-ray: Roesler's notches and 3's sign with absence of aortic button. Echocardiogram: non-dilated left ventricle (LV)
column26: moderate concentric LV hypertrophy (12 mm). Preserved systolic function (EF 68%)
column27: without alterations of segmental wall contractility. Normal diastolic pattern. Right ventricle of normal size
column28: preserved function (TAPSE 22 mm). Atria of normal size. Mitral valve: thin leaflets
column29: preserved opening kinetics. No reflux. Mild TR. PAPS 33 mmHg. Bicuspid type I aortic valve (VAo) with fusion of right coronary leaflet and left coronary leaflet. Preserved opening kinetics
column30: mild central regurgitation jet. Aortic root
column31: visualised ascending aorta and aortic arch of normal size (29 mm). Coarctation of the aorta after left subclavian outflow with a diameter of 4 mm
column32: peak systolic gradient of 63 mmHg and significant diastolic prolongation. Distal aortic arch 13 mm. Continuous abdominal aortic Doppler with peak systolic at 0.86 m/s. Decreased protomesosystolic flow in left femoral artery without protodiastolic inversion. Inferior vena cava not dilated
column33: with preserved inspiratory collapse. No pericardial effusion. Chest CT angiography: aortic coarctation with severe compromise of the aortic lumen (minimum diameter in the coarctation 5 mm). Presence of abundant collateral circulation through internal mammary
column34: intercostal and posterior scapular arteries. Bicuspid aortic valve.  MIX DUB After initial suspicion based on anamnesis and physical examination findings
column35: an echocardiogram was performed
column36: confirming the presumptive diagnosis: coarctation of the aorta and secondary hypertension. He was admitted to the cardiology ward for blood pressure control and to complete the study. Thoracic CT angiography was performed to assess management. He was assessed by the congenital heart unit of our hospital
column37: with controlled BP
column38: and was discharged from hospital pending percutaneous intervention. Treatment on discharge: olmesartan-amlodipine 40/5 mg
column39: bisoprolol 2.5 mg
column40: eplerenone 25 mg.  DIAGNOSIS Coarctation of the aorta. Secondary arterial hypertension. Bicuspid aortic valve without dysfunction. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  PERSONAL HISTORY Patient aged 49 years
column3: no known drug allergies
column4: Romanian nationality. No known family history. Personal history of: Cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF): ex-smoker since 2014
column5: dyslipidaemic with poor control with statins and overweight. Chronic ischaemic heart disease: acute myocardial infarction (AMI) q inferior in March 2014
column6: fibrinolised with reperfusion criteria. Epistenocardial pericarditis during admission. Coronary angiography 2014: 2-vessel coronary artery disease. Severe right coronary artery (RCA) (artery responsible for AMI): implantation of two drug-eluting stents proximally and distally. Descending anterior descending (DA) with moderate stenosis
column7: no action taken. Echocardiogram at discharge: preserved LVEF
column8: with basal inferior and inferior septal hypokinesia. Isotope stress test at one month after discharge with inferior necrosis. LVEF 47% and the rest of the segments without evidence of ischaemia or contractility alterations. At discharge on treatment with acetylsalicylic acid 100 mg/24 hours
column9: clopidogrel 75 mg/24 hours
column10: bisoprolol 5 mg/24 hours and atorvastatin 80 mg/24 hours.  CURRENT ILLNESS Since discharge he has been monitored in cardiology consultations. He was asymptomatic
column11: in class I
column12: with no recurrence of chest pain or evidence of inducible ischaemia in an isotope stress test performed one month later. He was started on a low-dose angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACE inhibitor)
column13: which he had not tolerated during admission due to hypotension
column14: and clopidogrel was withdrawn after one year without incident. However
column15: from the time of admission
column16: LDL cholesterol levels > 180 mg/dL despite switching to a high-dose high-potency statin (atorvastatin) and elevated levels of lipoprotein A
column17: apoB and homocystinuria were striking. In 2016
column18: he reported myalgias and laboratory tests showed elevated CPK and mild AST and insufficient LDL control
column19: so atorvastatin was replaced by rosuvastatin 20 mg/day and ezetimibe was added. The patient stopped coming for check-ups
column20: until 2018
column21: when he was again referred to our clinic for analytical abnormalities in lipid metabolism. According to the patient
column22: he continues to be asymptomatic from a cardiovascular point of view
column23: reporting only mild myalgias. He is taking medication correctly
column24: including the two lipid-lowering drugs. At this consultation it was decided to study the patient further.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION At consultation in 2018: Blood pressure (BP) 115/60 mmHg
column25: heart rate (HR) 60 bpm. Baseline SpO2 97%. No jugular venous engorgement. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic sounds without murmurs or extratonos. Pulmonary auscultation: normal. Abdomen: nondescript. Lower extremities: no oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram (ECG) (AMI 2014): sinus rhythm at 66 bpm
column26: normal PR
column27: narrow QRS
column28: normal axis
column29: up to 1.5 mm ST supradelevation in inferior face
column30: V5-V6 with specular image in I
column31: and AVL. ECG in consultation 2018: sinus rhythm at 56 bpm
column33: narrow QRS
column34: lower qR with negative asymmetric T wave in II
column35: III
column36: AVF
column37: and flattened in I
column38: AVL
column39: V5-V6
column40: unchanged from ECG of previous consultation in 2015. Normal QTc. Coronary angiography 2014: 2-vessel coronary artery disease: CD: severe stenosis due to complicated plaque extending from the end of the proximal segment (responsible for AMI). Significant stenosis in the mid-distal segment: percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty (PTCA) + implantation of two non-overlapping drug-eluting stents proximally and distally. AD: moderate stenosis in medial proximal segment
column41: uncomplicated
column42: assessed by intravascular echocardiography (IVUS). Echocardiogram at discharge 2014: left ventricle neither dilated nor hypertrophied (LVEDDVI 56 mm
column43: IVUS 10 mm
column44: PP 10 mm) with preserved systolic function (LVEF 54%) and inferior septal and basal inferior segment hypokinesia. Mild mitral and aortic regurgitation. Minimal pericardial effusion of 3 mm in posterior sac. Blood tests in AMI 2014: haemogram: Hb 14.2 g/dl; Hct 43.1%; leukocytes 10.9 mil/mm3; platelets 241 mil/mm3. Biochemistry: basal glucose 96 mg/dl; creatinine 0.91 mg/dl; total cholesterol 234 mg/dl; triglycerides 102 mg/dl; HDL-C 30 mg/dl; LDL-C 183.6 mg/dl; APO-B 148 mg/dl. Lipoprotein A 49.4mg/dl
column45: basal homocysteine 16.34 micromol/l
column47: AST 24 U/l; ALT 31 U/l; GGT 54 U/l. Maximal myocardial necrosis markers: TnI > 97 ng/ml (0-0.04); CPK 4443 U/l (39-308)
column48: CK-MB 510 U/l (5-24). Isotope stress test (one month after discharge): inferior necrosis. LVEF 47%. Rest of segments without evidence of ischaemia or contractility alterations. Blood tests at consultation in January 2016: haemogram: normal. Biochemistry: basal glucose 117 mg/dl; creatinine 1.05 mg/dl; total cholesterol 261 mg/dl; triglycerides 117 mg/dl; HDL-C 47 mg/dl; LDL-C 190.6 mg/dl
column50: CPK 507 U/l (39-308). Blood tests in consultation
column51: September 2018: total cholesterol 196 mg/dl; triglycerides 67 mg/dl; HDL-C 42 mg/dl; LDL-C 145 mg/dl
column52: AST 28 U/l (0-37); CPK 305 U/l (39-308). Genetic study of familial hypercholesterolemia: positive. Heterozygosis of the variant c.2478del
column53: p.(Val827Serfs*102)
column54: of the LDLR gene
column55: classified as pathogenic with respect to familial hypercholesterolemia. Heterozygosis: rs4149056 polymorphism in the SLCO1B1 gene and rs17244841 of the HMGCR gene. Homozygosis: rs2032582 polymorphism of the ABCB1 gene. Blood tests at consultation after starting iPCSK9 in April 2019: total cholesterol 120 mg/dl; triglycerides 99 mg/dl; HDL-C 49 mg/dl; LDL-C 58 mg/dl.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION This is a smoker
column56: sedentary
column57: obese and dyslipidaemic patient on treatment with simvastatin with LDL who debuted in 2014 with a lower AMI. On admission
column58: LDL levels > 180 mg/dl were found despite a change to a high-dose high-potency statin since the event. In the first consultations after the coronary event
column59: the patient had not presented chest pain again
column60: and isotope exercise stress test showed no inducible ischaemia in the anterior descending artery territory
column61: so percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) was not performed on this lesion. On anamnesis
column62: he reported weakness and myalgia in the extremities
column63: in addition to a discrete elevation of AST and CPK
column64: for which reason intolerance to atorvastatin was assumed
column65: so it was replaced by rosuvastatin 20 mg/day and ezetimibe was added to optimise LDL control. In 2016
column66: he stopped coming for check-ups
column67: until 2018
column68: when he was again referred to our offices for analytical alterations in lipid metabolism. According to him
column69: he remains asymptomatic from a cardiovascular point of view. He was taking medication correctly
column70: including the two lipid-lowering drugs
column71: but his LDL levels were still around 150 mg/dl. At this consultation
column72: it was decided to further study the patient and request genetic testing for familial hypercholesterolaemia
column73: which was positive. For this reason
column74: treatment was finally started with a PCSK9 inhibitor
column75: evolocumab at a dose of 140 mg every 2 weeks
column76: achieving a greater than 50% decrease with respect to the previous LDL figures with combined treatment.  DIAGNOSIS Chronic ischaemic heart disease: AMI Q lower Killip I in 2014 2-vessel coronary artery disease (DC [responsible] and LAD): effective fibrinolysis and subsequent PCI with implantation of two drug-eluting stents in DC. Absence of inducible ischaemia in the LAD territory. Preserved LVEF. Familial hypercholesterolemia in heterozygosis. CURRENT ILLNESS We present the case of a 60-year-old male patient with the previously described history who was referred to the outpatient cardiology department for a casual finding of calcification in the three coronary arteries in the thoraco-abdomino-pelvic CT scan performed for staging of prostate adenocarcinoma. The patient denies clinical chest pain on exertion
column13: although he occasionally presents chest discomfort related to anxiety. Melaj heavyestion procur S an merc Consus Escar Toristió fuck a  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION The patient was found to be in good general condition
column14: normal colour
column15: normohydrated
column16: eupneic at rest
column17: conscious
column18: oriented and cooperative
column19: with no signs of neurological focality. The constants recorded in the consultation room were normal: blood pressure (BP) 124/82 mmHg
column20: heart rate (HR) 75 bpm
column21: SaO2 98% (ambient air)
column22: afebrile. Cardiac auscultation was rhythmic with no murmurs and pulmonary auscultation showed preserved vesicular murmur with no added sounds. There are no congestive signs on examination and the radial pulses are palpable
column23: rhythmic and symmetrical.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS CBC (April 2018): Glucose 97 mg/dl. Glycated haemoglobin (HbA1c) 5.1%. Renal function preserved (creatinine 0.74 mg/dl) with electrolytes in range. Oliveariento haun sostenysety P haiento their emphascre a Lipid profile: triglycerides 81 mg/dl
column24: cholesterol 177 mg/dl
column25: HDL cholesterol 54 mg/dl
column26: LDL cholesterol 107 mg/dl. Prostate markers: PSA 7.57 ng/ml
column27: free PSA (FPSA) 1.51 ng/ml
column28: free PSA/total PSA ratio 0.20. Dutch distintaathunice paratividad their emphascre a No'etbiernos their Six t specific londo a Normal PR. M Christive porocusoem a Narrow QRS with left superoanterior hemiblock morphology (HSAI). Emphasajcre P laaldzanture a Chest X-ray PA + lateral: cardiomediastinal silhouette without alterations. Hilar thickening of vascular origin. No signs of consolidation or pleural effusion. Thoracic-abdominal-pelvic CT with IV contrast: no evidence of distant disease
column29: but calcified coronary atheromatosis of the three vessels and mild aortic valve calcification. Transthoracic echocardiography: left ventricle of normal diameters
column30: with slight concentric hypertrophy (IVT 11 mm
column31: PP 11 mm) and with good systolic function (LVEF 60%)
column32: without alterations in segmental contractility. Non-dilated right ventricle with good systolic function (TAPSE 20 mm). Type I diastolic dysfunction (impaired relaxation). E/e' 4. Left atrium slightly dilated (41 mm). Aortic root not dilated. Trivalve aortic valve with normal gradient and no insufficiency. Normal appearing mitral valve with minimal insufficiency. Absence of tricuspid insufficiency that would allow estimation of PAPS. Conclusion: mild hypertensive heart disease with good biventricular systolic function. Electrocardiographic stress test: maximal stress test (104% of predicted FCM) performed with Bruce protocol on treadmill
column33: stopped due to physical exhaustion. Abnormal for maximum ST-segment depression of 1.5 mm horizontal in 5 leads (II
column34: III
column35: aVF and V5-V6) in the recovery phase that normalises after 5 minutes
column36: without clinical chest pain. Adequate chronotropic response and adaptation of BP to effort. Good functional capacity: reaches 11.2 METS
column37: exercise time of 9 min 35 sec. No arrhythmias detected during the test. Duke Treadmill score: 1.5 (intermediate risk). Coronary angiography: left main coronary artery (LMCA): no significant irregularities. Anterior descending artery (ADA): severe stenosis in proximal and middle segment
column38: and significant stenosis in distal middle segment. First diagonal of good calibre with early bifurcation and severe stenosis in proximal segment with distal vessel of intermediate calibre. Circumflex artery (ACx): Non-dominant
column39: without significant lesions. Right coronary artery (RCA): dominant
column40: highly developed
column41: without lesions. Percutaneous coronary intervention with drug-eluting balloon angioplasty on the first diagonal and implantation of two overlapping stents (BioFreedom) in the proximal and middle RCA
column42: recommending 6 months of dual antiplatelet therapy
column43: although with the possibility of suspending it one month after the procedure. Blood tests (May 2019): Glucose 99 mg/dl. Renal function preserved (creatinine 0.87 mg/dl) with electrolytes in range. Urine sediment and urine electrolytes without alterations. Lipid profile: triglycerides 55 mg/dl
column44: cholesterol 93 mg/dl
column45: HDL cholesterol 48 mg/dl
column46: LDL cholesterol 34 mg/dl. Transaminases and cholestasis enzymes in range. CPK not elevated (139 U/l). Haemogram and coagulation without alterations.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION After discussing the different diagnostic and therapeutic options with the patient
column47: it was decided on the first visit to request an echocardiography
column48: paying special attention to ventricular function
column49: and an electrocardiographic stress test for diagnostic (to assess the presence of silent ischaemia) and prognostic purposes. It was also decided at that time to add to the treatment acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) 100 mg/day
column50: atorvastatin 40 mg/day (the patient is considered to have established cardiovascular disease due to the presence of coronary calcification and therefore his LDL target is less than 70 mg/dl)
column51: bisoprolol 5 mg/day (initially at half dose
column52: instructing to start depending on the heart rate at home) and omeprazole 20 mg/day. Echocardiography showed preserved left ventricular function (LVEF 60%) with no alterations in segmental contractility. On the other hand
column53: in the stress test the patient presented electrocardiogram (ECG) changes suggestive of myocardial ischaemia
column54: although at high load
column55: without clinical chest pain and reaching 11.2 METS
column56: so it is considered a low-risk exercise test with a good prognosis. After reviewing the information provided by the complementary tests and again discussing the management options with the patient
column57: it was decided
column58: due to the presence of coronary calcification and the ischaemia data in the treadmill test
column59: to request a coronary angiography
column60: with special emphasis on the need for surgery in the short-medium term due to prostate adenocarcinoma
column61: with respect to the need for percutaneous revascularisation and subsequent double antiplatelet therapy. Coronary angiography showed severe stenosis in the proximal and middle LAD and in the first diagonal branch
column62: treated with implantation of two overlapping drug-eluting stents in the proximal and middle LAD and drug-eluting balloon angioplasty in the diagonal branch. Biofreedom stents were selected
column63: allowing
column64: if deemed necessary
column65: interruption of the double antiplatelet therapy one month after implantation
column66: to allow
column67: in this case
column68: to perform the surgery required by the prostatic pathology without increasing either the risk of stent thrombosis or bleeding in the perioperative period. Treatment was therefore started with clopidogrel 75 mg/day. The patient's subsequent evolution has been good. There were no complications arising from the procedure and he has remained asymptomatic from the cardiological point of view. He has an excellent control of cardiovascular risk factors after treatment adjustment
column69: being within the LDL targets (which went from 107 to 34 mg/dl). He is currently awaiting the end of a month of double antiplatelet therapy with ASA + clopidogrel
column70: and then only simple antiplatelet therapy with ASA and radical prostatectomy.   DIAGNOSIS Asymptomatic coronary artery disease with evidence of silent ischaemia. Single vessel disease: severe stenosis in proximal and middle LAD and first diagonal branch. Percutaneous revascularisation: drug-eluting balloon angioplasty in diagonal branch and implantation of two drug-eluting stents. BioFreedom in proximal and mid LAD. Dyslipidaemia. Arterial hypertension.
