column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  PERSONAL HISTORY No known drug allergies. Active smoker of 20 cigarettes/day (cumulative consumption of 20 packs/year). Cardiovascular risk factors: hypertension (HT) and dyslipidaemia. No type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM2). Anxiety-depressive syndrome. Surgical intervention: left inguinal hernia and appendicitis. Family history of ischaemic heart disease in his father at 78 years of age. Usual treatment: losartan 50 mg (1 tablet every 24 hours)
column3: simvastatin 40 mg (1 tablet every 24 hours).  CURRENT DISEASE The patient is a 47-year-old man
column4: with the previously described personal history
column5: who one summer morning
column6: while working in his field
column7: presented with an episode of central thoracic pain
column8: with oppressive characteristics
column9: radiating to the throat
column10: accompanied by cold sweating and nausea without vomiting. There were no symptoms of dyspnoea or palpitations. The patient leads an active life. He had never before presented episodes similar to the one that prompted the consultation. No intercurrent infectious conditions or fever. No clinical signs of heart failure. He was attended by the emergency services who found the patient haemodynamically stable with blood pressure (BP) 135/85 mmHG
column11: heart rate (HR) 84 bpm
column12: conscious
column13: oriented and cooperative. An ECG was performed on arrival documenting ST-segment elevation of 2 mm in the inferior aspect and V6
column14: and the patient was transferred urgently to our hospital. The pain subsided during the transfer with sublingual nitroglycerine. On arrival at the emergency department of our hospital
column15: the patient was asymptomatic from the cardiovascular point of view. A new ECG was performed showing normalisation of the electrical changes (no ST segment elevation). The patient was monitored and on-call cardiology was contacted for urgent assessment. Given that the patient remained clinically and haemodynamically stable
column16: with no changes suggestive of ischaemia on the electrocardiogram and with normal bedside echocardioscopy (Vscan)
column17: it was decided not to activate the infarction code
column18: and the patient was classified as non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (NSTEACS) due to transient ST-segment elevation.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION When assessed by cardiology
column19: the patient was asymptomatic from the cardiovascular point of view
column20: with no new episodes of chest pain or any other anginal symptoms. Haemodynamically stable with BP 125/76 mmHg
column21: HR 79 bpm. Eupneic at rest and speech
column22: without supplementary oxygen therapy. Tolerating decubitus at 0 ̊. Afebrile. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic tones
column23: no audible murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur
column24: without added pathological sounds. Lower limbs: no oedema
column25: no signs of deep vein thrombosis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG with pain: sinus rhythm at 80 bpm
column26: normal axis
column27: PR 120 ms
column28: narrow QRS with ST segment elevation of maximum 2 mm in inferior face and V6; 1 mm ST decrease in V1 and aVR with negative T waves in these leads. Chest X-ray: normal cardiothoracic index. Free costophrenic sinuses. No evidence of pulmonary congestion. No evidence of pneumothorax or consolidation. CBC: glucose 125 mg/dl
column29: creatinine 1.05 mg/dl
column30: ions in normal range. No leukocytosis. Haemoglobin 14.2 g/dl. Platelets 235
column31: 000. Coagulation without alterations (INR 1.02). Myocardial damage markers: TnTus 135 - 580 - 420 - 289 ng/l. CPK 320 - 450 - 177 - 102 mU/ml. Lipid profile: total cholesterol 233 mg/dl
column33: LDL 166 mg/dl
column34: triglycerides 156 mg/dl. Glycated haemoglobin 5.1% Bedside echocardioscopy: left ventricle not appearing dilated
column35: with normal qualitative systolic function (55-60%)
column36: without segmental alterations of contractility. Right ventricle with normal qualitative systolic function. Aortic root not dilated (sinuses of Valsalva 36 mm)
column37: no flap image visualised. Inferior vena cava not dilated
column38: respiratory variations. No pericardial effusion. No valvulopathies of entity are visualized. Echocardiography: left atrium of normal dimensions (AP 37 mm
column39: volume 19 ml/m2). Normal mitral valve
column40: with leaflets without organic involvement or insufficiency. Left ventricle with normal volumes (DTD 49 mm
column41: VTD 125 ml
column42: VTDi 70 ml/m2
column43: VTS 55 ml). EF 59% without segmental alterations of contractility. Normal myocardial thickness
column44: with 8 mm septum and 8 mm posterior wall. Normal mitral filling pattern with E wave 78 cm/s and A wave 45 cm/s. Trivalve aortic valve
column45: with anatomically normal leaflets
column46: without insufficiency. Sine of Valsalva 36 mm. Right ventricle of normal dimensions and contractility. TAPSE 22 mm
column47: tricuspid S" 12.7 cm/s. Tricuspid valve without insufficiency. Pulmonary valve with slight central jet. Normal inferior vena cava with adequate inspiratory collapse. No pericardial effusion. No indirect evidence of pulmonary hypertension (PH). Coronary angiography: right radial artery. Ectatic right coronary artery (RCA) with severe stenosis (90%) in its middle segment treated by implantation of a direct drug-eluting stent (Synergy 4 x 38 mm) and post-dilatation with non-compliant balloon (4.5 x 20 mm). Mild atheromatosis of the anterior descending artery (ADA) and circumflex artery (ACx).  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was admitted to the cardiology intermediate care unit. During his stay in the unit
column48: his evolution was favourable; he remained haemodynamically stable at all times
column49: with no new episodes of chest pain or electrical changes. Continuous monitoring did not detect any arrhythmic events. Coronary angiography was performed 36 hours after admission to the unit
column50: revealing a significant lesion in the middle segment of the RCA
column51: which was revascularised by implanting a drug-eluting stent and post-dilatation with a balloon. The procedure passed without complications. Medical treatment was adjusted during admission
column52: insisting on secondary prevention measures for ischaemic heart disease and
column53: above all
column54: smoking cessation. On discharge he was referred to the cardiac rehabilitation unit
column55: with the following treatment: acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) 100 mg (1 tablet every 24 hours)
column56: ticagrelor 90 mg (1 tablet every 12 hours)
column57: atorvastatin 80 mg (1 tablet every 24 hours)
column58: losartan 50 mg (1 tablet every 24 hours)
column59: bisoprolol 5 mg (1 tablet every 24 hours)
column60: omeprazole 20 mg (1 tablet every 24 hours)
column61: sublingual nitroglycerin if chest pain.  DIAGNOSIS NSTEACS type transient ST-elevation secondary to severe mid RCA lesion revascularised by 1 drug-eluting stent. Preserved ventricular function. Hypertension and dyslipidaemia. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  PERSONAL HISTORY Independent in basic and instrumental activities of daily living. Active life. Works in the countryside. Toxic habits: active smoker of 1 pack a day (20 cigarettes/day) since the age of 17. No history of hypertension
column3: diabetes or dyslipidaemia. No history of cardiovascular disease. Other medical history: chronic pharyngitis
column4: herniated disc at C5-C6 and C7-D1. No previous surgical interventions. No medical treatment at present.  CURRENT ILLNESS She initially consulted the emergency department of our hospital for symptoms consisting of diffuse abdominal pain
column5: persistent nausea and vomiting despite home treatment. As associated symptomatology
column6: she reported a non-thermometric dysthermic sensation of months of evolution together with associated diaphoresis
column7: predominantly at night. The complementary tests performed were suggestive of acute pancreatitis (increased amylase in blood and urine)
column8: so a CT scan of the abdomen with contrast showed findings compatible with mild pancreatitis. At the same time
column9: the images obtained at the lower thoracic level showed a hypodense image with well-defined borders located in the left atrium dependent on the interatrial septum compatible with an intracardiac mass
column10: and atrial myxoma was considered the first possibility. Based on these findings
column11: the patient was assessed by cardiology
column12: who decided to admit the patient to our care to continue the study.   PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Blood pressure (BP) 163/95. Heart rate (HR) 60 beats per minute. Baseline O2 saturation 98% by pulse oximetry. Acceptable general condition. Conscious
column13: oriented and cooperative. Haemodynamically stable. Eupneic at rest. Normal skin colour and no lesions
column14: with increased body temperature (temperature 38 ̊C). No palpable lymph nodes in the cervical
column15: axillary
column16: inguinal or other areas. No jugular venous engorgement. Cardiac auscultation with rhythmic tones at a good frequency with no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation with preserved vesicular murmur. Abdomen soft and depressible
column17: with pain on palpation in the epigastrium and both hypochondrium. Purphy negative. Hydro-aerial sounds were preserved on abdominal auscultation. No masses or visceromegaly palpable. Lower limbs without malleolar oedema. Pulses preserved and symmetrical.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Precios bill' Pun a Haemogram: red blood cells 4

Leucocytes: -: -. Alpha amylase: 1109. Chest X-ray: poorly inspired. Enlargement of the bronchovascular tract. No increase in cardiac silhouette
column20: with normal cardiothoracic index. Electrocardiogram (ECG) on admission: sinus rhythm at 68 beats per minute. No pathological increase in voltage or P wave duration. 160 msec PR interval. Narrow QRS of 80 msec duration
column21: with axis at -30o
column22: with morphology of incomplete right bundle branch block. No pathological alterations of repolarisation were observed. QTc of 404 msec. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis: slight enlargement of the pancreatic head and uncinate process with infiltration of the adjacent fat
column23: without evidence of collections
column24: suggestive of mild acute pancreatitis. Hepatic steatosis
column25: with several simple cysts. Aliased gallbladder
column26: without intrahepatic or extrahepatic bile duct dilatation. Spleen without pathological alterations. No intra-abdominal free fluid is seen. Hypodense mass inside the left atrium of about 4 cm. This lesion has well-defined borders
column27: spherical morphology
column28: with a calcific point inside and a pedicle that depends on the interatrial septum. The mass prolapses towards the left ventricle
column29: as can be seen in successive slices. Transthoracic echocardiography: left ventricle neither dilated nor hypertrophic (LVED 50 mm; IVS 10 mm; PP 10 mm) with preserved global systolic function (LVEF 59% by Simpson). No segmental alterations of contractility were observed. Aortic root not dilated. Trivalve aortic valve with mild degenerative involvement. Dilated left atrium (volume 81 cm3)
column30: showing a pedunculated mass with well-defined borders anchored at the level of the fossa ovalis
column31: measuring 50 x 26 mm
column32: which prolapses towards the ventricle in diastole
column33: dragging the anterior mitral leaflet. These findings suggest left atrial myxoma as the first diagnostic option. Non-dilated right chambers
column34: with a normofunctioning right ventricle (TAPSE 25 mm). Doppler study with normal transmitral flows (Vel. E 1.09 m/s; Vel A 0.9 m/s)
column35: without pathological increase in pressure gradients (mean gradient 3 mmHg). Mitral insufficiency grade II with jet projected towards the lateral wall of the left atrium. Aortic valve with normal antegrade flows (max. velocity 1.15 m/s)
column36: with no evidence of valvular insufficiency. Coronary angiography: left dominance
column37: without lesions in coronary arteries. Pathological anatomy of the resected mass: nodular formation of 26 g and 4.5 x 4 x 3 cm in size. Smooth
column38: shiny and brownish surface. Serial sections show a heterogeneous surface with blackish and other irregular whitish areas
column39: including some cystic areas histologically compatible with atrial myxoma with large areas of haemorrhage and thrombosis.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION When atrial myxoma was suspected in the CT scan
column40: studies were completed with transthoracic echocardiography and coronary angiography. With the presumptive diagnosis of left atrial myxoma
column41: the case was discussed with cardiovascular surgery
column42: who advised deferring surgery until the pancreatic symptoms were controlled. During the first few days of admission
column43: the patient remained stable from a clinical and haemodynamic point of view. There was a progressive improvement in the abdominal symptoms
column44: which allowed for the reintroduction of an oral diet
column45: without incident. A new abdominal CT scan was performed
column46: which ruled out late complications derived from the pancreatic symptoms. In view of the evolutionary course
column47: surgery was performed on the 14th day of admission. Opening was performed by conventional median sternotomy and
column48: accessing through the right atriotomy
column49: the left atrial mass was resected along with its pedicle
column50: closing the residual septal defect by direct suture. Pathological anatomy confirms the diagnosis of atrial myxoma
column51: with extensive areas of haemorrhage and thrombosis. The evolution after surgery was long and torpid. His stay in the post-surgical unit was marked by the appearance of supraventricular tachycardia at 130 bpm compatible with atrial flutter
column52: with recurrent behaviour despite several attempts at electrical cardioversion
column53: some of which caused the tachyarrhythmia to temporarily degenerate into atrial fibrillation. Rhythm control was attempted with antiarrhythmic treatment (amiodarone)
column54: but had to be discontinued due to the appearance of complete atrioventricular block. Optimal ventricular rate control is also not achieved by adding beta-blockers to the treatment. Given that the ventricular response to the arrhythmia was well tolerated by the patient
column55: it was decided to discharge the patient to the cardiology ward to optimise treatment. The situation was discussed with the arrhythmology department and an electrophysiological study was scheduled
column56: which revealed counterclockwise atrial flutter
column57: and successful ablation of the cavotricuspid isthmus was performed. After completing the procedure
column58: together with the cessation of the arrhythmia
column59: loss of sinus leakage above 40 bpm was observed. This situation required the placement of a transient pacing device and the implantation of a permanent pacemaker (DDDR) was programmed. After implantation
column60: the patient evolved satisfactorily and was discharged a few days after implantation.  DIAGNOSIS Left atrial myxoma. Mild acute pancreatitis (RANSON 0). Counterclockwise isthmic atrial flutter with successful ablation. Transient atrial fibrillation in immediate postoperative period CHA2DS2-VASc 1; HAS-BLED 1. Sinus dysfunction with need for DDDR permanent pacemaker implantation
column61: in sinus rhythm at discharge. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION We present the case of a 4-year-old female patient
column3: under follow-up by her paediatrician
column4: who was found to have a systolic murmur at the last check-up. She had no relevant history (normal vaginal delivery) and no incidents in previous examinations. The parents were asked about unusual signs/symptoms in recent months. Although there was no limitation in terms of exercise ("she plays in the park with the other children")
column5: in the last few months they noticed that she was more tired. They also report that "when she runs she sometimes stops because of coughing fits". No sweating and/or noticeable tachypnoea in the context of meals. Adequate nutrition
column6: with a good natural weight curve. Good night's rest. No dizziness or loss of consciousness. No complaints of chest pain. Inquiries were made about a history of heart disease in the family
column7: which the parents denied. At the consultation
column8: the child was in an acceptable general state. Skin and mucous membranes were well coloured
column9: weight and height P75. Weight and height in P75. Blood pressure 90/60 mmHg
column10: with no differences between members of the family. Saturation of 100% without oxygen therapy. On auscultation
column11: systolic murmur III/VI predominantly in mitral focus with irradiation to the axilla. No crackles or other noises added to the pulmonary auscultation. Abdomen soft and depressible
column12: without hepatomegaly or hepatalgia. Lower limbs with good distal perfusion and preserved and symmetrical pulses. The patient was referred to the local cardiology department.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Laboratory tests: renal function preserved (creatinine 0.6 mg/dl) with ions in range. Liver profile without alterations. NT-proBNP 600 pg/l. CBC 98. Haemogram anodyne
column13: with white and red series and platelets in range. Coagulation without findings. Chest X-ray: increased cardiothoracic index. SCF free. No condensation or any other noticeable congestion. Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus rhythm at 100 bpm. Normal axis. Normal PR. Narrow QRS with anterolateral Q wave. ST elevation in precordial leads. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE): situs solitus. Atrioventricular (AV) concordance. Normal venous drainage. Inferior vena cava (IVC) not dilated with adequate respiratory variations. No effusion. Dilated left atrium (LA). Dilated left ventricle (LV) with systolic function at lower limits (LVEF by Simpson and Teich of 50%). Moderate-severe mitral insufficiency (MI) with anterior leaflet prolapse. Hyperechogenic anterior subvalvular apparatus
column14: suggestive of fibrosis. Trivalve aortic valve with good opening and no aortic insufficiency (AIo). The large vessel view shows dilatation of the ostium of the right coronary artery (RCA)
column15: with a proximal course of the artery of good calibre. The LMCA ostium is absent
column16: with proximal fine calibre/hypoplastic anterior descending artery (ADA) and circumflex artery (ACx). Retrograde flow in left branches by colour Doppler. No communication with the pulmonary artery is visualised. Right ventricle (RV) not dilated with preserved systolic function. Trivial tricuspid insufficiency (TI) jet with no entity gradient to estimate pulmonary pressures. Angiographic study: procedure performed under general anaesthesia. Right femoral access. Contrast injection is performed and anterograde filling of the RCA is observed
column17: which is dominant. The left coronary tree is not filled at first. Late and retrograde filling of the left tree
column18: from collateral branches provided by the right tree. ACx and ADA converge proximally in a blind cul-de-sac
column19: with no connection to the IVC
column20: which is absent. Conclusion: diagnosis of congenital atresia of the LMCA.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was assessed in cardiology
column21: where the anamnesis was similar to that carried out in her health centre. An ECG was initially performed which was clearly pathological (see complementary tests). Transthoracic echocardiography showed
column22: as the most significant finding
column23: mitral regurgitation of entity by colour Doppler. The fibrosis of the subvalvular apparatus is striking. The left ventricle is dilated but systolic function is preserved. A search for the origin of the coronary arteries was performed in the ECP (large vessel plane)
column24: and the origin of the dilated RCA was found
column25: without visualising the origin of the LMCA. Given these findings
column26: the patient was referred to a tertiary referral hospital. Aortography was scheduled by the haemodynamics team and the procedure was performed under general anaesthesia. On injecting the contrast agent
column27: the ACD was found to be filled in an anterograde manner
column28: with an initial absence of filling of the left aortic tree. Late retrograde filling of left branches from the RCA
column29: which provides collateral circulation. Poor tolerance to the procedure
column30: with arterial hypotension and bradycardia requiring vasoactive/inothropic support. Urgent echocardiography showed acute left ventricular dysfunction
column31: requiring mechanical circulatory support. Haemodynamic and echocardiographic improvement in the first 30 minutes
column32: with subsequent transfer to the intensive care unit (ICU) for close monitoring and stabilisation. The patient remained in the ICU for 15 days with progressive clinical improvement. After stabilisation
column33: the patient was proposed and accepted for revascularisation surgery. A coronary CT scan was requested beforehand for better pre-surgical characterisation of the anatomy.  DIAGNOSIS Congenital atresia of the left main coronary artery. Severe ischaemic mitral regurgitation in this context. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  PERSONAL HISTORY No known drug allergies. No toxic habits. Cardiovascular risk factors: regularly controlled hypertension. No known dyslipidaemia or diabetes. Overweight. No medical or surgical history of interest. Usual treatment: losartan 50 mg/hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg 1 tablet every 24 hours.  CURRENT ILLNESS A 53-year-old man with hypertension of approximately two years of evolution with poor control at home
column3: who consulted the emergency department for clinical pain described as shooting/oppressive in the interscapular region radiating towards the anterior region of the thorax and internal face of the left upper limb on moderate/high intensity exertion
column4: gradually subsiding with rest
column5: for the last 2 weeks. He also reported a slight sensation of dyspnoea
column6: without palpitations or vegetative cortex
column7: and denied previous similar episodes. After performing complementary tests in the emergency department (detailed below)
column8: it was decided to monitor her for the first 24 hours in the observation area
column9: with no new events.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Good general condition. Conscious and oriented. Collaborative. Well hydrated and perfused. Afebrile. Haemodynamically stable with blood pressure 132/87 mmHg (on arrival at the ED 200/112 mmHg) and heart rate 70 bpm. Eupneic at rest and when speaking
column10: tolerating full decubitus and with no need for supplementary oxygen therapy. On auscultation
column11: rhythmic heart tones without audible murmurs. Bladder murmur was preserved without crackles or other pathological noises. Abdominal examination was unremarkable. Lower limbs without oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). No other noteworthy findings on examination.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG on admission: sinus rhythm at 65 bpm. Normal axis. PR 160 msec. Narrow QRS with little R wave progression in right precordial leads. Symmetrical and deep negative T waves from V1 to V4 and isodiphasic in V5 (Wellens pattern). ECG after percutaneous coronary intervention: sinus rhythm at 70 bpm. Normal axis. Normal PR. Narrow QRS with little progression of R in right precordials and normalisation of T waves in precordial series. Blood tests: glycaemia 102 mg/dl. Creatinine 1.24 mg/dl. Urea 36 mg/dl. Sodium 143 mEq/l. Potassium 4.3 mEq/l. Lipid profile: total cholesterol 206 mg/dl
column12: HDL cholesterol 43 mg/dl
column13: LDL cholesterol 133 mg/dl
column14: triglycerides 148 mg/dl. Normal liver and thyroid profiles. Glycated haemoglobin 5.9%. Myocardial damage markers with ultrasensitive cTnT peak of 121.8 ng/l. Haemogram without leukocytosis with normal formula. Hb 150 g/l. Platelets 229
column15: 000. Normal coagulation study. Chest X-ray: normal cardiothoracic index. Well-defined hilarity
column16: no evidence of pulmonary congestion or parenchymal condensation. Free costophrenic sinuses. Transthoracic echocardiography: non-dilated left ventricle (LVEDD 45 mm
column17: LVOT 148 ml
column18: STV 54 ml) with 12.5 mm mid-basal septum
column19: with largely preserved systolic function (LVEF 63 % by Simpson biplane). No segmental contractility defects are seen. Left atrium at the high limit of normality (AP diameter 36 mm
column20: indexed volume 30 ml/m2). Normal mitral valve. Mitral E wave velocity 5 cm/sec
column21: A wave 61 cm/sec. Septal E" 7.7
column22: lateral E" 8.8
column23: E/E" 7.6. Trivalve aortic valve with normal flows. Aortic root not dilated (sinuses of Valsalva 38 mm). Right chambers not dilated
column24: without tricuspid insufficiency that would allow estimation of systolic pulmonary artery pressure (PAPs) (no indirect data of PHT). Inferior vena cava (IVC) not dilated. Absence of pericardial effusion. Coronary angiography: right radial access. Left main coronary artery without lesions. Anterior descending artery with proximal subtotal lesion with good distal vessel. Dominant circumflex artery without lesions. Hypodense right coronary artery without lesions. Direct implantation of a zotarolimus-eluting stent (Resolute Onyx 3.5 x 18 mm) was performed on the proximal anterior descending artery (ADA)
column25: without immediate complications and with good final angiographic results.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION During his hospital stay
column26: the patient presented an episode of chest pain with a typical profile for ischaemia without associated vegetative cortex
column27: during which minimal ST-segment elevation was observed in the anterior face
column28: which subsided after the administration of nitrates
column29: while the T-wave inversion described prior to admission persisted. Serial analytical controls showed discrete mobilisation of biomarkers of myocardial damage (peak TnTus 121.8 ng/l). Based on clinical symptoms compatible with recent-onset angina and the findings described
column30: preferential coronary angiography was requested
column31: which revealed a subtotal lesion at the proximal level of the anterior descending artery
column32: with no other associated coronary lesions. This lesion was percutaneously revascularised and a drug-eluting stent was implanted without incident and with good angiographic results. At the end of the procedure
column33: a new electrocardiogram was performed which showed normalisation of the repolarisation disorders described on admission. With regard to the imaging tests
column34: the echocardiography showed a ventricle of normal size and morphology with preserved ejection fraction (LVEF 63%)
column35: without identifying segmental alterations in contractility. After the coronary intervention
column36: the patient remained completely asymptomatic and without complications derived from the procedure and was discharged. He is currently undergoing a cardiac rehabilitation programme at our centre
column37: with good tolerance to the exercises performed at the gym
column38: remaining asymptomatic and with no notable clinical incidents.  DIAGNOSIS Acute non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) with single-vessel coronary artery disease (subtotal lesion of the proximal LAD). Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with direct drug-eluting stent (DES) without incident. Initial electrical manifestation with Wellens pattern. Poorly controlled hypertension. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column23: HDL 46 mg/dl
column24: LDL 45 mg/dl.  CLINICAL COURSE In the annual follow-up assessment
column25: a stress echocardiogram was requested due to the patient's dyspnoea on exertion. In the lipid profile
column26: high levels of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) were detected
column27: so lipid-lowering treatment was intensified
column28: replacing simvastatin 40 with rosuvastatin 10 mg. The patient returned to the clinic with the results of the stress echocardiogram
column29: which was negative for ischaemia (85% of BMF; 7 metabolic equivalents (MET); no data of ischaemia in echocardiography). The patient also reported muscle discomfort since the last visit and decided to discontinue treatment with rosuvastatin. For this reason
column30: a new lipid profile was requested and pitavastatin 2 mg and ezetimibe 10 mg were prescribed. At the same time
column31: the patient's beta-blocker dose was reduced
column32: in case the feeling of asthenia could be related to this (bisoprolol 2.5 mg/24 hours). The patient returned for consultation 3 months later
column33: reporting the same symptoms and that he could not tolerate the new statin. The blood test did not detect any liver alteration or muscle damage (GOT/GPT 19/18 U/L)
column34: but due to the patient's poor tolerance with up to three different statins
column35: it was proposed to start treatment with evolocumab. Evolocumab 140 mg/2 weeks was started
column36: with good tolerance. In the analytical control 2 months after starting treatment
column37: a lipid control was requested with LDL 45 mg/dl. After one year of follow-up
column38: and due to the need for oral anticoagulation
column39: it was decided to discontinue clopidogrel and maintain acenocoumarol
column40: in order to reduce the risk of haemorrhage.  DIAGNOSIS Single-vessel coronary artery disease. Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Intolerance to statins

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION A 72-year-old man attended the emergency department for an episode of sudden dyspnoea. Personal history of interest: ischaemic cerebrovascular accident in 2009 with an unidentified aetiology (echo-Doppler of supra-aortic trunks with no pathological findings)
column3: infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm and squamous cell carcinoma of the lung operated on with right upper lobectomy 5 months ago. He was under chronic treatment with acetylsalicylic acid 300 mg/24 hours and inhaled salmeterol/fluticasone propionate 50/500 mcg/12 hours. He reported several episodes of dyspnoea over the last month
column4: always standing upright
column5: unrelated to exertion. No orthopnoea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea. No cough
column6: expectoration or chest pain. Physical examination revealed oxygen desaturation up to 80%
column7: which improved with decubitus. Jugular venous pressure was normal. Cardiac auscultation rhythmic
column8: without murmurs or extratonos. Pulmonary auscultation with hypophonesis in the right lung base
column9: absence of crackles or rhonchi. Absence of oedema in the extremities.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ANALYSIS: glucose 80 mg/dl
column10: urea 50 mg/dl
column11: creatinine 0.85 mg/dl
column12: sodium 136 mEq/l
column13: potassium 4.1 mEq/l
column14: troponin I < 0.01 ng/ml
column15: BNP 102.6 pg/ml
column16: haemoglobin 16.1 g/dl
column17: haematocrit 50.8%
column18: MCV 96.8 fl
column19: leukocytes 9
column21: platelets 111
column23: D-dimer 2
column24: 005 ng/l. Coagulation normal. ARTERIAL GASOMETRY: pH 7
column26: pCO2 26
column27: 5 mmHg
column29: 3 mmHg
column30: oxygen saturation (SatO2) 98
column33: 5 mEq/l. ELECTROCARDIOGRAM (ECG): sinus rhythm at 95 bpm. PR 200 ms
column34: QRS of 100 ms
column35: with morphology of left anterosuperior hemiblock. No repolarisation alterations. THORAX RADIOGRAPHY: elevation of the right hemidiaphragm. Normal cardiac silhouette. THORACIC CT scan: loss of volume in the right upper lobe in relation to lobectomy. Residual middle lobe atelectasis and elevated right hemidiaphragm. No repletion defects in pulmonary arteries suggestive of pulmonary thromboembolism. Transthoracic echocardiogram: left ventricle of normal dimensions and systolic function
column36: without segmental alterations of contractility. Normal right chambers with preserved ventricular function. Mitral and aortic valves without abnormalities. Hypermobile interatrial septum. Normal pulmonary pressure. Bubble test was performed with agitated saline with massive passage of bubbles from right to left cavities in the first and second beats suggesting right-left shunt. Transesophageal echocardiogram: aneurysmal interatrial septum with extensive detachment of the membrane of the fossa ovalis and massive passage of bubbles with agitated physiological saline from the right to the left atrium.  CLINICAL COURSE Initially the patient responded to oxygen therapy with nasal goggles and was admitted to the ward for investigation. A thoracic CT scan was first performed to rule out pulmonary thromboembolism (PTE) or a complication of the recent lobectomy. In the absence of pulmonary pathology to justify the symptoms
column37: an echocardiogram was requested to rule out intracardiac shunt. The baseline study showed a hypermobile interatrial septum with possible shunt
column38: which was evident in the bubble test with agitated saline. The study was completed with a transesophageal echocardiogram that confirmed the presence of an atrial septal aneurysm with patent foramen ovale (PFO) and left right shunt. The patient presented rapidly progressive worsening
column39: with severe sustained hypoxaemia (SatO2 65%) that was not corrected with position or oxygen therapy. In view of this situation
column40: urgent percutaneous closure of the PFO was decided under intracardiac echo monitoring. After PFO closure
column41: oxygen saturation normalised and dyspnoea disappeared.  DIAGNOSIS Platypnoea-orthodeoxia syndrome due to patent foramen ovale after right lobectomy. Urgent percutaneous closure of patent foramen ovale. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  BACKGROUND: 72-year-old male. No known allergies. Retired administrative worker. Cardiovascular risk factors (CVR): arterial hypertension (AHT) of 10 years of evolution with good control with two drugs. column3: with good control. Dyslipidaemia treated with statins since 2002. Ex-smoker since 2002 (20 packs/year). Previous cardiological history: Ischaemic heart disease. Debuted in 2002 with acute coronary syndrome (ACS) of the unstable angina type with disease of a vessel: proximal anterior descending (LAD) with 80% stenosis
column4: revascularised with conventional stent. Normal left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF). Subsequently stable
column5: without angina. Mild aortic stenosis with last echocardiographic study in October 2016: normal ascending aorta. Left atrium (LA) slightly dilated (area of 28 cm2). Left ventricle (LV) slightly hypertrophic
column6: not dilated

column8: without insufficiency. Mitral valve with good opening and no insufficiency. Normal right chambers. Trivial tricuspid insufficiency. Pulmonary arterial systolic pressure (PSAP) 32 mmHg + central venous pressure (CVP) (estimated at 3-5 mmHg). Normal inferior vena cava and pericardium. Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. CHA2DS2-VASc = 4
column9: on treatment with rivaroxaban since 2016 without haemorrhagic events. No other history of interest
column10: nor surgical interventions. Home medication: acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) 100 mg (0-1-0)
column11: diltiazem 60 mg (1-0-0)

column17: accompanied by dyspnoea and vegetative cortex
column18: which had started 3 weeks previously. Initially they appeared with intense exertion
column19: but over the days they became more frequent and were triggered by progressively less exertion. On the day of admission
column20: she had a 15-minute episode at rest that subsided spontaneously.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Blood pressure (BP) 136/82 mmHg
column21: heart rate (HR) 66 bpm

column55: AP projection. Normal cardiothoracic index
column56: without costophrenic sinus pinching or vascular redistribution data. No pneumonic condensation. TELEMETRY during admission: sinus rhythm without arrhythmic events. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE): left atrium (LA) moderately dilated. Left ventricle (LV) not dilated

column62: TIMI grade 3 flow with good distal bed. Mid LAD with 70% stenosis
column63: TIMI grade 3 flow with good distal bed. Distal DA with 70% stenosis and TIMI grade 3 flow. Distal circumflex artery (Cx) has 60% stenosis
column64: TIMI grade 3 flow and good distal bed. Right coronary artery: no stenosis. PERCUTANEOUS CORONARY INTERVENTION (PCI) on the LAD: Percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty (PTCA) is performed on in-stent restenosis in the proximal LAD
column65: with predilatation and subsequent implantation of a 3 x 20 mm everolimus-eluting stent. Another 3 x 12 mm everolimus-eluting stent is overlapped distally in the middle third stenosis. We finished by implanting another 2.5 x 12 mm everolimus-eluting stent over the distal LAD stenosis.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was admitted to the hospital ward as non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (NSTEACS) of the non-Q acute myocardial infarction (AMI) type in a stable haemodynamic situation (Killip Kimball [KK] I). Given the aortic murmur and the history of mild aortic valve disease
column66: echocardiography was performed to confirm that there was no severe stenosis and to assess LV systolic function. TTE reveals mildly moderate aortic stenosis with preserved LVEF. Given a high-risk ACS
column67: coronary angiography was performed in the first 24 hours
column68: revealing severe in-stent restenosis in the proximal LAD and severe lesions in the mid and distal LAD with moderate lesions in the distal Cx. In the same procedure
column69: PCI was performed on the LAD with implantation of three overlapping drug-eluting stents from proximal to distal. The patient evolved favourably without complications. As for his CVRF
column70: it seems clear that LDL cholesterol is off target and we will increase his statin; but will this be enough? And regarding his type 2 DM
column71: he is well controlled with metformin (HbA1c 6.5%). So
column72: do I maintain his treatment or should I take advantage of this moment to do something else?  DIAGNOSIS Ischaemic heart disease. NSTEACS non-Q AMI. KKI. 2-vessel coronary artery disease: Severe proximal LAD with in-stent restenosis and severe mid and distal LAD; moderate distal Cx. PCI over LAD with three overlapping drug-eluting stents. Preserved LVEF without asynergies. Degenerative aortic valve disease
column73: mild-moderate aortic stenosis. Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation
