column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Male
column3: 41 years old
column4: no drug allergies.  BACKGROUND: Cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF): dyslipidaemia. Ex-smoker of 20 cigarettes/day. Sporadic cocaine and alcohol user. Left frontoparietal ischaemic stroke in the context of cocaine use (2009). Complementary studies performed (electrocardiogram [ECG] monitoring
column5: Doppler of supra-aortic trunks
column6: transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) with bubble test
column7: study of coagulopathy) compatible with normality. No sequelae at present. No personal or family cardiological history. Usual treatment: acetylsalicylic acid 300 mg/day
column8: simvastatin 20 mg/day.  CURRENT ILLNESS: She attended the emergency department for neurological focality consisting of motor aphasia and dysarthria of onset 30 minutes ago. A cranial computed tomography (CT) scan was performed showing a known left frontoparietal lesion
column9: with no acute ischaemic or haemorrhagic findings. The on-call neurology department was contacted and
column10: given a National Institute of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score of less than 4 (not very disabling symptoms)
column11: he was not considered a candidate for reperfusion treatment. He was admitted to the stroke unit for haemodynamic control
column12: evolution and study.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Blood pressure (BP) 130/70 mmHg. Heart rate (HR) 65 bpm. Oxygen saturation (SatO2) 96% (with room air). Afebrile. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic without murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: normoventilation. Abdomen nondescript. Lower extremities without oedema or indirect signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Pedial pulses present and symmetrical. Neurological examination: normoreactive isochoric pupils. Normal cranial nerves. Motor aphasia with mild dysarthria. Strength and sensitivity preserved and symmetrical. No campimetric alterations
column13: dysmetria or gait disturbances.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: sinus rhythm at 65 bpm
column14: without conduction disorders
column15: without repolarisation alterations. CHEST X-RAY: cardiothoracic index within the normal range
column16: lung fields without condensation. ANALYSIS: Biochemistry: glucose 90 mg/dl
column17: urea 24 mg/dl
column18: creatinine 0.9 mg/dl
column19: chlorine 99 mEq/l
column20: sodium 141 mEq/l
column21: potassium 4.5 mEq/l. Thyroid function
column22: vitamin B12 and folic acid normal. Haemogram: leucocytes 10
column24: Hb 16.4 g/dl
column26: platelets 260
column27: 000. Serology: negative. Urine toxins: negative. TROMBOPHILY STUDY: heterozygous for C677T polymorphism
column28: normal for factor V Leyden and prothrombin G20210A mutations. TTE: left ventricle (LV) not dilated or hypertrophic
column29: normal global and segmental systolic function. Left atrium slightly dilated. Right chambers normal
column30: right ventricular (RV) contractility normal. Mitral valve: on the free edge of the anterior mitral leaflet there is a nodular
column31: homogeneous image
column32: which does not interfere with valve kinetics. Aortic valve: trivalve
column33: thin leaflets
column34: competent. Mild tricuspid insufficiency (TI). Inferior vena cava (IVC) not dilated with preserved inspiratory collapse. Normal systolic pulmonary artery pressure (PAPS). Absence of pericardial effusion. CARDIAC NUCLEAR MAGNETIC RESONANCE (MRI): nodular image of about 7 mm attached to the septal leaflet of the mitral valve
column35: poorly defined
column36: which could correspond to fibroelastoma. Late enhancement sequences show no foci of uptake indicating areas of myocardial necrosis or fibrosis. Given the suspicion
column37: transesophageal echocardiography is recommended. Transesophageal echocardiogram: Atrial septum intact. Left atrial septum free of thrombus. Mitral valve: thin leaflets
column38: mobility and opening preserved. On the atrial side of the anterior mitral leaflet (festoon A1-A2) there is an oval mass
column39: heterogeneous in appearance
column40: sessile
column41: without interfering with valve function
column42: suggesting papillary fibroelastoma as a first diagnostic possibility. The rest of the study is superimposable on the transthoracic study. CARDIAC CATHETERISM: coronary angiography: right dominance. Left coronary artery (LMCA): good calibre
column43: without lesions. Descending anterior descending artery (DA): no stenosis
column44: intramyocardial middle segment with slight associated milking. Circumflex (Cx): moderate development
column45: no lesions. Bisector: long and of good calibre
column46: without stenosis. CD: no stenosis. Aortography: ascending aorta of normal size
column47: trivalve aortic valve
column48: normofunctioning.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION During his stay on the ward
column49: progressive improvement with complete resolution of the neurological symptoms within 24 hours. No arrhythmic events were observed on ECG monitoring. The echocardiographic study showed a mass in the anterior mitral leaflet suggesting papillary fibroelastoma as the underlying aetiological process of the vascular event presented by the patient. Given the risk of potential embolic complications
column50: it was decided to complete the study on an outpatient basis and to consider tumour excision
column51: and the patient was referred to the cardiac surgery department
column52: which accepted the case. Valve repair surgery and tumour excision was performed (CPB time 100 minutes): triangular resection of the anterior leaflet (A1 festoon) where the tumour was located and annuloplasty with Physio ring no. 34. Postoperative period in the intensive care unit (ICU) without incident
column53: starting rehabilitation and early discharge from the ward. The biopsy was sent to the pathological anatomy service
column54: confirming the definitive diagnosis of papillary fibroelastoma.  DIAGNOSIS Cardioembolic transient ischaemic attack. Mitral papillary fibroelastoma. Tumour resection surgery and mitral annuloplasty. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  BACKGROUND: No known drug allergies. CVRF: ex-smoker of one pack/day for 2 years after an acute myocardial infarction (AMI). Dyslipidaemia under pharmacological treatment. Cardiological history: under outpatient control for chronic ischaemic heart disease and dyslipidaemia. In 2016
column3: inferoposterolateral ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (STEMI): catheterisation revealed severe coronary artery disease in two vessels: circumflex (acute lesion) and right coronary artery
column4: with implantation of a drug-eluting stent in each of the vessels. Last echocardiogram (July 2017): non-dilated
column5: mildly hypertrophic left ventricle (LV) with preserved global systolic function and inferoposterior hypokinesia. Trivalve aortic valve without functional alterations. Mitral valve without detectable functional alterations. Non-dilated right ventricle (RV) with good function. No tricuspid insufficiency (TI) detected. Pulmonary acceleration curve not suggestive of pulmonary hypertension. No pericardial effusion. No known bronchopathy. No history of surgery. Usual treatment: omeprazole 20 mg (1-0-0)
column6: aceltisalicylic acid (ASA) 100 mg (0-1-0)
column7: ramipril 2.5 mg (0-1-0)
column8: rosuvastatin 20 mg (0-0-1)
column9: ezetimibe 10 mg (0-0-1).  CURRENT DISEASE: The patient attends his cardiology outpatient appointment
column10: one year after the infarction. Subjectively he is well
column11: without dyspnoea or new episodes of chest pain on exertion. Since the last change in his statin treatment
column12: he has had no more muscle pain. He goes outside daily and walks for more than 1 hour. He climbs up to his usual home (3rd floor) using the stairs without dyspnoea which forces him to stop to rest. He denies orthopnoea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea. Impatient for the results of the blood test. Since admission for the AMI
column13: he was diagnosed with dyslipidaemia
column14: starting treatment with atorvastatin 80 mg
column15: which had to be suspended 4 months after starting it due to disabling muscle pain. He is currently being treated with rosuvastatin 20 mg and ezetimibe 10 mg.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Blood pressure (BP) 135/70 mmHg
column16: heart rate (HR) 85 bpm
column17: arterial oxygen saturation measured by pulsimetry (SpO2) 98% room air. Eupneic at rest. C/C: No jugular plethora. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic without murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur. Extremities: no oedema or evidence of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ELECTROCARDIOGRAM (ECG): sinus rhythm at 80 bpm. Normal axis. Normal PR. Narrow QRS. Q wave in DIII and avF
column18: without acute repolarisation alterations. ANALYSIS: glucose 83 mg/dl
column19: urea 53 mg/dl
column20: creatinine 0.93mg/dl
column21: total cholesterol 160 mg/dl
column22: HDL cholesterol 47mg/dl
column23: LDL cholesterol 70 mg/dl
column24: triglycerides 130 mg/dl
column25: CK 112 U/l
column26: GOT 17 U/l
column27: GPT 30 U/l
column28: GGT 45 U/l
column29: sodium 141 mmol/l
column30: potassium 4.6 mmol/l
column31: haemoglobin 14.6 g/dl
column33: platelets 267.000 10^3/μl. Transthoracic echocardiogram: non-dilated
column34: mildly hypertrophic LV with preserved global systolic function and inferoposterior basal hypokinesia. Pseudonormalised diastolic pattern. Normal aortic root (35 mm). Trivalve aortic valve without functional alterations. Normal mitral valve in structure and function. Non-dilated RV with good function. No TR detected. Pulmonary acceleration curve not suggestive of pulmonary hypertension. No pericardial effusion.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION After the AMI
column35: the patient was diagnosed with dyslipidaemia. He initially started treatment with atorvastatin 80 mg
column36: which had to be discontinued after 3 months due to incapacitating myalgias
column37: with no evidence of myositis or rhabdomyolysis. Subsequently
column38: rosuvastatin 40 mg was prescribed
column39: achieving improvement in muscle pain
column40: but without complete cessation
column41: requiring a decrease in the dose to rosuvastatin 20 mg in the fourth month of the event. This brought about a great symptomatic improvement with disappearance of the myalgias
column42: and she was able to maintain a normal active life. However
column43: at the next outpatient check-up 6 months after the cardiovascular event
column44: the low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) levels recommended for secondary prevention were not achieved
column45: so ezetimibe was added to the treatment
column46: and special emphasis was placed on the importance of compliance with hygiene and dietary measures. He was seen again one year after the AMI. At the present time
column47: the patient reports being completely asymptomatic from the cardiological point of view
column48: although somewhat nervous and desperate due to the impossibility of achieving adequate control of LDL-C levels. He follows a Mediterranean diet with low fat intake
column49: walks daily at a brisk pace for 2 hours and takes all his medication exhaustively. With all this
column50: finally
column51: optimal target LDL-C levels have been achieved
column52: knowing that our patient has a very high established cardiovascular risk.  DIAGNOSIS Chronic ischaemic heart disease. Dyslipidaemia that is difficult to control. Intolerance to statins (myalgias). Preserved LV systolic function. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  BACKGROUND: Family history: several affected relatives in the previous two generations of early ischaemic heart disease. Personal history: No known drug allergies. Cardiovascular risk factors: ex-smoker for 20 years (5 packs/year). Dyslipidaemia type heterozygous monogenic familial hypercholesterolaemia and hypertriglyceridaemia. Hyperuricemia. No arterial hypertension or diabetes mellitus. Other history: stable meningioma in the pontocerebellar angle followed periodically with magnetic resonance imaging.  Cardiological history: Ischaemic heart disease debuting in 2000 with exertional angina. An ischaemia test was performed
column3: which was positive with high-risk criteria
column4: so the patient was offered a cardiac catheterisation
column5: which he accepted. Two-vessel coronary artery disease was detected: 99% stenosis in the proximal and middle anterior descending (AD) and under-occlusion of the right coronary artery (RCA) at a very distal level. Percutaneous revascularisation was performed with two drug-eluting stents in the proximal and middle LAD. Normal left ventricular ejection fraction. Valvular heart disease of the severe aortic stenosis type
column6: symptomatic due to exertional dyspnoea since March 2015. He had been asymptomatic from the point of view of angina. Pre-surgery cardiac catheterisation: severely calcified coronary arteries
column7: with moderate and short stenosis of the ostium of the left coronary trunk (LMCA) not significant by intravascular ultrasound (IVUS)
column8: the stents of the middle LAD are patent and without restenosis. Stenosis of 90% in the middle LAD
column9: distal to the stents. Chronic occlusion of proximal DC
column10: the middle DC is filled by homocoronary collaterals
column11: the posterior descending and posterolateral collaterals are dependent on the left coronary artery. Cardiac surgery in August 2015
column12: aortic valve replacement with St. Jude mechanical prosthesis no. 19 and bypass of the left mammary artery to the LAD
column13: with good postoperative evolution. Chronic treatment: warfarin
column14: omeprazole 20 mg/24 hours
column15: bisoprolol 2.5 mg/24 hours
column16: allopurinol 100 mg/24 hours
column17: rosuvastatin 40 mg/24 hours
column18: ezetimibe 10 mg/24 hours. Current status: asymptomatic from the cardiovascular point of view. Walks 1-1.5 hours a day
column19: reports a low-salt diet and no saturated fats
column20: never smoked again. Good adherence to treatment assured by the patient and his close family.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Blood pressure (BP) 127/78 mmHg. Heart rate (HR) 68 bpm. Body mass index (BMI) 26.5 kg/m2. Corneal arcus already described since 2000
column21: when ischaemic heart disease debuted at the age of 39. Jugular venous pressure normal. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column22: normal prosthetic sounds. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur. Abdomen soft
column23: depressible
column24: non-painful
column25: no palpable masses or megaliths. Lower extremities without oedema
column26: with peripheral pulses present and symmetrical. No tendon xanthomas were observed on inspection.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ELECTROCARDIOGRAM (ECG): sinus rhythm at 68 bpm. Normal axis. Normal PR. Narrow QRS. No repolarisation alterations. Current ANALYTICS 2018: glucose 95 mg/dl
column27: normal renal function (FGR 80 ml/min). Total cholesterol 145 mg/dl
column28: LDL cholesterol 67 mg/dl
column29: HDL cholesterol 48 mg/dl. Triglycerides 149 mg/dl. Transaminases normal. CK normal. TSH normal. HbA1c 5.5%. Previous LDL cholesterol figures and lipid-lowering treatments prescribed: April 2000
column30: no treatment: LDL 210 mg/dl. June 2000
column31: simvastatin 40 mg: LDL 135 mg/dl. April 2015
column32: atorvastatin 40 mg + ezetimibe 10 mg: LDL 85 mg/dl. October 2015
column33: rosuvastatin 20 mg + ezetimibe 10 mg: LDL 73 mg/dl. June 2016
column34: rosuvastatin 40 mg + ezetimibe 10 mg: LDL 65 mg/dl.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION Patient at very high cardiovascular risk with early ischaemic heart disease and clinical diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolaemia (FH). Throughout the follow-up
column35: she complies well with the lifestyle recommendations and adheres well to treatment. Increasing lipid-lowering treatment with good tolerance is required until LDL cholesterol (LDL-C) levels < 70 mg/dl are achieved with rosuvastatin 40 mg and ezetimibe 10 mg.  DIAGNOSIS Chronic stable ischaemic heart disease: two-vessel coronary artery disease partially revascularised percutaneously and surgically. Valvular heart disease: severe symptomatic aortic stenosis on trivalve valve
column36: corrected by aortic valve replacement with a mechanical prosthesis. Normal left ventricular systolic function. Heterozygous monogenic FH. LDL-C in range with combined treatment. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION A 31-year-old woman with no past history of interest consulted for occasional palpitations and syncope related to physical and emotional stress that had started 5 months earlier. She had a family history of infarction in a paternal grandfather (88 years old) and vasovagal syncope in a brother (25 years old). On first examination
column3: the patient was normotensive and afebrile
column4: well perfused
column5: eupneic at rest and with good skin and mucous membrane colouring. Carotid pulses were rhythmic and symmetrical and there was no jugular engorgement. Cardiopulmonary auscultation showed rhythmic tones and no murmurs with preserved vesicular murmur. There was no pain on superficial or deep abdominal palpation
column6: no masses or megaliths and hydroaerial sounds were present. Pedial and posterior tibial pulses were present and symmetrical and there was no malleolar oedema or stigmata of venous insufficiency or deep vein thrombosis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Blood tests were unremarkable and the chest X-ray showed a normal cardiac silhouette
column7: with no alterations in the bronchovascular pattern or alveolar or interstitial infiltrates and free costodiaphragmatic angles. The electrocardiogram showed sinus rhythm at 54 bpm
column8: axis at 60o
column9: PR 124 msec
column10: narrow QRS
column11: without ST-segment or T-wave abnormalities. An urgent transthoracic echocardiogram showed a non-dilated and non-hypertrophied left ventricle
column12: no gross alterations of segmental contractility
column13: preserved ejection fraction (62%) and no pericardial effusion. A 24-hour Holter electrocardiogram showed frequent bouts of non-sustained polymorphic ventricular tachycardia of helical morphology and high-density ventricular extrasystoles of various morphologies
column14: the most frequent being complete left bundle branch block with inferior axis
column15: with frequent R-over-T phenomena.  EVOLUTION In view of these findings
column16: the patient was admitted to the Cardiology Department. The determination of metanephrines and vanillylmandelic acid in 24-hour urine was normal. During her stay she remained with telemetry
column17: presenting occasional ventricular extrasystoles
column18: some couple and very occasional triplets
column19: without more complex forms. A transthoracic echocardiogram with contrast showed areas of non-compaction in the postero-lateral mid-apical region (ratio compacted/non-compacted myocardium 1.5 in end-systole and 2.2 in end-diastole)
column20: with Doppler flow between the intertrabecular recesses. On the other hand
column21: simple ergometry was performed without beta-blockers
column22: which was conclusive
column23: clinically and electrically negative for ischaemia
column24: although showing frequent ventricular extrasystoles of different morphology from the second Bruce stage onwards
column25: which joined in pairs from the third stage onwards
column26: and bouts of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia from the fourth stage onwards. Beta-blocker therapy was started
column27: with good tolerance
column28: and a second ergometry performed 48 hours later showed a marked improvement of arrhythmias with extrasystoles and isolated triplets at high load. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging was also performed
column29: which confirmed areas of non-compaction in anterior and lateral mid-apical regions
column30: with a ratio between non-compacted/compacted myocardium of 3.75 and 4.5 respectively
column31: with no enhancement in the late uptake sequence or hyperintensity in the pT2 sequences with fat suppression and preserved LVEF (68%). The genetic study revealed that the patient carried the variant 1:237947553 G/A in heterozygosis of the RyR2 gene
column32: a missense mutation that causes an amino acid substitution of glycine for arginine (Gly4181Arg)
column33: not previously described as pathogenic for catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (non-conclusive result) or non-compaction cardiomyopathy. The patient evolved well and three months later is asymptomatic with no evidence of recurrence.  DIAGNOSIS Polymorphic non-sustained catecholaminergic ventricular tachycardia with inconclusive genetic study. Non-compacted left ventricle. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  BACKGROUND: 69-year-old male
column3: worked in indoor mining. No known drug allergies. Cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF): ex-smoker for 40 years
column4: accumulated 25 paq/year. Ex-drinker. No known metabolic disorders. Meets criteria for antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) and partially for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Segmental pulmonary thromboembolism (PTE) in 2015 for which she received anticoagulation with acenocoumarol. Cardiological history: in December 2017
column5: acute non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) with 2-vessel coronary artery disease (AMD and PD) with partial revascularisation. On admission
column6: transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) was performed and detected mild left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) without valvular heart disease. Left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) preserved with normofunctioning right ventricle (RV). No family history of early sudden death. Treatment: acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) 100 mg
column7: clopidogrel 75 mg
column8: acenocoumarol
column9: atorvastatin 80 mg
column10: bisoprolol 2.5 mg
column11: hydroxychloroquine
column12: hydroxyzine and ranitidine.   CURRENT ILLNESS: The patient attends the emergency department for chest pain. He reports that 2 hours before consulting and while sitting down after eating
column13: he began to experience central thoracic oppression with irradiation to the left upper limb that reminded him of the previous STEMI
column14: although of lesser intensity. He denied having had anginal episodes since revascularisation. Good adherence to the prescribed treatment. On arrival
column15: an electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed which showed sustained monosystolic ventricular tachycardia (SMVT) that was well tolerated haemodynamically
column16: so it was decided to perform pharmacological cardioversion with procainamide. After 700 mg in 100 mg boluses
column17: the patient reverted to sinus rhythm. The patient was admitted to complete studies.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Blood pressure (BP) 140/80 mmHg. Heart rate (HR) 160 bpm. SatO2 without oxygen therapy 98%. Afebrile. Conscious
column18: oriented and cooperative. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds
column19: tachycardic
column20: no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur
column21: no added sounds. Abdomen: soft
column22: depressible
column23: not painful on palpation. Lower limbs well perfused
column24: positive and symmetrical pulses. No neurological focality on examination.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS BIOCHEMISTRY: renal function and ions normal. Ultrasensitive troponin T 17 ng/l
column25: without significant elevation (limit 35 ng/l). Haemogram: haemoglobin 14.9 g/dl
column26: leucocytes 8170 with normal formula
column27: platelets: 278000. CHEST X-RAY: normal cardiothoracic index with no evidence of acute pathology. ECG on arrival: VT with morphology of left bundle branch block (LBBB)
column28: inferior axis and V3-V4 transition. Postcardioversion ECG: sinus rhythm at 60 bpm
column29: negative T in I and aVL and from V4 to V6. Baseline ECG (2015): SR at 65 bpm
column30: negative T in I and aVL and from V4 to V6. Cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR): RV of normal size with dyskinesia in the anterior wall at mid-ventricular level and small sacculations of the free wall at subtricuspid level
column31: right ventricular ejection fraction (RVEF) 44%. Normal sized LV with basal septal hypertrophy (14 mm) and mildly depressed LVEF. Small area of intramyocardial late enhancement at the inferior junction of both ventricles at mid level. TTE: mild LVH with preserved LVEF.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION Given the morphology of the VT
column32: suggestive of right ventricular outflow tract (RVOT)
column33: a CMR was performed to rule out myocardial eschar as the origin of the same and a slightly affected LVEF was observed
column34: but an LVEF of 44% with small subtricuspid sacculations and an area of dyskinesia. An electrophysiological study (EPS) was performed
column35: showing VT with LBBB morphology
column36: inferior axis and transition in V3 and V4. In addition
column37: a zone of maximum precocity is determined at this subtricuspid level where the tachycardia is terminated by performing an effective ablation. The patient remained asymptomatic and without new arrhythmic events at post-discharge follow-up. However
column38: given the VT morphology
column39: CMR alterations and baseline ECG characteristics
column40: all minor criteria for RV arrhythmogenic dysplasia
column41: the borderline diagnosis of arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia (ARVD) is established.  DIAGNOSIS TVMS of the anterolateral aspect of the RV cardioverted pharmacologically with procainamide and successfully ablated. 2-vessel coronary artery disease with partial revascularisation. Slightly impaired LVEF. Possible arrhythmogenic RV dysplasia (3 minor criteria = borderline diagnosis). |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  BACKGROUND: 64-year-old male diagnosed with dextrocardia at 54 years of age
column3: following family screening. Toxic habits: non-smoker
column4: moderate drinker. He leads an active life.  CURRENT DISEASE: At the time of diagnosis in New York Heart Association (NYHA) functional class I with recurrent symptoms of palpitations
column5: dizziness and syncope
column6: limiting his quality of life. The night before admission she presented with precordial pain and palpitations together with loss of postural tone and level of consciousness
column7: for which she consulted her doctor
column8: who arranged hospital admission for medical care and examination.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Blood pressure 120/80 mmHg. Heart rate (HR) 100 bpm. Oxygen saturation 97%. No jugular ingurgitation. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic without murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: normoventilation
column9: no crackles. Abdomen nondescript. Lower limbs without oedema. Neurological examination: normoreactive isochoric pupils. Normal cranial nerves. Normal language. Strength and sensitivity preserved. Normal gait.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS THORAX RADIOGRAPHY: dextrocardia. Cardiothoracic index greater than 0.5 with slight vascular redistribution to upper fields.  ELECTROCARDIOGRAM (ECG): sinus rhythm. Atrioventricular conduction preserved
column10: QRS 120 ms with axis -30o. Initial Q wave in aVL. Negative T wave in DIII-aVF
column11: DI-aVL and V5-V6. ANALYTICS: Hb 14 g/dl
column12: Ht 42
column13: Cr 0.9 mg/dl
column14: NT-proBNP 1
column15: 000 pg/ml. HOLTER ECG: sinus rhythm with a maximum HR of 93 bpm
column16: minimum of 50 bpm
column17: average of 61 bpm. Ventricular extrasystoles in repetitive forms
column18: three bouts of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia
column19: lasting seconds
column20: with a maximum HR of 166 bpm. ECOCARDIOGRAM: left atrium (LA) slightly dilated. Left ventricle (LV) of normal diameter with moderate asymmetric septal hypertrophy (> 15 mm) with no obstruction across the LV outflow tract and no systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve. Mild LV systolic dysfunction (EF 55%) and grade 1 diastolic dysfunction. CARDIAC NUCLEAR MAGNETIC RESONANCE (CMRI): late gadolinium enhancement irregularly distributed in the medial wall of the entire septum
column21: anterior wall and free wall of the right ventricle. Interventricular septum 15 mm thick. CARDIODESFIBRILLATOR CONTROL: programmer shows appropriate shocks.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION During his admission
column22: the patient was asked about his family history: his paternal grandfather and two of his uncles died of MS. We found a patient with clinical symptoms that limited his quality of life and
column23: after the studies performed
column24: the diagnosis of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy was confirmed. An intermediate risk of SD was estimated (HCM Risk-SCD Calculator: 5-year risk of 4.68%)
column25: and a decision was made to implant an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) for primary prevention of SD. After a stable period of 11 months
column26: he presented appropriate ICD shocks at 80 J
column27: demonstrating the effectiveness of the therapy in the prevention of SD in a patient with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The evolution at the following year is favourable. Medical treatment was optimised
column28: and the absence of ICD discharges was found in the controls
column29: and the control electrocardiogram was in sinus rhythm. A control echocardiogram was performed
column30: showing LV with moderate asymmetric septal hypertrophy
column31: which has not progressed
column32: and maintaining LV systolic function (EF 57%). No dynamic gradient was observed in the LV outflow tract.  DIAGNOSIS Non-obstructive asymmetric septal hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). Family history of MS (2nd degree). Repeated syncope. Record of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT). Late intramyocardial enhancement on cardiac MRI. ICD carrier with appropriate shocks. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Male
column3: 65 years old.  BACKGROUND: No known allergies. Toxic habits: ex-smoker (IPA 20 packs/year). Occasional alcohol consumption (1 beer at weekends). Cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF): hypertension (HT)
column4: mixed dyslipidaemia
column5: no diabetes mellitus (DM). Cardiovascular history: chronic ischaemic heart disease: admission for non-Q AMI in 2010 with complete percutaneous revascularisation of severe lesion in middle anterior descending and distal right coronary artery. Asymptomatic for angina. No new events. Echocardiogram: left ventricle of normal size and wall thickness. Left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) preserved with akinesia of the basal segment of the inferior face
column6: the rest preserved. Left atrium of normal size. Right chambers of normal size. Normal right ventricular ejection fraction (RVEF). Tricuspid aortic valve anatomically and functionally normal. Mitral valve with focal annular calcification and trivial mitral regurgitation. Mild tricuspid insufficiency allowing estimation of normal pulmonary systolic pressure. Inferior vena cava of normal size and inspiratory collapse > 50%. Absence of pericardial effusion. ECG: sinus rhythm at 65 bpm. Normal PR. Narrow QRS. Normal axis. Q wave in lead III. Negative T waves in V4-6. Poor tolerance to atorvastatin 80 mg
column7: atorvastatin 40 mg and pitavastatin 2 mg due to myalgias and asthenia
column8: without CPK elevation. Other antecedents: hypothyroidism in substitutive treatment. Altered fasting blood glucose in dietary treatment. Fracture of the right radius after a traffic accident in 1995. Usual treatment: aspirin 100 mg
column9: lisinopril 10 mg
column10: levothyroxine 50 mcg
column11: omeprazole 20 mg
column12: rosuvastatin 40 mg.  CURRENT DISEASE: Annual follow-up in cardiology consultation. She went for consultation in April 2017: stable from a cardiovascular point of view. She reports that after the last check-up where the lipid-lowering treatment was changed due to intolerance
column13: she has had slightly elevated blood glucose levels
column14: for which her primary care doctor is closely monitoring her. However
column15: he reports good tolerance to the new drug in terms of asthenia and myalgia.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Blood pressure (BP) 130/65 mmhg. Heart rate (HR) 70 bpm. Body mass index (BMI) 24.5. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column16: no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation (PA): normal
column17: no extra sounds. No peripheral oedema. Signs of chronic venous insufficiency.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ANALYTICS (March 2017): total cholesterol 235 mg/dl; LDL cholesterol 110 mg/dl (baseline levels around 160 mg/dl)
column18: fasting blood glucose 110 mg/dl. HbA1c 5.9%. Rest without relevant alterations. ECG: sinus rhythm at 70 bpm. PR 200 msg. Narrow QRS. Q wave in III. Negative T waves in V4-6. Similar to previous. THORAX RADIOGRAPHY: normal cardiothoracic index. Free costophrenic sinuses. No images of infiltrates or signs of consolidation.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION It was decided to change treatment with rosuvastatin to start evolocumab 140 mg (1 injection every 15 days at home).  DIAGNOSIS Chronic ischaemic heart disease. Poor control of target lipid levels (LDL 110 mg/dl). HYPERTENSION. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  BACKGROUND: This is a 17-year-old male patient
column3: the younger of two siblings. His older sister (index case) has clinical suspicion of MFS
column4: presenting with marfanoid habitus and ectopia lentis but no aortic dilatation (she is the index case but does not meet diagnostic criteria for MFS). The patient's mother has marfanoid habitus
column5: but has not developed ectopia lentis or aortic dilatation. After family screening
column6: our patient
column7: a competitive sportsman (basketball)
column8: was studied.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: The patient was normotensive and afebrile
column9: well perfused
column10: eupneic at rest and with good skin and mucous membrane colouring. Carotid pulses rhythmic and symmetrical. No jugular ingurgitation. Thoracic deformity due to pectus carinatum. Cardiopulmonary auscultation with rhythmic tones and no murmurs
column11: with preserved vesicular murmur. Pedial and posterior tibial pulses present and symmetrical without malleolar oedema or stigmata of venous insufficiency or deep vein thrombosis. Positive wrist and thumb sign. Increased arm/stature ratio. Scoliosis. Subluxation of the crystalline lens.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ELECTROCARDIOGRAM (ECG): RS at 47 bpm. Narrow QRS. Normal axis. No repolarisation alterations. ECOCARDIOGRAM: left ventricle not dilated
column12: with normal thickness and preserved function (EF 60%)
column13: highlights inferolateral and apical hypertrabeculation. Normal right cavities. Absence of valvular heart disease. Aorta not dilated with maximum diameter at sinus level: 31 mm.  CARDIAC NUCLEAR MAGNETIC RESONANCE (MRI): no alterations of interest
column14: except for increased trabeculation in the areas referred to in the echocardiogram
column15: without fulfilling the criteria for non-compacted myocardium. Aorta within the normal range. EXERCISE TEST: stopped at minute 14.30 of the Bruce protocol after reaching the maximum theoretical heart rate (HR). Normal tension and chronotropic response. Isolated supraventricular extrasystoles. Conclusion: clinically and electrically negative for ischaemia. Good functional capacity. No significant arrhythmias. HOLTER-ECG: no significant arrhythmias. GENETIC STUDY: studied by massively parallel sequencing method using a library that includes 35 genes related to aortic-vascular syndromes. A heterozygous mutation in the FBN1 gene (p.Glu 1811Lys) previously described and considered pathogenic or associated with the disease and another heterozygous mutation in the FBN1 gene (p.Arg2Cys) previously undescribed and with uncertain pathogenicity are identified. column17: there was no aortic dilatation. In the absence of a family history of MFS
column18: the diagnosis is not confirmed and genetic testing is necessary. After confirming the pathogenic mutation in the FBN1 gene
column19: the diagnosis of MFS was confirmed
column20: and the patient was advised against intense physical exercise and competition.  DIAGNOSIS MFS (systemic scores > 7 points and lens subluxation) without involvement of the cardiovascular system

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  BACKGROUND: Essential arterial hypertension. Grade II obesity of central predominance. Non-ST-elevation acute coronary syndrome (NSTEACS) in 87 and 98
column3: being treated with conventional stent in the second episode in the right coronary artery. Heterozygous familial hypercholesterolemia with pathogenic LDL receptor mutation. Two sons with the same mutation. Atheromatosis of large vessels
column4: with carotid involvement detected by echo-Doppler. Restrictive pulmonary disorder in relation to obesity hypoventilation syndrome. Pending polysomnographic study. No known allergies. Intolerance to statins
column5: with clinical manifestations of myalgias and elevated muscle damage enzymes (CK). Previous treatment: acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) 100 mg
column6: atenolol 50 mg
column7: atorvastatin 40 mg
column8: ezetimibe 10 mg.  CURRENT DISEASE: A 79-year-old man with the history described above came to the endocrinology department for review of lipid-lowering treatment for secondary prevention after NSTEACS. The patient presented poor tolerance to statins
column9: with muscle pain and elevated CK levels after attempting to increase the dose of 40 mg of atorvastatin. Despite the combination of 40 mg atorvastatin with 10 mg ezetimibe
column10: the patient has LDL cholesterol levels of 145 mg/dl (well above the recommended limit of 70 mg/dl for this patient group). Therefore
column11: treatment with PCSK9 protein inhibitors
column12: specifically evolocumab
column13: is proposed and accepted
column14: starting at a dose of 140 mg subcutaneous every two weeks.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Congestive appearance. Weight 93.5 kg. Height 166 cm. Muscle mass index (BMI) 34 kg/m2. Blood pressure (BP) 140/80. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic without murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: hypoventilation in the bases. Peripheral pulses present. Discrete oedema with fovea in the lower limbs.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Last blood test (22/02/2018): glucose 101 mg/dl. Creatinine 0.79 mg/dl. GFR MDRD 6 97.50 ml/min. Urea 37 mg/dl. Uric acid 7.8 mg/dl. Sodium 141 mm/l. Potassium 4.9 mm/l. Chlorine 106 mm/l. Calcium 9.1 mg/dl. Phosphorus 3.1 mg/dl. Magnesium 1.80 mg/dl. Albumin 4
column15: 0 g/dl. Total bilirubin 0.78 mg/dl. AST/GOT 33 U/l. ALT/GPT 44 U/l. GGT 24 U/l. Alkaline phosphatase 54 U/l. Creatine kinase (CK) 170 U/l. Total cholesterol 102 mg/dl
column16: HDL cholesterol 30 mg/dl
column17: LDL cholesterol calc. 37 mg/dl
column18: triglycerides 174 mg/dl. C-reactive protein (ultra) 2.38 mg/l. Glycated haemoglobin (DCCT) 5.9%. ECG: sinus rhythm at 66 bpm
column19: PR of 180 ms
column20: narrow QRS at 60 degrees without acute repolarisation alterations.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient started treatment with evolocumab with LDL-cholesterol levels of 145 mg/dl. After one month of treatment the LDL-cholesterol level dropped to 26 mg/dl. Because of this sharp drop
column21: both the patient and his general practitioner decide to discontinue evolocumab without consulting his cardiologist or endocrinologist
column22: for fear of adverse effects related to such low cholesterol levels. Despite the endocrinologist explaining the absence of complications due to such low cholesterol levels
column23: the patient has poor adherence to treatment with a rise in LDL cholesterol levels for one year
column24: after which the patient agrees to resume treatment correctly. A further decrease in LDL cholesterol levels to 19 is obtained
column25: so the patient is de-escalated by withdrawing ezetimibe
column26: and the control observed in the last analysis is obtained. Image 2 shows the cholesterol evolution profile during this time.  DIAGNOSIS Heterozygous familial hypercholesterolemia with established vascular damage and good control of cholesterol levels after starting treatment with PCSK9 protein inhibitors. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 50-year-old male
column3: ex-smoker with no other history of interest
column4: suffered out-of-hospital CPR. On arrival of the emergency services
column5: advanced cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) manoeuvres were started and VF was observed
column6: requiring five shocks to restore sinus rhythm. Total CPR time was 40 minutes. She was transferred to the intensive care unit for support and treatment. Physical examination revealed no significant findings
column7: and the patient remained haemodynamically stable with no signs of heart failure (HF) or audible murmurs.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS TROPONIN I 0.33 --> 5.39 mcg/l. ELECTROCARDIOGRAM (ECG): sinus rhythm with evolution towards inferior necrosis: Q wave in II
column8: III and aVf with accompanying R and flattened repolarisation. THORAX RADIOGRAPHY: no alterations. CRANIAL CT: no significant alterations. CORONARY CHORONARYGRAPHY: coronary arteries without significant stenosis. Transthoracic echocardiogram: left ventricle (LV) neither dilated nor hypertrophic
column9: borderline LVEF (50-52%)
column10: akinesia of inferior face and basal inferior septum. Normal diastolic pattern for age. Right ventricle (RV) neither dilated nor hypertrophic
column11: preserved systolic function (TAPSE 20 mm
column12: S wave ́12 cm/sec). Atria of normal size. Aortic valve trivalve
column13: thin leaflets normofunctioning. Thin leaflet mitral valve with mild central insufficiency. Structurally normal tricuspid valve without insufficiency allowing estimation of pulmonary arterial systolic pressure (PSAP). No indirect evidence of pulmonary hypertension. Inferior vena cava (IVC) slightly dilated (23 mm) with inspiratory collapse > 50%. Aortic root not dilated (34 mm sinuses of Valsalva). No pericardial effusion. CARDIAC MRI9 MAGNETIC RESONANCE showing: LV slightly dilated with preserved systolic function. Thinning and hypocontractility in inferoseptal
column14: inferior and inferolateral segments at basal and medial level with oedema
column15: hypoperfusion and subendocardial late enhancement greater than 50% in these segments. RV of normal size and function. These findings are compatible with acute phase infarction.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION Given the high suspicion of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) as the cause of the CRA
column16: and that it was a primary VF
column17: cardiac MRI was requested in which signs compatible with acute phase infarction were observed. The patient evolved favourably
column18: with early extubation
column19: without neurological sequelae and maintaining haemodynamic stability. Days later he was discharged under double antiplatelet therapy
column20: beta-blocker
column21: high-potency statin and proton pump inhibitors (PPI). Up to the present time
column22: he continues to progress well.  DIAGNOSIS CRP in VF in the context of inferior AMI. Coronary arteries without significant lesions. Preserved LV systolic function. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  BACKGROUND: 47-year-old female
column3: ex-smoker as the only cardiovascular risk factor and no previous cardiological history. In 2004 she underwent a right hemithyroidectomy for a thyroid nodule. Anatomopathological diagnosis of follicular adenoma. In 2013
column4: he was diagnosed with diffuse fibrocystic mastopathy. In 2016
column5: following abdominal distension
column6: a large left retroperitoneal mass suggestive of primary adrenal neoplasia was found on CT scan. Functionality was ruled out and a unilateral adrenal adrenalectomy
column7: left nephrectomy
column8: splenectomy and para-aortic lymphadenectomy were performed. The anatomopathological study confirmed the diagnosis of stage II adrenal carcinoma. In 2017 diagnosis of uterine myoma. Family history: maternal grandmother breast neoplasia. Maternal grandfather lung neoplasia. Paternal grandmother leukaemia. Usual treatment: oral contraceptives
column9: levothyroxine
column10: hydrocortisone.  CURRENT ILLNESS: Regular follow-up in endocrinology and gynaecology. In the last control CT scan in endocrinology
column11: no signs of recurrence of adrenal carcinoma were found. However
column12: a mass was found in the left atrium
column13: for which a study was requested in our consultations. She is asymptomatic from the cardiovascular point of view. She reported mild asthenia and weight gain in the last year
column14: which she related to changes in pharmacological treatment.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: The presence of cutaneous lentigines at multiple levels is noteworthy. Cardiopulmonary auscultation was normal. No other striking findings.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Thoracic-abdomino-pelvic CT scan for endocrinology control: no signs of recurrence of adrenal carcinoma. Cystic lesion of 35 mm in the right adnexal region. Focal nodular hyperplasia of the liver. Juxtacisural pseudonodular lesion in LSI. Mass in left atrium
column15: requesting study in our offices. ELECTROCARDIOGRAM (ECG): sinus rhythm at 80 bpm. No repolarisation alterations. Transthoracic echocardiogram: there was evidence of a mass in the left atrium (LA)
column16: of heterogeneous texture
column17: adhered to the interatrial septum at the level of the fossa ovalis (myxoma as a first possibility; possible lipoma). Left ventricle (LV) of normal size
column18: non-hypertrophic with preserved systolic function
column19: without significant valvulopathy. Right ventricle (RV) not dilated with preserved systolic function. CARDIAC MRI: oval
column20: well-defined mass depending on the interatrial septum (2 x 1.5 cm; craniocaudal axis 2.2 cm)
column21: implanted in the area of the foramen ovale
column22: little pedunculated and does not alter the functionality of the mitral valve. Low signal intensity in cine sequences with central predominant contrast uptake
column23: compatible with myxoma. Normal sized cavities and preserved biventricular function.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The mass and its implantation base were resected and the defect was closed with a pericardial patch. The patient's evolution was favourable after surgery and the control transthoracic echocardiogram showed preserved biventricular function and interatrial septum with no flow through it and no evidence of myxoma. The anatomopathological study confirms the diagnosis of myxoma.  DIAGNOSIS Cardiac myxoma. Multiple neoplasia syndrome: Carney syndrome. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  BACKGROUND: 29-year-old male ex-smoker for the last year of a pack a day for 15 years
column3: with no other personal history of interest. He does not take any treatment on a regular basis. As family history
column4: his paternal uncle and grandfather died of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) at an age over 65 years. Previous baseline ECG is in sinus rhythm with normal axis
column5: narrow QRS with no repolarisation abnormalities.  CURRENT ILLNESS: The patient comes to the emergency department of our centre in July 2017 for a 48-hour course of intense odynophagia
column6: making swallowing difficult and thermometric fever at home of up to 39 oC. She denies dyspnoea
column7: cough or purulent expectoration. He has also been complaining for months of mechanical central thoracic discomfort that does not limit his usual activity.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: On arrival at the ED
column8: fever of 38°C and sinus tachycardia at 110 bpm were observed. He was haemodynamically stable with adequate blood pressure and good baseline oxygen saturation. Physical examination revealed an erythematous oropharynx with bilateral tonsillar pustular plaques and traces of secretions in the posterior pharyngeal wall
column9: with no palpable lymphadenopathies. Cardiopulmonary auscultation was normal.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ANALYSIS: leukocytosis with neutrophilia
column10: normal ions. VENOUS GASOMETRY: respiratory alkalosis. ECG on arrival at the ED (with fever of 38oC): sinus tachycardia at 110 bpm
column11: normal PR
column12: QRS 120 milliseconds. In V1-V2 there was an image of RsR' with descending ST-segment elevation and negative T wave. Compatible with Brugada type I pattern. ESG after an iv dose of paracetamol
column13: 37 oC: sinus rhythm at 95 bpm
column14: normal PR
column15: QRS 113 milliseconds. In V1-V2 there is an image of RsR' with descending ST-segment elevation but less pronounced than in previous ECG and negative T wave. THORAX RADIOGRAPHY: normal. Transthoracic echocardiogram: no data of structural heart disease. Non-dilated left ventricle with normal wall thickness and normal systolic function. Right ventricle of normal size with normal systolic function. Normal sized atria. No valvular heart disease. Absence of pericardial effusion.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION Following these findings
column16: the patient was re-interviewed and reported syncopal episodes of vasovagal profile (one episode in the last two years) related to heat or blood draws
column17: with no other cardiovascular symptoms. He also denies a history of sudden death in his family. The patient was discharged with antibiotic treatment with amoxicillin for acute pharyngotonsillitis and was referred to the arrhythmia unit to complete the study
column18: where a provocation test with flecainide was performed
column19: which was positive. An electrophysiological study was performed
column20: during which no inducible ventricular arrhythmias or prolongation of the HV interval were found. As the patient had no history of sudden death in the family
column21: no spontaneous Brugada type 1 pattern
column22: very low recurrence of syncope and a clear vasovagal profile
column23: it was decided not to implant an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) and to perform clinical follow-up.  DIAGNOSIS Electrocardiographic pattern of Brugada type I unmasked by fever. Syncope with a probable vasovagal profile. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  BACKGROUND: 60-year-old patient
column3: with a history of active smoking of 1 pack/day
column4: dyslipidaemia
column5: eosinophilic oesophagitis (under treatment with inhaled corticosteroids) and Tarlov's cyst with compression of left sacral roots. Family history of ischaemic heart disease. Cardiological history: recurrent episodes of chest pain. In 2015 an ischaemia test was performed
column6: which was negative
column7: and subsequently a coronary CT scan showed significant coronary artery disease. Coronary angiography showed severe right circumflex and coronary artery disease
column8: and percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with drug-eluting stents was performed.  CURRENT ILLNESS: After taking moxifloxacin for bronchitis
column9: she presented with an episode of sudden dyspnoea with generalised pruritus and chest tightness radiating to both extremities. She then suffered a syncopal episode. She was attended by 061 who observed: poor general condition
column10: blood pressure (BP) 69/20
column11: oxygen saturation (SatO2) 82% and on the electrocardiogram (ECG) sharp T waves with J point elevation of 2 mm in V3-V6. O2
column12: fluid therapy and treatment as ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (STEMI) were started and the patient was transferred to hospital for primary PCI. The patient arrived at the haemodynamics ward with systolic blood pressure (SBP) 60 mmHg and drowsy
column13: and treatment was started with plasma expanders and inotropes. Coronary angiography: coronary arteries without lesions and excellent results of previously implanted stents. Absence of aortic dissection. Ventriculography without segmental alterations and with competent mitral. On arrival in the ward
column14: skin erythema. Subsequent control ECG in the observation room: normalisation of repolarisation with flattening of the T waves on the anterolateral side. Favourable clinical evolution with progressive disappearance of the skin rash and normalisation of blood pressure
column15: and inotropic support could be withdrawn. Slight elevation of troponin I (peak TnI 0.46) in the biomarker serum. Admitted to cardiology with a diagnosis of anaphylactic shock after taking moxifloxacin + probable Kounis syndrome (KS) (coronary spasm in the context of allergic reaction).  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: BP 122/71
column16: heart rate (HR) 82 bpm
column17: SatO2 95%. Conscious and oriented
column18: skin congestion
column19: normohydrated. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds
column20: no murmurs. No jugular ingurgitation. Pulmonary auscultation: normal ventilation. Abdomen: soft
column21: depressible
column22: not painful on palpation. No masses or megaliths. No signs of peritoneal irritation. Peristalsis preserved. Lower extremities: no oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ANALYTICS: glucose 96 mg/dl. Creatinine 0.54 mg/dl
column23: Na 130 mEq/l
column24: TSH normal. Cholesterol 116 mg/dl
column25: HDL 46 mg/dl
column26: LDL 54 mg/dl. Haemoglobin 11.1 g/dl
column27: platelets 236 x 10^3/microl. Chest X-ray: no relevant findings. ECG (061): sinus rhythm at 97 bpm
column28: hyperacute T waves with J point elevation of about 2 mm in V3-V6. ECG at discharge: sinus rhythm at 63 bpm. rs in III
column29: aVF. T negative in III. ST rectilinear in V5-V6. ECOCARDIOGRAM: left ventricle (LV) of normal dimensions and wall thickness. Normal global systolic function
column30: without segmental asymmetries of contractility. Normal diastolic pattern. Left atrium of normal dimensions. Normal right chambers
column31: normocontractile right ventricle (RV). Mitral valve (MV): thin leaflets
column33: competent. Aortic valve (VAo): trivalve
column34: normal sigmoid leaflets
column35: not limited in opening
column36: competent. Aortic root and visualised portion of proximal ascending aorta normal. Tricuspid insufficiency (TI) minimal. Inferior vena cava (IVC) not dilated with normal inspiratory collapse. Normal estimated systolic pulmonary artery pressure (PAPs). Absence of pericardial effusion and intracavitary masses through this access route. CORONARYGRAPHY: coronary tree without lesions of interest
column37: with TIMI 3 flow and excellent results of previously implanted stents. Absence of aortic dissection. Good left ventricular function
column38: without segmental alterations and with competent mitral valve.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION On the ward the patient remained stable
column39: asymptomatic at all times. A control echocardiogram was performed showing normal systolic function
column40: with no other alterations of interest. Due to a history of hyperreactivity in a patient with normal systolic function
column41: without previous acute myocardial infarction (AMI)
column42: beta-blockers were discontinued. The patient was preferentially referred to the allergology department for monitoring. Asymptomatic and stable
column43: the patient was discharged from hospital.   DIAGNOSIS Anaphylactic shock after taking moxifloxacin. Kounis syndrome. Chronic ischaemic heart disease: coronary arteries without significant angiographic lesions. Good results of previous stents. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of an 83-year-old man who came to our hospital with syncope of unclear aetiology.  HISTORY
column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  BACKGROUND: No AMC. Hypertensive
column3: type 2 diabetic
column4: dyslipidaemic
column5: ex-smoker. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) moderate grade
column6: chronic kidney disease stage IIIB
column7: and peripheral vascular vascular disease in follow-up by vascular surgery. Surgical interventions: ascending aorta endoprosthesis in 2000 (in another centre outside our community) with left carotid-subclavian bypass and occlusion of left subclavian artery. He underwent an infrarenal aorto-bi-iliac abdominal endoprosthesis. Usual treatment: metformin 850/12 hours
column8: acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) 100 mg/24 hours
column9: nevibololol/hydrochlorothiazide 5/25 mg/24 hours
column10: atorvastatin 40 mg/24 hours.  CURRENT ILLNESS: 83-year-old male who comes to the emergency department of our centre brought by a neighbour for finding him fallen at home. He lives alone
column11: with no direct family. Anamnesis was difficult due to the patient being disorientated in time and space. On rehistorising the patient during his hospital stay
column12: the day before admission he began with central thoracic pain and paraparesis of the lower limbs
column13: which prevented him from standing upright
column14: as well as diffuse abdominal discomfort
column15: with no other apparent associated symptoms. On asking his neighbour
column16: he reported finding him at home with a wound in the occipital region
column17: without loss of sphincter control; apparently the patient had been asymptomatic from a cardiovascular point of view for the previous few days.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Disoriented in time and space. Verbose. Blood pressure (BP) 160/85 mmHg. Heart rate 90 bpm. Afebrile. No IY. Occipital trauma. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds without murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: generalised hypoventilation with some scattered rhonchi. Lower limbs: no oedema
column18: femoral and popliteal pulses present with abolished distal pulses. Abdomen: no pain on palpation
column19: hydroaerial sounds present
column20: no signs of peritoneal irritation. NRL: Bilateral PPCC preserved. Strength and sensibility preserved in all four limbs.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ANALYTICS (ED): biochemistry: glucose 250 mg/dl. Creatinine 3.19 mg/dl
column21: GFR (MDRD) 19 ml/min/m2. nA 140 mEq/l. K 4.9 mEq/l. Urea 89 mg/dl. GOT 25IU/l. GPT 16IU/l. Bilirubin 05 mg/dl. Haemogram: 21100 leukocytes (84% PMN
column22: 4 % keys)
column23: Hb 7.8 g/dl
column24: haematocrit 23%
column25: 192000 platelets/mm3. Coagulation: INR 1.0
column26: PT 100% ELECTROCARDIOGRAM (ECG): sinus rhythm at 85 bpm
column27: PR 180 ms
column28: wide QRS with right bundle branch block. Chest X-ray P-A: cardiomegaly. Significant mediastinal enlargement displacing the left lung. Left pleural effusion. Cranial CT scan (emergency): bilateral frontoparietal extra-axial collection
column29: suggestive of subdural haematoma with little compressive effect on the cerebral parenchyma. Small vessel ischaemic lesions. ECHOcardiogram (urgent): left ventricle of normal size
column30: with preserved global and segmental systolic function (calculated at 65%). No contractility alterations are evident. Right chambers of preserved size and function. No significant valvulopathies. No evidence of pericardial effusion Thoracic ANGIO-CT (emergency): performed without contrast due to creatinine levels. Increase in the aneurysmal sac with respect to the previous study in December 2011. The current measurements are 11 x 11 x 14 cm in the transverse
column31: anteroposterior and cranio-caudal axes respectively (the measurements of the previous study were 6 x 6 x 7 x 7 cm). There is a significant loculated left pleural effusion. Both in the aneurysmal sac and in the effusion
column32: areas of increased attenuation are identified suggesting extravasation of blood. In the prosthesis located in the aortic arch
column33: at the junction of the distal portion of the arch with the descending aorta
column34: there is an area of irregularity and apparent interruption of the continuity of the prosthesis walls. ANGIO-CT scan of the aorta (day 1 of admission): endoprosthesis in the aortic arch
column35: with slight bending in the proximal and distal areas. Large aortic aneurysm (11.5 cm) thrombosed
column36: although with dense areas suggesting haemorrhage and therefore instability
column37: especially in the anterior area. No direct or indirect leakage is demonstrated by this study. Above all
column38: in the superior zone
column39: calcifications are evident in the mural thrombus
column40: indicating dissection
column41: but no false lumen filling is seen. Pre-stent aorta of 36 mm and distal aorta of 31 mm. Patent left carotid-subclavian anastomosis. Significant left pleural effusion with haemorrhagic component with no visible leaks; it is loculated and lobulated
column42: with collapse of LII and atelectasis of the lingula. Discrete mediastinal shift to the right side. The aneurysm compresses the pulmonary artery and the left pulmonary artery branch. Coronary calcifications. Aorto-bi-iliac endoprosthesis without complications. Thoracic ARTERIOGRAPHY (day 2 of admission): performed via the right humeral route. No contrast leakage or branches contributing to the aneurysmal sac were identified.   CLINICAL EVOLUTION An 83-year-old man with the aforementioned history was admitted to the hospital emergency department for syncope; after performing the appropriate complementary tests
column43: acute aortic syndrome was detected and he was admitted to the coronary unit of our hospital. In view of the clinical stability of the patient
column44: his comorbidity and in agreement with the cardiac surgery department of our hospital
column45: intensive surveillance and conservative management were decided
column46: starting first with antihypertensive treatment
column47: transfusion of two red blood cell concentrates and serum therapy with a view to improving renal function in order to complete the study. On the first day of admission
column48: a new control CT angiography was performed
column49: this time with contrast
column50: with no evident leakage and showing thrombosis of the aneurysm
column51: and on the second day of hospitalisation
column52: after stabilising the patient's renal function and in a situation of haemodynamic stability
column53: a thoracic arteriography was performed with no evidence of contrast leakage. During his admission
column54: the patient showed good clinical evolution
column55: with haemodynamic stability
column56: no neurological deterioration and progressive improvement in renal function. Finally
column57: given the favourable evolution of the patient's condition
column58: conservative management of his acute aortic syndrome was decided. On discharge
column59: he was haemodynamically stable and asymptomatic from the cardiovascular point of view
column60: and treatment was prescribed with beta-blockers and vasodilators at low doses. Likewise
column61: he was assessed by the neurosurgery service without requiring treatment and
column62: due to the lack of family support
column63: he was assessed by the social worker and institutionalised.  DIAGNOSIS Acute aortic syndrome. Intramural haematoma secondary to leakage of ascending aortic stent. Rupture of aneurysmal sac with haemothorax. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
