column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  BACKGROUND: 60-year-old male
column3: no known drug allergies
column4: as cardiovascular risk factors he is a smoker of 15 cigarettes/day
column5: hypertensive and dyslipidaemic. Other antecedents include an anxious-depressive syndrome
column6: chronic bronchitis with bronchodilator treatment and he is an ex-miner. He underwent surgery for a right hip fracture 5 years ago and a right ankle fracture more than 20 years ago. No personal or family history of heart disease or sudden death. He follows regular treatment with fluoxetine 40 mg/24 hours
column7: omeprazole 20 mg/24 hours
column8: bromazepam 1.5 mg/24 hours
column9: valsartan 160 mg/24 hours
column10: pravastatin 20 mg/24 hours
column11: formoterol 100/beclomethasone 6 mcg 1 inhalation/24 hours
column12: and salbutamol on demand.  CURRENT ILLNESS: On the day prior to admission
column13: the patient reported starting with a catarrhal condition
column14: with general malaise and no fever
column15: for which reason he went to his primary care physician on the day of admission
column16: who prescribed antibiotic treatment with moxifloxacin 400 mg. After taking the first dose
column17: he began with intense itching of the scalp
column18: followed by sweating
column19: skin rash
column20: oppressive non-radiating central thoracic pain and intense dyspnoea. They called emergency services and on arrival of 112 they found the patient dyspnoeic
column21: with significant respiratory distress
column22: hypotensive (blood pressure [BP] 80/60) and with an oxygen saturation of 78%
column23: which improved after administration of serum therapy and bronchodilators
column24: so he was transferred to our centre. On arrival at our centre
column25: the patient was admitted to the emergency department and found to be haemodynamically stable and not in respiratory distress
column26: with improvement in oxygenation parameters
column27: and cardiology was contacted and he was admitted to the coronary unit of our centre.   PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Blood pressure 130/70. Heart rate 85 bpm. Temperature 36 °C. Conscious
column28: oriented
column29: good distal perfusion. Eupneic on room air without supplementary oxygen. Chest emphysematous. Head and neck: no IVY
column30: no hepatojugular reflux. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column31: no audible murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: Global hypoventilation. Abdomen: soft
column33: not painful on palpation. Extremities: no oedema
column34: no evidence of deep vein thrombosis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ELECTROCARDIOGRAM (ECG) (112): sinus rhythm at 95 bpm
column35: PR 160 MS
column36: narrow QRS. Axis 60o. Inferior ST supra-segment elevation. ECG (coronary unit): SR at 100 bpm
column37: PR 160ms
column38: narrow QRS. q III. ST segment normalisation. THORAX RADIOGRAPHY: normal cardiothoracic index with no evidence of vascular redistribution. ANALYSIS (in the coronary unit): CBC: leukocytes: 18.8 10e3/ul (80.2% neutrophils
column39: 16.7% lymphocytes); haemoglobin 17.5 g/dl; platelets 331 10e3/u. Biochemistry: creatinine 1.02 mg/dl (GFR 72ml/min/m2); urea 42 mg/dl
column40: sodium 140 mEq/l
column41: potassium 4.1 mEq/l
column42: blood glucose 119 mg/dl. Peak CK 232 U/l (normal range 10-192); peak CKMB 35 U/l; peak ultrasensitive troponin 195 ng/l (normal range 0-13). Total cholesterol 187; LDL 106; HDL 38; triglycerides 212. AST 23 U/l (normal range 15-41); ALT 15 U/l (normal range 0-13). Thyroid hormones within normal range. Coagulation: INR 1.02; prothrombin rate 89%. Arterial blood gas (FiO2 21%): pH 7.30
column43: PCO2 37
column44: PO2 76
column45: bicarbonate 18
column46: saturation 90%. CARDIAC CATHETERISM: coronary arteries without angiographically significant lesions. ECOCARDIOGRAM: left ventricle not dilated
column47: with slight hypertrophy
column48: with preserved global function without segmental abnormalities of contractility (LVEF calculated at 60%). Right ventricle of normal size and function. Left atrium slightly dilated. No valvular heart disease. Inferior vena cava not dilated with adequate inspiratory collapse. No pericardial effusion. Normal aortic arch.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION On arrival at the coronary unit
column49: the patient was asymptomatic
column50: with no new episodes of angina
column51: and haemodynamically stable
column52: with normalisation of the repolarisation alterations that he presented at the beginning of the picture. A haemodynamic study was performed
column53: showing coronary arteries without lesions and an echocardiogram showing a ventricle of preserved size and function with no contractility abnormalities. During admission
column54: he presented acute renal failure
column55: with metabolic acidosis that resolved with treatment
column56: and a referral was made to the allergology department. After performing skin tests
column57: the symptoms were interpreted as allergic vasospastic angina or KS secondary to moxifloxacin. Subsequently
column58: during his stay in the cardiology ward
column59: he remained asymptomatic from the cardiovascular point of view and it was decided to discharge him on the fifth day and continue outpatient controls.  DIAGNOSIS Allergic vasospastic angina (SK). Allergy to quinolones. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  BACKGROUND:  Family history: Mother with early ischaemic heart disease (46 years old). Died at the age of 50 due to acute myocardial infarction (AMI). Uncles on maternal side with early ischaemic heart disease. Brother died at the age of 28 due to AMI. Brother with ischaemic heart disease at the age of 39.  Personal history: No known drug allergies No known toxic habits. Cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF): no hypertension (HT)
column3: no known diabetes mellitus (DM). Heterozygous familial hypercholesterolemia with positive genetic study (M334 mutation) under follow-up in the lipid and cardiovascular (CV) risk unit.  Cardiological history: chronic multivessel ischaemic cardiopathy: debut in December 2006 with inferoposterior AMI with partially revascularised multivessel disease (ADA and marginal with implantation of 4 drug-eluting stents
column4: chronically occluded right coronary artery (RCA) with very diseased vessel). Left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) preserved. New admission in 2008 for unstable angina with new coronary angiography with slight luminal loss of previously implanted stents. Chronic occlusion of the RCA and no progression of the disease to other levels. In 2011
column5: stress echocardiography was performed and was positive with ischaemia in the RCA territory
column6: new catheterisation without restenosis of the stents implanted in the anterior descending artery (AD) and circumflex artery (CX). 100% occlusion of the middle RCA treated by percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty (PTCA) and two drug-eluting stents in the proximal and middle segments. Left hemispheric stroke in November 2010. Fibromyalgia. Operated on lumbar hernia. Usual treatment: acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) 100 mg c/24 hours; bisoprolol 2.5 mg c/24 hours; telmisartan 40 mg c/24 hours; pantoprazole 20 mg c/24 hours; NTG transdermal patch 10 mg; ezetimibe 10 mg c/24 hours; rosuvastatin 20 mg c/24 hours
column7: duloxetine 60 mg c/24 hours; sublingual NFC if chest pain.  CURRENT ILLNESS: Patient with personal history of heterozygous familial hypercholesterolaemia with positive genetic diagnosis and a history of revascularised early multivessel chronic ischaemic heart disease under follow-up in the lipid and CV risk unit of our hospital without reaching target therapeutic levels of LDL cholesterol according to current indications in secondary prevention
column8: despite treatment with combined lipid-lowering agents at maximum tolerated doses in addition to multiple readmissions to cardiology for unstable angina with progression of coronary heart disease. In October 2014
column9: given the persistent poor control of LDL cholesterol levels and his high cardiovascular risk
column10: it was decided to include the patient in the LDL apheresis programme
column11: which was started after performing an A-V fistula in MSI with good initial tolerance.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Good general condition
column12: well hydrated and perfused. Eupneic at rest
column13: tolerates decubitus. Afebrile and haemodynamically stable. Blood pressure (BP) 129/60 mmHg
column14: heart rate (HR) 65 bpm. Positive corneal arc. Cardiorespiratory auscultation with rhythmic tones
column15: no murmurs. Conservative vesicular murmur with no superimposed noises. Absence of oedema in the lower limbs with pulses present. Bilateral femoral murmurs.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ELECTROCARDIOGRAM (ECG): sinus rhythm at 78 bpm
column16: normal axis. PR 128 msec
column17: narrow QRS with low voltages in DIII. LIPID PROFILE (2014): total cholesterol 210 mg/Dl. Triglycerides 139 mg/dl. Apo-A Apolipoprotein 151 mg/dl. HDL cholesterol 52 mg/dl. LDL cholesterol 130 mg/dl. Apo-B Apolipoprotein 134 mg/dl. LDL/HDL 2.5. Lipoprotein (a) 59 mg/dl. ECOCARDIOGRAPHY: left atrium not dilated. Left ventricle (LV) of size (LVEDD 45 mm) and without wall thickening (septum 10 mm)
column18: slight apical hypokinesia with preserved global EF. Mitral valve with thin leaflets and preserved opening. Normal aortic root and valve. Normal right chambers. RV with preserved LVEF. No tricuspid insufficiency (TI). Carotid Doppler ultrasound: right internal carotid artery with concentric iosechoic plaque at its origin causing a stenosis of around 30%. Left internal carotid artery with hyperechoic plaque in the far wall of the bifurcation causing a stenosis of around 35%. A. dominant left and hypoplastic right vertebra. ILEO-FEMORAL DOPPLER ECOGRAPHY: using colour Doppler the iliac
column19: common/superficial femoral and popliteal arterial systems of both lower limbs
column20: obtaining flow curves with practically normal morphology and velocities in all the paths examined
column21: with only minimal alterations being observed
column22: although in no case compatible with significant stenosis. Conclusions: minimal atheromatous irregularities that in no case produce significant stenosis. Lipid profile pre-apheresis: cholesterol 190 mg/dl. HDL cholesterol 51 mg/dl. LDL cholesterol 117 mg/dl. Triglycerides 110 mg/dl. Apo-A lipoprotein 145 mg/dl. Apo-B Apolipoprotein 128 mg/dl. LDL/HDL 2.3. Lipoprotein 65 mg/dl. Lipid profile post-apheresis: cholesterol 76 mg/dl
column23: HDL-cholesterol 41 mg/dl
column24: LDL-cholesterol 28 mg/dl. Triglycerides 35 mg/dl. Apo-A Apolipoprotein 119 mg/dl. Apo-B Apolipoprotein 33 mg/dl. Last lipid profile: cholesterol 118 mg/dl
column25: HDL-cholesterol 43 mg/dl
column26: LDL-cholesterol 52 mg/dl
column27: triglycerides 115 mg/dl.  CLINICAL COURSE The patient started the LDL apheresis programme in October 2014 with good tolerance
column28: although he reported intense asthenia in the days following the sessions
column29: which gradually improved. In the months following the start of the apheresis programme
column30: the various follow-up visits showed that target LDL cholesterol levels were reached after the apheresis sessions
column31: which remained above target levels during the interapheresis periods
column32: but the patient began to show weight gain and progressive oedematisation from the start of the sessions
column33: with significant fatigue after the sessions
column34: which limited his life. A regular echocardiography was requested with preserved systolic function
column35: known segmental contractility alterations and no significant valvulopathies. Given the regular tolerance to the last sessions
column36: it was decided
column37: together with the patient
column38: to start treatment with a recently marketed anti-PCKS9 drug and to consider ending the LDL apheresis programme if good progress was made. In the following months
column39: after starting treatment with an anti-PCSK9 drug combined with rosuvastatin and ezetimibe
column40: LDL levels of <70 mg/dl were maintained in the inter-apheresis lipid profiles
column41: and so in August 2016 the patient was finally withdrawn from apheresis sessions. Subsequently
column42: he has continued to undergo check-ups in the lipid unit until today
column43: maintaining LDL cholesterol levels below the target levels in secondary prevention without complications or adverse effects related to the drug and allowing the titration of statin doses
column44: as well as without new admissions or consultations for angina.  DIAGNOSIS Heterozygous familial hypercholesterolemia with positive genetic study (M334 mutation) controlled under treatment with an anti-PCSK9 drug. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  BACKGROUND: 47-year-old female patient with the only history of being an active smoker of 10 cigarettes/day (IPA 9) and family history of myotonic dystrophy (MD) type I (Steinert's disease) in her brother and death of her father with no clear etiology. Younger brother aged 37 years with a diagnosis of type I DM; an older son who died at the age of 17
column3: with the same diagnosis and autism spectrum disorder; and a 25-year-old daughter diagnosed with type 1 DM who presented cerebral haemorrhage at birth and is under investigation for long QT.  CURRENT ILLNESS: Referred from neurology with a diagnosis of type I DM to the family heart disease consultation for assessment. She reported asthenia and muscle fatigue with slightly less exertion than usual for the last 2 months. The patient is in New York Heart Association (NYHA) functional class I and otherwise asymptomatic from a cardiovascular point of view.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Normal vital signs. Cardiopulmonary auscultation was normal. Neurological examination showed mild bilateral ptosis
column4: mild facial weakness despite complete ocular closure
column5: generalised hyporeflexia
column6: paresis 4/5 and myotonic buckle. The rest of the examination was unremarkable.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Echocardiogram TT: non-dilated left ventricle (LV) with normal wall thickness
column7: left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) 60-65%
column8: no alterations of segmental contractility
column9: anomalous movement of the septum in relation to conduction disorder
column10: normal transmitral filling pattern
column11: non-dilated right ventricle normocrontractile
column12: non-dilated atria. Aortic
column13: mitral
column14: tricuspid and pulmonary valves morphologically and functionally normal. No signs of pulmonary hypertension. No pericardial effusion. Inferior vena cava not dilated and with collapse greater than 50%. Aorta not dilated and no flow acceleration. ECG: sinus rhythm at 50 beats per minute
column15: PR 220 milliseconds
column16: axis at -30 o
column17: QRS 130 milliseconds with image of left bundle branch conduction disorder
column18: inverted T from V1 to V3
column19: QTc 445 milliseconds. HOLTER: sinus rhythm throughout the recording. Average heart rate 61 bpm. No ventricular or supraventricular arrhythmias. QTc 31% (470-490 msec)
column20: 5% (490-510 msec). ANALYSIS: biochemistry
column21: haemogram and coagulation without findings. GENETIC STUDY: negative for long QT. MYBPC3 p.Arg726Cys
column22: rare variant possibly associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy although with reports of families with second mutations and found in the general population (low frequency).  CLINICAL EVOLUTION In summary
column23: we are dealing with a 47-year-old patient diagnosed with type I DM with a family history of sudden death. In addition
column24: she had a conduction disorder with wide QRS
column25: first-degree atrioventricular block (AVB) and a borderline QT on the Holter monitor. Although the conduction disturbance may influence the duration of the QT interval
column26: there is a small percentage above 490 milliseconds. Conduction study and epinephrine test were requested. Positive epinephrine test (Shimizu protocol): after the bolus there is pathological QTc prolongation up to 566 milliseconds. Throughout the infusion the absolute QT slowly decreases to baseline values. Electrophysiological study: diagnostic quadripolar catheters are placed in the right atrium
column27: His and right ventricular apex. Abnormal basal intervals (HV 78 milliseconds). Basally poor AV conduction with Wenckebach point at 78 bpm
column28: concentric and decremental. Absence of V-A conduction. Due to the results of the previous tests
column29: it was decided to implant a bicameral implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) after cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to complete the study. After ICD implantation
column30: treatment was started with 1.25 mg of bisoprolol every 24 hours. Cardiac MRI showed a slightly dilated but not hypertrophic LV
column31: with preserved systolic function (LVEF 55%) and no intramyocardial late enhancement or other alterations of interest. From the point of view of relatives
column32: a long QT panel was performed
column33: which was negative.  DIAGNOSIS Myotonic dystrophy type 1 (Steinert's disease). Absence of significant structural heart disease on TT echocardiogram and cardiac MRI. Long QT syndrome probably associated with DM. First-degree history of sudden death
column34: probably arrhythmic. Significant nodal conduction disorder and His-Purkinje system with implantation of bicameral ICD. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 51-year-old woman with no known drug allergies
column3: no cardiovascular risk factors.  Cardiological history: Ebstein's anomaly type congenital heart disease. Wolff- Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW) diagnosed at 18 years of age. Followed in cardiology outpatient clinic
column4: in usual New York Heart Association (NYHA) functional class II-III/IV. Episodes of orthodromic paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). Holter study (October/2016): sinus rhythm without arrhythmic events. She does not take any treatment on a regular basis. Admitted to a regional hospital due to progressive worsening of his functional class in the last 3 months with progressive dyspnoea until becoming minimal effort. She reported a case of upper respiratory tract infection (one month prior to admission)
column5: coinciding with worsening dyspnoea until she was at rest and orthopnoea. No other symptoms. During his admission to El Bierzo Hospital
column6: depletive treatment was started for congestive heart failure with a tendency to hypotension. Transfer to our centre was requested to complete studies and assess treatment options. When assessed in our department
column7: she reported intense asthenia with improvement in dyspnoea. Blood pressure 124/88 mmHg
column8: heart rate 80 bpm. Cyanosis. Acropaquias. Basal oxygen saturation in the supine position 80%
column9: in the sitting position 65%. Jugular venous pressure normal. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column10: systolic murmur in tricuspid focus III/VI
column11: holosystolic. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur without added noise. Abdomen soft
column12: depressible
column13: not painful on palpation. No palpation of hepatomegaly or other masses. Lower extremities without oedema
column14: no signs of deep vein thrombosis and symmetrical peripheral pulses.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ELECTROCARDIOGRAM (ECG): sinus rhythm at 75 bpm. PR 200ms. Qtc 480ms. Right bundle branch block (RBBB). Predominance of positive P wave component in V1. THORAX RADIOGRAPHY: cardiomegaly
column15: without signs of vascular redistribution. Free costophrenic sinuses. No condensation. ANALYSIS: haemogram: leucocytes 9000 mil/mm3 (N 78%
column17: Hb 13.9 g/dl
column18: haematocrit 41.7%. MCV 92.4 fl
column19: platelets 114000/mm3
column20: haptoglobin 100 mg%. Coagulation: INR 1.2
column21: PT 72%
column22: TTPa 32 seconds. Biochemistry: glucose 87 mg/dl
column23: urea 30 mg/dl
column24: creatinine 0.98 mg/dl (FG 60)
column25: total cholesterol 108 mg/dl
column26: HDL 31 mg/dl
column27: LDL 64 mg/dl
column28: triglycerides 64 mg/dl
column29: GOT 24 U/l
column30: GPT 2624U/l
column31: total bilirubin 0.72 mg/dl
column32: NT-proBNP 207 pg/ml. Arterial blood gases: pH 7.53
column34: PO2 51
column35: bicarbonate 25.2. Echocardiogram: severely dilated right ventricle with depressed contractility. Normal sized left ventricle with preserved function. Severely dilated right atrium (RA) with interventricular septum bulging to the left. Thin leaflet pulmonary valve with normal opening. Post-valvular flow of 1 m/s with symmetrical branch Doppler flow. Tricuspid valve with Ebstein's morphology
column36: more apical implantation of the septal leaflet
column37: 48 mm from the mitral annulus
column38: with IV/IV regurgitation. Triangular morphology in spectral Doppler
column39: with maximum velocity of 2.4 m/sg. Normal mitral and aortic valves. After the injection of agitated saline
column40: there was abundant spontaneous passage of bubbles to the left cavities
column41: presenting syncope during the procedure
column42: with subsequent progressive recovery and headache. No obvious atrial septal defect (ASD) was observed
column43: so it was attributed to PFO. Conclusion: Ebstein's disease
column44: IV/IV tricuspid regurgitation with ventricular dysfunction
column45: right-to-left shunt due to probable PFO. HEMODYNAMIC STUDY (right femoral artery): ventriculography shows right-left shunt. After temporary occlusion of the defect with a balloon
column46: it was found that the pressures in the right atrium did not increase and the arterial pressures did not fall. With the use of a 35 mm Amplatzer FOP Tribiform MF 35 mm device
column47: the defect is almost completely occluded
column48: with minimal residual shunt
column49: with arterial saturation from 81% to 99% (video 4). No complications. Under control with intracardiac echocardiography and transesophageal echocardiography (TEE)
column50: an 18 mm balloon test was performed
column51: showing no significant haemodynamic changes (blood pressure and right atrial pressure).  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was admitted to complete the study due to progressive worsening of functional class. An echocardiographic study showed significant right-to-left interatrial shunt suggestive of PFO with platypnoea-ortodesoxia behaviour. With these results
column52: it was decided to perform a percutaneous technique on PFO. Prior to definitive closure
column53: haemodynamic response was assessed with transient balloon closure
column54: which was favourable
column55: so a 35 mm Amplatzer cribriform closure device was implanted
column56: with good final results and arterial saturation increased from 81% baseline to 99%. Post-procedure
column57: the patient was stable and asymptomatic
column58: with improvement in functional class and baseline saturation
column59: and it was decided to transfer her to her hospital of reference.  DIAGNOSIS Platypnoea-ortodesoxia syndrome. PFO with significant spontaneous right-left shunt. Congenital heart disease of the Ebstein's anomaly type. Global respiratory failure secondary to intracardiac shunt
column60: resolved. Implantation of a percutaneous Amplatzer cribriform 35 mm PFO closure device. Massive tricuspid regurgitation with no signs of pulmonary hypertension. Preserved LVEF. Intermittent WPW syndrome. Episodes of orthodromic TPSV. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  Personal history 53-year-old male
column3: active
column4: civil servant. He had no drug allergies
column5: had smoked sporadically (1-2 packs/year accumulated) and was diagnosed with mild arterial hypertension
column6: with no other associated cardiovascular risk factors. He took omeprazole on demand for occasional dyspepsia
column7: but did not take any treatment on a regular basis.  Current history She consulted her primary care physician for several episodes of oppressive central thoracic pain
column8: of sudden onset
column9: at rest
column10: lasting a few minutes. The pain is not related to meals
column11: does not change with respiratory movements or postural changes and is accompanied only by mild sweating. He was prescribed treatment with acetylsalicylic acid 100 mg (1-0-0)
column12: bisoprolol 2.5 mg (1-0-1)
column13: omeprazole 20 mg (1-0-0) and sublingual nitroglycerin on demand and was referred to the Cardiology Department. He went to the emergency department a few days later because the symptoms persisted despite treatment. With the use of nitroglycerine
column14: the duration was shorter
column15: but not the frequency; he reported up to 7 episodes in the last 3 weeks
column16: with a clear predominance at night.  Physical examination in the emergency department Blood pressure: 145/89 mmHg. Heart rate 60 beats per minute
column17: basal oxygen saturation 100%. Temperature 36.5°C. Good general condition. Conscious
column18: oriented
column19: cooperative. Eupneic at rest. Not hydrated. Normal colour. Jugular venous pressure normal. Carotid rhythmic
column20: no murmurs. Cardiac auscultation rhythmic without murmurs
column21: friction rubs or extratonos. Pulmonary auscultation with preserved vesicular murmur
column22: without extra sounds. Abdomen with no notable alterations. Lower extremities normal. Peripheral pulses present and symmetrical.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS  Emergency ECG: sinus rhythm at 55 bpm
column23: normal PR
column24: narrow QRS
column25: without repolarisation alterations.  Emergency laboratory tests: haemoglobin 15.8 g/dl
column26: leukocytes 8
column27: 650/mm3 (normal formula)
column28: platelets 212
column29: 000/mm3. Coagulation: prothrombin rate 91 %
column30: activated partial thromboplastin time 26.6 s
column31: fibrinogen 309 mg/dl. Biochemistry: glucose 113 mg/dl
column33: creatinine 1.13 mg/dl
column34: sodium 140 mEq/l
column35: potassium 3.4 mEq/l
column36: serial troponin I 0.00 ng/ml.  Chest X-ray in the emergency department: normal.  Echocardioscopy in the ED: left ventricle of normal size and overall systolic function
column37: without alterations in segmental contractility. Right ventricle of normal size and systolic function Normal atria. Absence of significant valvular heart disease. Visible segments of the great vessels normal. Normal pericardium.  Stress test: discontinued at minute 10.50 of the Bruce protocol (11.80 METS) for reaching the maximum theoretical heart rate. Normal blood pressure and chronotropic response. No arrhythmias were recorded. Conclusion: clinically and electrically negative for ischaemia.  Holter ECG of events of 10 days duration: coinciding with an episode of chest pain identical to the previous ones
column38: ST segment elevation of a few minutes duration is recorded
column39: as well as frequent supraventricular and ventricular extrasystoles.  CT scan of the coronary arteries: calcium score 191. Calcific plaques were seen in the proximal third of the anterior descending and circumflex arteries that did not cause significant stenosis
column40: as well as soft plaque in the middle third of the anterior descending artery that caused 50% stenosis.  EVOLUTION During his stay in the ED
column41: the patient remained asymptomatic and haemodynamically stable at all times. Serial myocardial damage markers were negative. He was assessed by the on-call Cardiology team
column42: who performed echocardioscopy where no alterations were observed. In view of the characteristics of the episodes
column43: the possibility of coronary vasospasm was raised
column44: so nitrates were added to his treatment and it was decided to complete the study on an outpatient basis. Admission was not considered necessary because the episodes of pain had not increased in intensity or duration and were not accompanied by palpitations
column45: dizziness or syncope. The Holter recording of long-term events two weeks later showed transient ST-segment elevation coinciding with a new episode of chest pain
column46: identical to the previous ones
column47: confirming the diagnosis of coronary vasospasm. Bisoprolol was discontinued (the patient had already discontinued nitrates due to headache and acetylsalicylic acid due to dyspepsia) and diltiazem was started at a dose of 120 mg every 12 hours. Given that he did not perform strenuous physical exertion
column48: ergometry was requested
column49: which was clinically and electrically negative for ischaemia. Despite this result
column50: in order to rule out underlying obstructive coronary lesions with greater certainty
column51: a CT scan of the coronary arteries was performed
column52: which showed non-significant stenosis in the anterior descending and circumflex arteries
column53: and simvastatin was added to his treatment at a dose of 20 mg daily. The patient has progressed well
column54: with no recurrence of symptoms to date. It is explained to him that in order to avoid new episodes as far as possible
column55: it is essential that he abstains from smoking and adheres to the pharmacological treatment.  DIAGNOSIS Vasospastic angina. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 60 year old patient who attended the Emergency Department on 26/08/2016 due to pain in the right lower limb  Personal history Intolerance to amoxicillin-clavulanic acid. Arterial hypertension under pharmacological treatment with poor control. Dyslipidaemia under pharmacological treatment. Anxiety syndrome.  Cardiological history: paroxysmal atrial fibrillation diagnosed on 01/08/2016 with CHA2DS2-VASc = 2 and HAS-BLED = 1. Treatment was started with beta-blockers and acenocoumarol. Echocardiogram: LVEF 60%. LA dilatation. Mild mitral stenosis. Episode of mild heart failure in the context of AF with rapid ventricular response on 13/08/2016 which was treated in the emergency department with diuretics and digoxin.  Current illness The patient came to the ED with pain
column3: coldness and functional impotence of the right lower limb.  Physical examination BP 178/99 mmHg
column4: HR 109 bpm
column5: SatO2 99 %. Cardiac auscultation: arrhythmic sounds at 110 bpm with systolic murmur II/VI with preserved 2R. Pulmonary auscultation: minimal bibasal crackles. Right lower extremity: decreased pulse and coldness in MID with intense pain on palpation.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Blood tests: urea 24 mg/dl
column6: creatinine 0.89 mg/dl
column7: Na 139 mmol/L
column8: K 3.9 mmol/L
column9: Hb 15.8 g/dL
column11: platelets 396
column13: INR 1.47. D-dimer > 5000 ug/L. ECG: atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response at 120 bpm. ST segment rectification with data of LV overload and negative T wave in DIII and aVF. Chest X-ray: cardiomegaly. Congestive hilae. Vascular redistribution. No condensation or pinching of costophrenic sinuses. MID Doppler ultrasound: decreased monophasic blood flow in the superficial femoral artery with echogenic material partially filling the lumen of the artery. The flow decreases even more in intensity in the distal arteries without being detected in the distal posterior tibial and anterior pedial arteries. Conclusion: MID arterial ischaemia due to thrombosis. Ultrasound Doppler MII: occupation of the left popliteal a. Popliteal left by echogenic material not in its entirety without flow in Doppler study and with post-stenotic morphology at the level of posterior tibial artery. Conclusion: arterial ischaemia in popliteal artery. Cranial/perfusion computed tomography: acute ischaemic stroke in the left MCA territory secondary to carotid occlusion of the ICA
column14: ICA
column15: IMCA-M1 and ACA-A1 of cardioembolic profile with mismatch 30%. Angio-CT: floating thrombus at the level of the aortic arch distal to the ICA exit occluding the origin of the left subclavian artery. Echocardiography: moderate mitral stenosis of rheumatic aspect. Severe dilatation of the left atrium. LVEF 60%. Aortic sclerosis.  EVOLUTION Given that the patient presented pain and coldness in the right lower limb (MID)
column16: a Doppler ultrasound of the lower limbs was performed which confirmed acute arterial ischaemia due to thrombotic occlusion at the level of the right superficial femoral artery. Treatment was started with intravenous sodium heparin and contact was made with Cardiovascular Surgery at the referral hospital and the patient was referred for evaluation. On arrival
column17: given that the patient showed signs of acute ischaemia of the entire limb despite perfusion
column18: mechanical embolectomy was performed with dissection of the right femoral tripod and MID embolectomy with Fogarty catheter associated with heparin lavage
column19: haemostasis and closure. At 24 hours
column20: the patient remained haemodynamically stable and a repeat Doppler ultrasound scan was performed with recovery of biphasic flow at femoral level. A review of the patient's INR since the start of anticoagulation had presented INR < 2 with time in therapeutic range of 0 %. Despite having suffered an embolic event with a SAMe-TT2R2 = 2 (which already predicts that the patient will have poor quality anticoagulation with antivitamin K)
column21: CHA2DS2-VASc = 4 and HAS-BLED = 2
column22: it was decided to maintain treatment at discharge with acenocoumarol. On 19/02/2017 the patient returned to the emergency department for pain
column23: coldness and functional impotence in the left lower limb
column24: this time with absence of distal pulse. An echo Doppler of the MII was performed and showed arterial ischaemia in the popliteal artery. Given that the occlusion was at a more distal level and the echogenic material did not occlude the lumen completely
column25: intravenous sodium heparin perfusion was started. On the 5th day of admission (24/02/0217) the patient suddenly presented pain and coldness in the left upper limb and 1 hour later presented dysarthria with haemiplegia of the right limbs. On suspicion of intracranial bleeding in the context of intravenous sodium heparin perfusion
column26: a cranial CT scan was performed which ruled out intracranial bleeding. In the following hours
column27: the patient presented a sudden deterioration in the level of consciousness with aphasia and left gaze deviation. With suspicion of stroke in the left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory
column28: the Stroke Code was activated (NIHSS = 22) and the patient was referred to the reference hospital. On arrival
column29: a brain CT scan was performed which confirmed acute ischaemic stroke in the left MCA territory secondary to carotid occlusion of the ICA-MCA. However
column30: the angio-CT scan also showed a floating thrombus at the level of the aortic arch distal to the exit of the LMCA (left common carotid artery) occluding the subclavian artery. Given the seriousness of the patient and the fact that she was being treated with sodium heparin
column31: it was decided to perform a primary mechanical intra-arterial thrombectomy with aspiration of the cervical thrombus and fragments at the level of the LMCA-ICCA. A control CT scan showed extensive infarction with mass effect that improved progressively over the following days in the ICU
column32: with improvement in aphasia but with right hemiplegia remaining as a sequela on discharge. At the MSI level
column33: there was an improvement in arterial ischaemia and pulse recovery
column34: so conservative management was decided. However
column35: there was no improvement in the MII
column36: presenting a very weak femoral and popliteal pulse with absence at distal level
column37: so it was decided to perform arterial thrombectomy with dissection of the left femoral tripod and extraction of thrombotic material at the left femoro-popliteal level with a Fogarty catheter. Cardiologically
column38: the patient initially showed signs of decompensated heart failure due to rapid AF that improved with diuretics and beta-blockade. Echocardiography was performed and showed moderate rheumatic mitral stenosis with severe dilatation of the left atrium and normal LVEF. All INRs were reviewed since discharge in August 2016 and only 2 of them were in therapeutic range with a TRT of 0%.  DIAGNOSIS Ischaemic stroke in the middle cerebral artery territory secondary to tandem ICA-MCA occlusion with a cardioembolic profile. Floating thrombus at the level of the arch with occlusion of origin of the left subclavian artery. Acute arterial ischaemia of MSI with spontaneous resolution. Acute arterial ischaemia of IIM resolved with mechanical thrombectomy with Fogarty catheter. Acute arterial ischaemia of MID resolved with mechanical thrombectomy with Fogarty catheter. Moderate rheumatic mitral stenosis with normal LVEF. Permanent atrial fibrillation: CHA2DS2-VASc = 4
column39: HAS-BLED = 3
column40: SAMe- TT2R2 = 2. Poor quality of anticoagulation with antivitamin K. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION The patient is a 68-year-old male with hypertension
column3: dyslipidaemia and World Health Organisation (WHO) grade 1 obesity. The patient also suffers from type 2 diabetes mellitus
column4: being treated with insulin on a bolus-basal regimen (lantus 60 IU daily)
column5: but with suboptimal control (HbA1C 8.6%). He had been an ex-smoker for 3 years with a P/A index of 40. His past history included chronic ischaemic heart disease with three-vessel coronary artery disease revascularised on multiple occasions. He had made his debut in 1998 with an inferior infarction revascularised with primary angioplasty to the right coronary artery
column6: and after a non-ST-segment elevation acute myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) in March 2009
column7: percutaneous revascularisation was performed with drug-eluting stents in the anterior descending (DA)
column8: native right coronary (CD) and circumflex (Cx) arteries. He had previously been rejected for revascularisation surgery due to poor distal vascular beds. He presented new acute episodes in August 2011
column9: July 2012 and January 2013
column10: with stent implantation in de novo lesions and on one occasion on a restenosis of the stent previously implanted in the proximal Cx. In the intercurrent period
column11: the patient had stable exertional angina
column12: whose threshold had been slowly and progressively shortening despite antianginal treatment until reaching CCS functional class III/IV. In addition
column13: his micro- and macrovascular metadiabetic involvement included polyneuropathy
column14: stage IIIb chronic kidney disease
column15: and chronic lower limb ischaemia with bilateral femoropopliteal occlusion treated percutaneously on several occasions. Finally
column16: in relation to moderate COPD with an exacerbating phenotype and severe SAHS
column17: he was being treated with inhalers
column18: home oxygen 16 hours a day and nocturnal CPAP. He was admitted to Cardiology after surgery for amputation of the 4th and 5th left metatarsophalangeal joints in the context of comprehensive treatment of diabetic foot. Despite the favourable postoperative evolution
column19: the patient presented daily episodes of rest angina triggered by foot pain
column20: poorly controlled despite the use of opioids. Physical examination revealed a good general condition
column21: and the patient was eupneic. Vital signs were: BP 120/60 mmHg
column22: HR 70 bpm
column23: SatO2 with GN at 2 bpm 92 %. Cardiopulmonary auscultation was unremarkable
column24: there was no oedema in the lower limbs and the left 1st and 2nd fingers had established erythrocyanosis
column25: together with necrotic lesions at the apex. The 3rd finger also had a necrotic lesion of 0.5 cm diameter.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: sinus rhythm at 60 bpm
column26: 1st degree BAV
column27: QRS 110 ms with HBAI
column28: ST rectification in I
column29: aVL
column30: V5-V6
column31: similar to previous ones. No changes with and without pain. Blood tests: Hb 10 g/dl
column34: platelets and coagulation normal
column35: creatinine 1.65 mg/dl
column36: ions normal
column37: troponin T serum US 26 - 25 (normal < 10 ng/l)
column38: CK and CK-MB normal. Echocardiogram: left ventricle not dilated
column39: with slightly increased wall thickness. Inferior basal akinesia and basal and medial segments of inferior lateral face. Hypokinesia of the inferior septum. Ejection fraction at the lower limit of normal (52%). Pseudonormalised transmitral filling pattern. Non-dilated right ventricle
column40: with normal global systolic function. No significant valvular heart disease. Inferior vena cava not dilated with physiological inspiratory collapse. No pericardial effusion. Aortic root not dilated. Coronary angiography: previously implanted patent stents. Multivessel coronary artery disease with poor distal beds
column41: thin calibre and diffuse disease
column42: not subsidiary of new revascularisation.  EVOLUTION Local treatment of the diabetic foot was carried out
column43: the antibiotic cycle was completed and antianginal medication was titrated
column44: and the patient tolerated bisoprolol 10 mg/day
column45: amlodipine 10 mg/day
column46: Uniket retard 50 mg/day
column47: ranolazine 750 mg/12 h and ivabradine 5 mg/12 h. From the analgesic point of view
column48: he is tolerating paracetamol c/8 h
column49: metamizole 1c/8 h
column50: fentanyl patches 75 mcg/72 h
column51: and rescue morphine and sublingual NTG. Despite some symptomatic improvement
column52: he continued to present very limiting mild exertional angina
column53: with peaks of pain in the lower extremities that were difficult to control
column54: requiring constant use of rescue medication. Having ruled out the possibility of further revascularisation
column55: spinal cord stimulation therapy was chosen with two posterior epidural electrodes at cervicothoracic (C7-T4) and lumbar (T9-L2) levels for angina and diabetic foot with chronic ischaemia
column56: respectively. With these devices
column57: a generator was placed in a subcutaneous pocket at left flank level. Subsequent evolution after implantation was favourable
column58: allowing angina-free daily activity at discharge
column59: avoiding intense physical activity and overexertion.  DIAGNOSIS Chronic ischaemic heart disease with mixed percutaneous and surgical revascularisation of three-vessel disease. Diffuse tertiary vessel disease. Refractory angina. Chronic lower limb ischaemia. Diabetic foot. Chronic renal disease. COPD with chronic home oxygen. SAHS with CPAP. Type 2 insulin-dependent diabetes. HYPERTENSION. Dyslipidaemia. Obesity. In the long-term evolution he had stable angina in CF II-III/IV of the CCS and the need for left infrapopliteal amputation one year later. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 72-year-old woman with a history of permanent atrial fibrillation
column3: anticoagulated with acenocoumarol
column4: without structural heart disease in previous echocardiograms. She consulted for months of chest pain on exertion compatible with typical angina on usual exertion. Acetylsalicylic acid was started and ambulatory exercise testing was requested. No findings on initial physical examination. Admitted for coronary angiography due to ergometry findings.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: sinus rhythm
column5: narrow QRS with normal axis
column6: normal repolarisation. Blood tests: biochemistry and haemogram parameters in range. Myocardial damage markers not elevated. Chest X-ray: normal cardiothoracic index. No mediastinal widening. No acute pleuroparenchymal pathology. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE): left ventricle neither dilated nor hypertrophic. Normal segmental contractility and systolic function. Mitral filling with normal pattern for his age. Normal right ventricle and atria. Aneurysm of the interatrial septum without evidence of shunt by Doppler. No significant valvulopathies. Estimated PSP of 21 mmHg. No pericardial effusion. Ergometry: stopped at minute 3 of the Bruce protocol due to limiting angina. Clinically positive (anginal chest pain and dyspnoea) from minute 1:30
column7: which becomes limiting at minute 3 and persists on recovery for 3 minutes. Electrically negative to charges reached. No arrhythmias. Normal blood pressure response. Severely limited functional class (4 METS). Coronary angiography: common trunk: no lesions. Anterior descending artery: vessel of good calibre and development
column8: with calcium
column9: without significant stenosis. Bordering the tip. Circumflex artery. Non-dominant
column10: without significant lesions. Right coronary artery: severely calcified from the ostium to the distal segment
column11: with subtotal stenosis at the beginning of the middle segment and distal TIMI 2 flow. The distal vessel receives heterocoronary collateral circulation.  EVOLUTION After performing diagnostic coronary angiography
column12: in the presence of critical stenosis of the right coronary artery with reduced flow
column13: ad hoc angioplasty was decided
column14: administering clopidogrel in the haemodynamics room. An attempt was made to cross the lesion with guidewires with increasing crossing and penetration capacity
column15: given that the lesion behaved like a chronic occlusion (BMW
column16: Miracle 3
column17: Pilot 150 and Confianza Pro). Support is increased with a 1.5F coaxial balloon catheter
column18: but only a false lumen is achieved
column19: causing dissection with an image of contrast retention in the arterial wall
column20: without images suggestive of leakage and with complete occlusion of the artery at the level of the lesion. The patient noted slight precordial pressure which subsided with 2 mg of Cl morphine. No changes were observed in the 12-lead ECG at the end of the procedure. She also presented generalised rash
column21: suggesting allergy to iodinated contrast agent
column22: which appeared to be controlled after administration of intravenous corticosteroid and antihistamine. He was transferred to the Coronary Care Unit for close monitoring
column23: and an urgent transthoracic echocardiogram was performed
column24: showing normal biventricular systolic function with no significant findings (highlighting the absence of pericardial effusion). The evolution was favourable
column25: with no recurrence of chest pain
column26: with progressive resolution of the allergic symptoms and with discrete elevation of biomarkers without changes in serum levels
column27: and the patient was transferred to the conventional hospital ward the following day. Neither double antiplatelet therapy nor anticoagulation was suspended
column28: given that the information transmitted was of occlusive coronary dissection and not perforation. Forty-eight hours after the procedure
column29: the patient reported chest pain that initially appeared to have an angina profile
column30: with constants in range
column31: so an ECG was performed with no signs of ischaemia and intravenous NTG perfusion was started
column33: general malaise and signs of hypoperfusion
column34: which persisted despite withdrawal of NTG. Urgent TTE was performed
column35: showing pericardial effusion with echocardiographic signs of tamponade
column36: an image suggestive of fibrin deposition at the level of the right AV groove and dyskinesia of the basal portion of the right ventricular free wall. Serum therapy was started
column37: the patient was transferred back to the Coronary Unit and urgent pericardiocentesis was performed with extraction of fluid with a haematic appearance until stabilisation
column38: with subsequent drainage and suspension of antithrombotic treatment. New instability a few hours after placing the pericardial drain
column39: with electromechanical dissociation
column40: with echocardiographic evidence of retapositioning that persisted despite repositioning the drain
column41: with the need for orotracheal intubation due to a low level of consciousness. Cardiac surgery was contacted for urgent surgical pericardial drainage and the time interval was used to perform a transesophageal echocardiogram with the same findings in the right AV groove and basal portion of the RV
column42: without loss of continuity or evidence of flow through the RV myocardium. After pericardial drainage and evacuation of abundant haematic fluid by median sternotomy
column43: a large thrombus was observed adhered to the right AV groove with no active bleeding and haematoma in the basal region of the RV free wall and in the RA
column44: suggestive of dissection of the right AV groove. On leaving the operating theatre
column45: the patient persisted with great haemodynamic instability
column46: so TTE was repeated
column47: ruling out cardiac tamponade but showing severe RV dysfunction with extension of dyskinesia and hyper-refringence to mid-basal portions of the RV free wall
column48: leading to severe systolic dysfunction of the same. Finally
column49: the indication for circulatory assistance was ruled out and it was decided to limit therapeutic effort
column50: and the patient died within a short period of time.  DIAGNOSIS Coronary dissection versus iatrogenic perforation by angioplasty guidewire of the right AV groove. Acute cardiac tamponade. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  We present a 49-year-old male
column3: with no previous allergies
column4: who consulted the emergency department for a condition compatible with an allergic reaction.  History Cardiovascular risk factors: smoker of 15 cigarettes a day. No hypertension
column5: diabetes or dyslipidaemia. No known cardiological history. As other history
column6: he is diagnosed with moderate COPD: spirometry: FVC 3.27 L ( 68 %) FEV1 1.90 l ( 51 %)
column7: FEV1 % 58 % moderate obstructive disorder. Volumes: TGV 5.51 L (147 %)
column9: RV 4.76 L (204 %) RV/TLC 56 %). Hyperinflation with air trapping. DLCO 27/88 (91 %). Chronic treatment with inhalers: tiotropium 1 inhalation every 24 hours
column10: budesonide/formoterol 1 inhalation every 12 hours and salbutamol on demand.  Present illness Patient suffers a casual fall
column11: hitting his side and right arm
column12: and decides to take the usual analgesia (Nolotil). He then began to experience pruritus
column13: generalised rash and very intense dyspnoea. He was taken by ambulance to the hospital emergency room. The patient arrived at the ED with great difficulty in breathing
column14: so immediate treatment with corticosteroids
column15: salbutamol and antihistamines was started
column16: with significant improvement in clinical symptoms and oxygen saturation. When the patient was able to speak (after improvement of his dyspnoea)
column17: he reported having started with chest pain of intensity 10/10 and an ECG was performed.  Physical examination Afebrile (36.8°C). BP 135/90
column18: HR 80
column19: eupneic (after treatment)
column20: rash on face and trunk. AC: RsCsRs without murmurs AP: VCM
column21: some isolated expiratory wheezing (after treatment). Abdomen soft
column22: non-painful
column23: without masses or megaliths. EEEII without oedema and with positive paedial pulses.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Laboratory tests on admission: biochemistry: glucose 202 mg/dl
column24: urea 25 mg/dl
column25: creatinine 0.87 mg/dl
column26: sodium ion 140 mmol/l 136 - 145
column27: alanine aminotransferase 8 U/l
column28: total bilirubin < 1.0 mg/dl. CBC: red blood cells 4.78 x10^6/μL
column29: haemoglobin 16.7 g/dl
column30: haematocrit 47.5 %
column31: V.C.M 99.4 fl

column2: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION The patient is a 61-year-old woman
column3: a former smoker
column4: recently diagnosed with LADA type 1 autoimmune diabetes mellitus
column5: dyslipidaemic
column6: with a history of spinocerebellar ataxia
column7: who consulted the emergency department due to a non-productive cough and a feeling of dystrophy that had been evolving for days. She was haemodynamically stable
column8: hypertensive (BP 189/114 mmHg)
column9: sinus tachycardia at 130 bpm
column10: tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 30 rpm at rest
column11: without tugging
column12: and oxygen saturation of 94% with Ventimask 40%
column13: flapping and afebrile. ECG with sinus rhythm without repolarisation alterations. The physical examination showed evidence of severe bronchospasm on respiratory auscultation and cardiac auscultation with rhythmic twists without murmurs. The rest of the patient had no pathological findings.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Emergency ECG: sinus rhythm at 70 bpm
column14: PR 140 ms
column15: narrow QRS QTc 448 ms without repolarisation alterations. ICU ECG: sinus rhythm at 78 bpm
column16: PR 140 ms
column17: narrow QRS
column18: QTc 579 ms diffuse symmetrical negative T waves. ED ABG: pH 7.18; PCO2 79.9 mmHg; PO2 142.3 mmHg; bicarbonate 29.6 mmol/l; BS 1.4; SaO2 98 %. Serial troponin I: 0.12- 1.45-2.51- 3.4- 2.8 ng/ml. Emergency blood tests: creatinine 0.73 mg/dl; urea 54 mg/dl; haemoglobin 13.2 g/dl; haematocrit 42.3 %; leucocytes 23
column19: 000/μl; CRP 2.4 mg/dl. Blood tests during admission to Cardiology: highlights: HbA1C 7.1 mg/dl
column20: total cholesterol 172 mg/dl
column21: HDL 49mg/dl
column22: LDL 91.58 mg/dl. Normal thyroid profile; D-Dimer 571 ng/Ml. Chest X-ray in ICU: hilar thickening. Apical redistribution. Transthoracic echocardiography: LV appears normal in size
column23: slightly increased wall thickness
column24: hyperdynamic symmetrical contractility. Normal LVEF. LA of normal size. RV of normal size and function. RA of normal size. IVC of normal size with inspiratory collapse greater than 50%. No pericardial effusion. Aortic root of normal size. VAo trivalva
column25: appears to open correctly. MV with thin leaflets
column26: correct kinetics. Competent. No IT detected. PV visualised subcostal
column27: appears to have normal echostructure and flow. LV findings of normal size and function. LA normal. RV of normal size and function. RA of normal size and function. No significant valvulopathies are appreciated by this study route. Signs of normal PVC. No pericardial effusion. Cardiac magnetic resonance: LV of normal size
column28: normal walls
column29: symmetrical contractility. Normal LVEF. LA normal size. RV of normal size and function. RA of normal size. No significant valvulopathies. Mild pericardial effusion. No evidence of oedema or abnormalities in gadolinium uptake. Catheterisation: right dominance. Coronary arteries without angiographic lesions with normal flow.   EVOLUTION He progressed with progressive respiratory failure and hypertensive crisis
column30: starting intravenous diuretic treatment
column31: non-invasive mechanical ventilation
column33: bronchodilators and intravenous corticoids
column34: and was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit
column35: with early improvement and early withdrawal of ventilatory support. During his stay with early improvement and withdrawal of ventilatory support
column36: an ECG with diffuse symmetrical T-negatives with elongated QTc and peak troponin 3.4 ng/ml was observed in this context. An echocardiogram was performed showing a slightly hypertrophic LV with preserved EF without clear segmentarism
column37: and the patient was initially referred to STEMI Killip II and started on double antiplatelet therapy and anticoagulation. Cardiology was consulted
column38: and given the possibility of type 2 AMI secondary to hypertensive crisis and bronchospasm in a patient with cardiovascular risk factors as opposed to type 1 AMI without clear alterations in the echocardiogram
column39: the patient was referred to Cardiology and it was decided to perform coronary angiography
column40: which showed no coronary lesions. In order to rule out other causes of myocardial necrosis without coronary lesions
column41: cardiac magnetic resonance imaging was requested
column42: which was compatible with normality. Since no evidence was found of transient global or segmental ventricular function impairment
column43: it was decided to withdraw double antiplatelet therapy and the most likely diagnosis was type 2 myocardial infarction in the context of respiratory infection with severe bronchospasm. After several days of hospitalisation
column44: she was discharged home without incident.  DIAGNOSIS Respiratory infection with severe bronchospasm. Type 2 myocardial infarction.
