column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  Personal history 18-year-old woman. No known drug allergies. No toxic habits. Cardiological history: under follow-up in general cardiology consultations for mild mitral insufficiency secondary to mitral prolapse; asymptomatic with preserved biventricular systolic function. G1P1A0. Instrumented delivery (vacuum extraction) with epidural anaesthesia on 23 January due to premature rupture of membranes at 40.3 weeks' gestation.  Present illness The 18-year-old patient consulted for two days presenting with erratic episodes of oppressive
column3: non-radiating
column4: central thoracic pain lasting 15-20 minutes. No catarrhal or diarrhoeal symptoms in previous days. Under treatment with bromocriptine since 27 January.  Physical examination BP 123/71. HR 77 beats per minute. Ta 36°C. Conscious
column5: oriented
column6: good distal perfusion. Good general condition. Eupneic on room air without supplementary oxygen. Tolerating decubitus. Head and neck: No IVY
column7: no negative hepatojugular reflux. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column8: with a mesosystolic murmur II/IV predominantly in the apex. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur
column9: without added phenomena. Abdomen: soft
column10: depressible
column11: not painful on palpation. Extremities: no oedema
column12: no evidence of deep vein thrombosis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: sinus rhythm at 82 beats per minute. ST elevation in DII
column13: DIII and avF. Specular decrease in V2-v3 and aVL. Control ECG: correction of previously described changes. Blood tests: Leukocytes 13200 (N 69.4%
column16: platelets 349
column17: 000. D Dimer 106. Urea 21. Crreat 0.6. Na 136. K 3.9. Coagulation normal. Markers of myocardial damage: 1st determination of TnI: 4.95 ng/ml. 2nd determination: 12.5 ng/ml (peak) (normal values less than 0.017 ng/ml) Chest X-ray: no evidence of acute pleuropulmonary pathology. Cardiopericardial silhouette at the limit of normality. TTE: non-dilated
column18: non-hypertrophic left ventricle with preserved global and segmental LVEF. Normal diastolic pattern. Mitral insufficiency due to mild posterior leaflet prolapse. Trivalve aortic valve
column19: without transvalvular gradient or significant insufficiency. Normal right chambers. No tricuspid insufficiency. No pericardial effusion. Inspiratory collapse of superior vena cava > 50% with respiration. Coronary angiography: left coronary tree: LMCA without angiographically significant lesions. Anterior descending artery without significant lesions. Circumflex without angiographically significant lesions. Right dominance. Right coronary artery without angiographically significant lesions.  EVOLUTION The patient was admitted to the Coronary Unit with a diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome with transient ST-segment elevation (suprathreshold is documented in the ECG at the health centre
column20: with correction of changes in the ECG on arrival at our regional hospital) and treatment with bromocriptine was suspended. A transthoracic echocardiogram was performed
column21: showing preserved global and segmental left ventricular systolic function
column22: with mitral insufficiency due to mitral prolapse already known. Coronary angiography was performed in the first 24 hours
column23: according to ESC guidelines recommendations
column24: in which angiographically significant coronary lesions were ruled out. The patient's evolution was favourable
column25: remaining haemodynamically stable
column26: with no arrhythmic or mechanical complications
column27: and asymptomatic from the cardiovascular point of view.  DIAGNOSIS Acute coronary syndrome with transient ST-segment elevation. Killip 1. Coronary vasospasm secondary to bromocriptine. Preserved left ventricular systolic function. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  A 52-year-old female smoker
column3: with no history of hypertension
column4: diabetes mellitus or dyslipidaemia. She was admitted in February 2016 for a syncopal episode without prodrome with cranioencephalic trauma associated with a baseline ECG without alterations and cranial CT scan showing a small focus of subarachnoid haemorrhage in the left parietal and temporal lobes. In November 2016
column5: he was readmitted for sudden recurrent syncope with fracture of the bones of the nose
column6: and an echocardiogram was performed with no abnormalities
column7: an orthostatic test and carotid massage were negative
column8: and a tilt test with mixed response after NTG sl
column9: with dizziness and hypotension with HR 40 bpm
column10: but without loss of consciousness. It was therefore decided to implant a subcutaneous Holter (Reveal LINQ). She came for a Reveal review
column11: after activating it due to an episode of loss of consciousness
column12: while in the washroom preparing to go to work
column13: preceded by a strange
column14: undefined sensation
column15: with a subsequent fall to the floor
column16: with rapid recovery
column17: without sphincter release or tongue biting. Reveal monitoring detected a 15-second pause (with a single wide QRS escape)
column18: with no previous tachycardia. The patient was admitted for further investigation. Physical examination showed a good general condition. BP 125/73 mmHg HR 65 bpm. Sat 02 96 %. AC: rhythmic heart tones without murmurs. AR: MVC
column19: without added aggregates. EEII: no oedema.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS CBC: urea 38 mg/dl
column20: creatinine 0.63 mg/dl
column21: Na 142 mEq/L
column22: K 3.7 mEq/l
column23: Hb 12.1 g/dl
column24: leukocytes 8
column26: platelets 309
column28: coagulation within normal limits. Electrocardiogram: RS at 60lpm PR 164 ms narrow QRS
column29: J-point elevation 0.5 mm V3-V6. 24-hour Holter: sinus rhythm throughout the recording at a mean HR of 60 bpm; maximum of 104 bpm and minimum of 49 bpm. Rare isolated supraventricular extrasystoles. No significant pauses
column30: maximum RR 1.33 seconds. Transthoracic echocardiogram: normal. Electrocardiogram after pacemaker implantation: atrial and ventricular pacing rhythm.  EVOLUTION On the cardiology ward
column31: he was kept under continuous monitoring
column32: 24-hour Holter with no evidence of new arrhythmic episodes and an echocardiogram within normal limits. The patient was diagnosed with malignant vasovagal syncope and it was decided to implant a DDD pacemaker
column33: without incident
column34: with correct pacing and sensing thresholds. After an adequate evolution
column35: she was discharged home.  DIAGNOSIS Malignant vasovagal syncope. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION The patient is a 42-year-old woman with hypertension on treatment with enalapril/hydrochlorothiazide 20/12.5 mg/day
column3: dyslipidaemia on treatment with atorvastatin 20 mg/day and a former smoker of 10 packs/year. History of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) diagnosed at the age of 27 following skin and renal involvement
column4: on chronic treatment with low-dose prednisone (5 mg/day). Class IIIB lupus nephropathy
column5: with biopsy compatible with segmental and focal glomerulonephritis. Positive antiphospholipid antibodies (anti-cardiolipin IgG
column6: anti-cardiolipin IgM
column7: anti-beta-2 glycoprotein-I and lupus anticoagulant positive). No history of thrombosis or obstetric and gynaecological problems. She consulted the emergency department for two days of symptoms consisting of paraesthesia
column8: pain and coldness in the right foot that worsened with supine decubitus and claudication of gait after 50 m. She also had an episode of dizziness and lightheadedness. In addition
column9: episode of dizziness and sweating without clear chest pain or other symptoms. On examination she was in good general condition. Eupneic. BP 115/75 mmHg
column10: HR 75 bpm. Cardiac auscultation rhythmic
column11: without murmurs or extratonos. Pulmonary auscultation with preserved vesicular murmur. Right lower limb with grade 3 femoral pulse
column12: grade 3 popliteal pulse
column13: without distal pulses. Pallor and coldness of the right foot
column14: venocapillary filling very slow compared to the contralateral one. Mobility and sensitivity preserved. Absence of trophic lesions.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: sinus rhythm at 91 bpm. Normal PR. Narrow QRS
column15: normal axis. Q wave in V1-V5 with negative T wave in V1-V2
column16: flattened in V3-V6. Echo-Doppler right lower limb: occlusion of 2nd portion of popliteal artery with recanalisation in posterior tibial. Transthoracic echocardiogram: non-dilated left ventricle
column17: with normal wall thickness. Apical dyskinesia and akinesia of the distal thirds of all faces; hypokinesia of the middle third of the anterior septum and anterior face. Preserved LVEF (Simpson biplane 55%). Occupation of the apex by a sessile
column18: crescentic mass; first diagnostic possibility: intraventricular thrombus. Mitral valve with a rounded mass of approximately 1 x 1 cm attached to the atrial side of the posterior annulus and the base of the posterior leaflet
column19: causing a very eccentric insufficiency directed towards the interatrial septum. The right ventricle is not dilated
column20: with normal global systolic function. No other valvular heart disease. No pericardial effusion. Transesophageal echocardiogram: mitral valve with thin leaflets
column21: normal opening. A rounded image of homogeneous echogenicity and well-defined borders is observed
column22: adhering to the atrial side of the posterior portion of the annulus and the base of the posterior leaflet
column23: at the level of the junction of the P2 and P3 festoons
column24: with a maximum diameter of 1.12 cm
column25: indicating II/IV insufficiency. Coronary CT scan: thrombosed dissection of the middle segment of the anterior descending artery
column26: with involvement of the origin of the second diagonal branch. Left intraventricular thrombus. Coronary angiography: right dominance. Disease of a vessel with a long lesion in the middle third of the anterior descending artery compatible with dissection
column27: distal vessel with TIMI 3 flow.  EVOLUTION An initial diagnosis was made of subacute ischaemia of the right lower limb secondary to infrapopliteal thrombosis
column28: which was related to antiphospholipid syndrome. Medical treatment with anticoagulation and prostaglandins was started with a good response. However
column29: the ECG showed anteroseptal QS
column30: which led to a transthoracic echocardiogram with findings of contractility alterations compatible with anterior infarction
column31: apical intraventricular thrombus
column32: and a rounded mass adhered to the mitral valve. A transesophageal echocardiogram with negative blood cultures confirmed the diagnosis of emboligenic Libman-Sacks endocarditis. In addition
column33: coronary CT and coronary angiography showed a long lesion in the middle LAD compatible with spontaneous thrombosed coronary artery dissection. The study was completed with a cerebral MRI which showed small ischaemic lacunar lesions in both cerebral hemispheres and an aneurysm located at the left-sided internal carotid bifurcation. Aggressive treatment of the SLE flare with methylprednisolone pulses
column34: rituximab
column35: mycophenolate mofetil and hydroxychloroquine sulphate and medical treatment of the thromboses with anticoagulation was performed. Asymptomatic at discharge
column36: treatment was started with low doses of beta-blockers. Subsequent follow-up showed good evolution: LV with preserved systolic function
column37: no new episodes of ischaemia
column38: and resolution of the Libman-Sacks endocarditis with disappearance of the mass.  DIAGNOSIS Acute flare of systemic lupus erythematosus: Emboligenic Libman-Sacks endocarditis. Left ventricular thrombus. Subacute infrapopliteal ischaemia of the right lower limb. Spontaneous coronary artery dissection of the anterior descending coronary artery. Evolved anterior myocardial infarction with preserved global ventricular function. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION An 8-month-old infant with no history of interest was referred to the outpatient cardiology department of our centre by her paediatrician after a murmur was found during a check-up. No medical treatment
column3: except for the vitamin D supplement indicated by protocol. The mother reported that the patient presented fatigue during feedings. The patient's staturo-ponderal development was normal and the examination revealed no cyanosis or respiratory tugging; peripheral pulses were preserved and the presence of a systolic murmur in mitral focus II/VI was confirmed.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS The electrocardiogram showed sinus tachycardia at 150 beats per minute with signs of left chamber enlargement and the consultation echocardiogram showed significant mitral regurgitation (MR)
column4: and a regular transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) was requested. The TTE showed situs solitus
column5: levocardia
column6: atrioventricular and ventricular-arterial concordance
column7: with a dilated left ventricle after adjusting for weight and height
column8: with preserved left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) despite mild inferior hypokinesia: diastolic diameter (DD): 42 mm; systolic diameter (SD) 28 mm; LVEF: 62%. The left atrium was very dilated
column9: with bulging of the interatrial septum towards the right atrium and left-right shunt through the foramen ovale. We observed massive MR due to lack of mitral leaflet coaptation secondary to posterior leaflet retraction with a significant gap between the two leaflets. In addition
column10: both papillary muscles and the chordae tendineae showed increased echogenicity
column11: suggestive of fibroelastosis. During the study of the pulmonary artery (PA) we observed a diastolic flow with colour Doppler at this level
column12: together with the presence of multiple intramyocardial diastolic flows both in the right ventricle and at the septal level. Pulmonary systolic pressure was 30 mmHg. All these findings in the TTE led us to suspect a possible anomalous coronary origin from the PA
column13: and we requested a coronary CT scan. The coronary CT confirmed the suspicion
column14: visualising the left main coronary artery emerging from the PA.  EVOLUTION After the diagnosis of ALCAPA (Anomalous Left Coronary Artery from the Pulmonary Artery)
column15: also called Bland-White-Garland syndrome
column16: the case was presented at a medical-surgical session
column17: and it was decided to intervene by means of coronary reimplantation and repair surgery on the mitral valve
column18: due to the fact that the lesions present in the mitral valve apparatus visualised with TTE suggested little expectation of improvement after isolated coronary reimplantation. The intervention was performed via sternotomy
column19: confirming the exit of the left main coronary artery from the PA. Resection of the left coronary button with anastomosis to the posterior wall of the ascending aorta and closure of the PA was performed. This was followed by mitral plasty with suturing of the anterior commissure to one third of the mitral valve and suturing of the posterior leaflet pseudo-cleft
column20: the latter probably because the dilatation of the mitral annulus caused excessive separation of the indentations dividing the different scallops of the posterior leaflet. Postoperative TTE showed a significant reduction in MR
column21: from massive to moderate
column22: and in ventricular diameters Our patient evolved favourably during her admission and was discharged 1 week later
column23: remaining asymptomatic during follow-up. The 6-month follow-up TTE showed a marked improvement from baseline
column24: with a significant reduction in ventricular diameters (DD: 31 mm; SD: 21 mm)
column25: persistence of a normal LVEF (61%) and reduction in left atrial volume. MR was classified as mild and no significant stenosis was observed after mitral plication (mean transmitral gradient of 4 mmHg). Both PA diastolic flow and intramyocardial flows disappeared
column26: and we found no significant PA gradient.  DIAGNOSIS ALCAPA (Anomalous Left Coronary Artery from the Pulmonary Artery or Bland-White-Garland Syndrome). Secondary severe mitral insufficiency. Coronary reimplantation surgery and mitral plasty. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 59-year-old woman with no cardiovascular risk factors with iatrogenic hypothyroidism following thyroidectomy for thyroid cancer on regular treatment with levothyroxine 75 mcg per day. She had no notable family history. The patient came to the Emergency Department because she suffered loss of consciousness while talking on the phone with her sister while they were arguing
column3: without prodromes and with spontaneous recovery in a few seconds. She did not report a vegetative cortex and had a similar episode when descending stairs months earlier. She had no dyspnoea
column4: palpitations or chest pain. On physical examination the patient was conscious
column5: oriented
column6: normal colour
column7: eupneic
column8: without jugular engorgement
column9: BP 120/70 mmHg
column10: 60 beats/minute
column11: peripheral O2 saturation 96% at baseline
column12: afebrile. Cardiopulmonary auscultation showed preserved vesicular murmur with rhythmic tones and no murmurs. In the abdomen there were no megaliths or signs of ascitesis and in the lower limbs there was no oedema with preserved distal pulses and no signs of deep thrombosis. The neurological examination was normal. A blood test was performed in the emergency department
column13: which detected mild anaemia with no other notable findings
column14: a portable chest X-ray and an electrocardiogram. Based on these data
column15: Cardiology was consulted
column16: and an urgent trathoracic echocardiogram was performed
column17: in which no notable anomalies were observed
column18: and the patient was admitted to the hospital ward with monitoring.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Laboratory tests: leukocytes 11
column20: haemoglobin 10.57 g/dl
column21: MCV 87 mm3
column22: MCH 24/cell
column23: platelets 210
column25: normal coagulation
column26: creatinine 0.57 mg/dl
column27: urea 34 mg/dl
column28: glomerular filtration rate 98 ml/min/1.73 m2
column29: Na 138 mEq/L
column30: K 4.1 mEq/L
column31: Mg 2.6
column33: troponin I 0.04 ng/ml. Urine toxins were negative and thyroid profile was normal. Portable chest X-ray: cardiothoracic index not very valuable
column34: without pleural effusion or infiltrates. ECG: sinus rhythm at 72 beats/minute
column35: normal axis
column36: normal PR interval and QRS complex and normal QTc interval QRS complex and QTc interval of approximately 650 ms. Urgent transthoracic echocardiogram: non-dilated left ventricle with DDVI of 40 mm without significant hypertrophy
column37: preserved LVEF without segmental alterations of contractility and normal diastolic function with normal diastolic pattern and average E/E" of 6.5. Mitral valve with preserved structure and function. Absence of atrial dilatation. Non-dilated aortic root
column38: normofunctioning trivalve aortic valve. Non-dilated right chambers
column39: normal right ventricular systolic function by TAPSE of 18
column40: absence of tricuspid insufficiency
column41: non-dilated inferior vena cava with inspiratory collapse without pericardial effusion. ECG: sinus rhythm with very prolonged QT interval and polymorphic ventricular triplets initiated with "R over T" phenomenon. Telemetry tracing with torsades de pointes and cardioversion at 100 joules. Chest X-ray: with bicameral implantable cardioverter defibrillator with normal electrode placement. ECG: atrial paced rhythm at 70 beats/minute. There was a reduction in the QT interval with respect to the initial ECG after optimising treatment with beta-blockers.  EVOLUTION On the Cardiology hospital ward
column42: the patient presented with polymorphic ventricular extrasystoles and non-sustained polymorphic ventricular tachycardias (PSVT). Given these findings
column43: with a baseline sinus rhythm rate of 65 bpm
column44: intravenous magnesium was administered and
column45: in the absence of improvement
column46: the patient was transferred to the Coronary Care Unit. Despite the initial measures
column47: the patient developed sustained ventricular tachycardia of the torsades de pointes type
column48: with loss of consciousness
column49: and cardioversion at 100 joules was performed
column50: which was effective. However
column51: she presented again with non-sustained DVT
column52: so it was decided to perform sedation. The patient showed signs of respiratory distress
column53: arterial hypertension and finally required deep sedoanalgesia and orotracheal intubation. Beta-blockers were started and haemodynamic and arrhythmic stabilisation was achieved
column54: although these drugs were titrated to low doses as the patient presented sinus bradycardia. An analytical study was completed with detection of toxins in urine
column55: which was negative
column56: and a thyroid profile showed no alterations
column57: and the use of drugs that could prolong the QT interval was ruled out. Given the presence of probable congenital long QT syndrome and cardiorespiratory arrest resuscitated by sustained DVT
column58: it was decided to implant a bicameral endovascular automatic defibrillator
column59: which was carried out without incident
column60: and the patient was subsequently transferred to the cardiology ward where the dose of beta-blocker was increased to bisoprolol 5 mg every 8 hours and blood tests were taken for genetic study. This detected a mutation in the KCNQ1 gene in heterozygosis associated with the development of long QT syndrome type 1 with an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance
column61: and a family study was performed.  DIAGNOSIS Long QT syndrome type 1. Pathogenic mutation in the KCNQ1 gene. Recurrent syncope. Cardiac arrest resuscitated by PSVT. Absence of significant structural heart disease. Implantation of DR ICD in secondary prevention. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION A 55-year-old woman
column3: asymptomatic from the cardiovascular point of view to date
column4: suddenly started with oppressive chest pain radiating to the left upper limb. The medical history of interest included the presence of arterial hypertension
column5: hypercholesterolemia and type 2 diabetes mellitus
column6: all of them under medical treatment with telmisartan 80 mg/24 h
column7: atorvastatin 20 mg/24 h and metformin 850 mg/24 h
column8: respectively. One year earlier
column9: during a periodic company check-up
column10: an incidental LBBB of the His bundle had been observed
column11: and for this reason a transthoracic cardiac ultrasound had been performed
column12: with no pathological findings. The patient was a non-smoker
column13: had no family history of early ischaemic heart disease and had never undergone surgery or any other medical condition under treatment. Within 30 minutes of the onset of the symptoms
column14: which had been preceded by a heated discussion
column15: the Emergency Services were notified and
column16: after observing the presence of an LBBB in the ECG
column17: they activated the Infarction Code. He was transferred urgently to our hospital (tertiary level) for primary angioplasty. On arrival
column18: the chest pain had disappeared
column19: the blood pressure was 133/70 mmHg and the heart rate was 70 beats per minute
column20: with no evidence of heart failure on physical examination.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS At the urgent coronary angiography
column21: it was decided to first catheterise the right coronary artery with a JR4 diagnostic catheter
column22: with no evidence of atheromatous lesions. The left coronary artery was then catheterised with an EBU3.5 guide catheter
column23: revealing an anterior descending artery without lesions
column24: as well as a fine
column25: diffuse and progressive narrowing of the first obtuse marginal branch (OM1; the only branch of the circumflex territory; involving the two branches into which the artery subsequently bifurcated. Despite the lesion being practically subocclusive at the distal level of the first branch
column26: flow was preserved in both branches (TIMI III). To further diagnose the pathology underlying the coronary finding
column27: it was decided to analyse the vessel with an intracoronary imaging technique
column28: the interventional cardiologist opting for optical coherence tomography (OCT) given its higher spatial resolution. After probing OM1 with two angioplasty guides
column29: progressing the OCT monorail
column30: and analysing the withdrawn artery together with the administration of 16 cc of iodinated contrast
column31: a clear progression of the lumen involvement was evidenced
column32: reaching the circumflex ostium. Despite this
column33: the patient remained asymptomatic
column34: with distal TIMI III flow in all branches
column35: and with the coronary trunk intact. During her hospital admission
column36: a clear ultrasensitive troponin T curve was observed (242 ng/ml to 1
column37: 860 ng/ml to 1
column38: 691 ng/ml to 800 ng/ml)
column39: as well as a reasonably controlled lipid profile (triglycerides 213 mg/dl
column40: total cholesterol 217 mg/dl
column41: HDL 34 mg/dl
column42: LDL 140 mg/dl. Hba1C 6.7%). The rest of the blood tests and chest X-ray were unremarkable. Transthoracic echocardiography showed significant akinesia of the OM1-dependent territory
column43: with a left ventricular ejection fraction of 40 %
column44: without other pathological findings. In this sense
column45: the study of myocardial function and its possible sequelae was extended with cardiac magnetic resonance imaging
column46: which corroborated the presence of mild ventricular dysfunction
column47: as well as the presence of late gadolinium enhancement (of 50 % of the myocardial thickness) in lateral and lateral-inferior aspect.  EVOLUTION Given the angiographic and OCT features of the coronary artery disease
column48: and the fact that the patient was haemodynamically stable and pain-free
column49: it was decided to opt for strictly conservative medical management. Since the patient did not develop new symptoms of ischaemia
column50: and after having tolerated starting carvedilol 6.25 mg/12 h together with dual antiplatelet therapy (ASA and clopidogrel) and the previous dose of ARA-II
column51: the patient was discharged 5 days after admission. Subsequent outpatient follow-up (1 year) showed no new coronary events
column52: and the patient is in NYHA functional class I/IV and without exertional angina.  DIAGNOSIS Acute coronary syndrome in the presence of left bundle branch block. HYPERTENSION. Dyslipidaemia. Type 2 diabetes mellitus. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Patient aged 22 years
column3: with no known pharmacological allergies and no medical or surgical history. No family history of heart disease or history of sudden death in the family. Habitual sportsman. No toxic habits.  Current illness The patient came to the hospital to have his teeth extracted by means of a scheduled operation in the maxillofacial operating theatre for outpatient surgery. He had been previously assessed by anaesthesia preoperatively
column4: with normal physical examination
column5: blood tests without alterations and ASA I evaluation. No baseline electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed due to his age
column6: in accordance with hospital protocol. During this procedure
column7: the patient presented with a heart rate of around 45-50 beats per minute
column8: and given that this was interpreted as bradycardia
column9: prior to anaesthetic induction
column10: 0.5 mg of atropine was administered as an intravenous bolus. The patient then presented with symptoms of precordial pressure
column11: palpitations and profuse diaphoresis
column12: and the monitor recorded a rhythmic tachycardia with wide QRS at 150-160 beats per minute
column13: compatible with sustained ventricular tachycardia lasting one minute
column14: with spontaneous transition to sinus rhythm. A bolus of 200 mg amiodarone was administered without further episodes.  Physical examination Blood pressure 110/50 mmHg. Heart rate 75 bpm. O2 saturation 100% (FiO2 0.21). Conscious
column15: oriented
column16: normal colour
column17: normohydrated
column18: good distal perfusion. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds without murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: normal vesicular murmur. Abdomen was nondescript. Extremities without oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG (operating room): sinus rhythm at 80 bpm. PR 0.180 msec. Narrow QRS. ST-segment depression in V3-V5 and in III and avF with negative T waves in these same leads. ECG (Emergency): sinus rhythm at 74 bpm
column19: variable PR (between 0.08-0.10) and occasionally retroconducted P wave
column20: some nodal beats. Blood tests: troponin I 0.22 mg/ml. Myoglobin 66. Serialisation: troponin I 2.56. Myoglobin 22. Haemogram without alterations (Hb 15.8 g/dl). Renal function and ions normal. Hepatic profile without alterations. Cholesterol 182 mg/dl. Transthoracic echocardiogram: LV of normal size and wall thickness
column21: with hypertrophy of both papillary muscles. Global LV systolic function normal
column22: without segmental asymmetries of contractility. Diastolic pattern: normal. Left atrium of normal dimensions. Right chambers of normal dimensions; RV normocontractile. Aortic root and visualized portion of proximal ascending aorta of normal dimensions. MV: thin leaflets
column23: not limited in its opening
column24: competent. VAo: trivalve
column25: normal sigmoids
column26: not limited in its opening
column27: competent. IT minimal. IVC not dilated with normal inspiratory collapse. Estimated normal PAPs. Absence of pericardial effusion and intracavitary masses through this access route. Cardiac MRI: left ventricle at the high limit of normality (DTD: 56 mm)
column28: with normal systolic function. No hypertrophy or focal areas of late enhancement indicating fibrosis. Mild RV dilatation with normal EF. Non-dilated atria. Minimal MI. Mild TR. Coronary angioCT: coronary arteries with normal anatomical origin. No lesions in epicardial coronary arteries.  EVOLUTION After the episode of self-limited ventricular tachycardia
column29: a 12-lead ECG was performed showing repolarisation alterations suggestive of myocardial ischaemia on the anteroseptal side with subsequent normalisation
column30: although showing competition between sinus rhythm and nodal rhythm. Since the patient had presented with clinical signs of precordial tightness together with the ECG findings described
column31: it was initially treated as an acute coronary syndrome and enzyme serology was performed with peak troponin I of 2.56 ng/dl. Beta-blockers (bisoprolol) were started at low doses. Subsequently
column32: the patient remained asymptomatic with no new episodes of angina
column33: arrhythmias or electrical changes in the electrocardiogram. Given the patient's clinical manifestations compatible with ventricular arrhythmia secondary to a probable acute coronary event
column34: it was decided to admit the patient for further study. Echocardiography and cardiac MRI were requested to rule out underlying cardiomyopathy
column35: as well as coronary angioCT to rule out coronary artery disease. These tests ruled out structural heart disease. The case was discussed with the arrhythmia unit
column36: which performed an electrophysiological study that was negative for induction of ventricular arrhythmias or reentrant arrhythmias and no evidence of accessory pathways. After ruling out structural heart disease and induction of arrhythmias in the electrophysiological study
column37: it was concluded that the ventricular tachycardia presented was secondary to a probable coronary ischaemic event (the patient presented chest tightness with associated vegetative symptoms
column38: clear alterations in the ECG and increased markers of myocardial damage). The ECG alterations described and the elevation of markers of myocardial damage would not be secondary to the ventricular tachycardia as it was of very short duration. Therefore
column39: we believe that the ventricular tachycardia was the secondary event to myocardial ischaemia. Given that the angioCT findings ruled out any structural abnormality that could cause ischaemia
column40: the presence of coronary vasospasm triggered by a sudden change in heart rate in the context of intravenous administration of atropine was proposed as the first diagnostic probability. Since the patient had no cardiovascular risk factors and no clinical history of angina
column41: it was not considered necessary to perform coronary vasospasm provocation studies. Medical treatment with calcium antagonists was not initiated as a clear trigger for the episode was identified. The beta-blockers that had been started were withdrawn as they have been described as a possible trigger for coronary vasospasm. With the results of the complementary tests and the good prognosis of the same
column42: and with a diagnosis of ventricular tachycardia in the context of probable coronary vasospasm secondary to the administration of intravenous atropine
column43: hospital discharge was decided for outpatient monitoring without initiating any pharmacological treatment for the time being. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History No known drug allergies. Marfan's syndrome. Subluxation of the crystalline lens. Dural ectasia. Family history of Marfan syndrome in father and paternal grandfather. In 2006
column3: she underwent surgery for dilatation of the ascending aorta with involvement of the sinuses of Valsalva using the David technique
column4: with preservation of the native aortic valve. Hyperparathyroidism secondary to vitamin D deficiency. Hypercalciuria. Osteopenia. One term delivery (vaginal delivery with vacuum extraction) in 2011. Usual treatment: currently on treatment with ASA 100 mg and labetalol (atenolol had been substituted for labetalol during the previous pregnancy).   Present illness Patient aged 36 years
column5: 10 weeks pregnant and operated 10 years ago for aortic root aneurysm
column6: referred to an outpatient cardiologist for advice and risk assessment.  Physical examination BP 109/73 mmHg; HR 90 bpm. Conscious and oriented. Well hydrated and perfused
column7: with good skin and mucous membrane colouring. Eupneic. Marfanoid habitus. Head and neck: no jugular ingurgitation. No nuchal rigidity or meningeal signs. No carotid murmurs. Chest: mid thoracotomy scar. Rhythmic cardiac auscultation with no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur. Abdomen: globular
column8: soft and depressible
column9: without pain on palpation or peritonism. No masses or visceromegaly were palpable. No murmurs were heard Lower extremities: no oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis. Peripheral pulses were preserved.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Echocardiogram: native aortic valve with three thin leaflets with normal opening and no functional alteration. A rigid structure is identified above the valvular plane with a 2D internal diameter of 35 mm. Aortic sagging visualised in the suprasternal recess
column10: 30 mm. Discrete image of mild anterior leaflet prolapse without fulfilling strict criteria
column11: with trivial MR. Left ventricle neither dilated nor hypertrophic
column12: with good global systolic function and no alterations in segmental contractility. Type I diastolic pattern. Non-dilated right chambers with mild TR and systolic gradient of 12 mmHg. Pulmonary normotension. MRI: mild dilatation of descending thoracic aorta and right common iliac aorta
column13: in a stable situation.  EVOLUTION The patient was referred to the Genetics Department
column14: where she was informed of a 50% probability of transmission
column15: as well as the phenotypic variability and the availability of a prenatal diagnostic test. A molecular study was performed
column16: which was found to be normal
column17: so prenatal diagnosis was not possible in her case. In conjunction with cardiac surgery
column18: discontinuation of ASA and treatment with labetalol 50 mg was recommended. The patient is being monitored by a High Risk Pregnancy Unit.  DIAGNOSIS Pregnant woman with Marfan syndrome with dilatation of the ascending aorta. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  Personal history 52-year-old patient with the following personal pathological history: smoker of 1⁄2 pack of cigarettes/day
column3: dyslipidaemia under treatment with statins
column4: no diabetes mellitus or arterial hypertension.  Current illness The patient consults for approximately 1-2 months for episodes of chest pain that usually appear at rest and at night
column5: but sometimes appear after heavy physical exertion. He refers to the pain as oppressive
column6: radiating to the left arm and jaw
column7: with no accompanying vegetative cortex; the duration of the episodes is usually a maximum of 10-15 minutes and they subside spontaneously. In the last week he presented 4 episodes of chest pain and consulted his primary care physician
column8: who referred him to Cardiology for assessment.  Physical examination Vital signs: BP 130/70
column9: HR 70 bpm
column10: O2 saturation 97% on room air. Patient conscious and oriented
column11: normal neurological examination. Pulmonary auscultation with preserved vesicular murmur. Auscultation of heart sounds normal
column12: no murmurs or extratonos
column13: no pericardial friction rub. Neck without jugular ingurgitation. Abdomen without pathological findings. Lower extremities without oedema or signs of thrombosis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Blood tests: glucose 120 mg/dl
column14: urea 30 mg/dl
column15: creatinine 0.85 mg/dl
column16: sodium 142 mEq/l
column17: potassium 4 mEq/l
column18: chlorine 104 mEq/l. Leukocytes 7
column19: 500 with 60 % neutrophils
column20: haemoglobin 13.2 g/dl
column21: haematocrit 40 %
column22: platelets 250
column23: 000. Baseline electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus rhythm at 80 bpm
column24: little R wave growth in right precordial leads. No other repolarisation abnormalities. Chest X-ray: normal cardiac silhouette
column25: no acute pleuroparenchymal findings. Transthoracic echocardiogram: left ventricle of normal dimensions
column26: normal wall thickness. Preserved systolic function without segmental alterations of contractility. Normal diastolic pattern. Normal left atrium. Mild mitral insufficiency. Aortic root and aortic valve normal. Normal right chambers. No pericardial effusion. Coronary angiography: right radial access 5F. Cardiac catheterisation: right dominance. Left common trunk (LMCA) without lesions. Anterior descending artery (AD) without lesions. Bisector branch: slight proximal lesion. Circumflex artery (Cx) with slight mid-level lesion. Right coronary artery (RCA) with severe pseudostenosis due to coronary spasm at midlevel that improves completely after administration of intracoronary nitroglycerin. Diagnosis: epicardial coronary arteries without significant hagiographic lesions. Coronary vasospasm of the right coronary artery.   EVOLUTION The patient was assessed in the outpatient cardiology department. At that time he was asymptomatic
column27: the physical examination was normal and the ECG showed no changes in repolarisation. A baseline transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) was performed
column28: which was normal
column29: with preserved global left ventricular function and no segmental asymmetries of contractility. Since the patient had cardiovascular risk factors (dyslipidaemia and smoking) and presented a typical clinical picture of exertional angina
column30: it was decided to request coronary angiography to rule out coronary artery disease. At the time of cardiac catheterisation
column31: the patient was asymptomatic and had no symptoms of angina. The ECG on arrival showed no changes with respect to the previous ones. Blood test parameters were normal. Cardiac catheterisation was performed via the right radial artery. First
column32: LMCA was cannulated with evidence of slight lesions in the bisector branch and proximal Cx. Subsequently
column33: the LMCA was cannulated without complications. After the first contrast injection
column34: a pseudo lesion with the appearance of a severe plaque was detected at the level of the middle LMCA. At that time
column35: the patient reported chest pain similar to the episodes described above and ST segment elevation in lead II of the monitoring. Initially it was thought that the patient had a fixed lesion over which there had been added vasospasm
column36: so it was decided to administer intracoronary nitroglycerine
column37: which progressively improved the angina and the repolarisation alterations on the monitor. After a new contrast injection
column38: complete resolution of the previously observed lesion was observed. In view of the typical angina symptoms and the coronary angiographic findings
column39: the case was labelled as vasospastic angina with severe vasospasm during cardiac catheterisation. Medical treatment with calcium antagonists and long-acting oral nitrates was started
column40: with excellent clinical evolution during follow-up.  DIAGNOSIS Vasospastic angina. Right coronary artery spasm triggered by catheter manipulation. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION We present the case of a 73-year-old male patient with a DDDR pacemaker since 2002 due to complete atrioventricular block (AVB). In November 2014
column3: he was admitted for facial and upper limb oedema with intoxication on decubitus.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS As part of the study
column4: venous Doppler ultrasound was performed
column5: showing complete thrombosis of the brachiocephalic venous trunk with extension to the right axillary and jugular veins. The diagnosis was confirmed by venography which reported thrombosis of the superior vena cava and both brachiocephalic venous axes up to the subclavian veins and collateral drainage through intercostal veins to the azygos vein.  EVOLUTION With a diagnosis of SVCS in relation to pacemaker electrodes (MP)
column6: the patient consulted vascular surgery
column7: which dismissed the case due to the impossibility of access for stent implantation in the venous territory. The patient was discharged with diuretic treatment and anticoagulation. He consulted the emergency department on two other occasions due to severe headache and intolerance to decubitus; the family also told us that he had suicidal ideas in relation to his symptoms. The procedure was performed in the operating theatre
column8: under general anaesthesia with invasive monitoring
column9: echocardiographic control and available ECC equipment. Prior to the procedure
column10: the right femoral vein was cannulated leaving a 7F introducer and an epicardial electrode was implanted through a left thoracotomy. This electrode was tunneled to a right suprapectoral neobolla and connected to external stimulation
column11: as the patient was dependent on cardiac stimulation. Subsequently
column12: after careful dissection
column13: the old generator was removed
column14: and using Cook radiofrequency sheaths and Spectranetic mechanical sheaths
column15: the electrodes were extracted in their entirety. Once the extraction was completed and prior to the removal of the sheath
column16: a guidewire was introduced through the sheath and advanced to the right femoral vein. Using the femoral access
column17: balloon angioplasty and implantation of two self-expanding stents in the superior vena cava (Sinus XL 14 x 40 mm
column18: Protégé GPS 9 x 40 mm) and another Gore-Tex® stent (Gore-Viabahn 54 mm) in the innominate vein were performed. Once the stent implantation was completed
column19: an SSI generator was connected to the right suprapectoral neobag. After 24 hours
column20: the patient was discharged to the ward with a notable decrease in the oedema in the sella
column21: and was able to sleep all night in the supine position
column22: which he had not been able to do in recent months. The patient was discharged without complications under anticoagulant treatment.  At the three-month follow-up CT scan
column23: the stents were found to be permeable. At the 6-month check-up
column24: he reported complete recovery of his symptoms and was able to lead a normal life.  DIAGNOSIS Superior vena cava syndrome after MP implantation. Hybrid approach: electrode extraction and venous stent implantation. Epicardial electrode implantation. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION The patient is a 73-year-old male with no allergies
column3: ex-smoker
column4: hypertensive
column5: dyslipidaemic
column6: with stage V chronic kidney disease (CKD) secondary to obstructive uropathy due to benign prostatic hypertrophy: had refused renal transplant
column7: started peritoneal dialysis (PD) in August 2008 with several infectious complications
column8: discontinuing PD in June 2012 due to partial recovery of renal function (creatinine 4"2 mg/dl and GFR 15 ml/min)
column9: and again presenting criteria for restarting renal replacement therapy (RRT) since November 2014 (creatinine 7"61 mg/dl and GFR 7"7 ml/min)
column10: which he had refused as he was asymptomatic. Hyperparathyroidism and anaemia secondary to CKD. No cardiac history. He reported poor compliance with pharmacological treatment. Admitted to nephrology in November 2016 with end-stage renal failure and anasarca
column11: requiring placement of a right femoral catheter for urgent haemodialysis and transfusion of red blood cell concentrates due to severe anaemia. Examination on admission: BP 224/92 mmHg
column12: HR 90 bpm. Conscious and oriented. Rhythmic heart tones without murmurs
column13: friction rubs or extratones. Jugular ingurgitation and oedema with fovea up to the genital region
column14: with distal pulses not palpable due to oedema. Tachypnoea with bibasal hypophonesis and decreased vocal transmissions of left predominance. Hepatomegaly.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: sinus rhythm at 90 bpm
column15: normal PR
column16: narrow QRS
column17: 0o axis
column18: with electrical alternation
column19: without repolarisation alterations. Blood tests: glucose 92 mg/dl
column20: urea 291 mg/dl
column21: creatinine 13.1 mg/dl (FG CKD-EPI 3.3 ml/min/1.73 m2)
column22: total Ca 8.69 mg/dl
column23: total proteins 7.17 g/dl
column24: Na 141.3 mmol/l
column25: Cl 114 mmol/l. Venous blood gases: pH 7.15
column26: pCO2 25 mmHg
column27: bicarbonate 8.7 mmol/l
column28: EB -18.6 mmol/l. Haemogram: leucocytes 6.46 x109/l (77.9 % neutrophils
column29: 11.1 % lymphocytes)
column30: Hb 4.5 g/dl
column33: MCH 27.4 pg
column34: platelets 148
column35: 000 x109/l. INR ratio 1.07. Serology: negative for HCV
column36: HBV and HIV. HBV DNA undetectable. Chest X-ray: cardiomegaly suggestive of pericardial effusion. Lung parenchyma without congestive signs. Left pleural effusion. Echocardiogram: severely hypertrophied LV with good systolic function and diastolic dysfunction due to poor relaxation. LA severely dilated. Normal right chambers. No significant valvulopathies. Severe global pericardial effusion with echocardiographic signs of haemodynamic involvement: partial collapse of the free wall of the RA
column37: RV and LA
column38: respiratory variation of mitral filling flow of 41%
column39: dilatation of inferior cava (24 mm) and suprahepatic veins without inspiratory collapse of the former and inspiratory inversion of the diastolic component of the suprahepatic vein Doppler. Bilateral pleural effusion. Pleural fluid: exudate. Proteins 3.9 g/dl (5.84 g/dl in serum)
column40: LDH 242 U/l (431 U/l in serum with normal values 208-378). Clear appearance. Red cells 300 cells/mm3
column41: leukocytes 391 cells/mm3 (7 % polymorphonuclear
column42: 93 % mononuclear)
column43: glucose 94 mg/dl
column44: ADA 9.2 U/l
column45: CRP 10.7 mg/l
column46: pH 7.45. Negative for malignant cells. Negative cultures. Pericardial fluid: exudate. Proteins 4.1 g/dl (6.78 g/dl in serum)
column47: LDH 2313 U/l (456 U/l in serum with normal values 208-378). Haemorrhagic appearance. Red cells 945
column48: 100 cells/mm3
column49: leukocytes 44
column50: 965 cells/mm3 (2 % mononuclear
column51: 98 % polymorphonuclear)
column52: glucose 79.7 mg/dl
column53: ADA 16.2 U/l. Negative for malignant cells. Thoracic-abdominal CT: sheet of pericardial effusion. Left pleural effusion with underlying compressive condensation/atelectasis. Bilateral renal atrophy and hydronephrosis and right renal tumours under study. Bilateral renal cortical micronodules
column54: non-specific.  EVOLUTION Given the suspicion of pericardial effusion on radiological imaging
column55: transthoracic echocardiography was performed
column56: which showed severe pericardial effusion with evidence of haemodynamic compromise but without clinical evidence of tamponade. Initially oriented as probable uremic pericardial effusion
column57: a tunnelled right jugular catheter was placed and haemodialysis was intensified
column58: achieving adequate volume depletion
column59: but without improvement of the pericardial effusion after 12 days. Thoracentesis of the pleural effusion was performed with exudate results
column60: and given the persistence of pericardial effusion despite adequate haemodialysis
column61: it was decided to perform a diagnostic and therapeutic pericardiocentesis. A total drainage of 1400 ml of haematic fluid was obtained
column62: exudate
column63: with abundant leukocytes with a predominance of polymorphonuclear cells
column64: no glucose consumption or increase in proteins
column65: elevated LDH and negative cytology for malignant cells. In view of these findings
column66: it was decided to perform a whole body CT scan to screen for occult neoplasia
column67: and two solid tumour-like masses were observed in the right kidney. With regard to the anaemia
column68: gastrointestinal losses
column69: haemolysis or metabolic deficits were ruled out and attributed to CKD
column70: and treatment with darbepoetin was started.  DIAGNOSIS Stage V chronic renal failure due to obstructive uropathy. Malignant pericardial effusion. Severe anaemia secondary to chronic renal disease. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History 54-year-old man with no toxic habits and a history of hypertension and dyslipidaemia. No diabetes mellitus. Fracture of 5th metacarpal. column4: lorazepam 1 mg

column6: pantoprazole 40 mg
column7: adiro 100 mg
column8: orfidal 1 mg
column9: escitalopram 10 mg.  Present illness On the day of his admission
column10: he came to the emergency department for an episode of oppressive chest pain and rapid palpitations of sudden onset with irradiation to the neck. The symptoms were precipitated by an argument. On arrival
column11: a wide QRS rhythmic tachycardia at 237 bpm was observed. He was assessed in the emergency department and underwent electrical cardioversion to stable sinus rhythm. He was admitted for further investigation and treatment.  Physical examination On arrival at the ED: blood pressure 101/65
column12: heart rate 190 bpm
column13: oxygen saturation 100. Conscious
column14: oriented

column16: no extra sounds. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic tones
column17: tachycardic. Abdomen soft and depressible
column18: not painful on palpation
column19: without signs of peritoneal irritation. Peristalsis preserved. Lower extremities: no oedema or signs of DVT.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG on admission: wide QRS tachycardia. QRS 0.24. QS in I. BRD morphology. R in V1 to V4. R R" aVR QRS in V6 with rS morphology. Visualisation of p" without dissociation at > 80 ms of preceding QRS. Discharge ECG: sinus rhythm at 55 bpm
column20: narrow QRS
column21: no repolarisation abnormalities. Chest X-ray: preserved silhouette. No congestive signs. Chest X-ray at discharge: automatic defibrillator with distal end of subcutaneous electrode in chest wall. Surgical staples. CBC: Biochemistry: glucose 107 mg/dl
column22: urea 37 mg/dl
column23: creatinine 1.04 mg/dl
column24: uric acid 5.00 mg/dl
column25: triglycerides 135 mg/dl
column26: total cholesterol 105 mg/dl
column27: HDL 40 mg/dl
column28: LDL 38 mg/dl
column29: sodium 137 mEq/l
column30: potassium 5.0 mEq/l
column31: CK 56 U/L
column33: GGT 101 U/L
column34: AST 29 U/L
column35: ALT 54 U/L. Cardiac markers (peak numbers): troponin I 0.23 ng/ml. Thyroid function: TSH 3.65 mIU/l
column36: T4 0.65 ng/dl. -CBC: red blood cells 4.67 mill/mm3
column37: haemoglobin 14.8 g/dl
column38: haematocrit 43 %
column39: MCV 92 fl
column40: leukocytes 6.6/mm3 (59 % N
column42: platelets 150 /mm3.   Echocardiogram: LV dimensions at the upper limit of normality (taking into account body surface area). Parietal thickness preserved. Global systolic function preserved (57% by Simpson ́s biplanar) and GLS -19%. No clear contractile asymmetries. No conclusive data suggesting LVOT elevation. LA slightly dilated (biplanar volume 36 ml/m2). Normal right chambers. Aortic root of normal size. MV and VAo without alterations. I do not detect IT adequately to estimate PAPs. Absence of pericardial effusion or intracavitary masses by this access route. Cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR): acute myocarditis (LV) with oedema (subepicardial linear hypersignal in middle and apical inferior segments and middle lateral segments) and fibrosis (subepicardial linear late enhancement in basal and middle anterior segments
column43: basal and middle lateral segments
column44: middle and apical inferior segments and middle inferoseptal segment). Moderately dilated left ventricle (DTD: 60 mm); with normal systolic function: (EF 52 %). Normal RV function. Atria not dilated. Mild AI. Electrophysiological study: no significant findings. No evidence of accessory pathway or double nodal pathway. Programmed stimulation does not induce ventricular arrhythmias.  EVOLUTION Since admission
column45: the patient had a favourable evolution with no new episodes of arrhythmias. CMR was performed which showed the existence of myocardial oedema and findings suggestive of acute myocarditis. The case was discussed with the Arrhythmia Unit
column46: which decided to implant a subcutaneous ICD. The EMBLEM MRI model subcutaneous ICD was implanted without complications or incidents. The implanted system was checked for proper functioning. Tolerates ambulation without limitations. Tension levels tended to be on the low limit
column47: so beta-blocker and ARAII treatment was adjusted
column48: with good tolerance
column49: asymptomatic. In a situation of clinical stability it was decided to discharge him from hospital.
