column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 63-year-old independent woman with no cognitive impairment. Cardiovascular risk factors: smoker
column3: hypertension and hypercholesterolemia under pharmacological treatment with good control. No previous cardiological history or other history of interest. She consulted because
column4: after receiving the news of the death of a relative
column5: she began with generalised malaise associated with abnormal facial movements and slurred speech with difficulty in producing long sentences
column6: the episode lasting about 30 minutes. Hours later
column7: the same symptoms reappeared and she was assessed by the emergency services who referred her to our centre.  Physical examination showed a good level of consciousness
column8: oriented in the three spheres
column9: no meningeal signs. Language not very fluent due to nominative difficulties. She understands and repeats correctly. Normal cranial nerves. Normal campimetry. Facial centred with the rest of the lower pairs normal. Normal long motor
column10: sensory and cerebellar pathways. Skin-plantar reflexes ambiguous. CYC: PVY normal
column11: carotid pulses normal AP: MVC AC: normal. Abdomen normal. Extremities: Normal pulses
column12: no oedema.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Laboratory tests on admission: biochemistry: glucose 87mg/dl
column13: urea 46 mg/dl
column14: creatinine 0.86 mg/dl
column15: sodium 143 mmol/l
column16: potassium 3.8 mmol/l
column17: CRP 1.2mg/dl. Coagulation: PT 87 %
column18: aPTT 1.23 FBN 580mg/dl
column19: INR 1.09. Haemogram: leucocytes 6.99*103 (normal formula)
column20: HB 14.2g/dl
column22: 000 platelets. ECG: sinus rhythm at 56 bpm
column23: without repolarisation alterations. Cranial CT scan without contrast
column24: urgent: left fronto-opercular hypodense lesion also affecting the anterior region of the insular cortex
column25: with loss of corticosubcortical differentiation compatible with subacute ischaemic lesion. There is no significant mass effect on adjacent structures. In the rest of the parenchyma
column26: no intra- or extra-axial haemorrhages or other ischaemic lesions are identified. Morphology of sulci and ventricles normal for the patient's age. Centred midline. Posterior cranial fossa structures without apparent alterations. No bony lesions were observed. Findings: subacute ischaemic lesion in the anterior superficial territory of the left MCA. Control cranial CT scan at 72 h: appearance of a focus of confluent petechial microhaemorrhage
column27: of nodular morphology and approximately 9 mm in diameter
column28: inside the known ischaemic or subacute frontal and left insular lesion. The latter has slightly increased in size with respect to the previous study
column29: with greater involvement of the left frontal subcortical white matter at the level of the corona radiata. There is no significant mass effect on the surrounding parenchyma
column30: the midline ventricular system. Pineal cystic lesion approximately 9 mm in diameter and with peripheral gross calcification
column31: non-specific and unchanged. The rest of the study showed no significant alterations or changes with respect to the previous one. Conclusions: appearance of a focus of confluent petechial microhaemorrhage
column33: within the lesion of subacute ischaemic profile of the known left MCA territory. Transthoracic echocardiogram 4 days after admission (Video 1 and 2): Normal sized LV with mild concentric hypertrophy. Preserved LVEF. Prolonged relaxation. RV of normal size and function. Left atrium slightly dilated. Mass in the left atrium dependent on the interatrial septum
column34: heterogeneous echogenic density
column35: deflected limits
column36: which prolapses into the ventricle through the mitral valve not generating significant gradient but mild-moderate mitral insufficiency. Impression of myxoma. Normofunctioning aortic valve. Mitral valve with insufficiency generated by prolapse of the atrial mass. Non-dilated IVC. No pericardial effusion.  EVOLUTION A 63-year-old woman attended the emergency department with clinical neurological deficit. An urgent cranial CT scan was performed
column37: showing a subacute ischaemic lesion in the anterior superficial territory of the left MCA. The patient was admitted to the Stroke Unit for routine management. She progressed favourably with complete recovery of the neurological deficit. After 72 hours
column38: a repeat CT scan showed a focus of confluent petechial microhaemorrhage
column39: without mass effect
column40: within the lesion with a known subacute ischaemic profile of the left MCA territory. The echocardiogram showed a mass in the left atrium
column41: dependent on the interatrial septum
column42: with deflected limits
column43: which prolapses through the mitral valve into the left ventricle
column44: causing mild-moderate mitral insufficiency. Given these findings
column45: the case was re-evaluated jointly with the Cardiology
column46: Neurology and Cardiac Surgery Departments; the patient presented a significant surgical risk as a result of the recent stroke with minor haemorrhagic transformation; however
column47: given the characteristics and behaviour of the tumour
column48: with repeated embolisms and given the risk of other complications
column49: it was decided to perform urgent surgery that same day. The atrial mass was excised with resection of the fossa ovalis and reconstruction with a pericardial patch. The patient had an uncomplicated postoperative period and was discharged from hospital. The pathological anatomy of the specimen confirmed the diagnosis of myxoma.   DIAGNOSIS Left frontal ischaemic stroke. Confluent petechial microhaemorrhage inside the ischaemic profile lesion. Left atrial myxoma. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  Personal history Allergy to mites and pollen. No known drug allergies. Toxic habits: smoker of 1 pack a day. Mild alcoholic habit. No other intoxicants reported. No hypertension
column3: no dyslipidaemia
column4: no diabetes mellitus. No known heart disease. Bronchial asthma treated with inhalers
column5: with 10 flare-ups related to mites and pollen in the last year treated with bronchodilators and auto-injectable adrenaline. Surgical interventions: right knee meniscus 2 years ago. Usual treatment (poor compliance): terbutaline 1 inhalation in the mornings. Fluticasone furoate/vilanterol 184/22 every 24 hours. Family history: father with acute myocardial infarction (AMI) at the age of 52.  Present illness A 21-year-old man
column6: with the history described above
column7: presented to his health centre with a sensation of chest tightness and sudden onset of dyspnoea. The report highlights: inspiratory stridor and BP 80/55. Intravenous methylprednisolone 80 mg and an ampoule of adrenaline 1 mg/ml intramuscular were administered
column8: with improvement of the respiratory symptoms
column9: but he presented with precordial pressure radiating to the neck. An ECG was performed showing an inferoposterolateral subepicardial lesion. Sublingual nitroglycerine was administered without clinical or electrocardiographic improvement
column10: so the Emergency Services were notified and he was transferred to our hospital. On arrival (30 minutes after the onset of pain)
column11: he reported a slight improvement in pain
column12: although ST-segment elevation persisted
column13: so the patient was transferred to the haemodynamics room for urgent catheterisation
column14: and coronary arteries were found to have no significant lesions. He was admitted to the Coronary Care Unit without pain
column15: haemodynamically stable and with normalisation of the ECG.  Physical examination BP 98/60
column16: HR 95 bpm. SatO2 97%. Well perfused and hydrated. Eupneic. Head and neck: no jugular ingurgitation
column17: no palpable adenopathies. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column18: no murmurs or extratonos. Pulmonary auscultation: mild global hypoventilation and scattered expiratory wheezing. Abdomen: soft
column19: depressible
column20: not painful on palpation. Renal fist-percussion negative. Lower extremities: no oedema
column21: no evidence of DVT
column22: symmetrical palpable pulses.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG health centre (with pain): sinus rhythm at 60 bpm
column23: normal axis
column24: subepicardial lesion up to 2-3 mm inferoposterolateral. Chest X-ray: cardiomediastinal silhouette
column25: costophrenic sinuses
column26: lung fields and bone skeleton studied without alterations. Analysis: Glucose 127. Urea 27. Creatinine 0.78. Sodium 138. Potassium 4.4. Chlorine 106. Osmolality (calculated) 296. PCR 0
column27: 04. Haemoglobin 14.4. Platelets 172. Leucocytes *11. Eosinophils 8 %. Cholesterol 158. Triglycerides 32. HDL-cholesterol 76. AST/GOT 23. ALT/GPT 11. Alkaline phosphatase 102. Initial tryptase 32.7 ug/L
column28: at 2 hours 27.5 ug/L and 7 ug/L at 24 hours. Total IgE 635 kU/L and normal complement. Enzymes (on arrival): CPK 205
column29: CK-MB mass 8.7. Troponin I 2520. Peak: CK 225. CK-MB mass 8.7. Troponin I 3407. Catheterisation: trunk: no significant stenosis. Anterior descending: no significant stenosis. Circumflex: no significant stenosis. Right coronary: dominant. No significant stenosis. ECG at discharge: sinus rhythm at 60 bpm
column30: axis at 60o
column31: R>S in V3 without repolarisation alterations. Transthoracic echocardiogram at discharge: left ventricle of normal size. The left ventricular wall shows normal thickness. Left ventricular systolic function is normal (EF 65%). Left ventricular wall motion is normal. The right ventricle is normal with respect to size and function. Left atrial size is normal. The size of the right atrium is normal. The mitral valve is normal in structure and function. Anterograde mitral inflow with normal filling pattern. Tricuspid valve appears normal. Minimal tricuspid valve insufficiency is detected. Aortic valve normal in structure and function. Conclusion: normal echocardiogram.  EVOLUTION This is a 21-year-old male
column33: smoker
column34: asthmatic with several annual crises requiring emergency department visits and administration of intravenous corticosteroids and intramuscular adrenaline
column35: who was admitted to the Coronary Care Unit of our hospital due to infero-posterior STEACS in relation to an anaphylactic reaction with severe bronchospasm and hypotension
column36: with no clear trigger (probably environmental factor). The patient required administration of intravenous methylprednisolone and intramuscular adrenaline
column37: improving the respiratory symptoms
column38: but subepicardial lesion persisted despite sublingual nitroglycerine. An urgent coronary angiography was therefore performed without significant lesions. The picture was interpreted as a possible Kounis Syndrome. The Allergy Department assessed the patient with altered tryptase serology and elevated immunoglobulins and eosinophilia
column39: and concluded that the symptoms were due to an immunoallergic mechanism
column40: all of which was compatible with Kounis syndrome. Allergic tests were positive for environmental factors
column41: mites and pollen
column42: as possible triggers. He presented an enzymatic peak of 250 CK with troponin 3
column43: 500 with an initial TTE with a subsequent basal and mean hypokinesia that resolved on discharge. The patient was treated with acetylsalicylic acid
column44: amlodipine
column45: corticotherapy in a descending pattern and antihistamines with good clinical evolution
column46: with no new episodes of chest pain. Cardiac MRI was requested
column47: which showed good contractility
column48: preserved fraction and absence of late enhancement in viability sequences. Given the good evolution
column49: the patient was discharged on the seventh day after admission.  DIAGNOSIS Kounis syndrome (allergic vasospastic angina). Anaphylactic reaction with severe bronchospasm and hypotension. column12: III and aVF with ST-segment elevation in V1 and aVR. Transthoracic echocardiogram: LV without apparent contractility alterations. A flap from the aorta is observed in the ventricular cavity

column14: without adequate visualisation of the ascending aorta. The right cavities are normal and there is no pericardial effusion. Angio-CT scan: in the non-contrast phase
column15: linear calcification is identified in the lumen of the aortic arch
column16: as well as calcifications in the lumen of the abdominal aorta cranial to the renal vessels and both common iliac arteries
column17: compatible with atheroma plaques with displacement of the intima and therefore compatible with the suspicion of dissection. Aneurysm of the ascending aorta measuring 5 cm. The lung parenchyma showed interstitial thickening
column18: bilateral infiltrates predominantly in posterior regions and small pleural effusions
column19: suggestive of oedema.  EVOLUTION Given the echocardiographic findings
column20: emergent CT angiography was requested and Cardiac Surgery was notified for possible intervention. Norepinephrine perfusion was started and the patient was immediately transferred to radiology. There he presented with desaturation requiring OTI and then extreme bradycardia which prevented a valid CT angiography. Only non-contrast images were acquired in the arterial phase
column21: which were compatible with the suspicion of dissection of a 5 cm ascending aortic aneurysm
column22: together with pulmonary oedema. The patient rapidly evolves unfavourably
column23: with extreme bradycardia persisting despite advanced resuscitation manoeuvres
column24: which degenerates into asystole and death.  DIAGNOSIS Ascending aortic aneurysm. Acute aortic syndrome with suspected coronary and aortic valve involvement. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Male
column3: 38 years old
column4: from Morocco. No drug allergies. No medical or surgical history of interest. No toxic habits. No treatment at present. Active baseline life. Works in the countryside. He has been living in Spain for 7 years. The patient comes to the Cardiology Department with very unspecific symptoms. He reported a sensation of "noises in the heart" that appeared at rest. He denies dyspnoea on exertion. He also had no history of chest pain or syncope. Physical examination showed BP 125/ 60 mmHg
column5: HR 90 bpm
column6: good general condition
column7: afebrile
column8: eupneic at rest with baseline O2 saturation 98%. Cardiac auscultation with rhythmic heart sounds
column9: reinforcement of the first sound
column10: mitral opening click and audible diastolic rumble in the apex. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur without rales. Abdomen: soft and depressible
column11: not painful on palpation
column12: no masses or organomegaly. Lower limbs: symmetrical paedial pulses present. No oedema.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: sinus rhythm at 62 bpm
column13: PR 0.19 sec
column14: nicked P wave in II
column15: III and aVF and in left precordial leads
column16: non-pathological q wave in aVL
column17: normal ventriculogram. Blood tests: glucose 90 mg/dl. Urea 25 mg/dl. Creatinine 0.88 mg/dl. GOT 23.0. GPT 13.0 g/dl. Total cholesterol 126 mg/dl. Triglycerides 57 mg/dl. HDL cholesterol 45 mg/dl. LDL cholesterol 70 mg/dl. Haemoglobin 16
column18: 0 g/dl. Haematocrit 48
column19: 3 %. MCV 87.8 fl. Platelets 194.0 10e3/uL. Leukocytes 7.96 10e3/uL; TSH 1.55 IU/ml. Chest X-ray: slightly increased cardiothoracic index. Left atrial enlargement. Slight vascular redistribution. Free costophrenic sinuses. No infiltrates or condensation. Echocardiography: severely dilated left atrium (34 cm2). Normal right atrium. Normal aortic root
column20: ascending aorta and arch. Rheumatic mitral valve with stenosis morphology and low score for valvuloplasty (4
column21: without commissural calcium). Aortic sigmoid aortic valve trivalves
column22: thickened
column23: rheumatic
column24: with slightly reduced opening. Left ventricle slightly dilated (59 mm
column26: normal thickness. Preserved global and segmental LVSF (EF 65%). Normal right ventricle. AIS intact. Pericardium and cava system normal. Doppler: severe mitral stenosis AVE 0.85 cm2 by THP
column27: by planimetry 1.1 cm2
column28: mean gradient 12-14 mmHg). Trivial mitral insufficiency. Mild aortic stenosis (peak gradient 21 mmHg). Aortic insufficiency II/IV (central jet not crossing papillary muscle plane
column29: no diastolic reversal in descending thoracic or abdominal aorta). Trivial tricuspid regurgitation allowing estimation of mild PH (42 mmHg).  EVOLUTION This is a patient with rheumatic valve disease (mainly severe mitral stenosis) with minimal PH. However
column30: he presents with dubious symptoms or symptoms discordant with the severity of MS. Given the characteristics of the valve disease
column31: percutaneous mitral commissurotomy (PMC) would be indicated (valve area 0.85 cm2
column33: ultrasound score < 8
column34: absence of significant calcification or other valve diseases of greater than mild degree). Age is also a factor in favour of PMC
column35: thus postponing valve replacement surgery. We decided to request an exercise ultrasound to evaluate changes in the mitral gradient and pulmonary pressures
column36: which was positive due to the appearance of clinical symptoms and an increase in the mean transmitral gradient to 20 mmHg and pulmonary pressure >60 mmHg. With these results
column37: the case was presented at a medical-surgical session and was accepted for percutaneous mitral commissurotomy. The commissurotomy was performed using an Inoue balloon. By transseptal puncture
column38: the guide wire was advanced from the right atrium to the left ventricle
column39: crossing the mitral valve. The balloon is progressively inflated from distal to proximal
column40: thus adopting an hourglass shape that will serve to anchor the balloon to the valve upon removal. The procedure proceeds without immediate complications. Postoperative echocardiography shows an optimal result with mitral valve area > 1.5 cm2
column41: with no increase in mitral regurgitation. The patient evolved favourably during hospitalisation and was discharged pending review in the outpatient cardiology department to assess progress and tolerance to effort.  DIAGNOSIS Rheumatic polyvalvulopathy: severe mitral stenosis
column42: mild double aortic lesion. Preserved left ventricular systolic function. mild pulmonary hypertension at rest

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History 46-year-old male patient. No cardiovascular risk factors. No known personal cardiological history. No marfanoid habit. Diagnosed with discoid lupus under treatment. Father died of aortic dissection in 2010 at the age of 61
column3: with no history of hypertension or marfanoid habit. Trivalve aortic valve. Two healthy children.  Current disease In view of the father's history
column4: our patient and his sister were referred for a study in 2010. At that time the patient had an aortic root at the level of the sinuses of Valsalva of 39 mm
column5: dilated for his body surface
column6: a trivalve aortic valve and no stigma of Marfan or other syndromic entities
column7: so it was decided to follow up. During the follow-up
column8: a progressive growth of the aortic root was observed. In March 2017
column9: an angio-CT scan was completed
column10: confirming a 46 mm aorta.  Physical examination Height 1.80 m
column11: weight 72 kg
column12: BP 105/59 mmHg (symmetrical in both upper limbs)
column13: HR 80 bpm
column14: SatO2 98% on room air. Normal phenotype. CBC: no jugular ingurgitation. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column15: no audible murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: no superimposed sounds. Abdomen: nondescript. EIA: no malleolar oedema.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Echocardiogram in September 2014: LV not dilated or hypertrophic with normal systolic function. Diastolic pattern of prolonged relaxation. Dilatation of the aortic root with effacement of the sino-tubular junction. Maximum diameter of 43 mm. Aortic root dilatation with normal systolic function. Normofunctioning MV. Normal right chambers. Echocardiogram in September 2016: LA of normal size. LV of normal dimensions
column16: without alterations in segmental contractility and with normal systolic function. Normal filling pressures. Normofunctioning MV. AoV trivalva normofunctioning. RV of normal size and function
column17: without adequate signal for PSAP calculation. Dilated aortic root of 46 mm. No pericardial effusion. Normal vena cava. Analysis: biochemistry: Glc 92 mg/dl. Urea 36 mg/dl. Creatinine 0.95 mg/dl. Na 144 mmol/l. K 4.5 mmol/L
column18: FA 68 U/l. AST 16 U/l. ALT 18 U/l. GGT 22 U/. Haemogram: Hb 14.2 g/dl. Haematocrit 44 %. Leukocytes 6
column19: 520/uL with 57 % neutrophils. Platelets 245.000/uL. PT coagulation 86 %. INR 1.11. Fibrinogen 397. Angio-CT of aorta and coronary arteries: trivalve aortic valve. No alterations are observed in the origin of the coronary arteries. The aortic root measures 29.5 x 23.5 mm at the valve annulus
column20: 46 x 42 mm at the sinuses of Valsalva and 40 x 37 mm at the sinotubular junction. The ascending aorta measures 41 x 37.5 mm. The proximal portion of the aortic arch measures 30.5 x 30 mm
column21: the medial portion 28.5 x 25.5 mm and the isthmus 25.5 x 23.5 mm. The descending aorta at the level of the diaphragmatic pillars measures 22 x 20.5 mm. Normal origin of coronary arteries. Coronary arteries without lesions.  EVOLUTION Given the angio-CT findings and measurements together with the family history
column22: once syndromic entities had been ruled out
column23: the patient was framed in the context of aneurysm syndrome and family dissections
column24: and was referred to Cardiac Surgery for surgery. The patient was admitted on a scheduled basis for aortic root and ascending aorta replacement with a 34 mm tube with aortic valve reimplantation according to David's technique. Immediate postoperative evolution was favourable
column25: with no notable incidents or complications. The post-surgery echocardiogram showed a 33 mm aortic root with correct valve function. The anatomopathological study of the aortic fragment analysed showed a thinned elastic lamina with myxoid degeneration of the media. Finally
column26: the patient was discharged home
column27: pending the results of the genetic study requested.  DIAGNOSIS Ascending aortic aneurysm in an asymptomatic patient with a history of aortic dissection in a first-degree relative. Surgery for aortic root replacement and ascending aorta. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  Personal history HBP. Dyslipidaemia. Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation on OAC treatment. Diagnosed with bladder tumour
column3: TUR performed by the Urology Department. Under outpatient follow-up. She has had a DDDR permanent pacemaker for 2 months due to sinus node disease diagnosed following a syncopal episode. Active fixation electrode.  Current illness Initially admitted to the Pneumology Department due to exertional dyspnoea
column4: asthenia and pleuritic chest pain.  Physical examination BP 110/60 mmHg. HR 90 bpm. SatO2 98 % with nasal goggles at 2 l/min. Cardiac auscultation: R1 and R2 rhythmic and regular
column5: no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: hypoventilation in the middle and lower left hemithorax. Abdomen: non-painful
column6: with no signs of peritoneal irritation. Lower extremities: no oedema. Neurological examination: functions preserved.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: sinus rhythm at 75 bpm
column7: BRDHH
column8: HBAS. T-negative lower and lateral face. CBC: leukocytes 6
column9: 800/uL with 63.7% neutrophils
column10: Hb 11.5 g/dL
column12: platelets 255
column14: urea 23 mg/dL
column15: creatinine 0.91 mg/dL
column16: Na 142 mEq/L
column17: K 4.3 mEq/L. Chest X-ray: bicameral pacemaker. Significant left pleural effusion. Echocardioscopy: LV of normal dimensions. Preserved LVEF. No apparent segmental alterations of contractility. Normal right cavities with preserved visual contractility. No significant valvulopathies. Absence of pericardial effusion. Computed tomography (CT) of the chest: bicameral pacemaker with leads in the right atrium and ventricle. Perforation of the apex of the right ventricle by the ventricular electrode
column18: the end of which is located about 4 cm outside the cardiac contour
column19: is confirmed. There is a small haematoma in the sinus of the cardiophrenic fat. There is no pericardial effusion. There is abundant left pleural effusion
column20: of high density
column21: compatible with haemothorax. No pneumothorax was identified. Partial passive atelectasis of LSI and complete atelectasis of LII.  EVOLUTION Twenty-four hours after admission
column22: he presented dizziness and postural instability without loss of consciousness and chest pain with pleuritic characteristics
column23: for which we requested an assessment. The pacemaker device was checked and failed to sense and stimulate the ventricular electrode. Echocardioscopy without pericardial effusion. Despite the absence of pericardial effusion
column24: due to suspicion of myocardial perforation by the ventricular electrode
column25: an urgent thoracic CT scan was requested and the diagnosis was confirmed. The patient underwent emergency surgery in the operating theatre
column26: and the ventricular electrode was removed percutaneously with repositioning in the RVOT
column27: verifying correct thresholds
column28: sensing and impedance
column29: and the respective chest drain was implanted in the same procedure. The evolution was favourable
column30: with resolution of the haemothorax
column31: correct functioning of the pacing device and asymptomatic at discharge.  DIAGNOSIS Late myocardial perforation of RV apex by pacemaker lead. Reimplantation of ventricular lead in RVOT. Secondary haemothorax resolved on discharge. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 46-year-old woman diagnosed by chance with hepatic angiomas
column3: with no other medical or surgical history of interest. She consulted the cardiology department for self-limited episodes of rapid and regular palpitations
column4: with abrupt onset and end
column5: with no other accompanying symptoms. Physical examination revealed elevated jugular venous pressure up to the mandibular angle
column6: with no oedema in the lower limbs. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column7: no murmurs. No other data of interest.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Laboratory tests: blood count and biochemistry normal. Normal thyroid hormones. Electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm at 65 bpm
column8: narrow QRS
column9: normal repolarisation. Chest X-ray: increased cardiothoracic index. Normal lung fields. Transthoracic echocardiogram: left ventricle of normal size and function. Normal left atrium. Right atrium occupied by a large intracavitary mass. Morphologically normal valves
column10: without dysfunction. Moderate pericardial effusion with dilated inferior vena cava. After administration of a sulphur hexafluoride ecopotentiator
column11: no uptake by the mass was observed. Transesophageal echocardiogram: large intracavitary mass at the level of the right atrium
column12: occupying and filling practically the entire cavity
column13: without reaching the tricuspid valve plane or the atrioventricular groove
column14: with a broad base of implantation at the level of the atrial roof and the interatrial septum
column15: well defined
column16: measuring 8 cm x 6 cm
column17: with very heterogeneous echographic characteristics inside
column18: with large anechoic areas and other dense areas
column19: with an irregular interior appearance. This mass crosses the fossa ovalis towards the left atrium
column20: resting superiorly against the aorta without infiltrating it. Cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR): large mass in the RA (9 x 7 cm)
column21: well-defined borders
column22: does not appear to infiltrate the wall or pericardium
column23: relatively homogeneous
column24: appearing isointense on T1 sequences
column25: while on T2-weighted sequences it appears hyperintense. After gadolinium administration
column26: there is an absence of perfusion in the first step and only very slight heterogeneous enhancement in the late phases. Cranio-thorax-abdomen CT scan: well-defined 84 x 99 mm lesion occupying practically the entire right atrium
column27: contacting the uppermost part of the atrium and the interatrial septum
column28: with minimal introduction through the interatrial septum into the left atrium. It contacts the anterior zone of the right pulmonary artery and the right ascending aorta. Persistently hypodense with IV contrast. Large hepatomegaly with areas of uptake
column29: in relation to his known angiomatosis. CT scan of coronary arteries: coronary arteries without lesions.  Pathological anatomy of the tumour: intramyocardial cavernous cavernous haemangioma with papillary endothelial hyperplasia. No signs of malignancy were observed in the material studied. Inguinal adenopathies reactive lymphadenitis.  EVOLUTION Following the clinical manifestations described and the findings on examination
column30: a transthoracic echocardiogram was requested with the results described. After finding evidence of a large tumour in the right atrium
column31: various imaging tests were performed. Without a definitive diagnosis
column32: and with the differential diagnosis of myxoma versus sarcoma
column33: the patient underwent surgery. Resection of the tumour in the right atrium was performed with intraoperative biopsy. The right atrium and interatrial septum were reconstructed with two patches of bovine pericardium. Surgical findings: atrial tumour with a spongy appearance
column34: highly vascularised
column35: with a wide base of implantation in the roof of both atria and the interatrial septum. Small atrial septal defect with respected fossa ovalis. Infiltration only of the interatrial septum
column36: with absence of epicardial infiltration of other structures. An intraoperative biopsy was performed
column37: which showed a tumour formed by inter-anastomosed vascular channels
column38: without cytological atypia with lymphoid aggregates. Vascular tumour of low malignant potential. Postoperative evolution was uneventful
column39: remaining haemodynamically stable and cardiovascular asymptomatic. In subsequent follow-ups
column40: the patient presented paroxysmal atrial fibrillation
column41: the rhythm being controlled with flecainide. She remained stable
column42: with no evidence of recurrence in subsequent echocardiograms.  DIAGNOSIS Intramyocardial cavernous haemangioma with papillary endothelial hyperplasia. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 64-year-old male
column3: ex-smoker
column4: with a history of long-standing arterial hypertension and suboptimal control
column5: treated with ACE inhibitors and diuretics. He had a heart murmur since childhood
column6: "functional". The first non-invasive imaging study was performed in 2007
column7: due to a radiological finding of cardiomegaly on chest X-ray
column8: in the context of a study of hypertensive crisis in the emergency department. A transthoracic echocardiogram was performed showing severe concentric left ventricular hypertrophy without dilatation of the cavity and with good systolic function (ejection fraction 72%). The mitral valve is congenitally defective
column9: with a "parachute" arrangement
column10: anterior leaflet prolapse and single posteromedial papillary muscle. All this leads to a double functional alteration with mild stenosis (effective area 2.5 cm2; mean gradient 4 mmHg) and moderate (III/IV) eccentric insufficiency. The aortic valve is bicuspid
column11: with a slightly restricted antero-posterior opening (intercoronary fusion) (systolic doming; maximum transvalvular gradient of 35 mm Hg and effective area by continuity equation of 1.9 cm2). No diastolic prolapse or regurgitation was observed. The aortic root and ascending aorta are of normal diameters. The right chambers are structurally and functionally normal
column12: with no evidence of pulmonary arterial hypertension. Flow analysis of the abdominal and descending thoracic aorta showed data suggestive of aortic coarctation (diastolic prolongation and gradient in the descending aorta reaching a systolic peak of 107 mmHg). In view of these findings

Doppler analysis shows a pattern of systolic acceleration with a peak gradient of 80 mmHg

Controlled massage of the left carotid sinus reproduced the same symptomatology with a positive cardioinhibitory response with pauses of 4 sec. After discussing the case with Cardiology and Otorhinolaryngology on duty
column54: beta-blocker treatment was suspended and the patient was admitted to the observation room for monitoring and ECG recording
column55: in addition to performing an ultrasound-guided FNA with the aim of identifying the cervical mass to allow therapeutic guidance. During monitoring
column56: the patient suffered new syncopal and presyncopal episodes with bradycardia and significant pauses. FNAUS was performed with inconclusive results. In view of the finding of episodes of symptomatic bradycardia with significant pauses
column57: the patient was diagnosed with peripheral neurocardiogenic syncope secondary to carotid compression by a large cervical mass pending filiation
column58: and was admitted to Cardiology for implantation of a VVIR pacemaker to control the cardioinhibitory reflex. This procedure was carried out without complications
column59: and its correct functioning was checked
column60: being programmed in VVIR at 70/60 beats per minute. Subsequently
column61: beta-blockers were restarted for AF at around 110 beats per minute. After a CT scan
column62: biopsy and anatomopathological study of the cervical mass
column63: Otorhinolaryngology concluded that it was a cervical adenopathic conglomerate with a diagnosis of high-grade diffuse large-cell B lymphoma. The patient was transferred to the haematology department to complete the study and start specific chemotherapy treatment according to the R-CHOP scheme (rituximab
column64: cyclophosphamide
column65: liposomal doxorubicin due to being a cardiac patient
column66: vincristine and prednisone). During admission to haematology
column67: episodes of dyspnoea and dysphagia with good response to corticoids and cytoreduction with cyclophosphamide. Rapid reduction of the cervical mass with symptomatic improvement and no new syncopal episodes. Given the clinical stability
column68: discharge was decided to continue treatment on an outpatient basis.  DIAGNOSIS Cardioinhibitory reflex vasovagal syncope secondary to compression of the carotid sinus by a large cervical mass. Large B-cell non-Hodgkin's lymphoma
column69: stage II-B
column70: triple-Hit (BCL-2
column71: BCL-6 and C-MYC). |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION We present the case of a 77-year-old woman
column3: hypertensive and diabetic
column4: with no family history or previous cardiological history. The patient consulted the emergency department of her hospital for an episode of chest pain at rest
column5: of about two hours' duration
column6: accompanied by vegetative crust. She reported symptoms compatible with exertional angina during the previous two weeks
column7: with a progressive drop in the pain threshold. There were no other cardiological symptoms in the anamnesis. An electrocardiogram was performed showing ST-segment elevation in the anterior face
column8: and the haemodynamics department was contacted
column9: and the patient was transferred to our hospital for primary angioplasty. Catheterisation revealed 95% stenosis in the middle LAD (see coronary angiography)
column10: which was revascularised by thromboaspiration and implantation of two drug-eluting stents. Subsequent transfer to ICU to continue immediate evolution. On admission
column11: the patient was haemodynamically stable and in good general condition. BP 140/70 HR 90 bpm ACP: rhythmic tones without murmurs. Bladder murmur preserved without pathological sounds. Lower limbs without oedema. No congestive or low output semiology.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG on admission to Cardiology: sinus rhythm at 75 bpm. Normal axis. Normal PR. Narrow QRS QS from V1-V4 with significant ST elevation in precordial leads (more pronounced in V3-V4
column12: "tombstone ST") and in inferior face. CBC: blood glucose 140 mg/dl
column13: creatinine 0.90 mg/dl
column14: urea 37 mg/dl
column15: Na 140 mEq/l
column16: K 3 mEq/l
column17: Hb 10 g/dl. Leukocytosis of 14
column18: 000 on admission (predominantly polymorphonuclear) which subsequently normalised. Platelets 500
column20: normal coagulation. Liver
column21: lipid and thyroid profile without alterations. Glycated Hb 10.7%. Peak TNTUs 1327 ng/L
column22: CPK 227 mU/ml. Coronary angiography: normo-developed anterior descending artery of good calibre
column23: with acute lesion (95 %) in the middle segment
column24: distal vessel TIMI 1 flow
column25: of regular calibre. Rest without significant lesions. Right dominance. Urgent PCI on middle LAD: thromboaspiration with catheter
column26: implanting zotarolimus-eluting stent (2.25 x 18 mm) and another non-consecutive stent-eluting stent (3 x 15 mm). Final TIMI flow 2 improved with intracoronary nitroprusside. Transthoracic echocardiography: left atrium slightly dilated (37 ml/m2). Mitral valve with calcification of the posterior annulus but with thin leaflets and good mobility. Mild central mitral regurgitation. Slightly dilated LV (VTDi 68.23 ml/m2) with 9 mm basal septum and 6.5 mm posterior wall. Mitral filling pattern with E > A and E/e ́ averaged 7. Akinesia of all apical segments with compensatory hypercontractility of the remaining segments and LVEF estimated by Simpson biplane at 65%. An interventricular septal defect was observed at the apical level compatible with VSD. The largest diameter is recorded in more anterior planes (1.3 mm). High velocity flow is achieved with Vmax 4.5 m/sec and mean gradient 42.5 mmHg. Fibrocalcified aortic valve with adequate opening and mild central insufficiency. Non-dilated RV with preserved systolic function (TAPSE 23 mm). Mild IT jet that allows estimating a PAPs of 56-57 mmHG. Non-dilated IVC with adequate inspiratory collapse. No pericardial effusion Transesophageal echocardiography: in the most apical segment of the septum
column27: which is akinetic
column28: there is a solution of continuity compatible with VSD with high velocity flow passage. This VSD is best defined in more anterior planes of the septum
column29: with diameters of 1.2 cm x 1.9 cm (area > 2 cm2 with friable surrounding tissue). The septal myocardium more proximal to the defect
column30: also akinetic
column31: has a rarefied and hollow appearance. The VSD lacks borders in its distal part
column32: continuing with the more apical myocardium which is very thinned.  EVOLUTION The patient evolves favourably in the first hours after the intervention. Bedside echocardiography showed akinesia in the apical territory and preserved LVEF. The patient was monitored and treatment for acute coronary syndrome was continued. At 12 hours
column33: the patient had a loud systolic murmur
column34: more audible in the left parasternal focus
column35: which was not present on arrival. A repeat transthoracic echocardiogram was performed to rule out early post-AMI mechanical complications. A solution of continuity was found in the apical interventricular septum with a high velocity left-to-right flow passage. Echocardiography also showed data compatible with pulmonary hypertension. After a diagnosis of ventricular septal defect (VSD)
column36: the Cardiac Surgery Department was consulted and
column37: given the clinical context (advanced age in a patient with comorbidity
column38: double antiplatelet therapy and relative stability)
column39: emergency surgery was ruled out at that time. The patient remained stable for the next 72 hours and was transferred to the cardiology monitoring unit for further treatment. She initially evolved unfavourably
column40: presenting congestive semiology
column41: so continuous perfusion of furosemide was started. A 24-hour infusion of levosimendan was prescribed
column42: with subsequent improvement.  Repeat transthoracic echocardiography showed a septoapical VSD with a high-speed left-to-right shunt (V max 4.5 m/sec mean gradient 43 mmHg). The RV-AD gradient is 53 mmHg
column43: compatible with at least moderate pulmonary hypertension. Given that there was an indication for VSD closure
column44: and in order to decide on the optimal approach (percutaneous versus surgical)
column45: transesophageal echocardiography was requested. A 3D TEE reconstruction of the septal defect (diameter 1.2 x 1.9 cm and area > 2 cm2) was performed. The VSD lacked borders in its distal part
column46: and the myocardium proximal to it was rarefied (friable appearance and with hollows). Given these findings
column47: percutaneous closure was ruled out and the patient was accepted for surgery. Surgery was performed three weeks after the AMI.  DIAGNOSIS Anterior STEMI subjected to primary angioplasty with revascularisation of the culprit lesion in the mid LAD using two drug-eluting stents. Septoapical VSD as an early post-AMI mechanical complication corrected surgically. Akinesia in the apical territory
column48: with preserved LVEF. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 78-year-old woman
column3: independent for basic activities of daily living and without cognitive impairment. She had previously been diagnosed with arterial hypertension
column4: obesity
column5: hypothyroidism and depression. She was being treated with candesartan 8 mg
column6: sertraline 100 mg and levothyroxine 150 mcg. She came to the emergency department for dyspnoea of 2 months' duration
column7: with no clear relationship with exertion. She reported no chest pain
column8: palpitations or other cardiac symptoms. Physical examination: afebrile
column9: with a heart rate of 77 bpm
column10: BP 140/94 mmHg and respiratory rate of 16 rpm. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic and without murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: moderate inspiratory stridor. The neurological
column11: abdominal and extremities examination showed no abnormalities.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Biochemistry: Na 141 mEq/L
column12: K 4.2 mEq/L
column13: Cr 0.9 mg/dl
column14: U 43 IU/L
column15: AST 26 IU/L
column16: ALT 31 IU/L. Blood count and coagulation: Hb 12.4 mg/dl
column17: MCV 95 fL
column18: Htco 45 %
column19: Leukocytes 10
column21: PT 97 %. Baseline arterial blood gases: pH 7.35
column22: SatO2 85 %
column23: pO2 55 mmHg
column24: pCO2 32 mmHg. ECG: sinus at 90 bpm. No evidence of ischaemia
column25: conduction disturbances or repolarisation. Chest X-ray: normal cardiothoracic index. No condensation. Angio-CT of pulmonary arteries: absence of acute PTE. No local complications at the level of the thoracic aorta.  EVOLUTION Given the absence of signs of decompensation due to heart failure and given that the initial tests were not suggestive of structural heart disease
column26: she was initially evaluated by pulmonology due to inspiratory stridor. Bronchoscopy revealed an intermediate tracheobronchomalacia
column27: for which bronchodilator and corticosteroid treatment was started. The evolution was poor
column28: with the patient presenting numerous episodes of dyspnoea and desaturation
column29: mainly when sitting or standing upright. Cardiology consultation was requested. A transthoracic echocardiogram was performed which showed: non-dilated left ventricle with preserved systolic function
column30: non-dilated and normofunctioning right ventricle
column31: aneurysmal interatrial septum with right-left bubble passage after infusion of agitated saline
column33: no pericardial effusion or other findings of interest. A catheterisation was requested for a pressure study
column34: with normal pulmonary pressure
column35: interlocking pressure and pressures in the left chambers. During this procedure
column36: an AL2 catheter was passed into the left atrium through the foramen ovale
column37: allowing oximetry samples to be obtained at the central venous level
column38: in the right and left chambers
column39: both in the supine and seated positions. A jump in O2 saturation and pressure was observed between the pulmonary veins and left chambers. Systemic flow was also 26 % higher than pulmonary flow. The patient was referred back to the haemodynamics laboratory for closure of the foramen ovale in a procedure guided by transesophageal echocardiography. A balloon occlusion test was initially performed
column40: showing an increase in supine arterial saturation from 78% to 93%. Subsequently
column41: the patent foramen ovale was closed using an 18 mm Amplatzer ASD device. Control TEE showed a near total reduction of the shunt with correct positioning of the Amplatzer.  DIAGNOSIS Platypnoea-orthodeoxia syndrome. Patent foramen ovale (with occasional right-to-left shunt). |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  Personal history Independent for ADLs. Lives with daughter. No known drug allergies. Denies toxic habits. She has a history of years of arterial hypertension and dyslipidaemia Diabetes mellitus type 2 in treatment with oral antidiabetics. Hypothyroidism on hormone replacement therapy. Ischaemic stroke (2015) in the left MCA territory
column3: of atherothrombotic aetiology
column4: the only sequelae being deviation of the oral commissure. The family reports a benign brain tumour (possible meningioma). Left optic nerve atrophy with secondary decrease in visual acuity  Cardiological history: chronic ischaemic heart disease starting with angina in 2003
column5: with TC and 3-vessel disease. In 2005
column6: double coronary artery bypass from internal mammary artery (IMA) to anterior descending (AD) and from saphenous vein (SV) to right coronary artery (RCA) was performed in another centre. Subsequently new episodes of angina
column7: with coronary angiography (2008): distal coronary trunk (TCd) 75% including ostium of DA and circumflex (CF) (90% in all these lesions)
column8: CDp CTO
column9: AMI-DA 100% and VS-DP permeable. PCI was not performed. In 2013
column10: she presented an episode of unstable angina and was studied at the centre where she had undergone surgery
column11: and echocardiography was performed with preserved LVEF and infero-basal akinesia
column12: and coronary angiography was repeated (2013): severe lesion in distal TC and DAp
column13: chronic underocclusion in proximal CF
column14: chronic complete occlusion in proximal CD; occluded AMI-DA graft and patent VS-DP without stenosis. It was considered a bad case for percutaneous revascularisation
column15: opting for medical treatment
column16: as it seems that she has had few symptoms from the cardiological point of view for several years.  Usual medication: ASA 100 mg 1-0-0
column17: atenolol 25 1-0-0
column18: oral nitrates (40 mg) 1-1-1
column19: metformin 850 mg 0-1-0
column20: levothyroxine 75 mcg 1-0-0
column21: atorvastatin 80 mg 0-0-1
column22: enalapril 20 mg 1-0-0.  CURRENT ILLNESS Since 17/04/17 he has had episodes of palpitations
column23: accompanied by oppressive central thoracic pain with irradiation to both upper extremities
column24: without vegetatism
column25: which subside with rest. She has presented daily episodes of chest pain of the same characteristics
column26: some related to small efforts and others at rest
column27: self-limited and of variable duration (up to 2 hours)
column28: which remind her of the episodes of angina with which her coronary disease debuted in 2003. On 21/04/17
column29: when she woke up at 9 am
column30: she had another episode of similar pain lasting about 30 minutes
column31: so she consulted the Accident and Emergency department of the corresponding regional hospital. On arrival
column32: the patient was asymptomatic and haemodynamically stable. An ECG was performed with evidence of AF at 69 bpm (not described in previous reports)
column33: with unknown LBBB (not described in the 2015 medical report). Troponin I was measured at 1.4 ng/ml (limit of significance 0.04 ng/ml). A 300 mg ASA and 300 mg clopidogrel and 40 mg enoxaparin were administered
column34: and the patient was referred to our centre for admission to the Coronary Unit.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Blood tests at the regional hospital: creatinine 1.06 mg/dl. CK 110U/L. Sodium 139 mEq/L
column35: potassium 4.8 mEq/L. Chlorine 108 mEq/L. Glucose 178 mg/dl. Lactate 1.82 mmol/L. GSV pH 7.28
column36: pCO2 43 mmHg. Bicarbonate 25.8 mmol/L. INR 1.18
column37: TTPAr 30.2s. Hb 11.4 g/dl
column38: Htc 35.6%. Leukocytes 5
column40: platelets 163
column41: 000. Troponin I: 1.42 - 1.948 (peak)- 1.3 ng/ml. Cardiological profile: Gluc 88 mg/dl. Urea 43 mg/dl. Creatinine 0
column42: 79 mg/dl. Cholesterol 119 mg/dl. HDL 36 mg/dl. LDL 64 mg/dl. TG 89 mg/dl. GOT 209 U/L. GPT 211 U/L. GGT 180 U/L. FAlc 134 U/l. Na 143 mEq/l. K 4.2 mEq/l. Hb 11.3 g/dl. Ht 3 7.2 %
column43: MCV 87. Platelets 146
column44: 000. TSH 0 m42 uU/ml
column45: free T4 1.26 ng/dl. HbA1c 8.2 % Control laboratory tests 8 weeks after discharge: HbA1c 7.1 %
column46: GOT 112
column47: GPT 71
column48: GGT 91U/L
column49: FAlc 96. ECG on admission: atrial fibrillation with FVM of 72 bpm
column50: LBBB. Control ECG: sinus rhythm 50 bpm
column51: LBBB
column52: frequent atrial extrasystoles. ECG at discharge: RS at 57 bpm
column53: LBBB. Chest X-ray: silhouette at high limit of normality. Sternotomy sutures. Normal lung fields. Coronary angiography: severe lesion at the level of the distal common trunk. It is a trifurcated trunk (DA-Biscitrus-CX). LAD with significant lesions in the middle third. Distal vessel of small calibre. Significant lesion at the level of the middle-distal third of the bisector branch. Small calibre distal vessel. CX with severe lesion at the level of the proximal third. Critical lesion at the level of the CX-1st OM bifurcation. Small calibre distal vessel. Dominant DC with chronic occlusion at the level of the proximal third. Distal vessel visible from saphenous graft to posterior descending artery. Saphenous graft to posterior descending without significant lesions. No cannulation of mammary graft to LAD (occluded according to previous reports). Echocardiogram: non-dilated left ventricle
column54: moderate septal hypertrophy
column55: preserved systolic function (EF Simpson 4C 53 %) with akinesia and thinning of mid and basal segments of inferior and inferoseptal face
column56: without other evident alterations of segmental wall contractility. Pseudonormal diastolic pattern. Right ventricle of normal size
column57: preserved function. Left atrium slightly dilated. Normal aortic diameters. Trivalve aortic valve
column58: with thickening and calcification of the base of all leaflets
column59: predominantly the non-coronary leaflet with preserved opening
column60: mild insufficiency. Mitral valve with slightly thickened leaflets
column61: preserved opening
column62: mild central regurgitation (EROA 0.04 cm2
column63: RV 8 ml). Tricuspid valve with mild insufficiency allowing estimation of PSAP of at least 26 mmHg. Non-dilated inferior vena cava with inspiratory collapse > 50%. No pericardial effusion. No intracardiac masses are evident.  EVOLUTION On arrival
column64: she remained asymptomatic. Echoscopy was performed with preserved LVEF. Akinesia of the basal segments of the inferior and inferolateral face and severe hypokinesia of the middle segments of the inferior and inferolateral face. RV with normal morphology and contractility. No significant valvulopathy or pericardial effusion. ECG on admission in AF with controlled FVM
column65: reverting to RS spontaneously at the time of admission. We maintain double antiplatelet therapy and anticoagulation (for NSTEACS and paroxysmal AF in patient with CHA2DS2-VASc 8). Tendency to bradycardia
column66: so beta-blockers were suspended and restarted on 24/4 at low doses. ECG persists with LBBB and supraventricular extrasystoles. Peak troponin I 1.9 ng/ml. Tolerates sitting. After reviewing the last coronary angiography
column67: and given the abruptness of the clinical picture with high suspicion of VS bypass lesion/occlusion
column68: it was decided to perform coronary angiography directly without prior ischaemia detection test
column69: which showed similar findings to those found (according to the report from the hospital where the revascularisation surgery was performed) in the study performed in 2013. Haematoma in relation to the radial puncture that is resolved by prolonging the compressive bandage given the clinical stability is discharged to the ward. On the ward it was considered that the infarction could be related to episodes of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation
column70: so amiodarone was added and beta-blockers were adjusted. It was decided to optimise medical treatment. An ordinary analysis revealed elevated transaminases
column71: already present in previous analyses
column72: probably related to high doses of statins
column73: so atorvastatin was replaced by pitavastatin. The patient was switched to pitavastatin 4 mg to assess liver enzyme control on an outpatient basis. HbA1c 8.2 % was also noted
column74: so it was decided to start empaglifazone on discharge. Given the history of a possible meningioma and the haematoma of the right arm
column75: it was decided not to start anticoagulation and to assess its initiation on an outpatient basis. She remained stable
column76: with no new episodes of chest pain. She began to ambulate with good tolerance and was discharged from hospital. The patient was seen 8 weeks after hospital discharge and presented CF II
column77: with no new episodes of angina since she had been at home and with a glycated haemoglobin of 7.1%
column78: as well as an improvement in her liver profile.  DIAGNOSIS Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction
column79: type 2. Chronic ischaemic heart disease. Coronary artery disease of LMCA and 3 vessels. Carrier of double bypass AMI-DA (occluded) and VS-DP (patent). Ischaemic heart disease with preserved ventricular function. History of ischaemic stroke. Arterial hypertension. Dyslipidaemia. Diabetes mellitus type 2 Hypothyroidism. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  Personal history No known drug allergies. Ex-smoker for 30 years. Ex-excessive drinker for 3-4 years. CVRF: hypertension
column3: dyslipidaemia. No diabetes mellitus. Studied in May 2015 by the Chest Pain Unit for recurrent chest pain with negative ischaemia detection tests. Previous surgical interventions: appendectomy. Usual treatment: simvastatin 20 mg c/24 hours; enalapril 20 mg c/24 hours.   Current disease Patient with the previously described personal history came to the emergency department of our hospital after starting with oppressive central thoracic pain
column4: radiating to the shoulder and left upper limb
column5: without associated vegetative cortex while he was shaving. Given the persistence of the pain
column6: he decided to sit down
column7: subsequently fainting with sudden loss of consciousness
column8: without prodrome and with associated cranioencephalic traumatism after hitting the floor
column9: recovery ad integrum
column10: without remembering anything of what had happened and without being able to specify the duration as it was not witnessed by anyone. The patient reported that he had previously been awakened by a central thoracic pain of similar characteristics
column11: but of shorter duration and self-limited. He denied worsening of functional class
column12: no orthopnoea or episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea. She had not had previous syncopal episodes or chest pain related to exertion or at rest.  Physical examination The patient was stable
column13: in good general condition. Well hydrated and perfused. Eupneic at rest and tolerating decubitus. Afebrile and haemodynamically stable. BP 203/96 mmHg. HR 80 bpm. On auscultation
column14: rhythmic tones
column15: no murmurs. Bladder murmur was preserved
column16: with no other superimposed noises. The rest of the examination was unremarkable.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm at 70 bpm
column17: normal axis. PR 160 msec. Narrow QRS
column18: rectified ST segment in V6 already described in previous records. Laboratory tests: biochemistry with renal function
column19: glycaemia and ions in range. Haemogram with values within normality. Serial cardiac enzymes within normal range. Chest X-ray: normal cardiothoracic index. No images of parenchymal condensation
column20: free costophrenic sinuses. Transthoracic echocardiography: left atrium of normal dimensions. Left ventricle not dilated
column21: normal myocardial thickness. No segmental alterations of contractility are visualised
column22: systolic function by Simpson biplane of 60 %. Trivalve aortic valve with slight fibrosclerosis
column23: opening and mobility of its leaflets preserved. Aortic root not dilated. Mitral valve with thin leaflets and good mobility. Mitral filling pattern with E>A wave. Right chambers not dilated
column24: preserved systolic function (TAPSE 20 mm). Mild tricuspid insufficiency allowing an estimated PAP of 17 mmHg. No pericardial effusion. Cardiac catheterisation: left coronary trunk without lesions. Descending artery without lesions with good distal vessel. Circumflex artery without lesions. Very high origin of the right coronary artery with impossibility of selective probing; aortography visualised the proximal
column25: middle and distal segments without disease. Coronary angio-CT: anomaly in the exit of the right coronary artery which instead of leaving the right coronary sinus leaves the medial portion of the left common coronary trunk
column26: following an interarterial path between the pulmonary artery and the ascending aorta to then reach its usual position (malignant coronary anomaly)
column27: measuring the maximum calibre at its interarterial passage of 2.5-3 mm to continue with its usual route with a calibre of 4 mm. The rest of the vessels without anomalies. Doppler ultrasound of supra-aortic trunks: non-significant stenosis of the left internal carotid artery. Non-significant stenosis of the right external carotid artery.  EVOLUTION Patient with multiple CVRF admitted to our ward for chest pain with a high intermediate pre-test probability of ischaemic heart disease
column28: so it was decided to carry out a test to detect intermediate ischaemia. During his admission the day before the stress test was performed
column29: the patient presented a new episode of chest pain coinciding with high blood pressure figures and documenting electrical changes in the ECG performed
column30: which normalised after the pain subsided
column31: so it was decided to request direct coronary angiography
column32: suspending the exercise stress test. The catheterisation was reported as a left coronary artery without lesions and the inability to probe the right coronary artery due to a very high origin which
column33: given the images
column34: was suggestive of an anomaly of the origin of this coronary artery. Given the findings
column35: it was decided to perform a coronary angio-CT scan to confirm the suspected diagnosis
column36: which documented the anomalous origin of the right coronary artery which
column37: instead of leaving its usual location in the right coronary sinus
column38: has its origin in the left common coronary trunk and then follows a path between both pulmonary arteries and the aorta and then follows its usual path
column39: this being a malignant coronary anomaly. It was decided to present the case at a medical-surgical session to discuss the possibility of surgery for this anomaly
column40: and the patient was accepted. The intervention was carried out during admission
column41: proceeding to dissection and reanostomosis of the right coronary artery to the right coronary sinus with good results and without intraoperative complications. The patient evolved favourably during the postoperative period
column42: without complications related to the intervention and without new episodes of chest pain or other symptoms
column43: and was subsequently discharged home. After hospital discharge and with regular check-ups
column44: the patient remains asymptomatic and in good functional class.  DIAGNOSIS Typical chest pain in a patient with malignant coronary anomaly with origin of the right coronary artery from the left main coronary artery. Surgical intervention with reanastomosis of the right coronary artery to the aortic coronary sinus on the same side. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
