column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION We present the case of an 85-year-old man
column3: in good baseline condition
column4: independent in all activities
column5: with no known medical history
column6: no regular treatment and no recent check-ups. He was completely asymptomatic in the early morning and went to the fields to do his work. He begins with oppressive chest pain but decides not to seek urgent medical attention. Some time later he was found by his relatives who
column7: alarmed by the fact that they also observed some difficulty in speaking and walking
column8: took him to the local health centre. The patient is unable to specify the exact time of evolution from the onset of symptoms
column9: although it could correspond to an interval of 4-5 hours until the first medical contact. On arrival he presented: BP 150/60 mmHg
column10: HR 45 bpm. Afebrile. O2 sat 96% at baseline. Cardiopulmonary auscultation: arrhythmic with ejection systolic murmur suggestive of aortic sclerosis. Bladder murmur preserved without clear crackles. He continued with residual chest discomfort
column11: of lesser intensity.  ECG shows atrial fibrillation at 50 bpm. Normal axis. Little marked ST-segment elevation in II
column12: III and avF
column13: without Q wave. Good R wave growth in precordial leads. During the first assessment
column14: the patient's speech was striking
column15: with difficulty in expressing certain words
column16: and the physical examination revealed haemiparesis of the left limbs. It was decided to transfer the patient to the Emergency Department of the hospital
column17: where the neurologist on duty was notified and an urgent brain CT scan was performed.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG on arrival at the Emergency Department: atrial fibrillation at 50 bpm. Normal axis. Little marked ST segment elevation in II
column18: III and avF
column19: without Q wave. Urgent brain CT scan: no signs of intracranial bleeding. There were signs of small vessel encephalopathy
column20: cerebral ageing and lacunar infarcts without evidence of acute extensive ischaemic infarction. Urgent echocardiogram: non-dilated left ventricle. Mild wall hypertrophy. Global contractility preserved
column21: estimated LVEF 60%. Inferolateral hypokinesia. No pericardial effusion. No aortic root dilatation. Good suprasternal window and no involvement of supra-aortic vessels. CBC: haemogram
column22: ions
column23: renal function in range. Elevation of cardiac markers. First determination of troponin I: 51 ng/ml.  EVOLUTION In the Emergency Department
column24: intravenous nitroglycerine perfusion was started
column25: which almost completely controlled the chest pain. Electrocardiographic findings showed an inferior STEACS in the context of non-anticoagulated AF. Neurological examination showed left hemiparesis 3/5
column26: facial nerve involvement on the same side and ipsilateral positive Babinski. The clinical suspicion was ischaemic stroke of embolic origin. We decided not to administer antiplatelet agents until an imaging test was available. First of all
column27: we transferred the patient for a cranial and thoracic CT scan1 . This confirmed the ischaemic nature of the stroke
column28: ruled out intracranial haemorrhage and possible anomalies of the supra-aortic trunks (dissection type).  Intravenous thrombolysis in the Stroke Code is only recommended in patients seen within 4.5 hours of the onset of symptoms1. At the time of our assessment
column29: the time was longer and did not meet the criteria for mechanical thrombectomy
column30: so no cerebral reperfusion treatment could be carried out. We then performed an urgent echocardiogram where we observed a hypokinesia in the inferolateral face
column31: with no other significant findings. After this
column32: urgent coronary angiography was performed via the femoral artery (radial access was not possible). The images showed angiographically normal left main coronary artery
column33: anterior descending
column34: circumflex and right coronary arteries. A stop was observed at the level of the middle circumflex artery with superior convexity
column35: compatible with coronary embolism. Thromboaspiration was performed
column36: recovering TIMI III flow
column37: with a good final result. There was no angiographic stenosis suggestive of underlying atherosclerotic disease. No stent implantation was necessary. The history of non-anticoagulated embolic AF
column38: the normal coronary angiography and the angiographic appearance of the culprit lesion suggested coronary embolism as the cause of the acute myocardial infarction. The patient was admitted to hospital and 72 hours later a repeat CT scan of the brain showed a new cortico-subcortical hypodensity in the medial aspect of the right temporal lobe in relation to the acute ischaemic stroke in progress
column39: with an intermediate risk of haemorrhagic transformation.  DIAGNOSIS Non-anticoagulated atrial fibrillation. Ischaemic stroke of embolic origin
column40: dependent on the right posterior cerebral artery. STEMI. Coronary embolism in the circumflex territory. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  Personal history Allergies to metamizole and tonopan (dihydroergotamine mesylate/caffeine/propifenazone). Cardiovascular risk factors: hypercholesteronemia. No diabetes mellitus or known hypertension. Smoker. Sedentary life in relation to joint problems in both MMII. Perthes disease (right hip cup arthroplasty). Left ankle fracture with prosthesis implant. Tonsillectomy. Usual treatment: No previous usual treatment.  Present illness Patient aged 44 years who
column3: while eating at home
column4: began to experience deviation of the corner of her mouth to the left and speech disturbance. The SAMU was notified and in the initial assessment they obtained a score of 3 on the NIHSS scale and observed ECG alterations with bouts of bigeminy and T wave inversion
column5: especially in the lateral face. The patient denied chest pain
column6: dyspnoea
column7: paraesthesia or neurovegetative symptoms.  Physical examination During her stay in the ED
column8: her general condition was acceptable. Well hydrated and perfused. BP 107/70 mmHg
column9: HR 111 bpm
column10: RR 18 rpm. Eupneic at rest with basal SatO2 98%. Carotids without murmurs. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds with mitral murmur. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur
column11: without aggregates. Soft
column12: non-painful
column13: depressible abdomen. No oedema in the lower extremities or evidence of DVT (painful
column14: reddened area on the left ankle). Neurological examination: mild expressive aphasia (difficulties in naming some objects with occasional paraphasia
column15: with preserved comprehension). No dysarthria. Right hemianopsia. No ophthalmoparesis. Mild right central facial paresis. No obvious motor or sensory deficits. Normal cerebellum. NIHSS scale 6.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Admission electrocardiogram: sinus tachycardia at 115 bpm. PR segment 90 ms (pre-excitation)
column16: incomplete right bundle branch block. Alterations in repolarisation characterised by ST underleveling and negative T waves of V3-V6 and DII
column17: DIII and aVF. QTc > 500. Chest X-ray: cardiac silhouette respected. No evidence of pulmonary congestion. Laboratory: haemoglobin 15.5 g/dL. Leukocytes 11
column18: 590 (N 68.4%). Platelets 249
column19: 000. Biochemistry: glucose 109 mg/dl
column20: urea 11 mg/dl
column21: creatinine 0.57 mg/dl
column22: sodium 136 mmol/l
column23: potassium 3.7 mmol/l. Coagulation normal with INR 0.97. Biomarkers: creatine kinase 57 U/L (normal 24-195). Troponin T 36 ng/L (< 14 negative). Homocysteine 19.3 μmol/L. Lupus anticoagulant SCT-C: 1.34 (high).  Cardiac monitoring: no arrhythmic events of interest
column24: in sinus rhythm at all times. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) on admission: left ventricle neither hypertrophic nor dilated. LVEF slightly affected visu visu with akinesia of all apical segments and compensatory hypercontractility of the basal segments. Intraventricular gradient up to 64 mmHg. Right chambers of normal size and function. Moderate mitral regurgitation due to SAM. Normofunctioning aortic valve. No pericardial effusion. Vena cava not dilated. Multimodal cranial CT scan on admission: no haemorrhages were observed. Slight loss of left hemispheric sulcus of temporal predominance without clear representation of hypodense areas
column25: except in a doubtful way in the deepest region of the left sylvian valley. ASPECTS 9-10. Perfusion: extensive cortical ischaemic lesion of the left temporal lobe and extending towards the parietal lobe with extensive areas of decreased flow and volume
column26: showing little mismatch. Only the highest area at the level of the parietal lobe is spared. Angio-CT: no alterations in the caudal outflow of the supra-aortic trunks. Permeable vertebrae. Carotid territories without significant alterations. Proximal obstruction of the left M2 parietal branch
column27: with scarce collaterals. Incidentally
column28: an incipient aneurysmal ectasia is seen in the most distal region of the right middle cerebral artery at the level of its bifurcation. Perfusion angio-CT scan: extensive cortical ischaemic lesion affecting the left temporal lobe and extending into the parietal lobe with extensive areas of decreased flow and volume
column29: reflecting low mismatch. The anterior two thirds of the infarct is low and only the highest area at the level of the parietal lobe is respected. CT of coronary arteries: no abnormalities are observed in the origin of the coronary arteries. TCI normal without lesions DA normal without lesions. Superficial intramyocardial tract of 14 mm in the middle third. Cx of small calibre and development
column30: without lesions. OM developed
column31: without lesions. Normal DC without lesions. Right dominance. Trivalve aortic valve. Mild pericardial effusion. Calcification of a middle dorsal intervertebral disc. Conclusion: coronary arteries without lesions. Echocardiogram in consultation
column32: after discharge: normal.  EVOLUTION Patient aged 44 years with smoking and dyslipidaemia as known risk factors
column33: admitted as a Code Ictus
column34: having received treatment with intravenous fibrinolysis within the protocol
column35: and with evidence of occlusion in left parietal M2 subsequently recanalised. Control neuroimaging studies showed subacute ischaemia of the infarcted territory
column36: as well as petechial haemorrhagic transformation and oedema. At the same time
column37: the patient presented striking alterations in the ECG
column38: with pathological TTE in the emergency department characterised by akinesia of all the apical segments and compensatory hypercontractility of the basal segments with suspicion of probable stress cardiopathy
column39: for which reason CT angiography of the coronary arteries was performed
column40: which showed no significant lesions. The control TTE showed normalisation of segmental contractility. In the aetiological study there was no evidence of a cardioembolic or vascular source with evanescent occlusion of the vessel. In the analytical study
column41: lupus anticoagulant was detected
column42: coinciding chronologically with an active infection at the level of the left ankle. On discharge
column43: lupus anticoagulant and thrombophilia studies by haematology were pending confirmation; antiplatelet treatment and statins were prescribed. As a sequel
column44: she persists with mild mixed dysphasia undergoing speech therapy.  DIAGNOSIS Ischaemic stroke in the left middle cerebral artery territory (M2). column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Male
column3: 68 years old.  History Allergic to penicillin. Ex-smoker for 20 years
column4: no alcohol consumption. Hypertension. No diabetes or dyslipidaemia. No personal or family history of heart disease. Usual treatment: amiloride/hydrochlorothiazide 5/50 mg per day.  Current illness In December 2016
column5: he presented with catarrhal symptoms with dry cough
column6: wheezing and dyspnoea on moderate exertion. He was assessed by his primary care doctor
column7: who classified the case as acute bronchitis and started bronchodilators and treatment with levofloxacin in January and February 2017. A chest X-ray in February 2017 showed vascular redistribution
column8: although diuretic treatment was not started. ECG in February 2017 in sinus rhythm with incomplete LBBB. No febrile or infectious symptoms after December 2016. Good blood pressure self-control. Due to progression of dyspnoea
column9: orthopnoea and oedema
column10: she went to the emergency department. Admitted to the cardiology ward for study and treatment of heart failure.  Physical examination Conscious and oriented. Tachypneic and tachycardic. BP 147/73 mmHg
column11: HR 90 bpm. Sat 02 95% with Ventimask at 31%. Jugular ingurgitation and hepatojugular reflux. Cardiac auscultation: tachycardic with gallop rhythm
column12: no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: bibasal crackles. ABD: soft and depressible
column13: no masses or megaliths
column14: not painful on palpation
column15: peristalsis present. Lower extremities: pretibial oedema in both extremities. No signs of DVT. Peripheral pulses present.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Laboratory tests on admission: creatinine 0.88 mg/dl
column16: urea 53 mg/dl
column17: K 3.5 mEq/L
column18: Na 144 mEq/L
column19: glucose 126 mg/dl
column20: INR 1.16. Haemogram without alterations. Arterial blood gases: pH 7.54
column21: pCO2 24.2 mmHg
column22: pO2 24.2 mmHg
column23: bicarbonate 21.3 mmol/L
column24: lactate 2.15 mmol/L. ECG: sinus rhythm at 86 bpm. Signs of LA growth. Normal PR. Narrow QRS with incomplete LBBB
column25: lateral negative T wave. Chest X-ray: cardiomegaly. Signs of vascular redistribution to upper fields. No pleural effusion or pneumonic consolidation. Echocardiogram 21/04/17: LV dilatation with severely depressed function
column26: hypertrabeculation without echocardiographic criteria of non-compaction (suboptimal window). Mild functional MR. Grade II diastolic dysfunction with elevated LVEDP criteria. Dilated RV with mild dysfunction. Mild TR. Normal PAPs (may be underestimated due to RV dysfunction). Minimally elevated PVC signs. No pericardial effusion. Coronary angiography 24/04/17: no angiographic lesions. Cardiac MRI 26/04/17: dilated LV
column27: wall thickness at the lower limit of normality
column28: hypertrabeculation with criteria of non-compaction in the inferolateral wall (ratio non-compacted myocardium: compacted of 4:1) global hypocontractility with severely depressed EF (24.5%). Dilated LA. Dilated RV with depressed function. Dilated RA. Subjectively mild MR. Minimal pericardial effusion. Presence of intramyocardial uptake in basal and middle segments of septal wall and RV insertion. Conclusions: dilated cardiomyopathy with severe ventricular dysfunction with non-compaction criteria. Intramyocardial septal uptake. Cranial CT 29/04/17: no established ischaemic brain lesions. No acute haemorrhages. Occlusion of the posterior communicating segment (P2) of the right posterior cerebral artery. Cranial CT 30/04/17: established ischaemic lesions at the level of the right temporo-occipital
column29: ipsilateral thalamus and bilateral cerebellar. Small focus of haemorrhagic transformation in the temporo-occipital lesion.  EVOLUTION During admission to the ward
column30: depletive treatment was started
column31: together with beta-blockers
column32: ARAII (intolerance to ACE inhibitors due to cough)
column33: eplerenone and ivabradine. An echocardiogram was performed showing cardiomyopathy with severe biventricular dysfunction and hypertrabeculation of the left ventricle
column34: without meeting the criteria for non-compaction with suboptimal window. Laboratory tests with normal thyroid profile
column35: autoimmunity and proteinogram. Normal renal function. Coronary angiography ruled out coronary lesions. Finally
column36: for the aetiological study
column37: cardiac MRI was performed which showed the presence of dilated cardiomyopathy with severe ventricular dysfunction with criteria of non-compaction and intramyocardial septal uptake. Enoxaparin was started at anticoagulant doses (1 mg/kg/12 h). During the evolution of the patient's clinical deterioration
column38: dobutamine perfusion at inotropic doses was started. After several days of treatment
column39: the patient improved and dobutamine was withdrawn and beta-blockers
column40: ARAII and eplerenone were restarted. As a complication during admission
column41: the patient had an ischaemic stroke despite the anticoagulation already started. Fibrinolysis was ruled out as the patient was anticoagulated and thrombectomy was ruled out as the territory was small and with progressive clinical improvement. On discharge the patient was anticoagulated with dabigatran 110 mg/12h for 1 month
column42: after which it was increased to 150 mg/12h as recommended by haematology. He will continue to be monitored in the heart failure unit and neurology consultation.  DIAGNOSIS Debut heart failure. Non-compaction cardiomyopathy with biventricular dysfunction. Ischaemic cerebral vascular accident. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column70: as were the laboratory tests
column71: and there was no evidence of enzyme elevation compatible with myocardial necrosis. A chest X-ray was performed
column72: showing no radiological alterations of acute evolution

column74: so the case was discussed with the Intensive Care Unit and
column75: given the patient's haemodynamic stability

column77: with continuous monitoring. After 24 hours
column78: coronary angiography showed very tortuous coronary arteries with no significant angiographic disease and mid-distal LAD with intramyocardial bridging leading to significant milking. The patient remained asymptomatic throughout admission
column79: with good control of blood pressure and no arrhythmic events during monitoring. She was discharged after 48 hours with low-dose beta-blocker treatment (emconcor 2.5 mg every 24 hours). The patient has recently been assessed in cardiology consultations

column81: so the prescribed treatment has been maintained.  DIAGNOSIS Chest pain. Coronary arteries without significant angiographic lesions. Intramyocardial tract of the anterior descending artery at mid-distal level with significant milking. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION We present the case of a 35-year-old woman with the following personal history: Family history: grandmother died at the age of 86 years due to acute myocardial infarction. Two paternal uncles with chronic ischaemic heart disease at 62 and 73 years of age respectively. Paternal aunt underwent aortic valve replacement at the age of 75. Cousin with congenital heart disease that he cannot specify. Father under follow-up for chest pain
column3: with coronary angiography without lesions at 64 years of age. No known drug allergies. Cardiovascular risk factors: smoker of 5 cigarettes per day (3.8 packs per year). No hypertension
column4: diabetes or dyslipidaemia. No previous cardiological history. No other medical or surgical illnesses. Baseline: sedentary lifestyle
column5: but no symptoms related to physical activity. No chronic home treatment.  She consulted the emergency department for having presented that same afternoon
column6: while seated
column7: with syncope lasting about 20 seconds
column8: with a sensation of palpitations and previous chest discomfort. After regaining consciousness
column9: she reported chest discomfort
column10: nausea
column11: headache and general weakness. No sphincter release and complete spontaneous recovery.  In the anamnesis
column12: she reported a very similar episode two or three weeks earlier
column13: with the same characteristics
column14: also at rest
column15: while lying in bed
column16: preceded by a vegetative cortex. Since then
column17: she reports having noticed isolated
column18: self-limited episodes of palpitations with sudden onset and end. She denies any other clinical manifestations in recent weeks
column19: or the use of drugs or other substances.  On arrival at the hospital
column20: the patient was asymptomatic and without neurological focality. Haemodynamically stable (blood pressure 120/75 mmHg
column21: heart rate 70 bpm
column22: baseline oxygen saturation 100%). Oriented and cooperative. No jugular ingurgitation. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds without murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur. Abdomen: soft
column23: non-painful
column24: no masses or megaliths. Lower limbs: no oedema
column25: no signs of deep vein thrombosis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS CBC: creatinine 0.6 mg/dl
column26: potassium 3.7 mEq/l
column27: sodium 136 mEq/l
column28: haemoglobin 11.8 g/dl
column29: haematocrit 36%
column30: leucocytes 9000/ml
column31: platelets 159000/mm3. Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus rhythm at 65 bpm
column33: normal PR
column34: narrow QRS
column35: no repolarisation abnormalities. No serial ECG changes. Chest X-ray: normal cardiothoracic index. Free costophrenic sinuses. No infiltrates were observed. Normal mediastinum. Transthoracic echocardiography: left ventricle (LV) of normal size
column36: thickness and systolic and diastolic function. Right ventricle (RV) of normal size and function. Left atrium (LA) and right atrium (RA) of normal size. No valvular heart disease. No indirect signs of PAH. Aortic root of normal size. No pericardial effusion. Cardiac MRI: ventricles with preserved morphology and systolic function. No oedema or myocardial fibrosis/necrosis. Telemetry (24 h): sinus rhythm. Ventricular extrasystoles (VE) of moderate monotopic density with very short coupling (in the ascending branch of the T) with episodes of doublets and 4 episodes of symptomatic polymorphic non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (PSVT) (palpitations and new syncopal symptoms). Electrophysiological study (EPS) and ablation with navigation system: baseline with moderate-density VS with LBBB morphology and transition in V5
column37: with short coupling period. Three-dimensional reconstruction of the RV is performed with echo-intracardiac. The presence of a prominent moderator band is noteworthy. Activation mapping was performed with greater precocity at the level of the middle portion of the RV free wall
column38: the anatomical point being located inside the cavity. Correlation mapping is also performed by topo-stimulation
column39: with 95% of the morphology reproduced in the moderator band. Radiofrequency applications are performed at this point (40-45 W
column40: 30 ml/min) with an irrigated catheter with a contact sensor
column41: repeatedly inducing intense automatic activity. Subsequently
column42: isoproterenol is administered without the appearance of extrasystoles after 30 minutes of waiting. Ventricular arrhythmia induction test was performed and was negative. Flecainide test: negative.   CLINICAL EVOLUTION After evaluation of the patient by cardiology in the emergency department
column43: despite the normality of the complementary tests (ECG
column44: chest X-ray and laboratory tests)
column45: given the characteristics of the syncope that suggest a cardiogenic profile
column46: it was decided to admit the patient for electrocardiographic monitoring and to complete the studies. On admission to the ward
column47: the patient remained stable and with no new syncope. Echocardiography ruled out structural heart disease. During the first hours of monitoring
column48: she had self-limited episodes of palpitations and a new syncopal episode
column49: identical to the previous ones that led to her admission. Telemetry showed isolated low-density VE and episodes of very rapid NSTEVT symptomatic due to the R-over-T phenomenon due to a very short coupling period (240 ms). He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) and an EPS was programmed with a view to navigation-guided ablation of the focus of the VS with possible origin in the RV moderator band (LBBB morphology
column50: transition in V5
column51: left superior axis and QRS <150 ms). Radiofrequency ablation was performed in the moderator band (BM) guided by the CARTO navigation system
column52: in addition to a flecainide test
column53: which was negative. The morphological study was completed with cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) without alterations. Subsequently
column54: he remained on the cardiology ward for telemetric monitoring without any sustained arrhythmias or clinical incidents. A 24-hour Holter recording 5 days after ablation showed a single isolated PVC in 24 hours. Given the success of the procedure and the absence of induction of ventricular arrhythmias
column55: it was decided to implant a subcutaneous Holter prior to discharge. On review 8 months after ablation
column56: an NSTEVT of 14 beats associated with palpitations was recorded
column57: and implantation of an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) was proposed
column58: which was carried out without complications. In addition
column59: a genetic study was completed which showed no mutations associated with channelopathies or sudden death. The patient was asymptomatic at subsequent check-ups and had no new events.  DIAGNOSIS Repeated syncope in the context of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia induced by short-coupled ventricular extrasystoles originating in the right ventricular moderator band. Ablation of right ventricular moderator band extrasystoles. ICD implantation for secondary prevention. No structural heart disease. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History 49-year-old male. Cardiovascular risk factors: hypertension
column3: very difficult to control
column4: treated with 4 drugs
column5: under follow-up by nephrology. No diabetes mellitus or dyslipidaemia. No toxic habits. Chronic kidney disease secondary to interstitial nephropathy due to vesicoureteral reflux with the start of haemodialysis at the age of 31 (in 1989)

column7: both dysfunctional and embolised
column8: currently under study for a new transplant and on haemodialysis. Multiple complications at the level of arteriovenous fistulas (AVF) (stenosis
column9: obstruction)
column10: currently presents AVF in right upper limb. Multifactorial anaemia being treated with erythropoietin and transfusions. Resistant secondary hyperparathyroidism with renal osteodystrophy and parathyroid adenoma in the right lower lobe. No significant structural heart disease except moderate ventricular hypertrophy with normal LVEF. Chronic treatment: pantoprazole 20 mg/12 h
column11: acfol 1 tablet/24 h

column19: the patient presented with general malaise and palpitations
column20: with haemodynamic stability. The monitor showed wide QRS tachycardia at 150 beats per minute (bpm). A 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed
column21: which was interpreted as sustained monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (SMVT)
column22: so 4 boluses of 100 mg of procainamide were administered
column23: and the patient progressed to an arrhythmic narrow QRS tachycardia that appeared to be atrial tachycardia and then went into sinus rhythm.   Physical examination Blood pressure 190/100
column24: 70 bpm
column25: saturation 98% baseline. No jugular ingurgitation. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur without over-additions. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds
column26: systolic murmur II/VI in the apex. Abdomen: soft
column27: non-painful
column28: with renal graft in FID. Lower extremities without oedema. Palpable and symmetrical paedial pulses.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Laboratory tests on admission: Biochemistry: creatinine 4.74 mg/dl
column29: estimated glomerular filtration rate 13 ml/min/1.73
column30: uric acid 5.04 mg/dl
column31: triglycerides 109 mg/dl
column33: HDL 30 mg/dl
column34: LDL 60 mg/dl
column35: total BR < 1.20 mg/dl
column36: AST 15 U/l
column37: ALT 13 U/l
column38: GGT 22 U/l
column39: sodium 141 mmol/l
column40: potassium 5.39 mmol/l
column41: magnesium 1.85 mg/dl
column42: inorganic phosphate 6.3 mg/dl
column43: Hb A1c: 3
column44: 90%. Albumin 3080 mg/dl. TSH 1.98 peak IU/ml
column45: free T4 1.26 ng/dl. Haemoglobin 9.5 g/dl
column46: MCV 94 fl
column47: MCHC 30.5 g/dl
column48: platelets 204000
column49: leukocytes 5990
column50: neutrophils 3960 (66.2%)
column51: lymphocytes 570 (21.2%). Coagulation: PT 12s
column52: ATP 79%
column53: INR 1.17
column54: aPTT 35.9s. Urgent blood gases after tachycardia: pH 7.480
column55: pCO2 41 mmHg
column56: pO2 93 mmHg
column57: sodium 131 mmol/l
column58: potassium 4.7 mmol/l
column59: bicarbonate 40.5 mmol/l
column60: oxygen saturation 97.8%. Chest X-ray on admission: normal cardiothoracic index with no signs of congestion or costophrenic sinus impingement. Calcified aorta with no other findings. Electrocardiogram (ECG) on admission: regular wide QRS tachycardia at 153 bpm with morphology of right bundle branch block (RBBB)
column61: superior axis; no fusion beats
column62: AV dissociation or concordance in precordials. Transthoracic echocardiogram on admission: non-dilated left ventricle with moderate concentric hypertrophy and preserved global systolic function without segmental disorders. Moderately dilated left atrium. Right ventricle of normal size and preserved contractility. Mitroaortic sclerosis without repercussion (mild mitral insufficiency). Filling pattern: impaired relaxation. Minimal posterior pericardial effusion without repercussion. Normal aorta. Electrophysiological study (EPS): poor and decremental ventriculoatrial conduction. Anterograde Wenkebach point 360 ms
column63: no overt pre-excitation with atrial stimulation; with adenosine administration there is evidence of pre-excitation at low frequencies but also simultaneous block of the pathway and atrioventricular node (AVN) (blocked P waves). Induction of atrial tachycardia is not achieved even after isoprenaline infusion. Coronary sinus mapping was performed and during bouts of pre-excitation an area of greater ventricular precocity was observed at the posterior-postero-lateral level and a pre-excitation pattern consistent (12/12) with clinical tachycardia. Transseptal puncture was performed and the mitral annulus was mapped to identify the area of maximum ventricular pre-excitation in the posterior area
column64: requiring several applications to achieve ablation of the pathway
column65: which was finally checked with adenosine. After adenosine
column66: the patient presented atrial fibrillation
column67: and electrical cardioversion was successfully performed.   CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was admitted to the cardiac intermediate care unit for monitoring. On arrival
column68: a transthoracic echocardiogram showed concentric hypertrophy with normal global systolic function without segmental disorders. The wide QRS tachycardia tracings were initially interpreted as ventricular tachycardia originating in the posterior papillary muscle (QRS with BCRDHH morphology and superior axis)
column69: so we started treatment with oral verapamil (120 mg every 12 hours)
column70: despite which he continued to present episodes of tachycardia with wide QRS on the monitor
column71: self-limited. Daily 12-lead ECG showed sinus rhythm at 75 bpm
column72: with evidence of ventricular enlargement
column73: early transition and left anterior hemiblock (HBAIHH)
column74: with a pseudo-delta wave in inferior leads and V3-V5
column75: which was interpreted as alterations typical of ventricular hypertrophy. Two days later
column76: an ECG was performed in sinus rhythm at 82 bpm where a clear delta wave was observed; in addition
column77: telemetry showed more obvious pre-excitation in supraventricular extrasystoles. Although the wide QRS tachycardia was initially interpreted as SMVT
column78: and the delta wave as a pseudo-delta wave in the context of ventricular hypertrophy
column79: what led us to suspect a possible pre-excitation was the ECG immediately after the infusion of procainamide
column80: in which a narrow basal QRS without a delta wave was observed
column81: and how in the following days
column82: without the effect of procainamide
column83: an inconspicuous delta wave was observed in the ECGs in sinus rhythm
column84: which became more pronounced with verapamil treatment. Given the suspicion of a left lateral accessory pathway
column85: we performed a test with 12 mg of i.v. adenosine
column86: which revealed pre-excitation. The case was discussed with arrhythmology and an electrophysiological study was performed
column87: where an accessory pathway was found in the posterior portion of the mitral annulus
column88: which was successfully ablated

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History Cardiovascular risk factors: no arterial hypertension
column3: no dyslipidaemia
column4: no diabetes mellitus. Non-smoker
column5: no other toxic habits. No known cardiological history. Other history: haemorrhoids
column6: anal fissure
column7: tension headache. Usual treatment: none.  Present illness A 55-year-old woman attended the emergency department for two episodes of central thoracic pain triggered by moderate exertion. She described oppressive
column8: non-radiating pain with associated vegetative cramping that persisted at the time of consultation. The patient had no previous angina or infectious symptoms.  Physical examination Weight 64 kg
column9: height 1.70 m. Body mass index (BMI) 22.14 kg/m2. Blood pressure (BP) 138/82 mmHg. Heart rate (HR) 86 bpm. Oxygen saturation (SatO2) 95% on room air. Eupneic at rest
column10: without orthopnoea or platypnoea. Jugular venous pressure normal. Negative hepatojugular reflex. Cardiac auscultation: regular rhythm
column11: no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur
column12: without aggregates. Extremities: no oedema. Peripheral pulses preserved and symmetrical.   COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiograms (ECG): ECG on arrival at the emergency department: sinus bradycardia at 54 bpm. PR 140 ms. QRS 80 ms
column13: axis at -30o. ST segment elevation in V3-V5. Q waves in DIII and aVF. Control ECG 24 hours after admission: negative T waves
column14: deep and symmetrical in V3-V6
column15: DII
column16: DIII and aVF. In recurrence of angina during admission: loss of R wave in V3-V4. ST segment elevation in V3-V5 with biphasic T wave. Blood tests: haemoglobin 12.4 g/dl
column17: haematocrit 41%
column18: platelets 164
column20: leukocytes 7
column21: 400/μl. International normalised ratio (INR) 1.05. Basal glycaemia 82 mg/dl. Urea 36 mg/dl
column22: creatinine 0.81 mg/dl
column23: sodium 137 mEq/l
column24: potassium 4.1 mEq/l. Biomarkers of myocardial damage: troponin I (hsTnI) 6
column29: 343 ng/l (normal range: 0.0-11.6 ng/l). RT-PCR for SARS-CoV2: negative. Chest X-ray: centred cardiomediastinal silhouette. Cardiothoracic index (CTI) less than 0.5. Lung fields translucent
column30: without pleural effusion or condensation. Transthoracic echocardiogram: Portable echocardiogram on admission to the coronary unit: non-dilated left ventricle
column31: with extensive septal akinesia
column32: without other alterations of segmental contractility
column33: with preserved global systolic function. Non-dilated right ventricle with preserved systolic function. Normal filling pressures. Absence of significant valvular heart disease. Aortic root and left atrium of normal diameters. Absence of pericardial effusion. Echocardiogram prior to discharge: similar to previous study. Global systolic function preserved. Haemodynamics: Emergent coronary angiography on arrival. Trunk: normal. Anterior descending artery: image compatible with spontaneous coronary dissection at mid-distal level. Distal flow TIMI 3. Circumflex artery: image compatible with spontaneous coronary artery dissection at first obtuse marginal level. Distal flow TIMI 3. Right coronary artery: dominant
column34: normal. Control coronary angiography on the third day of admission. Truncus: normal. Anterior descending artery: image compatible with spontaneous coronary artery dissection at mid level with progression to more distal level compared to previous catheterisation and increased haematoma causing distal flow TIMI 1. Circumflex artery: image compatible with spontaneous coronary artery dissection at first obtuse marginal level. Distal flow TIMI 3. Right coronary artery: dominant
column35: normal. Angio-CT: cardiac cavities of normal size. Ascending and descending thoracic aorta of normal calibre
column36: slightly elongated. Abdominal aorta of high normal calibre (28-29 mm) without arteriosclerosis. At the origin of the celiac trunk there is an image compatible with a haematoma with dense contrast in its interior that could correspond to intramural bleeding causing severe stenosis at that level. Hepatic
column37: splenic and mesenteric arteries without alterations. Normal renal arteries. Absence of coronary calcium. Coronary angiography: left coronary trunk of normal calibre and origin without arteriosclerosis. Anterior descending artery of normal calibre and origin without arteriosclerosis. Haematoma is visualised in the distal anterior descending (AD) artery causing significant stenosis. Circumflex artery of normal calibre and origin without arteriosclerosis. Marginal obtuse branch of good calibre
column38: without arteriosclerosis or signs of vascular involvement. Right coronary artery of normal calibre and origin
column39: without arteriosclerosis
column40: the distal segments are not adequately visualised due to movement artefacts. Absence of signs of vascular involvement. In summary: an image compatible with focal haematoma (small longitudinal extension) with signs of intramural bleeding (contrast density in the central area) located at the origin of the celiac trunk and in the distal portion of the anterior descending artery causing a significant decrease in the calibre of both vessels. No other notable vascular alterations were observed.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION On arrival at the emergency department
column41: an electrocardiogram was performed showing ST-segment elevation in anterior leads
column42: activating the haemodynamic alert. Diagnostic coronary angiography showed spontaneous coronary dissection in the middle anterior descending artery (mAD) and the first obtuse marginal branch (1st OM) with preserved distal flow in both arteries
column43: and conservative treatment was decided with double antiplatelet therapy and anticoagulation and admission to the coronary unit for follow-up. The patient remained asymptomatic for the first 2 days with a progressive decrease in biomarkers of myocardial damage and electrocardiographic evolution characterised by the appearance of deep negative T waves in the anterolateral and inferior face. On the third day of admission to the coronary unit
column44: he presented several episodes of angina-like central thoracic pain at rest with ST-segment elevation in anterior leads. It was decided to repeat the coronary angiography showing progression of the LAD dissection at distal level with compromise of distal flow (TIMI 1). In view of the findings described
column45: it was decided to maintain conservative and symptomatic management. Subsequent good evolution without new episodes of chest pain
column46: with progressive decrease in biomarkers of myocardial damage and electrocardiographic evolution of acute myocardial infarction
column47: so it was decided to discharge the patient with double antiplatelet therapy with acetylsalicylic acid 100 mg and clopidogrel 75 mg
column48: atorvastatin 40 mg
column49: ramipril 2.5 mg
column50: pantoprazole 40 mg and nebivolol 2.5 mg. The patient attended a scheduled outpatient check-up with the cardiologist in the area 2 weeks later
column51: reporting episodes of typical angina with moderate exertion
column52: so it was decided to request an angio-CT scan to assess the resolution of the haematoma and rule out fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD). The CT scan showed an image compatible with focal haematoma with signs of intramural bleeding located at the origin of the celiac trunk and in the distal portion of the anterior descending artery
column53: causing a significant reduction in the calibre of both vessels. The decision was made to maintain conservative management of both lesions by increasing the dose of oral beta-blockers
column54: withdrawing clopidogrel and adding nitrates to relieve symptoms
column55: with good initial clinical response
column56: no recurrence of episodes of chest pain and no associated abdominal symptoms.  DIAGNOSIS Anterior STEMI. Killip I. Spontaneous coronary artery dissection of the mid-distal anterior descending artery and first obtuse marginal artery. Preserved LV systolic function. Focal haematoma with signs of intramural bleeding located at the origin of the celiac trunk. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History Family history of ischaemic heart disease in his father at 47 years of age
column3: and in two maternal uncles at 42 and 50 years of age respectively. No known drug allergies. Cardiovascular risk factors: no hypertension
column4: no diabetes
column5: no dyslipidaemia. Obesity (body mass index [BMI] 35). No toxic habits.  Cardiological history: assessed in 2012 for progressive exertional angina
column6: antianginal and anti-ischaemic treatment was started and an echocardiogram was performed with globally and segmentally preserved systolic function; given clinical persistence despite medical treatment
column7: coronary catheterisation was performed with no significant angiographic lesions. Cardiological treatment was withdrawn
column8: anxiolytics and the usual analgesics were started
column9: and the patient was discharged from cardiology consultations. Referred again in 2014 for progressive exertional angina
column10: with sporadic episodes at rest
column11: which persisted despite antidepressant treatment combined with the usual analgesics
column12: it was decided to request another coronary catheterisation
column13: again showing no significant angiographic lesions. She was again discharged from cardiology and referred to psychiatry by her primary care physician. Referred again in 2019 due to functional worsening
column14: with persistent episodes of chest pain on exertion and isolated episodes of greater intensity at rest. In this case
column15: a diagnosis of "syndrome X" was made and only ranolazine 375 mg/12 hours was added to her treatment (without antiplatelet agents or statins) and myocardial perfusion SPECT
column16: a new transthoracic echocardiogram and a review in one year with the results were requested.  No other history of interest. Baseline situation: sedentary lifestyle. Life limited by episodes of chest pain with significant impairment and secondary emotional lability. Usual treatment: ranolazine 375 mg/ 12 hours
column17: sertraline 50 mg at breakfast
column18: lorazepam 2 mg 1 tablet at breakfast and another at dinner
column19: paracetamol 650 mg/tramadol 75 mg every 8 hours and ibuprofen 400 mg on demand.  Current illness Consultation at the emergency department for an episode of oppressive central thoracic pain
column20: with significant accompanying neurovegetative symptoms
column21: onset at rest
column22: self-limiting
column23: lasting about 20 minutes and with significant emotional involvement. He says that it reminds him of previous episodes of chest pain and that he has already had several coronary angiographies and that "he has never had to have stents fitted"
column24: but that he has recently undergone a test to study his heart
column25: which he cannot specify and that he is awaiting a review in the outpatient cardiology department with the results next week. After reviewing the patient's history and medical records
column26: it is found that a few weeks ago a myocardial perfusion SPECT was performed showing inducible myocardial ischaemia in the anterior aspect. Serial electrocardiograms performed in the emergency department
column27: carried out when the patient was no longer in pain
column28: showed no changes or dynamic alterations suggestive of ischaemia. The study was completed by enzyme seriation
column29: which was found to be normal. Chest X-ray with no findings. However
column30: despite the normality of the complementary tests performed in the emergency department
column31: they decided to contact the on-call cardiology team for assessment.  Physical examination On arrival
column33: with a blood pressure of 130/60 mmHg
column34: a heart rate of 64 beats per minute and an oxygen saturation of 98% at baseline. She was oriented and cooperative
column35: with marked emotional lability and crying. Physical examination was unremarkable. Echocardioscopy showed preserved systolic function globally and segmentally
column36: without significant valvular heart disease or pericardial effusion. At the insistence of the patient and her history
column37: it was decided to admit her to hospital for readjustment of medical treatment and to assess the possibility of performing a new coronary catheterisation with invasive functional study to rule out coronary vasospasm and/or microvascular dysfunction as the aetiology of the chest pain.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Laboratory tests: glucose 83 mg/dl
column38: glycosylated haemoglobin (A1c) 5.3%
column39: creatinine (serum) 0.86 mg/dl
column40: glomerular filtration rate calculated by CKD-EPI formula 76 ml/min/1.73 m2
column41: urea 38 mg/dl 21 - 43
column42: uric acid 4.1 mg/dl
column43: total proteins 7.7 g/dl
column44: total cholesterol 147 mg/dl
column45: hDL cholesterol 45 mg/dl
column46: LDL cholesterol (calculated) 125 mg/dl
column47: triglycerides 98 mg/dl
column48: total bilirubin 0.72 mg/dl
column49: aspartate transaminase (GOT) 19 U/l
column50: alanine transaminase (GPT) 22
column51: haemoglobin 12.7 g/dl
column52: leucocytes 9745 x 103μl
column53: platelets 289 x 103μl. Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus rhythm at 67 beats per minute
column54: PR 180 ms
column55: normal axis
column56: narrow QRS
column57: QTc 410 ms
column58: no acute repolarisation abnormalities. Chest X-ray: cardiothoracic index within the normal range. Free costophrenic sinuses
column59: no evidence of vascular redistribution. No masses or consolidations.  Echocardioscopy: preserved systolic function without segmentarity. Absence of significant valvulopathies. No pericardial effusion. Transthoracic echocardiogram: left ventricle (LV) of normal size
column60: thickness and systolic and diastolic function. Right ventricle (RV) of normal size and function. Left atrium (LA) and right atrium (RA) of normal size. No valvular heart disease. No indirect signs of pulmonary hypertension (PHT). Aortic root of normal size. No pericardial effusion. Myocardial perfusion SPECT: Mild precordial pressure without ECG alteration during regadenoson administration Baseline HR 90 bpm post-stress 120 bpm. Post-stress study shows anteroseptal myocardial hypocaptation which normalises at rest. Findings suggestive of myocardial ischaemia induced in the territory of the anterior descending coronary artery (AD). Coronary catheterisation with invasive functional study: coronary tree of normal distribution and development. Right dominance. Absence of angiographically significant lesions. A study of microvascular dysfunction was performed by thermodilution with saline boluses and an IMR of 78 and a CFR of 0.8 were obtained
column61: indicating severe microvascular dysfunction. Positive vasoreactivity test with acetylcholine in the territory of the anterior descending artery at a dose of 100 μm (reduction of coronary diameter > 90%
column62: ischaemic changes in the electrocardiogram and clinical signs of angina). Conclusion: severe microvascular dysfunction and coronary spasm in the territory of the anterior descending coronary artery.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION Once admitted to the cardiology ward
column63: anti-ischaemic and anti-anginal treatment was reinforced
column64: and a transthoracic echocardiogram and a new coronary catheterisation with invasive functional study were requested. The echocardiographic study showed preserved global and segmental systolic function
column65: without systolic dysfunction or valvular heart disease. However
column66: the coronary catheterisation performed showed no significant angiographic lesions
column67: with no changes with respect to previous studies. It was decided to perform a complete functional study in the haemodynamics room using thermodilution with saline boluses and intravenous adenosine perfusion to obtain the microvascular resistance index (MRI) and coronary flow reserve (CFR). The results obtained were markers of severe microvascular dysfunction: MRI 78 (cut-off point <25) and CFR of 0.8 (cut-off point >2-2.5). The study was completed with the coronary vasoreactivity test to rule out coronary vasospasm
column68: which was positive in the territory of the anterior descending coronary artery with an intracoronary dose of 100 μg (reduction in coronary diameter greater than 90%
column69: dynamic alterations in the ECG and clinical symptoms of angina). Given these results
column70: the patient was diagnosed with severe microvascular dysfunction and coronary vasospasm
column71: and it was decided to progressively withdraw anxiolytic and antidepressant treatment
column72: and acetylsalicylic acid
column73: atorvastatin
column74: amlodipine and nitroglycerin night patches were added
column75: showing clear symptomatic improvement
column76: as well as a marked decrease in emotional lability on finally learning the aetiology of the chest pain. At the review 12 months after admission to the cardiology outpatient clinic
column77: the patient is asymptomatic from the cardiovascular point of view
column78: and has managed to discontinue all antidepressant and anxiolytic medication and has progressively begun to engage in physical activity with excellent tolerance.   DIAGNOSIS Angina with documented ischaemia in AD territory with coronary arteries without significant lesions (INOCA). Severe microvascular dysfunction confirmed by invasive functional study. Coronary vasospasm in the territory of the anterior descending artery induced during acetylcholine test. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History 58-year-old male. No known drug allergies. Active smoker of 1 pack a day. No other cardiovascular risk factors. Recent diagnosis of gastric adenocarcinoma with lymph node involvement
column3: undergoing adjuvant chemotherapy treatment with docetaxel
column4: oxaliplatin
column5: leucovorin
column6: 5-fluorouracil (FLOT scheme). He started the first cycle 24 hours before admission to the cardiology department. Usual medication: metamizole 575 mg/8h
column7: metoclopramide 10 mg/8h
column8: paracetamol 1 g/8h
column9: tramadol 50 mg/8h
column10: dexamethasone 8 mg/24h
column11: omeprazole 20 mg/24h.  Present illness Started chemotherapy with 5-fluorouracil in continuous infusion through a reservoir 24 hours ago. He came to the emergency department for an episode of oppressive chest pain
column12: radiating to both extremities and associated with vegetative cortex
column13: with abrupt onset and spontaneous disappearance after 30 minutes
column14: and was subsequently asymptomatic. On arrival at the emergency department
column15: electrocardiogram (ECG) showed isoelectric ST and the patient was haemodynamically stable. After 2 hours in the ED
column16: he presented a second episode of typically angina-like central thoracic pain with electrical evidence of ST elevation of up to 4 mm on the inferolateral side associated with hypertensive reaction (blood pressure [BP] 198/101 mmHg). After administration of sublingual nitroglycerin
column17: there was clinical improvement and retrogradation of electrical changes with flattening of repolarisation in V5-V6. No dyspnoea or other associated symptoms. During his stay in the emergency department he presented a new recurrence of pain with ST elevation in II-III-aVF
column18: V1-V4. Cardiology was contacted and the AMI code was activated.   Initially the perfusion of 5-fluorouracil was stopped and i.v. nitroglycerin was started. On arrival in haemodynamics the patient was asymptomatic and the ECG changes had regressed. Emergent coronary angiography was performed with ectatic coronary arteries
column19: without significant angiographic lesions. Aortography ruled out signs of dissection at the level of the ascending aorta
column20: aortic arch and thoracic descending aorta.  Physical examination Weight 85 kg
column21: height 1.85m. Good general condition
column22: normohydrated
column23: normoperfused. Conscious and oriented. No signs of heart failure. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic tones
column24: no murmurs. Peripheral pulses present and symmetrical. Respiratory auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur. Abdomen: normal examination
column25: no pathological findings.   COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiograms: ECG with pain: sinus rhythm at 80 bpm
column26: normal PR
column27: narrow QRS axis at +30o
column28: ST elevation II
column29: III
column30: aVF
column31: V3
column33: V5
column34: V6 (maximum 4 mm in II). ECG without pain and on discharge: sinus rhythm at 74 bpm
column35: normalisation of the previously described changes with isoelectric ST
column36: without other repolarisation alterations. AP portable chest X-ray on arrival at the ED: no condensation in the lung parenchyma or signs of pulmonary congestion. Laboratory tests: Initial blood tests (in the ED): glucose 160 mg/dl; urea 51 mmol/l; creatinine 1 mg/dl; GFR 82 ml/min; sodium 139 mEq/l; potassium 3.85 mEq/l; leukocytes 10.82 x109/l; haemoglobin 15.6 g/dl; haematocrit 44.1%; platelets 210 x109/l; INR 1.14. Myocardial enzymes: peak TnI-US 29.70 pg/ml (normal 2-25 pg/ml) and peak CK 295 U/l (normal 10-195 U/l). SARS-CoV-2 PCR: negative. Complete laboratory tests 24 hours after admission: Metabolic profile: total cholesterol 186 mg/dl; LDL 123 mg/dl; HDL 40 mg/dl; triglycerides 115 mg/dl; HbA1c 5.1%. Liver function: GOT 23 U/l
column37: GPT 14 U/l
column38: GGT 20 U/l
column39: total bilirubin 0.71. Haemogram without alterations. Coronary angiography: right dominance. Ectatic coronary arteries
column40: without significant angiographic lesions. Aortography: absence of complications of ascending aorta and aortic arch. Transthoracic echocardiogram: left ventricle (LV) neither dilated nor hypertrophied with normal systolic function without regional contractile asymmetries. Right ventricle not dilated and normocontractile. Normal atria. Absence of functionally significant valvular heart disease. Normal pulmonary pressure. No pericardial effusion. No mechanical complications.   CLINICAL EVOLUTION Medical treatment was maintained with intravenous nitrates
column41: with subsequent enteral conversion after satisfactory blood pressure control
column42: remaining haemodynamically stable and without angina recurrence. After 48 hours of monitoring
column43: we contacted our medical oncology colleagues to adjust and control the medication for her oncological process. During the subsequent evolution
column44: given that he did not require treatment with 5-FU
column45: it was decided to perform a subtotal R2 gastrectomy and start treatment with irinotecan. On discharge
column46: from the cardiological point of view
column47: treatment was maintained with: acetylsalicylic acid 100 mg 0-1-0
column48: nifedipine 20 mg 1-1-1
column49: isosorbide mononitrate 40 mg 0-1-1 and fluvastatin 40 mg 0-0-1-1.  DIAGNOSIS Coronary vasospasm secondary to 5-fluoruracil treatment. Non-Q acute myocardial infarction (AMI). Killip I. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History  64-year-old female patient
column3: with the following history: No family history of interest for the current picture. No known adverse drug reactions. Cardiovascular risk factors: long-standing arterial hypertension
column4: dyslipidaemia and long-standing type 2 diabetes mellitus
column5: without target organ damage. Denies toxic habits. Previous surgeries: breast reduction
column6: tubal ligation. Previous admissions: admission in 2019 to internal medicine for atypical chest pain
column7: discharged after ergometry
column8: which was inconclusive
column9: and myocardial perfusion SPECT
column10: which was negative. Usual treatment: enalapril 20 mg/hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg 1 tablet every 24 hours
column11: sitagliptin 100 mg 1 tablet every 24 hours.  Present illness She was referred to the emergency department for chest pain of several days' duration. The patient describes the pain as central-thoracic
column12: oppressive
column13: intermittent
column14: non-radiating
column15: not accompanied by vegetative cortex
column16: which appears with exertion and improves with rest
column17: of 5 days' evolution. Today's episode was more intense
column18: so she went to her primary care physician
column19: who referred her to the hospital due to pathological findings on the electrocardiogram (ECG)
column20: suggestive of acute coronary syndrome without ST-segment elevation. The main finding of interest in the ED analysis was the presence of mobilisation of markers of myocardial damage in the range of myocardial necrosis: TnT-hs 25 - 47 - 93 ng/l. A diagnosis of non-ST-elevation acute coronary syndrome was therefore made
column21: and coronary angiography was requested
column22: which was performed the following day and showed a lesion in the middle circumflex artery
column23: which was revascularised by implanting a drug-eluting stent. During her stay on the hospital ward
column24: she progressed well
column25: with no new episodes of chest pain. Echocardiography was performed
column26: which showed preserved biventricular function
column27: without segmental contractility disorders. In-hospital laboratory tests showed preserved renal function
column28: an improved lipid profile and high levels of glycosylated haemoglobin. Finally
column29: she was discharged with the following treatment at discharge: acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) 100 mg (1 tablet every 24 h)
column30: ticagrelor 90 mg (1 tablet every 12 h)
column31: enalapril/hydrochlorothiazide 20/12.5 mg (1 tablet every 24 h)
column33: atorvastatin 80 mg (1 tablet in the evening)
column34: omeprazole 20 mg (1 tablet before breakfast)
column35: canaglifozin 100 mg (1 tablet every 24 h)
column36: sitagliptin/metformin 50 mg/1g (1 tablet every 12 h).   COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG in the emergency department. Coronary angiography: right dominance. Right coronary artery without significant lesions suggestive of revascularisation. Left coronary tree with significant lesion in the middle circumflex artery
column37: revascularised by implanting 1 drug-eluting stent. Echocardiography: non-dilated left ventricle with slight concentric hypertrophy of the walls. No segmental contractility disorders were observed. Right ventricle not dilated. Biventricular function preserved (LVEF 58%). Atria not dilated. Absence of significant valvular heart disease. No pericardial effusion. Regular laboratory tests: renal function preserved
column38: with baseline creatinine of 0.48 mg/dl and estimated filtration rate of 104 ml/min/1.73 m2. Lipid profile: total cholesterol 174 mg/dl
column39: with LDL cholesterol 98 mg/dl and HDL 46 mg/dl and triglycerides 150 mg/dl. Glycosylated haemoglobin: 7.3%.   CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was referred on discharge to cardiac rehabilitation
column40: where she started a structured exercise programme
column41: in addition to a comprehensive approach to cardiovascular risk factors. She was a diabetic patient with poor control
column42: with an HbA1c of 7.3%
column43: who was on home treatment with sitagliptin and who
column44: on discharge
column45: was upgraded to sitagliptin/metformin and it was decided to add canaglifozin for cardiovascular benefit.  During follow-up
column46: the patient presented gastrointestinal discomfort
column47: which subsided after stopping metformin
column48: so she started to discontinue oral hypoglycaemic treatment and began to have poor daily glycaemic control. Not only that
column49: but practically simultaneously
column50: the patient had several episodes of genitourinary tract infections
column51: all of fungal origin (C. albicans)
column52: associated with treatment with sodium-glucose cotransporter type 2 (iSGLT2) inhibitors
column53: which responded to antifungal treatment
column54: but relapsed a few days later. In this situation
column55: it was decided to take general measures to try to prevent new episodes of genitourinary infections
column56: but all these measures were ineffective
column57: so her primary care physician decided to discontinue treatment with iSGLT2 and to start treatment directly with slow-acting insulin. When she was reviewed again in cardiac rehabilitation consultations
column58: it was decided to try a different course of action
column59: which was to start treatment with a glucagon-like peptide type 1 receptor agonist (arGLP1). Therefore
column60: treatment was started with semaglutide 0.25 mg (1 injection per week)
column61: which was well tolerated. After 4 weeks
column62: the dose is increased to 0.5 mg (1 injection per week). Again it is well tolerated and with good glycaemic control. Finally
column63: after another 4 weeks
column64: a maximum dose of 1 g per week is reached
column65: with good clinical tolerance and good glycaemic control
column66: even leading to withdrawal of insulin. After 3 months of treatment
column67: the regular blood test showed an HbA1c of 6.4%
column68: reaching the desired target
column69: having lost 3 kg of weight throughout the process. All this led to the decision to maintain this monotherapy treatment indefinitely.  DIAGNOSIS Ischaemic heart disease. Acute coronary syndrome without ST-segment elevation
column70: with single-vessel involvement of the circumflex artery
column71: revascularised by implanting 1 stent. Preserved biventricular function. Very high cardiovascular risk: hypertension
column72: dyslipidaemia and long-standing type 2 diabetes mellitus with poor metabolic control. Intolerance to metformin. Repeated urinary tract infections with iSGLT2. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History No known drug allergies. Ex-smoker for 3 months. Cardiovascular risk factors: hypertension (HT)
column3: dyslipidaemia and DM2. Hyperuricaemia. Significant stenosis of right internal carotid artery with percutaneous revascularisation with stent in 2015. Usual treatment: acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) 100 mg every 24 h
column4: bisoprolol 2.5 mg every 24 h
column5: atorvastatin 80 mg every 24 h
column6: ramipril 5 mg every 24 h
column7: omeprazole 20 mg every 24 h
column8: metformin+empaglifozin 5 mg/1
column9: 000 mg every 12 h
column10: lormetazepam 2 mg every 24 h.  Present illness A 58-year-old male patient with the previously described family and personal history and under follow-up in outpatient cardiology consultations for progressive angina of 2 months' evolution and segmental alterations in transthoracic echocardiography
column11: who was admitted to the ward for scheduled coronary angiography.  Physical examination Good general condition
column12: well hydrated and perfused. Eupneic at rest
column13: tolerates decubitus. Blood pressure: 147/92 mmHg. Heart rate: 65 bpm. Central obesity. Height 165 cm. Weight 97
column14: 5 kg. Body mass index (BMI) 35
column15: 81. Cardiorespiratory auscultation with rhythmic tones
column16: no murmurs. Conservative vesicular murmur with no added noises. Absence of oedema in the lower limbs with pulses present.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm at 65 bpm
column17: normal axis. Normal PR. QRS with right bundle branch block image
column18: Q wave in DII
column19: DIII and avF. Laboratory tests on admission: glomerular filtration rate 78 ml/min
column20: glucose 148 mg/dl
column21: Hb1Ac 8.3%. Lipid profile with total cholesterol 307 mg/dl
column22: LDL cholesterol 215 mg/dl
column23: triglycerides 513 mg/dl. GOT 20 IU/l
column24: GPT 33 IU/l. Transthoracic echocardiogram: left atrium not dilated. Non-dilated left ventricle with moderate concentric hypertrophy. Inferobasal hypokinesia with remaining preserved segmental contractility. LVEF 61%. Mitral filling flow with impaired relaxation pattern. Trivalve aortic valve without significant valvulopathy. Aortic root and ascending aorta not dilated. Normal appearing mitral valve without significant valvulopathy. Right chambers not dilated
column25: right ventricular function preserved. No tricuspid insufficiency (TI) to estimate pulmonary artery systolic pressure. No pericardial effusion. Cardiac catheterisation: severe stenosis of 65% of the distal left main coronary artery (LMCA)
column26: 70% stenosis of the proximal anterior descending (LAD)
column27: 90% stenosis in the middle segment of the circumflex (Cx)
column28: 100% occlusion of the proximal segment. Post admission blood tests: normal haemogram. Renal function with glomerular filtration rate 90 ml/min
column29: normal ions
column30: urea 29 mg/dl. Lipid profile with total cholesterol 115 mg/dl
column31: HDL cholesterol 52 mg/dl
column33: triglycerides 150 mg/dl
column34: lipoprotein (a) 4.5 mg/dl. Glycosylated haemoglobin (HbA1c) 6.4%. GPT 18 IU/l
column35: GGT 38 IU/l.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION Scheduled coronary angiography was performed
column36: documenting significant LMCA disease and three-vessel disease. Given the multivessel coronary involvement
column37: the patient's age and DM2
column38: the option of surgical treatment was recommended. Cardiac surgery was consulted and accepted the case and the patient was scheduled for revascularisation surgery during admission. Myocardial revascularisation surgery was performed with quadruple aortocoronary bypass (proximal internal mammary artery - proximal LAD
column39: posterior descending saphenous
column40: marginal saphenous-obtuse
column41: saphenous-1odiagonal) without incident and with good evolution during the postoperative period. During admission and on discharge after the operation
column42: the analytical parameters were analysed
column43: highlighting poor metabolic control with HbA1c figures of 8.3% and a lipid profile outside target figures according to her cardiovascular risk level. Therefore
column44: in accordance with current recommendations on the management of patients at high cardiovascular risk
column45: it was decided to optimise treatment with high-potency statins (rosuvastatin 20 mg) plus ezetimibe 10 mg and to add arGLP1 to the oral antidiabetic treatment as a weekly injectable semaglutide
column46: given its proven cardiovascular and metabolic benefits. The initial dose of semaglutide 0.25 mg subcutaneous weekly is started and will be titrated in consultations according to tolerance.  On discharge
column47: the patient is reminded of the importance of smoking cessation and lifestyle changes. The patient was reviewed in consultations 4 months after admission
column48: the clinical evolution was favourable
column49: with no new episodes of chest pain and progressive recovery of his normal life after the operation. The patient reports that he has lost nearly 10 kg but continues to smoke. The control laboratory tests show LDL-cholesterol figures of 33 mg/dl and HbA1c levels of 6.4%
column50: as well as an improvement in the liver profile and normalisation of uric acid parameters. His primary care physician has titrated subcutaneous doses of semaglutide
column51: and he is currently on a maintenance dose (1 mg sc per week)
column52: and the patient does not report any intolerance to the drug and only highlights the increased feeling of satiety that has helped him to lose weight. It was decided to refer the patient to the smoking cessation centre at his health centre. At subsequent check-ups
column53: the patient remained asymptomatic
column54: had stopped smoking after starting treatment with varenicline (Champix©)
column55: continued analytical control with target figures in secondary prevention and no new hospital admissions.   DIAGNOSIS Chronic ischaemic heart disease. Progressive angina with multivessel coronary disease. Surgical revascularisation by quadruple coronary artery bypass grafting. Poorly controlled familial combined dyslipidaemia.
