column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 29-year-old woman.  History Family history: father died of sudden death with suspected ischaemic heart disease at the age of 58 years
column3: in April 2020 (no autopsy due to COVID-19 pandemic situation). No known drug allergies. Personal history: asthmatic bronchitis
column4: thalassaemia minor. No contact at risk for COVID-19 infection. No past infection. Not vaccinated. Toxic habits: active smoking (10 packs/year)
column5: daily use of cannabis. Previous medication: levonorgestrel/ethinylestradiol as oral contraceptive
column6: inhaled formoterol/budesonide on demand
column7: folic acid.  Current illness She came to the emergency department for chest pain. The previous day she had presented with oppressive central chest pain at rest one hour after eating
column8: increasing with deep inspiration
column9: non-radiating
column10: without vegetative cortex. The patient had consulted her health centre
column11: where she underwent an electrocardiogram that showed no abnormalities. During the night she presented vomiting and diarrhoeic stools
column12: as well as persistent pain
column13: which finally subsided with a 600 mg ibuprofen tablet
column14: allowing her to rest. The day she went to the emergency department
column15: she started again with more intense
column16: stabbing
column17: non-radiating pain
column18: which improved when seated and worsened in the supine decubitus and with inspiration
column19: without vegetative cortex
column20: with a fever of 37.5 oC
column21: with no other symptoms. The patient denied temperature control in previous days. On our assessment in the emergency department
column22: intravenous acetylsalicylic acid was administered
column23: with partial relief of pain
column24: which persisted only on deep inspiration. The patient reported having presented some months earlier with non-specific precordial discomfort
column25: always self-limited and without other symptoms
column26: which she related to anxiety. There were no previous episodes suggestive of angina and no recent worsening of functional class. Laboratory tests showed an elevation of ultrasensitive troponin
column27: in a downward curve. An electrocardiogram was performed
column28: showing diffuse ST segment elevation in the inferior and anterior face
column29: as well as urgent echocardioscopy at the bedside
column30: which showed a left ventricle that was neither dilated nor hypertrophic
column31: with apical septal akinesia and of the apical segment of the right ventricle
column32: with no other notable pathological findings.  Physical examination Blood pressure (BP) 142 /82 mmHg
column33: heart rate (HR) 120 bpm
column34: oxygen saturation 99% (with room air). Acceptable general condition
column35: normohydrated
column36: normoperfused
column37: eupneic at rest. No jugular ingurgitation. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column38: no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: vesicular murmur preserved in all fields
column39: no extra sounds. Lower limbs: no oedema
column40: no signs of deep vein thrombosis
column41: good distal perfusion
column42: symmetrical pulses.   COMPLEMENTARY TESTS CBC on admission: haemoglobin 12.9 g/dl
column43: leukocytes 18
column44: 040 /μl with 14
column45: 670 neutrophils/μl
column47: 880 lymphocytes/μl
column48: platelets 412.000 /μl
column49: D-dimer 310 mg/ml
column50: creatinine 0.67 mg/dl with estimated glomerular filtration rate > 90 ml/min/1.73 m2
column51: ions in normal range
column52: GOT 202
column53: GPT 36
column54: LDH 555
column55: GGT 20 IU/l
column56: total bilirubin 0.82 mg/dl. CPK 1
column57: 079 IU/l
column58: HDL cholesterol 36 mg/dl
column59: LDL 135 mg/dl
column60: CRP 18.7 mg/l
column61: troponin I (hs-TnI) 19
column63: 540 ng/l (normal < 53.5 ng/l)
column64: NTproBNP 1
column65: 982 pg/ml. CBC 3rd day of admission: haemogram normal
column66: renal function and ions normal; CRP rising 196 mg/l. Procalcitonin normal. Electrocardiogram on admission: sinus rhythm at 67 bpm
column67: PR < 200 ms
column68: narrow QRS
column69: normal axis. Amputated R wave in V4-V5. Diffuse ST elevation in V2-V5 and inferior aspect. Electrocardiogram after 24 hours: sinus rhythm at 75 bpm
column70: PR < 200 ms
column71: narrow QRS
column72: normal axis
column73: ST-segment elevation in V2-5 and inferior aspect with negative T-wave in the same leads. Chest X-ray on admission: cardiothoracic index within normal limits
column74: free costophrenic sinuses
column75: no evidence of vascular redistribution
column76: no parenchymal opacities. SARS-CoV-2 PCR on admission and at 8 days: undetectable. SARS-CoV-2 serology: IgG negative; IgM positive. Transthoracic echocardiogram 2nd day of admission: non-dilated
column77: non-hypertrophic left ventricle
column78: with preserved global systolic function. Akinesia of the apex and apical segments of the inferior septum and inferior face
column79: and of the apical and middle segment of the anterior septum. Apical intracavitary thrombus with a fresh appearance. Right ventricle of normal size and function. Akinesia of the most apical segment of the right ventricular free wall. Atria of normal size. Mild tricuspid insufficiency without other valvulopathies. Minimal amount of pericardial fluid. CT of coronary arteries 2nd day of admission: (video 2) calcium score: Agatston 0. Coronary arteries with normal anatomical origin. Right dominance. Left coronary artery trunk: vessel of good development
column80: without lesions. Anterior descending (AD): well-developed vessel. In the middle segment
column81: between the exit of the 2nd diagonal and the septal
column82: there is a lesion of about 5 mm in length that stenoses the lumen by 50%
column83: which is compatible with soft plaque as a first possibility. Diagonals: 2 of moderate development
column84: without lesions and one septal of good development. Circumflex (CX): well-developed vessel
column85: without lesions. Marginal obtuse: 4 vessels
column86: the first of which is very poorly developed
column87: the rest are well developed
column88: without lesions. Right coronary artery (RC): dominant vessel of good development
column89: without lesions. Posterior descending pulmonary artery (PVI): poorly developed
column90: no lesions. Chest visualisation: thrombus in the cardiac apex. No pericardial effusion. Catheterisation on the 2nd day of admission: (videos 3 and 4) right radial access. Trunk: no lesions. LAD: normodeveloped
column91: with eccentric focal stenosis in the middle segment
column92: with contrast defect highly suggestive of parietal thrombus. The distal LAD presents abundant contrastation defects that suggest thrombus embolisation as a first possibility. CX: no significant lesions. CD: dominant
column93: with contrastation defect in proximal segment compatible with intracoronary thrombus. Good distal vessel. Catheterisation on the 12th day of admission: angiographic review and optical coherence tomography (OCT). Left coronary artery (LMCA) without lesions. The anterior descending artery of good calibre and development with angiographically mild atheromatosis in the middle segment
column94: distal to the exit of the main diagonal branch. The distal vessel showed TIMI 3 flow
column95: with no angiographic evidence of thrombus. OCT was performed
column96: visualising a completely healthy distal vessel with the presence of a lipid plaque in the middle LAD
column97: with a thin layer fibroatheroma and very focal intimal rupture
column99: with a minimal non-pathological luminal area (MLA 7.5 mm2) and absence of thrombus. Circumflex of good calibre and development without significant lesions. Dominant right coronary artery of good calibre and development without significant lesions. The thrombus is not visualised in the proximal segment and the vessel has distal TIMI 3 flow. OCT was not performed in CD due to ostial spasm with the catheter. Conclusion: apical infarction secondary to thrombotic lesion in the middle LAD with embolisation of thrombus to the distal vessel (which is healthy on OCT). Probable coronary embolism from thrombus in LV apex to DC
column100: resolved after antithrombotic treatment. Transthoracic echocardiogram at discharge: non-dilated
column102: with preserved global systolic function. Akinesia of the apical segments and strict apex with mobile intracavitary thrombus of smaller size and echogenicity than in the previous echocardiogram (1.5 x 1.2 cm). Right ventricle of normal size and function. Atria of normal size. Minimal tricuspid insufficiency without other valvulopathies. No indirect evidence of pulmonary hypertension. Minimal amount of pericardial fluid as previously described.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was admitted to the coronary unit in respiratory and contact isolation due to the positive result of the Sars-Cov-2 PCR
column103: with the initial diagnostic suspicion of viral myopericarditis for observation and completion of the study. A regular echocardiogram was performed with an image of intracavitary thrombus that was not present the previous day
column104: so anticoagulant treatment was started with i.v. unfractionated heparin. Given the echocardiogram findings and taking into account the patient's low cardiovascular risk
column105: a CT scan of the coronary arteries was performed showing at least a moderate lesion in the LAD artery. Coronary angiography showed intracoronary thrombosis without underlying atherosclerotic lesions in the middle and distal LAD and proximal RCA
column106: with preserved flow. Given the suspicion of an underlying prothrombotic state (patient smoker
column107: in treatment with oral contraceptives and active SARS-CoV2 infection) and given that the patient was asymptomatic at that time and haemodynamically stable
column108: initial pharmacological management was decided with infusion of a glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor
column109: followed by treatment with anticoagulation and double antiplatelet therapy with acetylsalicylic acid and clopidogrel. During her stay in the coronary unit
column110: the patient presented chest discomfort with an inflammatory profile
column111: with an increase in acute phase reactants (CRP rising to 149 mg/l)
column112: without pericardial effusion. Bacterial superinfection was ruled out and treatment with colchicine was started
column113: with good clinical evolution and improvement in the analytical parameters of inflammation in the following days. He was transferred to the cardiology ward where he remained clinically stable. A new control coronary angiography was performed ten days after the first one
column114: where the previous thrombi in the LAD and DC were not visualised. OCT showed a lipid plaque in the middle LAD
column115: with thin layer fibroatheroma and very focal intimal rupture. Given the angiographic evolution
column116: the patient's clinical profile and the findings on intracoronary imaging techniques
column117: conservative management of the lesion in the middle LAD was decided. A control echocardiogram prior to discharge showed persistent thrombus in the apex
column118: although smaller than in previous studies. During the following days
column119: treatment was maintained with acenocoumarol and clopidogrel. The patient was discharged with the following treatment: clopidogrel
column123: atorvastatin and colchicine. She was assessed by haematology and a thrombophilia study was decided once the acute phase had passed
column124: on an outpatient basis. Smoking cessation was recommended and hormonal contraception was discontinued. The patient progressed favourably
column126: and she was discharged to continue outpatient follow-up.  DIAGNOSIS Acute pericarditis due to SARS-CoV-2. Acute coronary syndrome of the anterior STEMI type: thrombosis in the middle anterior descending artery due to atheroma plaque instability with distal embolisation. Embolic infarction in proximal right coronary artery with preserved distal flow
column127: without angiographically significant atheromatous stenosis. Apical akinesia with apical thrombus. Preserved global left ventricular systolic function. Suspected thrombophilia
column128: pending completion of the study. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History Cardiovascular risk factors: arterial hypertension (without medical treatment) and grade II obesity (weight 90 kg
column3: height 1.6 m
column4: body mass index [BMI] 35.15 kg/m2). Other history: low back pain due to L4-L5 and L5-S1 facet overload and L4-L5 disc degeneration
column5: cervical pain due to cervical spondylosis with slight posterior protrusion C3-C4
column6: C5-C6 and C6-C7 without spinal cord involvement. Anxiety syndrome
column7: claustrophobia. Peripheral vertigo. Surgical: right carpal tunnel syndrome
column8: caesarean section
column9: curettage for abortion. Toxic: denied. Family history: paternal grandfather died of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) at the age of 64. Usual medication: diazepam 5 mg orally (if required)
column10: dexketoprofen 25 mg orally (if required).  Present illness A 44-year-old woman presented with a clinical picture of 48 hours' evolution
column11: characterised by a first episode of oppressive
column12: retrosternal chest pain of moderate intensity
column13: while at rest
column14: self-limited for 30 minutes
column15: not radiating
column16: not accompanied by vegetative cortex and without modification with postural changes
column17: which she relieved spontaneously. In the following 24 hours
column18: he presented two new episodes of similar characteristics (one in the early morning
column19: self-limited
column20: and the other in the afternoon) for which he consulted a private centre. The electrocardiogram (ECG) showed an inframillimetric suprathreshold level in DI-AVL and a tendency to ST-segment sublevel in DIII and AVF. Anti-inflammatory treatment was administered with clinical improvement
column21: and she was referred to the emergency department of the referral hospital. On arrival at the emergency department
column22: the patient remained asymptomatic
column23: but during her stay she presented a febrile peak
column24: without associated infectious focus
column25: with the same electrocardiographic findings and echocardiogram with preserved left ventricular (LV) systolic function
column26: without segmental alterations of contractility
column27: without significant valvular heart disease and without pericardial effusion. In view of the patient's clinical condition
column28: it was decided to admit her to the coronary care unit
column29: with suspicion of acute myocarditis versus acute coronary syndrome
column30: for continuous cardiovascular monitoring and extension studies
column31: such as cardiac catheterisation. Physical examination Blood pressure (BP) 155/87 mmHg
column33: respiratory rate (RR) 14 rpm
column34: temperature 36.3 oC
column35: basal oxygen saturation 97%. General condition stable
column36: hydrated
column37: eupneic. Neck: jugular ingurgitation could not be assessed due to obesity. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds
column38: muffled tones without murmurs or friction rubs. Pulmonary auscultation: clear audible vesicular murmur
column39: no extra sounds. Lower extremities: no oedema or signs of venous thrombosis. Neurological: vigil
column40: conscious
column41: oriented
column42: without focality.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiograms: Initial ECG (with chest pain): RS 70 bpm
column43: PR 160 msec
column44: QRS 90 msec with 60o axis
column45: suprathreshold < 0.5 mm in DI-AVL and tendency to ST-segment sublevel in DIII and AVF. No significant changes in subsequent electrocardiograms without chest pain. ECG (ED
column46: without chest pain
column47: with fever): RS 70 bpm
column48: PR 160
column49: QRS 90 msec
column50: axis 60°
column51: ST elevation of 1mm in DI
column52: aVL
column53: DII with negative T in III and aVF and ST rectification in V4-V5. ECG at discharge: RS at 66 bpm. PR 160 msec. Narrow QRS. Normal electrical axis. ST elevation of 0.5 mm in I
column54: aVL with inferior rectification. Q wave in aVL. Blood tests: On admission (ED): glucose: 144 mg/dl
column55: urea: 27 mg/dl
column56: creatinine: 0.74 mg/dl
column57: Na 139.3 mmol/l
column58: K 3.84 mmol/l
column59: CRP 8.9 mg/dl. Venous gases: pH 7.41
column60: pCO2 40
column62: EB 0.7. Leukocytes 8990
column64: haemoglobin 13 g/dl
column65: haematocrit 39.5%
column66: platelets 354
column68: INR 1. Urine toxins: positive for benzodiazepines
column69: rest negative. Control: total cholesterol 182mg/dl
column70: HDL 42cmg/dl
column71: LDL 124 mg/dl
column72: TGC 79 mg/dl
column73: liver profile normal. CRP 6.7 mg/l
column74: TSH 1.35 mU/l
column75: Hb 1AC 5.6%. Evolution of myocardial necrosis markers: ultrasensitive troponin I 22
column76: 973 pg/ml on admission -> 15
column77: 255 pg/ml on discharge. CK 589 U/l on admission -> 85U/l on discharge. Chest X-ray: normal cardiothoracic index
column78: without alterations of the pulmonary parenchyma
column79: free costophrenic and cardiophrenic sinuses. Admission portable echocardiogram: LV neither dilated nor hypertrophied with preserved global contractility and altered relaxation. Left atrium (LA) slightly dilated. No structural or functional valvular alterations of note. Non-dilated right chambers with preserved ventricular contractility. Absence of indirect data indicative of significant pulmonary hypertension (PH). Control echocardiogram (before discharge): unchanged with respect to previous study. Coronary angiography: right radial. Right dominance. Coronary arteries without significant angiographic lesions. CMR (15 days after discharge): study in the late phase after contrast administration shows subepicardial gadolinium uptake in inferomedial
column80: inferolateromedial
column81: anterolateral basal and anterior basal and middle and intramyocardial anterolateral middle and apical segments. Normal systolic function. Conclusion: myocarditis with fibrosis in the described segments.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION During her admission to the coronary unit
column82: she remained asymptomatic
column83: coronary angiography performed 12 hours after admission ruled out obstructive coronary artery disease. A repeat transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) was performed 24 hours later
column84: with normal biventricular function persisting
column85: without segmental contractility defects or pericardial effusion. Myocardial injury markers remained elevated in plateau for the next 48 hours. Platelet antiplatelet therapy was maintained with acetylsalicylic acid
column86: due to suspicion of NOCA-PT
column87: and ACE inhibitors were started due to a tendency to hypertension (HT) with good tolerance
column88: as well as a high-potency statin. The clinical evolution was satisfactory
column89: remaining haemodynamically stable without signs of heart failure
column90: afebrile
column91: without anginal recurrence and without ventricular arrhythmias on continuous cardiac monitoring. Since CMR was not possible during admission
column92: he was scheduled for outpatient surgery 15 days later. CMR showed anterolateral and inferior subepicardial fibrosis compatible with clinical suspicion of myocarditis
column93: so antiplatelet treatment and statin was withdrawn. During follow-up
column94: the patient suffered some epigastric discomfort with a non-coronary profile and palpitations
column95: with no evidence of ventricular arrhythmias on Holter and normal residual ventricular function.  DIAGNOSIS Acute myocarditis. column6: while walking
column7: without associated vegetative cortex. column9: heart rate 65 bpm. No jugular venous engorgement. Normal cardiorespiratory auscultation

column16: INR 1

column18: creatinine 0.61 mg/dl

column20: potassium 4.33 mEq/l

column28: non-HDL 143 mg/dl. SARS-CoV-2 RNA detection (nasopharyngeal exudate): negative. Emergency ECG: sinus rhythm at 65 bpm. Normal and constant PR. Narrow QRS
column29: normal axis. Scarce R wave progression in precordial leads
column30: inferolateral subendocardial lesion with subepicardial ischaemia. Chest X-ray in the emergency department: normal cardiothoracic index
column31: free costophrenic sinuses
column33: no bone or pleural alterations. ECG on the cardiology ward
column34: first admission: sinus rhythm at 70 bpm. Normal and constant PR. Narrow QRS. Subepicardial lesion of up to 4 mm in the anterior face. First emergency catheterisation: left main coronary artery (LMCA) without lesions. Anterior descending artery (ADA) with diffuse lumen involvement and occlusion at the beginning of the distal segment with TIMI 0 distal flow
column35: suggesting spontaneous haematoma dissection. Circumflex artery (Cx) with diffuse involvement of the lumen also
column36: somewhat more marked in the middle third. Right coronary artery (RCA) dominant
column37: with no lesions and smooth contours. Angioplasty on RCA: the guidewire progresses but appears to be in false lumen. Intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) was performed
column38: which confirmed that it was a coronary dissection with haematoma from the origin of the artery
column39: and that the guidewire was in false lumen
column40: with collapsed true lumen. An attempt was made to pass the guidewire to the true lumen with a Sasuke double lumen catheter
column41: but without success. IVUS was repeated and the patient recovered distal TIMI 3 flow
column42: with spiroid dissection of the ADA in the mid-distal third. As the patient had no chest pain and isoelectric ST
column43: it was decided not to continue with the intervention. Angio-CT of the supra-aortic trunks and aorta: study within the normal range. The ascending aorta
column44: aortic arch and descending aorta and their visceral branches showed no abnormalities. Emergency ECG

column46: axis at 0o. Subepicardial lesion in high lateral face with associated subepicardial ischaemia
column47: specular descent in inferior face
column48: subendocardial lesion in anterior face with subepicardial ischaemia up to V4. LAD with intramural haematoma up to the beginning of the middle segment where a double lumen is seen
column49: similar to the final result of previous PCI
column50: with TIMI 3 flow and proven by IVUS. Cx with intramural haematoma compressing its lumen and causing a pseudo-occlusion of the marginal branch (previously not present) with TIMI 1 flow (lesion responsible). Dominant ACD
column51: intramural haematoma type: guidewire progresses to ADA
column52: Cx and OM. PCI is performed with simple balloon in OM (Pantera pro 2 x 20 mm at 8 atm) and in Cx
column53: then by cutting balloon (Wolverine 2 x 10 mm at 12 atm) with kissing
column54: and ends with simple balloon in Cx somewhat more distal due to displacement of the haematoma (Mozec 1.5 x 15 mm at 8 atm). Coronary CT angiography (images 4 A and B): Coronary CT angiography (after second admission): Thrombosis of the false lumen is observed in the IVC
column55: which conditions the filiform calibre of the true lumen. DA proximal proximal third filiform lumen due to thrombosis of the false lumen. Cx thrombosis of the false lumen and the proximal proximal proximal lumen. Control coronary CT angiography (at 3 weeks): TCI: short with normalisation of the luminal diameter. ADA: notable improvement in vessel calibre with persistence only at the ostial level of thrombosis of the false lumen. Intimal flap still present from the middle 1/3 with good filling of the distal vessel. Cx: normalisation of the vessel lumen with no evident signs of dissection at present. ACD: no evidence of lesions or images of dissection. DP and PL branches without lesions.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION During his stay on the cardiology ward he presented with angina at rest with vegetative cortex and in the ECG an anterior subepicardial lesion of up to 4 mm in V2
column56: for which urgent coronary angiography was performed where
column57: with the aid of IVUS
column58: an image of spontaneous coronary artery dissection (SCD) with mural haematoma was observed extending from LMCA towards Cx with TIMI 3 flow and towards the LAD with distal occlusion. Final TIMI 3 flow was achieved after passing the angioplasty guidewire without stent implantation
column59: but spiroid dissection persisted in the mid-distal segment. Angio-CT of the supra-aortic and aortic trunks was performed without detecting extracoronary vascular lesions
column60: at discharge echocardiography without segmentarism and with preserved ejection fraction. The possibility of an underlying antiphospholipid syndrome was not ruled out
column61: so after completing 1 week of double antiplatelet therapy and anticoagulation
column62: he was discharged with acetylsalicylic acid and low molecular weight heparin until the hypercoagulability study was completed. However
column63: two days after discharge from hospital
column64: she went to the emergency department for oppressive chest pain radiating to the upper limbs with vegetative cortex
column65: in ECG lateral subepicardial lesion
column66: activating AMI code. Coronary angiography with progression of dissection to LMCA verified by IVUS
column67: intramural haematoma in circumflex artery causing pseudo-occlusion of marginal branch (culprit lesion); angioplasty with simple balloon and cutting balloon was performed with resolution of the occlusion. A coronary angio-CT scan was performed 3 weeks apart
column68: the first during the last admission
column69: and after discharge home
column70: showing an improvement in the intramural haematoma
column71: with persistent intimal flap from the middle third of the anterior descending artery and thrombosis of the false lumen at the proximal anterior descending artery. On discharge
column72: double antiplatelet therapy was maintained for 3 months until a subsequent review
column73: and treatment was prescribed with statins
column74: beta-blockers and nitrates.  DIAGNOSIS Spontaneous coronary artery dissection in the left coronary tree due to intramural haematoma:  Acute myocardial infarction with anterior ST elevation. Spontaneous coronary artery dissection with occlusion of distal anterior descending artery
column75: recovery of TIMI 3 flow by low-pressure balloon angioplasty and coronary guidewire without stent implantation. 90 minutes of ischaemia. Recurrence of acute myocardial infarction with lateral ST elevation. Successful primary balloon angioplasty in obtuse marginal-circumflex bifurcation. Preserved biventricular ejection fraction. Angio-CT without extracoronary arterial anomalies. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History Allergy to acetylsalicylic acid. Cardiovascular risk factors: hypertension. Ex-smoker for 7 years
column3: previously smoked 10 cigarettes a day. No cardiological history. Other history: intraocular hypertension. Seasonal allergic rhinitis. Usual treatment: enalapril 10 mg (1 tablet per day)
column4: rupatadine fumarate 10 mg (1 tablet per day)
column5: latanoprost 50 mcg/ml (1 ophthalmic single-dose pack per day) Baseline: independent for activities of daily living. Active life. No cognitive impairment.  Present illness A 71-year-old man came to the emergency department with clinical manifestations of weakness and clumsiness in the right upper limb on waking up in the morning
column6: perceived as being unable to turn off the alarm clock. When trying to get out of bed
column7: he fell to the floor due to weakness in the right lower limb. In addition
column8: there was a deviation of the corner of the mouth to the right. He reported very slight improvement in these symptoms during his stay in the emergency room. Asymptomatic when he began to rest at night the previous night. No thermometric fever or dysthermic sensation. No chest pain
column9: dyspnoea or palpitations.  Physical examination Good general condition. Normal colour of skin and mucous membranes. Adequate nutrition and hydration. No rash or petechiae. No lymphadenopathies. Eupneic at rest. Blood pressure (BP) 159/94 mmHg; heart rate (HR) 79 bpm; oxygen saturation 97% aa; blood glucose 118 mg/dl; temperature 36.6 oC. Cardiac auscultation: regular sounds without murmurs. Respiratory auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur
column10: no pathological sounds.  Abdomen soft and depressible
column11: non-painful
column12: with no signs of peritoneal irritation and no evidence of visceromegaly or masses. Lower extremities without oedema and with present and symmetrical pulses. Neurological examination: NIHSS 2. Conscious and oriented with preserved language. Discrete dysarthria. Pupils isochoric and normoreactive. Normal confrontational campimetry. Normal extrinsic ocular motility. Deviation of the oral commissure to the right with disappearance of the left nasolabial fold. No signs of meningeal irritation. No carotid murmurs were heard. Strength in MSD 4/5
column13: MID 4+/5
column14: MSI 5/5
column15: MII 5/5. Sensibility and reflexes normal. Plantar cutaneous reflexes in flexion. No dysmetria or adiodokinesia. Romberg negative
column16: with no alterations in gait.   COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm at 58 bpm
column17: PR 200 ms
column18: left bundle branch block type ventricular conduction disorder. Blood tests: haemoglobin 15.5 g/dl
column19: haematocrit 45.4%
column20: mean corpuscular volume 90.7 fl
column21: mean corpuscular haemoglobin 30.9 pg
column22: leukocytes 6300/ml
column23: neutrophils 3500/ml
column24: lymphocytes 1700/ml
column25: monocytes 600/ml
column26: platelets 240000/ml. Coagulation: partial thromboplastin time (PTT) 29.8 s
column27: thromboplastin time (ratio) 1.02
column28: fibrinogen 248 mg/dl
column29: INR 1.0. Biochemistry: glucose 135 mg/dl
column30: urea 31 mg/dl
column31: creatinine 1.11 mg/dl
column33: sodium 140 mmol/l
column34: potassium 3.8 mmol/l
column35: total bilirubin 0.6 mg/dl
column36: ALT 26 U/l
column37: CK 70 U/l
column38: amylase 71 U/l
column39: C-reactive protein < 1 mg/l. Posteroanterior and lateral chest X-ray: normal cardiothoracic index. Elongation of the aorta. Thickening of the peribronchovascular interstitium
column40: without identifying areas of consolidation or pleural effusion. No other significant findings in lung parenchyma or cardiomediastinal silhouette. CT scan of the skull without contrast and cerebral angio-CT in the emergency department: empty cranial CT scan: hypoattenuation of periventricular white matter in relation to changes due to chronic hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy. Rest of brain and cerebellar parenchyma unaltered. No areas of intra- or extra-axial cerebral haemorrhage
column41: oedema
column42: midline deviation or hydrocephalus. No lesions in the calvarium. Signs of sinusopathy with mucosal debris occupying bilateral ethmoidal cells. Cerebral CT angiography of the supra-aortic trunks and the polygon of Willis: the large vessels forming the supra-aortic trunks and the polygon of Willis were patent and of normal calibre
column43: with no occlusions
column44: images of stenosis or aneurysms. Lipoma measuring 10 x 5 mm on the inferior aspect of the right sternocleidomastoid muscle. Cervical degenerative changes. Other structures included in the study
column45: with no other significant findings. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and angio-MRI (images 2
column46: 3 and 4): scan performed without and after administration of IVC: there are multiple foci of diffusion restriction due to acute ischaemia distributed dispersed throughout the right midbrain territory with both cortical and deep involvement. Although smaller in number and volume
column47: there were also multiple foci of acute ischaemia in the posterior border territory of the left hemisphere. No signs of haemorrhagic complications. Vascular examination showed no significant stenotic pathology in supra-aortic trunks or structures of the polygon of Willis. Holter: sinus rhythm throughout the recording. Mean heart rate 75 bpm
column48: minimum heart rate of 44 bpm and maximum of 110 bpm. There was a ventricular conduction disorder such as left bundle branch block and PR at the limit. No signs of high-grade atrioventricular block. Maximum RR 1.15 s. Conclusion: intraventricular disorder without arrhythmias with cardioembolic potential. Transthoracic echocardiography: mild concentric hypertrophy of the left ventricle with preserved global systolic function. Abnormal septobasal movement
column49: without other alterations of segmental contractility at rest. Absence of significant valvular heart disease. Transmitral filling pattern of impaired relaxation without signs of increased left ventricular filling pressures. Normal right ventricle. Mild tricuspid insufficiency allowing estimation of pulmonary systolic pressure of approximately 35 mmHg. Transesophageal echocardiography: transesophageal exploration carried out after sedation with midazolam i.v. 6 mg
column50: without complications. Vibrating
column51: filamentous mass of intermediate echorefringence
column52: approximately 6 x 2.5 mm in size on the ventricular side of the aortic valve
column53: suggestive of papillary fibroelastoma. Normal transvalvular aortic flow. Left aortic valve free of thrombus. No shunt through the interatrial septum after administration of agitated saline. The rest of the study is superimposable to the transthoracic examination.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION In summary
column54: this is a 71-year-old man who was admitted to the neurology department for a picture of neurological focality of sudden onset consisting of weakness of the right lower and upper limbs and facial asymmetry
column55: with progressive resolution during hospitalisation. As for the aetiological study
column56: cerebral magnetic resonance imaging revealed multiple cortical and deep ischaemic lesions in the territory of both middle cerebral arteries. In view of the suspected cardioembolic aetiology
column57: the cardiology department was contacted to complete the study. During her hospital stay
column58: electrocardiographic monitoring by Holter
column59: which showed no arrhythmias suggestive of causing the current clinical picture
column60: and transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiography
column61: the latter showing a lesion in the aortic valve compatible with papillary fibroelastoma. After finding evidence of this lesion
column62: the cardiac surgery department was contacted to assess the case. Given the symptoms of embolic origin consisting of ischaemic involvement of the right and left middle cerebral arteries
column63: surgery was performed consisting of resection of the tumour
column64: without the need for valve repair. In successive outpatient check-ups
column65: the patient was asymptomatic
column66: with no evidence of new embolic phenomena.  DIAGNOSIS Biterritorial ischaemic stroke (both middle cerebral arteries) of cardioembolic aetiology secondary to aortic fibroelastoma. |O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O Control with blood tests and iron studies in 6 months.  DIAGNOSIS Acute myocardial infarction without ST Killip I elevation (preserved LVEF). Significant coronary artery disease of a main vessel. Type II insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus with poor metabolic control. Obesity grade I. Smoking. Dyslipidaemia. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  39-year-old woman
column3: primigravida at 9 weeks
column4: with a personal history of grade II obesity and severe aortic insufficiency
column5: who underwent surgery at the age of 24 using the Tyrone-David technique (replacement of ascending aorta with valve repair). At the age of 29
column6: a new operation with implantation of a metallic aortic prosthesis. Usually anticoagulated with acenocoumarol
column7: at the beginning of pregnancy she started treatment with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) with a regimen of enoxaparin 12
column8: 000 IU (120 mg)/0.8 ml once a day. In addition
column9: he suffers from hypothyroidism and is treated with levothyroxine 150 mcg per day. After waking up in the morning
column10: she began to feel pain in the left cervical region and a significant sensation of corkiness in the homolateral side of the face
column11: associated with moderate precordial pain radiating to the left shoulder
column12: together with vomiting. Due to a feeling of general malaise
column13: 2 hours after the onset of symptoms
column14: she decided to return to bed and after sleeping for approximately 30 minutes she awoke without facial paresthesia
column15: however
column16: given that she continued with central thoracic discomfort
column17: she decided to consult the emergency services. There
column18: haemodynamic stability was observed with blood pressure of 117/63
column19: heart rate of 70 bpm
column20: afebrile state and baseline oxygen saturation of 92%. The neurological examination ruled out focality at that time. Cranial nerves were preserved and pupils were isochoric and normoreactive. There was rhythmic cardiac auscultation with metallic click
column21: without murmurs and respiratory auscultation with preserved vesicular murmur without added noises. The abdomen is soft
column22: depressible and painless and the lower limbs show no oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis. On arrival
column23: an electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed
column24: showing ST-segment rectification in the inferior face of approximately 0.5 mm
column25: and the patient was transferred to the monitored observation room. Following the results of the first analysis
column26: which showed elevated markers of myocardial damage
column27: the on-call cardiologist was consulted. On evaluation
column28: a new ECG was performed with negative T waves in leads V5-V6 and in II
column29: III and aVF. A transthoracic echocardiogram was performed showing inferoapical and apical segmental contractility defects. An attempt was made to perform a transesophageal echocardiogram to assess the mechanical aortic prosthesis
column30: ruling out thrombosis. Due to the analytical
column31: echo and electrocardiographic findings
column32: a diagnosis of high-risk non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (NSTEACS) was made and early coronary angiography was requested
column33: and the patient was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) for continuous monitoring.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Initial ECG: sinus rhythm at 74 bpm
column34: normal axis
column35: isoelectric ST
column36: flattened T waves in III and aVF but positive. ECG on admission to ICU: sinus rhythm at 80 bpm
column37: normal axis
column38: development of negative T waves in II
column39: III
column40: aVF and from V3 to V6. ST elevation 1 mm in III and rectification in aVF. CBC: haemogram: leukocytes 7.7 thousands/μl
column41: segmented (74%) 5.7 thousands/μl
column42: lymphocytes (18.5%) 1.4 thousands/μl
column43: red cells 4.23 million/μl
column44: haemoglobin 13 g/dl
column45: haematocrit 38.5%
column46: MCV 91.1 fl
column47: platelets 180 thousands/μl. Coagulation: prothrombin time 12.9 seconds
column48: prothrombin activity 80.0 %
column49: aTTP 37.2 seconds
column50: fibrinogen 638 mg/dl
column51: INR 1.17 INR. Biochemistry: glucose 87 mg/dl
column52: urea 10 mg/dl
column53: creatinine 0.51 mg/dl
column54: estimated glomerular filtration rate (MDRD-4- IDMS) > 60 ml/min/1.73
column55: sodium 136 mmol/l
column56: potassium 3.5 mmol/l
column57: chlorine 107 mmol/l
column58: magnesium 1.96 mg/dl. Peak myocardial damage markers: CPK 783 IU/l
column59: TnIhs: 6953.3 ng/l. Anti Xa levels: 1st determination: 0.71 IU/mL; 2nd determination: 0.8 IU/mL. Transthoracic echocardiogram: non-dilated left ventricle without significant hypertrophy
column60: subjectively preserved left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) with dyskinesia in the apex
column61: distal inferior and distal septal
column62: with normal diastolic pattern. No mitral valvulopathy. Left atrium not dilated. Mechanical aortic prosthesis with very discrete lavage jets and with parameters of GPAo 26 mmHg
column63: GMAo 12 mmHg
column64: LVOT LVOT/Ao ratio of 0.6 (no stenosis). Right ventricle (RV) not dilated with normal systolic function
column65: no tricuspid insufficiency (TI) to estimate pulmonary arterial systolic pressure (PSAP)
column66: no pericardial effusion. Transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) (videos 1 and 2): no thrombosis of aortic mechanical prosthesis. Left aortic valve without thrombus inside. Non-dilated LV with no thrombus inside. Preferential coronary angiography: left dominance. Left main coronary artery without significant stenosis. Anterior descending artery of good calibre and development
column67: with an image compatible with an embolus in the very distal section
column68: in the apex and when the vessel is already of fine calibre. Circumflex artery of good calibre and development
column69: dominant
column70: angiographically normal. Right coronary artery of small calibre and development
column71: non-dominant
column72: without lesions. Absence of significant atherosclerotic lesions. CT scan of the aorta: the metallic aortic valve prosthesis and the post-surgical changes of the aortic root in the first 40 mm are observed. Along the entire length of the ascending aorta there is a constant diameter of 30 mm. Although optimal aortic lumen density has not been reached in the images obtained
column73: there are no radiological findings suggestive of dissection along the aorta or its TSA. No other radiologically significant findings were found with this imaging technique.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was admitted to the ICU for monitoring. Prior to coronary angiography
column74: the on-call gynaecology team was contacted and the patient was informed of the benefits/risks of the procedure and warned that due to the average radiation dose received per patient (less than 500 mGy)
column75: it was not advisable to legally terminate the pregnancy. The haemodynamics department was then contacted to perform a preferential catheterisation
column76: which identified an angiographic image suggestive of embolism in the very distal anterior descending coronary artery. Subsequently
column77: obstetric ultrasound was performed
column78: which confirmed foetal viability. On admission
column79: aortic CT angiography was requested to detect aortic dissection and/or brachiocephalic and carotid trunk dissection
column80: which was finally ruled out. His stay in the ICU was uneventful. The haematology department was consulted to adjust the anticoagulation dose which
column81: prior to admission
column82: was maintained at 12
column83: 000 IU (120 mg)/0.8 ml once a day. The anticoagulant treatment was adjusted to 10
column84: 000 IU (100 mg)/1 ml every 12 hours and the patient was transferred to the cardiology ward
column85: where antiXa levels were requested and showed borderline levels between prophylactic and therapeutic doses. The most likely aetiology of NSTEACS was assumed to be coronary embolism in relation to the undercoagulated mechanical prosthesis
column86: which in addition to releasing a small embolus into the coronary circulation
column87: could possibly have released one into the cerebral circulation
column88: causing the facial paresthesia and cervical pain. After a multidisciplinary approach between the gynaecology
column89: cardiology and haematology teams
column90: it was decided that since the patient was still in the first trimester of pregnancy
column91: treatment with LMWH should continue until week 13 (adjusted according to anti-Xa levels) and then reintroduce vitamin K antagonists (VKA) until delivery. Her stay in the cardiology ward was uneventful and she was discharged after 5 days of hospitalisation.  DIAGNOSIS Acute myocardial infarction without septal and apical ST elevation in relation to embolism at the level of the very distal anterior descending coronary artery. Possible transient ischaemic attack. Undertherapeutic anticoagulation levels in a patient with a mechanical aortic prosthesis. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History 49-year-old woman
column3: with no known allergies or toxic habits. Lives at home with her parents
column4: under guardianship
column5: independent for basic activities of daily living (BADLL). No cardiovascular risk factors or family history of heart disease. Cardiological history of mitral prolapse with moderate mitral insufficiency under follow-up in cardiology consultations. Other history of: cognitive deficit secondary to intrauterine infection
column6: micrognathia and psoriasis without associated osteoarthritis. No treatment as usual.   Current illness Admission to cardiology
column7: after detecting in outpatient clinic
column8: where he went for review of his valvulopathy
column9: ECG compatible with evolved AMI with anteroseptal Q wave
column10: paucisymptomatic. Anamnesis was difficult due to the patient's baseline condition; we spoke to her parents
column11: who reported that she had presented at home in the previous days with episodes of epigastric pain and diffuse abdominal pain
column12: which subsided with paracetamol 1g/8h
column13: and for which they did not consult
column14: without associated vegetative cortex. They denied objective dyspnoea
column15: chest pain or syncope. There was no fever or associated infectious semiology at any level. Likewise
column16: for approximately two weeks
column17: the patient has had clinical symptoms of instability with behavioural alterations
column18: pending an appointment for neurological assessment.   Physical examination Blood pressure 120/75 mmHg
column19: heart rate 98 bpm. Baseline O2 saturation 98%. Afebrile. Conscious
column20: oriented
column21: normohydrated and perfused
column22: eupneic at rest. Cachexia (body mass index 15). No jugular ingurgitation at 45o. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds
column23: known mitral II/VI systolic murmur. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur. Abdomen: soft
column24: depressible
column25: preserved peristalsis
column26: painful on general palpation
column27: no signs of peritoneal irritation
column28: no murmurs. Lower extremities: no oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis. No loss of skin continuity.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG on admission: sinus tachycardia at 127 bpm. ST elevation V1-V4 Q in V1 V2. ECG on discharge: sinus rhythm at 90 bpm
column29: with negative T waves from V1 to V4. Myocardial necrosis markers: ultrasensitive troponin T: 1050 -> 968.8 ng/l. Blood tests: biochemistry: glucose 120 mg/dl
column30: HbA1c 5.5%
column31: urea 0.5 g/l
column33: glomerular filtration rate 90 ml/min. Total cholesterol 112 mg/dl
column34: LDL cholesterol 54 mg/dl
column35: HDL cholesterol 45 mg/dl
column36: triglycerides 83 mg/dl
column37: sodium140 mEq/l
column38: potassium 4 mEq/l. TSH 0.6 mcU/ml. Blood count: haemoglobin 14.2 g/dl
column39: haematocrit 40%
column40: leucocytes 6400/mm3
column41: platelets 305000/mm3. Coagulation: AP 75%
column42: INR 1
column43: fibrinogen 465 mg/dl. Chest X-ray: normal cardiomediastinal silhouette. Hiatal hernia. Bilateral apical fibrocystic fibrocystic tracts. No acute pleuroparenchymal alterations. Myocardial perfusion scan at rest: non-viability. Myocardial necrosis in the apex and anteroapical and anteroseptal segments (infarct area between 16% and 22% of the left ventricular area; LVEF 53%). Coronary computed tomography (CT): occlusion of the middle anterior descending artery (AD) with permeable and filiform apical bed. AMI in the anterior and apical septum (thinning and hypoperfusion in the apex and anterior septum). No perivalvular abscesses are observed. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) on admission: apical akinesia with preserved systolic function (LVEF 55%). Mass visualised on the atrial side of the anterior leaflet in the mitral valve suggestive of vegetations
column44: hypermobile
column45: 1.17/0.5 cm in size
column46: filiform with a wide base of implantation that conditions moderate-severe mitral insufficiency (A2-P3) with posterior eccentric jet and Coanda effect
column47: without systolic inversion in the pulmonary veins. No perforation of the leaflet or mitroaortic fibrosis was observed. There is no mitral valve stenosis. Dilated left atrium. Thin layer of pericardial effusion. Echocardiogram at 6 weeks: left ventricle of normal size and thickness
column48: with borderline systolic function (LVEF 50%). Akinesia and apical thinning. Moderate left atrial dilatation. Normal right chambers. Remarkable decrease in the size of the vegetation in the anterior mitral leaflet (almost complete disappearance). Mitral valve prolapse of the anterior leaflet causing moderate regurgitation with eccentric jet (similar to studies prior to admission). No perforation of the leaflet or involvement of the mitroaortic fibrosa was observed. The rest of the patient had no significant valvular alterations. Pulmonary arterial systolic pressure cannot be calculated due to the absence of tricuspid insufficiency. Aortic root of normal size. No pericardial effusion. Microbiology: Blood cultures 25/01/2020: Streptococcus anginosus. Urine culture 25/01/2020: negative. PCR influenza and respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) 07/02/2020: negative. Urine culture 07/02/2020: Escherichia coli. Blood cultures on 28/01
column50: 07/02 and 11/02/2020: negative. Abdominal CT scan: hiatus hernia. Uterine myoma of 14 mm. Rest without alterations. Craniocerebral CT scan: hyperdense area compatible with haemorrhagic focus of 10 x 7 mm in left fronto-parietal lobe
column51: which does not rule out the existence of underlying pathology. Rest of the brain parenchyma without significant alterations. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain: left occipital annular uptake that could be related to septic embolism
column52: as well as left occipital temporal temporal corticojuxtacortical signal alteration suggesting acute-subacute ischaemic lesion and left frontal subacute haemorrhagic focus. In context
column53: the findings could all be related to septic embolism.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION Admitted with a diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction
column54: paucisymptomatic. In the first hours of hospitalisation he presented febrile peaks of up to 38oC
column55: with no associated infectious semiology
column56: so blood and urine cultures were requested
column57: PCR for respiratory viruses and empirical antibiotic therapy was started
column58: which was modified after growth of S. anginosus in the first 24 hours in both blood cultures
column59: to intravenous penicillin G sodium and intravenous gentamicin. TTE showed apical akinesia with preserved LVEF and an image suggestive of vegetation in the anterior mitral leaflet (atrial side) of 11 mm
column60: which led to moderate regurgitation with eccentric jet. Of note
column61: it was impossible to perform a transesophageal echocardiogram due to the patient's facial anatomy. On the one hand
column62: in the case of a recently diagnosed advanced acute myocardial infarction
column63: a viability study was performed with myocardial perfusion scintigraphy at rest
column64: showing an absence of viability in the segments compatible with the LAD territory. A coronary CT scan was also performed
column65: confirming occlusion in the mid LAD with a permeable and filiform apical bed. It was decided not to revascularise due to the absence of clinical benefit
column66: and the patient remained stable without new episodes of chest pain. Residual LV systolic function was preserved with apical akinesia at discharge. On the other hand
column67: with the diagnosis of subacute endocarditis in native mitral valve
column68: together with the initial clinical manifestations of instability and behavioural alteration
column69: as well as diffuse abdominal pain
column70: an extension study was performed with: Cranioencephalic CT and cerebral MRI which confirmed the existence of images suggestive of septic embolisms and abdominal CT where no significant alterations were found. Both ruled out the presence of abscesses. A gynaecological examination was also performed
column71: which ruled out abscess or complications at this level.  Subsequent clinical and haemodynamic evolution was favourable
column72: with negative blood cultures at 72 hours
column73: presenting as a complication urinary tract infection by E coli and Enterococcus faecium 2 weeks after starting antibiotherapy
column74: for which treatment was escalated
column75: replacing penicillin with ceftriaxone
column76: completing 6 weeks of antibiotic treatment
column77: with no other complications. After completing the 6 weeks
column78: a new control TTE was repeated
column79: where the vegetation practically disappeared
column80: with prolapse of the anterior mitral leaflet leading to moderate residual mitral insufficiency similar to previous studies and preserved left ventricular systolic function. Given the absence of progression of mitral regurgitation (MR) and the disappearance of valvular vegetations in a frail patient (FRAIL 5; CFS 7)
column81: conservative treatment was chosen. Finally
column82: after completion of the physiotherapy programme by the rehabilitation service
column83: with progressive recovery of motor function
column84: she was discharged home with outpatient follow-up
column85: with no episodes of decompensation to date and in NYHA functional class I at the last review.  DIAGNOSIS Subacute endocarditis on native mitral valve (anterior leaflet) due to Streptococcus anginosus (viridans) resolved with prolonged antibiotic therapy and complicated with septic embolism:  Acute embolic apical myocardial infarction with occlusion in middle LAD not revascularised due to lack of viability. Left occipital and left frontotemporal ischaemic cerebrovascular accident (CVA) (with subsequent haemorrhagic transformation) due to septic embolisms.  Borderline residual LV systolic function (LVEF 50%) with apical akinesia.  Urinary tract infections due to E coli and Enterococcus faecium. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History 49-year-old male patient with the following personal history: No known adverse drug reactions. Cardiovascular risk factors: arterial hypertension of 13 years of evolution
column3: initially untreated and which
column4: in recent years
column5: has had treatment with irregular adherence to it; dyslipidaemia of 8 years of evolution
column6: in treatment with oral lipid-lowering drugs
column7: but also with irregular adherence to it. Toxic habits: active smoker of more than 15 cigarettes a day (IPA of 35 packs/year)
column8: alcoholism with a regular consumption of around 1 litre of beer a day since adolescence
column9: occasional cocaine user.   Cardiological history: Chronic coronary syndrome
column10: with debut in 2012 in the form of acute myocardial infarction without ST-segment elevation (NSTEMI). During this admission
column11: monovalvular coronary artery disease of the proximal anterior descending artery was detected
column12: which was revascularised with the implantation of 1 drug-eluting stent. Left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) was preserved at discharge. New admission in 2017 for NSTEMI
column13: caused by thrombosis at the level of the proximal ostial circumflex artery without total obstruction and treated with abciximab perfusion initially and subsequently with balloon PCI. Left ventricular systolic function preserved. Abandoned follow-up in cardiology outpatient clinic.   Usual treatment: acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) 100 mg (1 tablet every 24 h)
column14: omeprazole 20 mg (1 tablet every 24 h)
column15: telmisartan 40 mg (1 tablet every 24 h)
column16: lorazepam 1 mg (1 tablet every 12 h)
column17: bisoprolol 2.5 mg (1 tablet every 24 h)
column18: atorvastatin 80 mg (1 tablet every 24 h)
column19: fenofibrate 145 mg (1 tablet every 24 h).   Present illness The patient
column20: with the history described above
column21: presents with chest pain at home
column22: unrelated to exertion. He describes the pain as central thoracic
column23: oppressive
column24: radiating to the neck and left upper limb
column25: similar to the two previous heart attacks and accompanied by vegetative symptoms in the form of profuse sweating and nausea. Initially
column26: he decided to take one tablet of lorazepam and
column27: as his symptoms worsened
column28: he decided to take two tablets of sublingual caffeine
column29: which he vomited immediately. The family then called the emergency services. On arrival of the emergency team
column30: the patient was symptomatic
column31: with chest pain and significant impairment of the general condition
column33: oriented and cooperative
column34: with the following physical examination: Vitals: systolic blood pressure of 95/54 mmHg; heart rate of around 100 bpm
column35: saturating at 96% without oxygen supply. Skin pallor
column36: acral coldness
column37: weak peripheral pulses. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic tones
column38: tachycardic
column39: no audible murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: bilateral vesicular murmur preserved
column40: with crackles in the bases. Lower limbs: no oedema. An electrocardiogram (ECG) was then performed
column41: showing ST segment elevation (images 1 and 2)
column42: so it was decided to administer a loading dose of ASA (300 mg)
column43: ticagrelor (180 mg)
column44: and emergency cardiology was contacted pre-hospital for transfer to our hospital.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Emergency ECG: sinus rhythm at 90 bpm
column45: normal PR
column46: ST segment elevation in DII
column47: DIII
column48: AVF (up to 7 mm) and in V4-6
column49: with specular decrease in V1-2
column50: aVL. Initial coronary angiography (video 1): Left main coronary artery: No stenosis. Recurrence of very late thrombosis of the stent implanted in the ostial anterior descending artery
column51: a phenomenon that in this case affects the distal left main coronary artery (both anterior descending and circumflex)
column52: but maintaining TIMI 3 epicardial flow in both branches. Anterior descending: permeable ostial-proximal ostial stent
column53: not restenotic
column54: with presence of ostial thrombus. Rest of the vessel without de novo lesions. Occlusion by embolisation of the anterior descending artery at the terminal (apical) level. Circumflex: co-dominant
column55: without lesions
column56: with presence of ostial-proximal thrombus
column57: as previously detailed. Occlusion by embolus of the distal posterior descending artery of the circumflex. Right coronary artery: codominant
column58: without lesions. Post-catheterisation ECG on admission to the coronary unit (image 3): sinus rhythm with narrow QRS
column59: normalisation of the ST segment
column60: Q wave of 1 mm in DII
column61: DIII
column62: aVF
column63: V5-6.  Admission blood tests: haemogram: red series with Hb 15.7 g/dl and haematocrit 45.8%. White series with leukocytosis of 17
column64: 760 cells/mm3 and neutrophilia of 15
column65: 590 cells/mm3. Platelets 261
column66: 000 cells/mm3. Blood glucose: 74 mg/dl. Renal function: creatinine 1.04 mg/dl and urea 33 mg/dl. Ions within normal range. CRP 0.6 mg/l. Myocardial damage markers: CPK 365 - 1283 - 2487 - 731 - 203 - 142 - 83 - 87 U/l. Ultra-sensitive troponin T: 11 - 904 - 2166 - 871 - 1484 - 1069 - 1429 - 10 - 5 ng/l. GSV: pH 7.25; pCO2 40.4 mmHg; lactic acid 7.4 mmol/l; HCO3- 17.7 mmol/l. HbA1c: 5.6%. Lipid profile: total cholesterol 103 mg/dl; triglycerides 92 mg/dl; HDL cholesterol 60 mg/dl; LDL cholesterol 25 mg/dl. Urinalysis with toxins: positive for cocaine and benzodiazepines. Echocardiography in the ED: left ventricle of globular appearance
column67: with preserved LVEF
column68: no segmental contractility disorders can be seen due to poor endocardial visualisation. Right ventricle of normal size and preserved systolic function. No significant valvulopathies. No pericardial effusion. Vena cava of normal size and with adequate inspiratory collapse. Control coronary angiography at 7 days: resolution of the stent thrombosis generated in the ostial anterior descending artery
column69: described in the previous angiography
column70: was confirmed. Doppler ultrasound of the left groin: hypoechogenic image is seen in the perivascular soft tissues
column71: adjacent to the superficial femoral artery
column72: with no flow inside
column73: compatible with changes secondary to puncture
column74: probably haematic infiltration. No significant post-puncture haematoma is evident. All the vessels studied appear permeable and with normal flow morphology. There were no images suggesting additional complications: arteriovenous fistula or pseudoaneurysm. ECG at hospital discharge: sinus rhythm at 65 bpm. Constant PR of 100 ms. Narrow QRS of 80 ms. Negative T waves in II
column75: III
column76: aVF and V4-6. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) at discharge: non-dilated left ventricle
column77: with slight concentric hypertrophy of walls (13 mm of septum and 13 mm of posterior wall)
column78: with preserved left ventricular systolic function (57%)
column79: without segmental contractility disorders. Right ventricle not dilated and normofunctioning. Atria of normal dimensions. Normal aortic root. Absence of organic valvular pathology. No pericardial effusion. Inferior vena cava not dilated with adequate inspiratory collapse. The Doppler study showed normal anterograde valvular flows
column80: with no significant valvular insufficiencies. Blood tests at discharge: Normal haemogram of the 3 series. Coagulation normal. Biochemistry: glycaemia
column81: renal function and ions normal. Markers of myocardial damage: CPK 87 U/l and TnT 5 ng/l. CRP 1.2 mg/l. GSV: pH 7.37; pCO2 50.5 mmHg; HCO3 28.6 mmol/l; lactic 2.1 mmol/l.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION On arrival at the hospital emergency department
column82: the patient was found to be in a very poor general state
column83: hypotensive and with a low level of consciousness
column84: which made it necessary to initiate aminergic support (noradrenaline) with a view to performing primary angioplasty in which thrombosis was observed in the area of the ostium of the anterior descending trunk and trunk-circumflex. As in the NSTEACS of 2017
column85: initial pharmacological management was chosen in order to reduce the thrombotic burden prior to any interventional procedure. Thus
column86: an intracoronary bolus of abciximab was administered and intravenous perfusion was left in place. After starting this treatment
column87: haemodynamic improvement and recovery of the level of consciousness was observed
column88: and the patient was transferred to the coronary unit for continued monitoring and follow-up. The case was presented at a medical-surgical session and it was decided to repeat the coronary angiography after 7 days
column89: depending on the results of the coronary angiography
column90: medical treatment
column91: percutaneous revascularisation or surgery could be considered depending on the findings. During his stay
column92: initially in the coronary unit and subsequently in the cardiology ward
column93: the patient evolved favourably in clinical and haemodynamic terms
column94: with no congestive signs
column95: no arrhythmic events
column96: no recurrence of chest pain and with preserved LVEF without complications in the control TTE. On re-history
column97: the patient reported that in the previous weeks he had increased his alcohol and tobacco consumption
column98: and that he had used cocaine again on several occasions
column99: the last dose the day before the event. A repeat coronary angiography was performed 7 days later
column100: in this case via the femoral artery
column101: and resolution of the thrombus was observed. In view of this situation
column102: it was decided not to perform any more invasive procedures on this patient and
column103: after an adequate evolution on the hospital ward
column104: it was decided to discharge the patient with recommendations
column105: leaving him on a double anti-aggregation treatment with ASA and ticagrelor. Prior to discharge
column106: the patient presented a painful tumour in the inguinal region
column107: coinciding with the puncture site for coronary angiography via the femoral artery
column108: which made it necessary to perform a Doppler ultrasound to rule out complications of the procedure. After performing the ultrasound and ruling out these complications
column109: the patient was discharged from the hospital. Emphasis was placed on the importance of abandoning the consumption of toxic substances and the importance of therapeutic compliance. He was transferred to the cardiac rehabilitation unit on discharge
column110: where these recommendations were insisted on
column111: as well as diet and physical exercise. After follow-up
column112: he was discharged with subsequent review in outpatient cardiology consultations. At the present time
column113: and more than 1 year after the acute event
column114: the patient has completely abandoned the consumption of toxic substances and has not presented any further coronary events. Given his history
column115: it was also decided to prolong the double antiplatelet therapy
column116: and the patient is currently on ticagrelor 60 mg every 12 hours.  DIAGNOSIS Inferolateral KK IV STEACS. Late stent thrombosis in ostial anterior descending artery affecting the left common trunk and the ostium of the circumflex artery with TIMI 3 flow but with distal embolisation with occlusion of distal anterior descending and distal posterior descending arteries. Pharmacological treatment with intracoronary abciximab and later triple antiplatelet therapy with intravenous abciximab and ASA + ticagrelor orally. Global preserved LVEF with no mechanical complications or valvular heart disease. Cocaine use as a precipitating factor. Active smoking and alcoholism. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History 26-year-old male
column3: high-intensity sportsman
column4: firefighter by profession. No family history of heart disease or sudden death (SD) at an early age. No known drug allergies. No smoker or drinker. No consumption of other toxic substances. No known cardiovascular risk factors. No medical illnesses or surgical interventions of interest. No chronic treatment.  Current illness Patient attended the emergency department in March 2020 for an episode of dizziness associated with loss of vision and a fall to the floor while at rest
column5: while making a sudden neck twisting movement
column6: without knowing whether she lost consciousness. Immediate recovery with no post-critical period
column7: no sphincter relaxation or tonic-clonic movements. She reported that this was the first time this symptomatology had occurred
column8: denying previous syncopal episodes or palpitations.  Physical examination General state of health. Well hydrated and perfused. Athletic build. Eupneic at rest. Oxygen saturation 99% without oxygen therapy. Blood pressure (BP) 125/65 mmHg
column9: heart rate (HR) 55 bpm. No jugular ingurgitation. No adenopathies. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column10: at a good frequency. No murmurs or audible extratonos. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur. Abdomen: soft
column11: non-painful
column12: no masses or megaliths. Lower limbs: no oedema or signs of venous insufficiency or deep vein thrombosis. Distal pulses present and symmetrical  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: sinus bradycardia at 55 bpm
column13: normal axis
column14: short PR with marked pre-excitation (positive delta wave in I
column15: inferior face and from V1-V6
column16: negative in avL)
column17: wide QRS due to initial filling with RsR' morphology in V1 with marked repolarisation alterations with ST underleveling and negative T waves in II
column18: III
column19: aVF and V1-V6. Chest X-ray: normal cardiothoracic index. No images suggestive of condensation. Free costophrenic sinuses. Normal lung parenchyma. CBC: haemoglobin 14.6 g/dl
column20: leucocytes 7200/microl (67% PMN)
column21: platelets 365
column22: 000/microl. Coagulation: PT 80%. Biochemistry: creatinine 0.67 mg/dl
column23: urea 28 mg/dl
column24: ions normal. Hepatobiliary profile and thyroid hormones normal. Echocardiogram (videos 1 and 2): left ventricle not dilated
column25: without ventricular hypertrophy but showing marked hypertrabeculation especially at the apical
column26: lower apical
column27: middle and lateral apical levels
column28: with numerous intraventricular recesses which are checked by colour Doppler for communication with the ventricular cavity. LVEF at the limit of normality (LVEFbp 55%). No segmental contractility disorders. Left ventricular (LV) diastolic function: normal transmitral pattern with E/A ratio 1.4 and TDE 296 ms. Normal filling pressures (average E/E ́ 8
column29: lateral E ́ 16 cm/s
column30: medial E ́ 8.5 cm/s
column31: LA < 34 ml/m2
column32: IT < 2.8 m/s). Right ventricle of normal size with normal systolic function (TAPSE 23 mm). Normal left atrium. Normal right atrium. Normal size thoracic aorta. No valvulopathies. Pericardium without relevant findings. No intracavitary masses or thrombi. Inferior vena cava of adequate calibre and respiratory dynamics. Ergometry: Bruce MET protocol: 24. Excellent functional capacity. The test was stopped when the target heart rate (HR) was reached. No chest pain or dyspnoea during exercise. No dynamic changes suggestive of ischaemia. During the entire tracing
column33: there was overt pre-excitation with secondary repolarisation alterations
column34: which disappeared when the heart rate reached 170 bpm and the repolarisation alterations disappeared. Subsequently
column35: during recovery
column36: the patient remained without pre-excitation and without repolarisation alterations due to probable exhaustion of the accessory pathway. There were no arrhythmic events of interest. Adequate tension and chronotropic response. Conclusions: clinically and electrically negative for ischaemia. Pre-excitation that disappears at 170 bpm. Holter: RS study with HR between 24-43-95 bpm. Maximum pause of 3.7 seconds
column37: intermittent pre-excitation. Occasional nodal rhythm. Cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR): left ventricle (LV) slightly dilated with marked trabeculation of the myocardium
column38: on all sides except the septum and basal segments that show less trabeculae. The ratio of non-compacted myocardium to compacted myocardium (NCM/CM) is greater than 2.3 with a maximum value of 4.3 in several segments. Global and segmental mobility are preserved. The EF measured with the Simpson method is 62%. VTDVI of 243 ml
column39: indexed by body surface area of 124 ml/m2
column40: VTSVI of 91.6 ml
column41: indexed by body surface area of 47 ml/m2. Cardiac output of 10 l/min. There were deep crypts located at the inferior junction of both ventricles
column42: another in the middle anteroseptal segment and the third at the level of the apical inferior segment. The right ventricle is neither dilated nor hypertrophic
column43: with marked hypertrabeculation. Global and segmental mobility preserved. The EF measured with the Simpson method is 66%. Both atria are of normal size. The first-pass perfusion sequence shows no perfusion defect at rest. Late enhancement/viability sequence does not show gadolinium retention suggesting necrosis and/or fibrosis. Conclusion: non-compaction cardiomyopathy with involvement of both ventricles. Preserved biventricular function. Slight LV dilatation. Absence of fibrosis. ECG after ablation: sinus tachycardia at 105 bpm
column44: normal axis
column45: PR 146 ms
column46: narrow QRS
column47: non-pathological q wave in inferior face
column48: ST rectification in inferior face and V5-V6 with negative T in inferior face
column49: normal QTc.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was assessed in the emergency department by the cardiology service in the event of a syncopal episode
column50: and an electrocardiogram was performed in sinus rhythm with short PR and a marked positive delta wave in inferior aspect and V1-V6 and negative in aVL
column51: thus giving the impression of a left lateral accessory pathway. Laboratory tests and chest X-ray were performed
column52: compatible with normality
column53: as well as echocardiography showing a non-dilated left ventricle but with marked hypertrabeculation at the apical
column54: apical lateral and lower middle and apical levels
column55: with numerous recesses communicating with the ventricular cavity
column56: with preserved LVEF
column57: right ventricle of normal morphology and function and no significant valvulopathies (videos 1 and 2). Given the suspicion of non-compaction cardiomyopathy with left lateral accessory pathway
column58: studies were completed with genetic study and screening of first-degree relatives and CMR (images 2
column59: 3 and 4) which confirmed the presence of non-compaction cardiomyopathy with biventricular involvement
column60: more marked in the left ventricle
column61: which was slightly dilated and affected in all segments except the septum and basal segments
column62: with a maximum ratio between non-compacted and compacted myocardium of 4.3. There are deep crypts located at the inferior junction of both ventricles
column63: another in the mid anteroseptal segment and the third at the level of the apical inferior segment. The rest of the study was compatible with normality
column64: with preserved biventricular systolic function and no fibrosis in the late enhancement sequence. The patient was referred to the arrhythmia and electrophysiology unit and underwent ergometry
column65: reaching 24 METs
column66: without arrhythmic events during the test and with marked pre-excitation during the start of the test
column67: which disappeared when 170 bpm was reached
column68: and remained without pre-excitation during recovery. A 24-hour Holter monitor was also performed
column69: which showed the presence of intermittent pre-excitation but no arrhythmic events of interest. Based on the above
column70: it was decided to perform an electrophysiological study (EPS) in May 2020
column71: and programmed stimulation was performed with the finding of concentric decremental anterograde conduction at baseline (and
column72: therefore
column73: through the specific conduction system) which became eccentric and with an earlier ventriculogram at the left lateral level after infusion of isoproterenol (via the accessory pathway). Similarly
column74: atrioventricular dissociation is observed at 600 ms in programmed retrograde pacing from the right ventricular apex
column75: which changes to concentric decremental retrograde conduction after isoproterenol infusion. The anterograde refractory period of the pathway is measured and is 240 ms after isoproterenol infusion. No tachycardias are induced after baseline programmed atrial and ventricular pacing and after isoproterenol. Mitral annulus mapping was performed by retroaortic access
column76: with radiofrequency ablation at the left anterolateral level
column77: and ablation was effective with disappearance of pre-excitation in 2.5 seconds.  After ablation
column78: the patient continued subsequent follow-up in the arrhythmia and electrophysiology unit
column79: remaining asymptomatic in NYHA functional class I and without events in serial Holter monitoring
column80: in sinus rhythm without pre-excitation in the baseline ECG although maintaining marked alterations in ventricular repolarisation. In October 2020
column81: the results of the genetic study were obtained
column82: identifying a previously undescribed variant in the ACTC1 gene (p.Pro260Leu)
column83: which could be associated with the patient's phenotype (non-compaction cardiomyopathy)
column84: although more information is needed to confirm this
column85: and screening of first-degree relatives has yet to be completed.  DIAGNOSIS Non-compaction cardiomyopathy with biventricular involvement and preserved systolic function. Slight dilatation of the left ventricle. Left anterolateral accessory pathway with intermittent pre-excitation. Successful ablation of the pathway by radiofrequency.
