column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History 80-year-old woman. No known adverse drug reactions. Cardiovascular risk factors: hypertension with good ambulatory control. Non-insulin-dependent type 2 diabetes mellitus with good outpatient control. Mixed dyslipidaemia with good outpatient control. Denies toxic habits. Cardiological history: paroxysmal atrial fibrillation with two electrical cardioversions (2016 and 2018). Other medical and surgical history: depressive disorder
column3: essential thrombocythemia
column4: severe neurotrophic corneal ulcer operated on. Usual treatment: fluoxetine 20 mg (1 tablet every day
column5: started one month ago)
column6: lorazepam 1 mg (every day)
column7: acenocoumarol 1 mg (1 tablet every day and adjust according to controls)
column8: amiodarone 200 mg (1 tablet every other day)
column9: chlorthalidone 50 mg (1 tablet every day)
column10: irbesartan 300 mg (1 tablet every day)
column11: felodipine 5 mg (1 tablet every day)
column12: atorvastatin 20 mg (1 tablet every day)
column13: glimepiride 20 mg (1 tablet daily)
column14: linagliptin 5 mg (1 tablet daily)
column15: doxycycline 200 mg (1 capsule daily) and 1 tablet 100 mg (daily)
column16: moxifloxacin ophthalmic
column17: paracetamol/tramadol 75/650 mg (1 tablet every 12 hours)
column18: famotidine 20 mg (1 tablet daily)
column19: pantoprazole 20 mg (1 tablet daily)
column20: anagrelide 0.5 mg (2 tablets every 7 days).   Present illness The patient is an 80-year-old woman who comes to the point of continuous care (PAC) for symptoms of loss of consciousness the day before the consultation and on three occasions during the same
column21: lasting approximately 30 seconds and complete spontaneous recovery. She also had a feeling of dizziness of the unsteadiness type and previous tinnitus
column22: with no associated vegetative cortex. No palpitations. No semiology of heart failure. No chest pain. No infectious clinical manifestations due to equipment. During her stay in the PAC
column23: she presented a new episode witnessed by the doctor
column24: who defibrillated on evidence of pulseless ventricular fibrillation (PSVF) on the electrocardiogram - which we do not have - and performed cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) manoeuvres for less than 5 minutes. After recovery of sinus rhythm
column25: the patient was referred to the hospital emergency department. Once there
column26: the critical box monitor showed a torsade de Pointes (TdP) rhythm
column27: initiated by the phenomenon of R over T
column28: self-limited for seconds
column29: with presyncopal symptoms
column30: so isoproterenol and magnesium sulphate perfusion was started. It was decided not to implant a temporary pacemaker due to the non-relapse of the arrhythmia with isoproterenol perfusion (the patient remained in sinus rhythm at 95 bpm) and was admitted to the coronary care unit (CCU) for monitoring and correction of triggering factors. Physical examination Blood pressure (BP) 125/84 mmHg
column31: heart rate (HR) 95 bpm
column32: oxygen saturation 98% with FiO2 21%. Digital blood glucose 238 mg/dl. Good general condition. Conscious and oriented. No signs of respiratory distress. Cardiopulmonary auscultation: regular
column33: no audible murmurs. Vesicular murmur preserved
column34: without added noises. Abdomen: soft and depressible
column35: no palpable masses or organomegaly
column36: not painful on palpation. No signs of peritoneal irritation. Lower limbs: no oedema. No signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Neurological: conscious and oriented. Glasgow 15. Mild bradypsychia. Language correct in form and content. Cranial nerves without alterations. Normal eye movements. Pupils isochoric
column37: normoreactive. Strength and sensitivity of limbs preserved and symmetrical (5/5).  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiograms (ECG): Health Centre: sinus rhythm at 80 bpm
column38: PR 160 ms
column39: QRS 120 ms with morphology of complete right bundle branch block (CRBBB) and electrical axis at -60o
column40: asymmetrical negative T waves in V3-V6
column41: flattened T waves in I
column42: II
column43: III and aVL. QT 600 ms
column44: QTc (Bazett) 639 ms. In the critical care unit: polymorphic ventricular tachycardia of the TdP type. On discharge from the cardiology ward: sinus rhythm at 65 bpm
column45: PR 160 ms
column46: QRS 160 ms with BCRDHH morphology and electrical axis at -60o
column47: asymmetrical negative T waves in V1 and III. QT 480 ms
column48: QTc 492 ms. Blood tests: haemoglobin 10.9 g/dl
column49: MCV 81.6 fl
column50: MCH 25.3 pg
column51: MCHC 31 g/dl
column52: leukocytes 10 10*9/l
column53: neutrophils 8 10*9/l
column54: lymphocytes 1 10*9/l
column55: platelets 190 10*9/l. Coagulation: prothrombin time (PT) 16.3 sec. Quick's index 59%
column56: INR 1.39. APTT 28 s. Biochemistry: glucose 137 mg/dl
column57: sodium 136 mEq/l
column58: potassium 2.9 mEq/l
column59: magnesium 1.6 mg/dl
column60: calcium corrected to albumin 8.1 mg/dl
column61: chlorine 94 mEq/l total bilirubin 3.99 mg/dl
column62: direct bilirubin 2.07 mg/dl
column63: indirect bilirubin 1.92 mg/dl
column64: alanine aminotransferase GPT 34 U/l
column65: urea 91 mg/dl
column66: creatinine 1.08 mg/dl
column67: estimated glomerular filtration rate (GFR) CKDEPI 48.6 ml/min/1.73 m2
column68: C-reactive protein 7.1 mg/dl
column69: ferritin 109 ng/dl
column70: iron 47 g/dl
column71: transferrin saturation index 15.2%
column72: uric acid 10.2 mg/dl
column73: protein 6.6 g/dl
column74: TSH 2.3 mIU/l.  HF markers: Carbohydrate Ag. 125 (CA125) 154 IU/ml
column75: NT-proBNP > 35
column76: 000 pg/ml. Arterial blood gases: pH 7.52 pCO2 40 mmHg
column77: pO2 75 mmHg
column78: HCO3a 32.7 mmol/l
column79: O2SAT 95.7%
column80: lactate 2.3 mmol/l. Transthoracic echocardiogram: concentric left ventricular hypertrophy. Increased left ventricular volumes with global hypokinesia
column81: more severe in lower segments
column82: and severe depression of global systolic function (LVEF 32%). Moderate mitral regurgitation. Mitral filling pattern suggestive of increased end-diastolic pressure. Severe left atrial dilatation. Right ventricle with normal diameters and mild depression of global systolic function
column83: mild tricuspid insufficiency (TI) with GP 31 mmHg. Inferior vena cava (IVC) not dilated. Estimated systolic pulmonary artery pressure (SPAP) 35 mmHg. Absence of pericardial effusion. Chest X-ray: very poorly inspired study. Increased bilateral perihilar alveolar raster
column84: which could correspond to discrete oedema. There were no images suggestive of pulmonary consolidation. Free costophrenic sinuses. Cardiomegaly. Calcification of the aortic button. Degenerative changes in the dorsal spine. Coronary angiography: epicardial coronary arteries without lesions.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION During her stay in the OCU
column85: the patient remained asymptomatic and electrocardiograms showed prolonged QT interval (QTc 639 ms)
column86: of probable iatrogenic acquired aetiology
column87: as she was taking up to 3 drugs with known risk of TdP (moxifloxacin
column88: anagrelide
column89: amiodarone) and 4 that could be arrhythmogenic in specific conditions (fluoxetine
column90: pantoprazole
column91: famotidine and tramadol). In addition
column93: hypomagnesaemia and hypocalcaemia
column94: electrolyte disorders that predispose to prolongation of the QT interval. For all these reasons
column95: it was decided to discontinue the predisposing medication and to supplement magnesium
column96: calcium and potassium to correct their plasma levels. After 48 hours of monitoring without new episodes and correction of the QTc to 540 ms
column97: it was decided to transfer him to the cardiology ward to complete treatment and study (HF with severe ventricular dysfunction with moderate mitral insufficiency (MI) on regular echocardiography). During her stay in the cardiology ward
column98: coronary angiography was performed to complete the study of dilated cardiomyopathy without any pathological findings. The patient progressed favourably and due to clinical and haemodynamic stability and correction of the electrocardiographic alteration
column99: after 19 days in hospital it was decided to discharge her home with subsequent monitoring and follow-up by the heart failure unit. Pharmacological treatment was started for HF with reduced LVEF (sacubitril/valsartan 24/26 mg [1 tablet every 12 h]
column103: furosemide 40 mg [1 tablet every 24 h]) together with magnesium 53 mg [2 tablets every 12 h] and edoxaban 30 mg [1 tablet every 24 h]. Similarly
column104: it was decided to discontinue drugs precipitating QT interval prolongation (fluoxetine
column107: pantoprazole and famotidine). In the cardiology outpatient follow-up
column109: and after optimal medical treatment of HF
column110: the patient showed clinical stability with no recurrence of HF
column111: partial recovery of LVEF (current LVEF 40%) and QT interval within normal limits. Therefore
column112: the patient is labelled as non-ischaemic dilated cardiomyopathy with a tachycardiomyopathy component and treatment is maintained at the appropriate doses.  DIAGNOSIS Iatrogenic acquired prolonged QT interval (pharmacological and hydroelectrolytic) with arrhythmic events in the form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (torsade de Pointes) and recovered cardiorespiratory arrest. Heart failure with reduced LVEF in the context of non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy with some component of tachycardiomyopathy. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History Male
column3: 45 years old. No drug allergies. No arterial hypertension
column4: no diabetes mellitus
column5: no dyslipidaemia. No known heart disease or bronchopathy. Advanced chronic kidney disease on haemodialysis programme
column6: secondary to autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. Renal transplant in May 2018 with acute rejection on the 10th day with good subsequent response. Proximal deep vein thrombosis at the level of superficial femoral
column7: popliteal vein and deep and twin branches of left lower limb in November 2018 in current treatment with acenocoumarol. Pyelonephritis of the renal graft in March 2019 with good response to antibiotic treatment. Current treatment: prednisone 20 mg/24 hours
column8: tacrolimus 4 mg/24 hours
column9: omeprazole 20 mg/24 hours
column10: enoxaparin 60 mg/24 hours and furosemide 40 mg/24 hours.  Present illness He was admitted from the nephrology department for clinical manifestations of fever
column11: predominantly nocturnal
column12: up to 38.3oC
column13: of 2 weeks of evolution
column14: together with exertional dyspnoea NYHA III
column15: orthopnoea
column16: oedematisation of the lower limbs and cough with whitish expectoration. He had been admitted 2 months previously for the same reason with partial improvement and without identification of the aetiology
column17: but the symptoms recurred after discontinuation of antibiotic therapy. No micturition symptoms
column18: no alterations in bowel habits.  On previous admission
column19: a study was performed for a similar clinical picture and fever of unknown origin. Chest CT scan on admission showed mild pericardial effusion and a micronodular interstitial pattern with well-defined nodules
column20: bilaterally and symmetrically distributed. In this context
column21: blood cultures
column22: urine cultures and serology were negative and there was no PCR detection of cytomegalovirus
column23: Pneumocystis jirovecii (in bronchoalveolar lavage) and respiratory viruses. Negative smear microscopy
column24: PCR for tuberculosis in bronchoalveolar lavage and bronchoaspirate and negative mycobacterial culture. Galactomannan for aspergillus in bronchoalveolar lavage negative. Negative PCR for Leishmania in bone marrow. Given the lack of detection of an aetiological agent during admission and the improvement with antibiotic treatment
column25: it was decided to discharge the patient on a course of ciprofloxacin and follow-up in consultations.  Physical examination Good general condition. Eupneic at rest. Blood pressure 136/80 mmHg
column26: heart rate 100 bpm
column27: oxygen saturation 96% (FiO2 0.21). Central venous pressure: absence of jugular ingurgitation. Cardiac and respiratory auscultation: rhythmic tones without audible murmurs. Vesicular murmur with no added sounds. Abdomen: soft
column28: depressible
column29: not painful on palpation. Palpable hepatomegaly and splenomegaly. Murphy and Blumberg negative. Lower limbs: left lower limb with signs of deep venous thrombosis (already known) with increased diameter compared to the right. Right lower limb with oedema in the distal third with fovea.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Blood tests on admission: haemoglobin 11.6 g/dl

column103: he had a good evolution with no fever peaks and improvement of dyspnoea after diuretic and antibiotic treatment. Blood cultures
column105: sputum culture and Mantoux were negative. The transthoracic echocardiogram on admission showed preserved biventricular function with severe circumferential pericardial effusion without signs of haemodynamic compromise. As this was a patient with immunosuppressive treatment

column107: tuberculosis was suspected despite Mantoux and negative tests from the previous admission
column108: so treatment was extended for coverage. In addition

In the microbiological analysis
column112: the culture of the first days was negative
column113: but with positive PCR for tuberculous complex without the presence of mutations in the RPO-B gene associated with resistance to rifampicin. Thus
column114: the diagnosis of tuberculosis was confirmed despite the other negative tests and the corresponding treatment was completed. The patient remained afebrile and improved in analytical and radiographic controls
column115: so it was decided to discharge him from hospital with his immunosuppressive treatment (tacrolimus and prednisone) and with a specific regimen for tuberculosis with isoniazid + pyridoxine
column117: ethambutol and pyrazinamide for 2 months and
column119: with isoniazid + pyridoxine and rifabutin for 7 more months. On follow-up
column120: pericardial fluid culture was finally found to be positive for mycobacterium
column121: further supporting the diagnosis. A transthoracic echocardiogram was performed at 6 months
column122: with the pericardial effusion resolved and no pericardial constriction. The patient has now completed treatment for tuberculosis without complications and is afebrile and clinically well.  DIAGNOSIS Pericardial effusion due to Mycobacterium tuberculosis in a patient immunocompromised by renal transplantation. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History Smoker of 3 cigarettes a day. Severe mitral regurgitation secondary to chordal rupture pending surgery. Pre-anaesthetic assessment performed
column3: with last transthoracic echocardiography (TTE)
column4: transesophageal echocardiography (TTE) and pre-surgical coronary angiography without epicardial lesions the month prior to the episode. Inguinal hernia surgery. No chronic treatment.  Present illness 50-year-old male brought to hospital emergency department by SAMU after recovered cardiorespiratory arrest. The patient presented at rest while watching television with an episode of loss of consciousness without previous symptoms
column5: at which point his relative called 112 and started basic cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR). On arrival of the SAMU
column6: they observed cardiorespiratory arrest and began advanced CPR manoeuvres (laryngeal mask + mechanical ventilation)
column7: observing as the first rhythm ventricular fibrillation (VF)
column8: for which 5 shocks were administered
column9: 450 mg of amiodarone and 3 mg of adrenaline
column10: recovering sinus rhythm. On arrival at the emergency department
column11: a laryngeal mask was replaced by an endotracheal tube. The patient was sedoanalgesiated and well adapted to mechanical ventilation
column12: haemodynamically stable without vasopressor or inotropic drugs.  Physical examination Blood pressure (BP) 127/91 mmHg
column13: heart rate (HR) 93 bpm
column14: oxygen saturation 96% (IMV with FIO2 100%). Cardiac auscultation: regular heart sounds

column16: crackles in the bases. Abdomen: soft and depressible

column19: no response to pain
column20: medium photoreactive pupils.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram (ECG) on arrival at the critical care unit: sinus rhythm at 100 bpm
column21: isolated ventricular extrasystoles
column22: PR 160ms. Narrow QRS with normal axis
column23: without repolarisation alterations. ECG during monitoring: sinus rhythm at 100 bpm
column24: normal PR
column25: frequent polytopic ventricular extrasystoles
column26: narrow QRS with normal axis
column27: signs of LVH
column28: no significant repolarisation abnormalities. Blood tests on arrival at the critical care unit: haemoglobin 17 g/dl
column29: MCV 96.3 fl. Leukocytes 18100 (Ne 13300
column31: 000. D-dimer 11538 μg/ml. IQ 100%. Na+ 137mmEq/l
column33: Ur 36 mg/dl
column34: creatinine 1.15 mg/dl
column35: calcium 8.8 mg/dl
column36: protein 6.6 g/dl
column37: CRP 0.1 mg/dl
column38: GPT 186 U/l
column39: amylase 173 U/l. Arterial blood gases on arrival (FiO2 50%): pH 7.16
column40: pCO2 58 mmHg
column41: pO2 113 mmHg
column42: HCO3 20.7 mEq/l
column43: Sat O2 98.8%
column44: lactate 5.6 mmol/l. Arterial blood gas one hour after arrival: pH 7.24
column45: pCO2 50 mmHg
column46: pO2 131 mmHg

column48: Sat O2 99.3%
column49: lactate 3 mmol/l. PCR SARS VOC 2 on arrival: negative. Computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain: size of the ventricular system within the normal range
column50: without significant dilatation of sulci
column51: identifying no intracranial haematic collections
column52: space-occupying lesions
column53: fracture traces or alterations suggesting the presence of areas of acute ischaemia. Midline elements are centred. Chest X-ray: portable study with little inspiration
column54: signs of vascular redistribution without showing infiltrates or pleural effusion. TTE and TEE: mitral valve with eversion of the posterior leaflet at P2 (flail) due to chordal rupture. Two divergent regurgitant jets of globally severe regurgitation (ORE by PISA 0.5 cm2
column55: vena contracta 6-7 mm
column56: regurgitant volume 96 ml). Left ventricle (LV) of greatly increased diameters and volumes with mildly depressed systolic function (LVEF 45-50%). Absence of other significant valvulopathies. Very dilated left atrium. Right ventricle with normal diameters and systolic function preserved in limits. No signs of pulmonary hypertension (PAPS 30-35 mmHg). Inferior vena cava not dilated.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was transferred to the coronary unit (UCO). Cerebral and pulmonary CT was performed to rule out cerebrovascular accident (CVA)
column57: pulmonary thromboembolism (PTE) or acute aortic syndrome. Given the CT findings
column58: empirical antibiotic therapy was started. A few hours later
column59: he was extubated
column60: with good clinical evolution and remained stable in haemodynamic and respiratory terms. No neurological involvement was identified as a sequelae of the arrest. The control chest X-ray showed disappearance of the alveolar infiltrates. Ten days later
column61: the cardiac surgery team operated to repair the mitral valve
column62: placing a mitral ring and 4 neo-strings. During surgery
column63: extensive prolapse of P2
column64: chordal rupture and cleft between P1-P2 were observed. Postoperative TEE was performed and showed no residual mitral regurgitation (MR) after repair. After the operation
column65: he remained in the OCU
column66: presenting several episodes of atrial fibrillation (AF) that led to haemodynamic instability and were controlled by electrical cardioversion (ECV) and intravenous amiodarone perfusion. After reaching stability
column67: a single-chamber implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) was implanted for secondary prevention. The patient was subsequently discharged. He has continued to undergo check-ups at the clinic
column68: remaining in NYHA functional class I and with no new arrhythmic events.  DIAGNOSIS Malignant mitral valve prolapse (complicated with recovered CRP). Severe mitral insufficiency due to P2 prolapse due to chordal rupture

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History No known drug allergies. Lives with her husband. Never smoker. Occasional drinker. No cardiovascular risk factors or previous cardiological history. Other antecedents: varicose veins in lower limbs. No previous surgical intervention. Chronic treatment: oral contraceptive (levonorgestrel 0.1 mg/etinylestradiol 0.02 mg 1 tablet per day).  Present illness The patient presents with a self-limiting episode of precordial pain at rest. It is attributed to musculoskeletal origin and treated with anti-inflammatory drugs. At 22:15 hours the following day
column3: she presented with a new episode of precordial pain
column4: which did not subside with rest
column5: together with general malaise. Her husband called the emergency services. At that moment
column6: the patient suffered cardiorespiratory arrest (CRA) and her husband started basic cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR). On arrival of the emergency services
column7: a shockable rhythm was detected
column8: which changed to sinus rhythm after 3 shocks at 200 joules. Fifteen minutes of advanced CPR were recorded
column9: with orotracheal intubation and invasive mechanical ventilation. The outgoing electrocardiogram (ECG) showed right bundle branch block without clear ST-segment elevation
column10: so the Infarction Code was not activated. The patient was transferred to the emergency department of our centre.  Physical examination On arrival at the ED: temperature 36.7°C
column11: blood pressure 90/73 mmHg
column12: heart rate 92 bpm
column13: respiratory rate 16 rpm
column14: oxygen saturation 94%. Sedoanalgesia
column15: connected to invasive mechanical ventilation. Good distal perfusion. Jugular venous pressure normal. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds
column16: tachycardic
column17: no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur. Lower extremities without oedema. Carotid
column18: radial and femoral pulses present.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS CBC: haemoglobin 12.5 g/dl
column19: MCV 95.9 fl
column20: MCH 30.3 pg C
column21: leukocytes 13
column23: platelets 398
column24: 000/μl. Biochemistry: glucose 385 mg/dl
column25: urea 27 mg/dl

column27: sodium 139 mmol/l
column28: potassium 2.6 mmol/l
column29: C-reactive protein 0.3 mg/dl. Lipid profile: total cholesterol 165 mg/dl
column30: LDL 94 mg/dl
column31: HDL 33 mg/dl
column33: HbA1C 5.4%. TSH 1.22 μIU/ml. Ultrasensitive troponin T (normal < 14 ng/l): serial on admission (on arrival
column34: at 3 hours
column35: at 24 hours
column36: at 36 hours and at discharge): 204 --> 6
column40: 704 ng/l. Coagulation: INR 0.92. Prothrombin rate 115%. Partial thromboplastin time 28.6 sec. Partial thromboplastin time ratio 0.92. D-dimer 3
column41: 349 ng/ml. Arterial blood gas: pH 7.28. pO2 282 mmHg. pCO2 35 mmHg. Bicarbonate 16.9 mmol/l. ECG: post arrest: sinus rhythm
column42: negative T wave in V3-V5. On admission to ICU: sinus rhythm
column43: ST segment elevation from V2 to V4. Angio-CT of pulmonary arteries: no evidence of pulmonary thromboembolism or deep vein thrombosis. Cranial CT scan without contrast: no signs of acute intracranial pathology. Echocardiogram in ICU: moderately affected LVEF (39%) with septoapical and apex akinesia
column44: mid-septal and lateroapical hypokinesia. Doubtful image at apical level (two chambers)
column45: which could correspond to thrombus. Mild mitral insufficiency. Coronary angiography: right coronary artery without stenosis. Left main coronary artery without stenosis. Anterior descending artery (AD) with spiroid dissection from the proximal portion and occlusion in the middle segment
column46: TIMI 0 flow. Percutaneous coronary intervention to the LAD: intra-aortic balloon counterpulsation is implanted. After verifying by IVUS the presence of coronary dissection with guidewire in the true lumen
column47: three drug-eluting stents were implanted from the distal LAD to the ostial LAD with final TIMI 3 flow and without complications. Echocardiogram with contrast: 13 x 8 mm mural thrombus in the apex of the left ventricle (LV).  CLINICAL EVOLUTION A 46-year-old woman was admitted after an out-of-hospital CRA resuscitated by a relative. At the time no infarction code was activated by ECG without clear ST-segment elevation. On arrival at the ED
column48: other possible causes of CRA were ruled out (normal pulmonary CT angiography and cranial CT). Initial emergency echocardioscopy showed no segmental contractility alterations. She was transferred to the ICU
column49: where she was sedated
column50: perfused with low doses of noradrenaline
column51: in sinus rhythm and without respiratory compromise; reactive to verbal stimuli
column52: making coordinated movements with the upper limbs and with reactive pupils. An echocardiogram was performed on admission to the ICU which showed ventricular dysfunction and segmental alterations in contractility in the territory of the LAD artery
column53: so a repeat ECG was performed which showed an elevation of the anterior ST segment. Emergent coronary angiography was performed
column54: showing a spirodial dissection of the proximal LAD with occlusion at the level of the middle LAD and distal TIMI 0 flow
column55: and three drug-eluting stents were implanted with good angiographic results
column56: as well as intra-aortic balloon counterpulsation (IABP). In the ICU
column57: she had a favourable evolution that allowed the amine support and IABP to be withdrawn. She was discharged to the hospital ward. She remained in stable condition with amnesia of recent episodes as an identifiable immediate neurological sequela. She remained with a tendency to arterial hypotension and sinus tachycardia during admission without clinical repercussions
column58: which allowed the initiation of neurohormonal treatment with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors) and beta-blockers. Incidentally
column59: in the initial echocardiogram with moderate LV dysfunction
column60: an image suggestive of apical thrombus was observed
column61: which was later confirmed with contrast echocardiography. Electrocardiographically
column62: the patient progressed to established myocardial necrosis with Q wave from V1 to V3. At discharge
column63: triple antithrombotic therapy was maintained with double antiplatelet therapy with acetylsalicylic acid
column64: clopidogrel and acenocoumarol. Acenocoumarol was withdrawn after 3 months of outpatient follow-up
column65: after resolution of the thrombus.  DIAGNOSIS Out-of-hospital cardiorespiratory arrest in defibrillable rhythm
column66: resuscitated. Ischaemic heart disease
column67: ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (STEMI)
column68: Q-wave infarction secondary to spiroid dissection of the LAD with mid-segment occlusion. Percutaneous treatment with implantation of three drug-eluting overlapping stents from distal LAD to ostial LAD. column99: wide QRS with intraventricular conduction disturbances. PA chest X-ray: increased cardiothoracic index
column101: signs of left atrial dilatation. No alveolar infiltrates or images of pleural effusion. Echocardiogram on admission: non-hypertrophic left ventricle (LV)
column102: severely dilated with severely depressed global systolic function due to global hypokinesia and asynchrony (IVS 8 mm
column107: subjective LVEF 25%). Lateral and inferior trabeculation. Dilated left atrium (52 ml/m2). Biphasic left ventricular filling with diastolic dysfunction III and high filling pressures (E/A 2.5
column108: E/e': 19). Normal aortic root. No signs of coarctation. Dilated right chambers with mild RV dysfunction (TAPSE 15 mm). Mild tricuspid insufficiency (TI) allowing estimation of PSAP at 49 + PVC mmHg. Dilated suprahepatic vessels. Mild mitral insufficiency (MI). Mild circumferential pericardial effusion. Rest without findings. Conclusion: dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) with biventricular dysfunction. Severe LV dysfunction. Diastolic dysfunction III. High filling pressures. Pulmonary hypertension (PHT). Mild pericardial effusion. Coronary angio-CT: Dominance: right. No anomalies are visualised in coronary artery outflow. Left coronary: left coronary trunk (LMCA) without lesions. Normal LAD
column109: without stenosis or lesions. Two normal diagonal branches. Marginal obtuse circumflex artery (Cx-OM) without lesions or calcium plaques
column110: very thin. Right coronary artery: own CD without calcium or significant stenosis. Normal DP and TPL branches. Left ventricle very dilated along with the rest of the cavities with slow flow in the appendage (does not appear to be thrombus). Moderate pericardial effusion. Enlarged pulmonary trunk (32 mm) without central pulmonary thromboembolism (PTE). Persistent signs of pulmonary oedema (septal thickening
column112: etc.). No pleural effusion. Conclusion: study without significant coronary lesions. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) without and with contrast (video 2): Left ventricle markedly dilated with severe dysfunction. DDFV 295 ml; indexed DDFV: 164 ml/m2. ESR 244 ml; indexed ESR 136 ml/mV. LVEF 17%. Right ventricle equally dilated with severe dysfunction (end-diastolic diameter 53 mm). RSV 216 ml; indexed RSV 121 ml/m2. ESR 172 ml; indexed ESR 96 ml/m2. RVEF 20%. Generalised hypokinesia. Enlargement of both atria
column114: moderately dilated). Enlarged inferior vena cava (24 mm). Moderate pericardial effusion. No areas of myocardial oedema on T2 sequence. Ratio of non-compacted myocardium to compacted myocardium in the lateral aspect of the LV
column115: fulfilling MRI criteria for non-compacted cardiomyopathy. No myocardial perfusion defects are seen after contrast administration. In late enhancement
column116: a subendocardial area of late enhancement is seen at the septal level and to a lesser degree in the anterior aspect. Conclusion: severe dilated cardiomyopathy with severe biventricular dysfunction. No compaction in the lateral aspect (CNM criteria). PA and lateral radiography after ICD-CRT implantation: increased cardiothoracic index
column118: signs of left atrial dilatation. No alveolar infiltrates or images of pleural effusion. ICD-CRT in left upper hemithorax with 3 normally positioned leads. Blood tests prior to discharge: haemoglobin 12.5 g/dl

column141: TSI 12.02%. NTproBNP 8088 pg/ml. Genetic study: after study of genes related to dilated cardiomyopathy
column142: a variant of uncertain significance c.5009G>A; p.(Arg1670His)
column144: has been observed in the LAMA4 gene. Variants in this gene have been associated with dilated cardiomyopathy
column145: a pathology with an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. Echocardiogram at one year follow-up (video 3): Severely dilated and dysfunctional left ventricle
column146: due to very marked general hypokinesia and slight asynchrony; Dd 71 mm (2D)
column149: EF 34%. Biphasic left ventricular filling with E/A of 2.5
column150: average E/e' 9.5. Dilated left atrium (34 ml/m2). Normal aortic root. Coil catheter in right chambers
column151: right ventricle (RV) non-functioning with TAPSE of 19 mm and S' at 12 cm/s. Very mild TR allowing estimation of PSAP at 35 mmHg + PVC. Suprahepatic vessels not dilated. No pericardial effusion. Conclusion: DCM with biventricular dysfunction. Severe LV dysfunction with asynchrony unchanged with respect to previous ultrasound.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION During his evolution
column152: the patient showed improvement in dyspnoea and oedematisation of the lower limbs
column153: maintaining a good diuresis rate after adjustment of treatment. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging was requested
column154: showing dilated cardiomyopathy with severe biventricular dysfunction
column155: non-compaction on the lateral side and late anteroseptal subendocardial enhancement
column156: which ruled out myocarditis as the cause. However
column157: in view of the finding of subendocardial late enhancement
column158: angio-CT of the coronary arteries was requested to rule out ischaemic origin of the dysfunction in view of the possibility of a congenital coronary anomaly
column159: but the study was normal. Finally
column160: a genetic study was requested to determine the aetiology
column161: which was positive for DCM with variant of uncertain significance c.5009G>A; p.(Arg1670His) in probable heterozygosis in the LAMA4 gene. During follow-up
column162: the patient showed good evolution without clinical signs of heart failure
column163: but because the ejection fraction did not improve despite medical treatment
column164: an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) was implanted for primary prevention together with resynchronisation therapy (CRT) due to the presence of a wide QRS of 140 msec and asynchrony. The ICD was implanted without incident
column165: but a resynchronisation lead could not be implanted due to the impossibility of cannulating the coronary sinus. The case was presented to the Heart Team to determine the best therapeutic option for failed CRT implantation
column166: and the decision was made to implant a pacemaker with Hisian pacing. The procedure was performed 6 months after diagnosis
column167: in which the His zone was located with selective capture
column169: so the left branch was located
column170: obtaining a narrower QRS (144 msec) but with R morphology in V1. Currently
column171: the patient is asymptomatic from the cardiac point of view
column172: although with persistent left ventricular dysfunction and asynchrony in the echocardiographic control one year after diagnosis and after implantation of the pacemaker with physiological stimulation in the His bundle. Therefore
column173: this is a clinical case of a patient with diagnosed tuberous sclerosis associated with dilated cardiomyopathy whose aetiology has not been identified since the genetic study shows an inconclusive mutation. The association between both entities is rare.  DIAGNOSIS Dilated cardiomyopathy in a patient with tuberous sclerosis. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History 51-year-old male with the following personal history: No relevant family history of cardiological problems. No known drug allergies. Cardiovascular risk factors: no arterial hypertension
column3: diabetes or dyslipidaemia. No toxic habits. No previous cardiological history. Baseline situation: sportsman. Asymptomatic when performing physical exertion. No chronic home treatment.  Current illness Consultation at the emergency department due to palpitations of several hours' duration
column4: associated with a feeling of dizziness. According to the patient
column5: he had had palpitations on previous occasions
column6: although they subsided in a self-limited manner with rest. Given the persistence of the symptoms
column7: she decided to go to hospital. She had no other accompanying symptoms (no chest pain or dyspnoea). No history of syncope.  Physical examination On physical examination he was haemodynamically stable
column8: with a blood pressure of 110/55 mmHg and a heart rate of 217 bpm. Baseline oxygen saturation was 98%. No jugular venous engorgement. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds without murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur. Abdomen: soft
column9: non-painful
column10: no masses or megaliths. Lower extremities: no oedema
column11: no signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) with present and symmetrical pulses. The electrocardiogram showed a regular wide QRS tachycardia at 217 bpm with atrioventricular dissociation and absence of Q wave in aVR
column12: suggestive of ventricular tachycardia. In view of the findings
column13: the patient was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) for continuous monitoring and surveillance.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Laboratory tests: blood count and coagulation within normal range. Renal function and ions within normal parameters. NT-proBNP 1890 pg/ml. Electrocardiogram in tachycardia: regular tachycardia with wide QRS (LC 275 ms) with atrioventricular dissociation and absence of Q in aVR
column14: suggestive of monomorphic VT. Ventricular complex with superior electrical axis
column15: positive in V1 (BRD morphology) and negative in I. Basal electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm at 70 bpm. Narrow QRS
column16: with fractionated complexes. Electrical axis of -120o. Negative T waves in inferior face and lateral precordial. Echocardiogram: left ventricle neither dilated nor hypertrophic with mild systolic dysfunction (LVEF 47%). There was akinesia in the basal and middle segments of the inferolateral and lateral face. The right ventricle shows preserved systolic function
column17: with normal structure. Absence of valvulopathies of interest
column18: with normal morphology in the 4 valves. Absence of pericardial effusion. Inferior vena cava not dilated with respiratory phasic changes. Coronary catheterisation: coronary tree with normal distribution and development. Right dominance. Absence of angiographically significant lesions. Cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR): dilated left ventricle with eccentric remodelling and moderate systolic dysfunction. Left ventricular fatty infiltration and segmental contractility abnormalities. Late subepicardial inferior and inferior subepicardial gadolinium enhancement at basal and midventricular levels. Based on the enhancement observed
column19: the findings are suggestive of arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy
column20: and chronic myopericarditis cannot be ruled out.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION After admission to the ICU
column21: the patient remained haemodynamically stable despite persistent tachycardia. Echocardiography was performed
column22: showing left ventricular dysfunction and akinesia in the basal and middle segments at the inferolateral and lateral levels. The right ventricle maintained normal structure and preserved systolic function. Treatment with amiodarone (intravenous infusion) was administered to control the ventricular tachycardia
column23: achieving pharmacological cardioversion and recovering sinus rhythm a few hours after starting the infusion. He remained in sinus rhythm for the next 48 hours
column24: asymptomatic
column25: and was transferred to the cardiology hospital ward to complete the aetiological study of the tachycardia. Once on the hospital ward
column26: a regular echocardiography was performed (in sinus rhythm)
column27: which confirmed mild systolic dysfunction and segmental disorders of left ventricular contractility. In view of the findings
column28: it was subsequently decided to perform a preferential coronary angiography to rule out coronary ischaemia as the cause of the symptoms
column29: and a coronary tree with a normal distribution and no significant angiographic lesions was observed. The patient remained in hospital for several days
column30: remaining asymptomatic and in sinus rhythm. Finally
column31: cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) was performed
column32: showing a striking subepicardial fatty infiltration in the left ventricle and late gadolinium enhancement (LGE) with subepicardial distribution. These findings are suggestive of arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy of the left ventricle. Subsequent genetic study confirmed the diagnosis
column33: resulting in a pathogenic mutation for ACM in the FLNC gene (filamin C). Once the case was presented and discussed in a clinical session
column34: it was decided to implant an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) for primary prevention of sudden death and to start treatment with beta-blockers. Ablation of the arrhythmic substrate will be assessed in the follow-up in the event of persistent tachycardia or appropriate ICD discharges.  DIAGNOSIS Arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy of the left ventricle in structural phase. Sustained monomorphic ventricular tachycardia. Mild left ventricular systolic dysfunction. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History No drug allergies. No cardiovascular risk factors. Cardiovascular history: none. Other: not of interest. Usual treatment: denied. Family history: not of interest. Two healthy children.  Present illness She presented after a fall with rib trauma and fracture of several ribs. Chest X-ray showed cardiomegaly and alteration of the aortic arch
column3: so on-call cardiology was notified. On questioning
column4: the patient reported a previous episode of dizziness on exertion without loss of consciousness. She denied dyspnoea
column5: chest pain
column6: haemoptysis or other associated symptoms. She has two children born vaginally without complications.  Physical examination Heart rate 83 bpm
column7: oxygen saturation 98% at baseline and 95% when walking 300 metres. Cardiac auscultation: systolic murmur at the left sternal border. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur without added noise. Lower extremities: no oedema. Minimal acropacities.   COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Blood tests: haemoglobin 13.8 g/dl
column8: platelets 21 x1000/μl; NT-proBNP 230 pg/ml
column9: troponin T hs: 5.5 ng/l. Rest without relevant findings. Chest X-ray: fracture of the right posterior eighth arch and probable fracture of the seventh and ninth arch associated with right effusion
column10: probable haemothorax given the rib fractures. Cardiomegaly
column11: alteration in the morphology of the superior mediastinum suggesting alteration in the arrangement of the aortic arch. Likewise
column12: given the cardiac morphology
column13: pericardial effusion should be ruled out if there is no history of congenital heart disease. No previous studies are available for comparison. Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus rhythm at 70 bpm. Normal PR. Wide QRS left axis. Complete right bundle branch block and evidence of right ventricular hypertrophy. Anterior left bundle branch hemiblock. Portable transthoracic echocardiogram: left ventricle of normal size
column14: thickness and function. Severely dilated right ventricle (64 mm basal diameter)
column15: hypertrophic
column16: with preserved function. Biauricular dilatation
column17: greater right atrial dilatation. There is a large ostium primum type atrial septal defect with bidirectional flow. Mitral valve with cleft and moderate mitral insufficiency (grade III). Dysplastic tricuspid valve with moderate severe tricuspid regurgitation (grade III). Estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure of 62+5 mmHg. Mild pulmonary insufficiency. Pulmonary acceleration time of 81 msec without mesosystolic notch. Trivalve aortic valve without stenosis or insufficiency. Mild circumferential pericardial effusion.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION It was proposed that the patient be admitted to hospital to complete the study (right heart catheterisation and cardiopulmonary exercise test) and to consider starting pulmonary vasodilator treatment
column18: but for personal reasons the patient refused
column19: preferring to opt for outpatient management. Unfortunately
column20: the patient never attends the outpatient appointments and the study is never completed.  DIAGNOSIS Incomplete atrioventricular canal of new diagnosis. Suspicion of pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with uncorrected congenital heart disease. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History No known drug allergies. Ex-smoker for 15 years. Obesity. Arterial hypertension under pharmacological treatment
column3: with recent modification of treatment. Recently diagnosed type 2 diabetes mellitus (< 10 months)
column4: on treatment with oral antidiabetics. No other medical or surgical history of interest. Family history: father died of lung cancer > 60 years
column5: mother with acute myocardial infarction (AMI) > 60 years. Brother died at 25 years of age of unknown cause. Home treatment: amlodipine 10 mg (0-1-0)
column6: olmesartan medoxomil 20 mg (1-0-0)
column7: metformin 1000 mg - empagliflozin 5 mg (1-0-1).  Current disease A 45-year-old male patient
column8: with no history of heart disease
column9: attended the emergency department in the early hours of the morning due to deterioration of his functional class with progressive dyspnoea on minimal exertion
column10: associated with episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea in the previous two days
column11: as well as oedematisation of the lower limbs. In addition
column12: he reported an episode of epigastralgia two weeks earlier for which he had been seen in the emergency department and was discharged home with a diagnosis of suspected biliary colic. No infectious symptoms in the previous days or other associated symptoms
column13: afebrile. After initial assessment in the emergency department
column14: the patient was found to be stable although tending towards hypertension
column15: oligosymptomatic and unable to tolerate decubitus
column16: and an electrocardiogram was performed showing sinus tachycardia and electrical alternation. A chest X-ray was requested
column17: showing a large cardiomegaly
column18: with no other relevant pathological findings. Given the suspicion of pericardial effusion
column19: portable echocardiocopy was performed (video 1)
column20: confirming the diagnosis of severe circumferential pericardial effusion (> 20 mm)
column21: with collapse of the right chambers. Given the initial haemodynamic stability of the patient
column22: it was decided to admit him to cardiology with close monitoring and serum therapy
column23: with a view to performing a fluoroscopy-guided pericardiocentesis first thing the following morning. However
column24: 2 hours later
column25: the patient was again notified due to clinical and haemodynamic deterioration
column26: with arterial hypotension and tachypnoea
column27: so we proceeded to perform emergent pericardiocentesis guided by echocardiography using a subxiphoid approach
column28: achieving drainage of 1
column29: 500 ml of haematic pericardial fluid
column30: collecting samples for aetiological diagnosis
column31: with immediate haemodynamic recovery of the patient. After ultrasound verification of the practical resolution of the effusion
column32: continuous drainage is left in the bag and the patient is continuously monitored.  Physical examination Good general condition
column33: conscious
column34: oriented in the three spheres
column35: normal colour and normal depth
column36: no jugular venous engorgement. Hypertension 150/90 mmHg
column37: normocardic
column38: eupneic on room air with no increase in work of breathing
column39: but not tolerating decubitus
column40: maintaining basal oxygen saturation of 98%
column41: afebrile. Cardiopulmonary auscultation: low-pitched rhythmic heart sounds
column42: no murmurs. Bladder murmur was preserved
column43: with no additional pathological sounds. Abdomen globular
column44: soft and depressible
column45: not painful on superficial or deep palpation. Lower extremities with oedema and fovea up to the knees.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS CBC: haemoglobin 11 g/dl
column46: MCV 81 fl
column47: MCH 27 pg
column48: leukocytes 13
column50: neutrophils 79%
column51: lymphocytes 11%
column52: platelets 428.000/μl
column53: glucose 221 mg/dl
column54: creatinine 1.56 mg/dl
column55: GFR CKD-EPI 53 ml/min/1.73 m2
column56: CRP 4.25 mg/dl
column57: procalcitonin 0.21 ng/ml
column58: ultrasensitive troponin I 3.1 pg/ml
column59: CK-MB 1.20 ng/ml
column60: NT-proBNP 231 pg/ml
column61: glycosylated haemoglobin 9%
column62: TSH 1.870 mIU/l. Electrocardiogram: sinus tachycardia at 100 bpm
column63: normal PR
column64: normal axis
column65: narrow QRS
column66: little R progression in precordials
column67: generalised negative T waves
column68: electrical alternans. Chest X-ray: significant cardiomegaly
column69: without alterations of the lung parenchyma. Portable echocardioscopy: left ventricle (LV) with moderate-severe concentric hypertrophy
column70: preserved LV function
column71: severe pericardial effusion > 20 mm circumferential
column72: with swinging heart. Collapsed right chambers. Transthoracic echocardiogram after pericardiocentesis: moderate concentric LV hypertrophy with septal predominance
column73: without LV outflow tract obstruction. LVEF 65%. Moderate pericardial effusion (15 mm) in posterior face in PEEL and 5 mm in anterior face
column74: no respiratory variation of mitral flow
column75: no echographic data of tamponade. No valvulopathies. Analysis of the fluid: haematic aspect
column76: cellularity not assessable due to the presence of clots
column77: glucose 187 mg/dl
column78: protein 5.3 g/dl
column80: Gram stain with no microorganisms observed
column81: negative bacteriological culture. Samples could not be sent for mycobacteria or cytology. Tumour markers
column82: autoimmunity
column83: serology: CA 125 451 U/ml
column84: rest negative. Autoimmunity negative
column85: non-specific elevation of complement C3 and C4. Serology hepatotropic viruses
column86: CMV
column87: Treponema pallidum and Coxiella burnetii negative. EBV IgG positive. Chest-abdomen-pelvis CT scan: no radiological signs suggestive of neoproliferative process. Severe pericardial effusion and mild left pleural effusion
column88: slightly heterogeneous nodule in the right thyroid lobe (16 mm maximum diameter with fine calcifications inside)
column89: left renal angiomyolipoma
column90: enlarged prostate with stigmata of chronic prostatitis. Echocardiogram at discharge: moderate concentric LV hypertrophy. LVEF 68%. Mild pericardial effusion
column91: mostly posterior
column93: minimal in the left ventricle (LV). Visceral pericardial thickening in the apex. No cavity involvement. No valvular heart disease.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION During his admission to the ward the patient presented very good clinical evolution
column94: with better control of blood pressure after pharmacological adjustment
column95: with sinus tachycardia as the only event recorded on telemetry
column96: asymptomatic from the cardiorespiratory point of view
column97: minimal pericardial friction on auscultation. A regulated transthoracic echocardiogram was performed
column99: preserved left ventricular function and moderate pericardial effusion (15 mm) in the posterior face in PEEL
column100: and 5 mm in the anterior face
column101: with no evidence of tamponade. After more than 30 hours without debit
column102: drainage was removed. Empirical treatment was started with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and colchicine
column103: and a referral was made to internal medicine for an overall assessment of the case in order to search for the underlying aetiology
column104: with the initial objective of ruling out paraneoplastic pathology. The characteristics of the pericardial fluid were very unspecific: haematic with abundant clots that did not allow cellularity
column105: proteins and glucose within normal limits and negative bacteriological culture
column106: although it was not possible to send a new valid sample for mycobacterial studies. With regard to the analytical study with determination of tumour markers and autoimmunity
column107: he only presented non-specific elevation of CA 125 and complement fractions C3 and C4. Serology for hepatotropic viruses
column110: Treponema pallidum and Coxiella burnetii was negative
column111: IgG positive for EBV. As part of the extension study
column112: a CT scan of the thorax-abdomen-pelvis was performed which ruled out a neoproliferative process
column113: highlighting a nodule in the right lower thyroid lobe and an enlarged prostate with stigmata of chronic prostatitis. Serial echocardiographic controls were performed
column114: presenting progressive reduction of the effusion
column115: leaving only a slight pericardial effusion of 10 mm on the posterior and lateral wall of the LV at discharge. Finally
column116: given the favourable clinical and effusion evolution
column117: and despite the absence of a definitive aetiological diagnosis
column118: it was decided to discharge the patient home and continue close outpatient follow-up and study. After 8 months of follow-up
column120: with better control of blood pressure and glycaemia
column122: reporting only an episode of self-limited stabbing pain 6 months after the index event
column123: with complete recovery of renal function
column125: as well as CA 125 and glycosylated haemoglobin. Radiological improvement with disappearance of cardiomegaly
column126: leaving minimal residual pericardial effusion of 3-4 mm on the free wall of the RV. The patient is currently undergoing an aetiological study by internal medicine.   DIAGNOSIS Severe pericardial effusion with progression to cardiac tamponade. Urgent pericardiocentesis (haematic pericardial fluid). Etiology unknown
column127: so far idiopathic.
